"published_parsed": [2018, 10, 24, 5, 11, 34, 2, 297, 0], "title": "Origin of fermion generations from extended noncommutative geometry", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Origin of fermion generations from extended noncommutative geometry"}, "summary": "We propose a way to understand the 3 fermion generations by the algebraic\nstructures of noncommutative geometry, which is a promising framework to unify\nthe standard model and general relativity. We make the tensor product extension\nand the quaternion extension on the framework. Each of the two extensions alone\nkeeps the action invariant, and we consider them as the almost trivial\nstructures of the geometry. We combine the two extensions, and show the\ncorresponding physical effects, i.e., the emergence of 3 fermion generations\nand the mass relationships among those generations. We define the coordinate\nfiber space of the bundle of the manifold as the space in which the classical\nnoncommutative geometry is expressed, then the tensor product extension\nexplicitly shows the contribution of structures in the non-coordinate base\nspace of the bundle to the action. The extended geometry distinguishes between the ordinary\nspacetime based on the frame bundle and an extra non-coordinate spacetime based\non the biframe bundle constructed by our extensions. The ordinary spacetime\nframe is globally flat and plays the role as the spacetime frame in which the\nfields of the standard model are defined. The non-coordinate frame is locally\nflat and is the gravity spacetime frame. The extended geometry distinguishes between the ordinary\nspacetime based on the frame bundle and an extra non-coordinate spacetime based\non the biframe bundle constructed by our extensions. The ordinary spacetime\nframe is globally flat and plays the role as the spacetime frame in which the\nfields of the standard model are defined. The group of all diffeomorphisms of the\nmanifold naturally acts on P(M). The moduli group of positive scalar curvature\nmetrics is defined to be the quotient abelian group of this action, i.e. the\ncoinvariant of the action. The moduli group measures the size of the moduli\nspace of positive scalar curvature metrics on M. In this paper, we use the\nhigher rho invariant and the finite part of the K-theory of the group\nC*-algebra of the fundamental group of M to give a lower bound of the rank of\nthe moduli group.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Given a closed smooth manifold M which carries a positive scalar curvature\nmetric, one can associate an abelian group P(M) to the space of positive scalar\ncurvature metrics on this manifold. The group of all diffeomorphisms of the\nmanifold naturally acts on P(M). The moduli group of positive scalar curvature\nmetrics is defined to be the quotient abelian group of this action, i.e. the\ncoinvariant of the action. The moduli group measures the size of the moduli\nspace of positive scalar curvature metrics on M. In this paper, we use the\nhigher rho invariant and the finite part of the K-theory of the group\nC*-algebra of the fundamental group of M to give a lower bound of the rank of\nthe moduli group."}, "authors": [{"name": "Zhizhang Xie"}, {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}, "author": "Guoliang Yu", "arxiv_comment": "23 pages, with a couple of remarks added", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1310.1136v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1310.1136v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.GR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.KT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L80, 19D55, 53C23, 20F65, 58B34", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.02086v4", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.02086v4", "updated": "2021-03-01T20:12:58Z", "updated_parsed": [2021, 3, 1, 20, 12, 58, 0, 60, 0], "published": "2018-11-05T23:30:26Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 11, 5, 23, 30, 26, 0, 309, 0], "title": "The Novikov conjecture, the group of volume preserving diffeomorphisms\n  and Hilbert-Hadamard spaces", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The Novikov conjecture, the group of volume preserving diffeomorphisms\n  and Hilbert-Hadamard spaces"}, "summary": "We prove that the Novikov conjecture holds for any discrete group admitting\nan isometric and metrically proper action on an admissible Hilbert-Hadamard\nspace. Admissible Hilbert-Hadamard spaces are a class of (possibly\ninfinite-dimensional) non-positively curved metric spaces that contain dense\nsequences of closed convex subsets isometric to Riemannian manifolds. Examples\nof admissible Hilbert-Hadamard spaces include Hilbert spaces, certain simply\nconnected and non-positively curved Riemannian-Hilbertian manifolds and\ninfinite\\-/dimensional symmetric spaces. Thus our main theorem can be\nconsidered as an infinite-dimensional analogue of Kasparov's theorem on the\nNovikov conjecture for groups acting properly and isometrically on complete,\nsimply connected and non-positively curved manifolds. As a consequence, we show\nthat the Novikov conjecture holds for geometrically discrete subgroups of the\ngroup of volume preserving diffeomorphisms of a closed smooth manifold. This\nresult is inspired by Connes' theorem that the Novikov conjecture holds for\nhigher signatures associated to the Gelfand-Fuchs classes of groups of\ndiffeormorphisms.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We prove that the Novikov conjecture holds for any discrete group admitting\nan isometric and metrically proper action on an admissible Hilbert-Hadamard\nspace. Admissible Hilbert-Hadamard spaces are a class of (possibly\ninfinite-dimensional) non-positively curved metric spaces that contain dense\nsequences of closed convex subsets isometric to Riemannian manifolds. Examples\nof admissible Hilbert-Hadamard spaces include Hilbert spaces, certain simply\nconnected and non-positively curved Riemannian-Hilbertian manifolds and\ninfinite\\-/dimensional symmetric spaces. Thus our main theorem can be\nconsidered as an infinite-dimensional analogue of Kasparov's theorem on the\nNovikov conjecture for groups acting properly and isometrically on complete,\nsimply connected and non-positively curved manifolds. As a consequence, we show\nthat the Novikov conjecture holds for geometrically discrete subgroups of the\ngroup of volume preserving diffeomorphisms of a closed smooth manifold. This\nresult is inspired by Connes' theorem that the Novikov conjecture holds for\nhigher signatures associated to the Gelfand-Fuchs classes of groups of\ndiffeormorphisms."}, "authors": [{"name": "Sherry Gong"}, {"name": "Jianchao Wu"}, {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}, "author": "Guoliang Yu", "arxiv_comment": "55 pages; contains minor corrections and modifications from the last\n  version; to be published in GAFA", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.02086v4", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1811.02086v4", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.KT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.KT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L80", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1311.6197v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1311.6197v3", "updated": "2014-04-25T15:12:02Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 4, 25, 15, 12, 2, 4, 115, 0], "published": "2013-11-25T02:14:43Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 11, 25, 2, 14, 43, 0, 329, 0], "title": "Geometric Property (T)", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Geometric Property (T)"}, "summary": "This paper discusses `geometric property (T)'. This is a property of metric\nspaces introduced in earlier work of the authors for its applications to\nK-theory. Geometric property (T) is a strong form of `expansion property': in\nparticular for a sequence of finite graphs $(X_n)$, it is strictly stronger\nthan $(X_n)$ being an expander in the sense that the Cheeger constants $h(X_n)$\nare bounded below.\n  We show here that geometric property (T) is a coarse invariant, i.e. depends\nonly on the large-scale geometry of a metric space $X$. We also discuss the\nrelationships between geometric property (T) and amenability, property (T), and\nvarious coarse geometric notions of a-T-menability. In particular, we show that\nproperty (T) for a residually finite group is characterised by geometric\nproperty (T) for its finite quotients.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper discusses `geometric property (T)'. This is a property of metric\nspaces introduced in earlier work of the authors for its applications to\nK-theory. Geometric property (T) is a strong form of `expansion property': in\nparticular for a sequence of finite graphs $(X_n)$, it is strictly stronger\nthan $(X_n)$ being an expander in the sense that the Cheeger constants $h(X_n)$\nare bounded below.\n  We show here that geometric property (T) is a coarse invariant, i.e. depends\nonly on the large-scale geometry of a metric space $X$. We also discuss the\nrelationships between geometric property (T) and amenability, property (T), and\nvarious coarse geometric notions of a-T-menability. More\nprecisely, if a discrete group $\\Gamma$ acts on a bounded geometric space $X$\nproperly, isometrically, and with bounded distortion, $X/\\Gamma$ and $\\Gamma$\nadmit coarse embeddings into Hilbert space, then the $\\Gamma$-equivariant\ncoarse Novikov conjecture holds for $X$. "published": "2018-06-02T17:03:04Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 6, 2, 17, 3, 4, 5, 153, 0], "title": "A Stochastic Geometry Analysis of Energy Harvesting in Large Scale\n  Wireless Networks", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A Stochastic Geometry Analysis of Energy Harvesting in Large Scale\n  Wireless Networks"}, "summary": "In this paper, the theoretical sustainable capacity of wireless networks with\nradio frequency (RF) energy harvesting is analytically studied. Specifically,\nwe consider a large scale wireless network where base stations (BSs) and low\npower wireless devices are deployed by homogeneous Poisson point process (PPP)\nwith different spatial densities. Wireless devices exploit the downlink\ntransmissions from the BSs for either information delivery or energy\nharvesting. Generally, a BS schedules downlink transmission to wireless\ndevices. The scheduled device receives the data information while other devices\nharvest energy from the downlink signals. The data information can be\nsuccessfully received by the scheduled device only if the device has sufficient\nenergy for data processing, i.e., the harvested energy is larger than a\nthreshold. Given the densities of BSs and users, we apply stochastic geometry\nto analyze the expected number of users per cell and the successful information\ndelivery probability of a wireless device, based on which the total network\nthroughput can be derived. It is shown that the maximum network throughput per\ncell can be achieved under the optimal density of BSs. Extensive simulations\nvalidate the analysis.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, the theoretical sustainable capacity of wireless networks with\nradio frequency (RF) energy harvesting is analytically studied. Specifically,\nwe consider a large scale wireless network where base stations (BSs) and low\npower wireless devices are deployed by homogeneous Poisson point process (PPP)\nwith different spatial densities. Wireless devices exploit the downlink\ntransmissions from the BSs for either information delivery or energy\nharvesting. Generally, a BS schedules downlink transmission to wireless\ndevices. The scheduled device receives the data information while other devices\nharvest energy from the downlink signals. The data information can be\nsuccessfully received by the scheduled device only if the device has sufficient\nenergy for data processing, i.e., the harvested energy is larger than a\nthreshold. Given the densities of BSs and users, we apply stochastic geometry\nto analyze the expected number of users per cell and the successful information\ndelivery probability of a wireless device, based on which the total network\nthroughput can be derived. It is shown that the maximum network throughput per\ncell can be achieved under the optimal density of BSs. 10, 24, 5, 11, 34, 2, 297, 0], "title": "Origin of fermion generations from extended noncommutative geometry", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Origin of fermion generations from extended noncommutative geometry"}, "summary": "We propose a way to understand the 3 fermion generations by the algebraic\nstructures of noncommutative geometry, which is a promising framework to unify\nthe standard model and general relativity. We make the tensor product extension\nand the quaternion extension on the framework. Each of the two extensions alone\nkeeps the action invariant, and we consider them as the almost trivial\nstructures of the geometry. We combine the two extensions, and show the\ncorresponding physical effects, i.e., the emergence of 3 fermion generations\nand the mass relationships among those generations. We define the coordinate\nfiber space of the bundle of the manifold as the space in which the classical\nnoncommutative geometry is expressed, then the tensor product extension\nexplicitly shows the contribution of structures in the non-coordinate base\nspace of the bundle to the action. The quaternion extension plays an essential\nrole to reveal the physical effect of the structure in the non-coordinate base\nspace.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We propose a way to understand the 3 fermion generations by the algebraic\nstructures of noncommutative geometry, which is a promising framework to unify\nthe standard model and general relativity. We make the tensor product extension\nand the quaternion extension on the framework. Each of the two extensions alone\nkeeps the action invariant, and we consider them as the almost trivial\nstructures of the geometry. We combine the two extensions, and show the\ncorresponding physical effects, i.e., the emergence of 3 fermion generations\nand the mass relationships among those generations. We define the coordinate\nfiber space of the bundle of the manifold as the space in which the classical\nnoncommutative geometry is expressed, then the tensor product extension\nexplicitly shows the contribution of structures in the non-coordinate base\nspace of the bundle to the action. The quaternion extension plays an essential\nrole to reveal the physical effect of the structure in the non-coordinate base\nspace."}, "authors": [{"name": "Hefu Yu"}, {"name": "Bo-Qiang Ma"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Bo-Qiang Ma"}, "author": "Bo-Qiang Ma", "arxiv_doi": "10.1142/S0217751X18501683", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1142/S0217751X18501683", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1810.10189v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.10189v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "17 latex pages, no figure. In this\nway, in the lowest Landau level, a highly nontrivial quantum geometry in\ntwo-dimensional guiding center space emerges from these internal geometric\nmodes. Using the Dirac bracket method, we find that this quantum geometric\nfield theory is a topological non-commutative Chern-Simons theory.Topological\nindices, such as the guiding center angular momentum (also called the shift)\nand the guiding center spin, which characterize the fractional quantum Hall\n(FQH) states besides the filling factor, are naturally defined. A\nnoncommutative K-matrix Chern-Simons theory is proposed as a generalization to\na large class of Abelian FQH topological orders.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We relate the collective dynamic internal geometric degrees of freedom to the\ngauge fluctuations in $\\nu=1/m$(m odd) fractional quantum Hall effects. In this\nway, in the lowest Landau level, a highly nontrivial quantum geometry in\ntwo-dimensional guiding center space emerges from these internal geometric\nmodes. Using the Dirac bracket method, we find that this quantum geometric\nfield theory is a topological non-commutative Chern-Simons theory.Topological\nindices, such as the guiding center angular momentum (also called the shift)\nand the guiding center spin, which characterize the fractional quantum Hall\n(FQH) states besides the filling factor, are naturally defined. A\nnoncommutative K-matrix Chern-Simons theory is proposed as a generalization to\na large class of Abelian FQH topological orders."}, "authors": [{"name": "Xi Luo"}, {"name": "Yong-Shi Wu"}, {"name": "Yue Yu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Yue Yu"}, "author": "Yue Yu", "arxiv_doi": "10.1103/PhysRevD.93.125005", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevD.93.125005", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1308.2481v5", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1308.2481v5", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "11 pages, no figure,published version", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Phys. The extended geometry distinguishes between the ordinary\nspacetime based on the frame bundle and an extra non-coordinate spacetime based\non the biframe bundle constructed by our extensions. The ordinary spacetime\nframe is globally flat and plays the role as the spacetime frame in which the\nfields of the standard model are defined. The non-coordinate frame is locally\nflat and is the gravity spacetime frame. The field defined in both frames of\nsuch \"flat\" biframe spacetime can be quantized and plays the role as the\ngravity field which couples with all the fields to connect the gravity effect\nwith the standard model. Thus we provide a geometric paradigm in which gravity\nand the quantum field theory can be unified.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We make biframe and quaternion extensions on the noncommutative geometry, and\nconstruct the biframe spacetime for the unification of gravity and quantum\nfield theory. The extended geometry distinguishes between the ordinary\nspacetime based on the frame bundle and an extra non-coordinate spacetime based\non the biframe bundle constructed by our extensions. The ordinary spacetime\nframe is globally flat and plays the role as the spacetime frame in which the\nfields of the standard model are defined. Using this\napproach, we give new proofs of the strong Novikov conjecture in several\ninteresting cases, including crystallographic groups and surface groups. We prove that if a sequence of graphs is an\nexpander and the girth of the graphs tends to infinity, then the coarse\nBaum-Connes assembly map is injective, but not surjective, for the associated\nmetric space $X$.\n  Expanders with this girth property are a necessary ingredient in the\nconstruction of the so-called `Gromov monster' groups that (coarsely) contain\nexpanders in their Cayley graphs. We use this connection to show that the\nBaum-Connes assembly map with certain coefficients is injective but not\nsurjective for these groups. Using the results of the second paper in this\nseries, we also show that the maximal Baum-Cones assembly map with these\ncoefficients is an isomorphism.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, the first of a series of two, we continue the study of higher\nindex theory for expanders. We prove that if a sequence of graphs is an\nexpander and the girth of the graphs tends to infinity, then the coarse\nBaum-Connes assembly map is injective, but not surjective, for the associated\nmetric space $X$.\n  Expanders with this girth property are a necessary ingredient in the\nconstruction of the so-called `Gromov monster' groups that (coarsely) contain\nexpanders in their Cayley graphs. We use this connection to show that the\nBaum-Connes assembly map with certain coefficients is injective but not\nsurjective for these groups. Using the results of the second paper in this\nseries, we also show that the maximal Baum-Cones assembly map with these\ncoefficients is an isomorphism."}, "authors": [{"name": "Rufus Willett"}, {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}, "author": "Guoliang Yu", "arxiv_comment": "38 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.4150v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1012.4150v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.KT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.KT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.GR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.GT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.4151v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.4151v1", "updated": "2010-12-19T07:05:29Z", "updated_parsed": [2010, 12, 19, 7, 5, 29, 6, 353, 0], "published": "2010-12-19T07:05:29Z", "published_parsed": [2010, 12, 19, 7, 5, 29, 6, 353, 0], "title": "Higher index theory for certain expanders and Gromov monster groups II", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Higher index theory for certain expanders and Gromov monster groups II"}, "summary": "In this paper, the second of a series of two, we continue the study of higher\nindex theory for expanders. We prove that if a sequence of graphs has girth\ntending to infinity, then the maximal coarse Baum-Connes assembly map is an\nisomorphism for the associated metric space $X$. As discussed in the first\npaper in this series, this has applications to the Baum-Connes conjecture for\n`Gromov monster' groups.\n  We also introduce a new property, `geometric property (T)'. For the metric\nspace associated to a sequence of graphs, this property is an obstruction to\nthe maximal coarse assembly map being an isomorphism. This enables us to\ndistinguish between expanders with girth tending to infinity, and, for example,\nthose constructed from property (T) groups.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, the second of a series of two, we continue the study of higher\nindex theory for expanders. We prove that if a sequence of graphs has girth\ntending to infinity, then the maximal coarse Baum-Connes assembly map is an\nisomorphism for the associated metric space $X$. As discussed in the first\npaper in this series, this has applications to the Baum-Connes conjecture for\n`Gromov monster' groups.\n  We also introduce a new property, `geometric property (T)'. For the metric\nspace associated to a sequence of graphs, this property is an obstruction to\nthe maximal coarse assembly map being an isomorphism. This enables us to\ndistinguish between expanders with girth tending to infinity, and, for example,\nthose constructed from property (T) groups."}, "authors": [{"name": "Rufus Willett"}, {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}, "author": "Guoliang Yu", "arxiv_comment": "39 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.4151v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1012.4151v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.KT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.KT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.GR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.GT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1608.03661v5", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1608.03661v5", "updated": "2020-02-24T16:54:58Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 2, 24, 16, 54, 58, 0, 55, 0], "published": "2016-08-12T02:32:26Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 8, 12, 2, 32, 26, 4, 225, 0], "title": "Additivity of higher rho invariants and nonrigidity of topological\n  manifolds", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Additivity of higher rho invariants and nonrigidity of topological\n  manifolds"}, "summary": "Let $X$ be a closed oriented connected topological manifold of dimension\n$n\\geq 5$. The structure group of $X$ is the abelian group of equivalence\nclasses of all pairs $(f, M)$ such that $M$ is a closed oriented manifold and\n$f\\colon M \\to X$ is an orientation-preserving homotopy equivalence. The main\npurpose of this article is to prove that a higher rho invariant defines a group\nhomomorphism from the topological structure group of $X$ to the $C^*$-algebraic\nstructure group of $X$. In fact, we introduce a higher rho invariant map on the\nhomology manifold structure group of a closed oriented connected\n$\\textit{topological}$ manifold, and prove its additivity. This higher rho\ninvariant map restricts to the higher rho invariant map on the topological\nstructure group. More generally, the same techniques developed in this paper\ncan be applied to define a higher rho invariant map on the homology manifold\nstructure group of a closed oriented connected $\\textit{homology}$ manifold. As\nan application, we use the additivity of the higher rho invariant map to study\nnon-rigidity of topological manifolds. More precisely, we give a lower bound\nfor the free rank of the $\\textit{algebraically reduced}$ structure group of\n$X$ by the number of torsion elements in $\\pi_1 X$. Here the algebraic reduced\nstructure group of $X$ is the quotient of the topological structure group of\n$X$ modulo a certain action of self-homotopy equivalences of $X$. We also\nintroduce a notion of homological higher rho invariant, which can be used to\ndetect many elements in the structure group of a closed oriented topological\nmanifold, even when the fundamental group of the manifold is torsion free. In\nparticular, we apply this homological higher rho invariant to show that the\nstructure group is not finitely generated for a class of manifolds.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $X$ be a closed oriented connected topological manifold of dimension\n$n\\geq 5$. The structure group of $X$ is the abelian group of equivalence\nclasses of all pairs $(f, M)$ such that $M$ is a closed oriented manifold and\n$f\\colon M \\to X$ is an orientation-preserving homotopy equivalence. The main\npurpose of this article is to prove that a higher rho invariant defines a group\nhomomorphism from the topological structure group of $X$ to the $C^*$-algebraic\nstructure group of $X$. In fact, we introduce a higher rho invariant map on the\nhomology manifold structure group of a closed oriented connected\n$\\textit{topological}$ manifold, and prove its additivity. This higher rho\ninvariant map restricts to the higher rho invariant map on the topological\nstructure group. More generally, the same techniques developed in this paper\ncan be applied to define a higher rho invariant map on the homology manifold\nstructure group of a closed oriented connected $\\textit{homology}$ manifold. As\nan application, we use the additivity of the higher rho invariant map to study\nnon-rigidity of topological manifolds. More precisely, we give a lower bound\nfor the free rank of the $\\textit{algebraically reduced}$ structure group of\n$X$ by the number of torsion elements in $\\pi_1 X$. Here the algebraic reduced\nstructure group of $X$ is the quotient of the topological structure group of\n$X$ modulo a certain action of self-homotopy equivalences of $X$. We also\nintroduce a notion of homological higher rho invariant, which can be used to\ndetect many elements in the structure group of a closed oriented topological\nmanifold, even when the fundamental group of the manifold is torsion free. In\nparticular, we apply this homological higher rho invariant to show that the\nstructure group is not finitely generated for a class of manifolds."}, "authors": [{"name": "Shmuel Weinberger"}, {"name": "Zhizhang Xie"}, {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}, "author": "Guoliang Yu", "arxiv_comment": "Minor changes. We show that if the sequence $\\left( N_n \\right)_{n\\in\n\\mathbb{N}} $ with the induced metric from the word metrics of $\\left( G_n\n\\right)_{n\\in \\mathbb{N}} $ has property A, and the sequence $\\left( Q_n\n\\right)_{n\\in \\mathbb{N}} $ with the quotient metrics coarsely embeds into\nHilbert space, then the coarse Baum-Connes conjecture holds for the sequence\n$\\left( G_n \\right)_{n\\in \\mathbb{N}}$, which may not admit a coarse embedding\ninto Hilbert space. It follows that the coarse Baum-Connes conjecture holds for\nthe relative expanders and group extensions exhibited by G. Arzhantseva and R.\nTessera, and special box spaces of free groups discovered by T. Delabie and A.\nKhukhro, which do not coarsely embed into Hilbert space, yet do not contain a\nweakly embedded expander. This in particular solves an open problem raised by\nG. Arzhantseva and R. Tessera \\cite{Arzhantseva-Tessera 2015}.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $\\left( 1\\to N_n\\to G_n\\to Q_n\\to 1 \\right)_{n\\in \\mathbb{N}}$ be a\nsequence of extensions of finitely generated groups with uniformly finite\ngenerating subsets. We show that if the sequence $\\left( N_n \\right)_{n\\in\n\\mathbb{N}} $ with the induced metric from the word metrics of $\\left( G_n\n\\right)_{n\\in \\mathbb{N}} $ has property A, and the sequence $\\left( Q_n\n\\right)_{n\\in \\mathbb{N}} $ with the quotient metrics coarsely embeds into\nHilbert space, then the coarse Baum-Connes conjecture holds for the sequence\n$\\left( G_n \\right)_{n\\in \\mathbb{N}}$, which may not admit a coarse embedding\ninto Hilbert space. It follows that the coarse Baum-Connes conjecture holds for\nthe relative expanders and group extensions exhibited by G. Arzhantseva and R.\nTessera, and special box spaces of free groups discovered by T. Delabie and A.\nKhukhro, which do not coarsely embed into Hilbert space, yet do not contain a\nweakly embedded expander. This in particular solves an open problem raised by\nG. Arzhantseva and R. Tessera \\cite{Arzhantseva-Tessera 2015}."}, "authors": [{"name": "Jintao Deng"}, {"name": "Qin Wang"}, {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}, "author": "Guoliang Yu", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2102.10617v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2102.10617v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.KT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.KT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1208.4543v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1208.4543v1", "updated": "2012-08-22T15:59:59Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 8, 22, 15, 59, 59, 2, 235, 0], "published": "2012-08-22T15:59:59Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 8, 22, 15, 59, 59, 2, 235, 0], "title": "The maximal coarse Baum-Connes conjecture for spaces which admit a\n  fibred coarse embedding into Hilbert space", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The maximal coarse Baum-Connes conjecture for spaces which admit a\n  fibred coarse embedding into Hilbert space"}, "summary": "We introduce a notion of fibred coarse embedding into Hilbert space for\nmetric spaces, which is a generalization of Gromov's notion of coarse embedding\ninto Hilbert space. It turns out that a large class of expander graphs admit\nsuch an embedding. It turns out that a large class of expander graphs admit\nsuch an embedding. A metric space X is said to\nhave operator norm localization property if there exists a positive number c\nsuch that for every r>0, there is R>0 for which, if m is a positive locally\nfinite Borel measure on X, H is a separable infinite dimensional Hilbert space\nand T is a bounded linear operator acting on L^2(X,m) with propagation r, then\nthere exists an unit vector v satisfying with support of diameter at most R and\nsuch that |Tv| is larger or equal than c|T|. If X has finite asymptotic\ndimension, then X has operator norm localization property. In this paper, we\nintroduce a sufficient geometric condition for the operator norm localization\nproperty. This is used to give many examples of finitely generated groups with\ninfinite asymptotic dimension and the operator norm localization property. 10, 24, 5, 11, 34, 2, 297, 0], "title": "Origin of fermion generations from extended noncommutative geometry", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Origin of fermion generations from extended noncommutative geometry"}, "summary": "We propose a way to understand the 3 fermion generations by the algebraic\nstructures of noncommutative geometry, which is a promising framework to unify\nthe standard model and general relativity. We make the tensor product extension\nand the quaternion extension on the framework. Each of the two extensions alone\nkeeps the action invariant, and we consider them as the almost trivial\nstructures of the geometry. We combine the two extensions, and show the\ncorresponding physical effects, i.e., the emergence of 3 fermion generations\nand the mass relationships among those generations. We define the coordinate\nfiber space of the bundle of the manifold as the space in which the classical\nnoncommutative geometry is expressed, then the tensor product extension\nexplicitly shows the contribution of structures in the non-coordinate base\nspace of the bundle to the action. The quaternion extension plays an essential\nrole to reveal the physical effect of the structure in the non-coordinate base\nspace.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We propose a way to understand the 3 fermion generations by the algebraic\nstructures of noncommutative geometry, which is a promising framework to unify\nthe standard model and general relativity. The extended geometry distinguishes between the ordinary\nspacetime based on the frame bundle and an extra non-coordinate spacetime based\non the biframe bundle constructed by our extensions. The ordinary spacetime\nframe is globally flat and plays the role as the spacetime frame in which the\nfields of the standard model are defined. We prove for instance that\nif the fundamental group of a compact aspherical manifold M has FDC, and if N\nis homotopy equivalent to M, then M x R^n is homeomorphic to N x R^n, for n\nlarge enough. This statement is known as the stable Borel conjecture. We prove that if a sequence of graphs is an\nexpander and the girth of the graphs tends to infinity, then the coarse\nBaum-Connes assembly map is injective, but not surjective, for the associated\nmetric space $X$.\n  Expanders with this girth property are a necessary ingredient in the\nconstruction of the so-called `Gromov monster' groups that (coarsely) contain\nexpanders in their Cayley graphs. We use this connection to show that the\nBaum-Connes assembly map with certain coefficients is injective but not\nsurjective for these groups. Using the results of the second paper in this\nseries, we also show that the maximal Baum-Cones assembly map with these\ncoefficients is an isomorphism.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, the first of a series of two, we continue the study of higher\nindex theory for expanders. We prove that if a sequence of graphs is an\nexpander and the girth of the graphs tends to infinity, then the coarse\nBaum-Connes assembly map is injective, but not surjective, for the associated\nmetric space $X$.\n  Expanders with this girth property are a necessary ingredient in the\nconstruction of the so-called `Gromov monster' groups that (coarsely) contain\nexpanders in their Cayley graphs. We use this connection to show that the\nBaum-Connes assembly map with certain coefficients is injective but not\nsurjective for these groups. Using the results of the second paper in this\nseries, we also show that the maximal Baum-Cones assembly map with these\ncoefficients is an isomorphism."}, "authors": [{"name": "Rufus Willett"}, {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Guoliang Yu"}, "author": "Guoliang Yu", "arxiv_comment": "38 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.4150v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1012.4150v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.KT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.KT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.GR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.GT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.4151v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.4151v1", "updated": "2010-12-19T07:05:29Z", "updated_parsed": [2010, 12, 19, 7, 5, 29, 6, 353, 0], "published": "2010-12-19T07:05:29Z", "published_parsed": [2010, 12, 19, 7, 5, 29, 6, 353, 0], "title": "Higher index theory for certain expanders and Gromov monster groups II", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Higher index theory for certain expanders and Gromov monster groups II"}, "summary": "In this paper, the second of a series of two, we continue the study of higher\nindex theory for expanders. We prove that if a sequence of graphs has girth\ntending to infinity, then the maximal coarse Baum-Connes assembly map is an\nisomorphism for the associated metric space $X$. As discussed in the first\npaper in this series, this has applications to the Baum-Connes conjecture for\n`Gromov monster' groups.\n  We also introduce a new property, `geometric property (T)'. For the metric\nspace associated to a sequence of graphs, this property is an obstruction to\nthe maximal coarse assembly map being an isomorphism. This enables us to\ndistinguish between expanders with girth tending to infinity, and, for example,\nthose constructed from property (T) groups.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, the second of a series of two, we continue the study of higher\nindex theory for expanders. We prove that if a sequence of graphs has girth\ntending to infinity, then the maximal coarse Baum-Connes assembly map is an\nisomorphism for the associated metric space $X$. As discussed in the first\npaper in this series, this has applications to the Baum-Connes conjecture for\n`Gromov monster' groups.\n  We also introduce a new property, `geometric property (T)'. We apply this index theorem to\nstudy the Arveson-Douglas conjecture. Let $\\ball^m$ be the unit ball in\n$\\mathbb{C}^m$, and $I$ an ideal in the polynomial algebra $\\mathbb{C}[z_1,\n\\cdots, z_m]$. We prove that if a sequence of graphs is an\nexpander and the girth of the graphs tends to infinity, then the coarse\nBaum-Connes assembly map is injective, but not surjective, for the associated\nmetric space $X$.\n  Expanders with this girth property are a necessary ingredient in the\nconstruction of the so-called `Gromov monster' groups that (coarsely) contain\nexpanders in their Cayley graphs. We use this connection to show that the\nBaum-Connes assembly map with certain coefficients is injective but not\nsurjective for these groups. Using the results of the second paper in this\nseries, we also show that the maximal Baum-Cones assembly map with these\ncoefficients is an isomorphism.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, the first of a series of two, we continue the study of higher\nindex theory for expanders. We prove that if a sequence of graphs is an\nexpander and the girth of the graphs tends to infinity, then the coarse\nBaum-Connes assembly map is injective, but not surjective, for the associated\nmetric space $X$.\n  Expanders with this girth property are a necessary ingredient in the\nconstruction of the so-called `Gromov monster' groups that (coarsely) contain\nexpanders in their Cayley graphs. We use this connection to show that the\nBaum-Connes assembly map with certain coefficients is injective but not\nsurjective for these groups. We apply this theorem to study\nRiemannian metrics of positive scalar curvature on manifolds. For every two\nmetrics of positive scalar curvature on a closed manifold and a Galois cover of\nthe manifold, we define a secondary higher index class. Non-vanishing of this\nhigher index class is an obstruction for the two metrics to be in the same\nconnected component of the space of metrics of positive scalar curvature. In\nthe special case where one metric is induced from the other by a diffeomorphism\nof the manifold, we obtain a formula for computing this higher index class. We apply this theorem to study\nRiemannian metrics of positive scalar curvature on manifolds. For every two\nmetrics of positive scalar curvature on a closed manifold and a Galois cover of\nthe manifold, we define a secondary higher index class. Non-vanishing of this\nhigher index class is an obstruction for the two metrics to be in the same\nconnected component of the space of metrics of positive scalar curvature. In\nthe special case where one metric is induced from the other by a diffeomorphism\nof the manifold, we obtain a formula for computing this higher index class. representations:\nthis is partly inspired by ideas of Lusztig using the Atiyah-Singer families\nindex theorem, and partly by Carlsson's deformation $K$--theory. In this article, we prove the equivariant\ncoarse Novikov conjecture under certain coarse embeddability conditions. More\nprecisely, if a discrete group $\\Gamma$ acts on a bounded geometric space $X$\nproperly, isometrically, and with bounded distortion, $X/\\Gamma$ and $\\Gamma$\nadmit coarse embeddings into Hilbert space, then the $\\Gamma$-equivariant\ncoarse Novikov conjecture holds for $X$. Admissible Hilbert-Hadamard spaces are a class of (possibly\ninfinite-dimensional) non-positively curved metric spaces that contain dense\nsequences of closed convex subsets isometric to Riemannian manifolds. Examples\nof admissible Hilbert-Hadamard spaces include Hilbert spaces, certain simply\nconnected and non-positively curved Riemannian-Hilbertian manifolds and\ninfinite\\-/dimensional symmetric spaces. 19, 45, 44, 1, 237, 0], "title": "Convergence and optimality of higher-order adaptive finite element\n  methods for eigenvalue clusters", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Convergence and optimality of higher-order adaptive finite element\n  methods for eigenvalue clusters"}, "summary": "Proofs of convergence of adaptive finite element methods for the\napproximation of eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of linear elliptic problems\nhave been given in a several recent papers. A key step in establishing such\nresults for multiple and clustered eigenvalues was provided by Dai et. al.\n(2014), who proved convergence and optimality of AFEM for eigenvalues of\nmultiplicity greater than one. There it was shown that a theoretical\n(non-computable) error estimator for which standard convergence proofs apply is\nequivalent to a standard computable estimator on sufficiently fine grids.\nGallistl (2015) used a similar tool in order to prove that a standard adaptive\nFEM for controlling eigenvalue clusters for the Laplacian using continuous\npiecewise linear finite element spaces converges with optimal rate. When\nconsidering either higher-order finite element spaces or non-constant diffusion\ncoefficients, however, the arguments of Dai et. al. and Gallistl do not yield\nequivalence of the practical and theoretical estimators for clustered\neigenvalues. In this note we provide this missing key step, thus showing that\nstandard adaptive FEM for clustered eigenvalues employing elements of arbitrary\npolynomial degree converge with optimal rate. We additionally establish that a\nkey user-defined input parameter in the AFEM, the bulk marking parameter, may\nbe chosen entirely independently of the properties of the target eigenvalue\ncluster. All of these results assume a fineness condition on the initial mesh\nin order to ensure that the nonlinearity is sufficiently resolved.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Proofs of convergence of adaptive finite element methods for the\napproximation of eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of linear elliptic problems\nhave been given in a several recent papers. A key step in establishing such\nresults for multiple and clustered eigenvalues was provided by Dai et. al.\n(2014), who proved convergence and optimality of AFEM for eigenvalues of\nmultiplicity greater than one. There it was shown that a theoretical\n(non-computable) error estimator for which standard convergence proofs apply is\nequivalent to a standard computable estimator on sufficiently fine grids.\nGallistl (2015) used a similar tool in order to prove that a standard adaptive\nFEM for controlling eigenvalue clusters for the Laplacian using continuous\npiecewise linear finite element spaces converges with optimal rate. When\nconsidering either higher-order finite element spaces or non-constant diffusion\ncoefficients, however, the arguments of Dai et. al. and Gallistl do not yield\nequivalence of the practical and theoretical estimators for clustered\neigenvalues. In this note we provide this missing key step, thus showing that\nstandard adaptive FEM for clustered eigenvalues employing elements of arbitrary\npolynomial degree converge with optimal rate. We additionally establish that a\nkey user-defined input parameter in the AFEM, the bulk marking parameter, may\nbe chosen entirely independently of the properties of the target eigenvalue\ncluster. All of these results assume a fineness condition on the initial mesh\nin order to ensure that the nonlinearity is sufficiently resolved."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Alan Demlow"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Alan Demlow"}, "author": "Alan Demlow", "arxiv_comment": "10 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.06265v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1508.06265v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65N12, 65N15, 65N25, 65N30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.01566v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.01566v1", "updated": "2017-07-05T20:10:21Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 7, 5, 20, 10, 21, 2, 186, 0], "published": "2017-07-05T20:10:21Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 7, 5, 20, 10, 21, 2, 186, 0], "title": "Numerical Methods for Fractional Diffusion", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Numerical Methods for Fractional Diffusion"}, "summary": "We present three schemes for the numerical approximation of fractional\ndiffusion, which build on different definitions of such a non-local process.\nThe first method is a PDE approach that applies to the spectral definition and\nexploits the extension to one higher dimension. The second method is the\nintegral formulation and deals with singular non-integrable kernels. The third\nmethod is a discretization of the Dunford-Taylor formula. The second method is the\nintegral formulation and deals with singular non-integrable kernels. The third\nmethod is a discretization of the Dunford-Taylor formula. The time dependent solution $u(x,t)$ is represented as a\nDunford Taylor integral along a contour in the complex plane.\n  The contour integrals are approximated using sinc quadratures. In the case of\nhomogeneous right-hand-sides and initial value $v$, the approximation results\nin a linear combination of functions $(z_qI-L)^{-1}v\\in H^1_0(\\Omega)$ for a\nfinite number of quadrature points $z_q$ lying along the contour. In turn,\nthese quantities are approximated using complex valued continuous piecewise\nlinear finite elements.\n  Our main result provides $L^2(\\Omega)$ error estimates between the solution\n$u(\\cdot,t)$ and its final approximation. Numerical results illustrating the\nbehavior of the algorithms are provided.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study the numerical approximation of a time dependent equation involving\nfractional powers of an elliptic operator $L$ defined to be the unbounded\noperator associated with a Hermitian, coercive and bounded sesquilinear form on\n$H^1_0(\\Omega)$. The time dependent solution $u(x,t)$ is represented as a\nDunford Taylor integral along a contour in the complex plane.\n  The contour integrals are approximated using sinc quadratures. In the case of\nhomogeneous right-hand-sides and initial value $v$, the approximation results\nin a linear combination of functions $(z_qI-L)^{-1}v\\in H^1_0(\\Omega)$ for a\nfinite number of quadrature points $z_q$ lying along the contour. In turn,\nthese quantities are approximated using complex valued continuous piecewise\nlinear finite elements.\n  Our main result provides $L^2(\\Omega)$ error estimates between the solution\n$u(\\cdot,t)$ and its final approximation. Numerical results illustrating the\nbehavior of the algorithms are provided."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Wenyu Lei"}, {"name": "Joseph E. Pasciak", "arxiv_comment": "20 pages, 4 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1607.07832v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1607.07832v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1802.01625v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1802.01625v2", "updated": "2019-02-14T20:32:23Z", "updated_parsed": [2019, 2, 14, 20, 32, 23, 3, 45, 0], "published": "2018-02-05T19:58:22Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 2, 5, 19, 58, 22, 0, 36, 0], "title": "A posteriori error estimates for the Laplace-Beltrami operator on\n  parametric $C^2$ surfaces", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A posteriori error estimates for the Laplace-Beltrami operator on\n  parametric $C^2$ surfaces"}, "summary": "We prove new a posteriori error estimates for surface finite element methods\n(SFEM). Surface FEM approximate solutions to PDE posed on surfaces.\nPrototypical examples are elliptic PDE involving the Laplace-Beltrami operator.\nTypically the surface is approximated by a polyhedral or higher-order\npolynomial approximation. The resulting FEM exhibits both a geometric\nconsistency error due to the surface approximation and a standard Galerkin\nerror. A posteriori estimates for SFEM require practical access to geometric\ninformation about the surface in order to computably bound the geometric error.\nIt is thus advantageous to allow for maximum flexibility in representing\nsurfaces in practical codes when proving a posteriori error estimates for SFEM.\nHowever, previous a posteriori estimates using general parametric surface\nrepresentations are suboptimal by one order on $C^2$ surfaces. Proofs of error\nestimates optimally reflecting the geometric error instead employ the closest\npoint projection, which is defined using the signed distance function. Because\nthe closest point projection is often unavailable or inconvenient to use\ncomputationally, a posteriori estimates using the signed distance function have\nnotable practical limitations. We merge these two perspectives by assuming {\\it\npractical} access only to a general parametric representation of the surface,\nbut using the distance function as a {\\it theoretical} tool. This allows us to\nderive sharper geometric estimators which exhibit improved experimentally\nobserved decay rates when implemented in adaptive surface finite element\nalgorithms.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We prove new a posteriori error estimates for surface finite element methods\n(SFEM). Surface FEM approximate solutions to PDE posed on surfaces.\nPrototypical examples are elliptic PDE involving the Laplace-Beltrami operator.\nTypically the surface is approximated by a polyhedral or higher-order\npolynomial approximation. The resulting FEM exhibits both a geometric\nconsistency error due to the surface approximation and a standard Galerkin\nerror. A posteriori estimates for SFEM require practical access to geometric\ninformation about the surface in order to computably bound the geometric error.\nIt is thus advantageous to allow for maximum flexibility in representing\nsurfaces in practical codes when proving a posteriori error estimates for SFEM.\nHowever, previous a posteriori estimates using general parametric surface\nrepresentations are suboptimal by one order on $C^2$ surfaces. Proofs of error\nestimates optimally reflecting the geometric error instead employ the closest\npoint projection, which is defined using the signed distance function. Because\nthe closest point projection is often unavailable or inconvenient to use\ncomputationally, a posteriori estimates using the signed distance function have\nnotable practical limitations. We merge these two perspectives by assuming {\\it\npractical} access only to a general parametric representation of the surface,\nbut using the distance function as a {\\it theoretical} tool. This allows us to\nderive sharper geometric estimators which exhibit improved experimentally\nobserved decay rates when implemented in adaptive surface finite element\nalgorithms."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Alan Demlow"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Alan Demlow"}, "author": "Alan Demlow", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1802.01625v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1802.01625v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "58J32, 65N15, 65N30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1906.02786v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1906.02786v1", "updated": "2019-06-06T19:35:04Z", "updated_parsed": [2019, 6, 6, 19, 35, 4, 3, 157, 0], "published": "2019-06-06T19:35:04Z", "published_parsed": [2019, 6, 6, 19, 35, 4, 3, 157, 0], "title": "Finite Element Methods for the Laplace-Beltrami Operator", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Finite Element Methods for the Laplace-Beltrami Operator"}, "summary": "Partial differential equations posed on surfaces arise in a number of\napplications. In this survey we describe three popular finite element methods\nfor approximating solutions to the Laplace-Beltrami problem posed on an\n$n$-dimensional surface $\\gamma$ embedded in $\\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$: the\nparametric, trace, and narrow band methods. The parametric method entails\nconstructing an approximating polyhedral surface $\\Gamma$ whose faces comprise\nthe finite element triangulation. The finite element method is then posed over\nthe approximate surface $\\Gamma$ in a manner very similar to standard FEM on\nEuclidean domains. In the trace method it is assumed that the given surface\n$\\gamma$ is embedded in an $n+1$-dimensional domain $\\Omega$ which has itself\nbeen triangulated. An $n$-dimensional approximate surface $\\Gamma$ is then\nconstructed roughly speaking by interpolating $\\gamma$ over the triangulation\nof $\\Omega$, and the finite element space over $\\Gamma$ consists of the trace\n(restriction) of a standard finite element space on $\\Omega$ to $\\Gamma$. In\nthe narrow band method the PDE posed on the surface is extended to a\ntriangulated $n+1$-dimensional band about $\\gamma$ whose width is proportional\nto the diameter of elements in the triangulation. In all cases we provide\noptimal a priori error estimates for the lowest-order finite element methods,\nand we also present a posteriori error estimates for the parametric and trace\nmethods. Our presentation focuses especially on the relationship between the\nregularity of the surface $\\gamma$, which is never assumed better than of class\n$C^2$, the manner in which $\\gamma$ is represented in theory and practice, and\nthe properties of the resulting methods.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Partial differential equations posed on surfaces arise in a number of\napplications. In this survey we describe three popular finite element methods\nfor approximating solutions to the Laplace-Beltrami problem posed on an\n$n$-dimensional surface $\\gamma$ embedded in $\\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$: the\nparametric, trace, and narrow band methods. The parametric method entails\nconstructing an approximating polyhedral surface $\\Gamma$ whose faces comprise\nthe finite element triangulation. The finite element method is then posed over\nthe approximate surface $\\Gamma$ in a manner very similar to standard FEM on\nEuclidean domains. In the trace method it is assumed that the given surface\n$\\gamma$ is embedded in an $n+1$-dimensional domain $\\Omega$ which has itself\nbeen triangulated. An $n$-dimensional approximate surface $\\Gamma$ is then\nconstructed roughly speaking by interpolating $\\gamma$ over the triangulation\nof $\\Omega$, and the finite element space over $\\Gamma$ consists of the trace\n(restriction) of a standard finite element space on $\\Omega$ to $\\Gamma$. In\nthe narrow band method the PDE posed on the surface is extended to a\ntriangulated $n+1$-dimensional band about $\\gamma$ whose width is proportional\nto the diameter of elements in the triangulation. In all cases we provide\noptimal a priori error estimates for the lowest-order finite element methods,\nand we also present a posteriori error estimates for the parametric and trace\nmethods. Our presentation focuses especially on the relationship between the\nregularity of the surface $\\gamma$, which is never assumed better than of class\n$C^2$, the manner in which $\\gamma$ is represented in theory and practice, and\nthe properties of the resulting methods."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Alan Demlow"}, {"name": "Ricardo H. The former involves the second fundamental form of the middle plate\nand the later is a restriction on its first fundamental form. We discuss a\nformal derivation of this reduced model along with an equivalent formulation\nthat makes it amenable computationally. We propose a local discontinuous\nGalerkin (LDG) finite element approach that hinges on the notion of\nreconstructed Hessian. We design discrete gradient flows to minimize the\nensuing nonconvex problem and to find a suitable initial deformation. We\npresent several insightful numerical experiments, some of practical interest,\nand assess various computational aspects of the approximation process.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A reduced model for large deformations of prestrained plates consists of\nminimizing a second order bending energy subject to a nonconvex metric\nconstraint. The former involves the second fundamental form of the middle plate\nand the later is a restriction on its first fundamental form. We discuss a\nformal derivation of this reduced model along with an equivalent formulation\nthat makes it amenable computationally. We propose a local discontinuous\nGalerkin (LDG) finite element approach that hinges on the notion of\nreconstructed Hessian. We design discrete gradient flows to minimize the\nensuing nonconvex problem and to find a suitable initial deformation. The idea is to have the surface sufficiently well resolved in\n$W^1_\\infty$ relative to the current resolution of the PDE in $H^1$. This gives\nrise to a conditional contraction property of the PDE module. We present a\nsuitable approximation class and discuss its relation to Besov regularity of\nthe surface, solution, and forcing. Nochetto", "arxiv_comment": "51 pages, the published version contains an additional glossary", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1511.05019v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1511.05019v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.05869v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.05869v3", "updated": "2016-07-14T02:07:33Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 7, 14, 2, 7, 33, 3, 196, 0], "published": "2015-08-24T16:19:22Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 8, 24, 16, 19, 22, 0, 236, 0], "title": "Numerical Approximation of Fractional Powers of Regularly Accretive\n  Operators", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Numerical Approximation of Fractional Powers of Regularly Accretive\n  Operators"}, "summary": "We study the numerical approximation of fractional powers of accretive\noperators in this paper. Namely, if $A$ is the accretive operator associated\nwith an accretive sesquilinear form $A(\\cdot,\\cdot)$ defined on a Hilbert space\n$\\mathbb V$ contained in $L^2(\\Omega)$, we approximate $A^{-\\beta}$ for\n$\\beta\\in (0,1)$. The fractional powers are defined in terms of the so-called\nBalakrishnan integral formula. Given a finite element approximation space\n$\\mathbb V_h\\subset \\mathbb V$, $A^{-\\beta}$ is approximated by\n$A_h^{-\\beta}\\pi_h$ where $A_h$ is the operator associated with the form\n$A(\\cdot,\\cdot)$ restricted to $\\mathbb V_h$ and $\\pi_h$ is the\n$L^2(\\Omega)$-projection onto $\\mathbb V_h$. We first provide error estimates\nfor $(A^\\beta-A_h^{\\beta}\\pi_h)f$ in Sobolev norms with index in [0,1] for\nappropriate $f$. These results depend on elliptic regularity properties of\nvariational solutions involving the form $A(\\cdot,\\cdot)$ and are valid for the\ncase of less than full elliptic regularity. We also construct and analyze an\nexponentially convergent sinc quadrature approximation to the Balakrishnan\nintegral defining $A_h^{\\beta}\\pi_h f$. Finally, the results of numerical\ncomputations illustrating the proposed method are given.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study the numerical approximation of fractional powers of accretive\noperators in this paper. Namely, if $A$ is the accretive operator associated\nwith an accretive sesquilinear form $A(\\cdot,\\cdot)$ defined on a Hilbert space\n$\\mathbb V$ contained in $L^2(\\Omega)$, we approximate $A^{-\\beta}$ for\n$\\beta\\in (0,1)$. The fractional powers are defined in terms of the so-called\nBalakrishnan integral formula. Given a finite element approximation space\n$\\mathbb V_h\\subset \\mathbb V$, $A^{-\\beta}$ is approximated by\n$A_h^{-\\beta}\\pi_h$ where $A_h$ is the operator associated with the form\n$A(\\cdot,\\cdot)$ restricted to $\\mathbb V_h$ and $\\pi_h$ is the\n$L^2(\\Omega)$-projection onto $\\mathbb V_h$. We first provide error estimates\nfor $(A^\\beta-A_h^{\\beta}\\pi_h)f$ in Sobolev norms with index in [0,1] for\nappropriate $f$. These results depend on elliptic regularity properties of\nvariational solutions involving the form $A(\\cdot,\\cdot)$ and are valid for the\ncase of less than full elliptic regularity. We also construct and analyze an\nexponentially convergent sinc quadrature approximation to the Balakrishnan\nintegral defining $A_h^{\\beta}\\pi_h f$. Finally, the results of numerical\ncomputations illustrating the proposed method are given."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Joseph E. We introduce various anisotropic model\nclasses based on Taylor expansions, and study their approximation by finite\ndimensional polynomial spaces $\\cal{P}_{\\Lambda}$ described by lower sets\n$\\Lambda$. Given a budget $n$ for the dimension of $\\cal{P}_{\\Lambda}$, we\nprove that certain lower sets $\\Lambda_n$, with cardinality $n$, provide a\ncertifiable approximation error that is in a certain sense optimal, and that\nthese lower sets have a simple definition in terms of simplices. Our main goal\nis to obtain approximation results when the number of variables $d$ is large\nand even infinite, and so we concentrate almost exclusively on the case\n$d=\\infty$. We also emphasize obtaining results which hold for the full range\n$n\\ge 1$, rather than asymptotic results that only hold for $n$ sufficiently\nlarge. In applications, one typically wants $n$ small to comply with\ncomputational budgets.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Motivated by numerical methods for solving parametric partial differential\nequations, this paper studies the approximation of multivariate analytic\nfunctions by algebraic polynomials. We introduce various anisotropic model\nclasses based on Taylor expansions, and study their approximation by finite\ndimensional polynomial spaces $\\cal{P}_{\\Lambda}$ described by lower sets\n$\\Lambda$. Given a budget $n$ for the dimension of $\\cal{P}_{\\Lambda}$, we\nprove that certain lower sets $\\Lambda_n$, with cardinality $n$, provide a\ncertifiable approximation error that is in a certain sense optimal, and that\nthese lower sets have a simple definition in terms of simplices. Our main goal\nis to obtain approximation results when the number of variables $d$ is large\nand even infinite, and so we concentrate almost exclusively on the case\n$d=\\infty$. We also emphasize obtaining results which hold for the full range\n$n\\ge 1$, rather than asymptotic results that only hold for $n$ sufficiently\nlarge. In applications, one typically wants $n$ small to comply with\ncomputational budgets."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, {"name": "Diane Guignard"}, {"name": "Peter Jantsch"}, {"name": "Guergana Petrova"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Guergana Petrova"}, "author": "Guergana Petrova", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1904.12105v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1904.12105v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "41A10, 41A58, 41A63, 65N15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01576v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01576v1", "updated": "2018-08-05T07:56:55Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 8, 5, 7, 56, 55, 6, 217, 0], "published": "2018-08-05T07:56:55Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 8, 5, 7, 56, 55, 6, 217, 0], "title": "Finite element approximation of an obstacle problem for a class of\n  integro-differential operators", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Finite element approximation of an obstacle problem for a class of\n  integro-differential operators"}, "summary": "We study the regularity of the solution to an obstacle problem for a class of\nintegro-differential operators. The latter consists\nof an improper integral approximated via quadratures. At each quadrature point,\na reaction-diffusion problem must be approximated and is the method bottle\nneck. In this work, we propose to reduce the computational cost using a reduced\nbasis strategy allowing for a fast evaluation of the reaction-diffusion\nproblems. The reduced basis does not depend on the fractional power $s$ for\n$0<s_{\\min}\\leq s \\leq s_{\\max}<1$. It is built offline once for all and used\nonline irrespectively of the fractional power. This linear reduced model $V_n$ is then used for\nvarious tasks such as building an online forward solver for the PDE or\nestimating parameters from data observations. It is well understood in other\nproblems of numerical computation that nonlinear methods such as adaptive\napproximation, $n$-term approximation, and certain tree-based methods may\nprovide improved numerical efficiency. For model reduction, a nonlinear method\nwould replace the linear space $V_n$ by a nonlinear space $\\Sigma_n$. This idea\nhas already been suggested in recent papers on model reduction where the\nparameter domain is decomposed into a finite number of cells and a linear space\nof low dimension is assigned to each cell.\n  Up to this point, little is known in terms of performance guarantees for such\na nonlinear strategy. Moreover, most numerical experiments for nonlinear model\nreduction use a parameter dimension of only one or two. In this work, a step is\nmade towards a more cohesive theory for nonlinear model reduction. Framing\nthese methods in the general setting of library approximation allows us to give\na first comparison of their performance with those of standard linear\napproximation for any general compact set. We then turn to the study these\nmethods for solution manifolds of parametrized elliptic PDEs. We study a very\nspecific example of library approximation where the parameter domain is split\ninto a finite number $N$ of rectangular cells and where different reduced\naffine spaces of dimension $m$ are assigned to each cell. The performance of\nthis nonlinear procedure is analyzed from the viewpoint of accuracy of\napproximation versus $m$ and $N$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The usual approach to model reduction for parametric partial differential\nequations (PDEs) is to construct a linear space $V_n$ which approximates well\nthe solution manifold $\\mathcal{M}$ consisting of all solutions $u(y)$ with $y$\nthe vector of parameters. This linear reduced model $V_n$ is then used for\nvarious tasks such as building an online forward solver for the PDE or\nestimating parameters from data observations. It is well understood in other\nproblems of numerical computation that nonlinear methods such as adaptive\napproximation, $n$-term approximation, and certain tree-based methods may\nprovide improved numerical efficiency. For model reduction, a nonlinear method\nwould replace the linear space $V_n$ by a nonlinear space $\\Sigma_n$. This idea\nhas already been suggested in recent papers on model reduction where the\nparameter domain is decomposed into a finite number of cells and a linear space\nof low dimension is assigned to each cell.\n  Up to this point, little is known in terms of performance guarantees for such\na nonlinear strategy. Moreover, most numerical experiments for nonlinear model\nreduction use a parameter dimension of only one or two. In this work, a step is\nmade towards a more cohesive theory for nonlinear model reduction. Framing\nthese methods in the general setting of library approximation allows us to give\na first comparison of their performance with those of standard linear\napproximation for any general compact set. We then turn to the study these\nmethods for solution manifolds of parametrized elliptic PDEs. We study a very\nspecific example of library approximation where the parameter domain is split\ninto a finite number $N$ of rectangular cells and where different reduced\naffine spaces of dimension $m$ are assigned to each cell. The performance of\nthis nonlinear procedure is analyzed from the viewpoint of accuracy of\napproximation versus $m$ and $N$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Albert Cohen"}, {"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, {"name": "Diane Guignard"}, {"name": "Peter Jantsch"}, {"name": "Guergana Petrova"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Guergana Petrova"}, "author": "Guergana Petrova", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2005.02565v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2005.02565v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.04290v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.04290v2", "updated": "2018-12-18T19:13:37Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 12, 18, 19, 13, 37, 1, 352, 0], "published": "2017-07-13T19:54:48Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 7, 13, 19, 54, 48, 3, 194, 0], "title": "Numerical Approximation of the Integral Fractional Laplacian", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Numerical Approximation of the Integral Fractional Laplacian"}, "summary": "We propose a new nonconforming finite element algorithm to approximate the\nsolution to the elliptic problem involving the fractional Laplacian. We first\nderive an integral representation of the bilinear form corresponding to the\nvariational problem. The numerical approximation of the action of the\ncorresponding stiffness matrix consists of three steps: (i) apply a sinc\nquadrature scheme to approximate the integral representation by a finite sum\nwhere each term involves the solution of an elliptic partial differential\nequation defined on the entire space, (ii) truncate each elliptic problem to a\nbounded domain, (iii) use the finite element method for the space approximation\non each truncated domain. The consistency error analysis for the three steps is\ndiscussed together with the numerical implementation of the entire algorithm.\nThe results of computations are given illustrating the error behavior in terms\nof the mesh size of the physical domain, the domain truncation parameter and\nthe quadrature spacing parameter.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We propose a new nonconforming finite element algorithm to approximate the\nsolution to the elliptic problem involving the fractional Laplacian. We first\nderive an integral representation of the bilinear form corresponding to the\nvariational problem. The numerical approximation of the action of the\ncorresponding stiffness matrix consists of three steps: (i) apply a sinc\nquadrature scheme to approximate the integral representation by a finite sum\nwhere each term involves the solution of an elliptic partial differential\nequation defined on the entire space, (ii) truncate each elliptic problem to a\nbounded domain, (iii) use the finite element method for the space approximation\non each truncated domain.
