The numerical method is based on a\nrepresentation formula for $T^{-\\beta}$ in terms of Bochner integrals involving\n$(I+t^2L)^{-1}$ for $t\\in(0,\\infty)$.\n  To develop an approximation to $T^\\beta$, we introduce a finite element\napproximation $L_h$ to $L$ and base our approximation to $T^\\beta$ on\n$T_h^\\beta:= L_h^{-\\beta}$. The direct evaluation of $T_h^{\\beta}$ is extremely\nexpensive as it involves expansion in the basis of eigenfunctions for $L_h$.\nThe above mentioned representation formula holds for $T_h^{-\\beta}$ and we\npropose three quadrature approximations denoted generically by $Q_h^\\beta$. The\ntwo results of this paper bound the errors in the $H_0$ inner product of\n$T^\\beta-T_h^\\beta\\pi_h$ and $T_h^\\beta-Q_h^\\beta$ where $\\pi_h$ is the $H_0$\northogonal projection into the finite element space. We note that the\nevaluation of $Q_h^\\beta$ involves application of $(I+(t_i)^2L_h)^{-1}$ with\n$t_i$ being either a quadrature point or its inverse. Efficient solution\nalgorithms for these problems are available and the problems at different\nquadrature points can be straightforwardly solved in parallel. Numerical\nexperiments illustrating the theoretical estimates are provided for both the\nquadrature error $T_h^\\beta-Q_h^\\beta$ and the finite element error\n$T^\\beta-T_h^\\beta\\pi_h$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We present and study a novel numerical algorithm to approximate the action of\n$T^\\beta:=L^{-\\beta}$ where $L$ is a symmetric and positive definite unbounded\noperator on a Hilbert space $H_0$. The numerical method is based on a\nrepresentation formula for $T^{-\\beta}$ in terms of Bochner integrals involving\n$(I+t^2L)^{-1}$ for $t\\in(0,\\infty)$.\n  To develop an approximation to $T^\\beta$, we introduce a finite element\napproximation $L_h$ to $L$ and base our approximation to $T^\\beta$ on\n$T_h^\\beta:= L_h^{-\\beta}$. The direct evaluation of $T_h^{\\beta}$ is extremely\nexpensive as it involves expansion in the basis of eigenfunctions for $L_h$.\nThe above mentioned representation formula holds for $T_h^{-\\beta}$ and we\npropose three quadrature approximations denoted generically by $Q_h^\\beta$. The\ntwo results of this paper bound the errors in the $H_0$ inner product of\n$T^\\beta-T_h^\\beta\\pi_h$ and $T_h^\\beta-Q_h^\\beta$ where $\\pi_h$ is the $H_0$\northogonal projection into the finite element space. We note that the\nevaluation of $Q_h^\\beta$ involves application of $(I+(t_i)^2L_h)^{-1}$ with\n$t_i$ being either a quadrature point or its inverse. Efficient solution\nalgorithms for these problems are available and the problems at different\nquadrature points can be straightforwardly solved in parallel. Numerical\nexperiments illustrating the theoretical estimates are provided for both the\nquadrature error $T_h^\\beta-Q_h^\\beta$ and the finite element error\n$T^\\beta-T_h^\\beta\\pi_h$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Joseph E. Pasciak"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Joseph E. Pasciak"}, "author": "Joseph E. Pasciak", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.0888v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1307.0888v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35S15, 65R20, 65N12, 65N50, 65N30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.3203v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.3203v3", "updated": "2013-07-30T21:05:44Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 7, 30, 21, 5, 44, 1, 211, 0], "published": "2013-01-15T02:21:49Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 1, 15, 2, 21, 49, 1, 15, 0], "title": "Adaptive Finite Element Methods for Elliptic Problems with Discontinuous\n  Coefficients", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Adaptive Finite Element Methods for Elliptic Problems with Discontinuous\n  Coefficients"}, "summary": "Elliptic partial differential equations (PDEs) with discontinuous diffusion\ncoefficients occur in application domains such as diffusions through porous\nmedia, electro-magnetic field propagation on heterogeneous media, and diffusion\nprocesses on rough surfaces. The standard approach to numerically treating such\nproblems using finite element methods is to assume that the discontinuities lie\non the boundaries of the cells in the initial triangulation. However, this does\nnot match applications where discontinuities occur on curves, surfaces, or\nmanifolds, and could even be unknown beforehand. One of the obstacles to\ntreating such discontinuity problems is that the usual perturbation theory for\nelliptic PDEs assumes bounds for the distortion of the coefficients in the\n$L_\\infty$ norm and this in turn requires that the discontinuities are matched\nexactly when the coefficients are approximated. We present a new approach based\non distortion of the coefficients in an $L_q$ norm with $q<\\infty$ which\ntherefore does not require the exact matching of the discontinuities. We then\nuse this new distortion theory to formulate new adaptive finite element methods\n(AFEMs) for such discontinuity problems. We show that such AFEMs are optimal in\nthe sense of distortion versus number of computations, and report insightful\nnumerical results supporting our analysis.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Elliptic partial differential equations (PDEs) with discontinuous diffusion\ncoefficients occur in application domains such as diffusions through porous\nmedia, electro-magnetic field propagation on heterogeneous media, and diffusion\nprocesses on rough surfaces. The standard approach to numerically treating such\nproblems using finite element methods is to assume that the discontinuities lie\non the boundaries of the cells in the initial triangulation. However, this does\nnot match applications where discontinuities occur on curves, surfaces, or\nmanifolds, and could even be unknown beforehand. One of the obstacles to\ntreating such discontinuity problems is that the usual perturbation theory for\nelliptic PDEs assumes bounds for the distortion of the coefficients in the\n$L_\\infty$ norm and this in turn requires that the discontinuities are matched\nexactly when the coefficients are approximated. We present a new approach based\non distortion of the coefficients in an $L_q$ norm with $q<\\infty$ which\ntherefore does not require the exact matching of the discontinuities. We then\nuse this new distortion theory to formulate new adaptive finite element methods\n(AFEMs) for such discontinuity problems. We show that such AFEMs are optimal in\nthe sense of distortion versus number of computations, and report insightful\nnumerical results supporting our analysis."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Ronald A. DeVore"}, {"name": "Ricardo H. Nochetto"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Ricardo H. Nochetto"}, "author": "Ricardo H. Nochetto", "arxiv_comment": "24 pages", "arxiv_journal_ref": "SIAM J. Numer. Anal., 51(6), 3106--3134, 2013", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.3203v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1301.3203v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65N30, 65N15, 41A25, 65N50, 65Y20", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.04322v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.04322v1", "updated": "2015-01-18T16:10:22Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 1, 18, 16, 10, 22, 6, 18, 0], "published": "2015-01-18T16:10:22Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 1, 18, 16, 10, 22, 6, 18, 0], "title": "Numerical Simulations of Bouncing Jets", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Numerical Simulations of Bouncing Jets"}, "summary": "Bouncing jets are fascinating phenomenons occurring under certain conditions\nwhen a jet impinges on a free surface. This effect is observed when the fluid\nis Newtonian and the jet falls in a bath undergoing a solid motion. It occurs\nalso for non-Newtonian fluids when the jets falls in a vessel at rest\ncontaining the same fluid.\n  We investigate numerically the impact of the experimental setting and the\nrheological properties of the fluid on the onset of the bouncing phenomenon.\nOur investigations show that the occurrence of a thin lubricating layer of air\nseparating the jet and the rest of the liquid is a key factor for the bouncing\nof the jet to happen.\n  The numerical technique that is used consists of a projection method for the\nNavier-Stokes system coupled with a level set formulation for the\nrepresentation of the interface. The space approximation is done with adaptive\nfinite elements. Adaptive refinement is shown to be very important to capture\nthe thin layer of air that is responsible for the bouncing.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Bouncing jets are fascinating phenomenons occurring under certain conditions\nwhen a jet impinges on a free surface. This effect is observed when the fluid\nis Newtonian and the jet falls in a bath undergoing a solid motion. It occurs\nalso for non-Newtonian fluids when the jets falls in a vessel at rest\ncontaining the same fluid.\n  We investigate numerically the impact of the experimental setting and the\nrheological properties of the fluid on the onset of the bouncing phenomenon.\nOur investigations show that the occurrence of a thin lubricating layer of air\nseparating the jet and the rest of the liquid is a key factor for the bouncing\nof the jet to happen.\n  The numerical technique that is used consists of a projection method for the\nNavier-Stokes system coupled with a level set formulation for the\nrepresentation of the interface. The space approximation is done with adaptive\nfinite elements. Adaptive refinement is shown to be very important to capture\nthe thin layer of air that is responsible for the bouncing."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Jean-Luc Guermond"}, {"name": "Sanghyun Lee"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Sanghyun Lee"}, "author": "Sanghyun Lee", "arxiv_doi": "10.1002/fld.4071", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/fld.4071", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.04322v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1501.04322v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "physics.flu-dyn", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2102.08511v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2102.08511v2", "updated": "2021-08-05T18:51:21Z", "updated_parsed": [2021, 8, 5, 18, 51, 21, 3, 217, 0], "published": "2021-02-17T00:27:45Z", "published_parsed": [2021, 2, 17, 0, 27, 45, 2, 48, 0], "title": "Finite Element Approximation of Steady Flows of Colloidal Solutions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Finite Element Approximation of Steady Flows of Colloidal Solutions"}, "summary": "We consider the mathematical analysis and numerical approximation of a system\nof nonlinear partial differential equations that arises in models that have\nrelevance to steady isochoric flows of colloidal suspensions. The symmetric\nvelocity gradient is assumed to be a monotone nonlinear function of the\ndeviatoric part of the Cauchy stress tensor. We prove the existence of a unique\nweak solution to the problem, and under the additional assumption that the\nnonlinearity involved in the constitutive relation is Lipschitz continuous we\nalso prove uniqueness of the weak solution. We then construct mixed finite\nelement approximations of the system using both conforming and nonconforming\nfinite element spaces. For both of these we prove the convergence of the method\nto the unique weak solution of the problem, and in the case of the conforming\nmethod we provide a bound on the error between the analytical solution and its\nfinite element approximation in terms of the best approximation error from the\nfinite element spaces. We propose first a Lions-Mercier type iterative method\nand next a classical fixed-point algorithm to solve the finite-dimensional\nproblems resulting from the finite element discretisation of the system of\nnonlinear partial differential equations under consideration and present\nnumerical experiments that illustrate the practical performance of the proposed\nnumerical method.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider the mathematical analysis and numerical approximation of a system\nof nonlinear partial differential equations that arises in models that have\nrelevance to steady isochoric flows of colloidal suspensions. The symmetric\nvelocity gradient is assumed to be a monotone nonlinear function of the\ndeviatoric part of the Cauchy stress tensor. We prove the existence of a unique\nweak solution to the problem, and under the additional assumption that the\nnonlinearity involved in the constitutive relation is Lipschitz continuous we\nalso prove uniqueness of the weak solution. We then construct mixed finite\nelement approximations of the system using both conforming and nonconforming\nfinite element spaces. For both of these we prove the convergence of the method\nto the unique weak solution of the problem, and in the case of the conforming\nmethod we provide a bound on the error between the analytical solution and its\nfinite element approximation in terms of the best approximation error from the\nfinite element spaces. We propose first a Lions-Mercier type iterative method\nand next a classical fixed-point algorithm to solve the finite-dimensional\nproblems resulting from the finite element discretisation of the system of\nnonlinear partial differential equations under consideration and present\nnumerical experiments that illustrate the practical performance of the proposed\nnumerical method."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Vivette Girault"}, {"name": "Diane Guignard"}, {"name": "Kumbakonam R. Both the initial value problem and the\nnon-homogeneous forcing problem (with zero initial data) are considered. The\nsolution operator $E(t)$ for the initial value problem can be written as a\nDunford-Taylor integral involving the Mittag-Leffler function $e_{\\alpha,1}$\nand the resolvent of the underlying (non-fractional) spatial operator over an\nappropriate integration path in the complex plane. Here $\\alpha$ denotes the\norder of the fractional time derivative. The solution for the non-homogeneous\nproblem can be written as a convolution involving an operator $W(t)$ and the\nforcing function $F(t)$.\n  We develop and analyze semi-discrete methods based on finite element\napproximation to the underlying (non-fractional) spatial operator in terms of\nanalogous Dunford-Taylor integrals applied to the discrete operator. The space\nerror is of optimal order up to a logarithm of $1/h$. The fully discrete method\nfor the initial value problem is developed from the semi-discrete approximation\nby applying an exponentially convergent sinc quadrature technique to\napproximate the Dunford-Taylor integral of the discrete operator and is free of\nany time stepping.\n  To approximate the convolution appearing in the semi-discrete approximation\nto the non-homogeneous problem, we apply a pseudo midpoint quadrature. This\ninvolves the average of $W_h(s)$, (the semi-discrete approximation to $W(s)$)\nover the quadrature interval. This average can also be written as a\nDunford-Taylor integral. We first analyze the error between this quadrature and\nthe semi-discrete approximation. To develop a fully discrete method, we then\nintroduce sinc quadrature approximations to the Dunford-Taylor integrals for\ncomputing the averages.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we develop a numerical scheme for the space-time fractional\nparabolic equation, i.e., an equation involving a fractional time derivative\nand a fractional spatial operator. The\nsolution operator $E(t)$ for the initial value problem can be written as a\nDunford-Taylor integral involving the Mittag-Leffler function $e_{\\alpha,1}$\nand the resolvent of the underlying (non-fractional) spatial operator over an\nappropriate integration path in the complex plane. These include the fact that the velocity\nvector should be tangent to the given surface and the possible presence of\ndegenerate modes (Killing fields) in the solution. We analyze a surface finite\nelement method which provides solutions to these challenges. We consider an\ninterior penalty method based on the well-known Brezzi-Douglas-Marini $H({\\rm\ndiv})$-conforming finite element space. The resulting spaces are tangential to\nthe surface, but require penalization of jumps across element interfaces in\norder to weakly maintain $H^1$ conformity of the velocity field. In addition\nour method exactly satisfies the incompressibility constraint in the surface\nStokes problem. Secondly, we give a method which robustly filters Killing\nfields out of the solution. This problem is complicated by the fact that the\ndimension of the space of Killing fields may change with small perturbations of\nthe surface. We first approximate the Killing fields via a Stokes eigenvalue\nproblem and then give a method which is asymptotically guaranteed to correctly\nexclude them from the solution. The properties of our method are rigorously\nestablished via an error analysis and illustrated via numerical experiments.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The Stokes equation posed on surfaces is important in some physical models,\nbut its numerical solution poses several challenges not encountered in the\ncorresponding Euclidean setting. These include the fact that the velocity\nvector should be tangent to the given surface and the possible presence of\ndegenerate modes (Killing fields) in the solution. We analyze a surface finite\nelement method which provides solutions to these challenges. We consider an\ninterior penalty method based on the well-known Brezzi-Douglas-Marini $H({\\rm\ndiv})$-conforming finite element space. The resulting spaces are tangential to\nthe surface, but require penalization of jumps across element interfaces in\norder to weakly maintain $H^1$ conformity of the velocity field. In addition\nour method exactly satisfies the incompressibility constraint in the surface\nStokes problem. Secondly, we give a method which robustly filters Killing\nfields out of the solution. This problem is complicated by the fact that the\ndimension of the space of Killing fields may change with small perturbations of\nthe surface. We first approximate the Killing fields via a Stokes eigenvalue\nproblem and then give a method which is asymptotically guaranteed to correctly\nexclude them from the solution. The properties of our method are rigorously\nestablished via an error analysis and illustrated via numerical experiments."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Alan Demlow"}, {"name": "Martin Licht"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Martin Licht"}, "author": "Martin Licht", "arxiv_comment": "29 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1908.11460v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1908.11460v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65N12, 65N15, 65N25, 65N30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2002.00114v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2002.00114v2", "updated": "2020-08-12T21:55:41Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 8, 12, 21, 55, 41, 2, 225, 0], "published": "2020-02-01T00:35:54Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 2, 1, 0, 35, 54, 5, 32, 0], "title": "Discontinuous Galerkin Approach to Large Bending Deformation of a\n  Bilayer Plate with Isometry Constraint", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Discontinuous Galerkin Approach to Large Bending Deformation of a\n  Bilayer Plate with Isometry Constraint"}, "summary": "We present a computational model of thin elastic bilayers that undergo large\nbending isometric deformations when actuated by non-mechanical stimuli. The sequence\nof finite element approximations is shown to exhibit strong convergence to the\nunique weak solution of the model. Assuming that the material parameters\nfeaturing in the model are Lipschitz-continuous, and assuming that the weak\nsolution has additional regularity, the sequence of finite element\napproximations is shown to converge with a rate. An iterative algorithm is\nconstructed for the solution of the system of nonlinear algebraic equations\nthat arises from the finite element approximation. An appealing feature of the\niterative algorithm is that it decouples the monotone and linear elastic parts\nof the nonlinearity in the model. In particular, our choice of piecewise\nconstant approximation for the stress tensor (and continuous piecewise linear\napproximation for the displacement) allows us to compute the monotone part of\nthe nonlinearity by solving an algebraic system with $d(d+1)/2$ unknowns\nindependently on each element in the subdivision of the computational domain.\nThe theoretical results are illustrated by numerical experiments.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We construct a finite element approximation of a strain-limiting elastic\nmodel on a bounded open domain in $\\mathbb{R}^d$, $d \\in \\{2,3\\}$. Assuming that the material parameters\nfeaturing in the model are Lipschitz-continuous, and assuming that the weak\nsolution has additional regularity, the sequence of finite element\napproximations is shown to converge with a rate. An iterative algorithm is\nconstructed for the solution of the system of nonlinear algebraic equations\nthat arises from the finite element approximation. An appealing feature of the\niterative algorithm is that it decouples the monotone and linear elastic parts\nof the nonlinearity in the model. The liquid is located in between two\nconcentric circular electrodes which are either assumed to be of infinite\nheight or slim. Each configuration results in a different nonlocal\nelectro-magnetic model defined on a two dimensional bounded domain. The\nnumerical method consists in approximating the surface charge density, the\nliquid velocity and pressure, and the electric potential in the two dimensional\nliquid region. Finite elements for the space discretization coupled with\nstandard time stepping methods are put forward. Unlike for the infinite\nelectrodes configuration, our numerical simulations indicate that slim\nelectrodes are favorable for electroconvection to occur and are able to sustain\nthe phenomena over long period of time. Furthermore, we provide a numerical\nstudy on the influence of the three main parameters of the system: the Rayleigh\nnumber, the Prandtl number and the electrodes aspect ratio.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We propose a finite element method for the numerical simulation of\nelectroconvection of thin liquid crystals. The liquid is located in between two\nconcentric circular electrodes which are either assumed to be of infinite\nheight or slim. Each configuration results in a different nonlocal\nelectro-magnetic model defined on a two dimensional bounded domain. The\nnumerical method consists in approximating the surface charge density, the\nliquid velocity and pressure, and the electric potential in the two dimensional\nliquid region. Finite elements for the space discretization coupled with\nstandard time stepping methods are put forward. Unlike for the infinite\nelectrodes configuration, our numerical simulations indicate that slim\nelectrodes are favorable for electroconvection to occur and are able to sustain\nthe phenomena over long period of time. Furthermore, we provide a numerical\nstudy on the influence of the three main parameters of the system: the Rayleigh\nnumber, the Prandtl number and the electrodes aspect ratio."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Peng Wei"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Peng Wei"}, "author": "Peng Wei", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2019.109140", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2019.109140", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1903.05836v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1903.05836v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "28 pages", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "physics.comp-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.01180v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.01180v1", "updated": "2020-06-01T18:15:33Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 6, 1, 18, 15, 33, 0, 153, 0], "published": "2020-06-01T18:15:33Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 6, 1, 18, 15, 33, 0, 153, 0], "title": "Numerical Simulations of Surface-Quasi Geostrophic Flows on Periodic\n  Domains", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Numerical Simulations of Surface-Quasi Geostrophic Flows on Periodic\n  Domains"}, "summary": "We propose a novel algorithm for the approximation of surface-quasi\ngeostrophic (SQG) flows modeled by a nonlinear partial differential equation\ncoupling transport and fractional diffusion phenomena. The time discretization\nconsists of an explicit strong-stability-preserving three-stage Runge-Kutta\nmethod while a flux-corrected-transport (FCT) method coupled with\nDunford-Taylor representations of fractional operators is advocated for the\nspace discretization. Standard continuous piecewise linear finite elements are\nemployed and the algorithm does not have restrictions on the mesh structure nor\non the computational domain. In the inviscid case, we show that the resulting\nscheme satisfies a discrete maximum principle property under a standard CFL\ncondition and observe, in practice, its second-order accuracy in space. The\nalgorithm successfully approximates several benchmarks with sharp transitions\nand fine structures typical of SQG flows. In addition, theoretical Kolmogorov\nenergy decay rates are observed on a freely decaying atmospheric turbulence\nsimulation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We propose a novel algorithm for the approximation of surface-quasi\ngeostrophic (SQG) flows modeled by a nonlinear partial differential equation\ncoupling transport and fractional diffusion phenomena. The time discretization\nconsists of an explicit strong-stability-preserving three-stage Runge-Kutta\nmethod while a flux-corrected-transport (FCT) method coupled with\nDunford-Taylor representations of fractional operators is advocated for the\nspace discretization. Standard continuous piecewise linear finite elements are\nemployed and the algorithm does not have restrictions on the mesh structure nor\non the computational domain. In the inviscid case, we show that the resulting\nscheme satisfies a discrete maximum principle property under a standard CFL\ncondition and observe, in practice, its second-order accuracy in space. The\nalgorithm successfully approximates several benchmarks with sharp transitions\nand fine structures typical of SQG flows. In addition, theoretical Kolmogorov\nenergy decay rates are observed on a freely decaying atmospheric turbulence\nsimulation."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Murtazo Nazarov"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Murtazo Nazarov"}, "author": "Murtazo Nazarov", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.01180v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2006.01180v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.00197v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.00197v1", "updated": "2017-12-30T21:39:38Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 12, 30, 21, 39, 38, 5, 364, 0], "published": "2017-12-30T21:39:38Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 12, 30, 21, 39, 38, 5, 364, 0], "title": "A Priori Error Estimates for Finite Element Approximations to\n  Eigenvalues and Eigenfunctions of the Laplace-Beltrami Operator", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A Priori Error Estimates for Finite Element Approximations to\n  Eigenvalues and Eigenfunctions of the Laplace-Beltrami Operator"}, "summary": "Elliptic partial differential equations on surfaces play an essential role in\ngeometry, relativity theory, phase transitions, materials science, image\nprocessing, and other applications. They are typically governed by the\nLaplace-Beltrami operator. We present and analyze approximations by Surface\nFinite Element Methods (SFEM) of the Laplace-Beltrami eigenvalue problem. As\nfor SFEM for source problems, spectral approximation is challenged by two\nsources of errors: the geometric consistency error due to the approximation of\nthe surface and the Galerkin error corresponding to finite element resolution\nof eigenfunctions. We show that these two error sources interact for\neigenfunction approximations as for the source problem. The situation is\ndifferent for eigenvalues, where a novel situation occurs for the geometric\nconsistency error: The degree of the geometric error depends on the choice of\ninterpolation points used to construct the approximate surface. Thus the\ngeometric consistency term can sometimes be made to converge faster than in the\neigenfunction case through a judicious choice of interpolation points.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Elliptic partial differential equations on surfaces play an essential role in\ngeometry, relativity theory, phase transitions, materials science, image\nprocessing, and other applications. They are typically governed by the\nLaplace-Beltrami operator. We present and analyze approximations by Surface\nFinite Element Methods (SFEM) of the Laplace-Beltrami eigenvalue problem. As\nfor SFEM for source problems, spectral approximation is challenged by two\nsources of errors: the geometric consistency error due to the approximation of\nthe surface and the Galerkin error corresponding to finite element resolution\nof eigenfunctions. We show that these two error sources interact for\neigenfunction approximations as for the source problem. The situation is\ndifferent for eigenvalues, where a novel situation occurs for the geometric\nconsistency error: The degree of the geometric error depends on the choice of\ninterpolation points used to construct the approximate surface. Thus the\ngeometric consistency term can sometimes be made to converge faster than in the\neigenfunction case through a judicious choice of interpolation points."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Alan Demlow"}, {"name": "Justin Owen"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Justin Owen"}, "author": "Justin Owen", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.00197v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1801.00197v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1609.05231v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1609.05231v2", "updated": "2016-12-16T19:43:31Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 12, 16, 19, 43, 31, 4, 351, 0], "published": "2016-09-16T20:43:23Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 9, 16, 20, 43, 23, 4, 260, 0], "title": "Diffusion Coefficients Estimation for Elliptic Partial Differential\n  Equations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Diffusion Coefficients Estimation for Elliptic Partial Differential\n  Equations"}, "summary": "This paper considers the Dirichlet problem $$ -\\mathrm{div}(a\\nabla u_a)=f\n\\quad \\hbox{on}\\,\\,\\ D, \\qquad u_a=0\\quad \\hbox{on}\\,\\,\\partial D, $$ for a\nLipschitz domain $D\\subset \\mathbb R^d$, where $a$ is a scalar diffusion\nfunction. For a fixed $f$, we discuss under which conditions is $a$ uniquely\ndetermined and when can $a$ be stably recovered from the knowledge of $u_a$.\n  A first result is that whenever $a\\in H^1(D)$, with $0<\\lambda \\le a\\le\n\\Lambda$ on $D$, and $f\\in L_\\infty(D)$ is strictly positive, then $$\n\\|a-b\\|_{L_2(D)}\\le C\\|u_a-u_b\\|_{H_0^1(D)}^{1/6}. $$ More generally, it is\nshown that the assumption $a\\in H^1(D)$ can be weakened to $a\\in H^s(D)$, for\ncertain $s<1$, at the expense of lowering the exponent $1/6$ to a value that\ndepends on $s$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper considers the Dirichlet problem $$ -\\mathrm{div}(a\\nabla u_a)=f\n\\quad \\hbox{on}\\,\\,\\ D, \\qquad u_a=0\\quad \\hbox{on}\\,\\,\\partial D, $$ for a\nLipschitz domain $D\\subset \\mathbb R^d$, where $a$ is a scalar diffusion\nfunction. Each iteration entails the\napproximation of an elliptic problems performed using adaptive finite element\nmethods. We prove that the overall method converges with the best possible rate\nand illustrate numerically our theoretical findings."}, "authors": [{"name": "Stefano Berrone"}, {"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Rob Stevenson"}, {"name": "Marco Verani"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Marco Verani"}, "author": "Marco Verani", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1712.09281v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1712.09281v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.8246v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.8246v1", "updated": "2014-07-31T00:41:18Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 7, 31, 0, 41, 18, 3, 212, 0], "published": "2014-07-31T00:41:18Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 7, 31, 0, 41, 18, 3, 212, 0], "title": "Exponential decay of reconstruction error from binary measurements of\n  sparse signals", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Exponential decay of reconstruction error from binary measurements of\n  sparse signals"}, "summary": "Binary measurements arise naturally in a variety of statistical and\nengineering applications. They may be inherent to the problem---e.g., in\ndetermining the relationship between genetics and the presence or absence of a\ndisease---or they may be a result of extreme quantization. In one-bit\ncompressed sensing it has recently been shown that the number of one-bit\nmeasurements required for signal estimation mirrors that of unquantized\ncompressed sensing. Indeed, $s$-sparse signals in $\\mathbb{R}^n$ can be\nestimated (up to normalization) from $\\Omega(s \\log (n/s))$ one-bit\nmeasurements. Nevertheless, controlling the precise accuracy of the error\nestimate remains an open challenge. In this paper, we focus on optimizing the\ndecay of the error as a function of the oversampling factor $\\lambda := m/(s\n\\log(n/s))$, where $m$ is the number of measurements. It is known that the\nerror in reconstructing sparse signals from standard one-bit measurements is\nbounded below by $\\Omega(\\lambda^{-1})$. Without adjusting the measurement\nprocedure, reducing this polynomial error decay rate is impossible. However, we\nshow that an adaptive choice of the thresholds used for quantization may lower\nthe error rate to $e^{-\\Omega(\\lambda)}$. This improves upon guarantees for\nother methods of adaptive thresholding as proposed in Sigma-Delta quantization.\nWe develop a general recursive strategy to achieve this exponential decay and\ntwo specific polynomial-time algorithms which fall into this framework, one\nbased on convex programming and one on hard thresholding. This work is inspired\nby the one-bit compressed sensing model, in which the engineer controls the\nmeasurement procedure. Nevertheless, the principle is extendable to signal\nreconstruction problems in a variety of binary statistical models as well as\nstatistical estimation problems like logistic regression.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Binary measurements arise naturally in a variety of statistical and\nengineering applications. They may be inherent to the problem---e.g., in\ndetermining the relationship between genetics and the presence or absence of a\ndisease---or they may be a result of extreme quantization. In one-bit\ncompressed sensing it has recently been shown that the number of one-bit\nmeasurements required for signal estimation mirrors that of unquantized\ncompressed sensing. Indeed, $s$-sparse signals in $\\mathbb{R}^n$ can be\nestimated (up to normalization) from $\\Omega(s \\log (n/s))$ one-bit\nmeasurements. Nevertheless, controlling the precise accuracy of the error\nestimate remains an open challenge. In this paper, we focus on optimizing the\ndecay of the error as a function of the oversampling factor $\\lambda := m/(s\n\\log(n/s))$, where $m$ is the number of measurements. It is known that the\nerror in reconstructing sparse signals from standard one-bit measurements is\nbounded below by $\\Omega(\\lambda^{-1})$. Without adjusting the measurement\nprocedure, reducing this polynomial error decay rate is impossible. However, we\nshow that an adaptive choice of the thresholds used for quantization may lower\nthe error rate to $e^{-\\Omega(\\lambda)}$. This improves upon guarantees for\nother methods of adaptive thresholding as proposed in Sigma-Delta quantization.\nWe develop a general recursive strategy to achieve this exponential decay and\ntwo specific polynomial-time algorithms which fall into this framework, one\nbased on convex programming and one on hard thresholding. This work is inspired\nby the one-bit compressed sensing model, in which the engineer controls the\nmeasurement procedure. Nevertheless, the principle is extendable to signal\nreconstruction problems in a variety of binary statistical models as well as\nstatistical estimation problems like logistic regression."}, "authors": [{"name": "Richard Baraniuk"}, {"name": "Simon Foucart"}, {"name": "Deanna Needell"}, {"name": "Yaniv Plan"}, {"name": "Mary Wootters"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Mary Wootters"}, "author": "Mary Wootters", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.8246v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1407.8246v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "cs.IT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "cs.IT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.IT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.ST", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "stat.TH", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "94A12, 60D05, 90C25", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.00035v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.00035v2", "updated": "2019-07-17T16:58:41Z", "updated_parsed": [2019, 7, 17, 16, 58, 41, 2, 198, 0], "published": "2017-06-30T20:05:27Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 6, 30, 20, 5, 27, 4, 181, 0], "title": "On the convergence analysis of a hybrid numerical method for\n  multicomponent transport in porous media", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "On the convergence analysis of a hybrid numerical method for\n  multicomponent transport in porous media"}, "summary": "In this article, the convergence of a hybrid numerical method introduced in\nDaripa and Dutta (J. Comput. Phys., 335:249-282, 2017) has been established.\nThis method integrates a discontinuous finite element method with a modified\nmethod of characteristics (MMOC) in combination with finite difference (FD)\nprocedures, and has been successfully applied to solve a coupled system of\nnonlinear equations that arises in multicomponent two-phase porous media flows.\nThe present convergence analysis is focused on the MMOC-FD procedure for a\nnonlinear system of transport equations. For this purpose, an analogous\nsingle-component system of transport equations has been considered and some key\nideas for possible extension to multicomponent systems have been briefly\ndiscussed. Error estimates have been obtained and these estimates have also\nbeen shown to be consistent with realistic numerical simulations of flows\narising in enhanced oil recovery processes.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this article, the convergence of a hybrid numerical method introduced in\nDaripa and Dutta (J. Comput. Phys., 335:249-282, 2017) has been established.\nThis method integrates a discontinuous finite element method with a modified\nmethod of characteristics (MMOC) in combination with finite difference (FD)\nprocedures, and has been successfully applied to solve a coupled system of\nnonlinear equations that arises in multicomponent two-phase porous media flows.\nThe present convergence analysis is focused on the MMOC-FD procedure for a\nnonlinear system of transport equations. For this purpose, an analogous\nsingle-component system of transport equations has been considered and some key\nideas for possible extension to multicomponent systems have been briefly\ndiscussed. Error estimates have been obtained and these estimates have also\nbeen shown to be consistent with realistic numerical simulations of flows\narising in enhanced oil recovery processes."}, "authors": [{"name": "Prabir Daripa"}, {"name": "Sourav Dutta"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Sourav Dutta"}, "author": "Sourav Dutta", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.apnum.2019.07.009", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apnum.2019.07.009", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.00035v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1707.00035v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "Updating previous version with accepted preprint", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65M12, 65M25, 65M06, 76S05", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.10721v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.10721v1", "updated": "2018-11-26T22:32:15Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 11, 26, 22, 32, 15, 0, 330, 0], "published": "2018-11-26T22:32:15Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 11, 26, 22, 32, 15, 0, 330, 0], "title": "Time-dependent injection strategies and interfacial stability in\n  multi-layer Hele-Shaw and porous media flows", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Time-dependent injection strategies and interfacial stability in\n  multi-layer Hele-Shaw and porous media flows"}, "summary": "We study the stability of multi-layer radial flows in porous media within the\nHele-Shaw model. We perform a linear stability analysis for radial flows\nconsisting of an arbitrary number of fluid layers with interfaces separating\nfluids of constant viscosity and with positive viscosity jump at each interface\nin the direction of flow. Several different time-dependent injection strategies\nare analyzed including the maximal injection rate that maintains a stable flow.\nWe find numerically that flows with more fluid layers can be stable with faster\ntime-dependent injection rates than comparable flows with fewer fluid layers.\nIn particular, the injection rate for a stable flow increases at a rate that is\nproportional to the number of interfaces to the two-thirds power for large\ntimes. Additionally, we show that in any multi-layer radial Hele-Shaw flow, if\nall of the interfaces are circular except for one perturbed interface then\nthere exists a time-dependent injection rate such that the circular interfaces\nremain circular as they propagate and the disturbance on the perturbed\ninterface decays.\n  The motion of the interfaces within linear theory is also investigated\nnumerically for the case of constant injection rates. It is found that: (i) A\ndisturbance of one interface can be transferred to the other interface(s); (ii)\nThe disturbances on the interfaces can develop either in phase or out of phase\nfrom any arbitrary initial disturbance; and (iii) The dynamics of the flow can\nchange dramatically with the addition of more interfaces.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study the stability of multi-layer radial flows in porous media within the\nHele-Shaw model. We perform a linear stability analysis for radial flows\nconsisting of an arbitrary number of fluid layers with interfaces separating\nfluids of constant viscosity and with positive viscosity jump at each interface\nin the direction of flow. Several different time-dependent injection strategies\nare analyzed including the maximal injection rate that maintains a stable flow.\nWe find numerically that flows with more fluid layers can be stable with faster\ntime-dependent injection rates than comparable flows with fewer fluid layers.\nIn particular, the injection rate for a stable flow increases at a rate that is\nproportional to the number of interfaces to the two-thirds power for large\ntimes. Additionally, we show that in any multi-layer radial Hele-Shaw flow, if\nall of the interfaces are circular except for one perturbed interface then\nthere exists a time-dependent injection rate such that the circular interfaces\nremain circular as they propagate and the disturbance on the perturbed\ninterface decays.\n  The motion of the interfaces within linear theory is also investigated\nnumerically for the case of constant injection rates. It is found that: (i) A\ndisturbance of one interface can be transferred to the other interface(s); (ii)\nThe disturbances on the interfaces can develop either in phase or out of phase\nfrom any arbitrary initial disturbance; and (iii) The dynamics of the flow can\nchange dramatically with the addition of more interfaces."}, "authors": [{"name": "Craig Gin"}, {"name": "Prabir Daripa"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Prabir Daripa"}, "author": "Prabir Daripa", "arxiv_comment": "25 pages, 13 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.10721v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1811.10721v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.flu-dyn", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.flu-dyn", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "76E17, 76S05", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1901.03754v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1901.03754v2", "updated": "2019-08-29T15:23:54Z", "updated_parsed": [2019, 8, 29, 15, 23, 54, 3, 241, 0], "published": "2019-01-11T21:46:58Z", "published_parsed": [2019, 1, 11, 21, 46, 58, 4, 11, 0], "title": "Stability Results on Radial Porous Media and Hele-Shaw Flows with\n  Variable Viscosity Between Two Moving Interfaces", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Stability Results on Radial Porous Media and Hele-Shaw Flows with\n  Variable Viscosity Between Two Moving Interfaces"}, "summary": "We perform a linear stability analysis of three-layer radial porous media and\nHele-Shaw flows with variable viscosity in the middle layer. A nonlinear change\nof variables results in an eigenvalue problem that has time-dependent\ncoefficients and eigenvalue-dependent boundary conditions. We study this\neigenvalue problem and find upper bounds on the spectrum. We also give a\ncharacterization of the eigenvalues and prescribe a measure for which the\neigenfunctions are complete in the corresponding $L^2$ space. The limit as the\nviscous gradient goes to zero is compared with previous results on multi-layer\nradial flows. We then numerically compute the eigenvalues and obtain, among\nother results, optimal profiles within certain classes of functions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We perform a linear stability analysis of three-layer radial porous media and\nHele-Shaw flows with variable viscosity in the middle layer. A nonlinear change\nof variables results in an eigenvalue problem that has time-dependent\ncoefficients and eigenvalue-dependent boundary conditions. We study this\neigenvalue problem and find upper bounds on the spectrum. We also give a\ncharacterization of the eigenvalues and prescribe a measure for which the\neigenfunctions are complete in the corresponding $L^2$ space. The limit as the\nviscous gradient goes to zero is compared with previous results on multi-layer\nradial flows. We then numerically compute the eigenvalues and obtain, among\nother results, optimal profiles within certain classes of functions."}, "authors": [{"name": "Craig Gin"}, {"name": "Prabir Daripa"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Prabir Daripa"}, "author": "Prabir Daripa", "arxiv_comment": "21 pages, 10 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1901.03754v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1901.03754v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.flu-dyn", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.flu-dyn", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "76E17, 76S05, 34L10, 34L15, 34L16", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.00380v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.00380v1", "updated": "2015-02-02T07:07:21Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 2, 2, 7, 7, 21, 0, 33, 0], "published": "2015-02-02T07:07:21Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 2, 2, 7, 7, 21, 0, 33, 0], "title": "On a three-layer Hele-Shaw model of enhanced oil recovery with a linear\n  viscous profile", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "On a three-layer Hele-Shaw model of enhanced oil recovery with a linear\n  viscous profile"}, "summary": "We present a non-standard eigenvalue problem that arises in the linear\nstability of a three-layer Hele-Shaw model of enhanced oil recovery. A\nnonlinear transformation is introduced which allows reformulation of the\nnon-standard eigenvalue problem as a boundary value problem for Kummer's\nequation when the viscous profile of the middle layer is linear. Using the\nexisting body of works on Kummer's equation, we construct an exact solution of\nthe eigenvalue problem and provide the dispersion relation implicitly through\nthe existence criterion for the non-trivial solution. We also discuss the\nconvergence of the series solution. It is shown that this solution reduces to\nthe physically relevant solutions in two asymptotic limits: (i) when the linear\nviscous profile approaches a constant viscous profile; or (ii) when the length\nof the middle layer approaches zero.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We present a non-standard eigenvalue problem that arises in the linear\nstability of a three-layer Hele-Shaw model of enhanced oil recovery. A\nnonlinear transformation is introduced which allows reformulation of the\nnon-standard eigenvalue problem as a boundary value problem for Kummer's\nequation when the viscous profile of the middle layer is linear. Using the\nexisting body of works on Kummer's equation, we construct an exact solution of\nthe eigenvalue problem and provide the dispersion relation implicitly through\nthe existence criterion for the non-trivial solution. We also discuss the\nconvergence of the series solution. It is shown that this solution reduces to\nthe physically relevant solutions in two asymptotic limits: (i) when the linear\nviscous profile approaches a constant viscous profile; or (ii) when the length\nof the middle layer approaches zero."}, "authors": [{"name": "Prabir Daripa"}, {"name": "Oscar Orellana"}, {"name": "Rodrigo Meneses"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Rodrigo Meneses"}, "author": "Rodrigo Meneses", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.00380v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1502.00380v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.flu-dyn", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.flu-dyn", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.06342v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.06342v3", "updated": "2016-08-05T09:52:07Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 8, 5, 9, 52, 7, 4, 218, 0], "published": "2016-02-19T22:59:27Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 2, 19, 22, 59, 27, 4, 50, 0], "title": "Data Assimilation and Sampling in Banach spaces", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Data Assimilation and Sampling in Banach spaces"}, "summary": "This paper studies the problem of approximating a function $f$ in a Banach\nspace $X$ from measurements $l_j(f)$, $j=1,\\dots,m$, where the $l_j$ are linear\nfunctionals from $X^*$. Most results study this problem for classical Banach\nspaces $X$ such as the $L_p$ spaces, $1\\le p\\le \\infty$, and for $K$ the unit\nball of a smoothness space in $X$. Our interest in this paper is in the model\nclasses $K=K(\\epsilon,V)$, with $\\epsilon>0$ and $V$ a finite dimensional\nsubspace of $X$, which consists of all $f\\in X$ such that $dist(f,V)_X\\le\n\\epsilon$. These model classes, called {\\it approximation sets}, arise\nnaturally in application domains such as parametric partial differential\nequations, uncertainty quantification, and signal processing.\n  A general theory for the recovery of approximation sets in a Banach space is\ngiven. This theory includes tight a priori bounds on optimal performance, and\nalgorithms for finding near optimal approximations. We show how the recovery\nproblem for approximation sets is connected with well-studied concepts in\nBanach space theory such as liftings and the angle between spaces. Examples are\ngiven that show how this theory can be used to recover several recent results\non sampling and data assimilation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper studies the problem of approximating a function $f$ in a Banach\nspace $X$ from measurements $l_j(f)$, $j=1,\\dots,m$, where the $l_j$ are linear\nfunctionals from $X^*$. Most results study this problem for classical Banach\nspaces $X$ such as the $L_p$ spaces, $1\\le p\\le \\infty$, and for $K$ the unit\nball of a smoothness space in $X$. Our interest in this paper is in the model\nclasses $K=K(\\epsilon,V)$, with $\\epsilon>0$ and $V$ a finite dimensional\nsubspace of $X$, which consists of all $f\\in X$ such that $dist(f,V)_X\\le\n\\epsilon$. These model classes, called {\\it approximation sets}, arise\nnaturally in application domains such as parametric partial differential\nequations, uncertainty quantification, and signal processing.\n  A general theory for the recovery of approximation sets in a Banach space is\ngiven. This theory includes tight a priori bounds on optimal performance, and\nalgorithms for finding near optimal approximations. We show how the recovery\nproblem for approximation sets is connected with well-studied concepts in\nBanach space theory such as liftings and the angle between spaces. Examples are\ngiven that show how this theory can be used to recover several recent results\non sampling and data assimilation."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, {"name": "Guergana Petrova"}, {"name": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk"}, "author": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.06342v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.06342v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1509.07050v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1509.07050v1", "updated": "2015-09-23T16:19:40Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 9, 23, 16, 19, 40, 2, 266, 0], "published": "2015-09-23T16:19:40Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 9, 23, 16, 19, 40, 2, 266, 0], "title": "Sparse polynomial approximation of parametric elliptic PDEs. Part II:\n  lognormal coefficients", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Sparse polynomial approximation of parametric elliptic PDEs. Part II:\n  lognormal coefficients"}, "summary": "Elliptic partial differential equations with diffusion coefficients of\nlognormal form, that is $a=exp(b)$, where $b$ is a Gaussian random field, are\nconsidered. We study the $\\ell^p$ summability properties of the Hermite\npolynomial expansion of the solution in terms of the countably many scalar\nparameters appearing in a given representation of $b$. These summability\nresults have direct consequences on the approximation rates of best $n$-term\ntruncated Hermite expansions. Our results significantly improve on the state of\nthe art estimates available for this problem. In particular, they take into\naccount the support properties of the basis functions involved in the\nrepresentation of $b$, in addition to the size of these functions. One\ninteresting conclusion from our analysis is that in certain relevant cases, the\nKarhunen-Lo\\`eve representation of $b$ may not be the best choice concerning\nthe resulting sparsity and approximability of the Hermite expansion.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Elliptic partial differential equations with diffusion coefficients of\nlognormal form, that is $a=exp(b)$, where $b$ is a Gaussian random field, are\nconsidered. We study the $\\ell^p$ summability properties of the Hermite\npolynomial expansion of the solution in terms of the countably many scalar\nparameters appearing in a given representation of $b$. These summability\nresults have direct consequences on the approximation rates of best $n$-term\ntruncated Hermite expansions. Our results significantly improve on the state of\nthe art estimates available for this problem. In particular, they take into\naccount the support properties of the basis functions involved in the\nrepresentation of $b$, in addition to the size of these functions. One\ninteresting conclusion from our analysis is that in certain relevant cases, the\nKarhunen-Lo\\`eve representation of $b$ may not be the best choice concerning\nthe resulting sparsity and approximability of the Hermite expansion."}, "authors": [{"name": "Markus Bachmayr"}, {"name": "Albert Cohen"}, {"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, {"name": "Giovanni Migliorati"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Giovanni Migliorati"}, "author": "Giovanni Migliorati", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1509.07050v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1509.07050v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.09907v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.09907v1", "updated": "2020-09-21T14:26:40Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 9, 21, 14, 26, 40, 0, 265, 0], "published": "2020-09-21T14:26:40Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 9, 21, 14, 26, 40, 0, 265, 0], "title": "Optimal Stable Nonlinear Approximation", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Optimal Stable Nonlinear Approximation"}, "summary": "While it is well known that nonlinear methods of approximation can often\nperform dramatically better than linear methods, there are still questions on\nhow to measure the optimal performance possible for such methods. This paper\nstudies nonlinear methods of approximation that are compatible with numerical\nimplementation in that they are required to be numerically stable. A measure of\noptimal performance, called {\\em stable manifold widths}, for approximating a\nmodel class $K$ in a Banach space $X$ by stable manifold methods is introduced.\nFundamental inequalities between these stable manifold widths and the entropy\nof $K$ are established. The effects of requiring stability in the settings of\ndeep learning and compressed sensing are discussed.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "While it is well known that nonlinear methods of approximation can often\nperform dramatically better than linear methods, there are still questions on\nhow to measure the optimal performance possible for such methods. This paper\nstudies nonlinear methods of approximation that are compatible with numerical\nimplementation in that they are required to be numerically stable. A measure of\noptimal performance, called {\\em stable manifold widths}, for approximating a\nmodel class $K$ in a Banach space $X$ by stable manifold methods is introduced.\nFundamental inequalities between these stable manifold widths and the entropy\nof $K$ are established. The effects of requiring stability in the settings of\ndeep learning and compressed sensing are discussed."}, "authors": [{"name": "Albert Cohen"}, {"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, {"name": "Guergana Petrova"}, {"name": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk"}, "author": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.09907v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2009.09907v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.06797v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.06797v2", "updated": "2015-03-03T14:09:11Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 3, 3, 14, 9, 11, 1, 62, 0], "published": "2015-02-24T13:10:32Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 2, 24, 13, 10, 32, 1, 55, 0], "title": "Approximation of high-dimensional parametric PDEs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Approximation of high-dimensional parametric PDEs"}, "summary": "Parametrized families of PDEs arise in various contexts such as inverse\nproblems, control and optimization, risk assessment, and uncertainty\nquantification. In most of these applications, the number of parameters is\nlarge or perhaps even infinite. Thus, the development of numerical methods for\nthese parametric problems is faced with the possible curse of dimensionality.\nThis article is directed at (i) identifying and understanding which properties\nof parametric equations allow one to avoid this curse and (ii) developing and\nanalyzing effective numerical methodd which fully exploit these properties and,\nin turn, are immune to the growth in dimensionality. The first part of this\narticle studies the smoothness and approximability of the solution map, that\nis, the map $a\\mapsto u(a)$ where $a$ is the parameter value and $u(a)$ is the\ncorresponding solution to the PDE. It is shown that for many relevant\nparametric PDEs, the parametric smoothness of this map is typically holomorphic\nand also highly anisotropic in that the relevant parameters are of widely\nvarying importance in describing the solution. These two properties are then\nexploited to establish convergence rates of $n$-term approximations to the\nsolution map for which each term is separable in the parametric and physical\nvariables. These results reveal that, at least on a theoretical level, the\nsolution map can be well approximated by discretizations of moderate\ncomplexity, thereby showing how the curse of dimensionality is broken. This\ntheoretical analysis is carried out through concepts of approximation theory\nsuch as best $n$-term approximation, sparsity, and $n$-widths. These notions\ndetermine a priori the best possible performance of numerical methods and thus\nserve as a benchmark for concrete algorithms. The second part of this article\nturns to the development of numerical algorithms based on the theoretically\nestablished sparse separable approximations. The numerical methods studied fall\ninto two general categories. The first uses polynomial expansions in terms of\nthe parameters to approximate the solution map. The second one searches for\nsuitable low dimensional spaces for simultaneously approximating all members of\nthe parametric family. The numerical implementation of these approaches is\ncarried out through adaptive and greedy algorithms. An a priori analysis of the\nperformance of these algorithms establishes how well they meet the theoretical\nbenchmarks.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Parametrized families of PDEs arise in various contexts such as inverse\nproblems, control and optimization, risk assessment, and uncertainty\nquantification. In most of these applications, the number of parameters is\nlarge or perhaps even infinite. Thus, the development of numerical methods for\nthese parametric problems is faced with the possible curse of dimensionality.\nThis article is directed at (i) identifying and understanding which properties\nof parametric equations allow one to avoid this curse and (ii) developing and\nanalyzing effective numerical methodd which fully exploit these properties and,\nin turn, are immune to the growth in dimensionality. The first part of this\narticle studies the smoothness and approximability of the solution map, that\nis, the map $a\\mapsto u(a)$ where $a$ is the parameter value and $u(a)$ is the\ncorresponding solution to the PDE. It is shown that for many relevant\nparametric PDEs, the parametric smoothness of this map is typically holomorphic\nand also highly anisotropic in that the relevant parameters are of widely\nvarying importance in describing the solution. These two properties are then\nexploited to establish convergence rates of $n$-term approximations to the\nsolution map for which each term is separable in the parametric and physical\nvariables. These results reveal that, at least on a theoretical level, the\nsolution map can be well approximated by discretizations of moderate\ncomplexity, thereby showing how the curse of dimensionality is broken. This\ntheoretical analysis is carried out through concepts of approximation theory\nsuch as best $n$-term approximation, sparsity, and $n$-widths. These notions\ndetermine a priori the best possible performance of numerical methods and thus\nserve as a benchmark for concrete algorithms. The second part of this article\nturns to the development of numerical algorithms based on the theoretically\nestablished sparse separable approximations. The numerical methods studied fall\ninto two general categories. The first uses polynomial expansions in terms of\nthe parameters to approximate the solution map. The second one searches for\nsuitable low dimensional spaces for simultaneously approximating all members of\nthe parametric family. The numerical implementation of these approaches is\ncarried out through adaptive and greedy algorithms. An a priori analysis of the\nperformance of these algorithms establishes how well they meet the theoretical\nbenchmarks."}, "authors": [{"name": "Albert Cohen"}, {"name": "Ronald Devore"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Ronald Devore"}, "arxiv_affiliation": "TAMU", "author": "Ronald Devore", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.06797v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1502.06797v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.06795v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.06795v1", "updated": "2015-02-24T13:09:35Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 2, 24, 13, 9, 35, 1, 55, 0], "published": "2015-02-24T13:09:35Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 2, 24, 13, 9, 35, 1, 55, 0], "title": "Kolmogorov widths under holomorphic mappings", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Kolmogorov widths under holomorphic mappings"}, "summary": "If $L$ is a bounded linear operator mapping the Banach space $X$ into the\nBanach space $Y$ and $K$ is a compact set in $X$, then the Kolmogorov widths of\nthe image $L(K)$ do not exceed those of $K$ multiplied by the norm of $L$. We\nextend this result from linear maps to holomorphic mappings $u$ from $X$ to $Y$\nin the following sense: when the $n$ widths of $K$ are $O(n^{-r})$ for some\n$r\\textgreater{}1$, then those of $u(K)$ are $O(n^{-s})$ for any $s \\textless{}\nr-1$, We then use these results to prove various theorems about Kolmogorov\nwidths of manifolds consisting of solutions to certain parametrized PDEs.\nResults of this type are important in the numerical analysis of reduced bases\nand other reduced modeling methods, since the best possible performance of such\nmethods is governed by the rate of decay of the Kolmogorov widths of the\nsolution manifold.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "If $L$ is a bounded linear operator mapping the Banach space $X$ into the\nBanach space $Y$ and $K$ is a compact set in $X$, then the Kolmogorov widths of\nthe image $L(K)$ do not exceed those of $K$ multiplied by the norm of $L$. We\nextend this result from linear maps to holomorphic mappings $u$ from $X$ to $Y$\nin the following sense: when the $n$ widths of $K$ are $O(n^{-r})$ for some\n$r\\textgreater{}1$, then those of $u(K)$ are $O(n^{-s})$ for any $s \\textless{}\nr-1$, We then use these results to prove various theorems about Kolmogorov\nwidths of manifolds consisting of solutions to certain parametrized PDEs.\nResults of this type are important in the numerical analysis of reduced bases\nand other reduced modeling methods, since the best possible performance of such\nmethods is governed by the rate of decay of the Kolmogorov widths of the\nsolution manifold."}, "authors": [{"name": "Albert Cohen"}, {"name": "Ronald Devore"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Ronald Devore"}, "arxiv_affiliation": 211, 0], "published": "2013-01-15T02:21:49Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 1, 15, 2, 21, 49, 1, 15, 0], "title": "Adaptive Finite Element Methods for Elliptic Problems with Discontinuous\n  Coefficients", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Adaptive Finite Element Methods for Elliptic Problems with Discontinuous\n  Coefficients"}, "summary": "Elliptic partial differential equations (PDEs) with discontinuous diffusion\ncoefficients occur in application domains such as diffusions through porous\nmedia, electro-magnetic field propagation on heterogeneous media, and diffusion\nprocesses on rough surfaces. The standard approach to numerically treating such\nproblems using finite element methods is to assume that the discontinuities lie\non the boundaries of the cells in the initial triangulation. However, this does\nnot match applications where discontinuities occur on curves, surfaces, or\nmanifolds, and could even be unknown beforehand. One of the obstacles to\ntreating such discontinuity problems is that the usual perturbation theory for\nelliptic PDEs assumes bounds for the distortion of the coefficients in the\n$L_\\infty$ norm and this in turn requires that the discontinuities are matched\nexactly when the coefficients are approximated. We present a new approach based\non distortion of the coefficients in an $L_q$ norm with $q<\\infty$ which\ntherefore does not require the exact matching of the discontinuities. We then\nuse this new distortion theory to formulate new adaptive finite element methods\n(AFEMs) for such discontinuity problems. We show that such AFEMs are optimal in\nthe sense of distortion versus number of computations, and report insightful\nnumerical results supporting our analysis.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Elliptic partial differential equations (PDEs) with discontinuous diffusion\ncoefficients occur in application domains such as diffusions through porous\nmedia, electro-magnetic field propagation on heterogeneous media, and diffusion\nprocesses on rough surfaces. The standard approach to numerically treating such\nproblems using finite element methods is to assume that the discontinuities lie\non the boundaries of the cells in the initial triangulation. However, this does\nnot match applications where discontinuities occur on curves, surfaces, or\nmanifolds, and could even be unknown beforehand. One of the obstacles to\ntreating such discontinuity problems is that the usual perturbation theory for\nelliptic PDEs assumes bounds for the distortion of the coefficients in the\n$L_\\infty$ norm and this in turn requires that the discontinuities are matched\nexactly when the coefficients are approximated. We present a new approach based\non distortion of the coefficients in an $L_q$ norm with $q<\\infty$ which\ntherefore does not require the exact matching of the discontinuities. We then\nuse this new distortion theory to formulate new adaptive finite element methods\n(AFEMs) for such discontinuity problems. We show that such AFEMs are optimal in\nthe sense of distortion versus number of computations, and report insightful\nnumerical results supporting our analysis."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Ronald A.
