This paper\nstudies nonlinear methods of approximation that are compatible with numerical\nimplementation in that they are required to be numerically stable. A measure of\noptimal performance, called {\\em stable manifold widths}, for approximating a\nmodel class $K$ in a Banach space $X$ by stable manifold methods is introduced.\nFundamental inequalities between these stable manifold widths and the entropy\nof $K$ are established. The effects of requiring stability in the settings of\ndeep learning and compressed sensing are discussed."}, "authors": [{"name": "Albert Cohen"}, {"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, {"name": "Guergana Petrova"}, {"name": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk"}, "author": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.09907v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2009.09907v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1905.02199v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1905.02199v1", "updated": "2019-05-05T12:54:35Z", "updated_parsed": [2019, 5, 5, 12, 54, 35, 6, 125, 0], "published": "2019-05-05T12:54:35Z", "published_parsed": [2019, 5, 5, 12, 54, 35, 6, 125, 0], "title": "Nonlinear Approximation and (Deep) ReLU Networks", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Nonlinear Approximation and (Deep) ReLU Networks"}, "summary": "This article is concerned with the approximation and expressive powers of\ndeep neural networks. This is an active research area currently producing many\ninteresting papers. The results most commonly found in the literature prove\nthat neural networks approximate functions with classical smoothness to the\nsame accuracy as classical linear methods of approximation, e.g. approximation\nby polynomials or by piecewise polynomials on prescribed partitions. However,\napproximation by neural networks depending on n parameters is a form of\nnonlinear approximation and as such should be compared with other nonlinear\nmethods such as variable knot splines or n-term approximation from\ndictionaries. The performance of neural networks in targeted applications such\nas machine learning indicate that they actually possess even greater\napproximation power than these traditional methods of nonlinear approximation.\nThe main results of this article prove that this is indeed the case. This is\ndone by exhibiting large classes of functions which can be efficiently captured\nby neural networks where classical nonlinear methods fall short of the task.\nThe present article purposefully limits itself to studying the approximation of\nunivariate functions by ReLU networks. Many generalizations to functions of\nseveral variables and other activation functions can be envisioned. However,\neven in this simplest of settings considered here, a theory that completely\nquantifies the approximation power of neural networks is still lacking.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This article is concerned with the approximation and expressive powers of\ndeep neural networks. This is an active research area currently producing many\ninteresting papers. The results most commonly found in the literature prove\nthat neural networks approximate functions with classical smoothness to the\nsame accuracy as classical linear methods of approximation, e.g. approximation\nby polynomials or by piecewise polynomials on prescribed partitions. However,\napproximation by neural networks depending on n parameters is a form of\nnonlinear approximation and as such should be compared with other nonlinear\nmethods such as variable knot splines or n-term approximation from\ndictionaries. The performance of neural networks in targeted applications such\nas machine learning indicate that they actually possess even greater\napproximation power than these traditional methods of nonlinear approximation.\nThe main results of this article prove that this is indeed the case. This is\ndone by exhibiting large classes of functions which can be efficiently captured\nby neural networks where classical nonlinear methods fall short of the task.\nThe present article purposefully limits itself to studying the approximation of\nunivariate functions by ReLU networks. Many generalizations to functions of\nseveral variables and other activation functions can be envisioned. However,\neven in this simplest of settings considered here, a theory that completely\nquantifies the approximation power of neural networks is still lacking."}, "authors": [{"name": "I. Daubechies"}, {"name": "R. DeVore"}, {"name": "S. Foucart"}, {"name": "B. Hanin"}, {"name": "G. Petrova"}], "author_detail": {"name": "G. Petrova"}, "author": "G. Petrova", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1905.02199v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1905.02199v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "cs.LG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "cs.LG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "41A25, 41A30, 41A46, 68T99, 82C32, 92B20,", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1401.0334v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1401.0334v1", "updated": "2014-01-01T21:14:10Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 1, 1, 21, 14, 10, 2, 1, 0], "published": "2014-01-01T21:14:10Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 1, 1, 21, 14, 10, 2, 1, 0], "title": "Convex optimization on Banach Spaces", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Convex optimization on Banach Spaces"}, "summary": "Greedy algorithms which use only function evaluations are applied to convex\noptimization in a general Banach space $X$. Along with algorithms that use\nexact evaluations, algorithms with approximate evaluations are treated. A\npriori upper bounds for the convergence rate of the proposed algorithms are\ngiven. These bounds depend on the smoothness of the objective function and the\nsparsity or compressibility (with respect to a given dictionary) of a point in\n$X$ where the minimum is attained.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Greedy algorithms which use only function evaluations are applied to convex\noptimization in a general Banach space $X$. Along with algorithms that use\nexact evaluations, algorithms with approximate evaluations are treated. A\npriori upper bounds for the convergence rate of the proposed algorithms are\ngiven. These bounds depend on the smoothness of the objective function and the\nsparsity or compressibility (with respect to a given dictionary) of a point in\n$X$ where the minimum is attained."}, "authors": [{"name": "R. A. DeVore"}, {"name": "V. N. Temlyakov"}], "author_detail": {"name": "V. N. Temlyakov"}, "author": "V. N. For a fixed $f$, we discuss under which conditions is $a$ uniquely\ndetermined and when can $a$ be stably recovered from the knowledge of $u_a$.\n  A first result is that whenever $a\\in H^1(D)$, with $0<\\lambda \\le a\\le\n\\Lambda$ on $D$, and $f\\in L_\\infty(D)$ is strictly positive, then $$\n\\|a-b\\|_{L_2(D)}\\le C\\|u_a-u_b\\|_{H_0^1(D)}^{1/6}. $$ More generally, it is\nshown that the assumption $a\\in H^1(D)$ can be weakened to $a\\in H^s(D)$, for\ncertain $s<1$, at the expense of lowering the exponent $1/6$ to a value that\ndepends on $s$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper considers the Dirichlet problem $$ -\\mathrm{div}(a\\nabla u_a)=f\n\\quad \\hbox{on}\\,\\,\\ D, \\qquad u_a=0\\quad \\hbox{on}\\,\\,\\partial D, $$ for a\nLipschitz domain $D\\subset \\mathbb R^d$, where $a$ is a scalar diffusion\nfunction. For a fixed $f$, we discuss under which conditions is $a$ uniquely\ndetermined and when can $a$ be stably recovered from the knowledge of $u_a$.\n  A first result is that whenever $a\\in H^1(D)$, with $0<\\lambda \\le a\\le\n\\Lambda$ on $D$, and $f\\in L_\\infty(D)$ is strictly positive, then $$\n\\|a-b\\|_{L_2(D)}\\le C\\|u_a-u_b\\|_{H_0^1(D)}^{1/6}. $$ More generally, it is\nshown that the "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.6208v1", "updated": "2014-07-23T13:35:14Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 7, 23, 13, 35, 14, 2, 204, 0], "published": "2014-07-23T13:35:14Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 7, 23, 13, 35, 14, 2, 204, 0], "title": "Tensor-Sparsity of Solutions to High-Dimensional Elliptic Partial\n  Differential Equations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Tensor-Sparsity of Solutions to High-Dimensional Elliptic Partial\n  Differential Equations"}, "summary": "A recurring theme in attempts to break the curse of dimensionality in the\nnumerical approximations of solutions to high-dimensional partial differential\nequations (PDEs) is to employ some form of sparse tensor approximation.\nUnfortunately, there are only a few results that quantify the possible\nadvantages of such an approach. This paper introduces a class $\\Sigma_n$ of\nfunctions, which can be written as a sum of rank-one tensors using a total of\nat most $n$ parameters and then uses this notion of sparsity to prove a\nregularity theorem for certain high-dimensional elliptic PDEs. It is shown,\namong other results, that whenever the right-hand side $f$ of the elliptic PDE\ncan be approximated with a certain rate $\\mathcal{O}(n^{-r})$ in the norm of\n${\\mathrm H}^{-1}$ by elements of $\\Sigma_n$, then the solution $u$ can be\napproximated in ${\\mathrm H}^1$ from $\\Sigma_n$ to accuracy\n$\\mathcal{O}(n^{-r'})$ for any $r'\\in (0,r)$. Since these results require\nknowledge of the eigenbasis of the elliptic operator considered, we propose a\nsecond \"basis-free\" model of tensor sparsity and prove a regularity theorem for\nthis second sparsity model as well. We then proceed to address the important\nquestion of the extent such regularity theorems translate into results on\ncomputational complexity. It is shown how this second model can be used to\nderive computational algorithms with performance that breaks the curse of\ndimensionality on certain model high-dimensional elliptic PDEs with\ntensor-sparse data.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A recurring theme in attempts to break the curse of dimensionality in the\nnumerical approximations of solutions to high-dimensional partial differential\nequations (PDEs) is to employ some form of sparse tensor approximation.\nUnfortunately, there are only a few results that quantify the possible\nadvantages of such an approach. This paper introduces a class $\\Sigma_n$ of\nfunctions, which can be written as a sum of rank-one tensors using a total of\nat most $n$ parameters and then uses this notion of sparsity to prove a\nregularity theorem for certain high-dimensional elliptic PDEs. It is shown,\namong other results, that whenever the right-hand side $f$ of the elliptic PDE\ncan be approximated with a certain rate $\\mathcal{O}(n^{-r})$ in the norm of\n${\\mathrm H}^{-1}$ by elements of $\\Sigma_n$, then the solution $u$ can be\napproximated in ${\\mathrm H}^1$ from $\\Sigma_n$ to accuracy\n$\\mathcal{O}(n^{-r'})$ for any $r'\\in (0,r)$. Since these results require\nknowledge of the eigenbasis of the elliptic operator considered, we propose a\nsecond \"basis-free\" model of tensor sparsity and prove a regularity theorem for\nthis second sparsity model as well. We then proceed to address the important\nquestion of the extent such regularity theorems translate into results on\ncomputational complexity. It is shown how this second model can be used to\nderive computational algorithms with performance that breaks the curse of\ndimensionality on certain model high-dimensional elliptic PDEs with\ntensor-sparse data."}, "authors": [{"name": "Wolfgang Dahmen"}, {"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, {"name": "Lars Grasedyck"}, {"name": "Endre S\u00fcli"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Endre S\u00fcli"}, "author": "Endre S\u00fcli", "arxiv_comment": "41 pages, 1 figure", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.6208v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1407.6208v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35J25, 41A25, 41A63, 41A46, 65D99", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0802.2517v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0802.2517v1", "updated": "2008-02-18T18:52:55Z", "updated_parsed": [2008, 2, 18, 18, 52, 55, 0, 49, 0], "published": "2008-02-18T18:52:55Z", "published_parsed": [2008, 2, 18, 18, 52, 55, 0, 49, 0], "title": "Approximation using scattered shifts of a multivariate function", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Approximation using scattered shifts of a multivariate function"}, "summary": "The approximation of a general $d$-variate function $f$ by the shifts\n$\\phi(\\cdot-\\xi)$, $\\xi\\in\\Xi\\subset \\Rd$, of a fixed function $\\phi$ occurs in\nmany applications such as data fitting, neural networks, and learning theory.\nWhen $\\Xi=h\\Z^d$ is a dilate of the integer lattice, there is a rather complete\nunderstanding of the approximation problem \\cite{BDR,Johnson1} using Fourier\ntechniques. However, in most applications the {\\it center} set $\\Xi$ is either\ngiven, or can be chosen with complete freedom. In both of these cases, the\nshift-invariant setting is too restrictive. This paper studies the\napproximation problem in the case $\\Xi$ is arbitrary. It establishes\napproximation theorems whose error bounds reflect the local density of the\npoints in $\\Xi$. Two different settings are analyzed. The first is when the set\n$\\Xi$ is prescribed in advance. In this case, the theorems of this paper show\nthat, in analogy with the classical univariate spline approximation, improved\napproximation occurs in regions where the density is high. The second setting\ncorresponds to the problem of non-linear approximation. In that setting the set\n$\\Xi$ can be chosen using information about the target function $f$. We discuss\nhow to `best' make these choices and give estimates for the approximation\nerror.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The approximation of a general $d$-variate function $f$ by the shifts\n$\\phi(\\cdot-\\xi)$, $\\xi\\in\\Xi\\subset \\Rd$, of a fixed function $\\phi$ occurs in\nmany applications such as data fitting, neural networks, and learning theory.\nWhen $\\Xi=h\\Z^d$ is a dilate of the integer lattice, there is a rather complete\nunderstanding of the approximation problem \\cite{BDR,Johnson1} using Fourier\ntechniques. However, in most applications the {\\it center} set $\\Xi$ is either\ngiven, or can be chosen with complete freedom. In both of these cases, the\nshift-invariant setting is too restrictive. This paper studies the\napproximation problem in the case $\\Xi$ is arbitrary. It establishes\napproximation theorems whose error bounds reflect the local density of the\npoints in $\\Xi$. Two different settings are analyzed. The first is when the set\n$\\Xi$ is prescribed in advance. In this case, the theorems of this paper show\nthat, in analogy with the classical univariate spline approximation, improved\napproximation occurs in regions where the density is high. The second setting\ncorresponds to the problem of non-linear approximation. In that setting the set\n$\\Xi$ can be chosen using information about the target function $f$. We discuss\nhow to `best' make these choices and give estimates for the approximation\nerror."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, {"name": "Amos Ron"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Amos Ron"}, "author": "Amos Ron", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0802.2517v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0802.2517v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1411.0839v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1411.0839v1", "updated": "2014-11-04T09:55:40Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 11, 4, 9, 55, 40, 1, 308, 0], "published": "2014-11-04T09:55:40Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 11, 4, 9, 55, 40, 1, 308, 0], "title": "Classification algorithms using adaptive partitioning", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Classification algorithms using adaptive partitioning"}, "summary": "Algorithms for binary classification based on adaptive tree partitioning are\nformulated and analyzed for both their risk performance and their friendliness\nto numerical implementation. The algorithms can be viewed as generating a set\napproximation to the Bayes set and thus fall into the general category of set\nestimators. In contrast with the most studied tree-based algorithms, which\nutilize piecewise constant approximation on the generated partition [IEEE\nTrans. Inform. Theory 52 (2006) 1335-1353; Mach. Learn. 66 (2007) 209-242], we\nconsider decorated trees, which allow us to derive higher order methods.\nConvergence rates for these methods are derived in terms the parameter $\\alpha$\nof margin conditions and a rate $s$ of best approximation of the Bayes set by\ndecorated adaptive partitions. They can also be expressed in terms of the Besov\nsmoothness $\\beta$ of the regression function that governs its approximability\nby piecewise polynomials on adaptive partition. The execution of the algorithms\ndoes not require knowledge of the smoothness or margin conditions. Besov\nsmoothness conditions are weaker than the commonly used H\\\"{o}lder conditions,\nwhich govern approximation by nonadaptive partitions, and therefore for a given\nregression function can result in a higher rate of convergence. This in turn\nmitigates the compatibility conflict between smoothness and margin parameters.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Algorithms for binary classification based on adaptive tree partitioning are\nformulated and analyzed for both their risk performance and their friendliness\nto numerical implementation. The algorithms can be viewed as generating a set\napproximation to the Bayes set and thus fall into the general category of set\nestimators. In contrast with the most studied tree-based algorithms, which\nutilize piecewise constant approximation on the generated partition [IEEE\nTrans. Inform. Theory 52 (2006) 1335-1353; Mach. Learn. 66 (2007) 209-242], we\nconsider decorated trees, which allow us to derive higher order methods.\nConvergence rates for these methods are derived in terms the parameter $\\alpha$\nof margin conditions and a rate $s$ of best approximation of the Bayes set by\ndecorated adaptive partitions. They can also be expressed in terms of the Besov\nsmoothness $\\beta$ of the regression function that governs its approximability\nby piecewise polynomials on adaptive partition. The execution of the algorithms\ndoes not require knowledge of the smoothness or margin conditions. Besov\nsmoothness conditions are weaker than the commonly used H\\\"{o}lder conditions,\nwhich govern approximation by nonadaptive partitions, and therefore for a given\nregression function can result in a higher rate of convergence. This in turn\nmitigates the compatibility conflict between smoothness and margin parameters."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Binev"}, {"name": "Albert Cohen"}, {"name": "Wolfgang Dahmen"}, {"name": "Ronald DeVore"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, "author": "Ronald DeVore", "arxiv_doi": "10.1214/14-AOS1234", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1214/14-AOS1234", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1411.0839v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1411.0839v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "Published in at http://dx.doi.org/10.1214/14-AOS1234 the Annals of\n  Statistics (http://www.imstat.org/aos/) by the Institute of Mathematical\n  Statistics (http://www.imstat.org)", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Annals of Statistics 2014, Vol. 42, No. 6, 2141-2163", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.ST", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.ST", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "stat.TH", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0803.1718v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0803.1718v1", "updated": "2008-03-12T08:12:38Z", "updated_parsed": [2008, 3, 12, 8, 12, 38, 2, 72, 0], "published": "2008-03-12T08:12:38Z", "published_parsed": [2008, 3, 12, 8, 12, 38, 2, 72, 0], "title": "Approximation and learning by greedy algorithms", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Approximation and learning by greedy algorithms"}, "summary": "We consider the problem of approximating a given element $f$ from a Hilbert\nspace $\\mathcal{H}$ by means of greedy algorithms and the application of such\nprocedures to the regression problem in statistical learning theory. We improve\non the existing theory of convergence rates for both the orthogonal greedy\nalgorithm and the relaxed greedy algorithm, as well as for the forward stepwise\nprojection algorithm. For all these algorithms, we prove convergence results\nfor a variety of function classes and not simply those that are related to the\nconvex hull of the dictionary. We then show how these bounds for convergence\nrates lead to a new theory for the performance of greedy algorithms in\nlearning. In particular, we build upon the results in [IEEE Trans. Inform.\nTheory 42 (1996) 2118--2132] to construct learning algorithms based on greedy\napproximations which are universally consistent and provide provable\nconvergence rates for large classes of functions. The use of greedy algorithms\nin the context of learning is very appealing since it greatly reduces the\ncomputational burden when compared with standard model selection using general\ndictionaries.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider the problem of approximating a given element $f$ from a Hilbert\nspace $\\mathcal{H}$ by means of greedy algorithms and the application of such\nprocedures to the regression problem in statistical learning theory. We improve\non the existing theory of convergence rates for both the orthogonal greedy\nalgorithm and the relaxed greedy algorithm, as well as for the forward stepwise\nprojection algorithm. For all these algorithms, we prove convergence results\nfor a variety of function classes and not simply those that are related to the\nconvex hull of the dictionary. We then show how these bounds for convergence\nrates lead to a new theory for the performance of greedy algorithms in\nlearning. In particular, we build upon the results in [IEEE Trans. Inform.\nTheory 42 (1996) 2118--2132] to construct learning algorithms based on greedy\napproximations which are universally consistent and provide provable\nconvergence rates for large classes of functions. The use of greedy algorithms\nin the context of learning is very appealing since it greatly reduces the\ncomputational burden when compared with standard model selection using general\ndictionaries."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrew R. Barron"}, {"name": "Albert Cohen"}, {"name": "Wolfgang Dahmen"}, {"name": "Ronald A. DeVore"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Ronald A. DeVore"}, "author": "Ronald A. DeVore", "arxiv_doi": "10.1214/009053607000000631", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1214/009053607000000631", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0803.1718v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0803.1718v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "Published in at http://dx.doi.org/10.1214/009053607000000631 the\n  Annals of Statistics (http://www.imstat.org/aos/) by the Institute of\n  Mathematical Statistics (http://www.imstat.org)", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Annals of Statistics 2008, Vol. 36, No. 1, 64-94", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.ST", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.ST", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "stat.TH", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "62G07, 41A46, 41A63, 46N30 (Primary)", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1506.04779v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1506.04779v1", "updated": "2015-06-15T21:29:34Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 6, 15, 21, 29, 34, 0, 166, 0], "published": "2015-06-15T21:29:34Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 6, 15, 21, 29, 34, 0, 166, 0], "title": "Orthogonal Matching Pursuit under the Restricted Isometry Property", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Orthogonal Matching Pursuit under the Restricted Isometry Property"}, "summary": "This paper is concerned with the performance of Orthogonal Matching Pursuit\n(OMP) algorithms applied to a dictionary $\\mathcal{D}$ in a Hilbert space\n$\\mathcal{H}$. Given an element $f\\in \\mathcal{H}$, OMP generates a sequence of\napproximations $f_n$, $n=1,2,\\dots$, each of which is a linear combination of\n$n$ dictionary elements chosen by a greedy criterion. It is studied whether the\napproximations $f_n$ are in some sense comparable to {\\em best $n$ term\napproximation} from the dictionary. One important result related to this\nquestion is a theorem of Zhang \\cite{TZ} in the context of sparse recovery of\nfinite dimensional signals. This theorem shows that OMP exactly recovers\n$n$-sparse signal, whenever the dictionary $\\mathcal{D}$ satisfies a Restricted\nIsometry Property (RIP) of order $An$ for some constant $A$, and that the\nprocedure is also stable in $\\ell^2$ under measurement noise. The main\ncontribution of the present paper is to give a structurally simpler proof of\nZhang's theorem, formulated in the general context of $n$ term approximation\nfrom a dictionary in arbitrary Hilbert spaces $\\mathcal{H}$. Namely, it is\nshown that OMP generates near best $n$ term approximations under a similar RIP\ncondition.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper is concerned with the performance of Orthogonal Matching Pursuit\n(OMP) algorithms applied to a dictionary $\\mathcal{D}$ in a Hilbert space\n$\\mathcal{H}$. Given an element $f\\in \\mathcal{H}$, OMP generates a sequence of\napproximations $f_n$, $n=1,2,\\dots$, each of which is a linear combination of\n$n$ dictionary elements chosen by a greedy criterion. It is studied whether the\napproximations $f_n$ are in some sense comparable to {\\em best $n$ term\napproximation} from the dictionary. One important result related to this\nquestion is a theorem of Zhang \\cite{TZ} in the context of sparse recovery of\nfinite dimensional signals. This theorem shows that OMP exactly recovers\n$n$-sparse signal, whenever the dictionary $\\mathcal{D}$ satisfies a Restricted\nIsometry Property (RIP) of order $An$ for some constant $A$, and that the\nprocedure is also stable in $\\ell^2$ under measurement noise. The main\ncontribution of the present paper is to give a structurally simpler proof of\nZhang's theorem, formulated in the general context of $n$ term approximation\nfrom a dictionary in arbitrary Hilbert spaces $\\mathcal{H}$. Namely, it is\nshown that OMP generates near best $n$ term approximations under a similar RIP\ncondition."}, "authors": [{"name": "Albert Cohen"}, {"name": "Wolfgang Dahmen"}, {"name": "Ronald DeVore"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, "author": "Ronald DeVore", "arxiv_comment": "12 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1506.04779v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1506.04779v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "94A12, 94A15, 68P30, 41A46, 15A52", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1204.2290v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1204.2290v1", "updated": "2012-04-10T21:45:16Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 4, 10, 21, 45, 16, 1, 101, 0], "published": "2012-04-10T21:45:16Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 4, 10, 21, 45, 16, 1, 101, 0], "title": "Greedy Algorithms for Reduced Bases in Banach Spaces", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Greedy Algorithms for Reduced Bases in Banach Spaces"}, "summary": "Given a Banach space X and one of its compact sets F, we consider the problem\nof finding a good n dimensional space X_n \\subset X which can be used to\napproximate the elements of F. The best possible error we can achieve for such\nan approximation is given by the Kolmogorov width d_n(F)_X. However, finding\nthe space which gives this performance is typically numerically intractable.\nRecently, a new greedy strategy for obtaining good spaces was given in the\ncontext of the reduced basis method for solving a parametric family of PDEs.\nThe performance of this greedy algorithm was initially analyzed in A. Buffa, Y.\nMaday, A.T. Patera, C. Prud'homme, and G. Turinici, \"A Priori convergence of\nthe greedy algorithm for the parameterized reduced basis\", M2AN Math. Model.\nNumer. Anal., 46(2012), 595-603 in the case X = H is a Hilbert space. The\nresults there were significantly improved on in P. Binev, A. Cohen, W. Dahmen,\nR. DeVore, G. Petrova, and P. Wojtaszczyk, \"Convergence rates for greedy\nalgorithms in reduced bases Methods\", SIAM J. Math. Anal., 43 (2011),\n1457-1472. The purpose of the present paper is to give a new analysis of the\nperformance of such greedy algorithms. Our analysis not only gives improved\nresults for the Hilbert space case but can also be applied to the same greedy\nprocedure in general Banach spaces.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Given a Banach space X and one of its compact sets F, we consider the problem\nof finding a good n dimensional space X_n \\subset X which can be used to\napproximate the elements of F. The best possible error we can achieve for such\nan approximation is given by the Kolmogorov width d_n(F)_X. However, finding\nthe space which gives this performance is typically numerically intractable.\nRecently, a new greedy strategy for obtaining good spaces was given in the\ncontext of the reduced basis method for solving a parametric family of PDEs.\nThe performance of this greedy algorithm was initially analyzed in A. Buffa, Y.\nMaday, A.T. Patera, C. Prud'homme, and G. Turinici, \"A Priori convergence of\nthe greedy algorithm for the parameterized reduced basis\", M2AN Math. Model.\nNumer. Anal., 46(2012), 595-603 in the case X = H is a Hilbert space. The\nresults there were significantly improved on in P. Binev, A. Cohen, W. Dahmen,\nR. DeVore, G. Petrova, and P. Wojtaszczyk, \"Convergence rates for greedy\nalgorithms in reduced bases Methods\", SIAM J. Math. Anal., 43 (2011),\n1457-1472. The purpose of the present paper is to give a new analysis of the\nperformance of such greedy algorithms. Our analysis not only gives improved\nresults for the Hilbert space case but can also be applied to the same greedy\nprocedure in general Banach spaces."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, {"name": "Guergana Petrova"}, {"name": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk"}, "author": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1204.2290v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1204.2290v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "41A46, 41A25, 46B20, 15A15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.5027v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.5027v1", "updated": "2014-09-17T15:24:25Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 9, 17, 15, 24, 25, 2, 260, 0], "published": "2014-09-17T15:24:25Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 9, 17, 15, 24, 25, 2, 260, 0], "title": "Self-similar groups, automatic sequences, and unitriangular\n  representations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Self-similar groups, automatic sequences, and unitriangular\n  representations"}, "summary": "We study natural linear representations of self-similar groups over finite\nfields. We show that the answer is \"No\" in a strong sense. As\nthe first example we present the collection of amenable 4-generated groups\n$G_\\omega$, $\\omega\\in\\{0,1,2\\}^\\mathbb N$, constructed by the second author in\n1984. These spectra are\nsimple transforms of the Julia sets associated to some quadratic maps. The\ngraphs involved are Schreier graphs of fractal groups of intermediate growth,\nand are also ``substitutional graphs''. We also formulate our results in terms\nof Hecke type operators related to some irreducible quasi-regular\nrepresentations of fractal groups and in terms of the Markovian operator\nassociated to noncommutative dynamical systems via which these fractal groups\nwere originally defined. These spectra are\nsimple transforms of the Julia sets associated to some quadratic maps. The\ngraphs involved are Schreier graphs of fractal groups of intermediate growth,\nand are also ``substitutional graphs''. We also formulate our results in terms\nof Hecke type operators related to some irreducible quasi-regular\nrepresentations of fractal groups and in terms of the Markovian operator\nassociated to noncommutative dynamical systems via which these fractal groups\nwere originally defined. Math. 2000, no. 4 (231),\n  1--41", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/9910102v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/9910102v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.GR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.GR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "20F50; 20C12; 11F25; 43A65", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0202001v4", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0202001v4", "updated": "2002-09-13T18:26:29Z", "updated_parsed": [2002, 9, 13, 18, 26, 29, 4, 256, 0], "published": "2002-02-01T02:02:03Z", "published_parsed": [2002, 2, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 32, 0], "title": "From fractal groups to fractal sets", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "From fractal groups to fractal sets"}, "summary": "This paper is a survey, with few proofs, of ideas and notions related to\nself-similarity of groups, semi-groups and their actions. It attempts to relate\nthese concepts to more familiar ones, such as fractals, self-similar sets, and\nrenormalizable dynamical systems. In particular, it presents a plausible\ndefinition of what a \"fractal group\" should be, and gives many examples of such\ngroups.\n  A particularly interesting class of examples, derived from monodromy groups\nof iterated branch coverings, or equivalently from Galois groups of iterated\npolynomials, is presented. This class contains interesting groups from an\nalgebraic point of view (just-non-solvable groups, groups of intermediate\ngrowth, branch groups,...), and at the same time the geometry of the group is\napparent in that a limit of the group identifies naturally with the Julia set\nof the covering map.\n  In its survey, the paper discusses finite-state transducers, growth of groups\nand languages, limit spaces of groups, hyperbolic spaces and groups, dynamical\nsystems, Hecke-type operators, C^*-algebras, random matrices, ergodic theorems\nand entropy of non-commuting transformations. Self-similar groups appear then\nas a natural weaving thread through these seemingly different topics.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper is a survey, with few proofs, of ideas and notions related to\nself-similarity of groups, semi-groups and their actions. It attempts to relate\nthese concepts to more familiar ones, such as fractals, self-similar sets, and\nrenormalizable dynamical systems. In particular, it presents a plausible\ndefinition of what a \"fractal group\" should be, and gives many examples of such\ngroups.\n  A particularly interesting class of examples, derived from monodromy groups\nof iterated branch coverings, or equivalently from Galois groups of iterated\npolynomials, is presented. This class contains interesting groups from an\nalgebraic point of view (just-non-solvable groups, groups of intermediate\ngrowth, branch groups,...), and at the same time the geometry of the group is\napparent in that a limit of the group identifies naturally with the Julia set\nof the covering map.\n  In its survey, the paper discusses finite-state transducers, growth of groups\nand languages, limit spaces of groups, hyperbolic spaces and groups, dynamical\nsystems, Hecke-type operators, C^*-algebras, random matrices, ergodic theorems\nand entropy of non-commuting transformations. This is the first example of a group with infinitely many gaps\nin the spectrum of its Cayley graph. Our results show that the spectrum is a pure point spectrum for each value\nof the parameter, the eigenvalues are solutions of algebraic equations\ninvolving Chebyshev polynomials of the second kind, and the topological\nstructure of the spectrum makes a bifurcation when the parameter passes the\npoints 1 and -1.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We show that the lamplighter group L has a system of generators for which the\nspectrum of the discrete Laplacian on the Cayley graph is a union of an\ninterval and a countable set of isolated points accumulating to a point outside\nthis interval. This is the first example of a group with infinitely many gaps\nin the spectrum of its Cayley graph. The result is obtained by a careful study\nof spectral properties of a one-parametric family of convolution operators on\nL. which includes the first Grigorchuk\ngroup and the Gupta-Sidki 3-group. This description is made via the notion of\nblock subgroup. We then use this to show that all groups in the above family\nare subgroup separable (LERF). These results are obtained as a corollary of a\nmore general structural statement on subdirect products of just infinite\ngroups.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The aim of this paper is to describe the structure of the finitely generated\nsubgroups of a family of branch groups, which includes the first Grigorchuk\ngroup and the Gupta-Sidki 3-group. This description is made via the notion of\nblock subgroup. We then use this to show that all groups in the above family\nare subgroup separable (LERF). First, we review\nthe formalism of pseudogroups, which is well adapted to stating the alternative\nof Tarski, according to which a pseudogroup without invariant mean gives rise\nto paradoxical decompositions, and to defining a F{\\o}lner condition. Using a\nHall-Rado Theorem on matchings in graphs, we show then for pseudogroups that\nexistence of an invariant mean is equivalent to the F{\\o}lner condition; in the\ncase of the pseudogroup of bounded perturbations of the identity on a locally\nfinite metric space, these conditions are moreover equivalent to the negation\nof the Gromov's so-called doubling condition, to isoperimetric conditions, to\nKesten's spectral condition for related simple random walks, and to various\nother conditions. We define also the minimal Tarski number of paradoxical\ndecompositions associated to a non-amenable group action (an integer $\\ge 4$),\nand we indicate numerical estimates (Sections II.4 and IV.2). The final chapter\nexplores for metric spaces the notion of supramenability, due for groups to\nRosenblatt.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This is an expostion of various aspects of amenability and paradoxical\ndecompositions for groups, group actions and metric spaces. First, we review\nthe formalism of pseudogroups, which is well adapted to stating the alternative\nof Tarski, according to which a pseudogroup without invariant mean gives rise\nto paradoxical decompositions, and to defining a F{\\o}lner condition. Using a\nHall-Rado Theorem on matchings in graphs, we show then for pseudogroups that\nexistence of an invariant mean is equivalent to the F{\\o}lner condition; in the\ncase of the pseudogroup of bounded perturbations of the identity on a locally\nfinite metric space, these conditions are moreover equivalent to the negation\nof the Gromov's so-called doubling condition, to isoperimetric conditions, to\nKesten's spectral condition for related simple random walks, and to various\nother conditions. We define also the minimal Tarski number of paradoxical\ndecompositions associated to a non-amenable group action (an integer $\\ge 4$),\nand we indicate numerical estimates (Sections II.4 and IV.2). "http://arxiv.org/abs/0906.2105v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0906.2105v3", "updated": "2010-01-22T21:32:06Z", "updated_parsed": [2010, 1, 22, 21, 32, 6, 4, 22, 0], "published": "2009-06-11T13:46:42Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 6, 11, 13, 46, 42, 3, 162, 0], "title": "Nonuniform sampling and recovery of multidimensional bandlimited\n  functions by Gaussian radial-basis functions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Nonuniform sampling and recovery of multidimensional bandlimited\n  functions by Gaussian radial-basis functions"}, "summary": "Let $S\\subset\\R^d$ be a bounded subset with positive Lebesgue measure. The\nPaley-Wiener space associated to $S$, $PW_S$, is defined to be the set of all\nsquare-integrable functions on $\\R^d$ whose Fourier transforms vanish outside\n$S$. A sequence $(x_j:j\\kin\\N)$ in $\\R^d$ is said to be a Riesz-basis sequence\nfor $L_2(S)$ (equivalently, a complete interpolating sequence for $PW_S$) if\nthe sequence $(e^{-i\\la x_j,\\cdot\\ra}:j\\kin\\N)$ of exponential functions forms\na Riesz basis for $L_2(S)$. Let $(x_j:j\\kin\\N)$ be a Riesz-basis sequence for\n$L_2(S)$. Given $\\lambda>0$ and $f\\in PW_S$, there is a unique sequence $(a_j)$\nin $\\ell_2$ such that the function $$\nI_\\lambda(f)(x):=\\sum_{j\\in\\N}a_je^{-\\lambda \\|x-x_j\\|_2^2}, \\qquad x\\kin\\R^d,\n$$ is continuous and square integrable on $\\R^d$, and satisfies the condition\n$I_\\lambda(f)(x_n)=f(x_n)$ for every $n\\kin\\N$. This paper studies the\nconvergence of the interpolant $I_\\lambda(f)$ as $\\lambda$ tends to zero, {\\it\ni.e.,\\} as the variance of the underlying Gaussian tends to infinity. The\nfollowing result is obtained: Let $\\delta\\in(\\sqrt{2/3},1]$ and\n$0<\\beta<\\sqrt{3\\delta^2 -2}$. Suppose that $\\delta B_2\\subset Z\\subset B_2$,\nand let $(x_j:j\\in\\N)$ be a Riesz basis sequence for $L_2(Z)$. If $f\\in\nPW_{\\beta B_2}$, then $f=\\lim_{\\lambda\\to 0^+} I_\\lambda(f)$ in $L_2(\\R^d)$ and\nuniformly on $\\R^d$. If $\\delta=1$, then one may take $\\beta$ to be 1 as well,\nand this reduces to a known theorem in the univariate case. However, if\n$d\\ge2$, it is not known whether $L_2(B_2)$ admits a Riesz-basis sequence. On\nthe other hand, in the case when $\\delta<1$, there do exist bodies $Z$\nsatisfying the hypotheses of the theorem (in any space dimension).", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $S\\subset\\R^d$ be a bounded subset with positive Lebesgue measure. The\nPaley-Wiener space associated to $S$, $PW_S$, is defined to be the set of all\nsquare-integrable functions on $\\R^d$ whose Fourier transforms vanish outside\n$S$. A sequence $(x_j:j\\kin\\N)$ in $\\R^d$ is said to be a Riesz-basis sequence\nfor $L_2(S)$ (equivalently, a complete interpolating sequence for $PW_S$) if\nthe sequence $(e^{-i\\la x_j,\\cdot\\ra}:j\\kin\\N)$ of exponential functions forms\na Riesz basis for $L_2(S)$. Let $(x_j:j\\kin\\N)$ be a Riesz-basis sequence for\n$L_2(S)$. Given $\\lambda>0$ and $f\\in PW_S$, there is a unique sequence $(a_j)$\nin $\\ell_2$ such that the function $$\nI_\\lambda(f)(x):=\\sum_{j\\in\\N}a_je^{-\\lambda \\|x-x_j\\|_2^2}, \\qquad x\\kin\\R^d,\n$$ is continuous and square integrable on $\\R^d$, and satisfies the condition\n$I_\\lambda(f)(x_n)=f(x_n)$ for every $n\\kin\\N$. This paper studies the\nconvergence of the interpolant $I_\\lambda(f)$ as $\\lambda$ tends to zero, {\\it\ni.e.,\\} as the variance of the underlying Gaussian tends to infinity. The\nfollowing result is obtained: Let $\\delta\\in(\\sqrt{2/3},1]$ and\n$0<\\beta<\\sqrt{3\\delta^2 -2}$. Suppose that $\\delta B_2\\subset Z\\subset B_2$,\nand let $(x_j:j\\in\\N)$ be a Riesz basis sequence for $L_2(Z)$. If $f\\in\nPW_{\\beta B_2}$, then $f=\\lim_{\\lambda\\to 0^+} I_\\lambda(f)$ in $L_2(\\R^d)$ and\nuniformly on $\\R^d$. If $\\delta=1$, then one may take $\\beta$ to be 1 as well,\nand this reduces to a known theorem in the univariate case. However, if\n$d\\ge2$, it is not known whether $L_2(B_2)$ admits a Riesz-basis sequence. On\nthe other hand, in the case when $\\delta<1$, there do exist bodies $Z$\nsatisfying the hypotheses of the theorem (in any space dimension)."}, "authors": [{"name": "A. Bailey"}, {"name": "Th. Schlumprecht"}, {"name": "N. Sivakumar"}], "author_detail": {"name": "N. Sivakumar"}, "author": "N. Sivakumar", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0906.2105v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0906.2105v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "41A05; 42C30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0803.4344v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0803.4344v1", "updated": "2008-03-30T20:34:57Z", "updated_parsed": [2008, 3, 30, 20, 34, 57, 6, 90, 0], "published": "2008-03-30T20:34:57Z", "published_parsed": [2008, 3, 30, 20, 34, 57, 6, 90, 0], "title": "On the sampling and recovery of bandlimited functions via scattered\n  translates of the Gaussian", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "On the sampling and recovery of bandlimited functions via scattered\n  translates of the Gaussian"}, "summary": "Let $\\lambda$ be a positive number, and let $(x_j:j\\in\\mathbb\nZ)\\subset\\mathbb R$ be a fixed Riesz-basis sequence, namely, $(x_j)$ is\nstrictly increasing, and the set of functions $\\{\\mathbb R\\ni t\\mapsto\ne^{ix_jt}:j\\in\\mathbb Z\\}$ is a Riesz basis ({\\it i.e.,} unconditionalbasis)\nfor $L_2[-\\pi,\\pi]$. Given a function $f\\in L_2(\\mathbb R)$ whose Fourier\ntransform is zero almost everywhere outside the interval $[-\\pi,\\pi]$, there is\na unique square-summable sequence $(a_j:j\\in\\mathbb Z)$, depending on $\\lambda$\nand $f$, such that the function$$I_\\lambda(f)(x):=\\sum_{j\\in\\mathbb\nZ}a_je^{-\\lambda(x-x_j)^2}, \\qquad x\\in\\mathbb R, $$ is continuous and square\nintegrable on $(-\\infty,\\infty)$, and satisfies the interpolatory conditions\n$I_\\lambda (f)(x_j)=f(x_j)$, $j\\in\\mathbb Z$. It is shown that $I_\\lambda(f)$\nconverges to $f$ in $L_2(\\mathbb R)$, and also uniformly on $\\mathbb R$, as\n$\\lambda\\to0^+$. A multidimensional version of this result is also obtained. In\naddition, the fundamental functions for the univariate interpolation process\nare defined, and some of their basic properties, including their exponential\ndecay for large argument, are established. It is further shown that the\nassociated interpolation operators are bounded on $\\ell_p(\\mathbb Z)$ for every\n$p\\in[1,\\infty]$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $\\lambda$ be a positive number, and let $(x_j:j\\in\\mathbb\nZ)\\subset\\mathbb R$ be a fixed Riesz-basis sequence, namely, $(x_j)$ is\nstrictly increasing, and the set of functions $\\{\\mathbb R\\ni t\\mapsto\ne^{ix_jt}:j\\in\\mathbb Z\\}$ is a Riesz basis ({\\it i.e.,} unconditionalbasis)\nfor $L_2[-\\pi,\\pi]$. Given a function $f\\in L_2(\\mathbb R)$ whose Fourier\ntransform is zero almost everywhere outside the interval $[-\\pi,\\pi]$, there is\na unique square-summable sequence $(a_j:j\\in\\mathbb Z)$, depending on $\\lambda$\nand $f$, such that the function$$I_\\lambda(f)(x):=\\sum_{j\\in\\mathbb\nZ}a_je^{-\\lambda(x-x_j)^2}, \\qquad x\\in\\mathbb R, $$ is continuous and square\nintegrable on $(-\\infty,\\infty)$, and satisfies the interpolatory conditions\n$I_\\lambda (f)(x_j)=f(x_j)$, $j\\in\\mathbb Z$. It is shown that $I_\\lambda(f)$\nconverges to $f$ in $L_2(\\mathbb R)$, and also uniformly on $\\mathbb R$, as\n$\\lambda\\to0^+$. A multidimensional version of this result is also obtained. In\naddition, the fundamental functions for the univariate interpolation process\nare defined, and some of their basic properties, including their exponential\ndecay for large argument, are established. Our\noriginal application of this pairing was to answer a question on the Ceresa\ncycle posed by R. Hain and D. Reed. (This question has since been answered\nindependently by Hain.) Here we apply the pairing to show that a certain\nanalytic line bundle, called the biextension line bundle, defined in terms of\nnormal functions, always extends to any smooth partial compactification of the\nbase. We show that the the pairing on intersection cohomology governs the\nextension of the natural metric on this line bundle studied by Hain and Reed\n(as well as, more recently, by several other authors). The interest in this moduli comes\nfrom two sources: the study of certain weighted hypersurfaces whose middle\ncohomology admit Hodge structures of $K3$ type and, on the other hand, the\nstudy of the singularity $O_{16}$ (the cone over a cubic surface). In this\npaper we consider a $16$-dimensional family of special Horikawa surfaces which\nare certain bidouble covers of $\\mathbb{P}^2$. These components are the closure\nof the orbits (under strict equivalence) of r+1 matrix pencils which are in\nKronecker canonical form. In this paper, we provide a new explicit description\nof each of these irreducible components which is a parametrization of each\ncomponent. Therefore one can explicitly construct any pencil in each of these\ncomponents. The new description of each of these irreducible components\nconsists of the sum of r rank-1 matrix pencils, namely, a column polynomial\nvector of degree at most 1 times a row polynomial vector of degree at most 1,\nwhere we impose one of these two vectors to have degree zero. The number of row\nvectors with zero degree determines each irreducible component.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The set of mxn singular matrix pencils with normal rank at most r is an\nalgebraic set with r+1 irreducible components. In this paper, we provide a new explicit description\nof each of these irreducible components which is a parametrization of each\ncomponent. Therefore one can explicitly construct any pencil in each of these\ncomponents. For a tensor $T$, let $\\underline R(T)$ denote its border rank. We\n(i) give the first hand-checkable algebraic proof that $\\underline\nR(M_2)=7$,(ii) prove $\\underline R(M_{\\langle 223\\rangle})=10$, and $\\underline\nR(M_{\\langle 233\\rangle})=14$, where previously the only nontrivial matrix\nmultiplication tensor whose border rank had been determined was $M_2$,(iii)\nprove $\\underline R( M_3)\\geq 17$, (iv) prove $\\underline R( det_3)=17$,\nimproving the previous lower bound of $12$, (v) prove $\\underline R(M_{\\langle\n2nn\\rangle})\\geq n^2+1.32n$ for all $n\\geq 25$ (previously only $\\underline\nR(M_{\\langle 2nn\\rangle})\\geq n^2+1$ was known) as well as lower bounds for\n$4\\leq n\\leq 25$, and (vi) prove $\\underline R(M_{\\langle 3nn\\rangle})\\geq\nn^2+2 n+1$ for all $ n\\geq 21$, where previously only $\\underline R(M_{\\langle\n3nn\\rangle})\\geq n^2+2$ was known, as well as lower boundsfor $4\\leq n\\leq 21$.\n  Our results utilize a new technique initiated by Buczy\\'{n}ska and\nBuczy\\'{n}ski, called border apolarity. The two key ingredients are: (i) the\nuse of a multi-graded ideal associated to a border rank $r$ decomposition of\nany tensor, and (ii) the exploitation of the large symmetry group of $T$ to\nrestrict to $B_T$-invariant ideals, where $B_T$ is a maximal solvable subgroup\nof the symmetry group of $T$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $M_{\\langle u,v,w\\rangle}\\in C^{uv}\\otimes C^{vw}\\otimes C^{wu}$ denote\nthe matrix multiplication tensor (and write $M_n=M_{\\langle n,n,n\\rangle}$) and\nlet $det_3\\in ( C^9)^{\\otimes 3}$ denote the determinant polynomial considered\nas a tensor. For a tensor $T$, let $\\underline R(T)$ denote its border rank. We\n(i) give the first hand-checkable algebraic proof that $\\underline\nR(M_2)=7$,(ii) prove $\\underline R(M_{\\langle 223\\rangle})=10$, and $\\underline\nR(M_{\\langle 233\\rangle})=14$, where previously the only nontrivial matrix\nmultiplication tensor whose border rank had been determined was $M_2$,(iii)\nprove $\\underline R( M_3)\\geq 17$, (iv) prove $\\underline R( det_3)=17$,\nimproving the previous lower bound of $12$, (v) prove $\\underline R(M_{\\langle\n2nn\\rangle})\\geq n^2+1.32n$ for all $n\\geq 25$ (previously only $\\underline\nR(M_{\\langle 2nn\\rangle})\\geq n^2+1$ was known) as well as lower bounds for\n$4\\leq n\\leq 25$, and (vi) prove $\\underline R(M_{\\langle 3nn\\rangle})\\geq\nn^2+2 n+1$ for all $ n\\geq 21$, where previously only $\\underline R(M_{\\langle\n3nn\\rangle})\\geq n^2+2$ was known, as well as lower boundsfor $4\\leq n\\leq 21$.\n  Our results utilize a new technique initiated by Buczy\\'{n}ska and\nBuczy\\'{n}ski, called border apolarity. The two key ingredients are: (i) the\nuse of a multi-graded ideal associated to a border rank $r$ decomposition of\nany tensor, and (ii) the exploitation of the large symmetry group of $T$ to\nrestrict to $B_T$-invariant ideals, where $B_T$ is a maximal solvable subgroup\nof the symmetry group of $T$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Austin Conner"}, {"name": "Alicia Harper"}, {"name": "J. In particular, the theory produces algebraic tests for a\nproblem to be in the class P. In this article we streamline the implementation\nof holographic algorithms by eliminating one of the steps in the construction\nprocedure, and generalize their applicability to new signatures. Instead of\nmatchgates, which are weighted graph fragments that replace vertices of a\nnatural bipartite graph G associated to a problem P, our approach uses only\nonly a natural number-of-edges by number-of-edges matrix associated to G. An\neasy-to-compute multiple of its Pfaffian is the number of solutions to the\ncounting problem. This simplification improves our understanding of the\napplicability of holographic algorithms, indicates a more geometric approach to\ncomplexity classes, and facilitates practical implementations. The generalized\napplicability arises because our approach allows for new algebraic tests that\nare different from the \"Grassmann-Plucker identities\" used up until now.\nNatural problems treatable by these new methods have been previously considered\nin a different context, and we present one such example.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The theory of holographic algorithms, which are polynomial time algorithms\nfor certain combinatorial counting problems, yields insight into the hierarchy\nof complexity classes. In particular, the theory produces algebraic tests for a\nproblem to be in the class P. In this article we streamline the implementation\nof holographic algorithms by eliminating one of the steps in the construction\nprocedure, and generalize their applicability to new signatures. Instead of\nmatchgates, which are weighted graph fragments that replace vertices of a\nnatural bipartite graph G associated to a problem P, our approach uses only\nonly a natural number-of-edges by number-of-edges matrix associated to G. An\neasy-to-compute multiple of its Pfaffian is the number of solutions to the\ncounting problem. This simplification improves our understanding of the\napplicability of holographic algorithms, indicates a more geometric approach to\ncomplexity classes, and facilitates practical implementations. In other words, we classify minimal dimensional orbits in the\nspace of (m,m,m) tensors assuming 1-genericity. Our study uncovers new tensors\nwith striking geometry. This paper was motivated by Strassen's laser method for\nbounding the exponent of matrix multiplication. The best known tensor for the\nlaser method is the large Coppersmith-Winograd tensor, and our study began with\nthe observation that it has a large symmetry group, of dimension m^2/2 +m/2. We\nshow that in odd dimensions, this is the largest possible for a 1-generic\ntensor, but in even dimensions we exhibit a tensor with a larger dimensional\nsymmetry group. In other words, we classify minimal dimensional orbits in the\nspace of (m,m,m) tensors assuming 1-genericity. Our study uncovers new tensors\nwith striking geometry. This paper was motivated by Strassen's laser method for\nbounding the exponent of matrix multiplication. The best known tensor for the\nlaser method is the large Coppersmith-Winograd tensor, and our study began with\nthe observation that it has a large symmetry group, of dimension m^2/2 +m/2. Eisenbud's question\ngeneralizes a conjecture of Eisenbud, Koh and Stillman (EKS) for curves. We\nprove that set-theoretic equations of small secant varieties to a high degree\nVeronese re-embedding of a smooth variety are determined by equations of the\nambient Veronese variety and linear equations. However this is false for\nsingular varieties, and we give explicit counter-examples to the EKS conjecture\nfor singular curves. The techniques we use also allow us to prove a gap and\nuniqueness theorem for symmetric tensor rank. We put Eisenbud's question in a\nmore general context about the behaviour of border rank under specialisation to\na linear subspace, and provide an overview of conjectures coming from signal\nprocessing and complexity theory in this context.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We address special cases of a question of Eisenbud on the ideals of secant\nvarieties of Veronese re-embeddings of arbitrary varieties. Eisenbud's question\ngeneralizes a conjecture of Eisenbud, Koh and Stillman (EKS) for curves. We\nprove that set-theoretic equations of small secant varieties to a high degree\nVeronese re-embedding of a smooth variety are determined by equations of the\nambient Veronese variety and linear equations. However this is false for\nsingular varieties, and we give explicit counter-examples to the EKS conjecture\nfor singular curves. The techniques we use also allow us to prove a gap and\nuniqueness theorem for symmetric tensor rank. We put Eisenbud's question in a\nmore general context about the behaviour of border rank under specialisation to\na linear subspace, and provide an overview of conjectures coming from signal\nprocessing and complexity theory in this context."}, "authors": [{"name": "Jaros\u0142aw Buczy\u0144ski"}, {"name": "Adam Ginensky"}, {"name": "J. We provide improved lower bounds for the rank\nof a symmetric tensor (i.e., a homogeneous polynomial) obtained by considering\nthe singularities of the hypersurface defined by the polynomial. We show that if the\nprojective second fundamental form of $X$ at $x$ is isomorphic to the second\nfundamental form of a point of a Segre $P^n\\times P^m$, $n,m\\geq 2$, a\nGrassmaniann $G(2,n+2)$, $n\\geq 4$, or the Cayley plane $OP^2$, then $X$ is the\ncorresponding homogeneous variety (resp. a patch of the corresponding\nhomogeneous variety). If the projective second fundamental form of $X$ at $x$\nis isomorphic to the second fundamental form of a point of a Veronese\n$v_2(P^n)$ and the Fubini cubic form of $X$ at $x$ is zero, then $X=v_2(P^n)$\n(resp. a patch of $v_2(P^n)$). All these results are valid in the real or\ncomplex analytic categories and locally in the $C^{\\infty}$ category if one\nassumes the hypotheses hold in a neighborhood of any point $x$. As a byproduct,\nwe show that the systems of quadrics $I_2(P^{m-1}\\sqcup P^{n-1}), I_2(P^1\\times\nP^{n-1})$ and $I_2(S_5)$ are stable in the sense that if $A_t\\subset S^2T^*$ is\nan analytic family such that for $t\\neq 0$, $A_t\\simeq A$, then $A_0\\simeq A$.\n  We also make some observations related to the Fulton-Hansen connectedness\ntheorem.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $X\\subset P^N$ be a variety (respectively a patch of an analytic\nsubmanifold) and let $x\\in X$ be a general point. We show that if the\nprojective second fundamental form of $X$ at $x$ is isomorphic to the second\nfundamental form of a point of a Segre $P^n\\times P^m$, $n,m\\geq 2$, a\nGrassmaniann $G(2,n+2)$, $n\\geq 4$, or the Cayley plane $OP^2$, then $X$ is the\ncorresponding homogeneous variety (resp. a patch of the corresponding\nhomogeneous variety). If the projective second fundamental form of $X$ at $x$\nis isomorphic to the second fundamental form of a point of a Veronese\n$v_2(P^n)$ and the Fubini cubic form of $X$ at $x$ is zero, then $X=v_2(P^n)$\n(resp. a patch of $v_2(P^n)$). All these results are valid in the real or\ncomplex analytic categories and locally in the $C^{\\infty}$ category if one\nassumes the hypotheses hold in a neighborhood of any point $x$. As a byproduct,\nwe show that the systems of quadrics $I_2(P^{m-1}\\sqcup P^{n-1}), I_2(P^1\\times\nP^{n-1})$ and $I_2(S_5)$ are stable in the sense that if $A_t\\subset S^2T^*$ is\nan analytic family such that for $t\\neq 0$, $A_t\\simeq A$, then $A_0\\simeq A$.\n  We also make some observations related to the Fulton-Hansen connectedness\ntheorem."}, "authors": [{"name": "J. This\nnotion is developed in terms of trees and branches on Banach spaces. Every\ncountably infinite countably branching tree $\\mathcal T$ of a certain type on a\nspace X is presumed to have a branch with some property. It is shown that then\nX can be embedded into a space with an FDD $(E_i)$ so that all normalized\nsequences in X which are almost a skipped blocking of $(E_i)$ have that\nproperty. As an application of our work we prove that if X is a separable\nreflexive Banach space and for some $1<p<\\infty$ and $C<\\infty$ every weakly\nnull tree $\\mathcal T$ on the sphere of X has a branch C-equivalent to the unit\nvector basis of $\\ell_p$, then for all $\\epsilon>0$, there exists a finite\ncodimensional subspace of X which $C^2+\\epsilon$ embeds into the $\\ell_p$ sum\nof finite dimensional spaces.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "An infinite dimensional notion of asymptotic structure is considered. This\nnotion is developed in terms of trees and branches on Banach spaces. Every\ncountably infinite countably branching tree $\\mathcal T$ of a certain type on a\nspace X is presumed to have a branch with some property. It is shown that then\nX can be embedded into a space with an FDD $(E_i)$ so that all normalized\nsequences in X which are almost a skipped blocking of $(E_i)$ have that\nproperty. As an application of our work we prove that if X is a separable\nreflexive Banach space and for some $1<p<\\infty$ and $C<\\infty$ every weakly\nnull tree $\\mathcal T$ on the sphere of X has a branch C-equivalent to the unit\nvector basis of $\\ell_p$, then for all $\\epsilon>0$, there exists a finite\ncodimensional subspace of X which $C^2+\\epsilon$ embeds into the $\\ell_p$ sum\nof finite dimensional spaces."}, "authors": [{"name": "Edward Odell"}, {"name": "Thomas Schlumprecht"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Thomas Schlumprecht"}, "author": "Thomas Schlumprecht", "arxiv_comment": "LaTeX, 24pp", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0002219v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0002219v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46B03, 46B20", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1009.2923v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1009.2923v1", "updated": "2010-09-15T13:45:31Z", "updated_parsed": [2010, 9, 15, 13, 45, 31, 2, 258, 0], "published": "2010-09-15T13:45:31Z", "published_parsed": [2010, 9, 15, 13, 45, 31, 2, 258, 0], "title": "Dichotomy theorems for random matrices and closed ideals of operators on\n  $\\big(\\bigoplus_{n=1}^\\infty\\ell_1^n \\big)_{\\mathrm{c}_0}$", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Dichotomy theorems for random matrices and closed ideals of operators on\n  $\\big(\\bigoplus_{n=1}^\\infty\\ell_1^n \\big)_{\\mathrm{c}_0}$"}, "summary": "We prove two dichotomy theorems about sequences of operators into $L_1$ given\nby random matrices. In the second theorem we assume that the entries of each\nrandom matrix form a sequence of independent, symmetric random variables. Then\nthe corresponding sequence of operators either uniformly factor the identity\noperators on $\\ell_1^k$ $(k\\in\\mathbb N$) or uniformly approximately factor\nthrough $\\mathrm{c}_0$. The first theorem has a slightly weaker conclusion\nstill related to factorization properties but makes no assumption on the random\nmatrices. Indeed, it applies to operators defined on an arbitrary sequence of\nBanach spaces. These results provide information on the closed ideal structure\nof the Banach algebra of all operators on the space\n$\\big(\\bigoplus_{n=1}^\\infty\\ell_1^n \\big)_{\\mathrm{c}_0}$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We prove two dichotomy theorems about sequences of operators into $L_1$ given\nby random matrices. Given a function $f\\in L_2(\\mathbb R)$ whose Fourier\ntransform is zero almost everywhere outside the interval $[-\\pi,\\pi]$, there is\na unique square-summable sequence $(a_j:j\\in\\mathbb Z)$, depending on $\\lambda$\nand $f$, such that the function$$I_\\lambda(f)(x):=\\sum_{j\\in\\mathbb\nZ}a_je^{-\\lambda(x-x_j)^2}, \\qquad x\\in\\mathbb R, $$ is continuous and square\nintegrable on $(-\\infty,\\infty)$, and satisfies the interpolatory conditions\n$I_\\lambda (f)(x_j)=f(x_j)$, $j\\in\\mathbb Z$. It is shown that $I_\\lambda(f)$\nconverges to $f$ in $L_2(\\mathbb R)$, and also uniformly on $\\mathbb R$, as\n$\\lambda\\to0^+$. A multidimensional version of this result is also obtained. In\naddition, the fundamental functions for the univariate interpolation process\nare defined, and some of their basic properties, including their exponential\ndecay for large argument, are established. "http://arxiv.org/abs/0906.2105v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0906.2105v3", "updated": "2010-01-22T21:32:06Z", "updated_parsed": [2010, 1, 22, 21, 32, 6, 4, 22, 0], "published": "2009-06-11T13:46:42Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 6, 11, 13, 46, 42, 3, 162, 0], "title": "Nonuniform sampling and recovery of multidimensional bandlimited\n  functions by Gaussian radial-basis functions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Nonuniform sampling and recovery of multidimensional bandlimited\n  functions by Gaussian radial-basis functions"}, "summary": "Let $S\\subset\\R^d$ be a bounded subset with positive Lebesgue measure. The\nPaley-Wiener space associated to $S$, $PW_S$, is defined to be the set of all\nsquare-integrable functions on $\\R^d$ whose Fourier transforms vanish outside\n$S$. A sequence $(x_j:j\\kin\\N)$ in $\\R^d$ is said to be a Riesz-basis sequence\nfor $L_2(S)$ (equivalently, a complete interpolating sequence for $PW_S$) if\nthe sequence $(e^{-i\\la x_j,\\cdot\\ra}:j\\kin\\N)$ of exponential functions forms\na Riesz basis for $L_2(S)$. Let $(x_j:j\\kin\\N)$ be a Riesz-basis sequence for\n$L_2(S)$. Given $\\lambda>0$ and $f\\in PW_S$, there is a unique sequence $(a_j)$\nin $\\ell_2$ such that the function $$\nI_\\lambda(f)(x):=\\sum_{j\\in\\N}a_je^{-\\lambda \\|x-x_j\\|_2^2}, \\qquad x\\kin\\R^d,\n$$ is continuous and square integrable on $\\R^d$, and satisfies the condition\n$I_\\lambda(f)(x_n)=f(x_n)$ for every $n\\kin\\N$. This paper studies the\nconvergence of the interpolant $I_\\lambda(f)$ as $\\lambda$ tends to zero, {\\it\ni.e.,\\} as the variance of the underlying Gaussian tends to infinity. The\nfollowing result is obtained: Let $\\delta\\in(\\sqrt{2/3},1]$ and\n$0<\\beta<\\sqrt{3\\delta^2 -2}$. Suppose that $\\delta B_2\\subset Z\\subset B_2$,\nand let $(x_j:j\\in\\N)$ be a Riesz basis sequence for $L_2(Z)$. If $f\\in\nPW_{\\beta B_2}$, then $f=\\lim_{\\lambda\\to 0^+} I_\\lambda(f)$ in $L_2(\\R^d)$ and\nuniformly on $\\R^d$. If $\\delta=1$, then one may take $\\beta$ to be 1 as well,\nand this reduces to a known theorem in the univariate case. However, if\n$d\\ge2$, it is not known whether $L_2(B_2)$ admits a Riesz-basis sequence. On\nthe other hand, in the case when $\\delta<1$, there do exist bodies $Z$\nsatisfying the hypotheses of the theorem (in any space dimension).", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $S\\subset\\R^d$ be a bounded subset with positive Lebesgue measure. The\nPaley-Wiener space associated to $S$, $PW_S$, is defined to be the set of all\nsquare-integrable functions on $\\R^d$ whose Fourier transforms vanish outside\n$S$. A sequence $(x_j:j\\kin\\N)$ in $\\R^d$ is said to be a Riesz-basis sequence\nfor $L_2(S)$ (equivalently, a complete interpolating sequence for $PW_S$) if\nthe sequence $(e^{-i\\la x_j,\\cdot\\ra}:j\\kin\\N)$ of exponential functions forms\na Riesz basis for $L_2(S)$. Let $(x_j:j\\kin\\N)$ be a Riesz-basis sequence for\n$L_2(S)$. Given $\\lambda>0$ and $f\\in PW_S$, there is a unique sequence $(a_j)$\nin $\\ell_2$ such that the function $$\nI_\\lambda(f)(x):=\\sum_{j\\in\\N}a_je^{-\\lambda \\|x-x_j\\|_2^2}, \\qquad x\\kin\\R^d,\n$$ is continuous and square integrable on $\\R^d$, and satisfies the condition\n$I_\\lambda(f)(x_n)=f(x_n)$ for every $n\\kin\\N$. This paper studies the\nconvergence of the interpolant $I_\\lambda(f)$ as $\\lambda$ tends to zero, {\\it\ni.e.,\\} as the variance of the underlying Gaussian tends to infinity. The\nfollowing result is obtained: Let $\\delta\\in(\\sqrt{2/3},1]$ and\n$0<\\beta<\\sqrt{3\\delta^2 -2}$. Suppose that $\\delta B_2\\subset Z\\subset B_2$,\nand let $(x_j:j\\in\\N)$ be a Riesz basis sequence for $L_2(Z)$. If $f\\in\nPW_{\\beta B_2}$, then $f=\\lim_{\\lambda\\to 0^+} I_\\lambda(f)$ in $L_2(\\R^d)$ and\nuniformly on $\\R^d$. If $\\delta=1$, then one may take $\\beta$ to be 1 as well,\nand this reduces to a known theorem in the univariate case. However, if\n$d\\ge2$, it is not known whether $L_2(B_2)$ admits a Riesz-basis sequence. On\nthe other hand, in the case when $\\delta<1$, there do exist bodies $Z$\nsatisfying the hypotheses of the theorem (in any space dimension)."}, "authors": [{"name": "A. Bailey"}, {"name": "Th. Elton proved that every normalized weakly null sequence in a Banach space\nadmits a subsequence that is nearly unconditional which is a weak form of\nunconditionality. The notion of near-unconditionality is quantified by a\nconstant $K(\\delta)$ depending on a parameter $\\delta \\in (0,1]$. It is unknown\nif $\\sup_{\\delta>0} K(\\delta) < \\infty$. This problem turns out to be closely\nrelated to the question whether every infinite-dimensional Banach space\ncontains a quasi-greedy basic sequence. The notion of a quasi-greedy basic\nsequence was introduced recently by S. V. Konyagin and V. N. Temlyakov. We\npresent an extension of Elton's result which includes Schreier\nunconditionality. The proof involves a basic framework which we show can be\nalso employed to prove other partial unconditionality results including that of\nconvex unconditionality due to Argyros, Mercourakis and Tsarpalias. Various\nconstants of partial unconditionality are defined and we investigate the\nrelationships between them. We also explore the combinatorial problem\nunderlying the $\\sup_{\\delta>0} K(\\delta) < \\infty$ problem and show that\n$\\sup_{\\delta>0} K(\\delta) > 5/4$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "J. Elton proved that every normalized weakly null sequence in a Banach space\nadmits a subsequence that is nearly unconditional which is a weak form of\nunconditionality. The notion of near-unconditionality is quantified by a\nconstant $K(\\delta)$ depending on a parameter $\\delta \\in (0,1]$. It is unknown\nif $\\sup_{\\delta>0} K(\\delta) < \\infty$. This problem turns out to be closely\nrelated to the question whether every infinite-dimensional Banach space\ncontains a quasi-greedy basic sequence. The notion of a quasi-greedy basic\nsequence was introduced recently by S. V. Konyagin and V. N. Temlyakov. We\npresent an extension of Elton's result which includes Schreier\nunconditionality. The proof involves a basic framework which we show can be\nalso employed to prove other partial unconditionality results including that of\nconvex unconditionality due to Argyros, Mercourakis and Tsarpalias. Various\nconstants of partial unconditionality are defined and we investigate the\nrelationships between them. We also explore the combinatorial problem\nunderlying the $\\sup_{\\delta>0} K(\\delta) < \\infty$ problem and show that\n$\\sup_{\\delta>0} K(\\delta) > 5/4$."}, "authors": [{"name": "S. J. Dilworth"}, {"name": "E. Odell"}, {"name": "Th. Schlumprecht"}, {"name": "A. Zsak"}], "author_detail": {"name": "A. Zsak"}, "author": "A. We then show that every block sequence of the unit\nvector basis of S has a subsequence which spans a space isomorphic to its\nsquare. By the Pe{\\l}czy\\'nski decomposition method it follows that every basic\nsequence in S which spans a space complemented in S has a subsequence which\nspans a space isomorphic to S (i.e. S is a subsequentially prime space).", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We first include a result of the second author showing that the Banach space\nS is complementably minimal. A parallel section function (or\n(n-1)-dimensional X-ray) gives the ((n-1)-dimensional) volumes of all\nhyperplane sections of the body orthogonal to a given direction. This formula\nprovides a new characterization of intersection bodies in R^n and leads to a\nunified analytic solution to the Busemann-Petty problem: Suppose that K and L\nare two origin-symmetric convex bodies in R^n such that the ((n-1)-dimensional)\nvolume of each central hyperplane section of K is smaller than the volume of\nthe corresponding section of L; is the (n-dimensional) volume of K smaller than\nthe volume of L? In particular we\ngive an example of a reflexive $X$ so that all spreading models of $X$ contain\n$\\ell_1$ but none of them is isomorphic to $\\ell_1$. We also prove that for any\ncountable set $C$ of spreading models generated by weakly null sequences there\nis a spreading model generated by a weakly null sequence which dominates each\nelement of $C$.
