A key step in establishing such\nresults for multiple and clustered eigenvalues was provided by Dai et. al.\n(2014), who proved convergence and optimality of AFEM for eigenvalues of\nmultiplicity greater than one. There it was shown that a theoretical\n(non-computable) error estimator for which standard convergence proofs apply is\nequivalent to a standard computable estimator on sufficiently fine grids.\nGallistl (2015) used a similar tool in order to prove that a standard adaptive\nFEM for controlling eigenvalue clusters for the Laplacian using continuous\npiecewise linear finite element spaces converges with optimal rate. When\nconsidering either higher-order finite element spaces or non-constant diffusion\ncoefficients, however, the arguments of Dai et. al. and Gallistl do not yield\nequivalence of the practical and theoretical estimators for clustered\neigenvalues. In this note we provide this missing key step, thus showing that\nstandard adaptive FEM for clustered eigenvalues employing elements of arbitrary\npolynomial degree converge with optimal rate. We additionally establish that a\nkey user-defined input parameter in the AFEM, the bulk marking parameter, may\nbe chosen entirely independently of the properties of the target eigenvalue\ncluster. All of these results assume a fineness condition on the initial mesh\nin order to ensure that the nonlinearity is sufficiently resolved.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Proofs of convergence of adaptive finite element methods for the\napproximation of eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of linear elliptic problems\nhave been given in a several recent papers. A key step in establishing such\nresults for multiple and clustered eigenvalues was provided by Dai et. al.\n(2014), who proved convergence and optimality of AFEM for eigenvalues of\nmultiplicity greater than one. There it was shown that a theoretical\n(non-computable) error estimator for which standard convergence proofs apply is\nequivalent to a standard computable estimator on sufficiently fine grids.\nGallistl (2015) used a similar tool in order to prove that a standard adaptive\nFEM for controlling eigenvalue clusters for the Laplacian using continuous\npiecewise linear finite element spaces converges with optimal rate. When\nconsidering either higher-order finite element spaces or non-constant diffusion\ncoefficients, however, the arguments of Dai et. al. and Gallistl do not yield\nequivalence of the practical and theoretical estimators for clustered\neigenvalues. In this note we provide this missing key step, thus showing that\nstandard adaptive FEM for clustered eigenvalues employing elements of arbitrary\npolynomial degree converge with optimal rate. We additionally establish that a\nkey user-defined input parameter in the AFEM, the bulk marking parameter, may\nbe chosen entirely independently of the properties of the target eigenvalue\ncluster. All of these results assume a fineness condition on the initial mesh\nin order to ensure that the nonlinearity is sufficiently resolved."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Alan Demlow"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Alan Demlow"}, "author": "Alan Demlow", "arxiv_comment": "10 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.06265v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1508.06265v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65N12, 65N15, 65N25, 65N30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0808.2160v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0808.2160v1", "updated": "2008-08-15T16:04:14Z", "updated_parsed": [2008, 8, 15, 16, 4, 14, 4, 228, 0], "published": "2008-08-15T16:04:14Z", "published_parsed": [2008, 8, 15, 16, 4, 14, 4, 228, 0], "title": "Local energy estimates for the finite element method on sharply varying\n  grids", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Local energy estimates for the finite element method on sharply varying\n  grids"}, "summary": "Local energy error estimates for the finite element method for elliptic\nproblems were originally proved in 1974 by Nitsche and Schatz. These estimates\nshow that the local energy error may be bounded by a local approximation term,\nplus a global \"pollution\" term that measures the influence of solution quality\nfrom outside the domain of interest and is heuristically of higher order.\nHowever, the original analysis of Nitsche and Schatz is restricted to\nquasi-uniform grids. We present local a priori energy estimates that are valid\non shape regular grids, an assumption which allows for highly graded meshes and\nwhich much more closely matches the typical practical situation. Our chief\ntechnical innovation is an improved superapproximation result.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Local energy error estimates for the finite element method for elliptic\nproblems were originally proved in 1974 by Nitsche and Schatz. These estimates\nshow that the local energy error may be bounded by a local approximation term,\nplus a global \"pollution\" term that measures the influence of solution quality\nfrom outside the domain of interest and is heuristically of higher order.\nHowever, the original analysis of Nitsche and Schatz is restricted to\nquasi-uniform grids. We present local a priori energy estimates that are valid\non shape regular grids, an assumption which allows for highly graded meshes and\nwhich much more closely matches the typical practical situation. Our chief\ntechnical innovation is an improved superapproximation result."}, "authors": [{"name": "Alan Demlow"}, {"name": "Johnny Guzman"}, {"name": "Alfred H. Schatz"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Alfred H. Schatz"}, "author": "Alfred H. The finite element exterior calculus\nframework also relies extensively on accurate computation of harmonic forms. In\nthis work we study the convergence properties of adaptive finite element\nmethods (AFEM) for computing harmonic forms. We show that a properly defined\nAFEM is contractive and achieves optimal convergence rate beginning from any\ninitial conforming mesh. This result is contrasted with related AFEM\nconvergence results for elliptic eigenvalue problems, where the initial mesh\nmust be sufficiently fine in order for AFEM to achieve any provable convergence\nrate.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Numerical computation of harmonic forms (typically called harmonic fields in\nthree space dimensions) arises in various areas, including computer graphics\nand computational electromagnetics. The finite element exterior calculus\nframework also relies extensively on accurate computation of harmonic forms. In\nthis work we study the convergence properties of adaptive finite element\nmethods (AFEM) for computing harmonic forms. We show that a properly defined\nAFEM is contractive and achieves optimal convergence rate beginning from any\ninitial conforming mesh. This result is contrasted with related AFEM\nconvergence results for elliptic eigenvalue problems, where the initial mesh\nmust be sufficiently fine in order for AFEM to achieve any provable convergence\nrate."}, "authors": [{"name": "Alan Demlow"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Alan Demlow"}, "author": "Alan Demlow", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1605.08813v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1605.08813v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65N15, 65N30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1203.0803v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1203.0803v3", "updated": "2012-12-18T16:42:48Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 12, 18, 16, 42, 48, 1, 353, 0], "published": "2012-03-05T02:20:05Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 3, 5, 2, 20, 5, 0, 65, 0], "title": "A posteriori error estimates for finite element exterior calculus: The\n  de Rham complex", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A posteriori error estimates for finite element exterior calculus: The\n  de Rham complex"}, "summary": "Finite element exterior calculus (FEEC) has been developed over the past\ndecade as a framework for constructing and analyzing stable and accurate\nnumerical methods for partial differential equations by employing differential\ncomplexes. The recent work of Arnold, Falk and Winther \\cite{ArFaWi2010}\nincludes a well-developed theory of finite element methods for Hodge Laplace\nproblems, including a priori error estimates. In this work we focus on\ndeveloping a posteriori error estimates in which the computational error is\nbounded by some computable functional of the discrete solution and problem\ndata. More precisely, we prove a posteriori error estimates of residual type\nfor Arnold-Falk-Winther mixed finite element methods for Hodge-de Rham Laplace\nproblems. While a number of previous works consider a posteriori error\nestimation for Maxwell's equations and mixed formulations of the scalar\nLaplacian, the approach we take is distinguished by unified treatment of the\nvarious Hodge Laplace problems arising in the de Rham complex, consistent use\nof the language and analytical framework of differential forms, and the\ndevelopment of a posteriori error estimates for harmonic forms and the effects\nof their approximation on the resulting numerical method for the Hodge\nLaplacian.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Finite element exterior calculus (FEEC) has been developed over the past\ndecade as a framework for constructing and analyzing stable and accurate\nnumerical methods for partial differential equations by employing differential\ncomplexes. The recent work of Arnold, Falk and Winther \\cite{ArFaWi2010}\nincludes a well-developed theory of finite element methods for Hodge Laplace\nproblems, including a priori error estimates. In this work we focus on\ndeveloping a posteriori error estimates in which the computational error is\nbounded by some computable functional of the discrete solution and problem\ndata. More precisely, we prove a posteriori error estimates of residual type\nfor Arnold-Falk-Winther mixed finite element methods for Hodge-de Rham Laplace\nproblems. While a number of previous works consider a posteriori error\nestimation for Maxwell's equations and mixed formulations of the scalar\nLaplacian, the approach we take is distinguished by unified treatment of the\nvarious Hodge Laplace problems arising in the de Rham complex, consistent use\nof the language and analytical framework of differential forms, and the\ndevelopment of a posteriori error estimates for harmonic forms and the effects\nof their approximation on the resulting numerical method for the Hodge\nLaplacian."}, "authors": [{"name": "Alan Demlow"}, {"name": "Anil N. Goodenough, the\nmaestro who transformed energy usage and technology through the invention of\nthe lithium ion battery, opens the programme, reflecting on the ultimate limits\nof battery technology. This applied theme continues through the subsequent\npieces on energy related topics (the sodium ion battery and artificial fuels,\nby Mansson) and the ultimate challenge for 3 dimensional printing the eventual\nproduction of life, by Atala. A passage by Alexander follows, reflecting on a\nrelated issue: How might an artificially produced human being behave? Next\ncomes a consideration of consiousness and free will by Allen and Lidstrom.\nFurther voices and new instruments enter as Bowen, Mauranyapin and Madsen\ndiscuss whether dynamical processes of single molecules might be observed in\ntheir native state. The exploitation of chaos in science and technology,\napplications of Bose Einstein condensates and a consideration of the\nsignificance of entropy follow in pieces by Reichl, Rasel and Allen,\nrespectively. Katsnelson and Koonin then discuss the potential generalisation\nof thermodynamic concepts in the context of biological evolution. Entering with\nthe music of the cosmos, Yasskin discusses whether we might be able to observe\ntorsion in the geometry of the universe. The crescendo comes with the crisis of\nsingularities, their nature and whether they can be resolved through quantum\neffects, in the composition of Coley. Consider the automorphic\nforms for such a triangle group whose power series expansions in the natural\nparameter have algebraic coefficients. We show that the zeros of such forms are\neither transcendental or are \"CM.\" By \"CM,\" we mean they correspond to abelian\nvarieties with complex multiplication. This result is the first of its kind in\nthe case of non-arithmetic groups."}, "authors": [{"name": "Paula Tretkoff"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Paula Tretkoff"}, "author": "Paula Tretkoff", "arxiv_comment": "6 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1809.09656v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1809.09656v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0910.0188v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0910.0188v1", "updated": "2009-10-01T14:32:30Z", "updated_parsed": [2009, 10, 1, 14, 32, 30, 3, 274, 0], "published": "2009-10-01T14:32:30Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 10, 1, 14, 32, 30, 3, 274, 0], "title": "The Gauss-Bonnet Theorem for the noncommutative two torus", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The Gauss-Bonnet Theorem for the noncommutative two torus"}, "summary": "In this paper we show that the value at zero of the zeta function of the\nLaplacian on the non-commutative two torus, endowed with its canonical\nconformal structure, is independent of the choice of the volume element (Weyl\nfactor) given by a (non-unimodular) state. We had obtained, in the late\neighties, in an unpublished computation, a general formula for this value at\nzero involving modified logarithms of the modular operator of the state. We\ngive here the detailed computation and prove that the result is independent of\nthe Weyl factor as in the classical case, thus proving the analogue of the\nGauss-Bonnet theorem for the noncommutative two torus.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper we show that the value at zero of the zeta function of the\nLaplacian on the non-commutative two torus, endowed with its canonical\nconformal structure, is independent of the choice of the volume element (Weyl\nfactor) given by a (non-unimodular) state. We had obtained, in the late\neighties, in an unpublished computation, a general formula for this value at\nzero involving modified logarithms of the modular operator of the state. We\ngive here the detailed computation and prove that the result is independent of\nthe Weyl factor as in the classical case, thus proving the analogue of the\nGauss-Bonnet theorem for the noncommutative two torus."}, "authors": [{"name": "Alain Connes"}, {"name": "Paula Tretkoff"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Paula Tretkoff"}, "author": "Paula Tretkoff", "arxiv_comment": "17 pages, 1 Figure", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0910.0188v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0910.0188v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.QA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.QA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L87; 58B34", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.06342v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.06342v3", "updated": "2016-08-05T09:52:07Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 8, 5, 9, 52, 7, 4, 218, 0], "published": "2016-02-19T22:59:27Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 2, 19, 22, 59, 27, 4, 50, 0], "title": "Data Assimilation and Sampling in Banach spaces", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Data Assimilation and Sampling in Banach spaces"}, "summary": "This paper studies the problem of approximating a function $f$ in a Banach\nspace $X$ from measurements $l_j(f)$, $j=1,\\dots,m$, where the $l_j$ are linear\nfunctionals from $X^*$. Most results study this problem for classical Banach\nspaces $X$ such as the $L_p$ spaces, $1\\le p\\le \\infty$, and for $K$ the unit\nball of a smoothness space in $X$. Our interest in this paper is in the model\nclasses $K=K(\\epsilon,V)$, with $\\epsilon>0$ and $V$ a finite dimensional\nsubspace of $X$, which consists of all $f\\in X$ such that $dist(f,V)_X\\le\n\\epsilon$. These model classes, called {\\it approximation sets}, arise\nnaturally in application domains such as parametric partial differential\nequations, uncertainty quantification, and signal processing.\n  A general theory for the recovery of approximation sets in a Banach space is\ngiven. This theory includes tight a priori bounds on optimal performance, and\nalgorithms for finding near optimal approximations. We show how the recovery\nproblem for approximation sets is connected with well-studied concepts in\nBanach space theory such as liftings and the angle between spaces. Examples are\ngiven that show how this theory can be used to recover several recent results\non sampling and data assimilation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper studies the problem of approximating a function $f$ in a Banach\nspace $X$ from measurements $l_j(f)$, $j=1,\\dots,m$, where the $l_j$ are linear\nfunctionals from $X^*$. Most results study this problem for classical Banach\nspaces $X$ such as the $L_p$ spaces, $1\\le p\\le \\infty$, and for $K$ the unit\nball of a smoothness space in $X$. Our interest in this paper is in the model\nclasses $K=K(\\epsilon,V)$, with $\\epsilon>0$ and $V$ a finite dimensional\nsubspace of $X$, which consists of all $f\\in X$ such that $dist(f,V)_X\\le\n\\epsilon$. These model classes, called {\\it approximation sets}, arise\nnaturally in application domains such as parametric partial differential\nequations, uncertainty quantification, and signal processing.\n  A general theory for the recovery of approximation sets in a Banach space is\ngiven. This theory includes tight a priori bounds on optimal performance, and\nalgorithms for finding near optimal approximations. We show how the recovery\nproblem for approximation sets is connected with well-studied concepts in\nBanach space theory such as liftings and the angle between spaces. Examples are\ngiven that show how this theory can be used to recover several recent results\non sampling and data assimilation."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ronald DeVore"}, {"name": "Guergana Petrova"}, {"name": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk"}, "author": "Przemyslaw Wojtaszczyk", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.06342v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.06342v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1204.2290v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1204.2290v1", "updated": "2012-04-10T21:45:16Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 4, 10, 21, 45, 16, 1, 101, 0], "published": "2012-04-10T21:45:16Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 4, 10, 21, 45, 16, 1, 101, 0], "title": "Greedy Algorithms for Reduced Bases in Banach Spaces", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Greedy Algorithms for Reduced Bases in Banach Spaces"}, "summary": "Given a Banach space X and one of its compact sets F, we consider the problem\nof finding a good n dimensional space X_n \\subset X which can be used to\napproximate the elements of F. The best possible error we can achieve for such\nan approximation is given by the Kolmogorov width d_n(F)_X. However, finding\nthe space which gives this performance is typically numerically intractable.\nRecently, a new greedy strategy for obtaining good spaces was given in the\ncontext of the reduced basis method for solving a parametric family of PDEs.\nThe performance of this greedy algorithm was initially analyzed in A. Buffa, Y.\nMaday, A.T. Patera, C. Prud'homme, and G. Turinici, \"A Priori convergence of\nthe greedy algorithm for the parameterized reduced basis\", M2AN Math. Model.\nNumer. Anal., 46(2012), 595-603 in the case X = H is a Hilbert space. The\nresults there were significantly improved on in P. Binev, A. Cohen, W. Dahmen,\nR. DeVore, G. Petrova, and P. The best possible error we can achieve for such\nan approximation is given by the Kolmogorov width d_n(F)_X. However, finding\nthe space which gives this performance is typically numerically intractable.\nRecently, a new greedy strategy for obtaining good spaces was given in the\ncontext of the reduced basis method for solving a parametric family of PDEs.\nThe performance of this greedy algorithm was initially analyzed in A. Buffa, Y.\nMaday, A.T. Patera, C. Prud'homme, and G. Turinici, \"A Priori convergence of\nthe greedy algorithm for the parameterized reduced basis\", M2AN Math. Model.\nNumer. "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Diffusion Coefficients Estimation for Elliptic Partial Differential\n  Equations"}, "summary": "This paper considers the Dirichlet problem $$ -\\mathrm{div}(a\\nabla u_a)=f\n\\quad \\hbox{on}\\,\\,\\ D, \\qquad u_a=0\\quad \\hbox{on}\\,\\,\\partial D, $$ for a\nLipschitz domain $D\\subset \\mathbb R^d$, where $a$ is a scalar diffusion\nfunction. For a fixed $f$, we discuss under which conditions is $a$ uniquely\ndetermined and when can $a$ be stably recovered from the knowledge of $u_a$.\n  A first result is that whenever $a\\in H^1(D)$, with $0<\\lambda \\le a\\le\n\\Lambda$ on $D$, and $f\\in L_\\infty(D)$ is strictly positive, then $$\n\\|a-b\\|_{L_2(D)}\\le C\\|u_a-u_b\\|_{H_0^1(D)}^{1/6}. $$ More generally, it is\nshown that the assumption $a\\in H^1(D)$ can be weakened to $a\\in H^s(D)$, for\ncertain $s<1$, at the expense of lowering the exponent $1/6$ to a value that\ndepends on $s$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper considers the Dirichlet problem $$ -\\mathrm{div}(a\\nabla u_a)=f\n\\quad \\hbox{on}\\,\\,\\ D, \\qquad u_a=0\\quad \\hbox{on}\\,\\,\\partial D, $$ for a\nLipschitz domain $D\\subset \\mathbb R^d$, where $a$ is a scalar diffusion\nfunction. Working in 1+1D, we find that two main\neffects occur: First, the Casimir energy density experiences a tidal effect\nwhere negative energy is pushed toward the plates and the resulting force\nexperienced by the plates is increased. Second, the process of falling is\ninherently nonequilibrium and we treat it as such, demonstrating that the\nCasimir energy density moves back and forth between the plates after being\n\"dropped,'' with the force modulating in synchrony. In this way, the Casimir\nenergy behaves as a classical liquid might, putting (negative) pressure on the\nwalls as it moves about in its container. In particular, we consider this in\nthe context of a black hole and the multiple vacua that can be achieved outside\nof the apparatus.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this work, we consider a Casimir apparatus that is put into free fall\n(e.g., falling into a black hole). Working in 1+1D, we find that two main\neffects occur: First, the Casimir energy density experiences a tidal effect\nwhere negative energy is pushed toward the plates and the resulting force\nexperienced by the plates is increased. Second, the process of falling is\ninherently nonequilibrium and we treat it as such, demonstrating that the\nCasimir energy density moves back and forth between the plates after being\n\"dropped,'' with the force modulating in synchrony. In this way, the Casimir\nenergy behaves as a classical liquid might, putting (negative) pressure on the\nwalls as it moves about in its container. We argue that the analogy between\nthese systems is more than superficial: There is a sense in which a \"UD\ndetector\" in a quantized scalar field effectively acts as a classical source\nfor that field if the splitting of its energy levels is so small as to be\nignored. After showing explicitly that a detector with unresolved inner\nstructure does behave as a structureless scalar source, we use that analysis to\nrederive the scalar version of a previous analysis of the accelerated\nelectromagnetic charge, without appealing to the troublesome concept of\n\"zero-energy particles.\" Then we recover these results when the detector energy\ngap is taken to be zero from the beginning. This vindicates the informal\nterminology \"zero-frequency Rindler modes\" as a shorthand for \"Rindler modes\nwith arbitrarily small energy.\" In an appendix, the mathematical behavior of\nthe normal modes in the limit of small frequency is examined in more detail\nthan before. We argue that the analogy between\nthese systems is more than superficial: There is a sense in which a \"UD\ndetector\" in a quantized scalar field effectively acts as a classical source\nfor that field if the splitting of its energy levels is so small as to be\nignored. After showing explicitly that a detector with unresolved inner\nstructure does behave as a structureless scalar source, we use that analysis to\nrederive the scalar version of a previous analysis of the accelerated\nelectromagnetic charge, without appealing to the troublesome concept of\n\"zero-energy particles.\" Then we recover these results when the detector energy\ngap is taken to be zero from the beginning. Fulling", "arxiv_comment": "4 pages; plain TeX with vanilla.sty and pictex.tex macros", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/9911050v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/quant-ph/9911050v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0508335v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0508335v1", "updated": "2005-08-17T20:12:49Z", "updated_parsed": [2005, 8, 17, 20, 12, 49, 2, 229, 0], "published": "2005-08-17T20:12:49Z", "published_parsed": [2005, 8, 17, 20, 12, 49, 2, 229, 0], "title": "Local Spectral Density and Vacuum Energy near a Quantum Graph Vertex", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Local Spectral Density and Vacuum Energy near a Quantum Graph Vertex"}, "summary": "The delta interaction at a vertex generalizes the Robin (generalized Neumann)\nboundary condition on an interval. Study of a single vertex with N infinite\nleads suffices to determine the localized effects of such a vertex on densities\nof states, etc. For all the standard initial-value problems, such as that for\nthe wave equation, the pertinent integral kernel (Green function) on the graph\ncan be easily constructed from the corresponding elementary Green function on\nthe real line. From the results one obtains the spectral-projection kernel,\nlocal spectral density, and local energy density. The energy density, which\nrefers to an interpretation of the graph as the domain of a quantized scalar\nfield, is a coefficient in the asymptotic expansion of the Green function for\nan elliptic problem involving the graph Hamiltonian; that expansion contains\nspectral/geometrical information beyond that in the much-studied heat-kernel\nexpansion.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The delta interaction at a vertex generalizes the Robin (generalized Neumann)\nboundary condition on an interval. Study of a single vertex with N infinite\nleads suffices to determine the localized effects of such a vertex on densities\nof states, etc. For all the standard initial-value problems, such as that for\nthe wave equation, the pertinent integral kernel (Green function) on the graph\ncan be easily constructed from the corresponding elementary Green function on\nthe real line. From the results one obtains the spectral-projection kernel,\nlocal spectral density, and local energy density. We\nshow that atoms falling into a black hole emit acceleration radiation which,\nunder appropriate initial conditions (Boulware vacuum), has an energy spectrum\nwhich looks much like Hawking radiation. This analysis also provides insight\ninto the Einstein principle of equivalence between acceleration and gravity.\nThe Unruh temperature can also be obtained by using the Kubo--Martin--Schwinger\n(KMS) periodicity of the two-point thermal correlation function, for a system\nundergoing uniform acceleration; as with much of the material in this paper,\nthis known result is obtained with a twist.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "When ground-state atoms are accelerated and the field with which they\ninteract is in its normal vacuum state, the atoms detect Unruh radiation. We\nshow that atoms falling into a black hole emit acceleration radiation which,\nunder appropriate initial conditions (Boulware vacuum), has an energy spectrum\nwhich looks much like Hawking radiation. This analysis also provides insight\ninto the Einstein principle of equivalence between acceleration and gravity.\nThe Unruh temperature can also be obtained by using the Kubo--Martin--Schwinger\n(KMS) periodicity of the two-point thermal correlation function, for a system\nundergoing uniform acceleration; as with much of the material in this paper,\nthis known result is obtained with a twist."}, "authors": [{"name": "J. It is also well known\nthat the latter expansions are generally not literally true beyond the first\nterm. However, the terms in the heat-kernel expansion correspond rigorously to\nquantities called Riesz means of the spectral expansion, which damp out\noscillations in the spectral density at high frequencies by dint of performing\nan average over the density at all lower frequencies. In general, a change of\nvariables leads to new Riesz means that contain different information from the\nold ones. In particular, for the standard second-order elliptic operators,\nRiesz means with respect to the square root of the spectral parameter\ncorrespond to terms in the asymptotics of elliptic and hyperbolic Green\nfunctions associated with the operator, and these quantities contain \"nonlocal\"\ninformation not contained in the usual Riesz means and their correlates in the\nheat kernel. Here the relationship between these two sets of Riesz means is\nworked out in detail; this involves just classical one-dimensional analysis and\ncalculation, with no substantive input from spectral theory or quantum field\ntheory. This work provides a general framework for calculations that are often\ncarried out piecemeal (and without precise understanding of their rigorous\nmeaning) in the physics literature.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "It is well known that short-time expansions of heat kernels correlate to\nformal high-frequency expansions of spectral densities. It is also well known\nthat the latter expansions are generally not literally true beyond the first\nterm. However, the terms in the heat-kernel expansion correspond rigorously to\nquantities called Riesz means of the spectral expansion, which damp out\noscillations in the spectral density at high frequencies by dint of performing\nan average over the density at all lower frequencies. In general, a change of\nvariables leads to new Riesz means that contain different information from the\nold ones. In particular, for the standard second-order elliptic operators,\nRiesz means with respect to the square root of the spectral parameter\ncorrespond to terms in the asymptotics of elliptic and hyperbolic Green\nfunctions associated with the operator, and these quantities contain \"nonlocal\"\ninformation not contained in the usual Riesz means and their correlates in the\nheat kernel. Here the relationship between these two sets of Riesz means is\nworked out in detail; this involves just classical one-dimensional analysis and\ncalculation, with no substantive input from spectral theory or quantum field\ntheory. This work provides a general framework for calculations that are often\ncarried out piecemeal (and without precise understanding of their rigorous\nmeaning) in the physics literature."}, "authors": [{"name": "S. A. Fulling"}], "author_detail": {"name": "S. A. Fulling"}, "author": "S. A. Fulling", "arxiv_comment": "35 pages, REVTeX", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Electronic J. Diff. One of the most striking is that the Larmor radiation\nemitted by a charge can be seen as a consequence of the Unruh thermal bath.\nIndeed, this connection between the Unruh effect and classical bremsstrahlung\nwas used recently to propose an experiment to confirm (as directly as possible)\nthe existence of the Unruh thermal bath. This situation may sound puzzling in\ntwo ways: first, because the Unruh effect is a strictly quantum effect while\nLarmor radiation is a classical one, and second, because of the crucial role\nplayed by zero-frequency Rindler photons in this context. In this paper we\nsettle these two issues by showing how the quantum evolution leads naturally to\nall relevant aspects of Larmor radiation and, especially, how the corresponding\nclassical radiation is entirely built from such zero-Rindler-energy modes.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The interplay between acceleration and radiation harbors remarkable and\nsurprising consequences. One of the most striking is that the Larmor radiation\nemitted by a charge can be seen as a consequence of the Unruh thermal bath.\nIndeed, this connection between the Unruh effect and classical bremsstrahlung\nwas used recently to propose an experiment to confirm (as directly as possible)\nthe existence of the Unruh thermal bath. This situation may sound puzzling in\ntwo ways: first, because the Unruh effect is a strictly quantum effect while\nLarmor radiation is a classical one, and second, because of the crucial role\nplayed by zero-frequency Rindler photons in this context. In this paper we\nsettle these two issues by showing how the quantum evolution leads naturally to\nall relevant aspects of Larmor radiation and, especially, how the corresponding\nclassical radiation is entirely built from such zero-Rindler-energy modes."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andre G. S. Landulfo"}, {"name": "Stephen A. Fulling"}, {"name": "George E. A. Matsas"}], "author_detail": {"name": "George E. A. Matsas"}, "author": "George E. A. Matsas", "arxiv_doi": "10.1103/PhysRevD.100.045020", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevD.100.045020", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1907.06665v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1907.06665v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "7 pages, 1 figure", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Phys. Rev. D 100, 045020 (2019)", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "gr-qc", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "gr-qc", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "hep-th", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/funct-an/9710003v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/funct-an/9710003v2", "updated": "1998-03-06T21:03:57Z", "updated_parsed": [1998, 3, 6, 21, 3, 57, 4, 65, 0], "published": "1997-10-21T14:04:37Z", "published_parsed": [1997, 10, 21, 14, 4, 37, 1, 294, 0], "title": "Distributional Asymptotic Expansions of Spectral Functions and of the\n  Associated Green Kernels", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Distributional Asymptotic Expansions of Spectral Functions and of the\n  Associated Green Kernels"}, "summary": "Asymptotic expansions of Green functions and spectral densities associated\nwith partial differential operators are widely applied in quantum field theory\nand elsewhere. The mathematical properties of these expansions can be clarified\nand more precisely determined by means of tools from distribution theory and\nsummability theory. (These are the same, insofar as recently the classic\nCesaro-Riesz theory of summability of series and integrals has been given a\ndistributional interpretation.) When applied to the spectral analysis of Green\nfunctions (which are then to be expanded as series in a parameter, usually the\ntime), these methods show: (1) The \"local\" or \"global\" dependence of the\nexpansion coefficients on the background geometry, etc., is determined by the\nregularity of the asymptotic expansion of the integrand at the origin (in\n\"frequency space\"); this marks the difference between a heat kernel and a\nWightman two-point function, for instance. (2) The behavior of the integrand at\ninfinity determines whether the expansion of the Green function is genuinely\nasymptotic in the literal, pointwise sense, or is merely valid in a\ndistributional (cesaro-averaged) sense; this is the difference between the heat\nkernel and the Schrodinger kernel. (3) The high-frequency expansion of the\nspectral density itself is local in a distributional sense (but not pointwise).\nThese observations make rigorous sense out of calculations in the physics\nliterature that are sometimes dismissed as merely formal.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Asymptotic expansions of Green functions and spectral densities associated\nwith partial differential operators are widely applied in quantum field theory\nand elsewhere. The mathematical properties of these expansions can be clarified\nand more precisely determined by means of tools from distribution theory and\nsummability theory. (These are the same, insofar as recently the classic\nCesaro-Riesz theory of summability of series and integrals has been given a\ndistributional interpretation.) When applied to the spectral analysis of Green\nfunctions (which are then to be expanded as series in a parameter, usually the\ntime), these methods show: (1) The \"local\" or \"global\" dependence of the\nexpansion coefficients on the background geometry, etc., is determined by the\nregularity of the asymptotic expansion of the integrand at the origin (in\n\"frequency space\"); this marks the difference between a heat kernel and a\nWightman two-point function, for instance. (2) The behavior of the integrand at\ninfinity determines whether the expansion of the Green function is genuinely\nasymptotic in the literal, pointwise sense, or is merely valid in a\ndistributional (cesaro-averaged) sense; this is the difference between the heat\nkernel and the Schrodinger kernel. (3) The high-frequency expansion of the\nspectral density itself is local in a distributional sense (but not pointwise).\nThese observations make rigorous sense out of calculations in the physics\nliterature that are sometimes dismissed as merely formal."}, "authors": [{"name": "R. This analysis also provides insight\ninto the Einstein principle of equivalence between acceleration and gravity.\nThe Unruh temperature can also be obtained by using the Kubo--Martin--Schwinger\n(KMS) periodicity of the two-point thermal correlation function, for a system\nundergoing uniform acceleration; as with much of the material in this paper,\nthis known result is obtained with a twist."}, "authors": [{"name": "J. The divergences in\nthe stress tensor of a quantized scalar field interacting with a static scalar\npotential are isolated into a three-parameter local, covariant functional of\nthe background potential. These divergences can be naturally absorbed into\ncoupling constants of the potential, regarded as a dynamical object in its own\nright; here this is demonstrated in detail for two different models of the\nfield-potential coupling. here is a residual dependence on the logarithm of the\npotential, reminiscent of the renormalization group in fully interacting\nquantum field theories; these terms are finite but numerically dependent on an\narbitrary mass or length parameter, which is purely a matter of convention.\nThis work is one step in a program to elucidate boundary divergences by\nreplacing a sharp boundary by a steeply rising smooth potential.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The Pauli--Villars regularization procedure confirms and sharpens the\nconclusions reached previously by covariant point splitting. As an application\nwe give the first examples for which the volume conjecture of Chen and the\nthird named author\\,\\cite{Chen-Yang} is verified. Namely, we show that the\nasymptotics of the Turaev-Viro invariants of the Figure-eight knot and the\nBorromean rings complement determine the corresponding hyperbolic volumes. Our\ncalculations also exhibit new phenomena of asymptotic behavior of values of the\ncolored Jones polynomials that seem not to be predicted by neither the\nKashaev-Murakami-Murakami volume conjecture and various of its generalizations\nnor by Zagier's quantum modularity conjecture. Our method\nis nonconforming and uses a localized Lagrange basis that is constructed out of\nradial basis functions. By verifying that certain inf-sup conditions hold, we\ndemonstrate that both the continuous and discrete problems are well-posed, and\nalso present numerical and theoretical results for the convergence behavior of\nthe method. The stiffness matrix is assembled by a special quadrature routine\nunique to the localized basis. Combining the quadrature method with the\nlocalized basis produces a well-conditioned, symmetric matrix. This then is\nused to find the discretized solution.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We introduce a meshless method for solving both continuous and discrete\nvariational formulations of a volume constrained, nonlocal diffusion problem.\nWe use the discrete solution to approximate the continuous solution. Our method\nis nonconforming and uses a localized Lagrange basis that is constructed out of\nradial basis functions. By verifying that certain inf-sup conditions hold, we\ndemonstrate that both the continuous and discrete problems are well-posed, and\nalso present numerical and theoretical results for the convergence behavior of\nthe method. The stiffness matrix is assembled by a special quadrature routine\nunique to the localized basis. Combining the quadrature method with the\nlocalized basis produces a well-conditioned, symmetric matrix. This then is\nused to find the discretized solution."}, "authors": [{"name": "Richard B. Lehoucq"}, {"name": "Francis J. Narcowich"}, {"name": "Stephen T. Rowe"}, {"name": "Joseph D. Ward"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Joseph D. Ward"}, "author": "Joseph D. Ward", "arxiv_comment": "23 pages, 2, figures, submitted to Math Comp", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.02717v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1601.02717v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1205.3255v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1205.3255v1", "updated": "2012-05-15T04:23:10Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 5, 15, 4, 23, 10, 1, 136, 0], "published": "2012-05-15T04:23:10Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 5, 15, 4, 23, 10, 1, 136, 0], "title": "Localized bases for kernel spaces on the unit sphere", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Localized bases for kernel spaces on the unit sphere"}, "summary": "Approximation/interpolation from spaces of positive definite or conditionally\npositive definite kernels is an increasingly popular tool for the analysis and\nsynthesis of scattered data, and is central to many meshless methods. For a set\nof $N$ scattered sites, the standard basis for such a space utilizes $N$\n\\emph{globally} supported kernels; computing with it is prohibitively expensive\nfor large $N$. Easily computable, well-localized bases, with \"small-footprint\"\nbasis elements - i.e., elements using only a small number of kernels -- have\nbeen unavailable. Working on $\\sphere$, with focus on the restricted surface\nspline kernels (e.g. the thin-plate splines restricted to the sphere), we\nconstruct easily computable, spatially well-localized, small-footprint, robust\nbases for the associated kernel spaces. Our theory predicts that each element\nof the local basis is constructed by using a combination of only\n$\\mathcal{O}((\\log N)^2)$ kernels, which makes the construction computationally\ncheap. We prove that the new basis is $L_p$ stable and satisfies polynomial\ndecay estimates that are stationary with respect to the density of the data\nsites, and we present a quasi-interpolation scheme that provides optimal $L_p$\napproximation orders. Although our focus is on $\\mathbb{S}^2$, much of the\ntheory applies to other manifolds - $\\mathbb{S}^d$, the rotation group, and so\non. Finally, we construct algorithms to implement these schemes and use them to\nconduct numerical experiments, which validate our theory for interpolation\nproblems on $\\mathbb{S}^2$ involving over one hundred fifty thousand data\nsites.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Approximation/interpolation from spaces of positive definite or conditionally\npositive definite kernels is an increasingly popular tool for the analysis and\nsynthesis of scattered data, and is central to many meshless methods. For a set\nof $N$ scattered sites, the standard basis for such a space utilizes $N$\n\\emph{globally} supported kernels; computing with it is prohibitively expensive\nfor large $N$. Easily computable, well-localized bases, with \"small-footprint\"\nbasis elements - i.e., elements using only a small number of kernels -- have\nbeen unavailable. Working on $\\sphere$, with focus on the restricted surface\nspline kernels (e.g. the thin-plate splines restricted to the sphere), we\nconstruct easily computable, spatially well-localized, small-footprint, robust\nbases for the associated kernel spaces. Our theory predicts that each element\nof the local basis is constructed by using a combination of only\n$\\mathcal{O}((\\log N)^2)$ kernels, which makes the construction computationally\ncheap. We prove that the new basis is $L_p$ stable and satisfies polynomial\ndecay estimates that are stationary with respect to the density of the data\nsites, and we present a quasi-interpolation scheme that provides optimal $L_p$\napproximation orders. Although our focus is on $\\mathbb{S}^2$, much of the\ntheory applies to other manifolds - $\\mathbb{S}^d$, the rotation group, and so\non. Finally, we construct algorithms to implement these schemes and use them to\nconduct numerical experiments, which validate our theory for interpolation\nproblems on $\\mathbb{S}^2$ involving over one hundred fifty thousand data\nsites."}, "authors": [{"name": "E. A quasi-interpolation scheme is introduced that provides\n  optimal linear convergence rates", "arxiv_journal_ref": "SIAM J. Numer. Anal. 51-5 (2013), pp. 2538-2562", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "41A05, 41A30, 41A63, 65D05", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0909.0033v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0909.0033v2", "updated": "2010-05-13T21:05:01Z", "updated_parsed": [2010, 5, 13, 21, 5, 1, 3, 133, 0], "published": "2009-08-31T20:30:56Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 8, 31, 20, 30, 56, 0, 243, 0], "title": "Kernel Approximation on Manifolds I: Bounding the Lebesgue Constant", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Kernel Approximation on Manifolds I: Bounding the Lebesgue Constant"}, "summary": "The purpose of this paper is to establish that for any compact, connected\nC^{\\infty} Riemannian manifold there exists a robust family of kernels of\nincreasing smoothness that are well suited for interpolation. They generate\nLagrange functions that are uniformly bounded and decay away from their center\nat an exponential rate. An immediate corollary is that the corresponding\nLebesgue constant will be uniformly bounded with a constant whose only\ndependence on the set of data sites is reflected in the mesh ratio, which\nmeasures the uniformity of the data.\n  The analysis needed for these results was inspired by some fundamental work\nof Matveev where the Sobolev decay of Lagrange functions associated with\ncertain kernels on \\Omega \\subset R^d was obtained. With a bit more work, one\nestablishes the following: Lebesgue constants associated with surface splines\nand Sobolev splines are uniformly bounded on R^d provided the data sites \\Xi\nare quasi-uniformly distributed. The non-Euclidean case is more involved as the\ngeometry of the underlying surface comes into play. In addition to establishing\nbounded Lebesgue constants in this setting, a \"zeros lemma\" for compact\nRiemannian manifolds is established.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The purpose of this paper is to establish that for any compact, connected\nC^{\\infty} Riemannian manifold there exists a robust family of kernels of\nincreasing smoothness that are well suited for interpolation. They generate\nLagrange functions that are uniformly bounded and decay away from their center\nat an exponential rate. An immediate corollary is that the corresponding\nLebesgue constant will be uniformly bounded with a constant whose only\ndependence on the set of data sites is reflected in the mesh ratio, which\nmeasures the uniformity of the data.\n  The analysis needed for these results was inspired by some fundamental work\nof Matveev where the Sobolev decay of Lagrange functions associated with\ncertain kernels on \\Omega \\subset R^d was obtained. With a bit more work, one\nestablishes the following: Lebesgue constants associated with surface splines\nand Sobolev splines are uniformly bounded on R^d provided the data sites \\Xi\nare quasi-uniformly distributed. The non-Euclidean case is more involved as the\ngeometry of the underlying surface comes into play. In addition to establishing\nbounded Lebesgue constants in this setting, a \"zeros lemma\" for compact\nRiemannian manifolds is established."}, "authors": [{"name": "Thomas Hangelbroek"}, {"name": "Fran J. Both the direct and inverse\nestimates are based on approximation spaces spanned by local Lagrange functions\nwhich are spatially highly localized. The construction of such functions is\ncomputationally efficient and generalizes the construction given by the authors\nfor restricted surface splines on $\\mathbb{R}^d$. The kernels for which the\ntheory applies includes the Sobolev-Mat\\'ern kernels for closed, compact,\nconnected, $C^\\infty$ Riemannian manifolds.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This article develops direct and inverse estimates for certain finite\ndimensional spaces arising in kernel approximation. Both the direct and inverse\nestimates are based on approximation spaces spanned by local Lagrange functions\nwhich are spatially highly localized. The construction of such functions is\ncomputationally efficient and generalizes the construction given by the authors\nfor restricted surface splines on $\\mathbb{R}^d$. The kernels for which the\ntheory applies includes the Sobolev-Mat\\'ern kernels for closed, compact,\nconnected, $C^\\infty$ Riemannian manifolds."}, "authors": [{"name": "Thomas Hangelbroek"}, {"name": "Francis J. Narcowich"}, {"name": "Christian Rieger"}, {"name": "Joseph D. Ward"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Joseph D. Ward"}, "author": "Joseph D. Ward", "arxiv_comment": "29 pages. To appear in Festschrift for the 80th Birthday of Ian Sloan", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1406.1435v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1406.1435v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "41A17, 41A27, 41A63", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.4852v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.4852v2", "updated": "2011-04-19T16:47:20Z", "updated_parsed": [2011, 4, 19, 16, 47, 20, 1, 109, 0], "published": "2010-12-22T01:06:37Z", "published_parsed": [2010, 12, 22, 1, 6, 37, 2, 356, 0], "title": "Polyharmonic and Related Kernels on Manifolds: Interpolation and\n  Approximation", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Polyharmonic and Related Kernels on Manifolds: Interpolation and\n  Approximation"}, "summary": "This article is devoted to developing a theory for effective kernel\ninterpolation and approximation in a general setting. For a wide class of\ncompact, connected $C^\\infty$ Riemannian manifolds, including the important\ncases of spheres and SO(3), we establish, using techniques involving\ndifferential geometry and Lie groups, that the kernels obtained as fundamental\nsolutions of certain partial differential operators generate Lagrange functions\nthat are uniformly bounded and decay away from their center at an algebraic\nrate, and in certain cases, an exponential rate. An immediate corollary is that\nthe corresponding Lebesgue constants for interpolation as well as for $L_2$\nminimization are uniformly bounded with a constant whose only dependence on the\nset of data sites is reflected in the mesh ratio, which measures the uniformity\nof the data. The kernels considered here include the restricted surface splines\non spheres, as well as surface splines for SO(3), both of which have elementary\nclosed-form representations that are computationally implementable. In addition\nto obtaining bounded Lebesgue constants in this setting, we also establish a\n\"zeros lemma\" for domains on compact Riemannian manifolds -- one that holds in\nas much generality as the corresponding Euclidean zeros lemma (on Lipschitz\ndomains satisfying interior cone conditions) with constants that clearly\ndemonstrate the influence of the geometry of the boundary (via cone parameters)\nas well as that of the Riemannian metric.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This article is devoted to developing a theory for effective kernel\ninterpolation and approximation in a general setting. For a wide class of\ncompact, connected $C^\\infty$ Riemannian manifolds, including the important\ncases of spheres and SO(3), we establish, using techniques involving\ndifferential geometry and Lie groups, that the kernels obtained as fundamental\nsolutions of certain partial differential operators generate Lagrange functions\nthat are uniformly bounded and decay away from their center at an algebraic\nrate, and in certain cases, an exponential rate. An immediate corollary is that\nthe corresponding Lebesgue constants for interpolation as well as for $L_2$\nminimization are uniformly bounded with a constant whose only dependence on the\nset of data sites is reflected in the mesh ratio, which measures the uniformity\nof the data. The kernels considered here include the restricted surface splines\non spheres, as well as surface splines for SO(3), both of which have elementary\nclosed-form representations that are computationally implementable. In addition\nto obtaining bounded Lebesgue constants in this setting, we also establish a\n\"zeros lemma\" for domains on compact Riemannian manifolds -- one that holds in\nas much generality as the corresponding Euclidean zeros lemma (on Lipschitz\ndomains satisfying interior cone conditions) with constants that clearly\ndemonstrate the influence of the geometry of the boundary (via cone parameters)\nas well as that of the Riemannian metric."}, "authors": [{"name": "T. Hangelbroek"}, {"name": "F. J. Narcowich"}, {"name": "J. D. Ward"}], "author_detail": {"name": "J. D. Ward"}, "author": "J. D. Ward", "arxiv_doi": "10.1007/s10208-011-9113-5", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10208-011-9113-5", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.4852v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1012.4852v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "Final manuscript. The main purpose of this paper is to study\ncoordinate independent quadrature (or cubature) formulas associated with\ncertain classes of positive definite and conditionally positive definite\nkernels that are invariant under the group action of the homogeneous manifold.\nIn particular, we show that these formulas are accurate -- optimally so in many\ncases -- and stable under an increasing number of nodes and in the presence of\nnoise, provided the set X of quadrature nodes is quasi-uniform. The stability\nresults are new in all cases. In addition, we may use these quadrature formulas\nto obtain similar formulas for manifolds diffeomorphic to $\\mathbb{S}^n$,\noblate spheroids for instance. The weights are obtained by solving a single\nlinear system. For $\\mathbb{S}^2$, and the restricted thin plate spline kernel\n$r^2 \\log r$, these weights can be computed for two-thirds of a million nodes,\nusing a preconditioned iterative technique introduced by us.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Quadrature formulas for spheres, the rotation group, and other compact,\nhomogeneous manifolds are important in a number of applications and have been\nthe subject of recent research. The main purpose of this paper is to study\ncoordinate independent quadrature (or cubature) formulas associated with\ncertain classes of positive definite and conditionally positive definite\nkernels that are invariant under the group action of the homogeneous manifold.\nIn particular, we show that these formulas are accurate -- optimally so in many\ncases -- and stable under an increasing number of nodes and in the presence of\nnoise, provided the set X of quadrature nodes is quasi-uniform. The stability\nresults are new in all cases. In addition, we may use these quadrature formulas\nto obtain similar formulas for manifolds diffeomorphic to $\\mathbb{S}^n$,\noblate spheroids for instance. The weights are obtained by solving a single\nlinear system. Our method\nis nonconforming and uses a localized Lagrange basis that is constructed out of\nradial basis functions. By verifying that certain inf-sup conditions hold, we\ndemonstrate that both the continuous and discrete problems are well-posed, and\nalso present numerical and theoretical results for the convergence behavior of\nthe method. The stiffness matrix is assembled by a special quadrature routine\nunique to the localized basis. Combining the quadrature method with the\nlocalized basis produces a well-conditioned, symmetric matrix. This then is\nused to find the discretized solution.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We introduce a meshless method for solving both continuous and discrete\nvariational formulations of a volume constrained, nonlocal diffusion problem.\nWe use the discrete solution to approximate the continuous solution. Our method\nis nonconforming and uses a localized Lagrange basis that is constructed out of\nradial basis functions. By verifying that certain inf-sup conditions hold, we\ndemonstrate that both the continuous and discrete problems are well-posed, and\nalso present numerical and theoretical results for the convergence behavior of\nthe method. The stiffness matrix is assembled by a special quadrature routine\nunique to the localized basis. Combining the quadrature method with the\nlocalized basis produces a well-conditioned, symmetric matrix. This then is\nused to find the discretized solution."}, "authors": [{"name": "Richard B. Lehoucq"}, {"name": "Francis J. Narcowich"}, {"name": "Stephen T. Rowe"}, {"name": "Joseph D. Ward"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Joseph D. Ward"}, "author": "Joseph D. Ward", "arxiv_comment": "23 pages, 2, figures, submitted to Math Comp", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.02717v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1601.02717v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.00251v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.00251v1", "updated": "2015-01-01T06:13:14Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 1, 1, 6, 13, 14, 3, 1, 0], "published": "2015-01-01T06:13:14Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 1, 1, 6, 13, 14, 3, 1, 0], "title": "A Tutorial on Inverse Problems for Anomalous Diffusion Processes", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A Tutorial on Inverse Problems for Anomalous Diffusion Processes"}, "summary": "Over the last two decades, anomalous diffusion processes in which the mean\nsquares variance grows slower or faster than that in a Gaussian process have\nfound many applications. At a macroscopic level, these processes are adequately\ndescribed by fractional differential equations, which involves fractional\nderivatives in time or/and space. The fractional derivatives describe either\nhistory mechanism or long range interactions of particle motions at a\nmicroscopic level. The new physics can change dramatically the behavior of the\nforward problems. Naturally one expects that the new physics will impact\nrelated inverse problems in terms of uniqueness, stability, and degree of\nill-posedness. The last aspect is especially important from a practical point\nof view, i.e., stably reconstructing the quantities of interest.\n  In this paper, we employ a formal analytic and numerical way to examine the\ndegree of ill-posedness of several \"classical\" inverse problems for fractional\ndifferential equations involving a Djrbashian-Caputo fractional derivative in\neither time or space, which represent the fractional analogues of that for\nclassical integral order differential equations. We discuss four inverse\nproblems, i.e., backward fractional diffusion, sideways problem, inverse source\nproblem and inverse potential problem for time fractional diffusion, and\ninverse Sturm-Liouville problem, Cauchy problem, backward fractional diffusion\nand sideways problem for space fractional diffusion. It is found that contrary\nto the wide belief, the influence of anomalous diffusion on the degree of\nill-posedness is not definitive: it can either significantly improve or worsen\nthe conditioning of related inverse problems, depending crucially on the\nspecific type of given data and quantity of interest. Further, the study\nexhibits distinct new features of \"fractional\" inverse problems.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Over the last two decades, anomalous diffusion processes in which the mean\nsquares variance grows slower or faster than that in a Gaussian process have\nfound many applications. At a macroscopic level, these processes are adequately\ndescribed by fractional differential equations, which involves fractional\nderivatives in time or/and space. The fractional derivatives describe either\nhistory mechanism or long range interactions of particle motions at a\nmicroscopic level. The new physics can change dramatically the behavior of the\nforward problems. Naturally one expects that the new physics will impact\nrelated inverse problems in terms of uniqueness, stability, and degree of\nill-posedness. The last aspect is especially important from a practical point\nof view, i.e., stably reconstructing the quantities of interest.\n  In this paper, we employ a formal analytic and numerical way to examine the\ndegree of ill-posedness of several \"classical\" inverse problems for fractional\ndifferential equations involving a Djrbashian-Caputo fractional derivative in\neither time or space, which represent the fractional analogues of that for\nclassical integral order differential equations. We discuss four inverse\nproblems, i.e., backward fractional diffusion, sideways problem, inverse source\nproblem and inverse potential problem for time fractional diffusion, and\ninverse Sturm-Liouville problem, Cauchy problem, backward fractional diffusion\nand sideways problem for space fractional diffusion. It is found that contrary\nto the wide belief, the influence of anomalous diffusion on the degree of\nill-posedness is not definitive: it can either significantly improve or worsen\nthe conditioning of related inverse problems, depending crucially on the\nspecific type of given data and quantity of interest. Further, the study\nexhibits distinct new features of \"fractional\" inverse problems."}, "authors": [{"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "William Rundell"}], "author_detail": {"name": "William Rundell"}, "author": "William Rundell", "arxiv_doi": "10.1088/0266-5611/31/3/035003", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0266-5611/31/3/035003", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.00251v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1501.00251v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "29 pages, to appear at Inverse Problems", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1608.02840v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1608.02840v2", "updated": "2016-11-21T17:31:48Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 11, 21, 17, 31, 48, 0, 326, 0], "published": "2016-08-09T15:33:38Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 8, 9, 15, 33, 38, 1, 222, 0], "title": "Fraction diffusion: Recovering the distributed fractional derivative\n  from overposed data", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Fraction diffusion: Recovering the distributed fractional derivative\n  from overposed data"}, "summary": "There has been considerable recent study in \"sub-diffusion\" models that\nreplace the standard parabolic equation model by a one with a fractional\nderivative in the time variable. There are many ways to look at this newer\napproach and one such is to realize that the order of the fractional derivative\nis related to the time scales of the underlying diffusion process. This raises\nthe question of what order ? of derivative should be taken and if a single\nvalue actually suffices. This has led to models that combine a finite number of\nthese derivatives each with a different fractional exponent \\alpha_k and\ndifferent weighting value c_k to better model a greater possible range of time\nscales. Ultimately, one wants to look at a situation that combines derivatives\nin a continuous way { the so-called distributional model with parameter\n\\mu(\\alpha). However all of this begs the question of how one determines this\n\"order\" of differentiation. Recovering a single fractional value has been an\nactive part of the process from the beginning of fractional diffusion modeling\nand if this is the only unknown then the markers left by the fractional order\nderivative are relatively straightforward to determine. In the case of a finite\ncombination of derivatives this becomes much more complex due to the more\nlimited analytic tools available for such equations, but recent progress in\nthis direction has been made, [9, 8]. This paper considers the full\ndistributional model where the order is viewed as a function \\mu(\\alpha) on the\ninterval (0; 1]. We show existence, uniqueness and regularity for an\ninitial-boundary value problem including an important representation theorem in\nthe case of a single spatial variable. This is then used in the inverse problem\nof recovering the distributional coefficient \\mu(\\alpha) from a time trace of\nthe solution and a uniqueness result is proven.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "There has been considerable recent study in \"sub-diffusion\" models that\nreplace the standard parabolic equation model by a one with a fractional\nderivative in the time variable. There are many ways to look at this newer\napproach and one such is to realize that the order of the fractional derivative\nis related to the time scales of the underlying diffusion process. This raises\nthe question of what order ? of derivative should be taken and if a single\nvalue actually suffices. This has led to models that combine a finite number of\nthese derivatives each with a different fractional exponent \\alpha_k and\ndifferent weighting value c_k to better model a greater possible range of time\nscales. Ultimately, one wants to look at a situation that combines derivatives\nin a continuous way { the so-called distributional model with parameter\n\\mu(\\alpha). However all of this begs the question of how one determines this\n\"order\" of differentiation. Recovering a single fractional value has been an\nactive part of the process from the beginning of fractional diffusion modeling\nand if this is the only unknown then the markers left by the fractional order\nderivative are relatively straightforward to determine. In the case of a finite\ncombination of derivatives this becomes much more complex due to the more\nlimited analytic tools available for such equations, but recent progress in\nthis direction has been made, [9, 8]. This paper considers the full\ndistributional model where the order is viewed as a function \\mu(\\alpha) on the\ninterval (0; 1]. We show existence, uniqueness and regularity for an\ninitial-boundary value problem including an important representation theorem in\nthe case of a single spatial variable. This is then used in the inverse problem\nof recovering the distributional coefficient \\mu(\\alpha) from a time trace of\nthe solution and a uniqueness result is proven."}, "authors": [{"name": "William Rundell"}, {"name": "Zhidong Zhang"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhidong Zhang"}, "author": "Zhidong Zhang", "arxiv_doi": "10.1088/1361-6420/aa573e", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1361-6420/aa573e", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1608.02840v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1608.02840v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "24 pages", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35R30, 26A33, 60C22, 34A08", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.00845v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.00845v1", "updated": "2015-07-03T08:22:44Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 7, 3, 8, 22, 44, 4, 184, 0], "published": "2015-07-03T08:22:44Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 7, 3, 8, 22, 44, 4, 184, 0], "title": "Strong maximum principle for fractional diffusion equations and an\n  application to an inverse source problem", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Strong maximum principle for fractional diffusion equations and an\n  application to an inverse source problem"}, "summary": "The strong maximum principle is a remarkable characterization of parabolic\nequations, which is expected to be partly inherited by fractional diffusion\nequations. Based on the corresponding weak maximum principle, in this paper we\nestablish a strong maximum principle for time-fractional diffusion equations\nwith Caputo derivatives, which is slightly weaker than that for the parabolic\ncase. As a direct application, we give a uniqueness result for a related\ninverse source problem on the determination of the temporal component of the\ninhomogeneous term.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The strong maximum principle is a remarkable characterization of parabolic\nequations, which is expected to be partly inherited by fractional diffusion\nequations. Based on the corresponding weak maximum principle, in this paper we\nestablish a strong maximum principle for time-fractional diffusion equations\nwith Caputo derivatives, which is slightly weaker than that for the parabolic\ncase. As a direct application, we give a uniqueness result for a related\ninverse source problem on the determination of the temporal component of the\ninhomogeneous term."}, "authors": [{"name": "Yikan Liu"}, {"name": "William Rundell"}, {"name": "Masahiro Yamamoto"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Masahiro Yamamoto"}, "author": "Masahiro Yamamoto", "arxiv_doi": "10.1515/fca-2016-0048", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1515/fca-2016-0048", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.00845v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1507.00845v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_journal_ref": "Fract. Calc. Appl. Anal. 19 (2016) 888-906", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35R11, 26A33, 35B50, 35R30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.11673v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.11673v1", "updated": "2020-09-24T13:22:16Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 9, 24, 13, 22, 16, 3, 268, 0], "published": "2020-09-24T13:22:16Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 9, 24, 13, 22, 16, 3, 268, 0], "title": "Uniqueness for an inverse coefficient problem for a one-dimensional\n  time-fractional diffusion equation with non-zero boundary conditions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Uniqueness for an inverse coefficient problem for a one-dimensional\n  time-fractional diffusion equation with non-zero boundary conditions"}, "summary": "We consider initial boundary value problems for one-dimensional diffusion\nequation with time-fractional derivative of order $\\alpha \\in (0,1)$ which are\nsubject to non-zero Neumann boundary conditions. We prove the uniqueness for an\ninverse coefficient problem of determining a spatially varying potential and\nthe order of the time-fractional derivative by Dirichlet data at one end point\nof the spatial interval. The imposed Neumann conditions are required to be\nwithin the correct Sobolev space of order $\\alpha$. Our proof is based on a\nrepresentation formula of solution to an initial boundary value problem with\nnon-zero boundary data. Moreover, we apply such a formula and prove the\nuniqueness in the determination of boundary value at another end point by\nCauchy data at one end point.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider initial boundary value problems for one-dimensional diffusion\nequation with time-fractional derivative of order $\\alpha \\in (0,1)$ which are\nsubject to non-zero Neumann boundary conditions. We prove the uniqueness for an\ninverse coefficient problem of determining a spatially varying potential and\nthe order of the time-fractional derivative by Dirichlet data at one end point\nof the spatial interval. The imposed Neumann conditions are required to be\nwithin the correct Sobolev space of order $\\alpha$. Our proof is based on a\nrepresentation formula of solution to an initial boundary value problem with\nnon-zero boundary data. Moreover, we apply such a formula and prove the\nuniqueness in the determination of boundary value at another end point by\nCauchy data at one end point."}, "authors": [{"name": "W. Rundell"}, {"name": "M. Yamamoto"}], "author_detail": {"name": "M. Yamamoto"}, "author": "M.
