Surprisingly, it allows very satisfactory\nreconstructions for both smooth and discontinuous potentials, provided that the\norder $\\alpha\\in(1,2)$ of fractional derivative is sufficiently away from 2."}, "authors": [{"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "William Rundell"}], "author_detail": {"name": "William Rundell"}, "author": "William Rundell", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2012.04.005", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2012.04.005", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1204.2475v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1204.2475v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "16 pages, 6 figures, accepted for publication in Journal of\n  Computational Physics", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.08345v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.08345v1", "updated": "2017-08-25T08:07:19Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 8, 25, 8, 7, 19, 4, 237, 0], "published": "2017-08-25T08:07:19Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 8, 25, 8, 7, 19, 4, 237, 0], "title": "Recovering an Unknown Source in a Fractional Diffusion Problem", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Recovering an Unknown Source in a Fractional Diffusion Problem"}, "summary": "A standard inverse problem is to determine a source which is supported in an\nunknown domain $D$ from external boundary measurements. Here we consider the\ncase of a time-dependent situation where the source is equal to unity in an\nunknown subdomain $D$ of a larger given domain $\\Omega$. Overposed measurements\nconsist of time traces of the solution or its flux values on a set of discrete\npoints on the boundary $\\partial\\Omega$. The case of a parabolic equation was\nconsidered in [HettlichRundell:2001]. In our situation we extend this to cover\nthe subdiffusion case based on an anomalous diffusion model and leading to a\nfractional order differential operator. We will show a uniqueness result and\nexamine a reconstruction algorithm. One of the main motives for this work is to\nexamine the dependence of the reconstructions on the parameter $\\alpha$, the\nexponent of the fractional operator which controls the degree of anomalous\nbehaviour of the process. Some previous inverse problems based on fractional\ndiffusion models have shown considerable differences between classical Brownian\ndiffusion and the anomalous case.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A standard inverse problem is to determine a source which is supported in an\nunknown domain $D$ from external boundary measurements. Here we consider the\ncase of a time-dependent situation where the source is equal to unity in an\nunknown subdomain $D$ of a larger given domain $\\Omega$. Overposed measurements\nconsist of time traces of the solution or its flux values on a set of discrete\npoints on the boundary $\\partial\\Omega$. The case of a parabolic equation was\nconsidered in [HettlichRundell:2001]. In our situation we extend this to cover\nthe subdiffusion case based on an anomalous diffusion model and leading to a\nfractional order differential operator. We will show a uniqueness result and\nexamine a reconstruction algorithm. One of the main motives for this work is to\nexamine the dependence of the reconstructions on the parameter $\\alpha$, the\nexponent of the fractional operator which controls the degree of anomalous\nbehaviour of the process. Some previous inverse problems based on fractional\ndiffusion models have shown considerable differences between classical Brownian\ndiffusion and the anomalous case."}, "authors": [{"name": "William Rundell"}, {"name": "Zhidong Zhang"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhidong Zhang"}, "author": "Zhidong Zhang", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2018.04.046", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2018.04.046", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.08345v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1708.08345v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0411190v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0411190v1", "updated": "2004-11-09T11:30:55Z", "updated_parsed": [2004, 11, 9, 11, 30, 55, 1, 314, 0], "published": "2004-11-09T11:30:55Z", "published_parsed": [2004, 11, 9, 11, 30, 55, 1, 314, 0], "title": "Complete systems of invariants for rank 1 curves in Lagrange\n  Grassmannians", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Complete systems of invariants for rank 1 curves in Lagrange\n  Grassmannians"}, "summary": "Curves in Lagrange Grassmannians naturally appear when one studies\nintrinsically \"the Jacobi equations for extremals\", associated with control\nsystems and geometric structures. In this way one reduces the problem of\nconstruction of the curvature-type invariants for these objects to the much\nmore concrete problem of finding of invariants of curves in Lagrange\nGrassmannians w.r.t. the action of the linear Symplectic group. In the present\npaper we develop a new approach to differential geometry of so-called rank 1\ncurves in Lagrange Grassmannian, i.e., the curves with velocities being rank\none linear mappings (under the standard identification of the tangent space to\na point of the Lagrange Grassmannian with an appropriate space of linear\nmappings). The curves of this class are associated with \"the Jacobi equations\nfor extremals\", corresponding to control systems with scalar control and to\nrank 2 vector distributions. In particular, we construct the tuple of m\nprincipal invariants, where m is equal to half of dimension of the ambient\nlinear symplectic space, such that for a given tuple of arbitrary m smooth\nfunctions there exists the unique, up to a symplectic transformation, rank 1\ncurve having this tuple, as the tuple of the principal invariants. This\napproach extends and essentially simplifies some results of our previous paper\n(J. Dynamical and Control Systems, 8, 2002, No. 1, 93-140), where only the\nuniqueness part was proved and in rather cumbersome way. It is based on the\nconstruction of the new canonical moving frame with the most simple structural\nequation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Curves in Lagrange Grassmannians naturally appear when one studies\nintrinsically \"the Jacobi equations for extremals\", associated with control\nsystems and geometric structures. In this way one reduces the problem of\nconstruction of the curvature-type invariants for these objects to the much\nmore concrete problem of finding of invariants of curves in Lagrange\nGrassmannians w.r.t. the action of the linear Symplectic group. In the present\npaper we develop a new approach to differential geometry of so-called rank 1\ncurves in Lagrange Grassmannian, i.e., the curves with velocities being rank\none linear mappings (under the standard identification of the tangent space to\na point of the Lagrange Grassmannian with an appropriate space of linear\nmappings). The curves of this class are associated with \"the Jacobi equations\nfor extremals\", corresponding to control systems with scalar control and to\nrank 2 vector distributions. In particular, we construct the tuple of m\nprincipal invariants, where m is equal to half of dimension of the ambient\nlinear symplectic space, such that for a given tuple of arbitrary m smooth\nfunctions there exists the unique, up to a symplectic transformation, rank 1\ncurve having this tuple, as the tuple of the principal invariants. This\napproach extends and essentially simplifies some results of our previous paper\n(J. Dynamical and Control Systems, 8, 2002, No. 1, 93-140), where only the\nuniqueness part was proved and in rather cumbersome way. It is based on the\nconstruction of the new canonical moving frame with the most simple structural\nequation."}, "authors": [{"name": "Igor Zelenko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, "author": "Igor Zelenko", "arxiv_comment": "15 pages; submitted to Proceedings of 9th Conference on Differential\n  Geometry and its Applications, Prague 2004", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0411190v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0411190v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "53A55, 70G45", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1909.09201v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1909.09201v1", "updated": "2019-09-17T16:06:34Z", "updated_parsed": [2019, 9, 17, 16, 6, 34, 1, 260, 0], "published": "2019-09-17T16:06:34Z", "published_parsed": [2019, 9, 17, 16, 6, 34, 1, 260, 0], "title": "A canonical form for pairs consisting of a Hermitian form and a\n  self-adjoint antilinear operator", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A canonical form for pairs consisting of a Hermitian form and a\n  self-adjoint antilinear operator"}, "summary": "Motivated by a problem in local differential geometry of Cauchy--Riemann (CR)\nstructures of hypersurface type, we find a canonical form for pairs consisting\nof a nondegenerate Hermitian form and a self-adjoint antilinear operator, or,\nequivalently, consisting of a nondegenerate Hermitian form and a symmetric\nbilinear form. "http://arxiv.org/abs/1812.10501v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1812.10501v1", "updated": "2018-12-26T19:01:34Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 12, 26, 19, 1, 34, 2, 360, 0], "published": "2018-12-26T19:01:34Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 12, 26, 19, 1, 34, 2, 360, 0], "title": "Canonical bundles of moving frames for parametrized curves in Lagrangian\n  Grassmannians: algebraic approach", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Canonical bundles of moving frames for parametrized curves in Lagrangian\n  Grassmannians: algebraic approach"}, "summary": "The aim of these notes is to describe how to construct canonical bundles of\nmoving frames and differential invariants for parametrized curves in Lagrangian\nGrassmannians, at least in the monotonic case. Such curves appear as Jacobi\ncurves of sub-Riemannian extremals [1,2] . Originally this construction was\ndone in [6,7], where it uses the specifics of Lagrangian Grassmannian. In later\nworks [3,4] a much more general theory for construction of canonical bundles of\nmoving frames for parametrized or unparametrized curves in the so-called\ngeneralized flag varieties was developed, so that the problem which is\ndiscussed here can be considered as a particular case of this general theory.\nAlthough this was briefly discussed at the very end of [3], the application of\nthe theory of [3,4] to obtain the results of [6,7] were never written in detail\nand this is our goal here. We believe that this exposition gives a more\nconceptual point of view on the original results of [6,7] and especially\nclarifies the origin of the normalization conditions of the canonical bundles\nof moving frames there, which in fact boil down to a choice of a complement to\na certain subspace of the symplectic Lie algebra. The notes in almost the same\nform are included under my authorship as the Appendix in the book \"A\nComprehensive Introduction to sub-Riemannian Geometry from Hamiltonian view\npoint\" by A. Agrachev D. Barilari, U. Boscain. Following the style of this\nbook, some not difficult statements are given as exercises for pedagogical\npurposes.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The aim of these notes is to describe how to construct canonical bundles of\nmoving frames and differential invariants for parametrized curves in Lagrangian\nGrassmannians, at least in the monotonic case. Such curves appear as Jacobi\ncurves of sub-Riemannian extremals [1,2] . Originally this construction was\ndone in [6,7], where it uses the specifics of Lagrangian Grassmannian. In later\nworks [3,4] a much more general theory for construction of canonical bundles of\nmoving frames for parametrized or unparametrized curves in the so-called\ngeneralized flag varieties was developed, so that the problem which is\ndiscussed here can be considered as a particular case of this general theory.\nAlthough this was briefly discussed at the very end of [3], the application of\nthe theory of [3,4] to obtain the results of [6,7] were never written in detail\nand this is our goal here. We believe that this exposition gives a more\nconceptual point of view on the original results of [6,7] and especially\nclarifies the origin of the normalization conditions of the canonical bundles\nof moving frames there, which in fact boil down to a choice of a complement to\na certain subspace of the symplectic Lie algebra. The notes in almost the same\nform are included under my authorship as the Appendix in the book \"A\nComprehensive Introduction to sub-Riemannian Geometry from Hamiltonian view\npoint\" by A. Agrachev D. Barilari, U. Boscain. Following the style of this\nbook, some not difficult statements are given as exercises for pedagogical\npurposes."}, "authors": [{"name": "Igor Zelenko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, "author": "Igor Zelenko", "arxiv_comment": "22 pages; The notes in almost the same form are included under my\n  authorship as the Appendix in the book \"A Comprehensive Introduction to\n  sub-Riemannian Geometry from Hamiltonian view point\"S by A. Following the style of this book, some not difficult\n  statements are given as exercises for pedagogical purposes", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1812.10501v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1812.10501v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "53C30, 53A55, 14M15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0504319v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0504319v1", "updated": "2005-04-15T12:39:41Z", "updated_parsed": [2005, 4, 15, 12, 39, 41, 4, 105, 0], "published": "2005-04-15T12:39:41Z", "published_parsed": [2005, 4, 15, 12, 39, 41, 4, 105, 0], "title": "A Canonical Frame for Nonholonomic Rank Two Distributions of Maximal\n  Class", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A Canonical Frame for Nonholonomic Rank Two Distributions of Maximal\n  Class"}, "summary": "In 1910 E. Cartan constructed the canonical frame and found the most\nsymmetric case for maximally nonholonomic rank 2 distributions on a\n5-dimensional manifold. We solve the analogous problems for rank 2\ndistributions on an n-dimensional manifold for arbitrary n greater than 5. Our\nmethod is a kind of symplectification of the problem and it is completely\ndifferent from the Cartan method of equivalence.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In 1910 E. Cartan constructed the canonical frame and found the most\nsymmetric case for maximally nonholonomic rank 2 distributions on a\n5-dimensional manifold. We solve the analogous problems for rank 2\ndistributions on an n-dimensional manifold for arbitrary n greater than 5. Our\nmethod is a kind of symplectification of the problem and it is completely\ndifferent from the Cartan method of equivalence."}, "authors": [{"name": "Boris Doubrov"}, {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, "author": "Igor Zelenko", "arxiv_comment": "8 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0504319v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0504319v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "58A30, 34A26, 53A55", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0708.1100v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0708.1100v1", "updated": "2007-08-08T17:57:12Z", "updated_parsed": [2007, 8, 8, 17, 57, 12, 2, 220, 0], "published": "2007-08-08T17:57:12Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 8, 8, 17, 57, 12, 2, 220, 0], "title": "Differential geometry of curves in Lagrange Grassmannians with given\n  Young diagram", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Differential geometry of curves in Lagrange Grassmannians with given\n  Young diagram"}, "summary": "Curves in Lagrange Grassmannians appear naturally in the intrinsic study of\ngeometric structures on manifolds. By a smooth geometric structure on a\nmanifold we mean any submanifold of its tangent bundle, transversal to the\nfibers. One can consider the time-optimal problem naturally associate with a\ngeometric structure. The Pontryagin extremals of this optimal problem are\nintegral curves of certain Hamiltonian system in the cotangent bundle. The\ndynamics of the fibers of the cotangent bundle w.r.t. this system along an\nextremal is described by certain curve in a Lagrange Grassmannian, called\nJacobi curve of the extremal. Any symplectic invariant of the Jacobi curves\nproduces the invariant of the original geometric structure. The basic\ncharacteristic of a curve in a Lagrange Grassmannian is its Young diagram. The\nnumber of boxes in its kth column is equal to the rank of the kth derivative of\nthe curve (which is an appropriately defined linear mapping) at a generic\npoint. We will describe the construction of the complete system of symplectic\ninvariants for parameterized curves in a Lagrange Grassmannian with given Young\ndiagram. It allows to develop in a unified way local differential geometry of\nvery wide classes of geometric structures on manifolds, including both\nclassical geometric structures such as Riemannian and Finslerian structures and\nless classical ones such as sub-Riemannian and sub-Finslerian structures,\ndefined on nonholonomic distributions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Curves in Lagrange Grassmannians appear naturally in the intrinsic study of\ngeometric structures on manifolds. By a smooth geometric structure on a\nmanifold we mean any submanifold of its tangent bundle, transversal to the\nfibers. One can consider the time-optimal problem naturally associate with a\ngeometric structure. The Pontryagin extremals of this optimal problem are\nintegral curves of certain Hamiltonian system in the cotangent bundle. The\ndynamics of the fibers of the cotangent bundle w.r.t. this system along an\nextremal is described by certain curve in a Lagrange Grassmannian, called\nJacobi curve of the extremal. Any symplectic invariant of the Jacobi curves\nproduces the invariant of the original geometric structure. The basic\ncharacteristic of a curve in a Lagrange Grassmannian is its Young diagram. The\nnumber of boxes in its kth column is equal to the rank of the kth derivative of\nthe curve (which is an appropriately defined linear mapping) at a generic\npoint. We will describe the construction of the complete system of symplectic\ninvariants for parameterized curves in a Lagrange Grassmannian with given Young\ndiagram. It allows to develop in a unified way local differential geometry of\nvery wide classes of geometric structures on manifolds, including both\nclassical geometric structures such as Riemannian and Finslerian structures and\nless classical ones such as sub-Riemannian and sub-Finslerian structures,\ndefined on nonholonomic distributions."}, "authors": [{"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, {"name": "Chengbo Li"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Chengbo Li"}, "author": "Chengbo Li", "arxiv_comment": "26 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0708.1100v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0708.1100v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "53A55, 70G45", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1709.10083v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1709.10083v1", "updated": "2017-09-28T17:46:13Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 9, 28, 17, 46, 13, 3, 271, 0], "published": "2017-09-28T17:46:13Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 9, 28, 17, 46, 13, 3, 271, 0], "title": "Platooning in the Presence of a Speed Drop: A Generalized Control Model", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Platooning in the Presence of a Speed Drop: A Generalized Control Model"}, "summary": "The positive impacts of platooning on travel time reliability, congestion,\nemissions, and energy consumption have been shown for homogeneous roadway\nsegments. However, speed limit changes frequently throughout the transportation\nnetwork, due to either safety-related considerations (e.g., workzone\noperations) or congestion management schemes (e.g., speed harmonization\nsystems). These abrupt changes in speed limit can result in shock- wave\nformation and cause travel time unreliability. Therefore, designing a\nplatooning strategy for tracking a reference velocity profile is critical to\nenabling end-to-end platooning. Accordingly, this study introduces a\ngeneralized control model to track a desired velocity profile, while ensuring\nsafety in the platoon of autonomous vehicles. We define appropriate natural\nerror terms and the target curve in the state space of the control system,\nwhich is the set of points where all error terms vanish and corresponds to the\ncase when all vehicles move with the desired velocities and in the minimum safe\ndistance between them. In this way, we change the tracking velocity profile\nproblem into a state- feedback stabilization problem with respect to the target\ncurve. Under certain mild assumptions on the Lipschitz constant of the speed\ndrop profile, we show that the stabilizing feedback can be obtained via\nintroducing a natural dynamics for the maximum of the error terms for each\nvehicle. Moreover, we show that with this stabilizing feedback collisions will\nnot occur if the initial state of the system of vehicles is sufficiently close\nto the target curve. We also show that the error terms remain bounded\nthroughout the time and space. Two scenarios were simulated, with and without\ninitial perturbations, and results confirmed the effectiveness of the proposed\ncontrol model in tracking the speed drop while ensuring safety and string\nstability.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The positive impacts of platooning on travel time reliability, congestion,\nemissions, and energy consumption have been shown for homogeneous roadway\nsegments. However, speed limit changes frequently throughout the transportation\nnetwork, due to either safety-related considerations (e.g., workzone\noperations) or congestion management schemes (e.g., speed harmonization\nsystems). These abrupt changes in speed limit can result in shock- wave\nformation and cause travel time unreliability. Therefore, designing a\nplatooning strategy for tracking a reference velocity profile is critical to\nenabling end-to-end platooning. Accordingly, this study introduces a\ngeneralized control model to track a desired velocity profile, while ensuring\nsafety in the platoon of autonomous vehicles. We define appropriate natural\nerror terms and the target curve in the state space of the control system,\nwhich is the set of points where all error terms vanish and corresponds to the\ncase when all vehicles move with the desired velocities and in the minimum safe\ndistance between them. In this way, we change the tracking velocity profile\nproblem into a state- feedback stabilization problem with respect to the target\ncurve. Under certain mild assumptions on the Lipschitz constant of the speed\ndrop profile, we show that the stabilizing feedback can be obtained via\nintroducing a natural dynamics for the maximum of the error terms for each\nvehicle. Moreover, we show that with this stabilizing feedback collisions will\nnot occur if the initial state of the system of vehicles is sufficiently close\nto the target curve. We also show that the error terms remain bounded\nthroughout the time and space. Two scenarios were simulated, with and without\ninitial perturbations, and results confirmed the effectiveness of the proposed\ncontrol model in tracking the speed drop while ensuring safety and string\nstability."}, "authors": [{"name": "Sina Arefizadeh"}, {"name": "Alireza Talebpour"}, {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, "author": "Igor Zelenko", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1709.10083v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1709.10083v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "cs.SY", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "cs.SY", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1304.2658v6", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1304.2658v6", "updated": "2014-11-09T02:07:30Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 11, 9, 2, 7, 30, 6, 313, 0], "published": "2013-04-09T16:44:28Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 4, 9, 16, 44, 28, 1, 99, 0], "title": "Ricci curvature type lower bounds for sub-Riemannian structures on\n  Sasakian manifolds", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Ricci curvature type lower bounds for sub-Riemannian structures on\n  Sasakian manifolds"}, "summary": "Measure contraction properties are generalizations of the notion of Ricci\ncurvature lower bounds in Riemannian geometry to more general metric measure\nspaces. In this paper, we give sufficient conditions for a Sasakian manifold\nequipped with a natural sub-Riemannian distance to satisfy these properties.\nMoreover, the sufficient conditions are defined by the Tanaka-Webster\ncurvature. This generalizes the earlier work in \\cite{AgLe1} for the three\ndimensional case and in \\cite{Ju} for the Heisenberg group. To obtain our\nresults we use the intrinsic Jacobi equations along sub-Riemannian extremals,\ncoming from the theory of canonical moving frames for curves in Lagrangian\nGrassmannians \\cite{LiZe1, LiZe2}. The crucial new tool here is a certain\ndecoupling of the corresponding matrix Riccati equation. It is also worth\npointing out that our method leads to exact formulas for the measure\ncontraction in the case of the corresponding homogeneous models in the\nconsidered class of sub-Riemannian structures.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Measure contraction properties are generalizations of the notion of Ricci\ncurvature lower bounds in Riemannian geometry to more general metric measure\nspaces. In this paper, we give sufficient conditions for a Sasakian manifold\nequipped with a natural sub-Riemannian distance to satisfy these properties.\nMoreover, the sufficient conditions are defined by the Tanaka-Webster\ncurvature. This generalizes the earlier work in \\cite{AgLe1} for the three\ndimensional case and in \\cite{Ju} for the Heisenberg group. To obtain our\nresults we use the intrinsic Jacobi equations along sub-Riemannian extremals,\ncoming from the theory of canonical moving frames for curves in Lagrangian\nGrassmannians \\cite{LiZe1, LiZe2}. The crucial new tool here is a certain\ndecoupling of the corresponding matrix Riccati equation. It is also worth\npointing out that our method leads to exact formulas for the measure\ncontraction in the case of the corresponding homogeneous models in the\nconsidered class of sub-Riemannian structures."}, "authors": [{"name": "Paul W. This leads to new results such as the fundamental\nsystem of invariants for all these problems and the explicit description of the\nmaximally symmetric models. It appears that there are many ways to convert such system of\nODEs to an exterior differential system. They lead to different series of\nfinite-dimensional symmetry algebras. For example, for (k,l)=(2,3) we get two\nnon-isomorphic symmetry algebras of the same dimension. We explore how these\nsymmetry algebras are related to both Sternberg prolongation of G-structures\nand Tanaka prolongation of graded nilpotent Lie algebras.\n  Surprisingly, the case (k,l)=(2,3) provides an example of a linear subalgebra\ng in gl(5,R) such that the Sternberg prolongations of g and g^t are both of the\nsame dimension, but are non-isomorphic.\n  We also discuss the non-linear case and the link with flag structures on\nsmooth manifolds.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We compute symmetry algebras of a system of two equations y^(k)=z^(l)=0,\nwhere 2<=k<l. It appears that there are many ways to convert such system of\nODEs to an exterior differential system. They lead to different series of\nfinite-dimensional symmetry algebras. For example, for (k,l)=(2,3) we get two\nnon-isomorphic symmetry algebras of the same dimension. We explore how these\nsymmetry algebras are related to both Sternberg prolongation of G-structures\nand Tanaka prolongation of graded nilpotent Lie algebras.\n  Surprisingly, the case (k,l)=(2,3) provides an example of a linear subalgebra\ng in gl(5,R) such that the Sternberg prolongations of g and g^t are both of the\nsame dimension, but are non-isomorphic.\n  We also discuss the non-linear case and the link with flag structures on\nsmooth manifolds."}, "authors": [{"name": "Boris Doubrov"}, {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, "author": "Igor Zelenko", "arxiv_comment": "Corrected misprints, added more details on symmetry computation", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1302.7119v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1302.7119v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "17B70, 34A26, 34A34, 34C14, 53C10", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1003.1405v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1003.1405v1", "updated": "2010-03-06T17:09:17Z", "updated_parsed": [2010, 3, 6, 17, 9, 17, 5, 65, 0], "published": "2010-03-06T17:09:17Z", "published_parsed": [2010, 3, 6, 17, 9, 17, 5, 65, 0], "title": "Canonical frames for distributions of odd rank and corank 2 with maximal\n  first Kronecker index", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Canonical frames for distributions of odd rank and corank 2 with maximal\n  first Kronecker index"}, "summary": "We construct canonical frames and find all maximally symmetric models for a\nnatural generic class of corank 2 distributions on manifolds of odd dimension\ngreater or equal to 7. This class of distributions is characterized by the\nfollowing two conditions: the pencil of 2-forms associated with the\ncorresponding Pfaffian system has the maximal possible first Kronecker index\nand the Lie square of the subdistribution generated by the kernels of all these\n2-forms is equal to the original distribution. In particular, we show that the\nunique, up to a local equivalence, maximally symmetric model in this class of\ndistributions with given dimension of the ambient manifold exists if and only\nif the dimension of the ambient manifold is equal to 7, 9, 11, 15 or 8l-3,\nwhere $l$ is an arbitrary natural number. Besides, if the dimension of the\nambient manifold is equal to 19, then there exist two maximally symmetric\nmodels, up to a local equivalence, distinguished by certain discrete invariant.\nFor all other dimensions of ambient manifold there are families of maximally\nsymmetric models, depending on continuous parameters. Our main tool is the\nso-called symplectification procedure having its origin in Optimal Control\nTheory. Our results can be seen as an extension of some classical Cartan's\nresults about rank 3 distributions on a 5-dimensional manifold to corank 2\ndistributions of higher odd rank.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We construct canonical frames and find all maximally symmetric models for a\nnatural generic class of corank 2 distributions on manifolds of odd dimension\ngreater or equal to 7. This class of distributions is characterized by the\nfollowing two conditions: the pencil of 2-forms associated with the\ncorresponding Pfaffian system has the maximal possible first Kronecker index\nand the Lie square of the subdistribution generated by the kernels of all these\n2-forms is equal to the original distribution. In particular, we show that the\nunique, up to a local equivalence, maximally symmetric model in this class of\ndistributions with given dimension of the ambient manifold exists if and only\nif the dimension of the ambient manifold is equal to 7, 9, 11, 15 or 8l-3,\nwhere $l$ is an arbitrary natural number. Besides, if the dimension of the\nambient manifold is equal to 19, then there exist two maximally symmetric\nmodels, up to a local equivalence, distinguished by certain discrete invariant.\nFor all other dimensions of ambient manifold there are families of maximally\nsymmetric models, depending on continuous parameters. Our main tool is the\nso-called symplectification procedure having its origin in Optimal Control\nTheory. Our results can be seen as an extension of some classical Cartan's\nresults about rank 3 distributions on a 5-dimensional manifold to corank 2\ndistributions of higher odd rank."}, "authors": [{"name": "Wojciech Krynski"}, {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, "author": "Igor Zelenko", "arxiv_comment": "29 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1003.1405v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1003.1405v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "58A30, 58A17, 53A55, 35B06", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0502031v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0502031v2", "updated": "2005-02-02T07:43:44Z", "updated_parsed": [2005, 2, 2, 7, 43, 44, 2, 33, 0], "published": "2005-02-01T20:41:53Z", "published_parsed": [2005, 2, 1, 20, 41, 53, 1, 32, 0], "title": "On feedback classification of control-affine systems with one and\n  two-dimensional inputs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "On feedback classification of control-affine systems with one and\n  two-dimensional inputs"}, "summary": "The paper is devoted to the local classification of generic control-affine\nsystems on an n-dimensional manifold with scalar input for any n>3 or with two\ninputs for n=4 and n=5, up to state-feedback transformations, preserving the\naffine structure. First using the Poincare series of moduli numbers we\nintroduce the intrinsic numbers of functional moduli of each prescribed number\nof variables on which a classification problem depends. In order to classify\naffine systems with scalar input we associate with such a system the canonical\nframe by normalizing some structural functions in a commutative relation of the\nvector fields, which define our control system. Then, using this canonical\nframe, we introduce the canonical coordinates and find a complete system of\nstate-feedback invariants of the system. It also gives automatically the\nmicro-local (i.e. local in state-input space) classification of the generic\nnon-affine n-dimensional control system with scalar input for n>2. Further we\nshow how the problem of feedback-equivalence of affine systems with\ntwo-dimensional input in state space of dimensions 4 and 5 can be reduced to\nthe same problem for affine systems with scalar input. In order to make this\nreduction we distinguish the subsystem of our control system, consisting of the\ndirections of all extremals in dimension 4 and all abnormal extremals in\ndimension 5 of the time optimal problem, defined by the original control\nsystem. In each classification problem under consideration we find the\nintrinsic numbers of functional moduli of each prescribed number of variables\naccording to its Poincare series.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The paper is devoted to the local classification of generic control-affine\nsystems on an n-dimensional manifold with scalar input for any n>3 or with two\ninputs for n=4 and n=5, up to state-feedback transformations, preserving the\naffine structure. First using the Poincare series of moduli numbers we\nintroduce the intrinsic numbers of functional moduli of each prescribed number\nof variables on which a classification problem depends. In order to classify\naffine systems with scalar input we associate with such a system the canonical\nframe by normalizing some structural functions in a commutative relation of the\nvector fields, which define our control system. Then, using this canonical\nframe, we introduce the canonical coordinates and find a complete system of\nstate-feedback invariants of the system. It also gives automatically the\nmicro-local (i.e. local in state-input space) classification of the generic\nnon-affine n-dimensional control system with scalar input for n>2. Further we\nshow how the problem of feedback-equivalence of affine systems with\ntwo-dimensional input in state space of dimensions 4 and 5 can be reduced to\nthe same problem for affine systems with scalar input. In order to make this\nreduction we distinguish the subsystem of our control system, consisting of the\ndirections of all extremals in dimension 4 and all abnormal extremals in\ndimension 5 of the time optimal problem, defined by the original control\nsystem. In each classification problem under consideration we find the\nintrinsic numbers of functional moduli of each prescribed number of variables\naccording to its Poincare series."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrei Agrachev"}, {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, "author": "Igor Zelenko", "arxiv_comment": "26 pages, submitted to SIAM Journal On Control and Optimization,\n  minor corrections of misprints", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0502031v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0502031v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "93B29, 53A55", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1210.7334v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1210.7334v2", "updated": "2013-09-19T13:37:45Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 9, 19, 13, 37, 45, 3, 262, 0], "published": "2012-10-27T15:20:26Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 10, 27, 15, 20, 26, 5, 301, 0], "title": "Prolongation of quasi-principal frame bundles and geometry of flag\n  structures on manifolds", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Prolongation of quasi-principal frame bundles and geometry of flag\n  structures on manifolds"}, "summary": "Motivated by the geometric theory of differential equations and the\nvariational approach to the equivalence problem for geometric structures on\nmanifolds, we consider the problem of equivalence for distributions with fixed\nsubmanifolds of flags on each fiber. We call them flag structures. The\nconstruction of the canonical frames for these structures can be given in the\ntwo prolongation steps: the first step, based on our previous works, gives the\ncanonical bundle of moving frames for the fixed submanifolds of flags on each\nfiber and the second step consists of the prolongation of the bundle obtained\nin the first step. The bundle obtained in the first step is not as a rule a\nprincipal bundle so that the classical Tanaka prolongation procedure for\nfiltered structures can not be applied to it. However, under natural\nassumptions on submanifolds of flags and on the ambient distribution, this\nbundle satisfies a nice weaker property. The main goal of the present paper is\nto formalize this property, introducing the so-called quasi-principle frame\nbundles, and to generalize the Tanaka prolongation procedure to these bundles.\nApplications to the equivalence problems for systems of differential equations\nof mixed order, bracket generating distributions, sub-Riemannian and more\ngeneral structures on distributions are given.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Motivated by the geometric theory of differential equations and the\nvariational approach to the equivalence problem for geometric structures on\nmanifolds, we consider the problem of equivalence for distributions with fixed\nsubmanifolds of flags on each fiber. We call them flag structures. The\nconstruction of the canonical frames for these structures can be given in the\ntwo prolongation steps: the first step, based on our previous works, gives the\ncanonical bundle of moving frames for the fixed submanifolds of flags on each\nfiber and the second step consists of the prolongation of the bundle obtained\nin the first step. The bundle obtained in the first step is not as a rule a\nprincipal bundle so that the classical Tanaka prolongation procedure for\nfiltered structures can not be applied to it. However, under natural\nassumptions on submanifolds of flags and on the ambient distribution, this\nbundle satisfies a nice weaker property. The main goal of the present paper is\nto formalize this property, introducing the so-called quasi-principle frame\nbundles, and to generalize the Tanaka prolongation procedure to these bundles.\nApplications to the equivalence problems for systems of differential equations\nof mixed order, bracket generating distributions, sub-Riemannian and more\ngeneral structures on distributions are given."}, "authors": [{"name": "Boris Doubrov"}, {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, "author": "Igor Zelenko", "arxiv_comment": "49 pages. Two sub-Riemannian metrics on $(M,D)$ are said to be\nprojectively (resp. affinely) equivalent if they have the same geodesics up to\nreparameterization (resp. up to affine reparameterization). A sub-Riemannian\nmetric $g$ is called rigid (resp. conformally rigid) with respect to\nprojective/affine equivalence, if any sub-Riemannian metric which is\nprojectively/affinely equivalent to $g$ is constantly proportional to $g$\n(resp. conformal to $g$). In the Riemannian case the local classification of\nprojectively and affinely equivalent metrics is classical (Levi-Civita,\nEisenhart). In particular, a Riemannian metric which is not rigid satisfies the\nfollowing two special properties: its geodesic flow possesses nontrivial\nintegrals and the metric induces certain canonical product structure on the\nambient manifold. These classification results were extended to contact and\nquasi-contact distributions by Zelenko. Our general goal is to extend these\nresults to arbitrary sub-Riemannian manifolds, and we establish two types of\nresults toward this goal: if a sub-Riemannian metric is not projectively\nconformally rigid, then, first, its flow of normal extremals has at least one\nnontrivial integral quadratic on the fibers of the cotangent bundle and,\nsecond, the nilpotent approximation of the underlying distribution at any point\nadmits a product structure. As a consequence we obtain two types of genericity\nresults: first, we show that a generic sub-Riemannian metric on a fixed pair\n$(M,D)$ is projectively conformally rigid. Second, we prove that, except for\nspecial pairs $(m,n)$, every sub-Riemannian metric on a rank $m$ generic\ndistribution in an $n$-dimensional manifold is projectively conformally rigid.\nFor the affine equivalence in both genericity results conformal rigidity can be\nreplaced by usual rigidity.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Consider a smooth manifold $M$ equipped with a bracket generating\ndistribution $D$. Two sub-Riemannian metrics on $(M,D)$ are said to be\nprojectively (resp. affinely) equivalent if they have the same geodesics up to\nreparameterization (resp. up to affine reparameterization). A sub-Riemannian\nmetric $g$ is called rigid (resp. conformally rigid) with respect to\nprojective/affine equivalence, if any sub-Riemannian metric which is\nprojectively/affinely equivalent to $g$ is constantly proportional to $g$\n(resp. conformal to $g$). In the Riemannian case the local classification of\nprojectively and affinely equivalent metrics is classical (Levi-Civita,\nEisenhart). In particular, a Riemannian metric which is not rigid satisfies the\nfollowing two special properties: its geodesic flow possesses nontrivial\nintegrals and the metric induces certain canonical product structure on the\nambient manifold. These classification results were extended to contact and\nquasi-contact distributions by Zelenko. Our general goal is to extend these\nresults to arbitrary sub-Riemannian manifolds, and we establish two types of\nresults toward this goal: if a sub-Riemannian metric is not projectively\nconformally rigid, then, first, its flow of normal extremals has at least one\nnontrivial integral quadratic on the fibers of the cotangent bundle and,\nsecond, the nilpotent approximation of the underlying distribution at any point\nadmits a product structure. Second, we prove that, except for\nspecial pairs $(m,n)$, every sub-Riemannian metric on a rank $m$ generic\ndistribution in an $n$-dimensional manifold is projectively conformally rigid.\nFor the affine equivalence in both genericity results conformal rigidity can be\nreplaced by usual rigidity."}, "authors": [{"name": "F. Using Pontryagin Maximum Principle, we treat Riemannian and\nsub-Riemannian cases in an unified way and obtain some algebraic necessary\nconditions for the geodesic equivalence of (sub-)Riemannian metrics. In this\nway first we obtain a new elementary proof of classical Levi-Civita's Theorem\nabout the classification of all Riemannian geodesically equivalent metrics in a\nneighborhood of so-called regular (stable) point w.r.t. these metrics. In\ncontrast to the classical Tanaka symbol, the set of Jacobi symbols is discrete\nand classifiable. We give an explicit and unified algebraic procedure for the\nconstruction of the canonical frames (the structure of absolute parallelism)\nfor all distribution with given Jacobi symbol. We describe all Jacobi symbols\nfor which this procedure ends up in a finite number of steps (i.e. all Jacobi\nsymbols of finite type) and distinguish the symplectically flat distributions\nwith given Jacobi symbol, which in the case of finite type are the maximally\nsymmetric distribution among all distribution with given Jacobi symbol. Also,\nfor the most of Jacobi symbols we relate the prolongation procedure and the\nresulting prolongation algebra, which is the algebra of infinitesimal\nsymmetries of the corresponding symplectically flat distribution, to the\nstandard (in the sense of Kobayashi and Sternberg) prolongation of certain\nsubspace in the algebra of infinitesimal symmetries of the flat\n(unparametrized) curve of flags associated with the Jacobi symbol. Finally, we\ngive an upper bounds for the size of the resulting prolongation algebra in\nterms of certain spaces of polynomials vanishing on certain projective\nvarieties. For some class of Jacobi symbols we are able to identify the\nresulting prolongation algebra with such spaces of polynomials. In this way we\nget the description of the prolongation algebra for all Jacobi symbols of\nfinite type appearing in rank 2 and rank 3 distributions and also for most of\nsuch Jacobi symbols appearing in rank 4 distributions. In particular, in the\ncase of rank 3 distributions this description is given in terms of the\ntangential developable and the secant varieties of a rational normal curve.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Based on the ideas of Optimal Control, we introduce the new basic\ncharacteristic of a bracket generating distribution, the Jacobi symbol. In\ncontrast to the classical Tanaka symbol, the set of Jacobi symbols is discrete\nand classifiable. We give an explicit and unified algebraic procedure for the\nconstruction of the canonical frames (the structure of absolute parallelism)\nfor all distribution with given Jacobi symbol. We describe all Jacobi symbols\nfor which this procedure ends up in a finite number of steps (i.e. all Jacobi\nsymbols of finite type) and distinguish the symplectically flat distributions\nwith given Jacobi symbol, which in the case of finite type are the maximally\nsymmetric distribution among all distribution with given Jacobi symbol. Also,\nfor the most of Jacobi symbols we relate the prolongation procedure and the\nresulting prolongation algebra, which is the algebra of infinitesimal\nsymmetries of the corresponding symplectically flat distribution, to the\nstandard (in the sense of Kobayashi and Sternberg) prolongation of certain\nsubspace in the algebra of infinitesimal symmetries of the flat\n(unparametrized) curve of flags associated with the Jacobi symbol. Finally, we\ngive an upper bounds for the size of the resulting prolongation algebra in\nterms of certain spaces of polynomials vanishing on certain projective\nvarieties. For some class of Jacobi symbols we are able to identify the\nresulting prolongation algebra with such spaces of polynomials. In this way we\nget the description of the prolongation algebra for all Jacobi symbols of\nfinite type appearing in rank 2 and rank 3 distributions and also for most of\nsuch Jacobi symbols appearing in rank 4 distributions. The basic differential invariants of a\ndynamical Lagrangian distribution w.r.t. the action of the group of\nsymplectomorphisms of the ambient symplectic manifold are the curvature\noperator and the curvature form. These invariants can be seen as\ngeneralizations of the classical curvature tensor in Riemannian Geometry. In\nparticular, in terms of these invariants one can localize the focal points\nalong extremals of the corresponding variational problems. In the present paper\nwe study the behavior of the curvature operator, the curvature form and the\nfocal points of a dynamical Lagrangian distribution after its reduction by\narbitrary first integrals in involution. The interesting phenomenon is that the\ncurvature form of so-called monotone increasing Lagrangian dynamical\ndistributions, which appear naturally in mechanical systems, does not decrease\nafter reduction. It also turns out that the set of focal points to the given\npoint w.r.t. the monotone increasing dynamical Lagrangian distribution and the\ncorresponding set of focal points w.r.t. its reduction by one integral are\nalternating sets on the corresponding integral curve of the Hamiltonian system\nof the considered dynamical distributions. Moreover, the first focal point\ncorresponding to the reduced Lagrangian distribution comes before any focal\npoint related to the original dynamical distribution. We illustrate our results\non the classical $N$-body problem.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Pairs (Hamiltonian system, Lagrangian distribution), called dynamical\nLagrangian distributions, appear naturally in Differential Geometry, Calculus\nof Variations and Rational Mechanics. The basic differential invariants of a\ndynamical Lagrangian distribution w.r.t. the action of the group of\nsymplectomorphisms of the ambient symplectic manifold are the curvature\noperator and the curvature form. These invariants can be seen as\ngeneralizations of the classical curvature tensor in Riemannian Geometry. In\nparticular, in terms of these invariants one can localize the focal points\nalong extremals of the corresponding variational problems. In the present paper\nwe study the behavior of the curvature operator, the curvature form and the\nfocal points of a dynamical Lagrangian distribution after its reduction by\narbitrary first integrals in involution. The interesting phenomenon is that the\ncurvature form of so-called monotone increasing Lagrangian dynamical\ndistributions, which appear naturally in mechanical systems, does not decrease\nafter reduction. It also turns out that the set of focal points to the given\npoint w.r.t. the monotone increasing dynamical Lagrangian distribution and the\ncorresponding set of focal points w.r.t. its reduction by one integral are\nalternating sets on the corresponding integral curve of the Hamiltonian system\nof the considered dynamical distributions. Moreover, the first focal point\ncorresponding to the reduced Lagrangian distribution comes before any focal\npoint related to the original dynamical distribution. We illustrate our results\non the classical $N$-body problem."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrej A. Agrachev"}, {"name": "Natalia N. Chtcherbakova"}, {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, "author": "Igor Zelenko", "arxiv_comment": "28 pages, submitted to \"Journal of Dynamical and Control Systems\"", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0409152v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0409152v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.SG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "37J15, 37J05, 53D20", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.2797v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.2797v1", "updated": "2013-01-13T17:15:08Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 1, 13, 17, 15, 8, 6, 13, 0], "published": "2013-01-13T17:15:08Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 1, 13, 17, 15, 8, 6, 13, 0], "title": "Geometry of rank 2 distributions with nonzero Wilczynski invariants and\n  affine control systems with one input", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Geometry of rank 2 distributions with nonzero Wilczynski invariants and\n  affine control systems with one input"}, "summary": "We demonstrate how the novel approach to the local geometry of structures of\nnonholonomic nature, originated by Andrei Agrachev, works in the following two\nsituations: rank 2 distributions of maximal class in R^n with non-zero\ngeneralized Wilczynski invariants and rank 2 distributions of maximal class in\nR^n with additional structures such as affine control system with one input\nspanning these distributions, sub-(pseudo)Riemannian structures etc. The common\nfeature of these two situations is that each abnormal extremal (of the\nunderlying rank 2 distribution) possesses a distinguished parametrization. This\nfact allows one to construct the canonical frame on a (2n-3)-dimensional bundle\nin both situations for arbitrary n greater than 4. The moduli spaces of the\nmost symmetric models for both situations are described as well. The relation\nof our results to the divergence equivalence of Lagrangians of higher order is\ngiven", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We demonstrate how the novel approach to the local geometry of structures of\nnonholonomic nature, originated by Andrei Agrachev, works in the following two\nsituations: rank 2 distributions of maximal class in R^n with non-zero\ngeneralized Wilczynski invariants and rank 2 distributions of maximal class in\nR^n with additional structures such as affine control system with one input\nspanning these distributions, sub-(pseudo)Riemannian structures etc. The common\nfeature of these two situations is that each abnormal extremal (of the\nunderlying rank 2 distribution) possesses a distinguished parametrization. The scope of applicability of the theory\nincludes geometry of natural classes of curves of flags with respect to\nreductive linear groups or their parabolic subgroups. The case of\nclassical groups is considered in more detail.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We develop an algebraic version of Cartan method of equivalence or an analog\nof Tanaka prolongation for the (extrinsic) geometry of curves of flags of a\nvector space $W$ with respect to the action of a subgroup $G$ of the $GL(W)$.\nUnder some natural assumptions on the subgroup $G$ and on the flags, one can\npass from the filtered objects to the corresponding graded objects and describe\nthe construction of canonical bundles of moving frames for these curves in the\nlanguage of pure Linear Algebra. The scope of applicability of the theory\nincludes geometry of natural classes of curves of flags with respect to\nreductive linear groups or their parabolic subgroups. The case of\nclassical groups is considered in more detail."}, "authors": [{"name": "Boris Doubrov"}, {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, "author": "Igor Zelenko", "arxiv_comment": "39 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1110.0242v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1110.0242v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "53B25, 53B15, 53A55, 17B70", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0908.4397v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0908.4397v1", "updated": "2009-08-30T20:32:18Z", "updated_parsed": [2009, 8, 30, 20, 32, 18, 6, 242, 0], "published": "2009-08-30T20:32:18Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 8, 30, 20, 32, 18, 6, 242, 0], "title": "Jacobi Equations and Comparison Theorems for Corank 1 sub-Riemannian\n  Structures with Symmetries", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Jacobi Equations and Comparison Theorems for Corank 1 sub-Riemannian\n  Structures with Symmetries"}, "summary": "The Jacobi curve of an extremal of optimal control problem is a curve in a\nLagrangian Grassmannian defined up to a symplectic transformation and\ncontaining all information about the solutions of the Jacobi equations along\nthis extremal. In our previous works we constructed the canonical bundle of\nmoving frames and the complete system of symplectic invariants, called\ncurvature maps, for parametrized curves in Lagrange Grassmannians satisfying\nvery general assumptions. The structural equation for a canonical moving frame\nof the Jacobi curve of an extremal can be interpreted as the normal form for\nthe Jacobi equation along this extremal and the curvature maps can be seen as\nthe \"coefficients\" of this normal form. In the case of a Riemannian metric\nthere is only one curvature map and it is naturally related to the Riemannian\nsectional curvature. In the present paper we study the curvature maps for a\nsub-Riemannian structure on a corank 1 distribution having an additional\ntransversal infinitesimal symmetry. After the factorization by the integral\nfoliation of this symmetry, such sub-Riemannian structure can be reduced to a\nRiemannian manifold equipped with a closed 2-form (a magnetic field). We obtain\nexplicit expressions for the curvature maps of the original sub-Riemannian\nstructure in terms of the curvature tensor of this Riemannian manifold and the\nmagnetic field. We also estimate the number of conjugate points along the\nsub-Riemannian extremals in terms of the bounds for the curvature tensor of\nthis Riemannian manifold and the magnetic field in the case of an uniform\nmagnetic field. The language developed for the calculation of the curvature\nmaps can be applied to more general sub-Riemannian structures with symmetries,\nincluding sub-Riemmannian structures appearing naturally in Yang-Mills fields.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The Jacobi curve of an extremal of optimal control problem is a curve in a\nLagrangian Grassmannian defined up to a symplectic transformation and\ncontaining all information about the solutions of the Jacobi equations along\nthis extremal. In our previous works we constructed the canonical bundle of\nmoving frames and the complete system of symplectic invariants, called\ncurvature maps, for parametrized curves in Lagrange Grassmannians satisfying\nvery general assumptions. The structural equation for a canonical moving frame\nof the Jacobi curve of an extremal can be interpreted as the normal form for\nthe Jacobi equation along this extremal and the curvature maps can be seen as\nthe \"coefficients\" of this normal form. In the case of a Riemannian metric\nthere is only one curvature map and it is naturally related to the Riemannian\nsectional curvature. In the present paper we study the curvature maps for a\nsub-Riemannian structure on a corank 1 distribution having an additional\ntransversal infinitesimal symmetry. After the factorization by the integral\nfoliation of this symmetry, such sub-Riemannian structure can be reduced to a\nRiemannian manifold equipped with a closed 2-form (a magnetic field). We obtain\nexplicit expressions for the curvature maps of the original sub-Riemannian\nstructure in terms of the curvature tensor of this Riemannian manifold and the\nmagnetic field. We also estimate the number of conjugate points along the\nsub-Riemannian extremals in terms of the bounds for the curvature tensor of\nthis Riemannian manifold and the magnetic field in the case of an uniform\nmagnetic field. The language developed for the calculation of the curvature\nmaps can be applied to more general sub-Riemannian structures with symmetries,\nincluding sub-Riemmannian structures appearing naturally in Yang-Mills fields."}, "authors": [{"name": "Chengbo Li"}, {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Igor Zelenko"}, "author": "Igor Zelenko", "arxiv_comment": "27 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0908.4397v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0908.4397v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.OC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "53C17; This has\napplications to the \"growth\" of certain operator spaces: It implies\nasymptotically sharp estimates for the growth of the multiplicity of\n$M_N$-spaces needed to represent (up to a constant $C>1$) the $M_N$-version of\nthe $n$-dimensional operator Hilbert space $OH_n$ as a direct sum of copies of\n$M_N$. We show that, when $C$ is close to 1, this multiplicity grows as\n$\\exp{\\beta n N^2}$ for some constant $\\beta>0$. The main idea is to relate\nquantum expanders with \"smooth\" points on the matricial analogue of the\nEuclidean unit sphere. This generalizes to operator spaces a classical\ngeometric result on $n$-dimensional Hilbert space (corresponding to N=1). Our inequality is less sharp but\nalso appears to apply with more general (and even matricial) coefficients. It\nshows that up to a universal constant all moments of the norm of a linear\ncombination of the form\n  $$S=\\sum\\nolimits_j a_j U_j \\otimes \\bar U_j (1-P)$$ are dominated by those\nof the corresponding Gaussian sum\n  $$S'=\\sum\\nolimits_j a_j Y_j \\otimes \\bar Y'_j .$$ The advantage is that $S'$\nis now simply separately a Gaussian random variable with respect to the\nindependent Gaussian random matrices $(Y_j)$ and $(Y'_j)$, and hence is much\neasier to majorize. Note we plan to incorporate this appendix into our future\npublication.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this appendix to our paper with the same title posted on arxiv we give a\nquick proof of an inequality that can be substituted to Hastings's result,\nquoted as Lemma 1.9 in our previous paper. Our inequality is less sharp but\nalso appears to apply with more general (and even matricial) coefficients. It\nshows that up to a universal constant all moments of the norm of a linear\ncombination of the form\n  $$S=\\sum\\nolimits_j a_j U_j \\otimes \\bar U_j (1-P)$$ are dominated by those\nof the corresponding Gaussian sum\n  $$S'=\\sum\\nolimits_j a_j Y_j \\otimes \\bar Y'_j .$$ The advantage is that $S'$\nis now simply separately a Gaussian random variable with respect to the\nindependent Gaussian random matrices $(Y_j)$ and $(Y'_j)$, and hence is much\neasier to majorize. Note we plan to incorporate this appendix into our future\npublication."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gilles Pisier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Gilles Pisier"}, "author": "Gilles Pisier", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1211.1055v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1211.1055v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/9704209v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/9704209v1", "updated": "1997-04-04T00:00:00Z", "updated_parsed": [1997, 4, 4, 0, 0, 0, 4, 94, 0], "published": "1997-04-04T00:00:00Z", "published_parsed": [1997, 4, 4, 0, 0, 0, 4, 94, 0], "title": "Non-commutative martingale inequalities", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Non-commutative martingale inequalities"}, "summary": "We prove the analogue of the classical Burkholder-Gundy inequalites for\nnon-commutative martingales. This\nsharpens their result that it is 5-fold tensor Sidon. The proof is somewhat\nreminiscent of the author's original one for (Abelian) group characters, based\non ideas due to Drury and Rider. However, we use Talagrand's majorizing measure\ntheorem in place of Fernique's metric entropy lower bound. We also show that a\nuniformly bounded orthonormal system is randomly Sidon iff it is 4-fold tensor\nSidon, or equivalently $k$-fold tensor Sidon for some (or all) $k\\ge 4$.\nVarious generalizations are presented, including the case of random matrices,\nfor systems analogous to the Peter-Weyl decomposition for compact non-Abelian\ngroups. This\nsharpens their result that it is 5-fold tensor Sidon. The proof is somewhat\nreminiscent of the author's original one for (Abelian) group characters, based\non ideas due to Drury and Rider. However, we use Talagrand's majorizing measure\ntheorem in place of Fernique's metric entropy lower bound. We also show that a\nuniformly bounded orthonormal system is randomly Sidon iff it is 4-fold tensor\nSidon, or equivalently $k$-fold tensor Sidon for some (or all) $k\\ge 4$.\nVarious generalizations are presented, including the case of random matrices,\nfor systems analogous to the Peter-Weyl decomposition for compact non-Abelian\ngroups. For any $n$-tuple $u_1,\\ldots, u_n$ of unitary operators in\n$B(H)$, we have $$2\\sqrt{n-1} \\le \\left\\|\\sum^n_1 u_i \\otimes \\bar\nu_i\\right\\|.\\leqno (6)$$ In other words, the right side of (6) is minimal\nexactly when $u_i = \\lambda(g_i)$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $u_1,\\ldots,u_n$ be unitary operators on a Hilbert space $H$. We study\nthe norm $$\\left\\|\\sum^{i=n}_{i=1} u_i \\otimes \\bar u_i\\right\\|\\leqno (1)$$ of\nthe operator $\\sum u_i \\otimes \\bar u_i$ acting on the Hilbertian tensor\nproduct $H\\otimes_2 \\overline H$. The main result of this note is\n  Theorem 1. For any $n$-tuple $u_1,\\ldots, u_n$ of unitary operators in\n$B(H)$, we have $$2\\sqrt{n-1} \\le \\left\\|\\sum^n_1 u_i \\otimes \\bar\nu_i\\right\\|.\\leqno (6)$$ In other words, the right side of (6) is minimal\nexactly when $u_i = \\lambda(g_i)$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gilles Pisier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Gilles Pisier"}, "author": "Gilles Pisier", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Linear Algebra and its Applications. 267 (1997) 125-137.", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/9512207v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/9512207v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46H", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/9706211v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/9706211v1", "updated": "1997-06-06T00:00:00Z", "updated_parsed": [1997, 6, 6, 0, 0, 0, 4, 157, 0], "published": "1997-06-06T00:00:00Z", "published_parsed": [1997, 6, 6, 0, 0, 0, 4, 157, 0], "title": "The similarity degree of an operator algebra", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The similarity degree of an operator algebra"}, "summary": "Let $A$ be a unital operator algebra. Let us assume that every {\\it\nbounded\\/} unital homomorphism $u\\colon \\ A\\to B(H)$ is similar to a {\\it\ncontractive\\/} one. Let $\\text{\\rm Sim}(u) = \\inf\\{\\|S\\|\\, \\|S^{-1}\\|\\}$ where\nthe infimum runs over all invertible operators $S\\colon \\ H\\to H$ such that the\n``conjugate'' homomorphism $a\\to S^{-1}u(a)S$ is contractive. Now for all\n$c>1$, let $\\Phi(c) = \\sup\\text{\\rm Sim}(u)$ where the supremum runs over all\nunital homomorphism $u\\colon\\ A\\to B(H)$ with $\\|u\\|\\le c$. Then, there is\n$\\alpha\\ge 0$ such that for some constant $K$ we have: $$\\Phi(c) \\le\nKc^\\alpha.\\leqno (*)\\qquad \\forall c>1$$ Moreover, the smallest $\\alpha$ for\nwhich this holds is an integer, denoted by $d(A)$ (called the similarity degree\nof $A$) and $(*)$ still holds for some $K$ when $\\alpha=d(A)$. Among the\napplications of these results, we give new characterizations of proper uniform\nalgebras on one hand, and of nuclear $C^*$-algebras on the other. Moreover, we\nobtain a characterization of amenable groups which answers (at least partially)\na question on group representations going back to a 1950 paper of Dixmier.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $A$ be a unital operator algebra. Let $\\text{\\rm Sim}(u) = \\inf\\{\\|S\\|\\, \\|S^{-1}\\|\\}$ where\nthe infimum runs over all invertible operators $S\\colon \\ H\\to H$ such that the\n``conjugate'' homomorphism $a\\to S^{-1}u(a)S$ is contractive. This means that for any unital homomorphism $u\\colon A_d\\to\nB(H)$ we have $\\|u\\|_{cb} \\le K\\|u\\|^d$ with $K>0$ independent of $u$, and the\nexponent $d$ in this estimate cannot be improved. This paper brings several\ncomplements: we give direct proofs (with slight improvements) of several known\nfacts on the length which were only known via the degree, and we show that the\nlength of a type $II_1$ factor with property $\\Gamma$ is at most 5, improving\non a previous bound ($\\le 44$) due to E. By an\noperator space, we mean a closed subspace $E\\subset B(H)$, with $H$ Hilbert.\n  We will be mainly concerned here with the ``geometry'' of {\\it finite\ndimensional\\/} operator spaces. In the Banach space category, it is well known\nthat every separable space embeds isometrically into $\\ell_\\infty$. Moreover,\nif $E$ is a finite dimensional normed space then for each $\\vp>0$, there is an\ninteger $n$ and a subspace $F\\subset \\ell^n_\\infty$ which is\n$(1+\\vp)$-isomorphic to $E$, i.e. there is an isomorphism $u\\colon \\ E\\to F$\nsuch that $\\|u\\|\\ \\|u^{-1}\\|\\le 1+\\vp$. Here of course, $n$ depends on $\\vp$,\nsay $n=n(\\vp)$ and usually (for instance if $E = \\ell^k_2$) we have $n(\\vp)\\to\n\\infty$ when $\\vp\\to 0$.\n  Quite interestingly, it turns out that this fact is not valid in the category\nof operator spaces:\\ although every operator space embeds completely\nisometrically into $B(H)$ (the non-commutative analogue of $\\ell_\\infty$) it is\nnot true that a finite dimensional operator space must be close to a subspace\nof $M_n$ (the non-commutative analogue of $\\ell^n_\\infty$) for some $n$. The\nmain object of this paper is to study this phenomenon.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we study {\\it operator spaces\\/} in the sense of the theory\ndeveloped recently by Blecher-Paulsen [BP] and Effros-Ruan [ER1]. By an\noperator space, we mean a closed subspace $E\\subset B(H)$, with $H$ Hilbert.\n  We will be mainly concerned here with the ``geometry'' of {\\it finite\ndimensional\\/} operator spaces. In the Banach space category, it is well known\nthat every separable space embeds isometrically into $\\ell_\\infty$. Moreover,\nif $E$ is a finite dimensional normed space then for each $\\vp>0$, there is an\ninteger $n$ and a subspace $F\\subset \\ell^n_\\infty$ which is\n$(1+\\vp)$-isomorphic to $E$, i.e. there is an isomorphism $u\\colon \\ E\\to F$\nsuch that $\\|u\\|\\ \\|u^{-1}\\|\\le 1+\\vp$. We study a class of bounded linear maps $u\\colon E\\to F^*$ which we call\ntracially bounded. In particular, we prove that every completely bounded (in\nshort $c.b.$) map $u\\colon E\\to F^*$ factors boundedly through a Hilbert space.\nThis is used to show that the set $OS_n$ of all $n$-dimensional operator spaces\nequipped with the $c.b.$ version of the Banach Mazur distance is not separable\nif $n>2$.\n  As an application we show that there is more than one $C^*$-norm on\n$B(H)\\otimes B(H)$, or equivalently that\n$$B(H)\\otimes_{\\min}B(H)\\not=B(H)\\otimes_{\\max}B(H),$$ which answers a long\nstanding open question.\n  Finally we show that every ``maximal\" operator space (in the sense of\nPaulsen) is not exact in the infinite dimensional case, and in the finite\ndimensional case, we give a lower bound for the ``exactness constant\".", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $E,F$ be exact operators (For example subspaces of the $C^*$-algebra\n$K(H)$ of all the compact operators on an infinite dimensional Hilbert space\n$H$). In particular, we prove that every completely bounded (in\nshort $c.b.$) map $u\\colon E\\to F^*$ factors boundedly through a Hilbert space.\nThis is used to show that the set $OS_n$ of all
