Our inequality is less sharp but\nalso appears to apply with more general (and even matricial) coefficients. It\nshows that up to a universal constant all moments of the norm of a linear\ncombination of the form\n  $$S=\\sum\\nolimits_j a_j U_j \\otimes \\bar U_j (1-P)$$ are dominated by those\nof the corresponding Gaussian sum\n  $$S'=\\sum\\nolimits_j a_j Y_j \\otimes \\bar Y'_j .$$ The advantage is that $S'$\nis now simply separately a Gaussian random variable with respect to the\nindependent Gaussian random matrices $(Y_j)$ and $(Y'_j)$, and hence is much\neasier to majorize. Note we plan to incorporate this appendix into our future\npublication.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this appendix to our paper with the same title posted on arxiv we give a\nquick proof of an inequality that can be substituted to Hastings's result,\nquoted as Lemma 1.9 in our previous paper. Our inequality is less sharp but\nalso appears to apply with more general (and even matricial) coefficients. It\nshows that up to a universal constant all moments of the norm of a linear\ncombination of the form\n  $$S=\\sum\\nolimits_j a_j U_j \\otimes \\bar U_j (1-P)$$ are dominated by those\nof the corresponding Gaussian sum\n  $$S'=\\sum\\nolimits_j a_j Y_j \\otimes \\bar Y'_j .$$ The advantage is that $S'$\nis now simply separately a Gaussian random variable with respect to the\nindependent Gaussian random matrices $(Y_j)$ and $(Y'_j)$, and hence is much\neasier to majorize. Note we plan to incorporate this appendix into our future\npublication."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gilles Pisier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Gilles Pisier"}, "author": "Gilles Pisier", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1211.1055v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1211.1055v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0810.5705v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0810.5705v2", "updated": "2008-11-17T10:50:20Z", "updated_parsed": [2008, 11, 17, 10, 50, 20, 0, 322, 0], "published": "2008-10-31T15:05:00Z", "published_parsed": [2008, 10, 31, 15, 5, 0, 4, 305, 0], "title": "Remarks on the non-commutative Khintchine inequalities for $0<p<2$", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Remarks on the non-commutative Khintchine inequalities for $0<p<2$"}, "summary": "We show that the validity of the non-commutative Khintchine inequality for\nsome $q$ with $1<q<2$ implies its validity (with another constant) for all\n$1\\le p<q$. We prove this for the inequality involving the Rademacher\nfunctions, but also for more general \"lacunary\" sequences, or even\nnon-commutative analogues of the Rademacher functions. For instance, we may\napply it to the \"Z(2)-sequences\" previously considered by Harcharras. The\nresult appears to be new in that case. It implies that the space $\\ell^n_1$\ncontains (as an operator space) a large subspace uniformly isomorphic (as an\noperator space) to $R_k+C_k$ with $k\\sim n^{\\frac12}$. This naturally raises\nseveral interesting questions concerning the best possible such $k$.\nUnfortunately we cannot settle the validity of the non-commutative Khintchine\ninequality for $0<p<1$ but we can prove several would be corollaries. For\ninstance, given an infinite scalar matrix $[x_{ij}]$, we give a necessary and\nsufficient condition for $[\\pm x_{ij}]$ to be in the Schatten class $S_p$ for\nalmost all (independent) choices of signs $\\pm 1$. We also characterize the\nbounded Schur multipliers from $S_2$ to $S_p$. The latter two characterizations\nextend to $0<p<1$ results already known for $1\\le p\\le2$. In addition, we\nobserve that the hypercontractive inequalities, proved by Carlen and Lieb for\nthe Fermionic case, remain valid for operator space valued functions, and hence\nthe Kahane inequalities are valid in this setting.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We show that the validity of the non-commutative Khintchine inequality for\nsome $q$ with $1<q<2$ implies its validity (with another constant) for all\n$1\\le p<q$. We prove this for the inequality involving the Rademacher\nfunctions, but also for more general \"lacunary\" sequences, or even\nnon-commutative analogues of the Rademacher functions. For instance, we may\napply it to the \"Z(2)-sequences\" previously considered by Harcharras. The\nresult appears to be new in that case. It implies that the space $\\ell^n_1$\ncontains (as an operator space) a large subspace uniformly isomorphic (as an\noperator space) to $R_k+C_k$ with $k\\sim n^{\\frac12}$. This naturally raises\nseveral interesting questions concerning the best possible such $k$.\nUnfortunately we cannot settle the validity of the non-commutative Khintchine\ninequality for $0<p<1$ but we can prove several would be corollaries. For\ninstance, given an infinite scalar matrix $[x_{ij}]$, we give a necessary and\nsufficient condition for $[\\pm x_{ij}]$ to be in the Schatten class $S_p$ for\nalmost all (independent) choices of signs $\\pm 1$. We also characterize the\nbounded Schur multipliers from $S_2$ to $S_p$. The latter two characterizations\nextend to $0<p<1$ results already known for $1\\le p\\le2$. In addition, we\nobserve that the hypercontractive inequalities, proved by Carlen and Lieb for\nthe Fermionic case, remain valid for operator space valued functions, and hence\nthe Kahane inequalities are valid in this setting."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gilles Pisier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Gilles Pisier"}, "author": "Gilles Pisier", "arxiv_comment": "Some more minor corrections", "arxiv_journal_ref": "J. A function $\\ph : G \\to \\comp$ is called a completely bounded\nmultiplier (= Herz-Schur multiplier) if the transformation defined on the\nlinear span $K(G)$ of $\\{\\lambda(x),x \\in G\\}$ by $$\\sum_{x \\in G} f(x)\n\\lambda(x) \\to \\sum_{x \\in G} f(x) \\ph(x) \\lambda(x)$$ is completely bounded\n(in short c.b.) on the $C^*$-algebra $C_\\lambda^*(G)$ which is generated by\n$\\lambda$ ($C_\\lambda^*(G)$ is the closure of $K(G)$ in\n$B(\\ell_2(G),\\ell_2(G))$.) A function $\\ph : G \\to \\comp$ is called a completely bounded\nmultiplier (= Herz-Schur multiplier) if the transformation defined on the\nlinear span $K(G)$ of $\\{\\lambda(x),x \\in G\\}$ by $$\\sum_{x \\in G} f(x)\n\\lambda(x) \\to \\sum_{x \\in G} f(x) \\ph(x) \\lambda(x)$$ is completely bounded\n(in short c.b.) on the $C^*$-algebra $C_\\lambda^*(G)$ which is generated by\n$\\lambda$ ($C_\\lambda^*(G)$ is the closure of $K(G)$ in\n$B(\\ell_2(G),\\ell_2(G))$.) In fact we obtain a\nmore general fact: assuming that the families $X^{(k)}=\\{X_i^{(k)}\\}$ and\n$Y^{(k)}=\\{Y_j^{(k)}\\}$ are $*$-free as well as their limits (in moments) $X\n=\\{X_i \\}$ and $Y =\\{Y_j\\}$, the strong convergences $X^{(k)}\\to X$ and\n$Y^{(k)}\\to Y$ imply that of $\\{X^{(k)},Y^{(k)} \\}$ to $\\{X ,Y\\}$. Phrased in\nmore striking language: the reduced free product is \"continuous\" with respect\nto strong convergence. The analogue for weak convergence (i.e. convergence of\nall moments) is obvious. Our approach extends to the amalgamated free product,\nleft open by Skoufranis.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Using an inequality due to Ricard and Xu, we give a different proof of Paul\nSkoufranis's recent result showing that the strong convergence of possibly\nnon-commutative random variables $X^{(k)}\\to X$ is stable under reduced free\nproduct with a fixed non-commutative random variable $Y$. In fact we obtain a\nmore general fact: assuming that the families $X^{(k)}=\\{X_i^{(k)}\\}$ and\n$Y^{(k)}=\\{Y_j^{(k)}\\}$ are $*$-free as well as their limits (in moments) $X\n=\\{X_i \\}$ and $Y =\\{Y_j\\}$, the strong convergences $X^{(k)}\\to X$ and\n$Y^{(k)}\\to Y$ imply that of $\\{X^{(k)},Y^{(k)} \\}$ to $\\{X ,Y\\}$. This is optimal. The first example of this kind was given by\nBourgain and Lewko, but with constant $\\approx \\sqrt {\\log n}$. We also include\nthe analogous $n\\times n$-matrix valued example, for which the optimal constant\nis $\\approx n$. We deduce from our example that there are two $n$-tuples each\nSidon with constant 1, lying in orthogonal linear subspaces and such that their\nunion is Sidon only with constant $\\approx \\sqrt n$. This is again\nasymptotically optimal. We show that any martingale difference sequence with\nvalues in $[-1,1]$ is \"dominated\" in a natural sense (related to our results)\nby any sequence of independent, identically distributed, symmetric\n$\\{-1,1\\}$-valued variables (e.g. the Rademacher functions). We include a\nself-contained proof that any sequence $(\\varphi_n)$ that is the union of two\nSidon sequences lying in orthogonal subspaces is such that\n$(\\varphi_n\\otimes\\varphi_n \\otimes\\varphi_n\\otimes\\varphi_n)$ is Sidon.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We give a simple example of an $n$-tuple of orthonormal elements in $L_2$\n(actually martingale differences) bounded by a fixed constant, and hence\nsubgaussian with a fixed constant but that are Sidon only with constant\n$\\approx \\sqrt n$. We also include\nthe analogous $n\\times n$-matrix valued example, for which the optimal constant\nis $\\approx n$. We deduce from our example that there are two $n$-tuples each\nSidon with constant 1, lying in orthogonal linear subspaces and such that their\nunion is Sidon only with constant $\\approx \\sqrt n$. This is again\nasymptotically optimal. We show that any martingale difference sequence with\nvalues in $[-1,1]$ is \"dominated\" in a natural sense (related to our results)\nby any sequence of independent, identically distributed, symmetric\n$\\{-1,1\\}$-valued variables (e.g. the Rademacher functions). We are interested either in\nestimates independent of the dimension or in asymptotic estimates when the\ndimension tends to $\\infty$. For instance, we prove that, if $N({B_n},d,\n1+\\varepsilon)$ is the smallest number of \"balls\" of \"radius\" $1+\\varepsilon$\nthat cover $ B_n$, then for any $\\varepsilon>0$ we have $$0<\\liminf_{n\\to\n\\infty}n^{-1} \\log\\log N(B_n,d,1+\\varepsilon)\\le \\limsup_{n\\to \\infty}n^{-1}\n\\log\\log N(B_n,d,1+\\varepsilon)<\\infty.$$ We also prove an analogous result for\nthe metric entropy of the set of n-dimensional operator spaces equipped with\nthe distance $d_N$ naturally associated to $N\\times N$-matrices with operator\nentries. In that case $N$ is arbitrary but our estimates are valid\nindependently of $N$. In the Banach space case (i.e.N=1) the above upper bound\nis part of the folklore, and the lower bound is at least partially known (but\napparently has not appeared in print). While we follow the same approach in\nboth cases, the matricial case requires more delicate ingredients, namely\nestimates (from our previous work) on certain $n$-tuples of $N\\times N$ unitary\nmatrices known as \"quantum expanders\".", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study the metric entropy of the metric space $B_n$ of all n-dimensional\nBanach spaces (the so-called Banach-Mazur compactum) equipped with the\nBanach-Mazur (multiplicative) \"distance\" $d$. We are interested either in\nestimates independent of the dimension or in asymptotic estimates when the\ndimension tends to $\\infty$. For instance, we prove that, if $N({B_n},d,\n1+\\varepsilon)$ is the smallest number of \"balls\" of \"radius\" $1+\\varepsilon$\nthat cover $ B_n$, then for any $\\varepsilon>0$ we have $$0<\\liminf_{n\\to\n\\infty}n^{-1} \\log\\log N(B_n,d,1+\\varepsilon)\\le \\limsup_{n\\to \\infty}n^{-1}\n\\log\\log N(B_n,d,1+\\varepsilon)<\\infty.$$ We also prove an analogous result for\nthe metric entropy of the set of n-dimensional operator spaces equipped with\nthe distance $d_N$ naturally associated to $N\\times N$-matrices with operator\nentries. In that case $N$ is arbitrary but our estimates are valid\nindependently of $N$. In the Banach space case (i.e.N=1) the above upper bound\nis part of the folklore, and the lower bound is at least partially known (but\napparently has not appeared in print). While we follow the same approach in\nboth cases, the matricial case requires more delicate ingredients, namely\nestimates (from our previous work) on certain $n$-tuples of $N\\times N$ unitary\nmatrices known as \"quantum expanders\"."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gilles Pisier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Gilles Pisier"}, "author": "Gilles Pisier", "arxiv_doi": "10.1112/S0025579314000102", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1112/S0025579314000102", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1306.5325v6", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1306.5325v6", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "The role of quantum expanders is better highlighted in version 3. More\ngenerally, we prove the folllowing theorem. Let $1<p<2$. Let $(T(t))_{t>0}$ be\na holomorphic semigroup on $L_p$ (relative to a probability space). Assume the\nfollowing mild form of hypercontractivity: for some large enough number $s>0$,\n$T(s)$ is bounded from $L_p$ to $L_2$. Then for any $t>0$, $T(t)$ is in the\nnorm closure in $B(L_p)$ (denoted by $\\bar{\\Gamma_2}$) of the subset (denoted\nby ${\\Gamma_2}$) formed by the operators mapping $L_p$ to $L_2$ (a fortiori\nthese operators factor through a Hilbert space).", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this note, we answer a question raised by Johnson and Schechtman\n\\cite{JS}, about the hypercontractive semigroup on $\\{-1,1\\}^{\\NN}$. More\ngenerally, we prove the folllowing theorem. Let $1<p<2$. Let $(T(t))_{t>0}$ be\na holomorphic semigroup on $L_p$ (relative to a probability space). Assume the\nfollowing mild form of hypercontractivity: for some large enough number $s>0$,\n$T(s)$ is bounded from $L_p$ to $L_2$. Then for any $t>0$, $T(t)$ is in the\nnorm closure in $B(L_p)$ (denoted by $\\bar{\\Gamma_2}$) of the subset (denoted\nby ${\\Gamma_2}$) formed by the operators mapping $L_p$ to $L_2$ (a fortiori\nthese operators factor through a Hilbert space)."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gilles Pisier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Gilles Pisier"}, "author": "Gilles Pisier", "arxiv_comment": "Wolfgang Arendt kindly pointed out to me that the main point of this\n  remark is essentially obvious, just by the analyticity of the semigroup. "published": "1997-04-04T00:00:00Z", "published_parsed": [1997, 4, 4, 0, 0, 0, 4, 94, 0], "title": "The ``maximal\" tensor product of operator spaces", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The ``maximal\" tensor product of operator spaces"}, "summary": "In analogy with the maximal tensor product of $C^*$-algebras, we define the\n``maximal\" tensor product $E_1\\otimes_\\mu E_2$ of two operator spaces $E_1$ and\n$E_2$ and we show that it can be identified completely isometrically with the\nsum of the two Haagerup tensor products: \\ $E_1\\otimes_h E_2 + E_2\\otimes_h\nE_1$. Let $E$ be an $n$-dimensional operator space. As an application, we show\nthat the equality $E^* \\otimes_\\mu E=E^* \\otimes_{\\rm min} E$ holds\nisometrically iff $E = R_n$ or $E=C_n$ (the row or column $n$-dimensional\nHilbert spaces). Moreover, we show that if an operator space $E$ is such that,\nfor any operator space $F$, we have $F\\otimes_{\\min} E=F\\otimes_{\\mu} E$\nisomorphically, then $E$ is completely isomorphic to either a row or a column\nHilbert space.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In analogy with the maximal tensor product of $C^*$-algebras, we define the\n``maximal\" tensor product $E_1\\otimes_\\mu E_2$ of two operator spaces $E_1$ and\n$E_2$ and we show that it can be identified completely isometrically with the\nsum of the two Haagerup tensor products: \\ $E_1\\otimes_h E_2 + E_2\\otimes_h\nE_1$. Let $E$ be an $n$-dimensional operator space. As an application, we show\nthat the equality $E^* \\otimes_\\mu E=E^* \\otimes_{\\rm min} E$ holds\nisometrically iff $E = R_n$ or $E=C_n$ (the row or column $n$-dimensional\nHilbert spaces). More precisely, if $F$\ndenotes $\\ell_2$ equipped with the operator space structure of $(C,R)_\\theta$,\nthen $u: A \\to F$ is completely bounded iff there are states $f,g$ on $A$ and\n$C>0$ such that \\[ \\forall a\\in A\\quad \\|ua\\|^2\\le C\nf(a^*a)^{1-\\theta}g(aa^*)^{\\theta}.\\] This extends the case $\\theta=1/2$\ntreated in a recent paper with Shlyakhtenko. The constants we obtain tend to 1\nwhen $\\theta \\to 0$ or $\\theta\\to 1$. We use analogues of \"free Gaussian\"\nfamilies in non semifinite von Neumann algebras. As an application, we obtain\nthat, if $0<\\theta<1$, $(C,R)_\\theta$ does not embed completely isomorphically\ninto the predual of a semifinite von Neumann algebra. Moreover, we characterize\nthe subspaces $S\\subset R\\oplus C$ such that the dual operator space $S^*$\nembeds (completely isomorphically) into $M_*$ for some semifinite von neumann\nalgebra $M$: the only possibilities are $S=R$, $S=C$, $S=R\\cap C$ and direct\nsums built out of these three spaces. We also discuss when $S\\subset R\\oplus C$\nis injective, and give a simpler proof of a result due to Oikhberg on this\nquestion. In the appendix, we present a proof of Junge's theorem that $OH$\nembeds completely isomorphically into a non-commutative $L_1$-space. The main\nidea is similar to Junge's, but we base the argument on complex interpolation\nand Shlyakhtenko's generalized circular systems (or ``generalized free\nGaussian\"), that somewhat unifies Junge's ideas with those of our work with\nShlyakhtenko.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We prove a factorization of completely bounded maps from a $C^*$-algebra $A$\n(or an exact operator space $E\\subset A$) to $\\ell_2$ equipped with the\noperator space structure of $(C,R)_\\theta$ ($0<\\theta<1$) obtained by complex\ninterpolation between the column and row Hilbert spaces. More precisely, if $F$\ndenotes $\\ell_2$ equipped with the operator space structure of $(C,R)_\\theta$,\nthen $u: A \\to F$ is completely bounded iff there are states $f,g$ on $A$ and\n$C>0$ such that \\[ \\forall a\\in A\\quad \\|ua\\|^2\\le C\nf(a^*a)^{1-\\theta}g(aa^*)^{\\theta}.\\] This extends the case $\\theta=1/2$\ntreated in a recent paper with Shlyakhtenko. The constants we obtain tend to 1\nwhen $\\theta \\to 0$ or $\\theta\\to 1$. We use analogues of \"free Gaussian\"\nfamilies in non semifinite von Neumann algebras. As an application, we obtain\nthat, if $0<\\theta<1$, $(C,R)_\\theta$ does not embed completely isomorphically\ninto the predual of a semifinite von Neumann algebra. Moreover, we characterize\nthe subspaces $S\\subset R\\oplus C$ such that the dual operator space $S^*$\nembeds (completely isomorphically) into $M_*$ for some semifinite von neumann\nalgebra $M$: the only possibilities are $S=R$, $S=C$, $S=R\\cap C$ and direct\nsums built out of these three spaces. We also discuss when $S\\subset R\\oplus C$\nis injective, and give a simpler proof of a result due to Oikhberg on this\nquestion. In the appendix, we present a proof of Junge's theorem that $OH$\nembeds completely isomorphically into a non-commutative $L_1$-space. The main\nidea is similar to Junge's, but we base the argument on complex interpolation\nand Shlyakhtenko's generalized circular systems (or ``generalized free\nGaussian\"), that somewhat unifies Junge's ideas with those of our work with\nShlyakhtenko."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gilles Pisier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Gilles Pisier"}, "author": "Gilles Pisier", "arxiv_comment": "Minor corrections of misprints and addition of an introduction", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0403220v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0403220v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L07, 46L54, 47L25, 47L50", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1710.08896v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1710.08896v1", "updated": "2017-10-24T17:18:20Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 10, 24, 17, 18, 20, 1, 297, 0], "published": "2017-10-24T17:18:20Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 10, 24, 17, 18, 20, 1, 297, 0], "title": "Impossibility of dimension reduction in the nuclear norm", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Impossibility of dimension reduction in the nuclear norm"}, "summary": "Let $\\mathsf{S}_1$ (the Schatten--von Neumann trace class) denote the Banach\nspace of all compact linear operators $T:\\ell_2\\to \\ell_2$ whose nuclear norm\n$\\|T\\|_{\\mathsf{S}_1}=\\sum_{j=1}^\\infty\\sigma_j(T)$ is finite, where\n$\\{\\sigma_j(T)\\}_{j=1}^\\infty$ are the singular values of $T$. We prove that\nfor arbitrarily large $n\\in \\mathbb{N}$ there exists a subset\n$\\mathcal{C}\\subseteq \\mathsf{S}_1$ with $|\\mathcal{C}|=n$ that cannot be\nembedded with bi-Lipschitz distortion $O(1)$ into any $n^{o(1)}$-dimensional\nlinear subspace of $\\mathsf{S}_1$. $\\mathcal{C}$ is not even a $O(1)$-Lipschitz\nquotient of any subset of any $n^{o(1)}$-dimensional linear subspace of\n$\\mathsf{S}_1$. Thus, $\\mathsf{S}_1$ does not admit a dimension reduction\nresult \\'a la Johnson and Lindenstrauss (1984), which complements the work of\nHarrow, Montanaro and Short (2011) on the limitations of quantum dimension\nreduction under the assumption that the embedding into low dimensions is a\nquantum channel. Such a statement was previously known with $\\mathsf{S}_1$\nreplaced by the Banach space $\\ell_1$ of absolutely summable sequences via the\nwork of Brinkman and Charikar (2003). In fact, the above set $\\mathcal{C}$ can\nbe taken to be the same set as the one that Brinkman and Charikar considered,\nviewed as a collection of diagonal matrices in $\\mathsf{S}_1$. The challenge is\nto demonstrate that $\\mathcal{C}$ cannot be faithfully realized in an arbitrary\nlow-dimensional subspace of $\\mathsf{S}_1$, while Brinkman and Charikar\nobtained such an assertion only for subspaces of $\\mathsf{S}_1$ that consist of\ndiagonal operators (i.e., subspaces of $\\ell_1$). We establish this by proving\nthat the Markov 2-convexity constant of any finite dimensional linear subspace\n$X$ of $\\mathsf{S}_1$ is at most a universal constant multiple of $\\sqrt{\\log\n\\mathrm{dim}(X)}$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $\\mathsf{S}_1$ (the Schatten--von Neumann trace class) denote the Banach\nspace of all compact linear operators $T:\\ell_2\\to \\ell_2$ whose nuclear norm\n$\\|T\\|_{\\mathsf{S}_1}=\\sum_{j=1}^\\infty\\sigma_j(T)$ is finite, where\n$\\{\\sigma_j(T)\\}_{j=1}^\\infty$ are the singular values of $T$. We prove that\nfor arbitrarily large $n\\in \\mathbb{N}$ there exists a subset\n$\\mathcal{C}\\subseteq \\mathsf{S}_1$ with $|\\mathcal{C}|=n$ that cannot be\nembedded with bi-Lipschitz distortion $O(1)$ into any $n^{o(1)}$-dimensional\nlinear subspace of $\\mathsf{S}_1$. $\\mathcal{C}$ is not even a $O(1)$-Lipschitz\nquotient of any subset of any $n^{o(1)}$-dimensional linear subspace of\n$\\mathsf{S}_1$. Thus, $\\mathsf{S}_1$ does not admit a dimension reduction\nresult \\'a la Johnson and Lindenstrauss (1984), which complements the work of\nHarrow, Montanaro and Short (2011) on the limitations of quantum dimension\nreduction under the assumption that the embedding into low dimensions is a\nquantum channel. Such a statement was previously known with $\\mathsf{S}_1$\nreplaced by the Banach space $\\ell_1$ of absolutely summable sequences via the\nwork of Brinkman and Charikar (2003). In fact, the above set $\\mathcal{C}$ can\nbe taken to be the same set as the one that Brinkman and Charikar considered,\nviewed as a collection of diagonal matrices in $\\mathsf{S}_1$. The challenge is\nto demonstrate that $\\mathcal{C}$ cannot be faithfully realized in an arbitrary\nlow-dimensional subspace of $\\mathsf{S}_1$, while Brinkman and Charikar\nobtained such an assertion only for subspaces of $\\mathsf{S}_1$ that consist of\ndiagonal operators (i.e., subspaces of $\\ell_1$). We establish this by proving\nthat the Markov 2-convexity constant of any finite dimensional linear subspace\n$X$ of $\\mathsf{S}_1$ is at most a universal constant multiple of "", "value": "Complex Interpolation between Hilbert, Banach and Operator spaces"}, "summary": "Motivated by a question of Vincent Lafforgue, we study the Banach spaces $X$\nsatisfying the following property: there is a function $\\vp\\to \\Delta_X(\\vp)$\ntending to zero with $\\vp>0$ such that every operator $T\\colon L_2\\to L_2$ with\n$\\|T\\|\\le \\vp$ that is simultaneously contractive (i.e. of norm $\\le 1$) on\n$L_1$ and on $L_\\infty$ must be of norm $\\le \\Delta_X(\\vp)$ on $L_2(X)$.\n  We show that $\\Delta_X(\\vp)\\in O(\\vp^\\alpha)$ for some $\\alpha>0$ iff $X$ is\nisomorphic to a quotient of a subspace of an ultraproduct of\n$\\theta$-Hilbertian spaces for some $ \\theta>0$ (see Corollary\n\\ref{comcor4.3}), where $\\theta$-Hilbertian is meant in a slightly more general\nsense than in our previous paper \\cite{P1}. This paper brings several\ncomplements: we give direct proofs (with slight improvements) of several known\nfacts on the length which were only known via the degree, and we show that the\nlength of a type $II_1$ factor with property $\\Gamma$ is at most 5, improving\non a previous bound ($\\le 44$) due to E. Christensen.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The \"similarity\" degree of a unital operator algebra $A$ was defined and\nstudied in two recent papers of ours, where in particular we showed that it\ncoincides with the \"length\" of an operator algebra. Analogously a $C^*$-algebra $A$ is nuclear iff\nany bounded homomorphism $u: A\\to B(H)$ is strongly similar to a\n$*$-homomorphism in the sense that there is an invertible operator $\\xi$ in the\nvon Neumann algebra generated by the range of $u$ such that $a\\to \\xi u(a)\n\\xi^{-1}$ is a $*$-homomorphism. An analogous characterization holds in terms\nof derivations. We apply this to answer several questions left open in our\nprevious work concerning the length $\\ell(A,B)$ of the maximal tensor product\n$A\\otimes_{\\max} B$ of two unital $C^*$-algebras, when we consider its\ngeneration by the subalgebras $A\\otimes 1$ and $1\\otimes B$. We show that if\n$\\ell(A,B)<\\infty$ either for $B=B(\\ell_2)$ or when $B$ is the $C^*$-algebra\n(either full or reduced) of a non Abelian free group, then $A$ must be nuclear.\nWe also show that $\\ell(A,B)\\le d$ iff the canonical quotient map from the\nunital free product $A\\ast B$ onto $A\\otimes_{\\max} B$ remains a complete\nquotient map when restricted to the closed span of the words of length $\\le d$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We prove that a discrete group $G$ is amenable iff it is strongly\nunitarizable in the following sense: every unitarizable representation $\\pi$ on\n$G$ can be unitarized by an invertible chosen in the von Neumann algebra\ngenerated by the range of $\\pi$. Analogously a $C^*$-algebra $A$ is nuclear iff\nany bounded homomorphism $u: A\\to B(H)$ is strongly similar to a\n$*$-homomorphism in the sense that there is an invertible operator $\\xi$ in the\nvon Neumann algebra generated by the range of $u$ such that $a\\to \\xi u(a)\n\\xi^{-1}$ is a $*$-homomorphism. An analogous characterization holds in terms\nof derivations. We apply this to answer several questions left open in our\nprevious work concerning the length $\\ell(A,B)$ of the maximal tensor product\n$A\\otimes_{\\max} B$ of two unital $C^*$-algebras, when we consider its\ngeneration by the subalgebras $A\\otimes 1$ and $1\\otimes B$. We show that if\n$\\ell(A,B)<\\infty$ either for $B=B(\\ell_2)$ or when $B$ is the $C^*$-algebra\n(either full or reduced) of a non Abelian free group, then $A$ must be nuclear.\nWe also show that $\\ell(A,B)\\le d$ iff the canonical quotient map from the\nunital free product $A\\ast B$ onto $A\\otimes_{\\max} B$ remains a complete\nquotient map when restricted to the closed span of the words of length $\\le d$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gilles Pisier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Gilles Pisier"}, "author": "Gilles Pisier", "arxiv_comment": "There are several improvements both to the exposition and to some\n  results. Given any positive\ninteger $d$, we study the operator space structure of the subspace\n$\\Word_p(n,d)$ of $L_p(\\tau)$ generated by the family of operators\n$\\lambda(g_{i_1}g_{i_2} ... g_{i_d})$ with $1 \\le i_k \\le n$. Moreover, our\ndescription of this operator space holds up to a constant which does not depend\non $n$ or $p$, so that our result remains valid for infinitely many generators.\nWe also consider the subspace of $L_p(\\tau)$ generated by the image under\n$\\lambda$ of the set of reduced words of length $d$. Our result extends to any\nexponent $1 \\le p \\le \\infty$ a previous result of Buchholz for the space\n$\\Word_{\\infty}(n,d)$. The main application is a certain interpolation theorem,\nvalid for any degree $d$ (extending a result of the second author restricted to\n$d=1$). In the simplest case $d=2$, our theorem can be stated as follows:\nconsider the space $\\mathcal{K}_p$ formed of all block matrices $a=(a_{ij})$\nwith entries in the Schatten class $S_p$, such that $a$ is in $S_p$ relative to\n$\\ell_2 \\otimes \\ell_2$ and moreover such that $(\\sum_{ij} a_{ij}^* a_{ij}\n)^{1/2}$ and $(\\sum_{ij} a_{ij} a_{ij}^*)^{1/2}$ both belong to $S_p$. We equip\n$\\mathcal{K}_p$ with the maximum of the three corresponding norms. Then, for $2\n\\le p \\le \\infty$ we have $\\mathcal{K}_p \\simeq (\\mathcal{K}_2,\n\\mathcal{K}_\\infty)_\\theta$ with $1/p = (1-\\theta)/2$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $\\Free_n$ denote the free group with $n$ generators $g_1, g_2, ..., g_n$.\nLet $\\lambda$ stand for the left regular representation of $\\Free_n$ and let\n$\\tau$ be the standard trace associated to $\\lambda$. Given any positive\ninteger $d$, we study the operator space structure of the subspace\n$\\Word_p(n,d)$ of $L_p(\\tau)$ generated by the family of operators\n$\\lambda(g_{i_1}g_{i_2} ... g_{i_d})$ with $1 \\le i_k \\le n$. Moreover, our\ndescription of this operator space holds up to a constant which does not depend\non $n$ or $p$, so that our result remains valid for infinitely many generators.\nWe also consider the subspace of $L_p(\\tau)$ generated by the image under\n$\\lambda$ of the set of reduced words of length $d$. Our result extends to any\nexponent $1 \\le p \\le \\infty$ a previous result of Buchholz for the space\n$\\Word_{\\infty}(n,d)$. The main application is a certain interpolation theorem,\nvalid for any degree $d$ (extending a result of the second author restricted to\n$d=1$). In the simplest case $d=2$, our theorem can be stated as follows:\nconsider the space $\\mathcal{K}_p$ formed of all block matrices $a=(a_{ij})$\nwith entries in the Schatten class $S_p$, such that $a$ is in $S_p$ relative to\n$\\ell_2 \\otimes \\ell_2$ and moreover such that $(\\sum_{ij} a_{ij}^* a_{ij}\n)^{1/2}$ and $(\\sum_{ij} a_{ij} a_{ij}^*)^{1/2}$ both belong to $S_p$. We equip\n$\\mathcal{K}_p$ with the maximum of the three corresponding norms. Then, for $2\n\\le p \\le \\infty$ we have $\\mathcal{K}_p \\simeq (\\mathcal{K}_2,\n\\mathcal{K}_\\infty)_\\theta$ with $1/p = (1-\\theta)/2$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Javier Parcet"}, {"name": "Gilles Pisier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Gilles Pisier"}, "author": "Gilles Pisier", "arxiv_comment": "20 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0312300v7", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0312300v7", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L52; 46L53", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1109.1006v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1109.1006v1", "updated": "2011-09-05T20:14:35Z", "updated_parsed": [2011, 9, 5, 20, 14, 35, 0, 248, 0], "published": "2011-09-05T20:14:35Z", "published_parsed": [2011, 9, 5, 20, 14, 35, 0, 248, 0], "title": "Real interpolation and transposition of certain function spaces", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Real interpolation and transposition of certain function spaces"}, "summary": "Our starting point is a lemma due to Varopoulos. 21, 50, 29, 2, 197, 0], "title": "Nonexistence of Positive Supersolutions of Nonlinear Biharmonic\n  Equations without the Maximum Principle", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Nonexistence of Positive Supersolutions of Nonlinear Biharmonic\n  Equations without the Maximum Principle"}, "summary": "We study classical positive solutions of the biharmonic inequality\n  $-\\Delta^2 v \\geq f(v)$\n  in exterior domains in $\\mathbb{R}^n$ where $f:(0,\\infty)\\to (0,\\infty)$ is\ncontinuous function. We give lower bounds on the growth of $f(s)$ at $s=0$\nand/or $s=\\infty$ such that this inequality has no $C^4$ positive solution in\nany exterior domain of $\\mathbb R^n$. Similar results were obtained by\nArmstrong and Sirakov [ Nonexistence of positive supersolutions of elliptic\nequations via the maximum principle, Comm. Partial Differential Equations 36\n(2011) 2011-2047] for $-\\Delta v\\ge f(v)$ using a method which depends only on\nproperties related to the maximum principle. Since the maximum principle does\nnot hold for the biharmonic operator, we adopt a different approach which\nrelies on a new representation formula and an a priori pointwise bound for\nnonnegative solutions of $-\\Delta^2u \\ge 0$ in a punctured neighborhood of the\norigin in $\\mathbb{R}^n$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study classical positive solutions of the biharmonic inequality\n  $-\\Delta^2 v \\geq f(v)$\n  in exterior domains in $\\mathbb{R}^n$ where $f:(0,\\infty)\\to (0,\\infty)$ is\ncontinuous function. We give lower bounds on the growth of $f(s)$ at $s=0$\nand/or $s=\\infty$ such that this inequality has no $C^4$ positive solution in\nany exterior domain of $\\mathbb R^n$. Similar results were obtained by\nArmstrong and Sirakov [ Nonexistence of positive supersolutions of elliptic\nequations via the maximum principle, Comm. Partial Differential Equations 36\n(2011) 2011-2047] for $-\\Delta v\\ge f(v)$ using a method which depends only on\nproperties related to the maximum principle. Since the maximum principle does\nnot hold for the biharmonic operator, we adopt a different approach which\nrelies on a new representation formula and an a priori pointwise bound for\nnonnegative solutions of $-\\Delta^2u \\ge 0$ in a punctured neighborhood of the\norigin in $\\mathbb{R}^n$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Marius Ghergu"}, {"name": "Steven D. Taliaferro"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Steven D. Taliaferro"}, "author": "Steven D. We provide optimal\nconditions on $f$ and $g$ at $\\infty$ such that solutions of this system\nsatisfy pointwise bounds near the origin. The best previous complexity bounds were\nexponential in the sparse encoding, even for n fixed. We then give a\ncharacterization of those functions k(n) such that the complexity of detecting\nreal roots for n-variate (n+k(n))-nomials transitions from P to NP-hardness as\nn tends to infinity. We show that deciding whether X contains a point all of whose\ncoordinates are d_th roots of unity can be done within NP^NP (relative to the\nsparse encoding), under a plausible assumption on primes in arithmetic\nprogression. In particular, our hypothesis can still hold even under certain\nfailures of the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis, such as the presence of\nSiegel-Landau zeroes. Furthermore, we give a similar (but UNconditional)\ncomplexity upper bound for n=1. Finally, letting T be any algebraic subgroup of\n(C^*)^n we show that deciding whether X contains T is coNP-complete (relative\nto an even more efficient encoding),unconditionally. We thus obtain new\nnon-trivial families of multivariate polynomial systems where deciding the\nexistence of complex roots can be done unconditionally in the polynomial\nhierarchy -- a family of complexity classes lying between PSPACE and P,\nintimately connected with the P=?NP Problem. In particular - for a version of the\ncondition number defined by Cucker, Krick, Malajovich, and Wschebor - we\nestablish new probabilistic estimates that allow a much broader family of\nmeasures than considered earlier. More precisely, we show that the following two problems\ncan be solved in the complexity class PSPACE:\n  (I) Given polynomials f_1,...,f_m in Z[x_1,...,x_n] defining a variety of\ndimension <=0 in C^n, find all solutions in Z^n of f_1=...=f_m=0. (II) For a\ngiven polynomial f in Z[v,x,y] defining an irreducible nonsingular non-ruled\nsurface in C^3, decide the sentence ``\\exists v \\forall x \\exists y such that\nf(v,x,y)=0?'' quantified over N. Better still, we show that the truth of the\nGeneralized Riemann Hypothesis implies that detecting roots in Q^n for the\npolynomial systems in (I) can be done via a two-round Arthur-Merlin protocol,\ni.e., well within the second level of the polynomial hierarchy. (Problem (I)\nis, of course, undecidable without the dimension assumption.) The decidability\nof problem (II) was previously unknown. Along the way, we also prove new\ncomplexity and size bounds for solving polynomial systems over C and Z/pZ. A\npractical point of interest is that the aforementioned Diophantine problems\nshould perhaps be avoided in the construction of crypto-systems.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider the average-case complexity of some otherwise undecidable or open\nDiophantine problems. More precisely, we show that the following two problems\ncan be solved in the complexity class PSPACE:\n  (I) Given polynomials f_1,...,f_m in Z[x_1,...,x_n] defining a variety of\ndimension <=0 in C^n, find all solutions in Z^n of f_1=...=f_m=0. (II) For a\ngiven polynomial f in Z[v,x,y] defining an irreducible nonsingular non-ruled\nsurface in C^3, decide the sentence ``\\exists v \\forall x \\exists y such that\nf(v,x,y)=0?'' quantified over N. Better still, we show that the truth of the\nGeneralized Riemann Hypothesis implies that detecting roots in Q^n for the\npolynomial systems in (I) can be done via a two-round Arthur-Merlin protocol,\ni.e., well within the second level of the polynomial hierarchy. (Problem (I)\nis, of course, undecidable without the dimension assumption.) The decidability\nof problem (II) was previously unknown. Along the way, we also prove new\ncomplexity and size bounds for solving polynomial systems over C and Z/pZ. A\npractical point of interest is that the aforementioned Diophantine problems\nshould perhaps be avoided in the construction of crypto-systems."}, "authors": [{"name": "J. Maurice Rojas"}], "author_detail": {"name": "J. Maurice Rojas"}, "author": "J. Maurice Rojas", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/9811088v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/9811088v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1011.4128v5", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1011.4128v5", "updated": "2012-11-06T04:16:53Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 11, 6, 4, 16, 53, 1, 311, 0], "published": "2010-11-18T03:10:42Z", "published_parsed": [2010, 11, 18, 3, 10, 42, 3, 322, 0], "title": "Fewnomial Systems with Many Roots, and an Adelic Tau Conjecture", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Fewnomial Systems with Many Roots, and an Adelic Tau Conjecture"}, "summary": "Consider a system F of n polynomials in n variables, with a total of n+k\ndistinct exponent vectors, over any local field L. We discuss conjecturally\ntight bounds on the maximal number of non-degenerate roots F can have over L,\nwith all coordinates having fixed phase, as a function of n, k, and L only. In\nparticular, we give new explicit systems with number of roots approaching the\nbest known upper bounds. We also briefly review the background behind such\nbounds, and their application, including connections to computational number\ntheory and variants of the Shub-Smale tau-Conjecture and the P vs. NP Problem.\nOne of our key tools is the construction of combinatorially constrained\ntropical varieties with maximally many intersections.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Consider a system F of n polynomials in n variables, with a total of n+k\ndistinct exponent vectors, over any local field L. We discuss conjecturally\ntight bounds on the maximal number of non-degenerate roots F can have over L,\nwith all coordinates having fixed phase, as a function of n, k, and L only. In\nparticular, we give new explicit systems with number of roots approaching the\nbest known upper bounds. We also briefly review the background behind such\nbounds, and their application, including connections to computational number\ntheory and variants of the Shub-Smale tau-Conjecture and the P vs. NP Problem.\nOne of our key tools is the construction of combinatorially constrained\ntropical varieties with maximally many intersections."}, "authors": [{"name": "Kaitlyn Phillipson"}, {"name": "J. More precisely, we show that the following two problems\ncan be solved in the complexity class PSPACE:\n  (I) Given polynomials f_1,...,f_m in Z[x_1,...,x_n] defining a variety of\ndimension <=0 in C^n, find all solutions in Z^n of f_1=...=f_m=0. (II) For a\ngiven polynomial f in Z[v,x,y] defining an irreducible nonsingular non-ruled\nsurface in C^3, decide the sentence ``\\exists v \\forall x \\exists y such that\nf(v,x,y)=0?'' quantified over N. Better still, we show that the truth of the\nGeneralized Riemann Hypothesis implies that detecting roots in Q^n for the\npolynomial systems in (I) can be done via a two-round Arthur-Merlin protocol,\ni.e., well within the second level of the polynomial hierarchy. (Problem (I)\nis, of course, undecidable without the dimension assumption.) The decidability\nof problem (II) was previously unknown. Along the way, we also prove new\ncomplexity and size bounds for solving polynomial systems over C and Z/pZ. A\npractical point of interest is that the aforementioned Diophantine problems\nshould perhaps be avoided in the construction of crypto-systems.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider the average-case complexity of some otherwise undecidable or open\nDiophantine problems. We obtain this as a corollary of a new positive\ncomplexity result: the Diophantine prefixes EAE and EEAE are generically\ndecidable. This means, taking the former prefix as an example, that we give a\nprecise geometric classification of those polynomials f in Z[v,x,y] for which\nthe question...\n  ``Does there exists a v in N such that for all x in N, there exists a y in N\nwith f(v,x,y)=0?''\n  ...may be undecidable, and we show that this set of polynomials is quite\nsmall in a rigourous sense. We obtain this as a corollary of a new positive\ncomplexity result: the Diophantine prefixes EAE and EEAE are generically\ndecidable. This means, taking the former prefix as an example, that we give a\nprecise geometric classification of those polynomials f in Z[v,x,y] for which\nthe question...\n  ``Does there exists a v in N such that for all x in N, there exists a y in N\nwith f(v,x,y)=0?''\n  ...may be undecidable, and we show that this set of polynomials is quite\nsmall in a rigourous sense. We show that the real part, $R$, of such a zero\nset can be approximated by the $(n-1)$-dimensional skeleton, $T$, of a\npolyhedral subdivision of $\\mathbb{R}^n$. In particular, we give an explicit\nupper bound on the Hausdorff distance: $\\Delta(R,T)\n=O\\left(t^{3.5}/\\delta\\right)$, where $t$ and $\\delta$ are respectively the\nnumber of terms and the minimal spacing of the frequencies of $g$. On the side\nof computational complexity, we show that even the $n=2$ case of the membership\nproblem for $R$ is undecidable in the Blum-Shub-Smale model over $\\mathbb{R}$,\nwhereas membership and distance queries for our polyhedral approximation $T$\ncan be decided in polynomial-time for any fixed $n$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study the complexity of approximating complex zero sets of certain\n$n$-variate exponential sums. We show that the real part, $R$, of such a zero\nset can be approximated by the $(n-1)$-dimensional skeleton, $T$, of a\npolyhedral subdivision of $\\mathbb{R}^n$. In particular, we give an explicit\nupper bound on the Hausdorff distance: $\\Delta(R,T)\n=O\\left(t^{3.5}/\\delta\\right)$, where $t$ and $\\delta$ are respectively the\nnumber of terms and the minimal spacing of the frequencies of $g$. More precisely, consider the following: (I) Given a\npolynomial f in Z[v,x,y], decide the sentence \\exists v \\forall x \\exists y\nf(v,x,y)=0, with all three quantifiers ranging over N (or Z). (II) Given\npolynomials f_1,...,f_m in Z[x_1,...,x_n] with m>=n, decide if there is a\nrational solution to f_1=...=f_m=0. We show that, for almost all inputs,\nproblem (I) can be done within coNP. The decidability of problem (I), over N\nand Z, was previously unknown. We also show that the Generalized Riemann\nHypothesis (GRH) implies that, for almost all inputs, problem (II) can be done\nvia within the complexity class PP^{NP^NP}, i.e., within the third level of the\npolynomial hierarchy. The decidability of problem (II), even in the case m=n=2,\nremains open in general.\n  Along the way, we prove results relating polynomial system solving over C, Q,\nand Z/pZ. We also prove a result on Galois groups associated to sparse\npolynomial systems which may be of independent interest. A practical\nobservation is that the aforementioned Diophantine problems should perhaps be\navoided in the construction of crypto-systems.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider the average-case complexity of some otherwise undecidable or open\nDiophantine problems. More precisely, consider the following: (I) Given a\npolynomial f in Z[v,x,y], decide the sentence \\exists v \\forall x \\exists y\nf(v,x,y)=0, with all three quantifiers ranging over N (or Z). (II) Given\npolynomials f_1,...,f_m in Z[x_1,...,x_n] with m>=n, decide if there is a\nrational solution to f_1=...=f_m=0. We show that, for almost all inputs,\nproblem (I) can be done within coNP. The decidability of problem (I), over N\nand Z, was previously unknown. We also show that the Generalized Riemann\nHypothesis (GRH) implies that, for almost all inputs, problem (II) can be done\nvia within the complexity class PP^{NP^NP}, i.e., within the third level of the\npolynomial hierarchy. The decidability of problem (II), even in the case m=n=2,\nremains open in general.\n  Along the way, we prove results relating polynomial system solving over C, Q,\nand Z/pZ. We also prove a result on Galois groups associated to sparse\npolynomial systems which may be of independent interest. A practical\nobservation is that the aforementioned Diophantine problems should perhaps be\navoided in the construction of crypto-systems."}, "authors": [{"name": "J. We give a Las Vegas randomized algorithm that computes\nthe number of roots of $f$ in $\\mathbb{Z}/\\!\\left(p^k\\right)$ within time\n$d^3(k\\log p)^{2+o(1)}$. (We in fact prove a more intricate complexity bound\nthat is slightly better.) The best previous general algorithm had\n(deterministic) complexity exponential in $k$. We also present some\nexperimental data evincing the potential practicality of our algorithm.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Suppose $k,p\\!\\in\\!\\mathbb{N}$ with $p$ prime and $f\\!\\in\\!\\mathbb{Z}[x]$ is\na univariate polynomial with degree $d$ and all coefficients having absolute\nvalue less than $p^k$. We give a Las Vegas randomized algorithm that computes\nthe number of roots of $f$ in $\\mathbb{Z}/\\!\\left(p^k\\right)$ within time\n$d^3(k\\log p)^{2+o(1)}$. We\ngive an efficiently constructible polyhedral approximation,\n$\\mathrm{ArchtTrop}(f)$, of $\\mathrm{Amoeba}(f)$, and derive explicit upper and\nlower bounds, solely as a function of the number of monomial terms of $f$, for\nthe Hausdorff distance between these two sets. We also show that deciding\nwhether a given point lies in $\\mathrm{ArchTrop}(f)$ is doable in\npolynomial-time, for any fixed dimension, unlike the corresponding problem for\n$\\mathrm{Amoeba}(f)$, which is $\\mathbf{NP}$-hard already in one variable.\n$\\mathrm{ArchTrop}(f)$ can thus serve as a canonical low order approximation to\nstart any higher order iterative polynomial system solving algorithm, such as\nhomotopy continuation. $\\mathrm{ArchTrop}(f)$ also provides an Archimedean\nanalogue of Kapranov's Non-Archimedean Amoeba Theorem and a higher-dimensional\nextension of earlier estimates of Mikhalkin and Ostrowski.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Given any complex Laurent polynomial $f$, $\\mathrm{Amoeba}(f)$ is the image\nof its complex zero set under the coordinate-wise log absolute value map. For the case of affine space minus an arbitrary union\nof coordinate hyperplanes, these formulae are also the tightest possible upper\nbounds on the number of isolated roots. We also characterize, in terms of\nsparse resultants, precisely when these upper bounds are attained. Our bound\nis novel in that it is stated in terms of the volumes of certain polytopes and,\nfor a large class of inputs, beats the best previous bounds by a factor\nexponential in the number of variables. (2) A new algorithm for approximating\nthe real roots of certain sparse polynomial systems. Two features of our\nalgorithm are (a) arithmetic complexity polylogarithmic in the degree of the\nunderlying complex variety (as opposed to the super-linear dependence in\nearlier algorithms) and (b) a simple and efficient generalization to certain\nunivariate exponential sums. Defined on open hypercubes, these\nfamilies are characterized by particular good behavior under projection maps.\nThe motivating examples are certain families of reaction networks -- including\nreversible, weakly reversible, endotactic, and strongly endotactic reaction\nnetworks -- that give rise to vertexical families of mass-action differential\ninclusions. We prove that vertexical families are amenable to structural\ninduction. Consequently, a trajectory of a vertexical family approaches the\nboundary if and only if either the trajectory approaches a vertex of the\nhypercube, or a trajectory in a lower-dimensional member of the family\napproaches the boundary. With this technology, we make progress on the global\nattractor conjecture, a central open problem concerning mass-action kinetics\nsystems. Additionally, we phrase mass-action kinetics as a functor on reaction\nnetworks with variable rates.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Motivated by questions in mass-action kinetics, we introduce the notion of\nvertexical family of differential inclusions. Defined on open hypercubes, these\nfamilies are characterized by particular good behavior under projection maps.\nThe motivating examples are certain families of reaction networks -- including\nreversible, weakly reversible, endotactic, and strongly endotactic reaction\nnetworks -- that give rise to vertexical families of mass-action differential\ninclusions. We prove that vertexical families are amenable to structural\ninduction. Consequently, a trajectory of a vertexical family approaches the\nboundary if and only if either the trajectory approaches a vertex of the\nhypercube, or a trajectory in a lower-dimensional member of the family\napproaches the boundary. With this technology, we make progress on the global\nattractor conjecture, a central open problem concerning mass-action kinetics\nsystems. Additionally, we phrase mass-action kinetics as a functor on reaction\nnetworks with variable rates."}, "authors": [{"name": "Manoj Gopalkrishnan"}, {"name": "Ezra Miller"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, "author": "Anne Shiu", "arxiv_doi": "10.3842/SIGMA.2013.025", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.3842/SIGMA.2013.025", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1208.0874v5", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1208.0874v5", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "v5: published version; v3 and v4: minor additional edits; v2:\n  contains more general version of main theorem on vertexical families,\n  including its accompanying corollaries -- some of them new; final section\n  contains new results relating to prior and future research on persistence of\n  mass-action systems; improved exposition throughout", "arxiv_journal_ref": "SIGMA 9 (2013), 025, 25 pages", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.SY", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "q-bio.MN", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.1590v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.1590v2", "updated": "2011-07-12T13:20:09Z", "updated_parsed": [2011, 7, 12, 13, 20, 9, 1, 193, 0], "published": "2011-02-08T12:43:02Z", "published_parsed": [2011, 2, 8, 12, 43, 2, 1, 39, 0], "title": "Chemical reaction systems with toric steady states", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Chemical reaction systems with toric steady states"}, "summary": "Mass-action chemical reaction systems are frequently used in Computational\nBiology. The corresponding polynomial dynamical systems are often large\n(consisting of tens or even hundreds of ordinary differential equations) and\npoorly parametrized (due to noisy measurement data and a small number of data\npoints and repetitions). Therefore, it is often difficult to establish the\nexistence of (positive) steady states or to determine whether more complicated\nphenomena such as multistationarity exist. If, however, the steady state ideal\nof the system is a binomial ideal, then we show that these questions can be\nanswered easily. The focus of this work is on systems with this property, and\nwe say that such systems have toric steady states. Our main result gives\nsufficient conditions for a chemical reaction system to have toric steady\nstates. Furthermore, we analyze the capacity of such a system to exhibit\npositive steady states and multistationarity. Examples of systems with toric\nsteady states include weakly-reversible zero-deficiency chemical reaction\nsystems. An important application of our work concerns the networks that\ndescribe the multisite phosphorylation of a protein by a kinase/phosphatase\npair in a sequential and distributive mechanism.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Mass-action chemical reaction systems are frequently used in Computational\nBiology. The corresponding polynomial dynamical systems are often large\n(consisting of tens or even hundreds of ordinary differential equations) and\npoorly parametrized (due to noisy measurement data and a small number of data\npoints and repetitions). Therefore, it is often difficult to establish the\nexistence of (positive) steady states or to determine whether more complicated\nphenomena such as multistationarity exist. If, however, the steady state ideal\nof the system is a binomial ideal, then we show that these questions can be\nanswered easily. The focus of this work is on systems with this property, and\nwe say that such systems have toric steady states. Our main result gives\nsufficient conditions for a chemical reaction system to have toric steady\nstates. Furthermore, we analyze the capacity of such a system to exhibit\npositive steady states and multistationarity. Examples of systems with toric\nsteady states include weakly-reversible zero-deficiency chemical reaction\nsystems. An important application of our work concerns the networks that\ndescribe the multisite phosphorylation of a protein by a kinase/phosphatase\npair in a sequential and distributive mechanism."}, "authors": [{"name": "Mercedes Perez Millan"}, {"name": "Alicia Dickenstein"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, {"name": "Carsten Conradi"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Carsten Conradi"}, "author": "Carsten Conradi", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.1590v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1102.1590v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "q-bio.MN", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1106.1578v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1106.1578v2", "updated": "2012-02-14T17:47:02Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 2, 14, 17, 47, 2, 1, 45, 0], "published": "2011-06-08T15:04:17Z", "published_parsed": [2011, 6, 8, 15, 4, 17, 2, 159, 0], "title": "Simplifying the Jacobian Criterion for precluding multistationarity in\n  chemical reaction networks", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Simplifying the Jacobian Criterion for precluding multistationarity in\n  chemical reaction networks"}, "summary": "Chemical reaction networks taken with mass-action kinetics are dynamical\nsystems that arise in chemical engineering and systems biology. In general,\ndetermining whether a chemical reaction network admits multiple steady states\nis difficult, as this requires determining existence of multiple positive\nsolutions to a large system of polynomials with unknown coefficients. However,\nin certain cases, various easy criteria can be applied. One such test is the\nJacobian Criterion, due to Craciun and Feinberg, which gives sufficient\nconditions for ruling out the possibility of multiple steady states. A chemical\nreaction network is said to pass the Jacobian Criterion if all terms in the\ndeterminant expansion of its parametrized Jacobian matrix have the same sign.\nIn this article, we present a procedure which simplifies the application of the\nJacobian Criterion, and as a result, we identify a new class of networks for\nwhich multiple steady states is precluded: those in which all chemical species\nhave total molecularity of at most two. The total molecularity of a species\nrefers to the sum of all of its stoichiometric coefficients in the network. We\nillustrate our results by examining enzyme catalysis networks.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Chemical reaction networks taken with mass-action kinetics are dynamical\nsystems that arise in chemical engineering and systems biology. In general,\ndetermining whether a chemical reaction network admits multiple steady states\nis difficult, as this requires determining existence of multiple positive\nsolutions to a large system of polynomials with unknown coefficients. However,\nin certain cases, various easy criteria can be applied. One such test is the\nJacobian Criterion, due to Craciun and Feinberg, which gives sufficient\nconditions for ruling out the possibility of multiple steady states. A chemical\nreaction network is said to pass the Jacobian Criterion if all terms in the\ndeterminant expansion of its parametrized Jacobian matrix have the same sign.\nIn this article, we present a procedure which simplifies the application of the\nJacobian Criterion, and as a result, we identify a new class of networks for\nwhich multiple steady states is precluded: those in which all chemical species\nhave total molecularity of at most two. The total molecularity of a species\nrefers to the sum of all of its stoichiometric coefficients in the network. We\nillustrate our results by examining enzyme catalysis networks."}, "authors": [{"name": "Badal Joshi"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, "author": "Anne Shiu", "arxiv_comment": "26 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1106.1578v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1106.1578v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "q-bio.MN", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0605173v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0605173v2", "updated": "2006-07-20T17:08:15Z", "updated_parsed": [2006, 7, 20, 17, 8, 15, 3, 201, 0], "published": "2006-05-07T03:57:13Z", "published_parsed": [2006, 5, 7, 3, 57, 13, 6, 127, 0], "title": "Geometry of rank tests", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Geometry of rank tests"}, "summary": "We study partitions of the symmetric group which have desirable geometric\nproperties. The statistical tests defined by such partitions involve counting\nall permutations in the equivalence classes. These permutations are the linear\nextensions of partially ordered sets specified by the data. Our methods refine\nrank tests of non-parametric statistics, such as the sign test and the runs\ntest, and are useful for the exploratory analysis of ordinal data. Convex rank\ntests correspond to probabilistic conditional independence structures known as\nsemi-graphoids. Submodular rank tests are classified by the faces of the cone\nof submodular functions, or by Minkowski summands of the permutohedron. We\nenumerate all small instances of such rank tests. Graphical tests correspond to\nboth graphical models and to graph associahedra, and they have excellent\nstatistical and algorithmic properties.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study partitions of the symmetric group which have desirable geometric\nproperties. The statistical tests defined by such partitions involve counting\nall permutations in the equivalence classes. These permutations are the linear\nextensions of partially ordered sets specified by the data. Our methods refine\nrank tests of non-parametric statistics, such as the sign test and the runs\ntest, and are useful for the exploratory analysis of ordinal data. Convex rank\ntests correspond to probabilistic conditional independence structures known as\nsemi-graphoids. Submodular rank tests are classified by the faces of the cone\nof submodular functions, or by Minkowski summands of the permutohedron. We\nenumerate all small instances of such rank tests. Graphical tests correspond to\nboth graphical models and to graph associahedra, and they have excellent\nstatistical and algorithmic properties."}, "authors": [{"name": "Jason Morton"}, {"name": "Lior Pachter"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, {"name": "Bernd Sturmfels"}, {"name": "Oliver Wienand"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Oliver Wienand"}, "author": "Oliver Wienand", "arxiv_comment": "8 pages, 4 figures.
