Combinatorial codes, comprised of binary patterns of neural\nactivity, encode information via the collective behavior of populations of\nneurons. A code is called convex if its codewords correspond to regions defined\nby an arrangement of convex open sets in Euclidean space. Convex codes have\nbeen observed experimentally in many brain areas, including sensory cortices\nand the hippocampus, where neurons exhibit convex receptive fields. What makes\na neural code convex? That is, how can we tell from the intrinsic structure of\na code if there exists a corresponding arrangement of convex open sets? In this\nwork, we provide a complete characterization of local obstructions to\nconvexity. This motivates us to define max intersection-complete codes, a\nfamily guaranteed to have no local obstructions. We then show how our\ncharacterization enables one to use free resolutions of Stanley-Reisner ideals\nin order to detect violations of convexity. Taken together, these results\nprovide a significant advance in understanding the intrinsic combinatorial\nproperties of convex codes.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Neural codes allow the brain to represent, process, and store information\nabout the world. Combinatorial codes, comprised of binary patterns of neural\nactivity, encode information via the collective behavior of populations of\nneurons. A code is called convex if its codewords correspond to regions defined\nby an arrangement of convex open sets in Euclidean space. Convex codes have\nbeen observed experimentally in many brain areas, including sensory cortices\nand the hippocampus, where neurons exhibit convex receptive fields. What makes\na neural code convex? That is, how can we tell from the intrinsic structure of\na code if there exists a corresponding arrangement of convex open sets? In this\nwork, we provide a complete characterization of local obstructions to\nconvexity. This motivates us to define max intersection-complete codes, a\nfamily guaranteed to have no local obstructions. We then show how our\ncharacterization enables one to use free resolutions of Stanley-Reisner ideals\nin order to detect violations of convexity. Taken together, these results\nprovide a significant advance in understanding the intrinsic combinatorial\nproperties of convex codes."}, "authors": [{"name": "Carina Curto"}, {"name": "Elizabeth Gross"}, {"name": "Jack Jeffries"}, {"name": "Katherine Morrison"}, {"name": "Mohamed Omar"}, {"name": "Zvi Rosen"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, {"name": "Nora Youngs"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Nora Youngs"}, "author": "Nora Youngs", "arxiv_comment": "25 pages, 9 figures, and 2 tables. Supplementary Text begins on page\n  17. Accepted to SIAM Journal on Applied Algebra and Geometry (SIAGA)", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.00150v4", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1508.00150v4", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "q-bio.NC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "q-bio.NC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1404.5524v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1404.5524v2", "updated": "2014-10-22T01:05:21Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 10, 22, 1, 5, 21, 2, 295, 0], "published": "2014-04-22T15:23:09Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 4, 22, 15, 23, 9, 1, 112, 0], "title": "A global convergence result for processive multisite phosphorylation\n  systems", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A global convergence result for processive multisite phosphorylation\n  systems"}, "summary": "Multisite phosphorylation plays an important role in intracellular signaling.\nThere has been much recent work aimed at understanding the dynamics of such\nsystems when the phosphorylation/dephosphorylation mechanism is distributive,\nthat is, when the binding of a substrate and an enzyme molecule results in\naddition or removal of a single phosphate group and repeated binding therefore\nis required for multisite phosphorylation. In particular, such systems admit\nbistability. Here we analyze a different class of multisite systems, in which\nthe binding of a substrate and an enzyme molecule results in addition or\nremoval of phosphate groups at all phosphorylation sites. That is, we consider\nsystems in which the mechanism is processive, rather than distributive. We show\nthat in contrast with distributive systems, processive systems modeled with\nmass-action kinetics do not admit bistability and, moreover, exhibit rigid\ndynamics: each invariant set contains a unique equilibrium, which is a global\nattractor. Additionally, we obtain a monomial parametrization of the steady\nstates. Our proofs rely on a technique of Johnston for using \"translated\"\nnetworks to study systems with \"toric steady states\", recently given sign\nconditions for injectivity of polynomial maps, and a result from monotone\nsystems theory due to Angeli and Sontag.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Multisite phosphorylation plays an important role in intracellular signaling.\nThere has been much recent work aimed at understanding the dynamics of such\nsystems when the phosphorylation/dephosphorylation mechanism is distributive,\nthat is, when the binding of a substrate and an enzyme molecule results in\naddition or removal of a single phosphate group and repeated binding therefore\nis required for multisite phosphorylation. In particular, such systems admit\nbistability. Here we analyze a different class of multisite systems, in which\nthe binding of a substrate and an enzyme molecule results in addition or\nremoval of phosphate groups at all phosphorylation sites. That is, we consider\nsystems in which the mechanism is processive, rather than distributive. We show\nthat in contrast with distributive systems, processive systems modeled with\nmass-action kinetics do not admit bistability and, moreover, exhibit rigid\ndynamics: each invariant set contains a unique equilibrium, which is a global\nattractor. Additionally, we obtain a monomial parametrization of the steady\nstates. Our proofs rely on a technique of Johnston for using \"translated\"\nnetworks to study systems with \"toric steady states\", recently given sign\nconditions for injectivity of polynomial maps, and a result from monotone\nsystems theory due to Angeli and Sontag."}, "authors": [{"name": "Carsten Conradi"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, "author": "Anne Shiu", "arxiv_comment": "23 pages; substantial revision", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1404.5524v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1404.5524v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "q-bio.MN", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "q-bio.MN", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1311.5493v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1311.5493v2", "updated": "2014-10-30T08:22:41Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 10, 30, 8, 22, 41, 3, 303, 0], "published": "2013-11-21T17:43:57Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 11, 21, 17, 43, 57, 3, 325, 0], "title": "Sign conditions for injectivity of generalized polynomial maps with\n  applications to chemical reaction networks and real algebraic geometry", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Sign conditions for injectivity of generalized polynomial maps with\n  applications to chemical reaction networks and real algebraic geometry"}, "summary": "We give necessary and sufficient conditions in terms of sign vectors for the\ninjectivity of families of polynomial maps with arbitrary real exponents\ndefined on the positive orthant. Our work relates and extends existing\ninjectivity conditions expressed in terms of Jacobian matrices and\ndeterminants. In the context of chemical reaction networks with power-law\nkinetics, our results can be used to preclude as well as to guarantee multiple\npositive steady states. In the context of real algebraic geometry,our work\nrecognizes a prior result of Craciun, Garcia-Puente, and Sottile, together with\nwork of two of the authors, as the first partial multivariate generalization of\nthe classical Descartes' rule, which bounds the number of positive real roots\nof a univariate real polynomial in terms of the number of sign variations of\nits coefficients.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We give necessary and sufficient conditions in terms of sign vectors for the\ninjectivity of families of polynomial maps with arbitrary real exponents\ndefined on the positive orthant. Our work relates and extends existing\ninjectivity conditions expressed in terms of Jacobian matrices and\ndeterminants. In the context of chemical reaction networks with power-law\nkinetics, our results can be used to preclude as well as to guarantee multiple\npositive steady states. In the context of real algebraic geometry,our work\nrecognizes a prior result of Craciun, Garcia-Puente, and Sottile, together with\nwork of two of the authors, as the first partial multivariate generalization of\nthe classical Descartes' rule, which bounds the number of positive real roots\nof a univariate real polynomial in terms of the number of sign variations of\nits coefficients."}, "authors": [{"name": "Stefan M\u00fcller"}, {"name": "Elisenda Feliu"}, {"name": "Georg Regensburger"}, {"name": "Carsten Conradi"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, {"name": "Alicia Dickenstein"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Alicia Dickenstein"}, "author": "Alicia Dickenstein", "arxiv_comment": "To appear in FoCM", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1311.5493v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1311.5493v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.06441v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.06441v2", "updated": "2016-09-19T17:33:35Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 9, 19, 17, 33, 35, 0, 263, 0], "published": "2016-03-21T14:40:09Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 3, 21, 14, 40, 9, 0, 81, 0], "title": "Which small reaction networks are multistationary?", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Which small reaction networks are multistationary?"}, "summary": "Reaction networks taken with mass-action kinetics arise in many settings,\nfrom epidemiology to population biology to systems of chemical reactions.\nBistable reaction networks are posited to underlie biochemical switches, which\nmotivates the following question: which reaction networks have the capacity for\nmultiple steady states? Mathematically, this asks: among certain parametrized\nfamilies of polynomial systems, which admit multiple positive roots? No\ncomplete answer is known. This work analyzes the smallest networks, those with\nonly a few chemical species or reactions. For these \"smallest\" networks, we\ncompletely answer the question of multistationarity and, in some cases,\nmultistability too, thereby extending related work of Boros. Our results\nhighlight the role played by the Newton polytope of a network (the convex hull\nof the reactant vectors). Also, our work is motivated by recent results that\nexplain how a given network's capacity for multistationarity arises from that\nof certain related networks which are typically smaller. Hence, we are\ninterested in classifying small multistationary networks, and our work forms a\nfirst step in this direction.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Reaction networks taken with mass-action kinetics arise in many settings,\nfrom epidemiology to population biology to systems of chemical reactions.\nBistable reaction networks are posited to underlie biochemical switches, which\nmotivates the following question: which reaction networks have the capacity for\nmultiple steady states? Mathematically, this asks: among certain parametrized\nfamilies of polynomial systems, which admit multiple positive roots? No\ncomplete answer is known. This work analyzes the smallest networks, those with\nonly a few chemical species or reactions. For these \"smallest\" networks, we\ncompletely answer the question of multistationarity and, in some cases,\nmultistability too, thereby extending related work of Boros. Our results\nhighlight the role played by the Newton polytope of a network (the convex hull\nof the reactant vectors). Also, our work is motivated by recent results that\nexplain how a given network's capacity for multistationarity arises from that\nof certain related networks which are typically smaller. Hence, we are\ninterested in classifying small multistationary networks, and our work forms a\nfirst step in this direction."}, "authors": [{"name": "Badal Joshi"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, "author": "Anne Shiu", "arxiv_comment": "27 pages, small corrections, added citations, new definition of\n  \"arrow diagram\"", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.06441v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1603.06441v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1305.5303v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1305.5303v2", "updated": "2013-12-18T09:16:30Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 12, 18, 9, 16, 30, 2, 352, 0], "published": "2013-05-23T02:43:50Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 5, 23, 2, 43, 50, 3, 143, 0], "title": "A geometric approach to the Global Attractor Conjecture", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A geometric approach to the Global Attractor Conjecture"}, "summary": "This paper introduces the class of \"strongly endotactic networks\", a subclass\nof the endotactic networks introduced by G. Craciun, F. Nazarov, and C. Pantea.\nThe main result states that the global attractor conjecture holds for\ncomplex-balanced systems that are strongly endotactic: every trajectory with\npositive initial condition converges to the unique positive equilibrium allowed\nby conservation laws. This extends a recent result by D. F. Anderson for\nsystems where the reaction diagram has only one linkage class (connected\ncomponent). The results here are proved using differential inclusions, a\nsetting that includes power-law systems. The key ideas include a perspective on\nreaction kinetics in terms of combinatorial geometry of reaction diagrams, a\nprojection argument that enables analysis of a given system in terms of systems\nwith lower dimension, and an extension of Birch's theorem, a well-known result\nabout intersections of affine subspaces with manifolds parameterized by\nmonomials.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper introduces the class of \"strongly endotactic networks\", a subclass\nof the endotactic networks introduced by G. Craciun, F. Nazarov, and C. Pantea.\nThe main result states that the global attractor conjecture holds for\ncomplex-balanced systems that are strongly endotactic: every trajectory with\npositive initial condition converges to the unique positive equilibrium allowed\nby conservation laws. This extends a recent result by D. F. Anderson for\nsystems where the reaction diagram has only one linkage class (connected\ncomponent). The results here are proved using differential inclusions, a\nsetting that includes power-law systems. The key ideas include a perspective on\nreaction kinetics in terms of combinatorial geometry of reaction diagrams, a\nprojection argument that enables analysis of a given system in terms of systems\nwith lower dimension, and an extension of Birch's theorem, a well-known result\nabout intersections of affine subspaces with manifolds parameterized by\nmonomials."}, "authors": [{"name": "Manoj Gopalkrishnan"}, {"name": "Ezra Miller"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, "author": "Anne Shiu", "arxiv_doi": "10.1137/130928170", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1137/130928170", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1305.5303v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1305.5303v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "v2: 49 pages, 8 figures, minor changes; v1: 48 pages, 8 figures", "arxiv_journal_ref": "SIAM J. Appl. Dyn. Syst. 2014, 13(2), 758--797, (40 pages)", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "q-bio.MN", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1108.5238v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1108.5238v2", "updated": "2012-07-09T17:57:32Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 7, 9, 17, 57, 32, 0, 191, 0], "published": "2011-08-26T04:43:54Z", "published_parsed": [2011, 8, 26, 4, 43, 54, 4, 238, 0], "title": "Atoms of multistationarity in chemical reaction networks", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Atoms of multistationarity in chemical reaction networks"}, "summary": "Chemical reaction systems are dynamical systems that arise in chemical\nengineering and systems biology. In this work, we consider the question of\nwhether the minimal (in a precise sense) multistationary chemical reaction\nnetworks, which we propose to call `atoms of multistationarity,' characterize\nthe entire set of multistationary networks. Our main result states that the\nanswer to this question is `yes' in the context of fully open continuous-flow\nstirred-tank reactors (CFSTRs), which are networks in which all chemical\nspecies take part in the inflow and outflow. In order to prove this result, we\nshow that if a subnetwork admits multiple steady states, then these steady\nstates can be lifted to a larger network, provided that the two networks share\nthe same stoichiometric subspace. We also prove an analogous result when a\nsmaller network is obtained from a larger network by `removing species.' Our\nresults provide the mathematical foundation for a technique used by\nSiegal-Gaskins et al. of establishing bistability by way of `network ancestry.'\nAdditionally, our work provides sufficient conditions for establishing\nmultistationarity by way of atoms and moreover reduces the problem of\nclassifying multistationary CFSTRs to that of cataloging atoms of\nmultistationarity. As an application, we enumerate and classify all 386\nbimolecular and reversible two-reaction networks. Of these, exactly 35 admit\nmultiple positive steady states. Moreover, each admits a unique minimal\nmultistationary subnetwork, and these subnetworks form a poset (with respect to\nthe relation of `removing species') which has 11 minimal elements (the atoms of\nmultistationarity).", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Chemical reaction systems are dynamical systems that arise in chemical\nengineering and systems biology. In this work, we consider the question of\nwhether the minimal (in a precise sense) multistationary chemical reaction\nnetworks, which we propose to call `atoms of multistationarity,' characterize\nthe entire set of multistationary networks. Our main result states that the\nanswer to this question is `yes' in the context of fully open continuous-flow\nstirred-tank reactors (CFSTRs), which are networks in which all chemical\nspecies take part in the inflow and outflow. In order to prove this result, we\nshow that if a subnetwork admits multiple steady states, then these steady\nstates can be lifted to a larger network, provided that the two networks share\nthe same stoichiometric subspace. We also prove an analogous result when a\nsmaller network is obtained from a larger network by `removing species.' Our\nresults provide the mathematical foundation for a technique used by\nSiegal-Gaskins et al. of establishing bistability by way of `network ancestry.'\nAdditionally, our work provides sufficient conditions for establishing\nmultistationarity by way of atoms and moreover reduces the problem of\nclassifying multistationary CFSTRs to that of cataloging atoms of\nmultistationarity. As an application, we enumerate and classify all 386\nbimolecular and reversible two-reaction networks. Of these, exactly 35 admit\nmultiple positive steady states. Moreover, each admits a unique minimal\nmultistationary subnetwork, and these subnetworks form a poset (with respect to\nthe relation of `removing species') which has 11 minimal elements (the atoms of\nmultistationarity)."}, "authors": [{"name": "Badal Joshi"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, "author": "Anne Shiu", "arxiv_comment": "Theorem 3.1 updated to allow general kinetics, conjecture now proven\n  (Theorem 4.2), 3 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1108.5238v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1108.5238v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "q-bio.MN", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1412.5257v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1412.5257v3", "updated": "2015-08-20T19:30:31Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 8, 20, 19, 30, 31, 3, 232, 0], "published": "2014-12-17T04:49:12Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 12, 17, 4, 49, 12, 2, 351, 0], "title": "A survey of methods for deciding whether a reaction network is\n  multistationary", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A survey of methods for deciding whether a reaction network is\n  multistationary"}, "summary": "Which reaction networks, when taken with mass-action kinetics, have the\ncapacity for multiple steady states? There is no complete answer to this\nquestion, but over the last 40 years various criteria have been developed that\ncan answer this question in certain cases. This work surveys these\ndevelopments, with an emphasis on recent results that connect the capacity for\nmultistationarity of one network to that of another. In this latter setting, we\nconsider a network $N$ that is embedded in a larger network $G$, which means\nthat $N$ is obtained from $G$ by removing some subsets of chemical species and\nreactions. This embedding relation is a significant generalization of the\nsubnetwork relation. For arbitrary networks, it is not true that if $N$ is\nembedded in $G$, then the steady states of $N$ lift to $G$. Nonetheless, this\ndoes hold for certain classes of networks; one such class is that of fully open\nnetworks. This motivates the search for embedding-minimal multistationary\nnetworks: those networks which admit multiple steady states but no proper,\nembedded networks admit multiple steady states. We present results about such\nminimal networks, including several new constructions of infinite families of\nthese networks.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Which reaction networks, when taken with mass-action kinetics, have the\ncapacity for multiple steady states? There is no complete answer to this\nquestion, but over the last 40 years various criteria have been developed that\ncan answer this question in certain cases. This work surveys these\ndevelopments, with an emphasis on recent results that connect the capacity for\nmultistationarity of one network to that of another. In this latter setting, we\nconsider a network $N$ that is embedded in a larger network $G$, which means\nthat $N$ is obtained from $G$ by removing some subsets of chemical species and\nreactions. This embedding relation is a significant generalization of the\nsubnetwork relation. For arbitrary networks, it is not true that if $N$ is\nembedded in $G$, then the steady states of $N$ lift to $G$. Nonetheless, this\ndoes hold for certain classes of networks; one such class is that of fully open\nnetworks. This motivates the search for embedding-minimal multistationary\nnetworks: those networks which admit multiple steady states but no proper,\nembedded networks admit multiple steady states. Chemical reaction network theory can provide sufficient\nconditions for the existence of bistability, and on the other hand can rule out\nthe possibility of multiple steady states. Understanding small networks is\nimportant because the existence of multiple steady states in a subnetwork of a\nbiochemical model can sometimes be lifted to establish multistationarity in the\nlarger network. This paper establishes the smallest reversible, mass-preserving\nnetwork that admits bistability and determines the semi-algebraic set of\nparameters for which more than one steady state exists.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Biochemical models that exhibit bistability are of interest to biologists and\nmathematicians alike. One way is through hippocampal\nneurons called place cells, which become associated to convex regions of space\nknown as their receptive fields: each place cell fires at a high rate precisely\nwhen the animal is in the receptive field. The firing patterns of multiple\nplace cells form what is known as a convex neural code. How can we tell when a\nneural code is convex? To address this question, Giusti and Itskov identified a\nlocal obstruction, defined via the topology of a code's simplicial complex, and\nproved that convex neural codes have no local obstructions. Curto et al. proved\nthe converse for all neural codes on at most four neurons. Via a counterexample\non five neurons, we show that this converse is false in general. Additionally,\nwe classify all codes on five neurons with no local obstructions. This\nclassification is enabled by our enumeration of connected simplicial complexes\non 5 vertices up to isomorphism. Finally, we examine how local obstructions are\nrelated to maximal codewords (maximal sets of neurons that co-fire). Curto et\nal. proved that a code has no local obstructions if and only if it contains\ncertain \"mandatory\" intersections of maximal codewords. We give a new criterion\nfor an intersection of maximal codewords to be non-mandatory, and prove that it\nclassifies all such non-mandatory codewords for codes on up to 5 neurons.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "How does the brain encode spatial structure? One way is through hippocampal\nneurons called place cells, which become associated to convex regions of space\nknown as their receptive fields: each place cell fires at a high rate precisely\nwhen the animal is in the receptive field. The firing patterns of multiple\nplace cells form what is known as a convex neural code. How can we tell when a\nneural code is convex? To address this question, Giusti and Itskov identified a\nlocal obstruction, defined via the topology of a code's simplicial complex, and\nproved that convex neural codes have no local obstructions. Curto et al. proved\nthe converse for all neural codes on at most four neurons. Via a counterexample\non five neurons, we show that this converse is false in general. Additionally,\nwe classify all codes on five neurons with no local obstructions. This\nclassification is enabled by our enumeration of connected simplicial complexes\non 5 vertices up to isomorphism. Finally, we examine how local obstructions are\nrelated to maximal codewords (maximal sets of neurons that co-fire). Curto et\nal. proved that a code has no local obstructions if and only if it contains\ncertain \"mandatory\" intersections of maximal codewords. We give a new criterion\nfor an intersection of maximal codewords to be non-mandatory, and prove that it\nclassifies all such non-mandatory codewords for codes on up to 5 neurons."}, "authors": [{"name": "Caitlin Lienkaemper"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, {"name": "Zev Woodstock"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zev Woodstock"}, "author": "Zev Woodstock", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.aam.2016.11.006", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.aam.2016.11.006", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1509.03328v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1509.03328v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "21 pages, 1 table; published version", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Advances in Applied Mathematics, vol. 85, pp. 31-59 (2017)", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "q-bio.NC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "q-bio.NC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "05E45, 55U10, 92C20", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.07522v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.07522v3", "updated": "2016-04-21T15:34:40Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 4, 21, 15, 34, 40, 3, 112, 0], "published": "2015-08-30T01:55:57Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 8, 30, 1, 55, 57, 6, 242, 0], "title": "Analyzing Multistationarity in Chemical Reaction Networks using the\n  Determinant Optimization Method", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Analyzing Multistationarity in Chemical Reaction Networks using the\n  Determinant Optimization Method"}, "summary": "Multistationary chemical reaction networks are of interest to scientists and\nmathematicians alike. While some criteria for multistationarity exist,\nobtaining explicit reaction rates and steady states that exhibit\nmultistationarity for a given network -- in order to check nondegeneracy or\ndetermine stability of the steady states, for instance -- is nontrivial.\nNonetheless, we accomplish this task for a certain family of sequestration\nnetworks. Additionally, our results allow us to prove the existence of\nnondegenerate steady states for some of these sequestration networks, thereby\nresolving a subcase of a conjecture of Joshi and Shiu. Our work relies on the\ndeterminant optimization method, developed by Craciun and Feinberg, for\nasserting that certain networks are multistationary. More precisely, we\nimplement the construction of reaction rates and multiple steady states which\nappears in the proofs that underlie their method. Furthermore, we describe in\ndetail the steps of this construction so that other researchers can more easily\nobtain, as we did, multistationary rates and steady states.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Multistationary chemical reaction networks are of interest to scientists and\nmathematicians alike. While some criteria for multistationarity exist,\nobtaining explicit reaction rates and steady states that exhibit\nmultistationarity for a given network -- in order to check nondegeneracy or\ndetermine stability of the steady states, for instance -- is nontrivial.\nNonetheless, we accomplish this task for a certain family of sequestration\nnetworks. Additionally, our results allow us to prove the existence of\nnondegenerate steady states for some of these sequestration networks, thereby\nresolving a subcase of a conjecture of Joshi and Shiu. Our work relies on the\ndeterminant optimization method, developed by Craciun and Feinberg, for\nasserting that certain networks are multistationary. More precisely, we\nimplement the construction of reaction rates and multiple steady states which\nappears in the proofs that underlie their method. Furthermore, we describe in\ndetail the steps of this construction so that other researchers can more easily\nobtain, as we did, multistationary rates and steady states."}, "authors": [{"name": "Bryan F\u00e9lix"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, {"name": "Zev Woodstock"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zev Woodstock"}, "author": "Zev Woodstock", "arxiv_comment": "24 pages; made small edits and corrected typos", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.07522v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1508.07522v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0903.0901v5", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0903.0901v5", "updated": "2009-11-25T15:39:10Z", "updated_parsed": [2009, 11, 25, 15, 39, 10, 2, 329, 0], "published": "2009-03-05T04:23:59Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 3, 5, 4, 23, 59, 3, 64, 0], "title": "The dynamics of weakly reversible population processes near facets", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The dynamics of weakly reversible population processes near facets"}, "summary": "This paper concerns the dynamical behavior of weakly reversible,\ndeterministically modeled population processes near the facets (codimension-one\nfaces) of their invariant manifolds and proves that the facets of such systems\nare \"repelling.\" It has been conjectured that any population process whose\nnetwork graph is weakly reversible (has strongly connected components) is\npersistent. We prove this conjecture to be true for the subclass of weakly\nreversible systems for which only facets of the invariant manifold are\nassociated with semilocking sets, or siphons. An important application of this\nwork pertains to chemical reaction systems that are complex-balancing. For\nthese systems it is known that within the interior of each invariant manifold\nthere is a unique equilibrium. The Global Attractor Conjecture states that each\nof these equilibria is globally asymptotically stable relative to the interior\nof the invariant manifold in which it lies. Our results pertaining to weakly\nreversible systems imply that this conjecture holds for all complex-balancing\nsystems whose boundary equilibria lie in the relative interior of the boundary\nfacets. As a corollary, we show that the Global Attractor Conjecture holds for\nthose systems for which the associated invariant manifolds are two-dimensional.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper concerns the dynamical behavior of weakly reversible,\ndeterministically modeled population processes near the facets (codimension-one\nfaces) of their invariant manifolds and proves that the facets of such systems\nare \"repelling.\" It has been conjectured that any population process whose\nnetwork graph is weakly reversible (has strongly connected components) is\npersistent. We prove this conjecture to be true for the subclass of weakly\nreversible systems for which only facets of the invariant manifold are\nassociated with semilocking sets, or siphons. An important application of this\nwork pertains to chemical reaction systems that are complex-balancing. For\nthese systems it is known that within the interior of each invariant manifold\nthere is a unique equilibrium. The Global Attractor Conjecture states that each\nof these equilibria is globally asymptotically stable relative to the interior\nof the invariant manifold in which it lies. Our results pertaining to weakly\nreversible systems imply that this conjecture holds for all complex-balancing\nsystems whose boundary equilibria lie in the relative interior of the boundary\nfacets. As a corollary, we show that the Global Attractor Conjecture holds for\nthose systems for which the associated invariant manifolds are two-dimensional."}, "authors": [{"name": "David F. We present a characterization\nof minimal siphons in terms of primary decomposition of binomial ideals, we\nexplore the underlying geometry, and we demonstrate the effective computation\nof siphons using computer algebra software. This leads to a new method for\ndetermining whether given initial concentrations allow for various boundary\nsteady states.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Siphons in a chemical reaction system are subsets of the species that have\nthe potential of being absent in a steady state. We present a characterization\nof minimal siphons in terms of primary decomposition of binomial ideals, we\nexplore the underlying geometry, and we demonstrate the effective computation\nof siphons using computer algebra software. This leads to a new method for\ndetermining whether given initial concentrations allow for various boundary\nsteady states."}, "authors": [{"name": "Anne Shiu"}, {"name": "Bernd Sturmfels"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Bernd Sturmfels"}, "author": "Bernd Sturmfels", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0904.4529v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0904.4529v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "q-bio.MN", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/q-bio/0702049v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/q-bio/0702049v3", "updated": "2007-05-22T17:43:12Z", "updated_parsed": [2007, 5, 22, 17, 43, 12, 1, 142, 0], "published": "2007-02-23T19:39:57Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 2, 23, 19, 39, 57, 4, 54, 0], "title": "The Cyclohedron Test for Finding Periodic Genes in Time Course\n  Expression Studies", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The Cyclohedron Test for Finding Periodic Genes in Time Course\n  Expression Studies"}, "summary": "The problem of finding periodically expressed genes from time course\nmicroarray experiments is at the center of numerous efforts to identify the\nmolecular components of biological clocks. We present a new approach to this\nproblem based on the cyclohedron test, which is a rank test inspired by recent\nadvances in algebraic combinatorics. The test has the advantage of being robust\nto measurement errors, and can be used to ascertain the significance of\ntop-ranked genes. We apply the test to recently published measurements of gene\nexpression during mouse somitogenesis and find 32 genes that collectively are\nsignificant. Among these are previously identified periodic genes involved in\nthe Notch/FGF and Wnt signaling pathways, as well as novel candidate genes that\nmay play a role in regulating the segmentation clock. These results confirm\nthat there are an abundance of exceptionally periodic genes expressed during\nsomitogenesis. The emphasis of this paper is on the statistics and\ncombinatorics that underlie the cyclohedron test and its implementation within\na multiple testing framework.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The problem of finding periodically expressed genes from time course\nmicroarray experiments is at the center of numerous efforts to identify the\nmolecular components of biological clocks. We present a new approach to this\nproblem based on the cyclohedron test, which is a rank test inspired by recent\nadvances in algebraic combinatorics. The test has the advantage of being robust\nto measurement errors, and can be used to ascertain the significance of\ntop-ranked genes. We apply the test to recently published measurements of gene\nexpression during mouse somitogenesis and find 32 genes that collectively are\nsignificant. Among these are previously identified periodic genes involved in\nthe Notch/FGF and Wnt signaling pathways, as well as novel candidate genes that\nmay play a role in regulating the segmentation clock. These results confirm\nthat there are an abundance of exceptionally periodic genes expressed during\nsomitogenesis. The emphasis of this paper is on the statistics and\ncombinatorics that underlie the cyclohedron test and its implementation within\na multiple testing framework."}, "authors": [{"name": "Jason Morton"}, {"name": "Lior Pachter"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, {"name": "Bernd Sturmfels"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Bernd Sturmfels"}, "author": "Bernd Sturmfels", "arxiv_comment": "Revision consists of reorganization and further statistical\n  discussion; 19 pages, 4 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/q-bio/0702049v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/q-bio/0702049v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "q-bio.QM", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "q-bio.QM", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "stat.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0708.3431v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0708.3431v2", "updated": "2007-11-03T02:15:28Z", "updated_parsed": [2007, 11, 3, 2, 15, 28, 5, 307, 0], "published": "2007-08-25T12:20:42Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 8, 25, 12, 20, 42, 5, 237, 0], "title": "Toric dynamical systems", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Toric dynamical systems"}, "summary": "Toric dynamical systems are known as complex balancing mass action systems in\nthe mathematical chemistry literature, where many of their remarkable\nproperties have been established. They include as special cases all deficiency\nzero systems and all detailed balancing systems. One feature is that the steady\nstate locus of a toric dynamical system is a toric variety, which has a unique\npoint within each invariant polyhedron. We develop the basic theory of toric\ndynamical systems in the context of computational algebraic geometry and show\nthat the associated moduli space is also a toric variety. It is conjectured\nthat the complex balancing state is a global attractor. We prove this for\ndetailed balancing systems whose invariant polyhedron is two-dimensional and\nbounded.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Toric dynamical systems are known as complex balancing mass action systems in\nthe mathematical chemistry literature, where many of their remarkable\nproperties have been established. They include as special cases all deficiency\nzero systems and all detailed balancing systems. One feature is that the steady\nstate locus of a toric dynamical system is a toric variety, which has a unique\npoint within each invariant polyhedron. We develop the basic theory of toric\ndynamical systems in the context of computational algebraic geometry and show\nthat the associated moduli space is also a toric variety. It is conjectured\nthat the complex balancing state is a global attractor. We prove this for\ndetailed balancing systems whose invariant polyhedron is two-dimensional and\nbounded."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gheorghe Craciun"}, {"name": "Alicia Dickenstein"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, {"name": "Bernd Sturmfels"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Bernd Sturmfels"}, "author": "Bernd Sturmfels", "arxiv_comment": "We include the proof of our Conjecture 5 (now Lemma 5) and add some\n  references", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0708.3431v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0708.3431v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0702564v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0702564v2", "updated": "2008-02-16T22:45:36Z", "updated_parsed": [2008, 2, 16, 22, 45, 36, 5, 47, 0], "published": "2007-02-20T20:58:04Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 2, 20, 20, 58, 4, 1, 51, 0], "title": "Convex Rank Tests and Semigraphoids", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Convex Rank Tests and Semigraphoids"}, "summary": "Convex rank tests are partitions of the symmetric group which have desirable\ngeometric properties. The statistical tests defined by such partitions involve\ncounting all permutations in the equivalence classes. Each class consists of\nthe linear extensions of a partially ordered set specified by data. Our methods\nrefine existing rank tests of non-parametric statistics, such as the sign test\nand the runs test, and are useful for exploratory analysis of ordinal data. We\nestablish a bijection between convex rank tests and probabilistic conditional\nindependence structures known as semigraphoids. The subclass of submodular rank\ntests is derived from faces of the cone of submodular functions, or from\nMinkowski summands of the permutohedron. We enumerate all small instances of\nsuch rank tests. Of particular interest are graphical tests, which correspond\nto both graphical models and to graph associahedra.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Convex rank tests are partitions of the symmetric group which have desirable\ngeometric properties. The statistical tests defined by such partitions involve\ncounting all permutations in the equivalence classes. Each class consists of\nthe linear extensions of a partially ordered set specified by data. Our methods\nrefine existing rank tests of non-parametric statistics, such as the sign test\nand the runs test, and are useful for exploratory analysis of ordinal data. We\nestablish a bijection between convex rank tests and probabilistic conditional\nindependence structures known as semigraphoids. The subclass of submodular rank\ntests is derived from faces of the cone of submodular functions, or from\nMinkowski summands of the permutohedron. We enumerate all small instances of\nsuch rank tests. Of particular interest are graphical tests, which correspond\nto both graphical models and to graph associahedra."}, "authors": [{"name": "Jason Morton"}, {"name": "Lior Pachter"}, {"name": "Anne Shiu"}, {"name": "Bernd Sturmfels"}, {"name": "Oliver Wienand"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Oliver Wienand"}, "author": "Oliver Wienand", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0702564v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0702564v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.ST", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "stat.TH", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.03828v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.03828v1", "updated": "2015-02-12T21:03:16Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 2, 12, 21, 3, 16, 3, 43, 0], "published": "2015-02-12T21:03:16Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 2, 12, 21, 3, 16, 3, 43, 0], "title": "Hierarchical multiscale modeling for flows in fractured media using\n  Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Hierarchical multiscale modeling for flows in fractured media using\n  Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method"}, "summary": "In this paper, we develop a multiscale finite element method for solving\nflows in fractured media. Our approach is based on Generalized Multiscale\nFinite Element Method (GMsFEM), where we represent the fracture effects on a\ncoarse grid via multiscale basis functions. These multiscale basis functions\nare constructed in the offline stage via local spectral problems following\nGMsFEM. To represent the fractures on the fine grid, we consider two approaches\n(1) Discrete Fracture Model (DFM) (2) Embedded Fracture Model (EFM) and their\ncombination. In DFM, the fractures are resolved via the fine grid, while in EFM\nthe fracture and the fine grid block interaction is represented as a source\nterm. In the proposed multiscale method, additional multiscale basis functions\nare used to represent the long fractures, while short-size fractures are\ncollectively represented by a single basis functions. The procedure is\nautomatically done via local spectral problems. In this regard, our approach\nshares common concepts with several approaches proposed in the literature as we\ndiscuss. Numerical results are presented where we demonstrate how one can\nadaptively add basis functions in the regions of interest based on error\nindicators. We also discuss the use of randomized snapshots\n(\\cite{randomized2014}) which reduces the offline computational cost.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we develop a multiscale finite element method for solving\nflows in fractured media. Our approach is based on Generalized Multiscale\nFinite Element Method (GMsFEM), where we represent the fracture effects on a\ncoarse grid via multiscale basis functions. These multiscale basis functions\nare constructed in the offline stage via local spectral problems following\nGMsFEM. To represent the fractures on the fine grid, we consider two approaches\n(1) Discrete Fracture Model (DFM) (2) Embedded Fracture Model (EFM) and their\ncombination. In DFM, the fractures are resolved via the fine grid, while in EFM\nthe fracture and the fine grid block interaction is represented as a source\nterm. In the proposed multiscale method, additional multiscale basis functions\nare used to represent the long fractures, while short-size fractures are\ncollectively represented by a single basis functions. The procedure is\nautomatically done via local spectral problems. In this regard, our approach\nshares common concepts with several approaches proposed in the literature as we\ndiscuss. Numerical results are presented where we demonstrate how one can\nadaptively add basis functions in the regions of interest based on error\nindicators. We also discuss the use of randomized snapshots\n(\\cite{randomized2014}) which reduces the offline computational cost."}, "authors": [{"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Seong Lee"}, {"name": "Guanglian Li"}, {"name": "Jun Yao"}, {"name": "Na Zhang"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Na Zhang"}, "author": "Na Zhang", "arxiv_comment": "17 pp", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.03828v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1502.03828v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.10955v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.10955v1", "updated": "2018-07-28T15:56:53Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 7, 28, 15, 56, 53, 5, 209, 0], "published": "2018-07-28T15:56:53Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 7, 28, 15, 56, 53, 5, 209, 0], "title": "Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\n  Method for dual continuum model", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\n  Method for dual continuum model"}, "summary": "The dual continuum model serves as a powerful tool in the modeling of\nsubsurface applications. It allows a systematic coupling of various components\nof the solutions. The system is of multiscale nature as it involves high\nheterogeneous and high contrast coefficients. To numerically compute the\nsolutions, some types of reduced order methods are necessary. We will develop\nand analyze a novel multiscale method based on the recent advances in\nmultiscale finite element methods. Our method will compute multiple local\nmultiscale basis functions per coarse region. The idea is based on some local\nspectral problems, which are important to identify high contrast channels, and\nan energy minimization principle. Using these concepts, we show that the basis\nfunctions are localized, even in the presence of high contrast long channels\nand fractures. In addition, we show that the convergence of the method depends\nonly on the coarse mesh size. Finally, we present several numerical tests to\nshow the performance.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The dual continuum model serves as a powerful tool in the modeling of\nsubsurface applications. It allows a systematic coupling of various components\nof the solutions. The system is of multiscale nature as it involves high\nheterogeneous and high contrast coefficients. To numerically compute the\nsolutions, some types of reduced order methods are necessary. We will develop\nand analyze a novel multiscale method based on the recent advances in\nmultiscale finite element methods. Our method will compute multiple local\nmultiscale basis functions per coarse region. The idea is based on some local\nspectral problems, which are important to identify high contrast channels, and\nan energy minimization principle. Using these concepts, we show that the basis\nfunctions are localized, even in the presence of high contrast long channels\nand fractures. In addition, we show that the convergence of the method depends\nonly on the coarse mesh size. Finally, we present several numerical tests to\nshow the performance."}, "authors": [{"name": "Siu Wun Cheung"}, {"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, {"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}, "author": "Maria Vasilyeva", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.10955v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1807.10955v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1402.5068v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1402.5068v1", "updated": "2014-02-20T16:47:14Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 2, 20, 16, 47, 14, 3, 51, 0], "published": "2014-02-20T16:47:14Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 2, 20, 16, 47, 14, 3, 51, 0], "title": "Multilevel Markov Chain Monte Carlo Method for High-Contrast\n  Single-Phase Flow Problems", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Multilevel Markov Chain Monte Carlo Method for High-Contrast\n  Single-Phase Flow Problems"}, "summary": "In this paper we propose a general framework for the uncertainty\nquantification of quantities of interest for high-contrast single-phase flow\nproblems. It is based on the generalized multiscale finite element method\n(GMsFEM) and multilevel Monte Carlo (MLMC) methods. The former provides a\nhierarchy of approximations of different resolution, whereas the latter gives\nan efficient way to estimate quantities of interest using samples on different\nlevels. The number of basis functions in the online GMsFEM stage can be varied\nto determine the solution resolution and the computational cost, and to\nefficiently generate samples at different levels. In particular, it is cheap to\ngenerate samples on coarse grids but with low resolution, and it is expensive\nto generate samples on fine grids with high accuracy. By suitably choosing the\nnumber of samples at different levels, one can leverage the expensive\ncomputation in larger fine-grid spaces toward smaller coarse-grid spaces, while\nretaining the accuracy of the final Monte Carlo estimate. Further, we describe\na multilevel Markov chain Monte Carlo method, which sequentially screens the\nproposal with different levels of approximations and reduces the number of\nevaluations required on fine grids, while combining the samples at different\nlevels to arrive at an accurate estimate. The framework seamlessly integrates\nthe multiscale features of the GMsFEM with the multilevel feature of the MLMC\nmethods following the work in \\cite{ketelson2013}, and our numerical\nexperiments illustrate its efficiency and accuracy in comparison with standard\nMonte Carlo estimates.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper we propose a general framework for the uncertainty\nquantification of quantities of interest for high-contrast single-phase flow\nproblems. It is based on the generalized multiscale finite element method\n(GMsFEM) and multilevel Monte Carlo (MLMC) methods. The former provides a\nhierarchy of approximations of different resolution, whereas the latter gives\nan efficient way to estimate quantities of interest using samples on different\nlevels. The number of basis functions in the online GMsFEM stage can be varied\nto determine the solution resolution and the computational cost, and to\nefficiently generate samples at different levels. In particular, it is cheap to\ngenerate samples on coarse grids but with low resolution, and it is expensive\nto generate samples on fine grids with high accuracy. By suitably choosing the\nnumber of samples at different levels, one can leverage the expensive\ncomputation in larger fine-grid spaces toward smaller coarse-grid spaces, while\nretaining the accuracy of the final Monte Carlo estimate. Further, we describe\na multilevel Markov chain Monte Carlo method, which sequentially screens the\nproposal with different levels of approximations and reduces the number of\nevaluations required on fine grids, while combining the samples at different\nlevels to arrive at an accurate estimate. The framework seamlessly integrates\nthe multiscale features of the GMsFEM with the multilevel feature of the MLMC\nmethods following the work in \\cite{ketelson2013}, and our numerical\nexperiments illustrate its efficiency and accuracy in comparison with standard\nMonte Carlo estimates."}, "authors": [{"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "Michael Presho"}, {"name": "Xiaosi Tan"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Xiaosi Tan"}, "author": "Xiaosi Tan", "arxiv_doi": "10.4208/cicp.021013.260614a", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.4208/cicp.021013.260614a", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1402.5068v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1402.5068v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "29 pages, 6 figures", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.01990v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.01990v1", "updated": "2017-11-06T16:22:41Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 11, 6, 16, 22, 41, 0, 310, 0], "published": "2017-11-06T16:22:41Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 11, 6, 16, 22, 41, 0, 310, 0], "title": "Cluster-based Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method for elliptic\n  PDEs with random coefficients", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Cluster-based Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method for elliptic\n  PDEs with random coefficients"}, "summary": "We propose a generalized multiscale finite element method (GMsFEM) based on\nclustering algorithm to study the elliptic PDEs with random coefficients in the\nmulti-query setting. Our method consists of offline and online stages. In the\noffline stage, we construct a small number of reduced basis functions within\neach coarse grid block, which can then be used to approximate the multiscale\nfinite element basis functions. In addition, we coarsen the corresponding\nrandom space through a clustering algorithm. In the online stage, we can obtain\nthe multiscale finite element basis very efficiently on a coarse grid by using\nthe pre-computed multiscale basis. The new GMsFEM can be applied to multiscale\nSPDE starting with a relatively coarse grid, without requiring the coarsest\ngrid to resolve the smallest-scale of the solution. The new method offers\nconsiderable savings in solving multiscale SPDEs. Numerical results are\npresented to demonstrate the accuracy and efficiency of the proposed method for\nseveral multiscale stochastic problems without scale separation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We propose a generalized multiscale finite element method (GMsFEM) based on\nclustering algorithm to study the elliptic PDEs with random coefficients in the\nmulti-query setting. Our method consists of offline and online stages. In the\noffline stage, we construct a small number of reduced basis functions within\neach coarse grid block, which can then be used to approximate the multiscale\nfinite element basis functions. In addition, we coarsen the corresponding\nrandom space through a clustering algorithm. In the online stage, we can obtain\nthe multiscale finite element basis very efficiently on a coarse grid by using\nthe pre-computed multiscale basis. The new GMsFEM can be applied to multiscale\nSPDE starting with a relatively coarse grid, without requiring the coarsest\ngrid to resolve the smallest-scale of the solution. The new method offers\nconsiderable savings in solving multiscale SPDEs. Numerical results are\npresented to demonstrate the accuracy and efficiency of the proposed method for\nseveral multiscale stochastic problems without scale separation."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, {"name": "Zhiwen Zhang"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhiwen Zhang"}, "author": "Zhiwen Zhang", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2018.05.041", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2018.05.041", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.01990v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1711.01990v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.08379v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.08379v1", "updated": "2017-08-28T15:38:08Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 8, 28, 15, 38, 8, 0, 240, 0], "published": "2017-08-28T15:38:08Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 8, 28, 15, 38, 8, 0, 240, 0], "title": "Non-local Multi-continua Upscaling for Flows in Heterogeneous Fractured\n  Media", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Non-local Multi-continua Upscaling for Flows in Heterogeneous Fractured\n  Media"}, "summary": "In this paper, we propose a rigorous and accurate non-local (in the\noversampled region) upscaling framework based on some recently developed\nmultiscale methods [10]. Our proposed method consists of identifying\nmulti-continua parameters via local basis functions and constructing non-local\n(in the oversampled region) transfer and effective properties. To achieve this,\nwe significantly modify our recent work proposed within Generalized Multiscale\nFinite Element Method (GMsFEM) in [10] and derive appropriate local problems in\noversampled regions once we identify important modes representing each\ncontinua. We use piecewise constant functions in each fracture network and in\nthe matrix to write an upscaled equation. Thus, the resulting upscaled equation\nis of minimal size and the unknowns are average pressures in the fractures and\nthe matrix. We note that the use of non-local upscaled model for porous media\nflows is not new, e.g., in [14], the authors derive non-local approach. Our\nmain contribution is identifying appropriate local problems together with local\nspectral modes to represent each continua. The model problem for fractures\nassumes that one can identify fracture networks. The resulting non-local\nequation (restricted to the oversampling region, which is several times larger\ncompared to the target coarse block) has the same form as \\cite{Hamdi_Nonlocal}\nwith much smaller local regions. We present numerical results, which show that\nthe proposed approach can provide good accuracy.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we propose a rigorous and accurate non-local (in the\noversampled region) upscaling framework based on some recently developed\nmultiscale methods [10]. Our proposed method consists of identifying\nmulti-continua parameters via local basis functions and constructing non-local\n(in the oversampled region) transfer and effective properties. To achieve this,\nwe significantly modify our recent work proposed within Generalized Multiscale\nFinite Element Method (GMsFEM) in [10] and derive appropriate local problems in\noversampled regions once we identify important modes representing each\ncontinua. We use piecewise constant functions in each fracture network and in\nthe matrix to write an upscaled equation. Thus, the resulting upscaled equation\nis of minimal size and the unknowns are average pressures in the fractures and\nthe matrix. We note that the use of non-local upscaled model for porous media\nflows is not new, e.g., in [14], the authors derive non-local approach. Our\nmain contribution is identifying appropriate local problems together with local\nspectral modes to represent each continua. The model problem for fractures\nassumes that one can identify fracture networks. The resulting non-local\nequation (restricted to the oversampling region, which is several times larger\ncompared to the target coarse block) has the same form as \\cite{Hamdi_Nonlocal}\nwith much smaller local regions. We present numerical results, which show that\nthe proposed approach can provide good accuracy."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, {"name": "Yating Wang"}, {"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}, "author": "Maria Vasilyeva", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2018.05.038", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2018.05.038", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.08379v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1708.08379v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1605.07634v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1605.07634v1", "updated": "2016-05-24T20:01:07Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 5, 24, 20, 1, 7, 1, 145, 0], "published": "2016-05-24T20:01:07Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 5, 24, 20, 1, 7, 1, 145, 0], "title": "Generalized multiscale finite element methods for space-time\n  heterogeneous parabolic equations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Generalized multiscale finite element methods for space-time\n  heterogeneous parabolic equations"}, "summary": "In this paper, we consider local multiscale model reduction for problems with\nmultiple scales in space and time. We developed our approaches within the\nframework of the Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM) using\nspace-time coarse cells. The main idea of GMsFEM is to construct a local\nsnapshot space and a local spectral decomposition in the snapshot space.\nPrevious research in developing multiscale spaces within GMsFEM focused on\nconstructing multiscale spaces and relevant ingredients in space only. In this\npaper, our main objective is to develop a multiscale model reduction framework\nwithin GMsFEM that uses space-time coarse cells. We construct space-time\nsnapshot and offline spaces. We compute these snapshot solutions by solving\nlocal problems. A complete snapshot space will use all possible boundary\nconditions; however, this can be very expensive. We propose using randomized\nboundary conditions and oversampling. We construct the local spectral\ndecomposition based on our analysis, as presented in the paper. We present\nnumerical results to confirm our theoretical findings and to show that using\nour proposed approaches, we can obtain an accurate solution with low\ndimensional coarse spaces. We remark that the proposed method is a significant\nextension compared to existing methods, which use coarse cells in space only\nbecause of (1) the parabolic nature of cell solutions, (2) extra degrees of\nfreedom associated with space-time cells, and (3) local boundary conditions in\nspace-time cells.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we consider local multiscale model reduction for problems with\nmultiple scales in space and time. We developed our approaches within the\nframework of the Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM) using\nspace-time coarse cells. The main idea of GMsFEM is to construct a local\nsnapshot space and a local spectral decomposition in the snapshot space.\nPrevious research in developing multiscale spaces within GMsFEM focused on\nconstructing multiscale spaces and relevant ingredients in space only. In this\npaper, our main objective is to develop a multiscale model reduction framework\nwithin GMsFEM that uses space-time coarse cells. We construct space-time\nsnapshot and offline spaces. We compute these snapshot solutions by solving\nlocal problems. A complete snapshot space will use all possible boundary\nconditions; however, this can be very expensive. We propose using randomized\nboundary conditions and oversampling. We construct the local spectral\ndecomposition based on our analysis, as presented in the paper. We present\nnumerical results to confirm our theoretical findings and to show that using\nour proposed approaches, we can obtain an accurate solution with low\ndimensional coarse spaces. We remark that the proposed method is a significant\nextension compared to existing methods, which use coarse cells in space only\nbecause of (1) the parabolic nature of cell solutions, (2) extra degrees of\nfreedom associated with space-time cells, and (3) local boundary conditions in\nspace-time cells."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, {"name": "Shuai Ye"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Shuai Ye"}, "author": "Shuai Ye", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1605.07634v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1605.07634v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.01659v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.01659v1", "updated": "2015-07-07T02:33:17Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 7, 7, 2, 33, 17, 1, 188, 0], "published": "2015-07-07T02:33:17Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 7, 7, 2, 33, 17, 1, 188, 0], "title": "Adaptive mixed GMsFEM for flows in heterogeneous media", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Adaptive mixed GMsFEM for flows in heterogeneous media"}, "summary": "In this paper, we present two adaptive methods for the basis enrichment of\nthe mixed Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM) for solving the\nflow problem in heterogeneous media. We develop an a-posteriori error indicator\nwhich depends on the norm of a local residual operator. Based on this\nindicator, we construct an offline adaptive method to increase the number of\nbasis functions locally in coarse regions with large local residuals. We also\ndevelop an online adaptive method which iteratively enriches the function space\nby adding new functions computed based on the residual of the previous solution\nand special minimum energy snapshots. We show theoretically and numerically the\nconvergence of the two methods. The online method is, in general, better than\nthe offline method as the online method is able to capture distant effects (at\na cost of online computations), and both methods have faster convergence than a\nuniform enrichment. Analysis shows that the online method should start with\ncertain number of initial basis functions in order to have the best\nperformance. The numerical results confirm this and show further that with\ncorrect selection of initial basis functions, the convergence of the online\nmethod can be independent of the contrast of the medium. We consider cases with\nboth very high and very low conducting inclusions and channels in our numerical\nexperiments.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we present two adaptive methods for the basis enrichment of\nthe mixed Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM) for solving the\nflow problem in heterogeneous media. We develop an a-posteriori error indicator\nwhich depends on the norm of a local residual operator. Based on this\nindicator, we construct an offline adaptive method to increase the number of\nbasis functions locally in coarse regions with large local residuals. We also\ndevelop an online adaptive method which iteratively enriches the function space\nby adding new functions computed based on the residual of the previous solution\nand special minimum energy snapshots. We show theoretically and numerically the\nconvergence of the two methods. The online method is, in general, better than\nthe offline method as the online method is able to capture distant effects (at\na cost of online computations), and both methods have faster convergence than a\nuniform enrichment. Analysis shows that the online method should start with\ncertain number of initial basis functions in order to have the best\nperformance. The numerical results confirm this and show further that with\ncorrect selection of initial basis functions, the convergence of the online\nmethod can be independent of the contrast of the medium. We consider cases with\nboth very high and very low conducting inclusions and channels in our numerical\nexperiments."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ho Yuen Chan"}, {"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, "author": "Yalchin Efendiev", "arxiv_comment": "23 pages, 12 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.01659v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1507.01659v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1704.03193v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1704.03193v1", "updated": "2017-04-11T08:30:29Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 4, 11, 8, 30, 29, 1, 101, 0], "published": "2017-04-11T08:30:29Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 4, 11, 8, 30, 29, 1, 101, 0], "title": "Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\n  Method", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\n  Method"}, "summary": "The main goal of this paper is to design multiscale basis functions within\nGMsFEM framework such that the convergence of method is independent of the\ncontrast and linearly decreases with respect to mesh size if oversampling size\nis appropriately chosen. We would like to show a mesh-dependent convergence\nwith a minimal number of basis functions. Our construction starts with an\nauxiliary multiscale space by solving local spectral problems. In auxiliary\nmultiscale space, we select the basis functions that correspond to small\n(contrast-dependent) eigenvalues. These basis functions represent the channels\n(high-contrast features that connect the boundaries of the coarse block). Using\nthe auxiliary space, we propose a constraint energy minimization to construct\nmultiscale spaces. The minimization is performed in the oversampling domain,\nwhich is larger than the target coarse block. The constraints allow handling\nnon-decaying components of the local minimizers. If the auxiliary space is\ncorrectly chosen, we show that the convergence rate is independent of the\ncontrast (because the basis representing the channels are included in the\nauxiliary space) and is proportional to the coarse-mesh size (because the\nconstrains handle non-decaying components of the local minimizers). The\noversampling size weakly depends on the contrast as our analysis shows. The\nconvergence theorem requires that channels are not aligned with the coarse\nedges, which hold in many applications, where the channels are oblique with\nrespect to the coarse-mesh geometry. The numerical results confirm our\ntheoretical results. In particular, we show that if the oversampling domain\nsize is not sufficiently large, the errors are large. To remove the\ncontrast-dependence of the oversampling size, we propose a modified\nconstruction for basis functions and present numerical results and the\nanalysis.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The main goal of this paper is to design multiscale basis functions within\nGMsFEM framework such that the convergence of method is independent of the\ncontrast and linearly decreases with respect to mesh size if oversampling size\nis appropriately chosen. We would like to show a mesh-dependent convergence\nwith a minimal number of basis functions. Our construction starts with an\nauxiliary multiscale space by solving local spectral problems.
