In auxiliary\nmultiscale space, we select the basis functions that correspond to small\n(contrast-dependent) eigenvalues. These basis functions represent the channels\n(high-contrast features that connect the boundaries of the coarse block). Using\nthe auxiliary space, we propose a constraint energy minimization to construct\nmultiscale spaces. The minimization is performed in the oversampling domain,\nwhich is larger than the target coarse block. The constraints allow handling\nnon-decaying components of the local minimizers. If the auxiliary space is\ncorrectly chosen, we show that the convergence rate is independent of the\ncontrast (because the basis representing the channels are included in the\nauxiliary space) and is proportional to the coarse-mesh size (because the\nconstrains handle non-decaying components of the local minimizers). The\noversampling size weakly depends on the contrast as our analysis shows. The\nconvergence theorem requires that channels are not aligned with the coarse\nedges, which hold in many applications, where the channels are oblique with\nrespect to the coarse-mesh geometry. The numerical results confirm our\ntheoretical results. In particular, we show that if the oversampling domain\nsize is not sufficiently large, the errors are large. To remove the\ncontrast-dependence of the oversampling size, we propose a modified\nconstruction for basis functions and present numerical results and the\nanalysis."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, "author": "Wing Tat Leung", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.cma.2018.04.010", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cma.2018.04.010", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1704.03193v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1704.03193v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.05959v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.05959v1", "updated": "2017-05-16T23:55:58Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 5, 16, 23, 55, 58, 1, 136, 0], "published": "2017-05-16T23:55:58Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 5, 16, 23, 55, 58, 1, 136, 0], "title": "Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\n  Method in the Mixed Formulation", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\n  Method in the Mixed Formulation"}, "summary": "This paper presents a novel mass-conservative mixed multiscale method for\nsolving flow equations in heterogeneous porous media. The media properties (the\npermeability) contain multiple scales and high contrast. The proposed method\nsolves the flow equation in a mixed formulation on a coarse grid by\nconstructing multiscale basis functions. The resulting velocity field is mass\nconservative on the fine grid. Our main goal is to obtain first-order\nconvergence in terms of the mesh size which is independent of local contrast.\nThis is achieved, first, by constructing some auxiliary spaces, which contain\nglobal information that can not be localized, in general. This is built on our\nprevious work on the Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM). In\nthe auxiliary space, multiscale basis functions corresponding to small\n(contrast-dependent) eigenvalues are selected. These basis functions represent\nthe high-conductivity channels (which connect the boundaries of a coarse\nblock). Next, we solve local problems to construct multiscale basis functions\nfor the velocity field. These local problems are formulated in the oversampled\ndomain taking into account some constraints with respect to auxiliary spaces.\nThe latter allows fast spatial decay of local solutions and, thus, allows\ntaking smaller oversampled regions. The number of basis functions depends on\nsmall eigenvalues of the local spectral problems. Moreover, multiscale pressure\nbasis functions are needed in constructing the velocity space. Our multiscale\nspaces have a minimal dimension, which is needed to avoid contrast-dependence\nin the convergence. The method's convergence requires an oversampling of\nseveral layers. We present an analysis of our approach. Our numerical results\nconfirm that the convergence rate is first order with respect to the mesh size\nand independent of the contrast.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper presents a novel mass-conservative mixed multiscale method for\nsolving flow equations in heterogeneous porous media. The media properties (the\npermeability) contain multiple scales and high contrast. The proposed method\nsolves the flow equation in a mixed formulation on a coarse grid by\nconstructing multiscale basis functions. The resulting velocity field is mass\nconservative on the fine grid. Our main goal is to obtain first-order\nconvergence in terms of the mesh size which is independent of local contrast.\nThis is achieved, first, by constructing some auxiliary spaces, which contain\nglobal information that can not be localized, in general. This is built on our\nprevious work on the Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM). In\nthe auxiliary space, multiscale basis functions corresponding to small\n(contrast-dependent) eigenvalues are selected. These basis functions represent\nthe high-conductivity channels (which connect the boundaries of a coarse\nblock). Next, we solve local problems to construct multiscale basis functions\nfor the velocity field. These local problems are formulated in the oversampled\ndomain taking into account some constraints with respect to auxiliary spaces.\nThe latter allows fast spatial decay of local solutions and, thus, allows\ntaking smaller oversampled regions. The number of basis functions depends on\nsmall eigenvalues of the local spectral problems. Moreover, multiscale pressure\nbasis functions are needed in constructing the velocity space. Our multiscale\nspaces have a minimal dimension, which is needed to avoid contrast-dependence\nin the convergence. The method's convergence requires an oversampling of\nseveral layers. We present an analysis of our approach. Our numerical results\nconfirm that the convergence rate is first order with respect to the mesh size\nand independent of the contrast."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, "author": "Wing Tat Leung", "arxiv_doi": "10.1007/s10596-018-9719-7", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10596-018-9719-7", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.05959v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1705.05959v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1706.07093v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1706.07093v1", "updated": "2017-06-21T19:27:41Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 6, 21, 19, 27, 41, 2, 172, 0], "published": "2017-06-21T19:27:41Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 6, 21, 19, 27, 41, 2, 172, 0], "title": "Fast Online Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method using\n  Constraint Energy Minimization", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Fast Online Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method using\n  Constraint Energy Minimization"}, "summary": "Local multiscale methods often construct multiscale basis functions in the\noffline stage without taking into account input parameters, such as source\nterms, boundary conditions, and so on. These basis functions are then used in\nthe online stage with a specific input parameter to solve the global problem at\na reduced computational cost. Recently, online approaches have been introduced,\nwhere multiscale basis functions are adaptively constructed in some regions to\nreduce the error significantly. In multiscale methods, it is desired to have\nonly 1-2 iterations to reduce the error to a desired threshold. Using\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite Element Framework, it was shown that by choosing\nsufficient number of offline basis functions, the error reduction can be made\nindependent of physical parameters, such as scales and contrast. In this paper,\nour goal is to improve this. Using our recently proposed approach and special\nonline basis construction in oversampled regions, we show that the error\nreduction can be made sufficiently large by appropriately selecting\noversampling regions. Our numerical results show that one can achieve a three\norder of magnitude error reduction, which is better than our previous methods.\nWe also develop an adaptive algorithm and enrich in selected regions with large\nresiduals. In our adaptive method, we show that the convergence rate can be\ndetermined by a user-defined parameter and we confirm this by numerical\nsimulations. The analysis of the method is presented.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Local multiscale methods often construct multiscale basis functions in the\noffline stage without taking into account input parameters, such as source\nterms, boundary conditions, and so on. These basis functions are then used in\nthe online stage with a specific input parameter to solve the global problem at\na reduced computational cost. Recently, online approaches have been introduced,\nwhere multiscale basis functions are adaptively constructed in some regions to\nreduce the error significantly. In multiscale methods, it is desired to have\nonly 1-2 iterations to reduce the error to a desired threshold. Using\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite Element Framework, it was shown that by choosing\nsufficient number of offline basis functions, the error reduction can be made\nindependent of physical parameters, such as scales and contrast. In this paper,\nour goal is to improve this. Using our recently proposed approach and special\nonline basis construction in oversampled regions, we show that the error\nreduction can be made sufficiently large by appropriately selecting\noversampling regions. Our numerical results show that one can achieve a three\norder of magnitude error reduction, which is better than our previous methods.\nWe also develop an adaptive algorithm and enrich in selected regions with large\nresiduals. In our adaptive method, we show that the convergence rate can be\ndetermined by a user-defined parameter and we confirm this by numerical\nsimulations. The analysis of the method is presented."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, "author": "Wing Tat Leung", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2017.11.022", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2017.11.022", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1706.07093v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1706.07093v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.10955v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.10955v1", "updated": "2018-07-28T15:56:53Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 7, 28, 15, 56, 53, 5, 209, 0], "published": "2018-07-28T15:56:53Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 7, 28, 15, 56, 53, 5, 209, 0], "title": "Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\n  Method for dual continuum model", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\n  Method for dual continuum model"}, "summary": "The dual continuum model serves as a powerful tool in the modeling of\nsubsurface applications. It allows a systematic coupling of various components\nof the solutions. The system is of multiscale nature as it involves high\nheterogeneous and high contrast coefficients. To numerically compute the\nsolutions, some types of reduced order methods are necessary. We will develop\nand analyze a novel multiscale method based on the recent advances in\nmultiscale finite element methods. Our method will compute multiple local\nmultiscale basis functions per coarse region. The idea is based on some local\nspectral problems, which are important to identify high contrast channels, and\nan energy minimization principle. Using these concepts, we show that the basis\nfunctions are localized, even in the presence of high contrast long channels\nand fractures. In addition, we show that the convergence of the method depends\nonly on the coarse mesh size. Finally, we present several numerical tests to\nshow the performance.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The dual continuum model serves as a powerful tool in the modeling of\nsubsurface applications. It allows a systematic coupling of various components\nof the solutions. The system is of multiscale nature as it involves high\nheterogeneous and high contrast coefficients. To numerically compute the\nsolutions, some types of reduced order methods are necessary. We will develop\nand analyze a novel multiscale method based on the recent advances in\nmultiscale finite element methods. Our method will compute multiple local\nmultiscale basis functions per coarse region. The idea is based on some local\nspectral problems, which are important to identify high contrast channels, and\nan energy minimization principle. Using these concepts, we show that the basis\nfunctions are localized, even in the presence of high contrast long channels\nand fractures. In addition, we show that the convergence of the method depends\nonly on the coarse mesh size. Finally, we present several numerical tests to\nshow the performance."}, "authors": [{"name": "Siu Wun Cheung"}, {"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, {"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}, "author": "Maria Vasilyeva", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.10955v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1807.10955v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2012.01817v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2012.01817v1", "updated": "2020-12-03T10:44:22Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 12, 3, 10, 44, 22, 3, 338, 0], "published": "2020-12-03T10:44:22Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 12, 3, 10, 44, 22, 3, 338, 0], "title": "Iterative Oversampling Technique for Constraint Energy Minimizing\n  Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method in the Mixed Formulation", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Iterative Oversampling Technique for Constraint Energy Minimizing\n  Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method in the Mixed Formulation"}, "summary": "In this paper, we develop an iterative scheme to construct multiscale basis\nfunctions within the framework of the Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized\nMultiscale Finite Element Method (CEM-GMsFEM) for the mixed formulation. The\niterative procedure starts with the construction of an energy minimizing\nsnapshot space that can be used for approximating the solution of the model\nproblem. A spectral decomposition is then performed on the snapshot space to\nform global multiscale space. Under this setting, each global multiscale basis\nfunction can be split into a non-decaying and a decaying parts. The\nnon-decaying part of a global basis is localized and it is fixed during the\niteration. Then, one can approximate the decaying part via a modified\nRichardson scheme with an appropriately defined preconditioner. Using this set\nof iterative-based multiscale basis functions, first-order convergence with\nrespect to the coarse mesh size can be shown if sufficiently many times of\niterations with regularization parameter being in an appropriate range are\nperformed. Numerical results are presented to illustrate the effectiveness and\nefficiency of the proposed computational multiscale method.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we develop an iterative scheme to construct multiscale basis\nfunctions within the framework of the Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized\nMultiscale Finite Element Method (CEM-GMsFEM) for the mixed formulation. The\niterative procedure starts with the construction of an energy minimizing\nsnapshot space that can be used for approximating the solution of the model\nproblem. A spectral decomposition is then performed on the snapshot space to\nform global multiscale space. Under this setting, each global multiscale basis\nfunction can be split into a non-decaying and a decaying parts. The\nnon-decaying part of a global basis is localized and it is fixed during the\niteration. Then, one can approximate the decaying part via a modified\nRichardson scheme with an appropriately defined preconditioner. Using this set\nof iterative-based multiscale basis functions, first-order convergence with\nrespect to the coarse mesh size can be shown if sufficiently many times of\niterations with regularization parameter being in an appropriate range are\nperformed. Numerical results are presented to illustrate the effectiveness and\nefficiency of the proposed computational multiscale method."}, "authors": [{"name": "Siu Wun Cheung"}, {"name": "Eric Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, {"name": "Sai-Mang Pun"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Sai-Mang Pun"}, "author": "Sai-Mang Pun", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2012.01817v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2012.01817v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.00113v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.00113v1", "updated": "2015-07-01T05:51:56Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 7, 1, 5, 51, 56, 2, 182, 0], "published": "2015-07-01T05:51:56Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 7, 1, 5, 51, 56, 2, 182, 0], "title": "Multiscale model reduction for shale gas transport in fractured media", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Multiscale model reduction for shale gas transport in fractured media"}, "summary": "In this paper, we develop a multiscale model reduction technique that\ndescribes shale gas transport in fractured media. Due to the pore-scale\nheterogeneities and processes, we use upscaled models to describe the matrix.\nWe follow our previous work \\cite{aes14}, where we derived an upscaled model in\nthe form of generalized nonlinear diffusion model to describe the effects of\nkerogen. To model the interaction between the matrix and the fractures, we use\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite Element Method. In this approach, the matrix and\nthe fracture interaction is modeled via local multiscale basis functions. We\ndeveloped the GMsFEM and applied for linear flows with horizontal or vertical\nfracture orientations on a Cartesian fine grid. In this paper, we consider\narbitrary fracture orientations and use triangular fine grid and developed\nGMsFEM for nonlinear flows. Moreover, we develop online basis function\nstrategies to adaptively improve the convergence. The number of multiscale\nbasis functions in each coarse region represents the degrees of freedom needed\nto achieve a certain error threshold. Our approach is adaptive in a sense that\nthe multiscale basis functions can be added in the regions of interest.\nNumerical results for two-dimensional problem are presented to demonstrate the\nefficiency of proposed approach.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we develop a multiscale model reduction technique that\ndescribes shale gas transport in fractured media. Due to the pore-scale\nheterogeneities and processes, we use upscaled models to describe the matrix.\nWe follow our previous work \\cite{aes14}, where we derived an upscaled model in\nthe form of generalized nonlinear diffusion model to describe the effects of\nkerogen. To model the interaction between the matrix and the fractures, we use\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite Element Method. In this approach, the matrix and\nthe fracture interaction is modeled via local multiscale basis functions. We\ndeveloped the GMsFEM and applied for linear flows with horizontal or vertical\nfracture orientations on a Cartesian fine grid. In this paper, we consider\narbitrary fracture orientations and use triangular fine grid and developed\nGMsFEM for nonlinear flows. Moreover, we develop online basis function\nstrategies to adaptively improve the convergence. The number of multiscale\nbasis functions in each coarse region represents the degrees of freedom needed\nto achieve a certain error threshold. Our approach is adaptive in a sense that\nthe multiscale basis functions can be added in the regions of interest.\nNumerical results for two-dimensional problem are presented to demonstrate the\nefficiency of proposed approach."}, "authors": [{"name": "I. Y. Akkutlu"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}, "author": "Maria Vasilyeva", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.00113v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1507.00113v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "cs.CE", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "cs.CE", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "physics.comp-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1810.12245v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1810.12245v1", "updated": "2018-10-29T16:45:39Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 10, 29, 16, 45, 39, 0, 302, 0], "published": "2018-10-29T16:45:39Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 10, 29, 16, 45, 39, 0, 302, 0], "title": "Prediction of Discretization of GMsFEM using Deep Learning", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Prediction of Discretization of GMsFEM using Deep Learning"}, "summary": "In this paper, we propose a deep-learning-based approach to a class of\nmultiscale problems. THe Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM)\nhas been proven successful as a model reduction technique of flow problems in\nheterogeneous and high-contrast porous media. The key ingredients of GMsFEM\ninclude mutlsicale basis functions and coarse-scale parameters, which are\nobtained from solving local problems in each coarse neighborhood. Given a fixed\nmedium, these quantities are precomputed by solving local problems in an\noffline stage, and result in a reduced-order model. However, these quantities\nhave to be re-computed in case of varying media. The objective of our work is\nto make use of deep learning techniques to mimic the nonlinear relation between\nthe permeability field and the GMsFEM discretizations, and use neural networks\nto perform fast computation of GMsFEM ingredients repeatedly for a class of\nmedia. We provide numerical experiments to investigate the predictive power of\nneural networks and the usefulness of the resultant multiscale model in solving\nchannelized porous media flow problems.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we propose a deep-learning-based approach to a class of\nmultiscale problems. THe Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM)\nhas been proven successful as a model reduction technique of flow problems in\nheterogeneous and high-contrast porous media. The key ingredients of GMsFEM\ninclude mutlsicale basis functions and coarse-scale parameters, which are\nobtained from solving local problems in each coarse neighborhood. Given a fixed\nmedium, these quantities are precomputed by solving local problems in an\noffline stage, and result in a reduced-order model. However, these quantities\nhave to be re-computed in case of varying media. The objective of our work is\nto make use of deep learning techniques to mimic the nonlinear relation between\nthe permeability field and the GMsFEM discretizations, and use neural networks\nto perform fast computation of GMsFEM ingredients repeatedly for a class of\nmedia. We provide numerical experiments to investigate the predictive power of\nneural networks and the usefulness of the resultant multiscale model in solving\nchannelized porous media flow problems."}, "authors": [{"name": "Min Wang"}, {"name": "Siu Wun Cheung"}, {"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, {"name": "Yating Wang"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Yating Wang"}, "author": "Yating Wang", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1810.12245v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.12245v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1402.6374v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1402.6374v2", "updated": "2014-04-07T18:49:33Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 4, 7, 18, 49, 33, 0, 97, 0], "published": "2014-02-25T23:37:18Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 2, 25, 23, 37, 18, 1, 56, 0], "title": "Homogenization of the evolution Stokes equation in a perforated domain\n  with a stochastic Fourier boundary condition", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Homogenization of the evolution Stokes equation in a perforated domain\n  with a stochastic Fourier boundary condition"}, "summary": "The evolution Stokes equation in a perforated domain subject to Fourier\nboundary condition on the boundaries of the holes is considered. We assume that\nthe dynamic is driven by a stochastic perturbation on the interior of the\ndomain and another stochastic perturbation on the boundaries of the holes. The\nmacroscopic (homogenized) equation is derived as another stochastic partial\ndifferential equation, defined in the whole non perforated domain. Here, the\ninitial stochastic perturbation on the boundary becomes part of the homogenized\nequation as another stochastic force. We use the two-scale convergence method\nafter extending the solution with 0 in the wholes to pass to the limit. By\nIt\\^o stochastic calculus, we get uniform estimates on the solution in\nappropriate spaces. In order to pass to the limit on the boundary integrals, we\nrewrite them in terms of integrals in the whole domain. In particular, for the\nstochastic integral on the boundary, we combine the previous idea of rewriting\nit on the whole domain with the assumption that the Brownian motion is of trace\nclass. Due to the particular boundary condition dealt with, we get that the\nsolution of the stochastic homogenized equation is not divergence free.\nHowever, it is coupled with the cell problem that has a divergence free\nsolution. This paper represents an extension of the results from of Duan and\nWang (Comm. Math. Phys. 275:1508--1527, 2007), where a reaction diffusion\nequation with a dynamical boundary condition with a noise source term on both\nthe interior of the domain and on the boundary was studied, and through a\ntightness argument and a pointwise two scale convergence method the homogenized\nequation was derived.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The evolution Stokes equation in a perforated domain subject to Fourier\nboundary condition on the boundaries of the holes is considered. We assume that\nthe dynamic is driven by a stochastic perturbation on the interior of the\ndomain and another stochastic perturbation on the boundaries of the holes. The\nmacroscopic (homogenized) equation is derived as another stochastic partial\ndifferential equation, defined in the whole non perforated domain. Here, the\ninitial stochastic perturbation on the boundary becomes part of the homogenized\nequation as another stochastic force. We use the two-scale convergence method\nafter extending the solution with 0 in the wholes to pass to the limit. By\nIt\\^o stochastic calculus, we get uniform estimates on the solution in\nappropriate spaces. In order to pass to the limit on the boundary integrals, we\nrewrite them in terms of integrals in the whole domain. In particular, for the\nstochastic integral on the boundary, we combine the previous idea of rewriting\nit on the whole domain with the assumption that the Brownian motion is of trace\nclass. Due to the particular boundary condition dealt with, we get that the\nsolution of the stochastic homogenized equation is not divergence free.\nHowever, it is coupled with the cell problem that has a divergence free\nsolution. This paper represents an extension of the results from of Duan and\nWang (Comm. Math. Phys. 275:1508--1527, 2007), where a reaction diffusion\nequation with a dynamical boundary condition with a noise source term on both\nthe interior of the domain and on the boundary was studied, and through a\ntightness argument and a pointwise two scale convergence method the homogenized\nequation was derived."}, "authors": [{"name": "Hakima Bessaih"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Florian Maris"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Florian Maris"}, "author": "Florian Maris", "arxiv_comment": "23 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1402.6374v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1402.6374v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "Primary 60H15, 76M50, 60H30, Secondary 76D07, 76M35", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.2866v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.2866v2", "updated": "2013-04-28T12:31:10Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 4, 28, 12, 31, 10, 6, 118, 0], "published": "2013-01-14T06:43:11Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 1, 14, 6, 43, 11, 0, 14, 0], "title": "Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Methods (GMsFEM)", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Methods (GMsFEM)"}, "summary": "In this paper, we propose a general approach called Generalized Multiscale\nFinite Element Method (GMsFEM) for performing multiscale simulations for\nproblems without scale separation over a complex input space. As in multiscale\nfinite element methods (MsFEMs), the main idea of the proposed approach is to\nconstruct a small dimensional local solution space that can be used to generate\nan efficient and accurate approximation to the multiscale solution with a\npotentially high dimensional input parameter space. In the proposed approach,\nwe present a general procedure to construct the offline space that is used for\na systematic enrichment of the coarse solution space in the online stage. The\nenrichment in the online stage is performed based on a spectral decomposition\nof the offline space. In the online stage, for any input parameter, a\nmultiscale space is constructed to solve the global problem on a coarse grid.\nThe online space is constructed via a spectral decomposition of the offline\nspace and by choosing the eigenvectors corresponding to the largest\neigenvalues. The computational saving is due to the fact that the construction\nof the online multiscale space for any input parameter is fast and this space\ncan be re-used for solving the forward problem with any forcing and boundary\ncondition. Compared with the other approaches where global snapshots are used,\nthe local approach that we present in this paper allows us to eliminate\nunnecessary degrees of freedom on a coarse-grid level. We present various\nexamples in the paper and some numerical results to demonstrate the\neffectiveness of our method.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we propose a general approach called Generalized Multiscale\nFinite Element Method (GMsFEM) for performing multiscale simulations for\nproblems without scale separation over a complex input space. As in multiscale\nfinite element methods (MsFEMs), the main idea of the proposed approach is to\nconstruct a small dimensional local solution space that can be used to generate\nan efficient and accurate approximation to the multiscale solution with a\npotentially high dimensional input parameter space. In the proposed approach,\nwe present a general procedure to construct the offline space that is used for\na systematic enrichment of the coarse solution space in the online stage. The\nenrichment in the online stage is performed based on a spectral decomposition\nof the offline space. In the online stage, for any input parameter, a\nmultiscale space is constructed to solve the global problem on a coarse grid.\nThe online space is constructed via a spectral decomposition of the offline\nspace and by choosing the eigenvectors corresponding to the largest\neigenvalues. The computational saving is due to the fact that the construction\nof the online multiscale space for any input parameter is fast and this space\ncan be re-used for solving the forward problem with any forcing and boundary\ncondition. Compared with the other approaches where global snapshots are used,\nthe local approach that we present in this paper allows us to eliminate\nunnecessary degrees of freedom on a coarse-grid level. We present various\nexamples in the paper and some numerical results to demonstrate the\neffectiveness of our method."}, "authors": [{"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Juan Galvis"}, {"name": "Thomas Y. Hou"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Thomas Y. Hou"}, "author": "Thomas Y. Hou", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2013.04.045", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2013.04.045", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.2866v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1301.2866v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "Revised version", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.CE", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.3550v4", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.3550v4", "updated": "2015-04-18T17:34:20Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 4, 18, 17, 34, 20, 5, 108, 0], "published": "2014-09-11T19:27:16Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 9, 11, 19, 27, 16, 3, 254, 0], "title": "Generalized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\n  propagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Generalized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\n  propagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media"}, "summary": "It is important to develop fast yet accurate numerical methods for seismic\nwave propagation to characterize complex geological structures and oil and gas\nreservoirs. However, the computational cost of conventional numerical modeling\nmethods, such as finite-difference method and finite-element method, becomes\nprohibitively expensive when applied to very large models. We propose a\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\npropagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media, where we construct basis\nfunctions from multiple local problems for both the boundaries and interior of\na coarse node support or coarse element. The application of multiscale basis\nfunctions can capture the fine scale medium property variations, and allows us\nto greatly reduce the degrees of freedom that are required to implement the\nmodeling compared with conventional finite-element method for wave equation,\nwhile restricting the error to low values. We formulate the continuous Galerkin\nand discontinuous Galerkin formulation of the multiscale method, both of which\nhave pros and cons. Applications of the multiscale method to three\nheterogeneous models show that our multiscale method can effectively model the\nelastic wave propagation in anisotropic media with a significant reduction in\nthe degrees of freedom in the modeling system.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "It is important to develop fast yet accurate numerical methods for seismic\nwave propagation to characterize complex geological structures and oil and gas\nreservoirs. However, the computational cost of conventional numerical modeling\nmethods, such as finite-difference method and finite-element method, becomes\nprohibitively expensive when applied to very large models. We propose a\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\npropagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media, where we construct basis\nfunctions from multiple local problems for both the boundaries and interior of\na coarse node support or coarse element. The application of multiscale basis\nfunctions can capture the fine scale medium property variations, and allows us\nto greatly reduce the degrees of freedom that are required to implement the\nmodeling compared with conventional finite-element method for wave equation,\nwhile restricting the error to low values. We formulate the continuous Galerkin\nand discontinuous Galerkin formulation of the multiscale method, both of which\nhave pros and cons. Applications of the multiscale method to three\nheterogeneous models show that our multiscale method can effectively model the\nelastic wave propagation in anisotropic media with a significant reduction in\nthe degrees of freedom in the modeling system."}, "authors": [{"name": "Kai Gao"}, {"name": "Shubin Fu"}, {"name": "Richard L. Gibson Jr."}, {"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, "author": "Yalchin Efendiev", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2015.03.068", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2015.03.068", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.3550v4", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1409.3550v4", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.geo-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.geo-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1504.04417v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1504.04417v1", "updated": "2015-04-17T01:31:24Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 4, 17, 1, 31, 24, 4, 107, 0], "published": "2015-04-17T01:31:24Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 4, 17, 1, 31, 24, 4, 107, 0], "title": "An online generalized multiscale discontinuous Galerkin method (GMsDGM)\n  for flows in heterogeneous media", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "An online generalized multiscale discontinuous Galerkin method (GMsDGM)\n  for flows in heterogeneous media"}, "summary": "Offline computation is an essential component in most multiscale model\nreduction techniques. However, there are multiscale problems in which offline\nprocedure is insufficient to give accurate representations of solutions, due to\nthe fact that offline computations are typically performed locally and global\ninformation is missing in these offline information. To tackle this difficulty,\nwe develop an online local adaptivity technique for local multiscale model\nreduction problems. We design new online basis functions within Discontinuous\nGalerkin method based on local residuals and some optimally estimates. The\nresulting basis functions are able to capture the solution efficiently and\naccurately, and are added to the approximation iteratively. Moreover, we show\nthat the iterative procedure is convergent with a rate independent of physical\nscales if the initial space is chosen carefully. Our analysis also gives a\nguideline on how to choose the initial space. We present some numerical\nexamples to show the performance of the proposed method.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Offline computation is an essential component in most multiscale model\nreduction techniques. However, there are multiscale problems in which offline\nprocedure is insufficient to give accurate representations of solutions, due to\nthe fact that offline computations are typically performed locally and global\ninformation is missing in these offline information. To tackle this difficulty,\nwe develop an online local adaptivity technique for local multiscale model\nreduction problems. We design new online basis functions within Discontinuous\nGalerkin method based on local residuals and some optimally estimates. The\nresulting basis functions are able to capture the solution efficiently and\naccurately, and are added to the approximation iteratively. Moreover, we show\nthat the iterative procedure is convergent with a rate independent of physical\nscales if the initial space is chosen carefully. Our analysis also gives a\nguideline on how to choose the initial space. We present some numerical\nexamples to show the performance of the proposed method."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, "author": "Wing Tat Leung", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1504.04417v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1504.04417v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1810.07534v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1810.07534v1", "updated": "2018-10-15T21:25:12Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 10, 15, 21, 25, 12, 0, 288, 0], "published": "2018-10-15T21:25:12Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 10, 15, 21, 25, 12, 0, 288, 0], "title": "Stochastic homogenization for a diffusion-reaction model", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Stochastic homogenization for a diffusion-reaction model"}, "summary": "In this paper, we study stochastic homogenization of a coupled\ndiffusion-reaction system. The diffusion-reaction system is coupled to\nstochastic differential equations, which govern the changes in the media\nproperties. Though homogenization with changing media properties has been\nstudied in previous findings, there is little research on homogenization when\nthe media properties change due to stochastic differential equations. Such\nprocesses occur in many applications, where the changes in media properties are\ndue to particle deposition. In the paper, we investigate the well-posedness of\nthe nonlinear fine-grid (resolved) problem and derive limiting equations. We\nformulate the cell problems and derive the limiting equations, which are\ndeterministic with nonlinear reaction terms. The limiting equations involve the\ninvariant measures corresponding to stochastic differential equations. These\nobtained results can play an important role for modeling in porous media and\nallow the use of simplified and deterministic limiting equations.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we study stochastic homogenization of a coupled\ndiffusion-reaction system. The diffusion-reaction system is coupled to\nstochastic differential equations, which govern the changes in the media\nproperties. Though homogenization with changing media properties has been\nstudied in previous findings, there is little research on homogenization when\nthe media properties change due to stochastic differential equations. Such\nprocesses occur in many applications, where the changes in media properties are\ndue to particle deposition. In the paper, we investigate the well-posedness of\nthe nonlinear fine-grid (resolved) problem and derive limiting equations. We\nformulate the cell problems and derive the limiting equations, which are\ndeterministic with nonlinear reaction terms. The limiting equations involve the\ninvariant measures corresponding to stochastic differential equations. These\nobtained results can play an important role for modeling in porous media and\nallow the use of simplified and deterministic limiting equations."}, "authors": [{"name": "Hakima Bessaih"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Razvan Florian Maris"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Razvan Florian Maris"}, "author": "Razvan Florian Maris", "arxiv_comment": "arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with arXiv:1504.04845", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1810.07534v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.07534v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "60H30, 76S05", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.05959v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.05959v1", "updated": "2017-05-16T23:55:58Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 5, 16, 23, 55, 58, 1, 136, 0], "published": "2017-05-16T23:55:58Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 5, 16, 23, 55, 58, 1, 136, 0], "title": "Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\n  Method in the Mixed Formulation", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\n  Method in the Mixed Formulation"}, "summary": "This paper presents a novel mass-conservative mixed multiscale method for\nsolving flow equations in heterogeneous porous media. The media properties (the\npermeability) contain multiple scales and high contrast. The proposed method\nsolves the flow equation in a mixed formulation on a coarse grid by\nconstructing multiscale basis functions. The resulting velocity field is mass\nconservative on the fine grid. Our main goal is to obtain first-order\nconvergence in terms of the mesh size which is independent of local contrast.\nThis is achieved, first, by constructing some auxiliary spaces, which contain\nglobal information that can not be localized, in general. This is built on our\nprevious work on the Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM). In\nthe auxiliary space, multiscale basis functions corresponding to small\n(contrast-dependent) eigenvalues are selected. These basis functions represent\nthe high-conductivity channels (which connect the boundaries of a coarse\nblock). Next, we solve local problems to construct multiscale basis functions\nfor the velocity field. These local problems are formulated in the oversampled\ndomain taking into account some constraints with respect to auxiliary spaces.\nThe latter allows fast spatial decay of local solutions and, thus, allows\ntaking smaller oversampled regions. The number of basis functions depends on\nsmall eigenvalues of the local spectral problems. Moreover, multiscale pressure\nbasis functions are needed in constructing the velocity space. Our multiscale\nspaces have a minimal dimension, which is needed to avoid contrast-dependence\nin the convergence. The method's convergence requires an oversampling of\nseveral layers. We present an analysis of our approach. Our numerical results\nconfirm that the convergence rate is first order with respect to the mesh size\nand independent of the contrast.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper presents a novel mass-conservative mixed multiscale method for\nsolving flow equations in heterogeneous porous media. The media properties (the\npermeability) contain multiple scales and high contrast. The proposed method\nsolves the flow equation in a mixed formulation on a coarse grid by\nconstructing multiscale basis functions. The resulting velocity field is mass\nconservative on the fine grid. Our main goal is to obtain first-order\nconvergence in terms of the mesh size which is independent of local contrast.\nThis is achieved, first, by constructing some auxiliary spaces, which contain\nglobal information that can not be localized, in general. This is built on our\nprevious work on the Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM). In\nthe auxiliary space, multiscale basis functions corresponding to small\n(contrast-dependent) eigenvalues are selected. These basis functions represent\nthe high-conductivity channels (which connect the boundaries of a coarse\nblock). Next, we solve local problems to construct multiscale basis functions\nfor the velocity field. These local problems are formulated in the oversampled\ndomain taking into account some constraints with respect to auxiliary spaces.\nThe latter allows fast spatial decay of local solutions and, thus, allows\ntaking smaller oversampled regions. The number of basis functions depends on\nsmall eigenvalues of the local spectral problems. Moreover, multiscale pressure\nbasis functions are needed in constructing the velocity space. Our multiscale\nspaces have a minimal dimension, which is needed to avoid contrast-dependence\nin the convergence. The method's convergence requires an oversampling of\nseveral layers. We present an analysis of our approach. Our numerical results\nconfirm that the convergence rate is first order with respect to the mesh size\nand independent of the contrast."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, "author": "Wing Tat Leung", "arxiv_doi": "10.1007/s10596-018-9719-7", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10596-018-9719-7", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.05959v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1705.05959v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2012.01817v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2012.01817v1", "updated": "2020-12-03T10:44:22Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 12, 3, 10, 44, 22, 3, 338, 0], "published": "2020-12-03T10:44:22Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 12, 3, 10, 44, 22, 3, 338, 0], "title": "Iterative Oversampling Technique for Constraint Energy Minimizing\n  Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method in the Mixed Formulation", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Iterative Oversampling Technique for Constraint Energy Minimizing\n  Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method in the Mixed Formulation"}, "summary": "In this paper, we develop an iterative scheme to construct multiscale basis\nfunctions within the framework of the Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized\nMultiscale Finite Element Method (CEM-GMsFEM) for the mixed formulation. The\niterative procedure starts with the construction of an energy minimizing\nsnapshot space that can be used for approximating the solution of the model\nproblem. A spectral decomposition is then performed on the snapshot space to\nform global multiscale space. Under this setting, each global multiscale basis\nfunction can be split into a non-decaying and a decaying parts. The\nnon-decaying part of a global basis is localized and it is fixed during the\niteration. Then, one can approximate the decaying part via a modified\nRichardson scheme with an appropriately defined preconditioner. Using this set\nof iterative-based multiscale basis functions, first-order convergence with\nrespect to the coarse mesh size can be shown if sufficiently many times of\niterations with regularization parameter being in an appropriate range are\nperformed. Numerical results are presented to illustrate the effectiveness and\nefficiency of the proposed computational multiscale method.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we develop an iterative scheme to construct multiscale basis\nfunctions within the framework of the Constraint Energy Minimizing Generalized\nMultiscale Finite Element Method (CEM-GMsFEM) for the mixed formulation. The\niterative procedure starts with the construction of an energy minimizing\nsnapshot space that can be used for approximating the solution of the model\nproblem. A spectral decomposition is then performed on the snapshot space to\nform global multiscale space. Under this setting, each global multiscale basis\nfunction can be split into a non-decaying and a decaying parts. The\nnon-decaying part of a global basis is localized and it is fixed during the\niteration. Then, one can approximate the decaying part via a modified\nRichardson scheme with an appropriately defined preconditioner. Using this set\nof iterative-based multiscale basis functions, first-order convergence with\nrespect to the coarse mesh size can be shown if sufficiently many times of\niterations with regularization parameter being in an appropriate range are\nperformed. Numerical results are presented to illustrate the effectiveness and\nefficiency of the proposed computational multiscale method."}, "authors": [{"name": "Siu Wun Cheung"}, {"name": "Eric Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, {"name": "Sai-Mang Pun"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Sai-Mang Pun"}, "author": "Sai-Mang Pun", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2012.01817v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2012.01817v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.08194v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.08194v1", "updated": "2017-07-24T15:18:38Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 7, 24, 15, 18, 38, 0, 205, 0], "published": "2017-07-24T15:18:38Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 7, 24, 15, 18, 38, 0, 205, 0], "title": "Generalized Multiscale Inversion for Heterogeneous Problems", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Generalized Multiscale Inversion for Heterogeneous Problems"}, "summary": "In this work, we propose a generalized multiscale inversion algorithm for\nheterogeneous problems that aims at solving an inverse problem on a\ncomputational coarse grid. Previous inversion techniques for multiscale\nproblems seek a coarse-grid media properties, e.g., permeability and\nconductivity, and by doing so, they assume that there exists a homogenized\nrepresentation of the underlying fine-scale permeability field on a coarse\ngrid. Generally such assumptions do not hold for highly heterogeneous fields,\ne.g., fracture media or channelized fields, where the width of channels are\nvery small compared to the coarse-grid sizes. In these cases, grid refinement\ncan lead to many degrees of freedom, and thus unattractive to apply. The\nproposed algorithm is based on the Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method\n(GMsFEM), which uses local spectral problems to identify non-localized\nfeatures, i.e., channels (high-conductivity inclusions that connect the\nboundaries of the coarse-grid block). The inclusion of these features in the\ncoarse space enables one to achieve a good accuracy. The approach is valid\nunder the assumption that the solution can be well represented in a\nreduced-dimensional space by multiscale basis functions. In practice, these\nbasis functions are non-observable as we do not identify the fine-scale\nfeatures of the permeability field. Our inversion algorithm finds the\ndiscretization parameters of the resulting system. By doing so, we identify the\nappropriate coarse-grid parameters representing the permeability field instead\nof fine-grid permeability field. We illustrate the approach by numerical\nresults for fractured media.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this work, we propose a generalized multiscale inversion algorithm for\nheterogeneous problems that aims at solving an inverse problem on a\ncomputational coarse grid. Previous inversion techniques for multiscale\nproblems seek a coarse-grid media properties, e.g., permeability and\nconductivity, and by doing so, they assume that there exists a homogenized\nrepresentation of the underlying fine-scale permeability field on a coarse\ngrid. Generally such assumptions do not hold for highly heterogeneous fields,\ne.g., fracture media or channelized fields, where the width of channels are\nvery small compared to the coarse-grid sizes. In these cases, grid refinement\ncan lead to many degrees of freedom, and thus unattractive to apply. The\nproposed algorithm is based on the Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method\n(GMsFEM), which uses local spectral problems to identify non-localized\nfeatures, i.e., channels (high-conductivity inclusions that connect the\nboundaries of the coarse-grid block). The inclusion of these features in the\ncoarse space enables one to achieve a good accuracy. The approach is valid\nunder the assumption that the solution can be well represented in a\nreduced-dimensional space by multiscale basis functions. In practice, these\nbasis functions are non-observable as we do not identify the fine-scale\nfeatures of the permeability field. Our inversion algorithm finds the\ndiscretization parameters of the resulting system. By doing so, we identify the\nappropriate coarse-grid parameters representing the permeability field instead\nof fine-grid permeability field. We illustrate the approach by numerical\nresults for fractured media."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, {"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}, "author": "Maria Vasilyeva", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.08194v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1707.08194v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.0123v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.0123v1", "updated": "2013-06-29T15:53:51Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 6, 29, 15, 53, 51, 5, 180, 0], "published": "2013-06-29T15:53:51Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 6, 29, 15, 53, 51, 5, 180, 0], "title": "Generalized multiscale finite element methods for wave propagation in\n  heterogeneous media", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Generalized multiscale finite element methods for wave propagation in\n  heterogeneous media"}, "summary": "Numerical modeling of wave propagation in heterogeneous media is important in\nmany applications. Due to the complex nature, direct numerical simulations on\nthe fine grid are prohibitively expensive. It is therefore important to develop\nefficient and accurate methods that allow the use of coarse grids. In this\npaper, we present a multiscale finite element method for wave propagation on a\ncoarse grid. The proposed method is based on the Generalized Multiscale Finite\nElement Method (GMsFEM). To construct multiscale basis functions, we start with\ntwo snapshot spaces in each coarse-grid block where one represents the degrees\nof freedom on the boundary and the other represents the degrees of freedom in\nthe interior. We use local spectral problems to identify important modes in\neach snapshot space. These local spectral problems are different from each\nother and their formulations are based on the analysis. To our best knowledge,\nthis is the first time where multiple snapshot spaces and multiple spectral\nproblems are used and necessary for efficient computations. Using the dominant\nmodes from local spectral problems, multiscale basis functions are constructed\nto represent the solution space locally within each coarse block. These\nmultiscale basis functions are coupled via the symmetric interior penalty\ndiscontinuous Galerkin method which provides a block diagonal mass matrix, and,\nconsequently, results in fast computations in an explicit time discretiza-\ntion. Our methods' stability and spectral convergence are rigorously analyzed.\nNumerical examples are presented to show our methods' performance. We also test\noversampling strategies. In particular, we discuss how the modes from different\nsnapshot spaces can affect the proposed methods' accuracy.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Numerical modeling of wave propagation in heterogeneous media is important in\nmany applications. Due to the complex nature, direct numerical simulations on\nthe fine grid are prohibitively expensive. It is therefore important to develop\nefficient and accurate methods that allow the use of coarse grids. In this\npaper, we present a multiscale finite element method for wave propagation on a\ncoarse grid. The proposed method is based on the Generalized Multiscale Finite\nElement Method (GMsFEM). To construct multiscale basis functions, we start with\ntwo snapshot spaces in each coarse-grid block where one represents the degrees\nof freedom on the boundary and the other represents the degrees of freedom in\nthe interior. We use local spectral problems to identify important modes in\neach snapshot space. These local spectral problems are different from each\nother and their formulations are based on the analysis. To our best knowledge,\nthis is the first time where multiple snapshot spaces and multiple spectral\nproblems are used and necessary for efficient computations. Using the dominant\nmodes from local spectral problems, multiscale basis functions are constructed\nto represent the solution space locally within each coarse block. These\nmultiscale basis functions are coupled via the symmetric interior penalty\ndiscontinuous Galerkin method which provides a block diagonal mass matrix, and,\nconsequently, results in fast computations in an explicit time discretiza-\ntion. Our methods' stability and spectral convergence are rigorously analyzed.\nNumerical examples are presented to show our methods' performance. We also test\noversampling strategies. In particular, we discuss how the modes from different\nsnapshot spaces can affect the proposed methods' accuracy."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, "author": "Wing Tat Leung", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.0123v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1307.0123v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.3550v4", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.3550v4", "updated": "2015-04-18T17:34:20Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 4, 18, 17, 34, 20, 5, 108, 0], "published": "2014-09-11T19:27:16Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 9, 11, 19, 27, 16, 3, 254, 0], "title": "Generalized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\n  propagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Generalized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\n  propagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media"}, "summary": "It is important to develop fast yet accurate numerical methods for seismic\nwave propagation to characterize complex geological structures and oil and gas\nreservoirs. However, the computational cost of conventional numerical modeling\nmethods, such as finite-difference method and finite-element method, becomes\nprohibitively expensive when applied to very large models. We propose a\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\npropagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media, where we construct basis\nfunctions from multiple local problems for both the boundaries and interior of\na coarse node support or coarse element. The application of multiscale basis\nfunctions can capture the fine scale medium property variations, and allows us\nto greatly reduce the degrees of freedom that are required to implement the\nmodeling compared with conventional finite-element method for wave equation,\nwhile restricting the error to low values. We formulate the continuous Galerkin\nand discontinuous Galerkin formulation of the multiscale method, both of which\nhave pros and cons. Applications of the multiscale method to three\nheterogeneous models show that our multiscale method can effectively model the\nelastic wave propagation in anisotropic media with a significant reduction in\nthe degrees of freedom in the modeling system.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "It is important to develop fast yet accurate numerical methods for seismic\nwave propagation to characterize complex geological structures and oil and gas\nreservoirs. However, the computational cost of conventional numerical modeling\nmethods, such as finite-difference method and finite-element method, becomes\nprohibitively expensive when applied to very large models. We propose a\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\npropagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media, where we construct basis\nfunctions from multiple local problems for both the boundaries and interior of\na coarse node support or coarse element. The application of multiscale basis\nfunctions can capture the fine scale medium property variations, and allows us\nto greatly reduce the degrees of freedom that are required to implement the\nmodeling compared with conventional finite-element method for wave equation,\nwhile restricting the error to low values. We formulate the continuous Galerkin\nand discontinuous Galerkin formulation of the multiscale method, both of which\nhave pros and cons. Applications of the multiscale method to three\nheterogeneous models show that our multiscale method can effectively model the\nelastic wave propagation in anisotropic media with a significant reduction in\nthe degrees of freedom in the modeling system."}, "authors": [{"name": "Kai Gao"}, {"name": "Shubin Fu"}, {"name": "Richard L.
