Symmetric Interior Penalty\n  Coupling", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method. Symmetric Interior Penalty\n  Coupling"}, "summary": "Motivated by applications to numerical simulation of flows in highly\nheterogeneous porous media, we develop multiscale finite element methods for\nsecond order elliptic equations. We discuss a multiscale model reduction\ntechnique in the framework of the discontinuous Galerkin finite element method.\nWe propose three different finite element spaces on the coarse mesh.\n  The first space is based on a local eigenvalue problem that uses a weighted\n$L_2-$norm for computing the \"mass\" matrix. The second space is generated by\namending the eigenvalue problem of the first case with a term related to the\npenalty. The third choice is based on generation of a large space of snapshots\nand subsequent selection of a subspace of a reduced dimension.\n  The approximation with these spaces is based on the discontinuous Galerkin\nfinite element method framework. We investigate the stability and derive error\nestimates for the methods and further experimentally study their performance on\na representative number of numerical examples.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Motivated by applications to numerical simulation of flows in highly\nheterogeneous porous media, we develop multiscale finite element methods for\nsecond order elliptic equations. We discuss a multiscale model reduction\ntechnique in the framework of the discontinuous Galerkin finite element method.\nWe propose three different finite element spaces on the coarse mesh.\n  The first space is based on a local eigenvalue problem that uses a weighted\n$L_2-$norm for computing the \"mass\" matrix. The second space is generated by\namending the eigenvalue problem of the first case with a term related to the\npenalty. The third choice is based on generation of a large space of snapshots\nand subsequent selection of a subspace of a reduced dimension.\n  The approximation with these spaces is based on the discontinuous Galerkin\nfinite element method framework. We investigate the stability and derive error\nestimates for the methods and further experimentally study their performance on\na representative number of numerical examples."}, "authors": [{"name": "Y. Efendiev"}, {"name": "J. Galvis"}, {"name": "R. Lazarov"}, {"name": "M. Moon"}, {"name": "M. Sarkis"}], "author_detail": {"name": "M. Sarkis"}, "author": "M. Sarkis", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2013.07.028", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2013.07.028", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1302.7071v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1302.7071v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1809.10826v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1809.10826v1", "updated": "2018-09-28T02:19:12Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 9, 28, 2, 19, 12, 4, 271, 0], "published": "2018-09-28T02:19:12Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 9, 28, 2, 19, 12, 4, 271, 0], "title": "Nonlinear nonlocal multicontinua upscaling framework and its\n  applications", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Nonlinear nonlocal multicontinua upscaling framework and its\n  applications"}, "summary": "In this paper, we discuss multiscale methods for nonlinear problems. The main\nidea of these approaches is to use local constraints and solve problems in\noversampled regions for constructing macroscopic equations. These techniques\nare intended for problems without scale separation and high contrast, which\noften occur in applications. For linear problems, the local solutions with\nconstraints are used as basis functions. This technique is called Constraint\nEnergy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (CEM-GMsFEM).\nGMsFEM identifies macroscopic quantities based on rigorous analysis. In\ncorresponding upscaling methods, the multiscale basis functions are selected\nsuch that the degrees of freedom have physical meanings, such as averages of\nthe solution on each continuum.\n  This paper extends the linear concepts to nonlinear problems, where the local\nproblems are nonlinear. The main concept consists of: (1) identifying\nmacroscopic quantities; (2) constructing appropriate oversampled local problems\nwith coarse-grid constraints; (3) formulating macroscopic equations. We\nconsider two types of approaches. In the first approach, the solutions of local\nproblems are used as basis functions (in a linear fashion) to solve nonlinear\nproblems. This approach is simple to implement; however, it lacks the nonlinear\ninterpolation, which we present in our second approach. In this approach, the\nlocal solutions are used as a nonlinear forward map from local averages\n(constraints) of the solution in oversampling region. This local fine-grid\nsolution is further used to formulate the coarse-grid problem. Both approaches\nare discussed on several examples and applied to single-phase and two-phase\nflow problems, which are challenging because of convection-dominated nature of\nthe concentration equation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we discuss multiscale methods for nonlinear problems. The main\nidea of these approaches is to use local constraints and solve problems in\noversampled regions for constructing macroscopic equations. These techniques\nare intended for problems without scale separation and high contrast, which\noften occur in applications. For linear problems, the local solutions with\nconstraints are used as basis functions. This technique is called Constraint\nEnergy Minimizing Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method (CEM-GMsFEM).\nGMsFEM identifies macroscopic quantities based on rigorous analysis. In\ncorresponding upscaling methods, the multiscale basis functions are selected\nsuch that the degrees of freedom have physical meanings, such as averages of\nthe solution on each continuum.\n  This paper extends the linear concepts to nonlinear problems, where the local\nproblems are nonlinear. The main concept consists of: (1) identifying\nmacroscopic quantities; (2) constructing appropriate oversampled local problems\nwith coarse-grid constraints; (3) formulating macroscopic equations. We\nconsider two types of approaches. In the first approach, the solutions of local\nproblems are used as basis functions (in a linear fashion) to solve nonlinear\nproblems. This approach is simple to implement; however, it lacks the nonlinear\ninterpolation, which we present in our second approach. In this approach, the\nlocal solutions are used as a nonlinear forward map from local averages\n(constraints) of the solution in oversampling region. This local fine-grid\nsolution is further used to formulate the coarse-grid problem. Both approaches\nare discussed on several examples and applied to single-phase and two-phase\nflow problems, which are challenging because of convection-dominated nature of\nthe concentration equation."}, "authors": [{"name": "Wing T. Leung"}, {"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Mary F. Wheeler"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Mary F. Wheeler"}, "author": "Mary F. Wheeler", "arxiv_doi": "10.1615/IntJMultCompEng.2018027832", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1615/IntJMultCompEng.2018027832", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1809.10826v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1809.10826v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2004.04308v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2004.04308v1", "updated": "2020-04-09T00:26:18Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 4, 9, 0, 26, 18, 3, 100, 0], "published": "2020-04-09T00:26:18Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 4, 9, 0, 26, 18, 3, 100, 0], "title": "Learning Algorithms for Coarsening Uncertainty Space and Applications to\n  Multiscale Simulations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Learning Algorithms for Coarsening Uncertainty Space and Applications to\n  Multiscale Simulations"}, "summary": "In this paper, we investigate and design multiscale simulations for\nstochastic multiscale PDEs. As for the space, we consider a coarse grid and a\nknown multiscale method, the Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method\n(GMsFEM). In order to obtain a small dimensional representation of the solution\nin each coarse block, the uncertainty space needs to be partitioned\n(coarsened). This coarsening collects realizations that provide similar\nmultiscale features as outlined in GMsFEM (or other method of choice). This\nstep is known to be computationally demanding as it requires many local solves\nand clustering based on them. In this paper, we take a different approach and\nlearn coarsening the uncertainty space. Our methods use deep learning\ntechniques in identifying clusters(coarsening) in the uncertainty space. We use\nconvolutional neural networks combined with some techniques in adversary neural\nnetworks. We define appropriate loss functions in the proposed neural networks,\nwhere the loss function is composed of several parts that includes terms\nrelated to clusters and reconstruction of basis functions. We present numerical\nresults for channelized permeability fields in the examples of flows in porous\nmedia.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we investigate and design multiscale simulations for\nstochastic multiscale PDEs. As for the space, we consider a coarse grid and a\nknown multiscale method, the Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method\n(GMsFEM). In order to obtain a small dimensional representation of the solution\nin each coarse block, the uncertainty space needs to be partitioned\n(coarsened). This coarsening collects realizations that provide similar\nmultiscale features as outlined in GMsFEM (or other method of choice). This\nstep is known to be computationally demanding as it requires many local solves\nand clustering based on them. In this paper, we take a different approach and\nlearn coarsening the uncertainty space. Our methods use deep learning\ntechniques in identifying clusters(coarsening) in the uncertainty space. We use\nconvolutional neural networks combined with some techniques in adversary neural\nnetworks. We define appropriate loss functions in the proposed neural networks,\nwhere the loss function is composed of several parts that includes terms\nrelated to clusters and reconstruction of basis functions. We present numerical\nresults for channelized permeability fields in the examples of flows in porous\nmedia."}, "authors": [{"name": "Zecheng Zhang"}, {"name": "Eric Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, "author": "Wing Tat Leung", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2004.04308v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2004.04308v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.04565v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.04565v1", "updated": "2015-01-19T17:22:24Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 1, 19, 17, 22, 24, 0, 19, 0], "published": "2015-01-19T17:22:24Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 1, 19, 17, 22, 24, 0, 19, 0], "title": "Residual-driven online Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Methods", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Residual-driven online Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Methods"}, "summary": "The construction of local reduced-order models via multiscale basis functions\nhas been an area of active research. In this paper, we propose online\nmultiscale basis functions which are constructed using the offline space and\nthe current residual. Online multiscale basis functions are constructed\nadaptively in some selected regions based on our error indicators. We derive an\nerror estimator which shows that one needs to have an offline space with\ncertain properties to guarantee that additional online multiscale basis\nfunction will decrease the error. This error decrease is independent of\nphysical parameters, such as the contrast and multiple scales in the problem.\nThe offline spaces are constructed using Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\nMethods (GMsFEM). We show that if one chooses a sufficient number of offline\nbasis functions, one can guarantee that additional online multiscale basis\nfunctions will reduce the error independent of contrast. We note that the\nconstruction of online basis functions is motivated by the fact that the\noffline space construction does not take into account distant effects. Using\nthe residual information, we can incorporate the distant information provided\nthe offline approximation satisfies certain properties. In the paper,\ntheoretical and numerical results are presented. Our numerical results show\nthat if the offline space is sufficiently large (in terms of the dimension)\nsuch that the coarse space contains all multiscale spectral basis functions\nthat correspond to small eigenvalues, then the error reduction by adding online\nmultiscale basis function is independent of the contrast. We discuss various\nways computing online multiscale basis functions which include a use of small\ndimensional offline spaces.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The construction of local reduced-order models via multiscale basis functions\nhas been an area of active research. In this paper, we propose online\nmultiscale basis functions which are constructed using the offline space and\nthe current residual. Online multiscale basis functions are constructed\nadaptively in some selected regions based on our error indicators. We derive an\nerror estimator which shows that one needs to have an offline space with\ncertain properties to guarantee that additional online multiscale basis\nfunction will decrease the error. This error decrease is independent of\nphysical parameters, such as the contrast and multiple scales in the problem.\nThe offline spaces are constructed using Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\nMethods (GMsFEM). We show that if one chooses a sufficient number of offline\nbasis functions, one can guarantee that additional online multiscale basis\nfunctions will reduce the error independent of contrast. We note that the\nconstruction of online basis functions is motivated by the fact that the\noffline space construction does not take into account distant effects. Using\nthe residual information, we can incorporate the distant information provided\nthe offline approximation satisfies certain properties. In the paper,\ntheoretical and numerical results are presented. Our numerical results show\nthat if the offline space is sufficiently large (in terms of the dimension)\nsuch that the coarse space contains all multiscale spectral basis functions\nthat correspond to small eigenvalues, then the error reduction by adding online\nmultiscale basis function is independent of the contrast. We discuss various\nways computing online multiscale basis functions which include a use of small\ndimensional offline spaces."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, "author": "Wing Tat Leung", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.04565v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1501.04565v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.3550v4", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.3550v4", "updated": "2015-04-18T17:34:20Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 4, 18, 17, 34, 20, 5, 108, 0], "published": "2014-09-11T19:27:16Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 9, 11, 19, 27, 16, 3, 254, 0], "title": "Generalized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\n  propagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Generalized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\n  propagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media"}, "summary": "It is important to develop fast yet accurate numerical methods for seismic\nwave propagation to characterize complex geological structures and oil and gas\nreservoirs. However, the computational cost of conventional numerical modeling\nmethods, such as finite-difference method and finite-element method, becomes\nprohibitively expensive when applied to very large models. We propose a\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\npropagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media, where we construct basis\nfunctions from multiple local problems for both the boundaries and interior of\na coarse node support or coarse element. The application of multiscale basis\nfunctions can capture the fine scale medium property variations, and allows us\nto greatly reduce the degrees of freedom that are required to implement the\nmodeling compared with conventional finite-element method for wave equation,\nwhile restricting the error to low values. We formulate the continuous Galerkin\nand discontinuous Galerkin formulation of the multiscale method, both of which\nhave pros and cons. Applications of the multiscale method to three\nheterogeneous models show that our multiscale method can effectively model the\nelastic wave propagation in anisotropic media with a significant reduction in\nthe degrees of freedom in the modeling system.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "It is important to develop fast yet accurate numerical methods for seismic\nwave propagation to characterize complex geological structures and oil and gas\nreservoirs. However, the computational cost of conventional numerical modeling\nmethods, such as finite-difference method and finite-element method, becomes\nprohibitively expensive when applied to very large models. We propose a\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite-Element Method (GMsFEM) for elastic wave\npropagation in heterogeneous, anisotropic media, where we construct basis\nfunctions from multiple local problems for both the boundaries and interior of\na coarse node support or coarse element. The application of multiscale basis\nfunctions can capture the fine scale medium property variations, and allows us\nto greatly reduce the degrees of freedom that are required to implement the\nmodeling compared with conventional finite-element method for wave equation,\nwhile restricting the error to low values. We formulate the continuous Galerkin\nand discontinuous Galerkin formulation of the multiscale method, both of which\nhave pros and cons. Applications of the multiscale method to three\nheterogeneous models show that our multiscale method can effectively model the\nelastic wave propagation in anisotropic media with a significant reduction in\nthe degrees of freedom in the modeling system."}, "authors": [{"name": "Kai Gao"}, {"name": "Shubin Fu"}, {"name": "Richard L. The\nmathematical model is described by the coupled system of equation for\ndisplacement, fracture and matrix pressures. For a fine grid approximation, we\nuse the finite volume method for flow problem and finite element method for\nmechanics. Due to the complexity of fractures, solutions have a variety of\nscales, and fine grid approximation results in a large discrete system. Our\nsecond focus in on constructing the upscaled coarse grid poroelasticity model\nfor fractured media. Our upscaled approach is based on the nonlocal\nmulticontinuum (NLMC) upscaling for coupled flow and mechanics problem, which\ninvolves computations of local basis functions via an energy minimization\nprinciple. This concept allows a systematic upscaling for processes in the\nfractured porous media, and provides an effective coarse scale model whose\ndegrees of freedoms have physical meaning. We obtain a fast and accurate solver\nfor the poroelasticity problem on a coarse grid and, at the same time, derive a\nnovel upscaled model. We present numerical results for the two dimensional\nmodel problem.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, our aim is to present (1) an embedded fracture model (EFM) for\ncoupled flow and mechanics problem based on the dual continuum approach on the\nfine grid and (2) an upscaled model for the resulting fine grid equations. The\nmathematical model is described by the coupled system of equation for\ndisplacement, fracture and matrix pressures. For a fine grid approximation, we\nuse the finite volume method for flow problem and finite element method for\nmechanics. Due to the complexity of fractures, solutions have a variety of\nscales, and fine grid approximation results in a large discrete system. Our\nsecond focus in on constructing the upscaled coarse grid poroelasticity model\nfor fractured media. Our upscaled approach is based on the nonlocal\nmulticontinuum (NLMC) upscaling for coupled flow and mechanics problem, which\ninvolves computations of local basis functions via an energy minimization\nprinciple. This concept allows a systematic upscaling for processes in the\nfractured porous media, and provides an effective coarse scale model whose\ndegrees of freedoms have physical meaning. We obtain a fast and accurate solver\nfor the poroelasticity problem on a coarse grid and, at the same time, derive a\nnovel upscaled model. We present numerical results for the two dimensional\nmodel problem."}, "authors": [{"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}, {"name": "Eric T. Existing stabilization techniques add a\nlimited number of degrees of freedom in the form of bubble functions or a\nmodified diffusion, which may not sufficient to stabilize multiscale systems.\nWe seek a local reduced-order model for this kind of multiscale transport\nproblems and thus, develop a systematic approach for finding reduced-order\napproximations of the solution. We start from a Petrov-Galerkin framework using\noptimal weighting functions. We introduce an auxiliary variable to a mixed\nformulation of the problem. The auxiliary variable stands for the optimal\nweighting function. The problem reduces to finding a test space (a reduced\ndimensional space for this auxiliary variable), which guarantees that the error\nin the primal variable (representing the solution) is close to the projection\nerror of the full solution on the reduced dimensional space that approximates\nthe solution. To find the test space, we reformulate some recent mixed\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite Element Methods. We introduce snapshots and local\nspectral problems that appropriately define local weight and trial spaces. In\nparticular, we use energy minimizing snapshots and local spectral\ndecompositions in the natural norm associated with the auxiliary variable. The\nresulting spectral decomposition adaptively identifies and builds the optimal\nmultiscale space to stabilize the system. We discuss the stability and its\nrelation to the approximation property of the test space. We design online\nbasis functions, which accelerate convergence in the test space, and\nconsequently, improve stability. We present several numerical examples and show\nthat one needs a few test functions to achieve an error similar to the\nprojection error in the primal variable irrespective of the Peclet number.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We develop a Petrov-Galerkin stabilization method for multiscale\nconvection-diffusion transport systems. Existing stabilization techniques add a\nlimited number of degrees of freedom in the form of bubble functions or a\nmodified diffusion, which may not sufficient to stabilize multiscale systems.\nWe seek a local reduced-order model for this kind of multiscale transport\nproblems and thus, develop a systematic approach for finding reduced-order\napproximations of the solution. We start from a Petrov-Galerkin framework using\noptimal weighting functions. We introduce an auxiliary variable to a mixed\nformulation of the problem. The auxiliary variable stands for the optimal\nweighting function. The problem reduces to finding a test space (a reduced\ndimensional space for this auxiliary variable), which guarantees that the error\nin the primal variable (representing the solution) is close to the projection\nerror of the full solution on the reduced dimensional space that approximates\nthe solution. To find the test space, we reformulate some recent mixed\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite Element Methods. We introduce snapshots and local\nspectral problems that appropriately define local weight and trial spaces. In\nparticular, we use energy minimizing snapshots and local spectral\ndecompositions in the natural norm associated with the auxiliary variable. The\nresulting spectral decomposition adaptively identifies and builds the optimal\nmultiscale space to stabilize the system. We discuss the stability and its\nrelation to the approximation property of the test space. We design online\nbasis functions, which accelerate convergence in the test space, and\nconsequently, improve stability. We present several numerical examples and show\nthat one needs a few test functions to achieve an error similar to the\nprojection error in the primal variable irrespective of the Peclet number."}, "authors": [{"name": "Victor M. Thus,\nmultilevel methods are desirable for problems with complex heterogeneities and\nhigh contrast. In this paper, we propose a novel three-level upscaling method\nfor flow problems in fractured porous media. Our method starts with a fine grid\ndiscretization for the system involving fractured porous media. In the next\nstep, based on the fine grid model, we construct a nonlocal multi-continua\nupscaling (NLMC) method using an intermediate grid. The system resulting from\nNLMC gives solutions that have physical meaning. In order to enhance locality,\nthe grid size of the intermediate grid needs to be relatively small, and this\nmotivates using such an intermediate grid. However, the resulting NLMC upscaled\nsystem has a relatively large dimension. This motivates a further step of\ndimension reduction. In particular, we will apply the idea of the Generalized\nMultiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM) to the NLMC system to obtain a final\nreduced model. We present simulation results for a two-dimensional model\nproblem with a large number of fractures using the proposed three-level method.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Traditional two level upscaling techniques suffer from a high offline cost\nwhen the coarse grid size is much larger than the fine grid size. Thus,\nmultilevel methods are desirable for problems with complex heterogeneities and\nhigh contrast. In this paper, we propose a novel three-level upscaling method\nfor flow problems in fractured porous media. Our method starts with a fine grid\ndiscretization for the system involving fractured porous media. In the next\nstep, based on the fine grid model, we construct a nonlocal multi-continua\nupscaling (NLMC) method using an intermediate grid. The system resulting from\nNLMC gives solutions that have physical meaning. In order to enhance locality,\nthe grid size of the intermediate grid needs to be relatively small, and this\nmotivates using such an intermediate grid. However, the resulting NLMC upscaled\nsystem has a relatively large dimension. This motivates a further step of\ndimension reduction. In particular, we will apply the idea of the Generalized\nMultiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM) to the NLMC system to obtain a final\nreduced model. We present simulation results for a two-dimensional model\nproblem with a large number of fractures using the proposed three-level method."}, "authors": [{"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}, {"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Aleksey Tyrylgin"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Aleksey Tyrylgin"}, "author": "Aleksey Tyrylgin", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1810.01581v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.01581v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1907.02921v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1907.02921v1", "updated": "2019-07-05T16:44:05Z", "updated_parsed": [2019, 7, 5, 16, 44, 5, 4, 186, 0], "published": "2019-07-05T16:44:05Z", "published_parsed": [2019, 7, 5, 16, 44, 5, 4, 186, 0], "title": "Learning macroscopic parameters in nonlinear multiscale simulations\n  using nonlocal multicontinua upscaling techniques", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Learning macroscopic parameters in nonlinear multiscale simulations\n  using nonlocal multicontinua upscaling techniques"}, "summary": "In this work, we present a novel nonlocal nonlinear coarse grid approximation\nusing a machine learning algorithm. We consider unsaturated and two-phase flow\nproblems in heterogeneous and fractured porous media, where mathematical models\nare formulated as general multicontinuum models. We construct a fine grid\napproximation using the finite volume method and embedded discrete fracture\nmodel. Macroscopic models for these complex nonlinear systems require nonlocal\nmulticontinua approaches, which are developed in earlier works. These rigorous\ntechniques require complex local computations, which involve solving local\nproblems in oversampled regions subject to constraints. The solutions of these\nlocal problems can be replaced by solving original problem on a coarse\n(oversampled) region for many input parameters (boundary and source terms) and\ncomputing effective properties derived by nonlinear nonlocal multicontinua\napproaches. The effective properties depend on many variables (oversampled\nregion and the number of continua), thus their calculations require some type\nof machine learning techniques. In this paper, our contribution is two fold.\nFirst, we present macroscopic models and discuss how to effectively compute\nmacroscopic parameters using deep learning algorithms. The proposed method can\nbe regarded as local machine learning and complements our earlier approaches on\nglobal machine learning. We consider a coarse grid approximation using two\nupscaling techniques with single phase upscaled transmissibilities and nonlocal\nnonlinear upscaled transmissibilities using a machine learning algorithm. We\npresent results for two model problems in heterogeneous and fractured porous\nmedia and show that the presented method is highly accurate and provides fast\ncoarse grid calculations.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this work, we present a novel nonlocal nonlinear coarse grid approximation\nusing a machine learning algorithm. We consider unsaturated and two-phase flow\nproblems in heterogeneous and fractured porous media, where mathematical models\nare formulated as general multicontinuum models. We construct a fine grid\napproximation using the finite volume method and embedded discrete fracture\nmodel. Macroscopic models for these complex nonlinear systems require nonlocal\nmulticontinua approaches, which are developed in earlier works. These rigorous\ntechniques require complex local computations, which involve solving local\nproblems in oversampled regions subject to constraints. The solutions of these\nlocal problems can be replaced by solving original problem on a coarse\n(oversampled) region for many input parameters (boundary and source terms) and\ncomputing effective properties derived by nonlinear nonlocal multicontinua\napproaches. The effective properties depend on many variables (oversampled\nregion and the number of continua), thus their calculations require some type\nof machine learning techniques. In this paper, our contribution is two fold.\nFirst, we present macroscopic models and discuss how to effectively compute\nmacroscopic parameters using deep learning algorithms. The proposed method can\nbe regarded as local machine learning and complements our earlier approaches on\nglobal machine learning. We consider a coarse grid approximation using two\nupscaling techniques with single phase upscaled transmissibilities and nonlocal\nnonlinear upscaled transmissibilities using a machine learning algorithm. We\npresent results for two model problems in heterogeneous and fractured porous\nmedia and show that the presented method is highly accurate and provides fast\ncoarse grid calculations."}, "authors": [{"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}, {"name": "Wing T. Leung"}, {"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Mary Wheeler"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Mary Wheeler"}, "author": "Mary Wheeler", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2020.109323", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2020.109323", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1907.02921v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1907.02921v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1706.07093v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1706.07093v1", "updated": "2017-06-21T19:27:41Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 6, 21, 19, 27, 41, 2, 172, 0], "published": "2017-06-21T19:27:41Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 6, 21, 19, 27, 41, 2, 172, 0], "title": "Fast Online Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method using\n  Constraint Energy Minimization", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Fast Online Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method using\n  Constraint Energy Minimization"}, "summary": "Local multiscale methods often construct multiscale basis functions in the\noffline stage without taking into account input parameters, such as source\nterms, boundary conditions, and so on. These basis functions are then used in\nthe online stage with a specific input parameter to solve the global problem at\na reduced computational cost. Recently, online approaches have been introduced,\nwhere multiscale basis functions are adaptively constructed in some regions to\nreduce the error significantly. In multiscale methods, it is desired to have\nonly 1-2 iterations to reduce the error to a desired threshold. Using\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite Element Framework, it was shown that by choosing\nsufficient number of offline basis functions, the error reduction can be made\nindependent of physical parameters, such as scales and contrast. In this paper,\nour goal is to improve this. Using our recently proposed approach and special\nonline basis construction in oversampled regions, we show that the error\nreduction can be made sufficiently large by appropriately selecting\noversampling regions. Our numerical results show that one can achieve a three\norder of magnitude error reduction, which is better than our previous methods.\nWe also develop an adaptive algorithm and enrich in selected regions with large\nresiduals. In our adaptive method, we show that the convergence rate can be\ndetermined by a user-defined parameter and we confirm this by numerical\nsimulations. The analysis of the method is presented.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Local multiscale methods often construct multiscale basis functions in the\noffline stage without taking into account input parameters, such as source\nterms, boundary conditions, and so on. These basis functions are then used in\nthe online stage with a specific input parameter to solve the global problem at\na reduced computational cost. Recently, online approaches have been introduced,\nwhere multiscale basis functions are adaptively constructed in some regions to\nreduce the error significantly. In multiscale methods, it is desired to have\nonly 1-2 iterations to reduce the error to a desired threshold. Using\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite Element Framework, it was shown that by choosing\nsufficient number of offline basis functions, the error reduction can be made\nindependent of physical parameters, such as scales and contrast. In this paper,\nour goal is to improve this. Using our recently proposed approach and special\nonline basis construction in oversampled regions, we show that the error\nreduction can be made sufficiently large by appropriately selecting\noversampling regions. Our numerical results show that one can achieve a three\norder of magnitude error reduction, which is better than our previous methods.\nWe also develop an adaptive algorithm and enrich in selected regions with large\nresiduals. In our adaptive method, we show that the convergence rate can be\ndetermined by a user-defined parameter and we confirm this by numerical\nsimulations. The analysis of the method is presented."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, "author": "Wing Tat Leung", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2017.11.022", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2017.11.022", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1706.07093v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1706.07093v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1105.1131v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1105.1131v1", "updated": "2011-05-05T17:46:20Z", "updated_parsed": [2011, 5, 5, 17, 46, 20, 3, 125, 0], "published": "2011-05-05T17:46:20Z", "published_parsed": [2011, 5, 5, 17, 46, 20, 3, 125, 0], "title": "Robust Domain Decomposition Preconditioners for Abstract Symmetric\n  Positive Definite Bilinear Forms", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Robust Domain Decomposition Preconditioners for Abstract Symmetric\n  Positive Definite Bilinear Forms"}, "summary": "An abstract framework for constructing stable decompositions of the spaces\ncorresponding to general symmetric positive definite problems into \"local\"\nsubspaces and a global \"coarse\" space is developed. Particular applications of\nthis abstract framework include practically important problems in porous media\napplications such as: the scalar elliptic (pressure) equation and the stream\nfunction formulation of its mixed form, Stokes' and Brinkman's equations. The\nconstant in the corresponding abstract energy estimate is shown to be robust\nwith respect to mesh parameters as well as the contrast, which is defined as\nthe ratio of high and low values of the conductivity (or permeability). The\nderived stable decomposition allows to construct additive overlapping Schwarz\niterative methods with condition numbers uniformly bounded with respect to the\ncontrast and mesh parameters. The coarse spaces are obtained by patching\ntogether the eigenfunctions corresponding to the smallest eigenvalues of\ncertain local problems. A detailed analysis of the abstract setting is\nprovided. The proposed decomposition builds on a method of Efendiev and Galvis,\nMultiscale Model. Simul., 8 (2010), pp. 1461--1483, developed for second order\nscalar elliptic problems with high contrast. Applications to the finite element\ndiscretizations of the second order elliptic problem in Galerkin and mixed\nformulation, the Stokes equations, and Brinkman's problem are presented. A\nnumber of numerical experiments for these problems in two spatial dimensions\nare provided.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "An abstract framework for constructing stable decompositions of the spaces\ncorresponding to general symmetric positive definite problems into \"local\"\nsubspaces and a global \"coarse\" space is developed. Particular applications of\nthis abstract framework include practically important problems in porous media\napplications such as: the scalar elliptic (pressure) equation and the stream\nfunction formulation of its mixed form, Stokes' and Brinkman's equations. The\nconstant in the corresponding abstract energy estimate is shown to be robust\nwith respect to mesh parameters as well as the contrast, which is defined as\nthe ratio of high and low values of the conductivity (or permeability). The\nderived stable decomposition allows to construct additive overlapping Schwarz\niterative methods with condition numbers uniformly bounded with respect to the\ncontrast and mesh parameters. The coarse spaces are obtained by patching\ntogether the eigenfunctions corresponding to the smallest eigenvalues of\ncertain local problems. A detailed analysis of the abstract setting is\nprovided. The proposed decomposition builds on a method of Efendiev and Galvis,\nMultiscale Model. Simul., 8 (2010), pp. 1461--1483, developed for second order\nscalar elliptic problems with high contrast. Applications to the finite element\ndiscretizations of the second order elliptic problem in Galerkin and mixed\nformulation, the Stokes equations, and Brinkman's problem are presented. A\nnumber of numerical experiments for these problems in two spatial dimensions\nare provided."}, "authors": [{"name": "Y. Efendiev"}, {"name": "J. Galvis"}, {"name": "R. Lazarov"}, {"name": "J. Willems", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1105.1131v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1105.1131v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65F10, 65N20, 65N22, 65N30, 65N55", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.0782v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.0782v1", "updated": "2014-07-03T04:47:52Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 7, 3, 4, 47, 52, 3, 184, 0], "published": "2014-07-03T04:47:52Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 7, 3, 4, 47, 52, 3, 184, 0], "title": "Global-Local Nonlinear Model Reduction for Flows in Heterogeneous Porous\n  Media", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Global-Local Nonlinear Model Reduction for Flows in Heterogeneous Porous\n  Media"}, "summary": "In this paper, we combine discrete empirical interpolation techniques, global\nmode decomposition methods, and local multiscale methods, such as the\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM), to reduce the\ncomputational complexity associated with nonlinear flows in\nhighly-heterogeneous porous media. To solve the nonlinear governing equations,\nwe employ the GMsFEM to represent the solution on a coarse grid with multiscale\nbasis functions and apply proper orthogonal decomposition on a coarse grid.\nComputing the GMsFEM solution involves calculating the residual and the\nJacobian on the fine grid. As such, we use local and global empirical\ninterpolation concepts to circumvent performing these computations on the fine\ngrid. The resulting reduced-order approach enables a significant reduction in\nthe flow problem size while accurately capturing the behavior of fully-resolved\nsolutions. We consider several numerical examples of nonlinear multiscale\npartial differential equations that are numerically integrated using\nfully-implicit time marching schemes to demonstrate the capability of the\nproposed model reduction approach to speed up simulations of nonlinear flows in\nhigh-contrast porous media.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we combine discrete empirical interpolation techniques, global\nmode decomposition methods, and local multiscale methods, such as the\nGeneralized Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM), to reduce the\ncomputational complexity associated with nonlinear flows in\nhighly-heterogeneous porous media. To solve the nonlinear governing equations,\nwe employ the GMsFEM to represent the solution on a coarse grid with multiscale\nbasis functions and apply proper orthogonal decomposition on a coarse grid.\nComputing the GMsFEM solution involves calculating the residual and the\nJacobian on the fine grid. As such, we use local and global empirical\ninterpolation concepts to circumvent performing these computations on the fine\ngrid. The resulting reduced-order approach enables a significant reduction in\nthe flow problem size while accurately capturing the behavior of fully-resolved\nsolutions. We consider several numerical examples of nonlinear multiscale\npartial differential equations that are numerically integrated using\nfully-implicit time marching schemes to demonstrate the capability of the\nproposed model reduction approach to speed up simulations of nonlinear flows in\nhigh-contrast porous media."}, "authors": [{"name": "Manal Alotaibi"}, {"name": "Victor M. Stabilization for these problems has been a challenging task,\nespecially for the case with high Peclet numbers. Our method is based on a\nconstraint energy minimization idea and the discontinuous Petrov-Galerkin\nformulation. In particular, the test functions are constructed by minimizing an\nappropriate energy subject to certain orthogonality conditions, and are related\nto the trial space. The resulting test functions have a localization property,\nand can therefore be computed locally. We will prove the stability, and present\nseveral numerical results. Our numerical results confirm that our test space\ngives a good stability, in the sense that the solution error is close to the\nbest approximation error.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We present a new stabilization technique for multiscale convection diffusion\nproblems. Stabilization for these problems has been a challenging task,\nespecially for the case with high Peclet numbers. Our method is based on a\nconstraint energy minimization idea and the discontinuous Petrov-Galerkin\nformulation. In particular, the test functions are constructed by minimizing an\nappropriate energy subject to certain orthogonality conditions, and are related\nto the trial space. The resulting test functions have a localization property,\nand can therefore be computed locally. We will prove the stability, and present\nseveral numerical results. Our numerical results confirm that our test space\ngives a good stability, in the sense that the solution error is close to the\nbest approximation error."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, "author": "Wing Tat Leung", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.11529v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1807.11529v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.5929v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.5929v1", "updated": "2014-08-25T21:06:55Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 8, 25, 21, 6, 55, 0, 237, 0], "published": "2014-08-25T21:06:55Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 8, 25, 21, 6, 55, 0, 237, 0], "title": "Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method for Elasticity Equations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method for Elasticity Equations"}, "summary": "In this paper, we discuss the application of Generalized Multiscale Finite\nElement Method (GMsFEM) to elasticity equation in heterogeneous media. Our\napplications are motivated by elastic wave propagation in subsurface where the\nsubsurface properties can be highly heterogeneous and have high contrast. We\npresent the construction of main ingredients for GMsFEM such as the snapshot\nspace and offline spaces. The latter is constructed using local spectral\ndecomposition in the snapshot space. The spectral decomposition is based on the\nanalysis which is provided in the paper. We consider both continuous Galerkin\nand discontinuous Galerkin coupling of basis functions. Both approaches have\ntheir cons and pros. Continuous Galerkin methods allow avoiding penalty\nparameters though they involve partition of unity functions which can alter the\nproperties of multiscale basis functions. On the other hand, discontinuous\nGalerkin techniques allow gluing multiscale basis functions without any\nmodifications. Because basis functions are constructed independently from each\nother, this approach provides an advantage. We discuss the use of oversampling\ntechniques that use snapshots in larger regions to construct the offline space.\nWe provide numerical results to show that one can accurately approximate the\nsolution using reduced number of degrees of freedom.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we discuss the application of Generalized Multiscale Finite\nElement Method (GMsFEM) to elasticity equation in heterogeneous media. Our\napplications are motivated by elastic wave propagation in subsurface where the\nsubsurface properties can be highly heterogeneous and have high contrast. We\npresent the construction of main ingredients for GMsFEM such as the snapshot\nspace and offline spaces. The latter is constructed using local spectral\ndecomposition in the snapshot space. The spectral decomposition is based on the\nanalysis which is provided in the paper. We consider both continuous Galerkin\nand discontinuous Galerkin coupling of basis functions. Both approaches have\ntheir cons and pros. Continuous Galerkin methods allow avoiding penalty\nparameters though they involve partition of unity functions which can alter the\nproperties of multiscale basis functions. On the other hand, discontinuous\nGalerkin techniques allow gluing multiscale basis functions without any\nmodifications. Because basis functions are constructed independently from each\nother, this approach provides an advantage. We discuss the use of oversampling\ntechniques that use snapshots in larger regions to construct the offline space.\nWe provide numerical results to show that one can accurately approximate the\nsolution using reduced number of degrees of freedom."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Shubin Fu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Shubin Fu"}, "author": "Shubin Fu", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.5929v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1408.5929v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1605.07645v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1605.07645v1", "updated": "2016-05-24T20:15:40Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 5, 24, 20, 15, 40, 1, 145, 0], "published": "2016-05-24T20:15:40Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 5, 24, 20, 15, 40, 1, 145, 0], "title": "Online Adaptive Local Multiscale Model Reduction for Heterogeneous\n  Problems in Perforated Domains", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Online Adaptive Local Multiscale Model Reduction for Heterogeneous\n  Problems in Perforated Domains"}, "summary": "In this paper, we develop and analyze an adaptive multiscale approach for\nheterogeneous problems in perforated domains. In many applications, these\nproblems have a multiscale nature arising because of the perforations, their\ngeometries, the sizes of the perforations, and configurations. In this paper,\nwe present a general offline/online procedure, which can adequately and\nadaptively represent the local degrees of freedom and derive appropriate\ncoarse-grid equations. The main contributions of this paper are (1) the\nrigorous analysis of the offline approach (2) the development of the online\nprocedures and their analysis (3) the development of adaptive strategies. We\npresent an online procedure, which allows adaptively incorporating global\ninformation and is important for a fast convergence when combined with the\nadaptivity. Our methodology allows adding and guides constructing new online\nmultiscale basis functions adaptively in appropriate regions. We present the\nconvergence analysis of the online adaptive enrichment algorithm for the Stokes\nsystem. In particular, we show that the online procedure has a rapid\nconvergence with a rate related to the number of offline basis functions, and\none can obtain fast convergence by a sufficient number of offline basis\nfunctions, which are computed in the offline stage. To illustrate the\nperformance of our method, we present numerical results with both small and\nlarge perforations. We see that only a few (1 or 2) online iterations can\nsignificantly improve the offline solution.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we develop and analyze an adaptive multiscale approach for\nheterogeneous problems in perforated domains. In many applications, these\nproblems have a multiscale nature arising because of the perforations, their\ngeometries, the sizes of the perforations, and configurations. In this paper,\nwe present a general offline/online procedure, which can adequately and\nadaptively represent the local degrees of freedom and derive appropriate\ncoarse-grid equations. The main contributions of this paper are (1) the\nrigorous analysis of the offline approach (2) the development of the online\nprocedures and their analysis (3) the development of adaptive strategies. We\npresent an online procedure, which allows adaptively incorporating global\ninformation and is important for a fast convergence when combined with the\nadaptivity. Our methodology allows adding and guides constructing new online\nmultiscale basis functions adaptively in appropriate regions. We present the\nconvergence analysis of the online adaptive enrichment algorithm for the Stokes\nsystem. In particular, we show that the online procedure has a rapid\nconvergence with a rate related to the number of offline basis functions, and\none can obtain fast convergence by a sufficient number of offline basis\nfunctions, which are computed in the offline stage. To illustrate the\nperformance of our method, we present numerical results with both small and\nlarge perforations. We see that only a few (1 or 2) online iterations can\nsignificantly improve the offline solution."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, {"name": "Maria Vasilyeva"}, {"name": "Yating Wang"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Yating Wang"}, "author": "Yating Wang", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1605.07645v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1605.07645v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.5735v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.5735v1", "updated": "2013-01-24T09:45:52Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 1, 24, 9, 45, 52, 3, 24, 0], "published": "2013-01-24T09:45:52Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 1, 24, 9, 45, 52, 3, 24, 0], "title": "Mode Decomposition Methods for Flows in High-Contrast Porous Media. Part\n  I. Global Approach", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Mode Decomposition Methods for Flows in High-Contrast Porous Media. Part\n  I. Global Approach"}, "summary": "We apply dynamic mode decomposition (DMD) and proper orthogonal decomposition\n(POD) methods to flows in highly-heterogeneous porous media to extract the\ndominant coherent structures and derive reduced-order models via Galerkin\nprojection. Permeability fields with high contrast are considered to\ninvestigate the capability of these techniques to capture the main flow\nfeatures and forecast the flow evolution within a certain accuracy. A DMD-based\napproach shows a better predictive capability due to its ability to accurately\nextract the information relevant to long-time dynamics, in particular, the\nslowly-decaying eigenmodes corresponding to largest eigenvalues. Our study\nenables a better understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of the\napplicability of these techniques for flows in high-contrast porous media.\nFurthermore, we discuss the robustness of DMD- and POD-based reduced-order\nmodels with respect to variations in initial conditions, permeability fields,\nand forcing terms.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We apply dynamic mode decomposition (DMD) and proper orthogonal decomposition\n(POD) methods to flows in highly-heterogeneous porous media to extract the\ndominant coherent structures and derive reduced-order models via Galerkin\nprojection. Permeability fields with high contrast are considered to\ninvestigate the capability of these techniques to capture the main flow\nfeatures and forecast the flow evolution within a certain accuracy. A DMD-based\napproach shows a better predictive capability due to its ability to accurately\nextract the information relevant to long-time dynamics, in particular, the\nslowly-decaying eigenmodes corresponding to largest eigenvalues. Our study\nenables a better understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of the\napplicability of these techniques for flows in high-contrast porous media.\nFurthermore, we discuss the robustness of DMD- and POD-based reduced-order\nmodels with respect to variations in initial conditions, permeability fields,\nand forcing terms."}, "authors": [{"name": "Mehdi Ghommem"}, {"name": "Victor M. Part\n  II. Local-Global Approach", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Mode Decomposition Methods for Flows in High-Contrast Porous Media. Part\n  II. Local-Global Approach"}, "summary": "In this paper, we combine concepts of the generalized multiscale finite\nelement method and mode decomposition methods to construct a robust\nlocal-global approach for model reduction of flows in high-contrast porous\nmedia. This is achieved by implementing proper orthogonal decomposition (POD)\nand dynamic mode decomposition (DMD) techniques on a coarse grid. The resulting\nreduced-order approach enables a significant reduction in the flow problem size\nwhile accurately capturing the behavior of fully resolved solutions. We\nconsider a variety of high-contrast coefficients and present the corresponding\nnumerical results to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed technique.\nThis paper is a continuation of the first part where we examine the\napplicability of POD and DMD to derive simplified and reliable representations\nof flows in high-contrast porous media. In the current paper, we discuss how\nthese global model reduction approaches can be combined with local techniques\nto speed-up the simulations. The speed-up is due to inexpensive, while\nsufficiently accurate, computations of global snapshots.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we combine concepts of the generalized multiscale finite\nelement method and mode decomposition methods to construct a robust\nlocal-global approach for model reduction of flows in high-contrast porous\nmedia. This is achieved by implementing proper orthogonal decomposition (POD)\nand dynamic mode decomposition (DMD) techniques on a coarse grid. The resulting\nreduced-order approach enables a significant reduction in the flow problem size\nwhile accurately capturing the behavior of fully resolved solutions. We\nconsider a variety of high-contrast coefficients and present the corresponding\nnumerical results to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed technique.\nThis paper is a continuation of the first part where we examine the\napplicability of POD and DMD to derive simplified and reliable representations\nof flows in high-contrast porous media. In the current paper, we discuss how\nthese global model reduction approaches can be combined with local techniques\nto speed-up the simulations. The speed-up is due to inexpensive, while\nsufficiently accurate, computations of global snapshots."}, "authors": [{"name": "Mehdi Ghommem"}, {"name": "Michael Presho"}, {"name": "Victor M. Calo"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, "author": "Yalchin Efendiev", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.5742v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1301.5742v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.comp-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.comp-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "physics.flu-dyn", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1611.01213v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1611.01213v3", "updated": "2018-02-09T02:53:41Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 2, 9, 2, 53, 41, 4, 40, 0], "published": "2016-11-03T22:31:05Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 11, 3, 22, 31, 5, 3, 308, 0], "title": "Bayesian and Variational Bayesian approaches for flows in heterogenous\n  random media", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Bayesian and Variational Bayesian approaches for flows in heterogenous\n  random media"}, "summary": "In this paper, we study porous media flows in heterogeneous stochastic media.\nWe propose an efficient forward simulation technique that is tailored for\nvariational Bayesian inversion. As a starting point, the proposed forward\nsimulation technique decomposes the solution into the sum of separable\nfunctions (with respect to randomness and the space), where each term is\ncalculated based on a variational approach. This is similar to Proper\nGeneralized Decomposition (PGD). Next, we apply a multiscale technique to solve\nfor each term and, further, decompose the random function into 1D fields. As a\nresult, our proposed method provides an approximation hierarchy for the\nsolution as we increase the number of terms in the expansion and, also,\nincrease the spatial resolution of each term. We use the hierarchical solution\ndistributions in a variational Bayesian approximation to perform uncertainty\nquantification in the inverse problem. We conduct a detailed numerical study to\nexplore the performance of the proposed uncertainty quantification technique\nand show the theoretical posterior concentration.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we study porous media flows in heterogeneous stochastic media.\nWe propose an efficient forward simulation technique that is tailored for\nvariational Bayesian inversion. As a starting point, the proposed forward\nsimulation technique decomposes the solution into the sum of separable\nfunctions (with respect to randomness and the space), where each term is\ncalculated based on a variational approach. This is similar to Proper\nGeneralized Decomposition (PGD). Next, we apply a multiscale technique to solve\nfor each term and, further, decompose the random function into 1D fields. As a\nresult, our proposed method provides an approximation hierarchy for the\nsolution as we increase the number of terms in the expansion and, also,\nincrease the spatial resolution of each term. We use the hierarchical solution\ndistributions in a variational Bayesian approximation to perform uncertainty\nquantification in the inverse problem. We conduct a detailed numerical study to\nexplore the performance of the proposed uncertainty quantification technique\nand show the theoretical posterior concentration."}, "authors": [{"name": "Keren Yang"}, {"name": "Nilabja Guha"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Bani K. Based on the\na-posteriori error estimator, we develop an adaptive enrichment algorithm for\nour GMsDGM and prove its convergence. The adaptive enrichment algorithm gives\nan automatic way to enrich the approximation space in regions where the\nsolution requires more basis functions, which are shown to perform well\ncompared with a uniform enrichment. We also discuss an approach that adaptively\nselects multiscale basis functions by correlating the residual to multiscale\nbasis functions (cf. [4]). The proposed error indicators are L2-based and can\nbe inexpensively computed which makes our approach efficient. Numerical results\nare presented that demonstrate the robustness of the proposed error indicators.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we develop an adaptive Generalized Multiscale Discontinuous\nGalerkin Method (GMs-DGM) for a class of high-contrast flow problems, and\nderive a-priori and a-posteriori error estimates for the method. Based on the\na-posteriori error estimator, we develop an adaptive enrichment algorithm for\nour GMsDGM and prove its convergence. The adaptive enrichment algorithm gives\nan automatic way to enrich the approximation space in regions where the\nsolution requires more basis functions, which are shown to perform well\ncompared with a uniform enrichment. We also discuss an approach that adaptively\nselects multiscale basis functions by correlating the residual to multiscale\nbasis functions (cf. [4]). The proposed error indicators are L2-based and can\nbe inexpensively computed which makes our approach efficient. Numerical results\nare presented that demonstrate the robustness of the proposed error indicators."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wing Tat Leung"}, "author": "Wing Tat Leung", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.3474v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1409.3474v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.07095v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.07095v1", "updated": "2017-02-23T04:43:43Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 2, 23, 4, 43, 43, 3, 54, 0], "published": "2017-02-23T04:43:43Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 2, 23, 4, 43, 43, 3, 54, 0], "title": "Coupling of multiscale and multi-continuum approaches", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Coupling of multiscale and multi-continuum approaches"}, "summary": "Simulating complex processes in fractured media requires some type of model\nreduction. Well-known approaches include multi-continuum techniques, which have\nbeen commonly used in approximating subgrid effects for flow and transport in\nfractured media. Our goal in this paper is to (1) show a relation between\nmulti-continuum approaches and Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method\n(GMsFEM) and (2) to discuss coupling these approaches for solving problems in\ncomplex multiscale fractured media. The GMsFEM, a systematic approach,\nconstructs multiscale basis functions via local spectral decomposition in\npre-computed snapshot spaces. We show that GMsFEM can automatically identify\nseparate fracture networks via local spectral problems. We discuss the relation\nbetween these basis functions and continuums in multi-continuum methods. The\nGMsFEM can automatically detect each continuum and represent the interaction\nbetween the continuum and its surrounding (matrix). For problems with\nsimplified fracture networks, we propose a simplified basis construction with\nthe GMsFEM. This simplified approach is effective when the fracture networks\nare known and have simplified geometries. We show that this approach can\nachieve a similar result compared to the results using the GMsFEM with spectral\nbasis functions. Further, we discuss the coupling between the GMsFEM and\nmulti-continuum approaches. In this case, many fractures are resolved while for\nunresolved fractures, we use a multi-continuum approach with local\nRepresentative Volume Element (RVE) information. As a result, the method deals\nwith a system of equations on a coarse grid, where each equation represents one\nof the continua on the fine grid. We present various basis construction\nmechanisms and numerical results.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Simulating complex processes in fractured media requires some type of model\nreduction. Well-known approaches include multi-continuum techniques, which have\nbeen commonly used in approximating subgrid effects for flow and transport in\nfractured media. Our goal in this paper is to (1) show a relation between\nmulti-continuum approaches and Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Method\n(GMsFEM) and (2) to discuss coupling these approaches for solving problems in\ncomplex multiscale fractured media. The GMsFEM, a systematic approach,\nconstructs multiscale basis functions via local spectral decomposition in\npre-computed snapshot spaces. We show that GMsFEM can automatically identify\nseparate fracture networks via local spectral problems. We discuss the relation\nbetween these basis functions and continuums in multi-continuum methods. The\nGMsFEM can automatically detect each continuum and represent the interaction\nbetween the continuum and its surrounding (matrix). For problems with\nsimplified fracture networks, we propose a simplified basis construction with\nthe GMsFEM. This simplified approach is effective when the fracture networks\nare known and have simplified geometries. We show that this approach can\nachieve a similar result compared to the results using the GMsFEM with spectral\nbasis functions. Further, we discuss the coupling between the GMsFEM and\nmulti-continuum approaches. In this case, many fractures are resolved while for\nunresolved fractures, we use a multi-continuum approach with local\nRepresentative Volume Element (RVE) information. As a result, the method deals\nwith a system of equations on a coarse grid, where each equation represents one\nof the continua on the fine grid. We present various basis construction\nmechanisms and numerical results."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. Part\n  I. Global Approach", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Mode Decomposition Methods for Flows in High-Contrast Porous Media. Part\n  I. Global Approach"}, "summary": "We apply dynamic mode decomposition (DMD) and proper orthogonal decomposition\n(POD) methods to flows in highly-heterogeneous porous media to extract the\ndominant coherent structures and derive reduced-order models via Galerkin\nprojection. Permeability fields with high contrast are considered to\ninvestigate the capability of these techniques to capture the main flow\nfeatures and forecast the flow evolution within a certain accuracy. A DMD-based\napproach shows a better predictive capability due to its ability to accurately\nextract the information relevant to long-time dynamics, in particular, the\nslowly-decaying eigenmodes corresponding to largest eigenvalues. Our study\nenables a better understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of the\napplicability of these techniques for flows in high-contrast porous media.\nFurthermore, we discuss the robustness of DMD- and POD-based reduced-order\nmodels with respect to variations in initial conditions, permeability fields,\nand forcing terms.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We apply dynamic mode decomposition (DMD) and proper orthogonal decomposition\n(POD) methods to flows in highly-heterogeneous porous media to extract the\ndominant coherent structures and derive reduced-order models via Galerkin\nprojection. Permeability fields with high contrast are considered to\ninvestigate the capability of these techniques to capture the main flow\nfeatures and forecast the flow evolution within a certain accuracy. A DMD-based\napproach shows a better predictive capability due to its ability to accurately\nextract the information relevant to long-time dynamics, in particular, the\nslowly-decaying eigenmodes corresponding to largest eigenvalues. Our study\nenables a better understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of the\napplicability of these techniques for flows in high-contrast porous media.\nFurthermore, we discuss the robustness of DMD- and POD-based reduced-order\nmodels with respect to variations in initial conditions, permeability fields,\nand forcing terms."}, "authors": [{"name": "Mehdi Ghommem"}, {"name": "Victor M. Local-Global Approach"}, "summary": "In this paper, we combine concepts of the generalized multiscale finite\nelement method and mode decomposition methods to construct a robust\nlocal-global approach for model reduction of flows in high-contrast porous\nmedia. This is achieved by implementing proper orthogonal decomposition (POD)\nand dynamic mode decomposition (DMD) techniques on a coarse grid. The resulting\nreduced-order approach enables a significant reduction in the flow problem size\nwhile accurately capturing the behavior of fully resolved solutions. We\nconsider a variety of high-contrast coefficients and present the corresponding\nnumerical results to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed technique.\nThis paper is a continuation of the first part where we examine the\napplicability of POD and DMD to derive simplified and reliable representations\nof flows in high-contrast porous media. Part I.\n  Polynomial and homogenization-based multiscale spaces"}, "summary": "We introduce a finite element method for numerical upscaling of second order\nelliptic equations with highly heterogeneous coefficients. The method is based\non a mixed formulation of the problem and the concepts of the domain\ndecomposition and the hybrid discontinuous Galerkin methods. The method\nutilizes three different scales: (1) the scale of the partition of the domain\nof the problem, (2) the sale of partition of the boundaries of the subdomains\n(related to the corresponding space of Lagrange multipliers), and (3) the fine\ngrid scale that is assumed to resolve the scale of the heterogeneous variation\nof the coefficients. Our proposed method gives a flexible framework that (1)\ncouples independently generated multiscale basis functions in each coarse patch\n(2) provides a stable global coupling independent of local discretization,\nphysical scales and contrast (3) allows avoiding any constraints on coarse\nspaces. In this paper, we develop and study a multiscale HDG method that uses\npolynomial and homogenization-based multiscale spaces. These coarse spaces are\ndesigned for problems with scale separation. The method is based\non a mixed formulation of the problem and the concepts of the domain\ndecomposition and the hybrid discontinuous Galerkin methods. The method\nutilizes three different scales: (1) the scale of the partition of the domain\nof the problem, (2) the sale of partition of the boundaries of the subdomains\n(related to the corresponding space of Lagrange multipliers), and (3) the fine\ngrid scale that is assumed to resolve the scale of the heterogeneous variation\nof the coefficients. Our proposed method gives a flexible framework that (1)\ncouples independently generated multiscale basis functions in each coarse patch\n(2) provides a stable global coupling independent of local discretization,\nphysical scales and contrast (3) allows avoiding any constraints on coarse\nspaces. In this paper, we develop and study a multiscale HDG method that uses\npolynomial and homogenization-based multiscale spaces. These coarse spaces are\ndesigned for problems with scale separation.
