The background conductivity is taken to be one and we\nassume the medium contains high (or low) conductivity inclusions. We derive an\nasymptotic expansion with respect to the contrast and provide a procedure to\ncompute the terms in the expansion. The computation of the expansion does not\ndepend on the contrast which is important for simulations. The latter allows\navoiding increased mesh resolution around high conductivity features. This work\nis partly motivated by our earlier work in \\cite{ge09_1} where we design\nefficient numerical procedures for solving high-contrast problems. These\nmultiscale approaches require local solutions and our proposed high-order\nexpansion can be used to approximate these local solutions inexpensively. In\nthe case of a large-number of inclusions, the proposed analysis can help to\ndesign localization techniques for computing the terms in the expansion. In the\npaper, we present a rigorous analysis of the proposed high-order expansion and\nestimate the remainder of it. We consider both high and low conductivity\ninclusions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we present a high-order expansion for elliptic equations in\nhigh-contrast media. The background conductivity is taken to be one and we\nassume the medium contains high (or low) conductivity inclusions. We derive an\nasymptotic expansion with respect to the contrast and provide a procedure to\ncompute the terms in the expansion. The computation of the expansion does not\ndepend on the contrast which is important for simulations. The latter allows\navoiding increased mesh resolution around high conductivity features. This work\nis partly motivated by our earlier work in \\cite{ge09_1} where we design\nefficient numerical procedures for solving high-contrast problems. These\nmultiscale approaches require local solutions and our proposed high-order\nexpansion can be used to approximate these local solutions inexpensively. In\nthe case of a large-number of inclusions, the proposed analysis can help to\ndesign localization techniques for computing the terms in the expansion. In the\npaper, we present a rigorous analysis of the proposed high-order expansion and\nestimate the remainder of it. We consider both high and low conductivity\ninclusions."}, "authors": [{"name": "Victor M. We give a brief overview of related\nmultiscale methods. Due to page limitations, the overview focuses on a few\nrelated methods and is not intended to be comprehensive. We present a general\nadaptive multiscale model reduction framework, the Generalized Multiscale\nFinite Element Method. Besides the method's basic outline, we discuss some\nimportant ingredients needed for the method's success. We also discuss several\napplications. The proposed method allows performing local model reduction in\nthe presence of high contrast and no scale separation."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric Chung"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Thomas Y. Hou"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Thomas Y. Hou"}, "author": "Thomas Y. Hou", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jcp.2016.04.054", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2016.04.054", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1604.08312v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1604.08312v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.0103v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.0103v1", "updated": "2014-07-01T05:07:44Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 7, 1, 5, 7, 44, 1, 182, 0], "published": "2014-07-01T05:07:44Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 7, 1, 5, 7, 44, 1, 182, 0], "title": "Multiscale Empirical Interpolation for Solving Nonlinear PDEs using\n  Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Methods", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Multiscale Empirical Interpolation for Solving Nonlinear PDEs using\n  Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Methods"}, "summary": "In this paper, we propose a multiscale empirical interpolation\n  method for solving nonlinear multiscale partial differential\n  equations. The proposed method combines empirical interpolation\n  techniques and local multiscale methods, such as the Generalized\n  Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM). To solve nonlinear\n  equations, the GMsFEM is used to represent the solution on a coarse\n  grid with multiscale basis functions computed offline. Computing\n  the GMsFEM solution involves calculating the residuals on the fine\n  grid. We use empirical interpolation concepts to evaluate the\n  residuals and the Jacobians of the multiscale system with a\n  computational cost which is proportional to the coarse scale problem\n  rather than the fully-resolved fine scale one. Empirical\n  interpolation methods use basis functions and an inexpensive\n  inversion which are computed in the offline stage for finding the\n  coefficients in the expansion based on a limited number of nonlinear\n  function evaluations. The proposed multiscale empirical\n  interpolation techniques: (1) divide computing the nonlinear\n  function into coarse regions; (2) evaluate contributions of\n  nonlinear functions in each coarse region taking advantage of a\n  reduced-order representation of the solution; and (3) introduce\n  multiscale proper-orthogonal-decomposition techniques to find\n  appropriate interpolation vectors. We demonstrate the effectiveness\n  of the proposed methods on several examples of nonlinear multiscale\n  PDEs that are solved with Newton's methods and fully-implicit time\n  marching schemes. Our numerical results show that the proposed\n  methods provide a robust framework for solving nonlinear multiscale\n  PDEs on a coarse grid with bounded error.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we propose a multiscale empirical interpolation\n  method for solving nonlinear multiscale partial differential\n  equations. The proposed method combines empirical interpolation\n  techniques and local multiscale methods, such as the Generalized\n  Multiscale Finite Element Method (GMsFEM). To solve nonlinear\n  equations, the GMsFEM is used to represent the solution on a coarse\n  grid with multiscale basis functions computed offline. Computing\n  the GMsFEM solution involves calculating the residuals on the fine\n  grid. We use empirical interpolation concepts to evaluate the\n  residuals and the Jacobians of the multiscale system with a\n  computational cost which is proportional to the coarse scale problem\n  rather than the fully-resolved fine scale one. Empirical\n  interpolation methods use basis functions and an inexpensive\n  inversion which are computed in the offline stage for finding the\n  coefficients in the expansion based on a limited number of nonlinear\n  function evaluations. The proposed multiscale empirical\n  interpolation techniques: (1) divide computing the nonlinear\n  function into coarse regions; (2) evaluate contributions of\n  nonlinear functions in each coarse region taking advantage of a\n  reduced-order representation of the solution; and (3) introduce\n  multiscale proper-orthogonal-decomposition techniques to find\n  appropriate interpolation vectors. We demonstrate the effectiveness\n  of the proposed methods on several examples of nonlinear multiscale\n  PDEs that are solved with Newton's methods and fully-implicit time\n  marching schemes. Our numerical results show that the proposed\n  methods provide a robust framework for solving nonlinear multiscale\n  PDEs on a coarse grid with bounded error."}, "authors": [{"name": "Victor Calo"}, {"name": "Yalchin Efendiev"}, {"name": "Juan Galvis"}, {"name": "Mehdi Ghommem"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Mehdi Ghommem"}, "author": "Mehdi Ghommem", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.0103v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1407.0103v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1406.0950v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1406.0950v1", "updated": "2014-06-04T06:47:50Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 6, 4, 6, 47, 50, 2, 155, 0], "published": "2014-06-04T06:47:50Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 6, 4, 6, 47, 50, 2, 155, 0], "title": "Mixed Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Methods and Applications", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Mixed Generalized Multiscale Finite Element Methods and Applications"}, "summary": "In this paper, we present a mixed Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\nMethod (GMsFEM) for solving flow in heterogeneous media. Our approach\nconstructs multiscale basis functions following a GMsFEM framework and couples\nthese basis functions using a mixed finite element method, which allows us to\nobtain a mass conservative velocity field. To construct multiscale basis\nfunctions for each coarse edge, we design a snapshot space that consists of\nfine-scale velocity fields supported in a union of two coarse regions that\nshare the common interface. The snapshot vectors have zero Neumann boundary\nconditions on the outer boundaries and we prescribe their values on the common\ninterface. We describe several spectral decompositions in the snapshot space\nmotivated by the analysis. In the paper, we also study oversampling approaches\nthat enhance the accuracy of mixed GMsFEM. A main idea of oversampling\ntechniques is to introduce a small dimensional snapshot space. We present\nnumerical results for two-phase flow and transport, without updating basis\nfunctions in time. Our numerical results show that one can achieve good\naccuracy with a few basis functions per coarse edge if one selects appropriate\noffline spaces.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we present a mixed Generalized Multiscale Finite Element\nMethod (GMsFEM) for solving flow in heterogeneous media. Our approach\nconstructs multiscale basis functions following a GMsFEM framework and couples\nthese basis functions using a mixed finite element method, which allows us to\nobtain a mass conservative velocity field. To construct multiscale basis\nfunctions for each coarse edge, we design a snapshot space that consists of\nfine-scale velocity fields supported in a union of two coarse regions that\nshare the common interface. The snapshot vectors have zero Neumann boundary\nconditions on the outer boundaries and we prescribe their values on the common\ninterface. We describe several spectral decompositions in the snapshot space\nmotivated by the analysis. In the paper, we also study oversampling approaches\nthat enhance the accuracy of mixed GMsFEM. A main idea of oversampling\ntechniques is to introduce a small dimensional snapshot space. We present\nnumerical results for two-phase flow and transport, without updating basis\nfunctions in time. Our numerical results show that one can achieve good\naccuracy with a few basis functions per coarse edge if one selects appropriate\noffline spaces."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric T. The sheet has\nan arbitrary, physically admissible, tensor valued and spatially homogeneous\nconductivity, and serves as a model for a family of two-dimensional conducting\nmaterials. We formulate a system of integral equations for the electric field\ntangential to the sheet in a homogeneous and isotropic ambient medium. We show\nhow this system is simplified via a length scale separation. This view entails\nthe quasi-electrostatic approximation, by which the tangential electric field\nis replaced by the gradient of a scalar potential, $\\varphi$. By the\nWiener-Hopf method, we solve an integral equation for $\\varphi$ in some\ngenerality. The EPP dispersion relation comes from the elimination of a\ndivergent limiting Fourier integral for $\\varphi$ at the edge. We connect the\nexistence, or lack thereof, of the EPP dispersion relation to the index for\nWiener-Hopf integral equations, an integer of topological character. We\nindicate that the values of this index may express an asymmetry due to the\nmaterial anisotropy in the number of wave modes propagating on the sheet away\nfrom the edge with respect to the EPP direction of propagation. We discuss\nextensions such as the setting of two semi-infinite, coplanar sheets. Our\ntheory forms a generalization of the treatment by Volkov and Mikhailov (1988\nSov. Phys. JETP 67 1639).", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "By an integral equation approach to the time-harmonic classical Maxwell\nequations, we describe the dispersion in the nonretarded frequency regime of\nthe edge plasmon-polariton (EPP) on a semi-infinite flat sheet. The sheet has\nan arbitrary, physically admissible, tensor valued and spatially homogeneous\nconductivity, and serves as a model for a family of two-dimensional conducting\nmaterials. We formulate a system of integral equations for the electric field\ntangential to the sheet in a homogeneous and isotropic ambient medium. We show\nhow this system is simplified via a length scale separation. This view entails\nthe quasi-electrostatic approximation, by which the tangential electric field\nis replaced by the gradient of a scalar potential, $\\varphi$. By the\nWiener-Hopf method, we solve an integral equation for $\\varphi$ in some\ngenerality. The EPP dispersion relation comes from the elimination of a\ndivergent limiting Fourier integral for $\\varphi$ at the edge. We connect the\nexistence, or lack thereof, of the EPP dispersion relation to the index for\nWiener-Hopf integral equations, an integer of topological character. We\nindicate that the values of this index may express an asymmetry due to the\nmaterial anisotropy in the number of wave modes propagating on the sheet away\nfrom the edge with respect to the EPP direction of propagation. This structure is motivated by the need to design\nplasmonic crystals that enable the propagation of electromagnetic waves with no\nphase delay (epsilon-near-zero effect). Our microscopic model incorporates the\nsurface conductivity of the two-dimensional (2D) material of each sheet and a\ncorresponding line charge density through a line conductivity along possible\nedges of the sheets. Our analysis generalizes averaging principles inherent in\nprevious Bloch-wave approaches. We investigate physical implications of our\nfindings. In particular, we emphasize the role of the vector-valued corrector\nfield, which expresses microscopic modes of surface waves on the 2D material.\nWe demonstrate how our homogenization procedure may set the foundation for\ncomputational investigations of: effective optical responses of reasonably\ngeneral geometries, and complicated design problems in the plasmonics of 2D\nmaterials.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "By using an asymptotic analysis and numerical simulations, we derive and\ninvestigate a system of homogenized Maxwell's equations for conducting material\nsheets that are periodically arranged and embedded in a heterogeneous and\nanisotropic dielectric host. This structure is motivated by the need to design\nplasmonic crystals that enable the propagation of electromagnetic waves with no\nphase delay (epsilon-near-zero effect). Our microscopic model incorporates the\nsurface conductivity of the two-dimensional (2D) material of each sheet and a\ncorresponding line charge density through a line conductivity along possible\nedges of the sheets. Our analysis generalizes averaging principles inherent in\nprevious Bloch-wave approaches. We investigate physical implications of our\nfindings. In particular, we emphasize the role of the vector-valued corrector\nfield, which expresses microscopic modes of surface waves on the 2D material.\nWe demonstrate how our homogenization procedure may set the foundation for\ncomputational investigations of: effective optical responses of reasonably\ngeneral geometries, and complicated design problems in the plasmonics of 2D\nmaterials."}, of a slowly\ndecaying electromagnetic wave, called surface plasmon-polariton (SPP), of small\nwavelength on a semi-infinite, flat conducting sheet irradiated by a plane wave\nin two spatial This setting is germane to wave diffraction by edges\nof large sheets of single-layer graphene. This setting is germane to wave diffraction by edges\nof large sheets of single-layer graphene. Our analytical approach includes: (i)\nformulation of a functional equation in the Fourier domain; (ii) evaluation of\na split function, which is expressed by a contour integral and is a key\ningredient of the Wiener-Hopf factorization; and (iii) extraction of the SPP as\na simple-pole residue of a Fourier integral. Our analytical solution is in good\nagreement with a finite-element numerical computation."}, "authors": [{"name": "Dionisios Margetis"}, {"name": "Matthias Maier"}, {"name": "Mitchell Luskin"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Mitchell Luskin"}, "author": "Mitchell Luskin", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1701.02784v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1701.02784v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35Q61, 45E10, 45K05", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1611.09437v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1611.09437v2", "updated": "2017-12-01T15:28:28Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 12, 1, 15, 28, 28, 4, 335, 0], "published": "2016-11-28T23:56:50Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 11, 28, 23, 56, 50, 0, 333, 0], "title": "A duality-based optimization approach for model adaptivity in\n  heterogeneous multiscale problems", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A duality-based optimization approach for model adaptivity in\n  heterogeneous multiscale problems"}, "summary": "This paper introduces a novel framework for model adaptivity in the context\nof heterogeneous multiscale problems. The framework is based on the idea to\ninterpret model adaptivity as a minimization problem of local error indicators,\nthat are derived in the general context of the Dual Weighted Residual (DWR)\nmethod. Based on the optimization approach a post-processing strategy is\nformulated that lifts the requirement of strict a priori knowledge about\napplicability and quality of effective models. This allows for the systematic,\n\"goal-oriented\" tuning of effective models with respect to a quantity of\ninterest.\n  The framework is tested numerically on elliptic diffusion problems with\ndifferent types of heterogeneous, random coefficients, as well as an\nadvection-diffusion problem with strong microscopic, random advection field.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper introduces a novel framework for model adaptivity in the context\nof heterogeneous multiscale problems. The solver is based on the\nconvex limiting technique introduced by Guermond et al. (SIAM J. Sci. Comput.\n40, A3211-A3239, 2018). As such it is invariant-domain preserving, i.e., the\nsolver maintains important physical invariants and is guaranteed to be stable\nwithout the use of ad-hoc tuning parameters. This stability comes at the\nexpense of a significantly more involved algorithmic structure that renders\nconventional high-performance discretizations challenging. We develop an\nalgorithmic design that allows SIMD vectorization of the compute kernel,\nidentify the main ingredients for a good node-level performance, and report\nexcellent weak and strong scaling of a hybrid thread/MPI parallelization.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We discuss the efficient implementation of a high-performance second-order\ncollocation-type finite-element scheme for solving the compressible Euler\nequations of gas dynamics on unstructured meshes. The solver is based on the\nconvex limiting technique introduced by Guermond et al. (SIAM J. Sci. Comput.\n40, A3211-A3239, 2018). As such it is invariant-domain preserving, i.e., the\nsolver maintains important physical invariants and is guaranteed to be stable\nwithout the use of ad-hoc tuning parameters. This stability comes at the\nexpense of a significantly more involved algorithmic structure that renders\nconventional high-performance discretizations challenging. We develop an\nalgorithmic design that allows SIMD vectorization of the compute kernel,\nidentify the main ingredients for a good node-level performance, and report\nexcellent weak and strong scaling of a hybrid thread/MPI parallelization."}, "authors": [{"name": "Matthias Maier"}, {"name": "Martin Kronbichler"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Martin Kronbichler"}, "author": "Martin Kronbichler", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.00094v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2007.00094v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "cs.MS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "cs.MS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2003.06531v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2003.06531v2", "updated": "2020-09-22T20:44:13Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 9, 22, 20, 44, 13, 1, 266, 0], "published": "2020-03-14T01:36:52Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 3, 14, 1, 36, 52, 5, 74, 0], "title": "Nonlinear eigenvalue problems for coupled Helmholtz equations modeling\n  gradient-index graphene waveguides", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Nonlinear eigenvalue problems for coupled Helmholtz equations modeling\n  gradient-index graphene waveguides"}, "summary": "We discuss a quartic eigenvalue problem arising in the context of an optical\nwaveguiding problem involving atomically thick 2D materials. The waveguide\nconfiguration we consider consists of a gradient-index (spatially dependent)\ndielectric equipped with conducting interior interfaces. This leads to a\nquartic eigenvalue problem with mixed transverse electric and transverse\nmagnetic modes, and strongly coupled electric and magnetic fields. We derive a\nweak formulation of the quartic eigenvalue problem and introduce a numerical\nsolver based on a quadratification approach in which the quartic eigenvalue\nproblem is transformed to a spectrally equivalent companion problem. We verify\nour numerical framework against analytical solutions for prototypical\ngeometries. As a practical example, we demonstrate how an improved quality\nfactor (defined by the ratio of the real and the imaginary part of the computed\neigenvalues) can be obtained for a family of gradient-index host materials with\ninternal conducting interfaces. We outline how this result lays the groundwork\nfor solving related shape optimization problems.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We discuss a quartic eigenvalue problem arising in the context of an optical\nwaveguiding problem involving atomically thick 2D materials. The waveguide\nconfiguration we consider consists of a gradient-index (spatially dependent)\ndielectric equipped with conducting interior interfaces. This leads to a\nquartic eigenvalue problem with mixed transverse electric and transverse\nmagnetic modes, and strongly coupled electric and magnetic fields. We derive a\nweak formulation of the quartic eigenvalue problem and introduce a numerical\nsolver based on a quadratification approach in which the quartic eigenvalue\nproblem is transformed to a spectrally equivalent companion problem. We verify\nour numerical framework against analytical solutions for prototypical\ngeometries. As a practical example, we demonstrate how an improved quality\nfactor (defined by the ratio of the real and the imaginary part of the computed\neigenvalues) can be obtained for a family of gradient-index host materials with\ninternal conducting interfaces. We outline how this result lays the groundwork\nfor solving related shape optimization problems."}, "authors": [{"name": "Jung Heon Song"}, {"name": "Matthias Maier"}, {"name": "Mitchell Luskin"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Mitchell Luskin"}, "author": "Mitchell Luskin", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2003.06531v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2003.06531v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.comp-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.comp-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65N30, 78M10, 78M30, 35P30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.06022v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.06022v2", "updated": "2020-11-23T21:05:31Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 11, 23, 21, 5, 31, 0, 328, 0], "published": "2020-09-13T15:27:54Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 9, 13, 15, 27, 54, 6, 257, 0], "title": "Second-order invariant domain preserving approximation of the\n  compressible Navier--Stokes equations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Second-order invariant domain preserving approximation of the\n  compressible Navier--Stokes equations"}, "summary": "We present a fully discrete approximation technique for the compressible\nNavier-Stokes equations that is second-order accurate in time and space,\nsemi-implicit, and guaranteed to be invariant domain preserving. By using a suitably rescaled form of time-harmonic Maxwell's\nequations, we derive a variational formulation that enables a direct numerical\ntreatment of the associated class of boundary value problems by appropriate\ncurl-conforming finite elements. The conducting sheet is modeled as an\nidealized hypersurface with an effective electric conductivity. The requisite\nweak discontinuity for the tangential magnetic field across the hypersurface\ncan be incorporated naturally into the variational formulation. We carry out\nnumerical simulations for an infinite sheet with constant isotropic\nconductivity embedded in two spatial dimensions; and validate our numerics\nagainst the closed-form exact solution obtained by the Fourier transform in the\ntangential coordinate. Numerical aspects of our treatment such as an absorbing\nperfectly matched layer, as well as local refinement and a-posteriori error\ncontrol are discussed.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We formulate and validate a finite element approach to the propagation of a\nslowly decaying electromagnetic wave, called surface plasmon-polariton, excited\nalong a conducting sheet, e.g., a single-layer graphene sheet, by an electric\nHertzian dipole. By using a suitably rescaled form of time-harmonic Maxwell's\nequations, we derive a variational formulation that enables a direct numerical\ntreatment of the associated class of boundary value problems by appropriate\ncurl-conforming finite elements. The conducting sheet is modeled as an\nidealized hypersurface with an effective electric conductivity. The requisite\nweak discontinuity for the tangential magnetic field across the hypersurface\ncan be incorporated naturally into the variational formulation. These consist of a finite number\nof stacked metallic sheets embedded in dielectric hosts with a subwavelength\nspacing. By adjustment of the frequency, spacing, number as well as geometry of\nthe layers, these structures may exhibit appealing transmission properties in a\nrange of frequencies from the terahertz to the mid-infrared regime. Our\napproach uses a blend of analytical and numerical methods for the distinct\ngeometries with infinite, translation invariant, flat sheets and nanoribbons.\nWe describe the transmission of plane waves through a plasmonic crystal in\ncomparison to an effective dielectric slab of equal total thickness that\nemerges from homogenization, in the limit of zero interlayer spacing. We\ndemonstrate numerically that the replacement of the discrete plasmonic crystal\nby its homogenized counterpart can accurately capture a transmission\ncoefficient akin to the extinction spectrum, even for a relatively small number\nof layers. These consist of a finite number\nof stacked metallic sheets embedded in dielectric hosts with a subwavelength\nspacing. By adjustment of the frequency, spacing, number as well as geometry of\nthe layers, these structures may exhibit appealing transmission properties in a\nrange of frequencies from the terahertz to the mid-infrared regime. Our\napproach uses a blend of analytical and numerical methods for the distinct\ngeometries with infinite, translation invariant, flat sheets and nanoribbons.\nWe describe the transmission of plane waves through a plasmonic crystal in\ncomparison to an effective dielectric slab of equal total thickness that\nemerges from homogenization, in the limit of zero interlayer spacing. We\ndemonstrate numerically that the replacement of the discrete plasmonic crystal\nby its homogenized counterpart can accurately capture a transmission\ncoefficient akin to the extinction spectrum, even for a relatively small number\nof layers. We point out the role of a geometry-dependent corrector field, which\nexpresses the effect of subwavelength surface plasmons. We construct an adaptive\nfinite-element method to compute the ratio of energy transmitted within these\nwaveguide structures reliably and efficiently. The\nmethod is second-order accurate in time and space. One example of\nsuch plasmonic crystals are graphene nanosheets that are periodically arranged\nwithin a non-magnetic bulk dielectric. We identify local geometric resonances\non the length scale of the small scale period. From a materials perspective,\nthe graphene surface exhibits a dispersive surface conductance captured by the\nDrude model. Together these phenomena conspire to generate Lorentz resonances\nat frequencies controlled by the surface geometry and the surface conductance.\nThe Lorentz resonances found in the frequency response of the effective\ndielectric tensor of the bulk metamaterial is shown to be given by an explicit\nformula, in which material properties and geometric resonances are decoupled.\nThis formula is rigorous and obtained directly from corrector fields describing\nlocal electrostatic fields inside the heterogeneous structure. Our analytical\nfindings can serve as an efficient computational tool to describe the general\nfrequency dependence of periodic optical devices. As a concrete example, we\ninvestigate two prototypical geometries composed of nanotubes and nanoribbons.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We explain the Lorentz resonances in plasmonic crystals that consist of 2D\nnano dielectric inclusions as the interaction between resonant material\nproperties and geometric resonances of electrostatic nature. One example of\nsuch plasmonic crystals are graphene nanosheets that are periodically arranged\nwithin a non-magnetic bulk dielectric. We identify local geometric resonances\non the length scale of the small scale period. From a materials perspective,\nthe graphene surface exhibits a dispersive surface conductance captured by the\nDrude model. Together these phenomena conspire to generate Lorentz resonances\nat frequencies controlled by the surface geometry and the surface conductance.\nThe Lorentz resonances found in the frequency response of the effective\ndielectric tensor of the bulk metamaterial is shown to be given by an explicit\nformula, in which material properties and geometric resonances are decoupled.\nThis formula is rigorous and obtained directly from corrector fields describing\nlocal electrostatic fields inside the heterogeneous structure. Our analytical\nfindings can serve as an efficient computational tool to describe the general\nfrequency dependence of periodic optical devices. As a concrete example, we\ninvestigate two prototypical geometries composed of nanotubes and nanoribbons."}, "authors": [{"name": "Wei Li"}, {"name": "Robert Lipton"}, {"name": "Matthias Maier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Matthias Maier"}, "author": "Matthias Maier", "arxiv_doi": "10.1098/rspa.2021.0609", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rspa.2021.0609", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.12166v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2009.12166v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.optics", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.optics", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.00848v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.00848v1", "updated": "2017-02-02T22:16:44Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 2, 2, 22, 16, 44, 3, 33, 0], "published": "2017-02-02T22:16:44Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 2, 2, 22, 16, 44, 3, 33, 0], "title": "Generation of surface plasmon-polaritons by edge effects", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Generation of surface plasmon-polaritons by edge effects"}, "summary": "By using numerical and analytical methods, we describe the generation of\nfine-scale lateral electromagnetic waves, called surface plasmon-polaritons\n(SPPs), on atomically thick, metamaterial conducting sheets in two spatial\ndimensions (2D). Our computations capture the two-scale character of the total\nfield and reveal how each edge of the sheet acts as a source of an SPP that may\ndominate the diffracted field. We use the finite element method to numerically\nimplement a variational formulation for a weak discontinuity of the tangential\nmagnetic field across a hypersurface. An adaptive, local mesh refinement\nstrategy based on a posteriori error estimators is applied to resolve the\npronounced two-scale character of wave propagation and radiation over the\nmetamaterial sheet. We demonstrate by numerical examples how a singular\ngeometry, e.g., sheets with sharp edges, and sharp spatial changes in the\nassociated surface conductivity may significantly influence surface plasmons in\nnanophotonics.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "By using numerical and analytical methods, we describe the generation of\nfine-scale lateral electromagnetic waves, called surface plasmon-polaritons\n(SPPs), on atomically thick, metamaterial conducting sheets in two spatial\ndimensions (2D). Our computations capture the two-scale character of the total\nfield and reveal how each edge of the sheet acts as a source of an SPP that may\ndominate the diffracted field. We use the finite element method to numerically\nimplement a variational formulation for a weak discontinuity of the tangential\nmagnetic field across a hypersurface. An adaptive, local mesh refinement\nstrategy based on a posteriori error estimators is applied to resolve the\npronounced two-scale character of wave propagation and radiation over the\nmetamaterial sheet. We demonstrate by numerical examples how a singular\ngeometry, e.g., sheets with sharp edges, and sharp spatial changes in the\nassociated surface conductivity may significantly influence surface plasmons in\nnanophotonics."}, "authors": [{"name": "Matthias Maier"}, {"name": "Dionisios Margetis"}, {"name": "Mitchell Luskin"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Mitchell Luskin"}, "author": "Mitchell Luskin", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.00848v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1702.00848v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.comp-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.comp-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65N30, 78M10, 78M30, 78A45", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1709.06626v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1709.06626v2", "updated": "2017-11-13T15:58:01Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 11, 13, 15, 58, 1, 0, 317, 0], "published": "2017-09-19T19:57:25Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 9, 19, 19, 57, 25, 1, 262, 0], "title": "Ultracompact amplitude modulator by coupling hyperbolic polaritons over\n  a graphene-covered gap", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Ultracompact amplitude modulator by coupling hyperbolic polaritons over\n  a graphene-covered gap"}, "summary": "The hyperbolic phonon-polaritons within the Reststrahlen band of hBN are of\ngreat interest for applications in nanophotonics as they are capable of\npropagating light signals with low losses over large distances. However, due to\nthe phononic nature of the polaritons in hBN, amplitude modulation of its\nsignal proves to be difficult and has been underexplored. In this paper, we\npropose theoretically a broadband efficient amplitude modulator for hyperbolic\nrays in hBN operating in the frequency range between 1450 cm$^{-1}$ and 1550\ncm$^{-1}$. The modulating region comprises a few tens of nanometers wide gap\ncarved within the hBN slab and covered by a graphene layer, where\nelectrostatically gated graphene serves as a mediator that facilitates the\ncoupling between phonon-polaritons on each side of the gap through plasmonic\nmodes within graphene. We demonstrate that such an ultra compact modulator has\ninsertion losses as low as 3 dB and provides modulation depth varying between\n14 and 20 dB within the type-II hyperbolicity region of hBN.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The hyperbolic phonon-polaritons within the Reststrahlen band of hBN are of\ngreat interest for applications in nanophotonics as they are capable of\npropagating light signals with low losses over large distances. However, due to\nthe phononic nature of the polaritons in hBN, amplitude modulation of its\nsignal proves to be difficult and has been underexplored. In this paper, we\npropose theoretically a broadband efficient amplitude modulator for hyperbolic\nrays in hBN operating in the frequency range between 1450 cm$^{-1}$ and 1550\ncm$^{-1}$. The modulating region comprises a few tens of nanometers wide gap\ncarved within the hBN slab and covered by a graphene layer, where\nelectrostatically gated graphene serves as a mediator that facilitates the\ncoupling between phonon-polaritons on each side of the gap through plasmonic\nmodes within graphene. One example of\nsuch plasmonic crystals are graphene nanosheets that are periodically arranged\nwithin a non-magnetic bulk dielectric. We identify local geometric resonances\non the length scale of the small scale period. From a materials perspective,\nthe graphene surface exhibits a dispersive surface conductance captured by the\nDrude model. Together these phenomena conspire to generate Lorentz resonances\nat frequencies controlled by the surface geometry and the surface conductance.\nThe Lorentz resonances found in the frequency response of the effective\ndielectric tensor of the bulk metamaterial is shown to be given by an explicit\nformula, in which material properties and geometric resonances are decoupled.\nThis formula is rigorous and obtained directly from corrector fields describing\nlocal electrostatic fields inside the heterogeneous structure. Our analytical\nfindings can serve as an efficient computational tool to describe the general\nfrequency dependence of periodic optical devices. As a concrete example, we\ninvestigate two prototypical geometries composed of nanotubes and nanoribbons.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We explain the Lorentz resonances in plasmonic crystals that consist of 2D\nnano dielectric inclusions as the interaction between resonant material\nproperties and geometric resonances of electrostatic nature. One example of\nsuch plasmonic crystals are graphene nanosheets that are periodically arranged\nwithin a non-magnetic bulk dielectric. We identify local geometric resonances\non the length scale of the small scale period. From a materials perspective,\nthe graphene surface exhibits a dispersive surface conductance captured by the\nDrude model. Together these phenomena conspire to generate Lorentz resonances\nat frequencies controlled by the surface geometry and the surface conductance.\nThe Lorentz resonances found in the frequency response of the effective\ndielectric tensor of the bulk metamaterial is shown to be given by an explicit\nformula, in which material properties and geometric resonances are decoupled.\nThis formula is rigorous and obtained directly from corrector fields describing\nlocal electrostatic fields inside the heterogeneous structure. Our analytical\nfindings can serve as an efficient computational tool to describe the general\nfrequency dependence of periodic optical devices. As a concrete example, we\ninvestigate two prototypical geometries composed of nanotubes and nanoribbons."}, "authors": [{"name": "Wei Li"}, {"name": "Robert Lipton"}, {"name": "Matthias Maier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Matthias Maier"}, "author": "Matthias Maier", "arxiv_doi": "10.1098/rspa.2021.0609", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rspa.2021.0609", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.12166v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2009.12166v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.optics", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.optics", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1906.00018v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1906.00018v1", "updated": "2019-05-31T18:10:20Z", "updated_parsed": [2019, 5, 31, 18, 10, 20, 4, 151, 0], "published": "2019-05-31T18:10:20Z", "published_parsed": [2019, 5, 31, 18, 10, 20, 4, 151, 0], "title": "Graphene epsilon-near-zero plasmonic crystals", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Graphene epsilon-near-zero plasmonic crystals"}, "summary": "Plasmonic crystals are a class of optical metamaterials that consist of\nengineered structures at the sub-wavelength scale. They exhibit optical\nproperties that are not found under normal circumstances in nature, such as\nnegative-refractive-index and epsilon-near-zero (ENZ) behavior. Graphene-based\nplasmonic crystals present linear, elliptical, or hyperbolic dispersion\nrelations that exhibit ENZ behavior, normal or negative-index diffraction. The\noptical properties can be dynamically tuned by controlling the operating\nfrequency and the doping level of graphene. We propose a construction approach\nto expand the frequency range of the ENZ behavior. We demonstrate how the\ncombination of a host material with an optical Lorentzian response in\ncombination with a graphene conductivity that follows a Drude model leads to an\nENZ condition spanning a large frequency range.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Plasmonic crystals are a class of optical metamaterials that consist of\nengineered structures at the sub-wavelength scale. They exhibit optical\nproperties that are not found under normal circumstances in nature, such as\nnegative-refractive-index and epsilon-near-zero (ENZ) behavior. Graphene-based\nplasmonic crystals present linear, elliptical, or hyperbolic dispersion\nrelations that exhibit ENZ behavior, normal or negative-index diffraction. The\noptical properties can be dynamically tuned by controlling the operating\nfrequency and the doping level of graphene. We propose a construction approach\nto expand the frequency range of the ENZ behavior. We demonstrate how the\ncombination of a host material with an optical Lorentzian response in\ncombination with a graphene conductivity that follows a Drude model leads to an\nENZ condition spanning a large frequency range."}, "authors": [{"name": "Marios Mattheakis"}, {"name": "Matthias Maier"}, {"name": "Wei Xi Boo"}, {"name": "Efthimios Kaxiras"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Efthimios Kaxiras"}, "author": "Efthimios Kaxiras", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1906.00018v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1906.00018v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.app-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.app-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "physics.optics", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1402.0208v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1402.0208v3", "updated": "2014-07-28T22:25:01Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 7, 28, 22, 25, 1, 0, 209, 0], "published": "2014-02-02T16:16:40Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 2, 2, 16, 16, 40, 6, 33, 0], "title": "Continued fraction digit averages an Maclaurin's inequalities", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Continued fraction digit averages an Maclaurin's inequalities"}, "summary": "A classical result of Khinchin says that for almost all real numbers\n$\\alpha$, the geometric mean of the first $n$ digits $a_i(\\alpha)$ in the\ncontinued fraction expansion of $\\alpha$ converges to a number $K =\n2.6854520\\ldots$ (Khinchin's constant) as $n \\to \\infty$. On the other hand,\nfor almost all $\\alpha$, the arithmetic mean of the first $n$ continued\nfraction digits $a_i(\\alpha)$ approaches infinity as $n \\to \\infty$. There is a\nsequence of refinements of the AM-GM inequality, Maclaurin's inequalities,\nrelating the $1/k$-th powers of the $k$-th elementary symmetric means of $n$\nnumbers for $1 \\leq k \\leq n$. On the left end (when $k=n$) we have the\ngeometric mean, and on the right end ($k=1$) we have the arithmetic mean.\n  We analyze what happens to the means of continued fraction digits of a\ntypical real number in the limit as one moves $f(n)$ steps away from either\nextreme. We prove sufficient conditions on $f(n)$ to ensure to ensure\ndivergence when one moves $f(n)$ steps away from the arithmetic mean and\nconvergence when one moves $f(n)$ steps away from the geometric mean. For\ntypical $\\alpha$ we conjecture the behavior for $f(n)=cn$, $0<c<1$.\n  We also study the limiting behavior of such means for quadratic irrational\n$\\alpha$, providing rigorous results, as well as numerically supported\nconjectures.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A classical result of Khinchin says that for almost all real numbers\n$\\alpha$, the geometric mean of the first $n$ digits $a_i(\\alpha)$ in the\ncontinued fraction expansion of $\\alpha$ converges to a number $K =\n2.6854520\\ldots$ (Khinchin's constant) as $n \\to \\infty$. On the other hand,\nfor almost all $\\alpha$, the arithmetic mean of the first $n$ continued\nfraction digits $a_i(\\alpha)$ approaches infinity as $n \\to \\infty$. There is a\nsequence of refinements of the AM-GM inequality, Maclaurin's inequalities,\nrelating the $1/k$-th powers of the $k$-th elementary symmetric means of $n$\nnumbers for $1 \\leq k \\leq n$. On the left end (when $k=n$) we have the\ngeometric mean, and on the right end ($k=1$) we have the arithmetic mean.\n  We analyze what happens to the means of continued fraction digits of a\ntypical real number in the limit as one moves $f(n)$ steps away from either\nextreme. We prove sufficient conditions on $f(n)$ to ensure to ensure\ndivergence when one moves $f(n)$ steps away from the arithmetic mean and\nconvergence when one moves $f(n)$ steps away from the geometric mean. Do"}, {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, {"name": "Beng Ong"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Beng Ong"}, "author": "Beng Ong", "arxiv_comment": "V2: some small text corrections and an extension of the result", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.04774v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1601.04774v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "81Q35, 81Q10, 35P99, 58J50", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0905.1310v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0905.1310v2", "updated": "2010-10-07T23:43:05Z", "updated_parsed": [2010, 10, 7, 23, 43, 5, 3, 280, 0], "published": "2009-05-08T18:07:53Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 5, 8, 18, 7, 53, 4, 128, 0], "title": "The support theorem for the single radius spherical mean transform", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The support theorem for the single radius spherical mean transform"}, "summary": "Let f(x) belong to L^p(R^n) and R>0. The transform is considered that\nintegrates the function f over (almost) all spheres of radius R in R^n. This\noperator is known to be non-injective (as one can see by taking Fourier\ntransform). However, the counterexamples that can be easily constructed using\nBessel functions of the 1st kind, only belong to L^p if p>2n/(n-1). It has been\nshown previously by S. Thangavelu that for p not exceeding the critical number\n2n/(n-1), the transform is indeed injective.\n  In this article, the support theorem is proven that strengthens this\ninjectivity result. Namely, if K is a convex bounded domain in R^n, the index p\nis not above 2n/(n-1), and (almost) all the integrals of $f$ over spheres of\nradius $R$ not intersecting K are equal to zero, then f is supported in the\nclosure of the domain K.\n  In fact, convexity in this case is too strong a condition, and the result\nholds for any what we call an R-convex domain.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let f(x) belong to L^p(R^n) and R>0. The transform is considered that\nintegrates the function f over (almost) all spheres of radius R in R^n. This\noperator is known to be non-injective (as one can see by taking Fourier\ntransform). However, the counterexamples that can be easily constructed using\nBessel functions of the 1st kind, only belong to L^p if p>2n/(n-1). It has been\nshown previously by S. Thangavelu that for p not exceeding the critical number\n2n/(n-1), the transform is indeed injective.\n  In this article, the support theorem is proven that strengthens this\ninjectivity result. Namely, if K is a convex bounded domain in R^n, the index p\nis not above 2n/(n-1), and (almost) all the integrals of $f$ over spheres of\nradius $R$ not intersecting K are equal to zero, then f is supported in the\nclosure of the domain K.\n  In fact, convexity in this case is too strong a condition, and the result\nholds for any what we call an R-convex domain."}, "authors": [{"name": "Mark Agranovsky"}, {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, "author": "Peter Kuchment", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Memoirs on Differential Equations and Mathematical Physics "2005-08-04T03:27:47Z", "updated_parsed": [2005, 8, 4, 3, 27, 47, 3, 216, 0], "published": "2005-08-04T03:27:47Z", "published_parsed": [2005, 8, 4, 3, 27, 47, 3, 216, 0], "title": "A range description for the planar circular Radon transform", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A range description for the planar circular Radon transform"}, "summary": "The transform considered in the paper integrates a function supported in the\nunit disk on the plane over all circles centered at the boundary of this disk.\nSuch circular Radon transform arises in several contemporary imaging\ntechniques, as well as in other applications. As it is common for transforms of\nRadon type, its range has infinite co-dimension in standard function spaces.\nRange descriptions for such transforms are known to be very important for\ncomputed tomography, for instance when dealing with incomplete data, error\ncorrection, and other issues. A complete range description for the circular\nRadon transform is obtained. Range conditions include the recently found set of\nmoment type conditions, which happens to be incomplete, as well as the rest of\nconditions that have less standard form. In order to explain the procedure\nbetter, a similar (non-standard) treatment of the range conditions is described\nfirst for the usual Radon transform on the plane.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The transform considered in the paper integrates a function supported in the\nunit disk on the plane over all circles centered at the boundary of this disk.\nSuch circular Radon transform arises in several contemporary imaging\ntechniques, as well as in other applications. As it is common for transforms of\nRadon type, its range has infinite co-dimension in standard function spaces.\nRange descriptions for such transforms are known to be very important for\ncomputed tomography, for instance when dealing with incomplete data, error\ncorrection, and other issues. A complete range description for the circular\nRadon transform is obtained. Range conditions include the recently found set of\nmoment type conditions, which happens to be incomplete, as well as the rest of\nconditions that have less standard form. In order to explain the procedure\nbetter, a similar (non-standard) treatment of the range conditions is described\nfirst for the usual Radon transform on the plane."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gaik Ambartsoumian"}, {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, "author": "Peter Kuchment", "arxiv_comment": "submitted for publication", "arxiv_journal_ref": "SIAM J. Kuchment, On the\nquestion of the affine-invariant points of convex bodies, (in Russian),\nOptimizacija No. 8(25) (1972), 48--51, 127. MR0350621. There partial solutions\nof some old problems of B. Gr\\\"unbaum concerning affine-invariant points of\nconvex bodies were obtained. The main restriction, due to which the solution\nwas incomplete, was the compactness restriction on the group of linear\ntransformations involved. It was noticed recently by O. Mordhorst\n(arXiv:1601.07850) that a simple additional argument allows one to restrict the\nconsideration to the bodies whose John's ellipsoid is a ball and consequently\nto a compact group case. This in turn extends the result to the complete\nsolution of B. Gr\\\"unbaum's problem (see also some partial progress in the\nprevious recent works by M. Meyer, C. Sch\\\"utt, and E. The perturbation is assumed to be\n\"along\" the eigenfunction $f$, namely $K_0f=0$. The eigenvalue $\\lambda^\\circ$\nbelongs to the spectra of both $H_0$ and $S$. Let $S$ have $\\sigma$ more\neigenvalues below $\\lambda^\\circ$ than $H_0$; $\\sigma$ is known as the spectral\nshift at $\\lambda^\\circ$.\n  We now allow the perturbation to vary in a suitable operator space and study\nthe continuation of the eigenvalue $\\lambda^\\circ$ in the spectrum of $H(K)=S +\nK^* K$. A version of this theorem also holds for some non-positive\nperturbations.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider a compact perturbation $H_0 = S + K_0^* K_0$ of a self-adjoint\noperator $S$ with an eigenvalue $\\lambda^\\circ$ below its essential spectrum\nand the corresponding eigenfunction $f$. The perturbation is assumed to be\n\"along\" the eigenfunction $f$, namely $K_0f=0$. The eigenvalue $\\lambda^\\circ$\nbelongs to the spectra of both $H_0$ and $S$. Let $S$ have $\\sigma$ more\neigenvalues below $\\lambda^\\circ$ than $H_0$; $\\sigma$ is known as the spectral\nshift at $\\lambda^\\circ$.\n  We now allow the perturbation to vary in a suitable operator space and study\nthe continuation of the eigenvalue $\\lambda^\\circ$ in the spectrum of $H(K)=S +\nK^* K$. Let also S be a finite part\nof its spectrum separated by gaps from the rest of the spectrum. We consider\nthe old question of existence of a finite set of exponentially decaying Wannier\nfunctions such that their G-shifts span the whole spectral subspace\ncorresponding to S in some \"nice\" manner. It is known that a topological\nobstruction might exist to finding exponentially decaying Wannier functions\nthat form an orthonormal basis of the spectral subspace. This obstruction has\nthe form of non-triviality of certain finite dimensional (with the dimension\nequal to the number of spectral bands in S) analytic vector bundle. We show\nthat it is always possible to find a finite number of exponentially decaying\ncomposite Wannier functions such that their G-shifts form a 1-tight frame in\nthe spectral subspace. This appears to be the best, one can do when the\ntopological obstruction is present. The number of the functions is the smallest\ndimension of a trivial bundle containing an equivalent copy of the \"obstacle\nbundle\". In particular, it coincides with the number of spectral bands if and\nonly if the bundle is trivial, in which case an orthonormal basis of\nexponentially decaying composite Wannier functions is known to exist. An\nestimate on this number is provided.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let L be a Schroedinger operator with periodic magnetic and electric\npotentials, a Maxwell operator in a periodic medium, or an arbitrary\nself-adjoint elliptic linear partial differential operator in R^n with\ncoefficients periodic with respect to a lattice G. Let also S be a finite part\nof its spectrum separated by gaps from the rest of the spectrum. We consider\nthe old question of existence of a finite set of exponentially decaying Wannier\nfunctions such that their G-shifts span the whole spectral subspace\ncorresponding to S in some \"nice\" manner. It is known that a topological\nobstruction might exist to finding exponentially decaying Wannier functions\nthat form an orthonormal basis of the spectral subspace. This obstruction has\nthe form of non-triviality of certain finite dimensional (with the dimension\nequal to the number of spectral bands in S) analytic vector bundle. We show\nthat it is always possible to find a finite number of exponentially decaying\ncomposite Wannier functions such that their G-shifts form a 1-tight frame in\nthe spectral subspace. This appears to be the best, one can do when the\ntopological obstruction is present. The number of the functions is the smallest\ndimension of a trivial bundle containing an equivalent copy of the \"obstacle\nbundle\". In particular, it coincides with the number of spectral bands if and\nonly if the bundle is trivial, in which case an orthonormal basis of\nexponentially decaying composite Wannier functions is known to exist. An\nestimate on this number is provided."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Kuchment"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, "author": "Peter Kuchment", "arxiv_doi": "10.1088/1751-8113/42/2/025203", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1751-8113/42/2/025203", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0807.1342v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0807.1342v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_journal_ref": "J. We establish binomial-type\nidentities for $D$ and $U$ assuming that either their commutator $[D,U]$ or the\nsecond commutator $[D,[D,U]]$ is proportional to $U$.\n  Operators $D=d/dx$ (differentiation) and $U$- multiplication by $e^{\\lambda\nx}$ or by $\\sin \\lambda x$ are basic examples, for which some of these\nrelations appeared unexpectedly as byproducts of an authors' previous medical\nimaging research.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $D$ and $U$ be linear operators in a vector space (or more generally,\nelements of an associative algebra with a unit). We establish binomial-type\nidentities for $D$ and $U$ assuming that either their commutator $[D,U]$ or the\nsecond commutator $[D,[D,U]]$ is proportional to $U$.\n  Operators $D=d/dx$ (differentiation) and $U$- multiplication by $e^{\\lambda\nx}$ or by $\\sin \\lambda x$ are basic examples, for which some of these\nrelations appeared unexpectedly as byproducts of an authors' previous medical\nimaging research."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, {"name": "Sergey Lvin"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Sergey Lvin"}, "author": "Sergey Lvin", "arxiv_comment": "12 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05308v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1801.05308v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.QA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "Primary 11B65, 16B99, 20F12, 47B47, Secondary, 33B9, 44A12, 92C55,\n  81S05", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1110.1819v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1110.1819v3", "updated": "2012-03-21T00:49:59Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 3, 21, 0, 49, 59, 2, 81, 0], "published": "2011-10-09T10:49:25Z", "published_parsed": [2011, 10, 9, 10, 49, 25, 6, 282, 0], "title": "Stabilizing Inverse Problems by Internal Data", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Stabilizing Inverse Problems by Internal Data"}, "summary": "Several newly developing hybrid imaging methods (e.g., those combining\nelectrical impedance or optical imaging with acoustics) enable one to obtain\nsome auxiliary interior information (usually some combination of the electrical\nconductivity and the current) about the parameters of the tissues. This\ninformation, in turn, happens to stabilize the exponentially unstable and thus\nlow resolution optical and electrical impedance tomography.\n  Various known instances of this effect have been studied individually. We\nshow that there is a simple general technique (covering all known cases) that\nshows what kind of interior data stabilizes the reconstruction, and why.\nNamely, we show when the linearized problem becomes elliptic\npseudo-differential one, and thus stable. Stability here is meant as the\nproblem being Fredholm, so the local uniqueness is not shown and probably does\nnot hold in such generality.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Several newly developing hybrid imaging methods (e.g., those combining\nelectrical impedance or optical imaging with acoustics) enable one to obtain\nsome auxiliary interior information (usually some combination of the electrical\nconductivity and the current) about the parameters of the tissues. This\ninformation, in turn, happens to stabilize the exponentially unstable and thus\nlow resolution optical and electrical impedance tomography.\n  Various known instances of this effect have been studied individually. We\nshow that there is a simple general technique (covering all known cases) that\nshows what kind of interior data stabilizes the reconstruction, and why.\nNamely, we show when the linearized problem becomes elliptic\npseudo-differential one, and thus stable. Stability here is meant as the\nproblem being Fredholm, so the local uniqueness is not shown and probably does\nnot hold in such generality."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, {"name": "Dustin Steinhauer"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Dustin Steinhauer"}, "author": "Dustin Steinhauer", "arxiv_doi": "10.1088/0266-5611/28/8/084007", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0266-5611/28/8/084007", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1110.1819v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1110.1819v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "The version 3 has been somewhat restructured; section on QPAT was\n  revised and corrected", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Inverse Problems 28(2012), no. 8, p.4007", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35R30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.0763v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.0763v2", "updated": "2014-11-03T01:13:46Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 11, 3, 1, 13, 46, 0, 307, 0], "published": "2014-07-03T02:24:42Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 7, 3, 2, 24, 42, 3, 184, 0], "title": "Stabilizing inverse problems by internal data. II. Non-local internal\n  data and generic linearized uniqueness", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Stabilizing inverse problems by internal data. II. Non-local internal\n  data and generic linearized uniqueness"}, "summary": "In the previous paper \"Stabilizing Inverse Problems by Internal Data\", the\nauthors introduced a simple procedure that allows one to detect whether and\nexplain why internal information arising in several novel coupled physics\n(hybrid) imaging modalities could turn extremely unstable techniques, such as\noptical tomography or electrical impedance tomography, into stable,\ngood-resolution procedures. It was shown that in all cases of interest, the\nFrechet derivative of the forward mapping is a pseudo-differential operator\nwith an explicitly computable principal symbol. If one can set up the imaging\nprocedure in such a way that the symbol is elliptic, this would indicate that\nthe problem was stabilized. In the cases when the symbol is not elliptic, the\ntechnique suggests how to change the procedure (e.g., by adding extra\nmeasurements) to achieve ellipticity.\n  In this article, we consider the situation arising in acousto-optical\ntomography (also called ultrasound modulated optical tomography), where the\ninternal data available involves the Green's function, and thus depends\nglobally on the unknown parameter(s) of the equation and its solution. It is\nshown that the technique of \"Stabilizing Inverse Problems by Internal Data\" can\nbe successfully adopted to this situation as well. We also obtain results on\ngeneric uniqueness for the linearized problem in a variety of situations,\nincluding those arising in acousto-electric and quantitative photoacoustic\ntomography.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In the previous paper \"Stabilizing Inverse Problems by Internal Data\", the\nauthors introduced a simple procedure that allows one to detect whether and\nexplain why internal information arising in several novel coupled physics\n(hybrid) imaging modalities could turn extremely unstable techniques, such as\noptical tomography or electrical impedance tomography, into stable,\ngood-resolution procedures. It was shown that in all cases of interest, the\nFrechet derivative of the forward mapping is a pseudo-differential operator\nwith an explicitly computable principal symbol. If one can set up the imaging\nprocedure in such a way that the symbol is elliptic, this would indicate that\nthe problem was stabilized. In the cases when the symbol is not elliptic, the\ntechnique suggests how to change the procedure (e.g., by adding extra\nmeasurements) to achieve ellipticity.\n  In this article, we consider the situation arising in acousto-optical\ntomography (also called ultrasound modulated optical tomography), where the\ninternal data available involves the Green's function, and thus depends\nglobally on the unknown parameter(s) of the equation and its solution. It is\nshown that the technique of \"Stabilizing Inverse Problems by Internal Data\" can\nbe successfully adopted to this situation as well. We also obtain results on\ngeneric uniqueness for the linearized problem in a variety of situations,\nincluding those arising in acousto-electric and quantitative photoacoustic\ntomography."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, {"name": "Dustin Steinhauer"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Dustin Steinhauer"}, "author": "Dustin Steinhauer", "arxiv_comment": "33 pages. However, a specific local coordinate chart on the\nGrassmanian of all possible vertex conditions was used, thus creating an\nerroneous impression that something ``wrong'' can happen at the boundaries of\nthe chart. Here we show that the analyticity of the corresponding ``dispersion\nrelation'' holds over the whole Grassmannian, as well as over other parameter\nspaces.\n  We also address the Dirichlet-to-Neumann (DtN) technique of relating quantum\nand discrete graph operators, which allows one to transfer some results from\nthe discrete to the quantum graph case, but which has issues at the Dirichlet\nspectrum. We conclude that this difficulty, as in the first part of the paper,\nstems from the use of specific coordinates in a Grassmannian and show how to\navoid it to extend some of the consequent results to the general situation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In some previous works, the analytic structure of the spectrum of a quantum\ngraph operator as a function of the vertex conditions and other parameters of\nthe graph was established. However, a specific local coordinate chart on the\nGrassmanian of all possible vertex conditions was used, thus creating an\nerroneous impression that something ``wrong'' can happen at the boundaries of\nthe chart. Here we show that the analyticity of the corresponding ``dispersion\nrelation'' holds over the whole Grassmannian, as well as over other parameter\nspaces.\n  We also address the Dirichlet-to-Neumann (DtN) technique of relating quantum\nand discrete graph operators, which allows one to transfer some results from\nthe discrete to the quantum graph case, but which has issues at the Dirichlet\nspectrum. Quantum graphs have been intensively studied lately\ndue to their numerous applications to mesoscopic physics, nanotechnology,\noptics, and other areas.\n  A Schnol type theorem is proven that allows one to detect that a point\nbelongs to the spectrum when a generalized eigenfunction with an subexponential\ngrowth integral estimate is available. This Radon\ntype transform arises in several contemporary applications, e.g. in\nthermoacoustic tomography and sonar and radar imaging. Range descriptions for\nsuch transforms are important in all these areas, for instance when dealing\nwith incomplete data, error correction, and other issues. Such\ntransforms arise naturally in thermoacoustic tomography, a novel method of\nmedical imaging. Range descriptions have recently been obtained for such\ntransforms, and consisted of smoothness and support conditions, moment\nconditions, and some additional orthogonality conditions of spectral nature.
