Such\ntransforms arise naturally in thermoacoustic tomography, a novel method of\nmedical imaging. Range descriptions have recently been obtained for such\ntransforms, and consisted of smoothness and support conditions, moment\nconditions, and some additional orthogonality conditions of spectral nature. It\nhas been noticed that in odd dimensions, surprisingly, the moment conditions\nare superfluous and can be eliminated. It is shown in this text that in fact\nthe same happens in any dimension."}, "authors": [{"name": "Mark Agranovsky"}, {"name": "David Finch"}, {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, "author": "Peter Kuchment", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Inverse Problems and Imaging, Volume 3, No. 3, 2009, 373-382", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0902.4272v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0902.4272v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35L05, 92C55, 65R32, 44A12", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math-ph/0511084v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math-ph/0511084v1", "updated": "2005-11-28T00:56:49Z", "updated_parsed": [2005, 11, 28, 0, 56, 49, 0, 332, 0], "published": "2005-11-28T00:56:49Z", "published_parsed": [2005, 11, 28, 0, 56, 49, 0, 332, 0], "title": "On the structure of eigenfunctions corresponding to embedded eigenvalues\n  of locally perturbed periodic graph operators", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "On the structure of eigenfunctions corresponding to embedded eigenvalues\n  of locally perturbed periodic graph operators"}, "summary": "The article is devoted to the following question. Consider a periodic\nself-adjoint difference (differential) operator on a graph (quantum graph) G\nwith a co-compact free action of the integer lattice Z^n. It is known that a\nlocal perturbation of the operator might embed an eigenvalue into the\ncontinuous spectrum (a feature uncommon for periodic elliptic operators of\nsecond order). In all known constructions of such examples, the corresponding\neigenfunction is compactly supported. One wonders whether this must always be\nthe case. The paper answers this question affirmatively. What is more\nsurprising, one can estimate that the eigenmode must be localized not far away\nfrom the perturbation (in a neighborhood of the perturbation's support, the\nwidth of the neighborhood determined by the unperturbed operator only).\n  The validity of this result requires the condition of irreducibility of the\nFermi (Floquet) surface of the periodic operator, which is expected to be\nsatisfied for instance for periodic Schroedinger operators.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The article is devoted to the following question. Consider a periodic\nself-adjoint difference (differential) operator on a graph (quantum graph) G\nwith a co-compact free action of the integer lattice Z^n. It is known that a\nlocal perturbation of the operator might embed an eigenvalue into the\ncontinuous spectrum (a feature uncommon for periodic elliptic operators of\nsecond order). In all known constructions of such examples, the corresponding\neigenfunction is compactly supported. One wonders whether this must always be\nthe case. The paper answers this question affirmatively. What is more\nsurprising, one can estimate that the eigenmode must be localized not far away\nfrom the perturbation (in a neighborhood of the perturbation's support, the\nwidth of the neighborhood determined by the unperturbed operator only).\n  The validity of this result requires the condition of irreducibility of the\nFermi (Floquet) surface of the periodic operator, which is expected to be\nsatisfied for instance for periodic Schroedinger operators."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, {"name": "Boris Vainberg"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Boris Vainberg"}, "author": "Boris Vainberg", "arxiv_doi": "10.1007/s00220-006-0105-2", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00220-006-0105-2", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math-ph/0511084v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math-ph/0511084v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "Submitted for publication", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Comm. Math. Phys. 268 (2006), 673-686", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "05C90, 34B45, 34L05, 34L40, 35P05, 47A10, 58J50", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1107.3489v6", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1107.3489v6", "updated": "2012-05-25T19:25:11Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 5, 25, 19, 25, 11, 4, 146, 0], "published": "2011-07-18T16:09:40Z", "published_parsed": [2011, 7, 18, 16, 9, 40, 0, 199, 0], "title": "Critical partitions and nodal deficiency of billiard eigenfunctions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Critical partitions and nodal deficiency of billiard eigenfunctions"}, "summary": "The paper addresses the the number of nodal domains for eigenfunctions of\nSchr\\\"{o}dinger operators with Dirichlet boundary conditions in bounded\ndomains. In dimension one, the $n$th eigenfunction has $n$ nodal domains. The\nCourant Theorem claims that in any dimension, the number of nodal domains of\nthe $n$th eigenfunction cannot exceed $n$. However, in dimensions higher than 1\nthe equality can hold for only finitely many eigenfunctions. Thus, a \"nodal\ndeficiency\" arises. Examples are known of eigenfunctions with arbitrarily large\nindex $n$ that have just two nodal domains.\n  It was suggested in the recent years to look at the partitions of the domain,\nrather than eigenfunctions. It was shown in a recent paper by Helffer,\nHoffmann-Ostenhof and Terracini that (under some natural conditions) bipartite\npartitions minimizing the maximum of the ground-state energies in sub-domains\nof the partition, correspond to the \"Courant sharp\" eigenfunctions, i.e. to\nthose with zero nodal deficiency.\n  In this paper, the authors show, under some genericity conditions, among the\nbipartite equipartitions, the nodal ones correspond exactly to the critical\npoints of an analogous functional, with the nodal deficiency being equal to the\nMorse index at this point. This explains, in particular, why all the minimal\npartitions must be Courant sharp.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The paper addresses the the number of nodal domains for eigenfunctions of\nSchr\\\"{o}dinger operators with Dirichlet boundary conditions in bounded\ndomains. In dimension one, the $n$th eigenfunction has $n$ nodal domains. The\nCourant Theorem claims that in any dimension, the number of nodal domains of\nthe $n$th eigenfunction cannot exceed $n$. However, in dimensions higher than 1\nthe equality can hold for only finitely many eigenfunctions. Thus, a \"nodal\ndeficiency\" arises. Examples are known of eigenfunctions with arbitrarily large\nindex $n$ that have just two nodal domains.\n  It was suggested in the recent years to look at the partitions of the domain,\nrather than eigenfunctions. It was shown in a recent paper by Helffer,\nHoffmann-Ostenhof and Terracini that (under some natural conditions) bipartite\npartitions minimizing the maximum of the ground-state energies in sub-domains\nof the partition, correspond to the \"Courant sharp\" eigenfunctions, i.e. to\nthose with zero nodal deficiency.\n  In this paper, the authors show, under some genericity conditions, among the\nbipartite equipartitions, the nodal ones correspond exactly to the critical\npoints of an analogous functional, with the nodal deficiency being equal to the\nMorse index at this point. This explains, in particular, why all the minimal\npartitions must be Courant sharp."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gregory Berkolaiko"}, {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, {"name": "Uzy Smilansky"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Uzy Smilansky"}, "author": "Uzy Smilansky", "arxiv_doi": "10.1007/s00039-012-0199-y", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00039-012-0199-y", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1107.3489v6", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1107.3489v6", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "In the 2nd version minor modifications were implemented", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Geom. Nadirashvili and\nthen M. Gromov and M. Shubin to computing indices of elliptic operators on\ncompact (as well as non-compact) manifolds, when a divisor mandates a finite\nnumber of zeros and allows a finite number of poles of solutions.\n  On the other hand, Liouville type theorems count the number of solutions that\nare allowed to have a \"pole at infinity.\" Usually these theorems do not provide\nthe exact dimensions of the spaces of such solutions (only\nfinite-dimensionality, possibly with estimates or asymptotics of the dimension.\nAn important case has been discovered by M. Avellaneda and F. H. Lin and\nadvanced further by J. Moser and M. Struwe. It pertains periodic elliptic\noperators of divergent type, where, surprisingly, exact dimensions can be\ncomputed. This study has been extended by P. Li and Wang and brought to its\nnatural limit for the case of periodic elliptic operators on co-compact abelian\ncoverings by P. Kuchment and Pinchover.\n  Comparison of the results and techniques of Nadirashvili and Gromov and\nShubin with those of Kuchment and Pinchover shows significant similarities, as\nwell as appearance of the same combinatorial expressions in the answers. Thus a\nnatural idea was considered that possibly the results could be combined somehow\nin the case of co-compact abelian coverings, if the infinity is \"added to the\ndivisor.\"\n  This work shows that such results indeed can be obtained, although they come\nout more intricate than a simple-minded expectation would suggest. Namely, the\ninteraction between the finite divisor and the point at infinity is\nnon-trivial.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The classical Riemann-Roch theorem has been extended by N. Nadirashvili and\nthen M. Gromov and M. Shubin to computing indices of elliptic operators on\ncompact (as well as non-compact) manifolds, when a divisor mandates a finite\nnumber of zeros and allows a finite number of poles of solutions.\n  On the other hand, Liouville type theorems count the number of solutions that\nare allowed to have a \"pole at infinity.\" Usually these theorems do not provide\nthe exact dimensions of the spaces of such solutions (only\nfinite-dimensionality, possibly with estimates or asymptotics of the dimension.\nAn important case has been discovered by M. Avellaneda and F. H. Lin and\nadvanced further by J. Moser and M. Struwe. It pertains periodic elliptic\noperators of divergent type, where, surprisingly, exact dimensions can be\ncomputed. This study has been extended by P. Li and Wang and brought to its\nnatural limit for the case of periodic elliptic operators on co-compact abelian\ncoverings by P. Kuchment and Pinchover.\n  Comparison of the results and techniques of Nadirashvili and Gromov and\nShubin with those of Kuchment and Pinchover shows significant similarities, as\nwell as appearance of the same combinatorial expressions in the answers. Thus a\nnatural idea was considered that possibly the results could be combined somehow\nin the case of co-compact abelian coverings, if the infinity is \"added to the\ndivisor.\"\n  This work shows that such results indeed can be obtained, although they come\nout more intricate than a simple-minded expectation would suggest. Agmon, S.\nHelgason, and other authors for solutions of the Helmholtz equation (i.e., for\ngeneralized eigenfunctions of Laplace operator). In a previous joint work with\nY. Agmon,\nS. Helgason, and other authors for solutions of the Helmholtz equation. When\none restricts the class of solutions further, requiring their growth to be\npolynomial, one arrives to Liouville type theorems, which describe the\nstructure and dimension of the spaces of such solutions. In this paper, the case\nof quantum graphs is addressed. A quantum graph is a graph considered as a\n(singular) one-dimensional variety and equipped with a second-order\ndifferential Hamiltonian H (a \"Laplacian\") with suitable conditions at\nvertices. For the case of scale-invariant vertex conditions (i.e., conditions\nthat do not mix the values of functions and of their derivatives), the constant\nterm of the heat-kernel expansion is shown to be proportional to the trace of\nthe internal scattering matrix of the graph. This observation is placed into\nthe index-theory context by factoring the Laplacian into two first-order\noperators, H =A*A, and relating the constant term to the index of A. An\nindependent consideration provides an index formula for any differential\noperator on a finite quantum graph in terms of the vertex conditions. It is\nfound also that the algebraic multiplicity of 0 as a root of the secular\ndeterminant of H is the sum of the nullities of A and A*.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In geometric analysis, an index theorem relates the difference of the numbers\nof solutions of two differential equations to the topological structure of the\nmanifold or bundle concerned, sometimes using the heat kernels of two\nhigher-order differential operators as an intermediary. In this paper, the case\nof quantum graphs is addressed. A quantum graph is a graph considered as a\n(singular) one-dimensional variety and equipped with a second-order\ndifferential Hamiltonian H (a \"Laplacian\") with suitable conditions at\nvertices. For the case of scale-invariant vertex conditions (i.e., conditions\nthat do not mix the values of functions and of their derivatives), the constant\nterm of the heat-kernel expansion is shown to be proportional to the trace of\nthe internal scattering matrix of the graph. This observation is placed into\nthe index-theory context by factoring the Laplacian into two first-order\noperators, H =A*A, and relating the constant term to the index of A. An\nindependent consideration provides an index formula for any differential\noperator on a finite quantum graph in terms of the vertex conditions. It is\nfound also that the algebraic multiplicity of 0 as a root of the secular\ndeterminant of H is the sum of the nullities of A and A*."}, "authors": [{"name": "S. A. Fulling"}, {"name": "P. Here one says that the Liouville theorem\nholds if the space of solutions of any given polynomial growth is finite\ndimensional. The necessary and sufficient condition for a Liouville type\ntheorem to hold is that the real Fermi surface of the elliptic operator\nconsists of finitely many points (modulo the reciprocal lattice). Thus, such a\ntheorem generically is expected to hold at the edges of the spectrum. The\nprecise description of the spaces of polynomially growing solutions depends\nupon a `homogenized' constant coefficient operator determined by the analytic\nstructure of the dispersion relation. In most cases, simple explicit formulas\nare found for the dimensions of the spaces of polynomially growing solutions in\nterms of the dispersion curves. The role of the base of the covering (in\nparticular its dimension) is rather limited, while the deck group is of the\nmost importance.\n  The results are also established for overdetermined elliptic systems, which\nin particular leads to Liouville theorems for polynomially growing holomorphic\nfunctions on abelian coverings of compact analytic manifolds.\n  Analogous theorems hold for abelian coverings of compact combinatorial or\nquantum graphs.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The paper describes relations between Liouville type theorems for solutions\nof a periodic elliptic equation (or a system) on an abelian cover of a compact\nRiemannian manifold and the structure of the dispersion relation for this\nequation at the edges of the spectrum. Here one says that the Liouville theorem\nholds if the space of solutions of any given polynomial growth is finite\ndimensional. The necessary and sufficient condition for a Liouville type\ntheorem to hold is that the real Fermi surface of the elliptic operator\nconsists of finitely many points (modulo the reciprocal lattice). Thus, such a\ntheorem generically is expected to hold at the edges of the spectrum. The\nprecise description of the spaces of polynomially growing solutions depends\nupon a `homogenized' constant coefficient operator determined by the analytic\nstructure of the dispersion relation. In most cases, simple explicit formulas\nare found for the dimensions of the spaces of polynomially growing solutions in\nterms of the dispersion curves. The role of the base of the covering (in\nparticular its dimension) is rather limited, while the deck group is of the\nmost importance.\n  The results are also established for overdetermined elliptic systems, which\nin particular leads to Liouville theorems for polynomially growing holomorphic\nfunctions on abelian coverings of compact analytic manifolds.\n  Analogous theorems hold for abelian coverings of compact combinatorial or\nquantum graphs."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, {"name": "Yehuda Pinchover"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Yehuda Pinchover"}, "author": "Yehuda Pinchover", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Trans. Let $T$ be a presentation of a group\n$\\mathcal{G}$ by bounded linear operators in a Banach space $G$ and $E\\subset\nG$ be a closed invariant subspace. Then $T$ generates in the natural way\npresentations $T_1$ in $E$ and $T_2$ in $F:=G/E$. What additional information\nis required besides $T_1, T_2$ to recover the presentation $T$? In\nfinite-dimensional (and even in infinite dimensional Hilbert) case the solution\nis well known: one needs to supply a group cohomology class $h\\in\nH^1(\\mathcal{G},Hom(F,E))$. The same holds in the Banach case, if the subspace\n$E$ is complemented in $G$. However, every Banach space that is not isomorphic\nto a Hilbert one has non-complemented subspaces, which aggravates the problem\nsignificantly and makes it non-trivial even in the case of a trivial group\naction, where it boils down to what is known as the three-space problem. This\nexplains the title we have chosen. A solution of the problem stated above has\nbeen announced by the author in 1976, but the complete proof, for\nnon-mathematical reasons, has not been made available. This article contains\nthe proof, as well as some related considerations of the functor $Ext^1$ in the\ncategory \\textbf{Ban} of Banach spaces.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We provide the proof of a previously announced result that resolves the\nfollowing problem posed by A.~A.~Kirillov. Let $T$ be a presentation of a group\n$\\mathcal{G}$ by bounded linear operators in a Banach space $G$ and $E\\subset\nG$ be a closed invariant subspace. Then $T$ generates in the natural way\npresentations $T_1$ in $E$ and $T_2$ in $F:=G/E$. What additional information\nis required besides $T_1, T_2$ to recover the presentation $T$? In\nfinite-dimensional (and even in infinite dimensional Hilbert) case the solution\nis well known: one needs to supply a group cohomology class $h\\in\nH^1(\\mathcal{G},Hom(F,E))$. The same holds in the Banach case, if the subspace\n$E$ is complemented in $G$. However, every Banach space that is not isomorphic\nto a Hilbert one has non-complemented subspaces, which aggravates the problem\nsignificantly and makes it non-trivial even in the case of a trivial group\naction, where it boils down to what is known as the three-space problem. This\nexplains the title we have chosen. A solution of the problem stated above has\nbeen announced by the author in 1976, but the complete proof, for\nnon-mathematical reasons, has not been made available. This article contains\nthe proof, as well as some related considerations of the functor $Ext^1$ in the\ncategory \\textbf{Ban} of Banach spaces."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Kuchment"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, "author": "Peter Kuchment", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.07696v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2006.07696v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.RT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "20C99, 46B03, 46M10, 46M15, 46M18", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0901.2552v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0901.2552v1", "updated": "2009-01-16T19:20:06Z", "updated_parsed": [2009, 1, 16, 19, 20, 6, 4, 16, 0], "published": "2009-01-16T19:20:06Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 1, 16, 19, 20, 6, 4, 16, 0], "title": "Synthetic focusing in ultrasound modulated tomography", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Synthetic focusing in ultrasound modulated tomography"}, "summary": "Several hybrid tomographic methods utilizing ultrasound modulation have been\nintroduced lately. Success of these methods hinges on the feasibility of\nfocusing ultrasound waves at an arbitrary point of interest. Such a focusing,\nhowever, is difficult to achieve in practice. We thus propose a way to avoid\nthe use of focused waves through the so called synthetic focusing, i.e. by the\nreconstruction of the would-be response to the focused modulation from the\nmeasurements corresponding to realistic unfocused waves. Examples of\nreconstructions from simulated data are provided. This non-technical paper\ndescribes only the general concept, while technical details will appear\nelsewhere.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Several hybrid tomographic methods utilizing ultrasound modulation have been\nintroduced lately. Success of these methods hinges on the feasibility of\nfocusing ultrasound waves at an arbitrary point of interest. Such a focusing,\nhowever, is difficult to achieve in practice. We thus propose a way to avoid\nthe use of focused waves through the so called synthetic focusing, i.e. by the\nreconstruction of the would-be response to the focused modulation from the\nmeasurements corresponding to realistic unfocused waves. Examples of\nreconstructions from simulated data are provided. This non-technical paper\ndescribes only the general concept, while technical details will appear\nelsewhere."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, {"name": "Leonid Kunyansky"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Leonid Kunyansky"}, "author": "Leonid Kunyansky", "arxiv_doi": "10.3934/ipi.2010.4.665", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.3934/ipi.2010.4.665", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0901.2552v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0901.2552v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "Dedicated to Jan Boman's 75th birthday", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Inverse Problems and Imaging, Volume 4, No. 4, 2010, p. 665-673", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35L05, 92C55, 65R32, 44A12", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.3373v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.3373v2", "updated": "2011-07-14T21:53:48Z", "updated_parsed": [2011, 7, 14, 21, 53, 48, 3, 195, 0], "published": "2010-12-13T21:37:55Z", "published_parsed": [2010, 12, 13, 21, 37, 55, 0, 347, 0], "title": "Detecting small low emission radiating sources", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Detecting small low emission radiating sources"}, "summary": "The article addresses the possibility of robust detection of geometrically\nsmall, low emission sources on a significantly stronger background. This\nproblem is important for homeland security. A technique of detecting such\nsources using Compton type cameras is developed, which is shown on numerical\nexamples to have high sensitivity and specificity and also allows to assign\nconfidence probabilities of the detection. 2D case is considered in detail.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The article addresses the possibility of robust detection of geometrically\nsmall, low emission sources on a significantly stronger background. This\nproblem is important for homeland security. II. Non-local internal\n  data and generic linearized uniqueness", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Stabilizing inverse problems by internal data. II. Non-local internal\n  data and generic linearized uniqueness"}, "summary": "In the previous paper \"Stabilizing Inverse Problems by Internal Data\", the\nauthors introduced a simple procedure that allows one to detect whether and\nexplain why internal information arising in several novel coupled physics\n(hybrid) imaging modalities could turn extremely unstable techniques, such as\noptical tomography or electrical impedance tomography, into stable,\ngood-resolution procedures. It was shown that in all cases of interest, the\nFrechet derivative of the forward mapping is a pseudo-differential operator\nwith an explicitly computable principal symbol. If one can set up the imaging\nprocedure in such a way that the symbol is elliptic, this would indicate that\nthe problem was stabilized. In the cases when the symbol is not elliptic, the\ntechnique suggests how to change the procedure (e.g., by adding extra\nmeasurements) to achieve ellipticity.\n  In this article, we consider the situation arising in acousto-optical\ntomography (also called ultrasound modulated optical tomography), where the\ninternal data available involves the Green's function, and thus depends\nglobally on the unknown parameter(s) of the equation and its solution. It is\nshown that the technique of \"Stabilizing Inverse Problems by Internal Data\" can\nbe successfully adopted to this situation as well. We also obtain results on\ngeneric uniqueness for the linearized problem in a variety of situations,\nincluding those arising in acousto-electric and quantitative photoacoustic\ntomography.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In the previous paper \"Stabilizing Inverse Problems by Internal Data\", the\nauthors introduced a simple procedure that allows one to detect whether and\nexplain why internal information arising in several novel coupled physics\n(hybrid) imaging modalities could turn extremely unstable techniques, such as\noptical tomography or electrical impedance tomography, into stable,\ngood-resolution procedures. It was shown that in all cases of interest, the\nFrechet derivative of the forward mapping is a pseudo-differential operator\nwith an explicitly computable principal symbol. If one can set up the imaging\nprocedure in such a way that the symbol is elliptic, this would indicate that\nthe problem was stabilized. In the cases when the symbol is not elliptic, the\ntechnique suggests how to change the procedure (e.g., by adding extra\nmeasurements) to achieve ellipticity.\n  In this article, we consider the situation arising in acousto-optical\ntomography (also called ultrasound modulated optical tomography), where the\ninternal data available involves the Green's function, and thus depends\nglobally on the unknown parameter(s) of the equation and its solution. It is\nshown that the technique of \"Stabilizing Inverse Problems by Internal Data\" can\nbe successfully adopted to this situation as well. We also obtain results on\ngeneric uniqueness for the linearized problem in a variety of situations,\nincluding those arising in acousto-electric and quantitative photoacoustic\ntomography."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, {"name": "Dustin Steinhauer"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Dustin Steinhauer"}, "author": "Dustin Steinhauer", "arxiv_comment": "33 pages. In the latter case, one deals with passively detecting the presence\nof low emission nuclear sources with significant background noise (with Signal\nTo Noise Ratio ($SNR$) $1\\%$ or less). In passive emission problems, direction\nsensitive detectors are needed, to match the dimensionalities of the image and\nthe data. Collimation, used for that purpose in standard Anger\n$\\gamma$-cameras, is not an option. Instead, Compton $\\gamma$-cameras (and\ntheir analogs for other types of radiation) can be utilized. Backprojection\nmethods suggested before by two of the authors and their collaborators enable\ndetection in the presence of a random uniform background. In most practical\napplications, however, cargo packing in shipping containers and trucks creates\nregions of strong absorption and scattering, while leaving some streaming gaps\nopen. In such cases backprojection methods prove ineffective and lose their\ndetection ability. Nonetheless, visual perception of the backprojection\npictures suggested that some indications of presence of a source might still be\nin the data. To learn such features (if they do exist), a deep neural network\napproach is implemented in 2D, which indeed exhibits higher sensitivity and\nspecificity than the backprojection techniques in a low scattering case and\nworks well when presence of complex cargo makes backprojection fail completely.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Methods for source detection in high noise environments are important for\nsingle-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) medical imaging and\nespecially crucial for homeland security applications, which is our main\ninterest. In the latter case, one deals with passively detecting the presence\nof low emission nuclear sources with significant background noise (with Signal\nTo Noise Ratio ($SNR$) $1\\%$ or less). In passive emission problems, direction\nsensitive detectors are needed, to match the dimensionalities of the image and\nthe data. Collimation, used for that purpose in standard Anger\n$\\gamma$-cameras, is not an option. Instead, Compton $\\gamma$-cameras (and\ntheir analogs for other types of radiation) can be utilized. Backprojection\nmethods suggested before by two of the authors and their collaborators enable\ndetection in the presence of a random uniform background. In most practical\napplications, however, cargo packing in shipping containers and trucks creates\nregions of strong absorption and scattering, while leaving some streaming gaps\nopen. In such cases backprojection methods prove ineffective and lose their\ndetection ability. Nonetheless, visual perception of the backprojection\npictures suggested that some indications of presence of a source might still be\nin the data. To learn such features (if they do exist), a deep neural network\napproach is implemented in 2D, which indeed exhibits higher sensitivity and\nspecificity than the backprojection techniques in a low scattering case and\nworks well when presence of complex cargo makes backprojection fail completely."}, "authors": [{"name": "Weston Baines"}, {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, {"name": "Jean Ragusa"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Jean Ragusa"}, "author": "Jean Ragusa", "arxiv_doi": "10.1088/1361-6420/abb51d", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1361-6420/abb51d", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2003.04089v4", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2003.04089v4", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.ins-det", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.ins-det", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "92C55, 82-XX, 68T05", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math-ph/0411003v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math-ph/0411003v3", "updated": "2004-12-24T03:03:19Z", "updated_parsed": [2004, 12, 24, 3, 3, 19, 4, 359, 0], "published": "2004-10-31T20:12:14Z", "published_parsed": [2004, 10, 31, 20, 12, 14, 6, 305, 0], "title": "Quantum Graphs II: Some spectral properties of quantum and combinatorial\n  graphs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Quantum Graphs II: Some spectral properties of quantum and combinatorial\n  graphs"}, "summary": "The paper deals with some spectral properties of (mostly infinite) quantum\nand combinatorial graphs. Quantum graphs have been intensively studied lately\ndue to their numerous applications to mesoscopic physics, nanotechnology,\noptics, and other areas.\n  A Schnol type theorem is proven that allows one to detect that a point\nbelongs to the spectrum when a generalized eigenfunction with an subexponential\ngrowth integral estimate is available. A theorem on spectral gap opening for\n``decorated'' quantum graphs is established (its analog is known for the\ncombinatorial case). It is also shown that if a periodic combinatorial or\nquantum graph has a point spectrum, it is generated by compactly supported\neigenfunctions (``scars'').", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The paper deals with some spectral properties of (mostly infinite) quantum\nand combinatorial graphs. Quantum graphs have been intensively studied lately\ndue to their numerous applications to mesoscopic physics, nanotechnology,\noptics, and other areas.\n  A Schnol type theorem is proven that allows one to detect that a point\nbelongs to the spectrum when a generalized eigenfunction with an subexponential\ngrowth integral estimate is available. A theorem on spectral gap opening for\n``decorated'' quantum graphs is established (its analog is known for the\ncombinatorial case). However, a specific local coordinate chart on the\nGrassmanian of all possible vertex conditions was used, thus creating an\nerroneous impression that something ``wrong'' can happen at the boundaries of\nthe chart. Here we show that the analyticity of the corresponding ``dispersion\nrelation'' holds over the whole Grassmannian, as well as over other parameter\nspaces.\n  We also address the Dirichlet-to-Neumann (DtN) technique of relating quantum\nand discrete graph operators, which allows one to transfer some results from\nthe discrete to the quantum graph case, but which has issues at the Dirichlet\nspectrum. We conclude that this difficulty, as in the first part of the paper,\nstems from the use of specific coordinates in a Grassmannian and show how to\navoid it to extend some of the consequent results to the general situation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In some previous works, the analytic structure of the spectrum of a quantum\ngraph operator as a function of the vertex conditions and other parameters of\nthe graph was established. However, a specific local coordinate chart on the\nGrassmanian of all possible vertex conditions was used, thus creating an\nerroneous impression that something ``wrong'' can happen at the boundaries of\nthe chart. Here we show that the analyticity of the corresponding ``dispersion\nrelation'' holds over the whole Grassmannian, as well as over other parameter\nspaces.\n  We also address the Dirichlet-to-Neumann (DtN) technique of relating quantum\nand discrete graph operators, which allows one to transfer some results from\nthe discrete to the quantum graph case, but which has issues at the Dirichlet\nspectrum. We conclude that this difficulty, as in the first part of the paper,\nstems from the use of specific coordinates in a Grassmannian and show how to\navoid it to extend some of the consequent results to the general situation."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, {"name": "Jia Zhao"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Jia Zhao"}, "author": "Jia Zhao", "arxiv_doi": "10.1063/1.5110193", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.5110193", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1907.03035v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1907.03035v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "Submitted", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Journal of Mathematical Physics, 2019", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.SP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "34B45, 35R02, 81Q35, 92E10, 94C15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0708.3456v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0708.3456v1", "updated": "2007-08-26T00:52:43Z", "updated_parsed": [2007, 8, 26, 0, 52, 43, 6, 238, 0], "published": "2007-08-26T00:52:43Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 8, 26, 0, 52, 43, 6, 238, 0], "title": "Index theorems for quantum graphs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Index theorems for quantum graphs"}, "summary": "In geometric analysis, an index theorem relates the difference of the numbers\nof solutions of two differential equations to the topological structure of the\nmanifold or bundle concerned, sometimes using the heat kernels of two\nhigher-order differential operators as an intermediary. In this paper, the case\nof quantum graphs is addressed. A quantum graph is a graph considered as a\n(singular) one-dimensional variety and equipped with a second-order\ndifferential Hamiltonian H (a \"Laplacian\") with suitable conditions at\nvertices. For the case of scale-invariant vertex conditions (i.e., conditions\nthat do not mix the values of functions and of their derivatives), the constant\nterm of the heat-kernel expansion is shown to be proportional to the trace of\nthe internal scattering matrix of the graph. This observation is placed into\nthe index-theory context by factoring the Laplacian into two first-order\noperators, H =A*A, and relating the constant term to the index of A. An\nindependent consideration provides an index formula for any differential\noperator on a finite quantum graph in terms of the vertex conditions. It is\nfound also that the algebraic multiplicity of 0 as a root of the secular\ndeterminant of H is the sum of the nullities of A and A*.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In geometric analysis, an index theorem relates the difference of the numbers\nof solutions of two differential equations to the topological structure of the\nmanifold or bundle concerned, sometimes using the heat kernels of two\nhigher-order differential operators as an intermediary. In this paper, the case\nof quantum graphs is addressed. A quantum graph is a graph considered as a\n(singular) one-dimensional variety and equipped with a second-order\ndifferential Hamiltonian H (a \"Laplacian\") with suitable conditions at\nvertices. For the case of scale-invariant vertex conditions (i.e., conditions\nthat do not mix the values of functions and of their derivatives), the constant\nterm of the heat-kernel expansion is shown to be proportional to the trace of\nthe internal scattering matrix of the graph. This observation is placed into\nthe index-theory context by factoring the Laplacian into two first-order\noperators, H =A*A, and relating the constant term to the index of A. An\nindependent consideration provides an index formula for any differential\noperator on a finite quantum graph in terms of the vertex conditions. It is\nfound also that the algebraic multiplicity of 0 as a root of the secular\ndeterminant of H is the sum of the nullities of A and A*."}, "authors": [{"name": "S. A. Fulling"}, {"name": "P. Let also $S$ be a finite part of\nits spectrum separated by gaps from the rest of the spectrum. We address here\nthe question of existence of a finite set of exponentially decaying Wannier\nfunctions $w_j(x)$ such that their $\\G$-shifts $w_{j,\\g}(x)=w_j(x-\\g)$ for\n$\\g\\in\\G$ span the whole spectral subspace corresponding to $S$. It was shown\nby D.~Thouless in 1984 that a topological obstruction sometimes exists to\nfinding exponentially decaying $w_{j,\\g}$ that form an orthonormal (or any)\nbasis of the spectral subspace. This obstruction has the form of non-triviality\nof certain finite dimensional (with the dimension equal to the number of\nspectral bands in $S$) analytic vector bundle (Bloch bundle). It was shown in\n2009 by one of the authors that it is always possible to find a finite number\n$l$ of exponentially decaying Wannier functions $w_j$ such that their\n$\\G$-shifts form a tight (Parseval) frame in the spectral subspace. This\nappears to be the best one can do when the topological obstruction is present.\nHere we significantly improve the estimate on the number of extra Wannier\nfunctions needed, showing that in physical dimensions the number $l$ can be\nchosen equal to $m+1$, i.e. only one extra family of Wannier functions is\nrequired. This is the lowest number possible in the presence of the topological\nobstacle. The result for dimension four is also stated (without a proof), in\nwhich case $m+2$ functions are needed.\n  The main result of the paper was announced without a proof in Bull. AMS, July\n2016.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $L$ be a periodic self-adjoint linear elliptic operator in $\\R^n$ with\ncoefficients periodic with respect to a lattice $\\G$, e.g. Schr\\\"{o}dinger\noperator $(i^{-1}\\partial/\\partial_x-A(x))^2+V(x)$ with periodic magnetic and\nelectric potentials $A,V$, or a Maxwell operator $\\nabla\\times\\varepsilon\n(x)^{-1}\\nabla\\times$ in a periodic medium. Let also $S$ be a finite part of\nits spectrum separated by gaps from the rest of the spectrum. We address here\nthe question of existence of a finite set of exponentially decaying Wannier\nfunctions $w_j(x)$ such that their $\\G$-shifts $w_{j,\\g}(x)=w_j(x-\\g)$ for\n$\\g\\in\\G$ span the whole spectral subspace corresponding to $S$. It was shown\nby D.~Thouless in 1984 that a topological obstruction sometimes exists to\nfinding exponentially decaying $w_{j,\\g}$ that form an orthonormal (or any)\nbasis of the spectral subspace. This obstruction has the form of non-triviality\nof certain finite dimensional (with the dimension equal to the number of\nspectral bands in $S$) analytic vector bundle (Bloch bundle). It was shown in\n2009 by one of the authors that it is always possible to find a finite number\n$l$ of exponentially decaying Wannier functions $w_j$ such that their\n$\\G$-shifts form a tight (Parseval) frame in the spectral subspace. This\nappears to be the best one can do when the topological obstruction is present.\nHere we significantly improve the estimate on the number of extra Wannier\nfunctions needed, showing that in physical dimensions the number $l$ can be\nchosen equal to $m+1$, i.e. only one extra family of Wannier functions is\nrequired. This is the lowest number possible in the presence of the topological\nobstacle. The result for dimension four is also stated (without a proof), in\nwhich case $m+2$ functions are needed.\n  The main result of the paper was announced without a proof in Bull. AMS, July\n2016."}, "authors": [{"name": "David Auckly"}, {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, "author": "Peter Kuchment", "arxiv_comment": "Submitted. arXiv admin note: text overlap with arXiv:0807.1342", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1704.05728v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1704.05728v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35Q40, 35P10, 47F05, 81V55, 65N25", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0912.1386v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0912.1386v1", "updated": "2009-12-08T01:55:35Z", "updated_parsed": [2009, 12, 8, 1, 55, 35, 1, 342, 0], "published": "2009-12-08T01:55:35Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 12, 8, 1, 55, 35, 1, 342, 0], "title": "On guided electromagnetic waves in photonic crystal waveguides", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "On guided electromagnetic waves in photonic crystal waveguides"}, "summary": "The paper addresses the issue of existence and confinement of electromagnetic\nmodes guided by linear defects in photonic crystals. A well known conjecture says\nthat generically (with respect to perturbations of the periodic potential) the\nextrema are attained by a single branch of the dispersion relation, are\nisolated, and have non-degenerate Hessian (i.e., dispersion relations are\ngraphs of Morse functions). The important notion of effective masses in solid\nstate physics, as well as Liouville property, Green's function asymptotics,\netc. hinge upon this property. The progress in proving this conjecture has been\nslow. It is natural to try to look at discrete problems, where the dispersion\nrelation is (in appropriate coordinates) an algebraic, rather than analytic,\nvariety. Such models are often used for computation in solid state physics (the\ntight binding model). Alas, counterexamples exist in some discrete situations.\nWe start establishing the following dichotomy: the non-degeneracy of extrema\neither fails or holds in the complement of a proper algebraic subset of the\nparameters.\n  The known counterexample has only two free parameters. This might be too\ntight for genericity to hold. We consider the maximal $Z^2$-periodic two-atomic\nnearest-cell interaction graph, with nine edges per unit cell and the discrete\n\"Laplace-Beltrami\" operator on it. We then use methods from computational and\ncombinatorial algebraic geometry to prove the genericity conjecture for this\ngraph. We show three different approaches to the genericity, which might be\nsuitable in various situations.\n  It is also proven in this case that adding more parameters does not destroy\nthe genericity result. We list all \"bad\" periodic subgraphs of the one we\nconsider and discover that in all these cases genericity fails for \"trivial\"\nreasons only.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "An old problem in mathematical physics deals with the structure of the\ndispersion relation of the Schr\\\"odinger operator $-\\Delta+V(x)$ in $R^n$ with\nperiodic potential near the edges of the spectrum. A well known conjecture says\nthat generically (with respect to perturbations of the periodic potential) the\nextrema are attained by a single branch of the dispersion relation, are\nisolated, and have non-degenerate Hessian (i.e., dispersion relations are\ngraphs of Morse functions). The important notion of effective masses in solid\nstate physics, as well as Liouville property, Green's function asymptotics,\netc. hinge upon this property. The progress in proving this conjecture has been\nslow. It is natural to try to look at discrete problems, where the dispersion\nrelation is (in appropriate coordinates) an algebraic, rather than analytic,\nvariety. Such models are often used for computation in solid state physics (the\ntight binding model). Alas, counterexamples exist in some discrete situations.\nWe start establishing the following dichotomy: the non-degeneracy of extrema\neither fails or holds in the complement of a proper algebraic subset of the\nparameters.\n  The known counterexample has only two free parameters. This might be too\ntight for genericity to hold. We consider the maximal $Z^2$-periodic two-atomic\nnearest-cell interaction graph, with nine edges per unit cell and the discrete\n\"Laplace-Beltrami\" operator on it. We then use methods from computational and\ncombinatorial algebraic geometry to prove the genericity conjecture for this\ngraph. We show three different approaches to the genericity, which might be\nsuitable in various situations.\n  It is also proven in this case that adding more parameters does not destroy\nthe genericity result. We list all \"bad\" periodic subgraphs of the one we\nconsider and discover that in all these cases genericity fails for \"trivial\"\nreasons only."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ngoc T. TAT\nand PAT represent probably the most developed of the several novel ``hybrid''\nmethods of medical imaging. These perturbations of the potential are then used as the data for the\nreconstruction of the conductivity. The present method does not rely on\n\"perfectly focused\" acoustic beams. Instead, more realistic propagating\nspherical fronts are utilized, and then the measurements that would correspond\nto perfect focusing are synthesized. In other words, we use \\emph{synthetic\nfocusing}. Numerical experiments with simulated data show that our techniques\nproduce high quality images, both in 2D and 3D, and that they remain accurate\nin the presence of high-level noise in the data. Local uniqueness and stability\nfor the problem also hold.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We propose and test stable algorithms for the reconstruction of the internal\nconductivity of a biological object using acousto-electric measurements.\nNamely, the conventional impedance tomography scheme is supplemented by\nscanning the object with acoustic waves that slightly perturb the conductivity\nand cause the change in the electric potential measured on the boundary of the\nobject. These perturbations of the potential are then used as the data for the\nreconstruction of the conductivity. The present method does not rely on\n\"perfectly focused\" acoustic beams. Instead, more realistic propagating\nspherical fronts are utilized, and then the measurements that would correspond\nto perfect focusing are synthesized. In other words, we use \\emph{synthetic\nfocusing}. Numerical experiments with simulated data show that our techniques\nproduce high quality images, both in 2D and 3D, and that they remain accurate\nin the presence of high-level noise in the data. Corbin"}, {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Peter Kuchment"}, "author": "Peter Kuchment", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1908.06222v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1908.06222v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35P99, 58J05, 58J90, 58Z05", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math-ph/0702035v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math-ph/0702035v2", "updated": "2007-02-14T17:39:26Z", "updated_parsed": [2007, 2, 14, 17, 39, 26, 2, 45, 0], "published": "2007-02-10T19:47:31Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 2, 10, 19, 47, 31, 5, 41, 0], "title": "On occurrence of spectral edges for periodic operators inside the\n  Brillouin zone", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "On occurrence of spectral edges for periodic operators inside the\n  Brillouin zone"}, "summary": "The article discusses the following frequently arising question on the\nspectral structure of periodic operators of mathematical physics (e.g.,\nSchroedinger, Maxwell, waveguide operators, etc.). Is it true that one can\nobtain the correct spectrum by using the values of the quasimomentum running\nover the boundary of the (reduced) Brillouin zone only, rather than the whole\nzone? Or, do the edges of the spectrum occur necessarily at the set of\n``corner'' high symmetry points? This is known to be true in 1D, while no\napparent reasons exist for this to be happening in higher dimensions. In many\npractical cases, though, this appears to be correct, which sometimes leads to\nthe claims that this is always true. There seems to be no definite answer in\nthe literature, and one encounters different opinions about this problem in the\ncommunity.\n  In this paper, starting with simple discrete graph operators, we construct a\nvariety of convincing multiply-periodic examples showing that the spectral\nedges might occur deeply inside the Brillouin zone. On the other hand, it is\nalso shown that in a ``generic'' case, the situation of spectral edges\nappearing at high symmetry points is stable under small perturbations. This\nexplains to some degree why in many (maybe even most) practical cases the\nstatement still holds.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The article discusses the following frequently arising question on the\nspectral structure of periodic operators of mathematical physics (e.g.,\nSchroedinger, Maxwell, waveguide operators, etc.). Is it true that one can\nobtain the correct spectrum by using the values of the quasimomentum running\nover the boundary of the (reduced) Brillouin zone only, rather than the whole\nzone? Or, do the edges of the spectrum occur necessarily at the set of\n``corner'' high symmetry points? This is known to be true in 1D, while no\napparent reasons exist for this to be happening in higher dimensions. In many\npractical cases, though, this appears to be correct, which sometimes leads to\nthe claims that this is always true. There seems to be no definite answer in\nthe literature, and one encounters different opinions about this problem in the\ncommunity.\n  In this paper, starting with simple discrete graph operators, we construct a\nvariety of convincing multiply-periodic examples showing that the spectral\nedges might occur deeply inside the Brillouin zone. On the other hand, it is\nalso shown that in a ``generic'' case, the situation of spectral edges\nappearing at high symmetry points is stable under small perturbations. This\nexplains to some degree why in many (maybe even most) practical cases the\nstatement still holds."}, "authors": [{"name": "J. M. Harrison"}, {"name": "P. Kuchment"}, {"name": "A. Math. Soc. Transl. v. 231, AMS, 2010, pp. 99-108", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0912.1386v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0912.1386v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35P99, 35Q60, 35Q72, 78A48", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1404.6840v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1404.6840v2", "updated": "2015-02-12T00:02:23Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 2, 12, 0, 2, 23, 3, 43, 0], "published": "2014-04-27T23:25:18Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 4, 27, 23, 25, 18, 6, 117, 0], "title": "A Finite Element Method With Singularity Reconstruction for Fractional\n  Boundary Value Problems", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A Finite Element Method With Singularity Reconstruction for Fractional\n  Boundary Value Problems"}, "summary": "We consider a two-point boundary value problem involving a Riemann-Liouville\nfractional derivative of order $\\al\\in (1,2)$ in the leading term on the unit\ninterval $(0,1)$. Generally the standard Galerkin finite element method can\nonly give a low-order convergence even if the source term is very smooth due to\nthe presence of the singularity term $x^{\\al-1}$ in the solution\nrepresentation. In order to enhance the convergence, we develop a simple\nsingularity reconstruction strategy by splitting the solution into a singular\npart and a regular part, where the former captures explicitly the singularity.\nWe derive a new variational formulation for the regular part, and establish\nthat the Galerkin approximation of the regular part can achieve a better\nconvergence order in the $L^2(0,1)$, $H^{\\al/2}(0,1)$ and $L^\\infty(0,1)$-norms\nthan the standard Galerkin approach, with a convergence rate for the recovered\nsingularity strength identical with the $L^2(0,1)$ error estimate. The\nreconstruction approach is very flexible in handling explicit singularity, and\nit is further extended to the case of a Neumann type boundary condition on the\nleft end point, which involves a strong singularity $x^{\\al-2}$. Extensive\nnumerical results confirm the theoretical study and efficiency of the proposed\napproach.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider a two-point boundary value problem involving a Riemann-Liouville\nfractional derivative of order $\\al\\in (1,2)$ in the leading term on the unit\ninterval $(0,1)$. Generally the standard Galerkin finite element method can\nonly give a low-order convergence even if the source term is very smooth due to\nthe presence of the singularity term $x^{\\al-1}$ in the solution\nrepresentation. In order to enhance the convergence, we develop a simple\nsingularity reconstruction strategy by splitting the solution into a singular\npart and a regular part, where the former captures explicitly the singularity.\nWe derive a new variational formulation for the regular part, and establish\nthat the Galerkin approximation of the regular part can achieve a better\nconvergence order in the $L^2(0,1)$, $H^{\\al/2}(0,1)$ and $L^\\infty(0,1)$-norms\nthan the standard Galerkin approach, with a convergence rate for the recovered\nsingularity strength identical with the $L^2(0,1)$ error estimate. The\nreconstruction approach is very flexible in handling explicit singularity, and\nit is further extended to the case of a Neumann type boundary condition on the\nleft end point, which involves a strong singularity $x^{\\al-2}$. Extensive\nnumerical results confirm the theoretical study and efficiency of the proposed\napproach."}, "authors": [{"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}, "author": "Zhi Zhou", "arxiv_comment": "23 pp. ESAIM: Math. Anal., to appear", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1404.6840v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1404.6840v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1410.0136v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1410.0136v1", "updated": "2014-10-01T07:52:55Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 10, 1, 7, 52, 55, 2, 274, 0], "published": "2014-10-01T07:52:55Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 10, 1, 7, 52, 55, 2, 274, 0], "title": "A finite element method for Dirichlet boundary control problems governed\n  by parabolic PDEs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A finite element method for Dirichlet boundary control problems governed\n  by parabolic PDEs"}, "summary": "Finite element approximations of Dirichlet boundary control problems governed\nby parabolic PDEs on convex polygonal domains are studied in this paper. The\nexistence of a unique solution to optimal control problems is guaranteed based\non very weak solution of the state equation and $L^2(0,T;L^2(\\Gamma))$ as\ncontrol space. For the numerical discretization of the state equation we use\nstandard piecewise linear and continuous finite elements for the space\ndiscretization of the state, while a dG(0) scheme is used for time\ndiscretization. The Dirichlet boundary control is realized through a space-time\n$L^2$-projection. We consider both piecewise linear, continuous finite element\napproximation and variational discretization for the controls and derive a\npriori $L^2$-error bounds for controls and states. We finally present numerical\nexamples to support our theoretical findings.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Finite element approximations of Dirichlet boundary control problems governed\nby parabolic PDEs on convex polygonal domains are studied in this paper. The\nexistence of a unique solution to optimal control problems is guaranteed based\non very weak solution of the state equation and $L^2(0,T;L^2(\\Gamma))$ as\ncontrol space. For the numerical discretization of the state equation we use\nstandard piecewise linear and continuous finite elements for the space\ndiscretization of the state, while a dG(0) scheme is used for time\ndiscretization. The Dirichlet boundary control is realized through a space-time\n$L^2$-projection. We consider both piecewise linear, continuous finite element\napproximation and variational discretization for the controls and derive a\npriori $L^2$-error bounds for controls and states. We finally present numerical\nexamples to support our theoretical findings."}, "authors": [{"name": "Wei Gong"}, {"name": "Michael Hinze"}, {"name": "Zhaojie Zhou"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhaojie Zhou"}, "author": "Zhaojie Zhou", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1410.0136v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1410.0136v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "49J20, 49K20, 65N15, 65N30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.07840v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.07840v1", "updated": "2015-02-27T09:49:17Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 2, 27, 9, 49, 17, 4, 58, 0], "published": "2015-02-27T09:49:17Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 2, 27, 9, 49, 17, 4, 58, 0], "title": "A simple finite element method for the boundary value problem with a\n  Riemann-Liouville derivative", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A simple finite element method for the boundary value problem with a\n  Riemann-Liouville derivative"}, "summary": "We consider a boundary value problem involving a Riemann-Liouville fractional\nderivative of order $\\alpha\\in (3/2,2)$ on the unit interval $(0,1)$. The\nstandard Galerkin finite element approximation converges slowly due to the\npresence of singularity term $x^{\\alpha-1}$ in the solution representation. In\nthis work, we develop a simple technique, by transforming it into a\nsecond-order two-point boundary value problem with nonlocal low order terms,\nwhose solution can reconstruct directly the solution to the original problem.\nThe stability of the variational formulation, and the optimal regularity pickup\nof the solution are analyzed. A novel Galerkin finite element method with\npiecewise linear or quadratic finite elements is developed, and $L^2(D)$ error\nestimates are provided. The approach is then applied to the corresponding\nfractional Sturm-Liouville problem, and error estimates of the eigenvalue\napproximations are given. Extensive numerical results fully confirm our\ntheoretical study.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider a boundary value problem involving a Riemann-Liouville fractional\nderivative of order $\\alpha\\in (3/2,2)$ on the unit interval $(0,1)$. The\nstandard Galerkin finite element approximation converges slowly due to the\npresence of singularity term $x^{\\alpha-1}$ in the solution representation. In\nthis work, we develop a simple technique, by transforming it into a\nsecond-order two-point boundary value problem with nonlocal low order terms,\nwhose solution can reconstruct directly the solution to the original problem.\nThe stability of the variational formulation, and the optimal regularity pickup\nof the solution are analyzed. A novel Galerkin finite element method with\npiecewise linear or quadratic finite elements is developed, and $L^2(D)$ error\nestimates are provided. The approach is then applied to the corresponding\nfractional Sturm-Liouville problem, and error estimates of the eigenvalue\napproximations are given. Extensive numerical results fully confirm our\ntheoretical study."}, "authors": [{"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "Raytcho Lazarov"}, {"name": "Xiliang Lu"}, {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}, "author": "Zhi Zhou", "arxiv_comment": "22 pp", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.07840v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1502.07840v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1505.06540v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1505.06540v1", "updated": "2015-05-25T05:02:11Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 5, 25, 5, 2, 11, 0, 145, 0], "published": "2015-05-25T05:02:11Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 5, 25, 5, 2, 11, 0, 145, 0], "title": "Penalty method with P1/P1 finite element approximation for the Stokes\n  equations under slip boundary condition", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Penalty method with P1/P1 finite element approximation for the Stokes\n  equations under slip boundary condition"}, "summary": "We consider the P1/P1 or P1b/P1 finite element approximations to the Stokes\nequations in a bounded smooth domain subject to the slip boundary condition. A\npenalty method is applied to address the essential boundary condition $u\\cdot n\n= g$ on $\\partial\\Omega$, which avoids a variational crime and simultaneously\nfacilitates the numerical implementation. A\npenalty method is applied to address the essential boundary condition $u\\cdot n\n= g$ on $\\partial\\Omega$, which avoids a variational crime and simultaneously\nfacilitates the numerical implementation. We give $O(h^{1/2} + \\epsilon^{1/2} +\nh/\\epsilon^{1/2})$-error estimate for velocity and pressure in the energy norm,\nwhere $h$ and $\\epsilon$ denote the discretization parameter and the penalty\nparameter, respectively. Then we investigate rank-jump behavior for\nhypergeometric systems H_A(\\beta) arising from a d x n integer matrix A and a\nparameter \\beta \\in \\CC^d. While originally derived\nusing symplectic methods, this result can also be understood through the\nspectral flow for a family of boundary conditions imposed on the nodal set, or,\nequivalently, a family of operators with delta function potentials supported on\nthe nodal set. Recent work has\nestablished conditions under which the underlying directed graph can be\nrecovered exactly the pairwise Path Correlation Data, namely, the set of\nweights of intersection of each pair of directed paths to and from each\nendpoint. Algorithmically, this enables us to consistently fused tree-based\nview of the set of network paths to and from each endpoint to reconstruct the\nunderlying network.\n  However, in practice the PCD is not consistently determined by path\nmeasurements. Statistical fluctuations give rise to inconsistent inferred\nweight of edges from measurement based on different endpoints, as do\noperational constraints on synchronization, and deviations from the underlying\npacket transmission model. Furthermore, ad hoc solutions to eliminate noise,\nsuch as pruning small weight inferred links, are hard to apply in a consistent\nmanner that preserves known end-to-end metric values.\n  This paper takes a unified approach to the problem of inconsistent weight\nestimation. We formulate two type of inconsistency: \\textsl{intrinsic}, when\nthe weight set is internally inconsistent, and \\textsl{extrinsic}, when they\nare inconsistent with a set of known end-to-end path metrics. In both cases we\nmap inconsistent weight to consistent PCD within a least-squares framework. We\nevaluate the performance of this mapping in composition with tree-based\ninference algorithms.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A communication network can be modeled as a directed connected graph with\nedge weights that characterize performance metrics such as loss and delay.\nNetwork tomography aims to infer these edge weights from their pathwise\nversions measured on a set of intersecting paths between a subset of boundary\nvertices, and even the underlying graph when this is not known. Recent work has\nestablished conditions under which the underlying directed graph can be\nrecovered exactly the pairwise Path Correlation Data, namely, the set of\nweights of intersection of each pair of directed paths to and from each\nendpoint. Algorithmically, this enables us to consistently fused tree-based\nview of the set of network paths to and from each endpoint to reconstruct the\nunderlying network.\n  However, in practice the PCD is not consistently determined by path\nmeasurements. Statistical fluctuations give rise to inconsistent inferred\nweight of edges from measurement based on different endpoints, as do\noperational constraints on synchronization, and deviations from the underlying\npacket transmission model. Furthermore, ad hoc solutions to eliminate noise,\nsuch as pruning small weight inferred links, are hard to apply in a consistent\nmanner that preserves known end-to-end metric values.\n  This paper takes a unified approach to the problem of inconsistent weight\nestimation. We formulate two type of inconsistency: \\textsl{intrinsic}, when\nthe weight set is internally inconsistent, and \\textsl{extrinsic}, when they\nare inconsistent with a set of known end-to-end path metrics. In both cases we\nmap inconsistent weight to consistent PCD within a least-squares framework. We\nevaluate the performance of this mapping in composition with tree-based\ninference algorithms."}, "authors": [{"name": "Mahmood Ettehad"}, {"name": "Nick Duffield"}, {"name": "Gregory Berkolaiko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Gregory Berkolaiko"}, "author": "Gregory Berkolaiko", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1908.03519v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1908.03519v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OC", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cs.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.07356v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.07356v2", "updated": "2016-12-17T05:11:10Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 12, 17, 5, 11, 10, 5, 352, 0], "published": "2016-03-23T20:55:37Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 3, 23, 20, 55, 37, 2, 83, 0], "title": "An elementary introduction to quantum graphs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "An elementary introduction to quantum graphs"}, "summary": "We describe some basic tools in the spectral theory of Schr\\\"odinger operator\non metric graphs (also known as \"quantum graph\") by studying in detail some\nbasic examples.
