We determine the limiting operator and study\nconvergence in a suitable norm resolvent sense. It is noteworthy that, as edge\nlengths tend to zero, standard Sobolev-type estimates break down, making\nconvergence fail for some graphs. We use a combination of functional-analytic\nbounds on the edges of the graph and Lagrangian geometry considerations for the\nvertex conditions to establish a sufficient condition for convergence. This\ncondition encodes an intricate balance between the topology of the graph and\nits vertex data. In particular, it does not depend on the potential, on the\ndifferences in the rates of convergence of the shrinking edges, or on the\nlengths of the unaffected edges.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We address the question of convergence of Schr\\\"odinger operators on metric\ngraphs with general self-adjoint vertex conditions as lengths of some of\ngraph's edges shrink to zero. We determine the limiting operator and study\nconvergence in a suitable norm resolvent sense. It is noteworthy that, as edge\nlengths tend to zero, standard Sobolev-type estimates break down, making\nconvergence fail for some graphs. We use a combination of functional-analytic\nbounds on the edges of the graph and Lagrangian geometry considerations for the\nvertex conditions to establish a sufficient condition for convergence. This\ncondition encodes an intricate balance between the topology of the graph and\nits vertex data. In particular, it does not depend on the potential, on the\ndifferences in the rates of convergence of the shrinking edges, or on the\nlengths of the unaffected edges."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gregory Berkolaiko"}, {"name": "Yuri Latushkin"}, {"name": "Selim Sukhtaiev"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Selim Sukhtaiev"}, "author": "Selim Sukhtaiev", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.aim.2019.06.017", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.aim.2019.06.017", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1806.00561v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1806.00561v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_journal_ref": "Advances in Mathematics v.352, 2019, Pages 632-669", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.SP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.SP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35P15, 34B09, 34B24, 34B45, 53D12, 47E05", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1111.4906v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1111.4906v2", "updated": "2012-05-04T08:27:08Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 5, 4, 8, 27, 8, 4, 125, 0], "published": "2011-11-21T15:57:46Z", "published_parsed": [2011, 11, 21, 15, 57, 46, 0, 325, 0], "title": "Universality in chaotic quantum transport: The concordance between\n  random matrix and semiclassical theories", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Universality in chaotic quantum transport: The concordance between\n  random matrix and semiclassical theories"}, "summary": "Electronic transport through chaotic quantum dots exhibits universal, system\nindependent, properties, consistent with random matrix theory. The quantum\ntransport can also be rooted, via the semiclassical approximation, in sums over\nthe classical scattering trajectories. Correlations between such trajectories\ncan be organized diagrammatically and have been shown to yield universal\nanswers for some observables. Here, we develop the general combinatorial\ntreatment of the semiclassical diagrams, through a connection to factorizations\nof permutations. We show agreement between the semiclassical and random matrix\napproaches to the moments of the transmission eigenvalues. The result is valid\nfor all moments to all orders of the expansion in inverse channel number for\nall three main symmetry classes (with and without time reversal symmetry and\nspin-orbit interaction) and extends to nonlinear statistics. This finally\nexplains the applicability of random matrix theory to chaotic quantum transport\nin terms of the underlying dynamics as well as providing semiclassical access\nto the probability density of the transmission eigenvalues.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Electronic transport through chaotic quantum dots exhibits universal, system\nindependent, properties, consistent with random matrix theory. The quantum\ntransport can also be rooted, via the semiclassical approximation, in sums over\nthe classical scattering trajectories. Correlations between such trajectories\ncan be organized diagrammatically and have been shown to yield universal\nanswers for some observables. Here, we develop the general combinatorial\ntreatment of the semiclassical diagrams, through a connection to factorizations\nof permutations. We show agreement between the semiclassical and random matrix\napproaches to the moments of the transmission eigenvalues. The result is valid\nfor all moments to all orders of the expansion in inverse channel number for\nall three main symmetry classes (with and without time reversal symmetry and\nspin-orbit interaction) and extends to nonlinear statistics. This finally\nexplains the applicability of random matrix theory to chaotic quantum transport\nin terms of the underlying dynamics as well as providing semiclassical access\nto the probability density of the transmission eigenvalues."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gregory Berkolaiko"}, {"name": "Jack Kuipers"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Jack Kuipers"}, "author": "Jack Kuipers", "arxiv_doi": "10.1103/PhysRevE.85.045201", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.85.045201", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1111.4906v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1111.4906v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "Refereed version. 5 pages, 4 figures", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Phys Rev E 85 (2012) 045201(R)", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "nlin.CD", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "nlin.CD", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cond-mat.mes-hall", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.04574v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.04574v2", "updated": "2018-09-13T04:13:22Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 9, 13, 4, 13, 22, 3, 256, 0], "published": "2018-04-12T15:36:51Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 4, 12, 15, 36, 51, 3, 102, 0], "title": "Graph Reconstruction from Path Correlation Data", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Graph Reconstruction from Path Correlation Data"}, "summary": "A communication network can be modeled as a directed connected graph with\nedge weights that characterize performance metrics such as loss and delay.\nNetwork tomography aims to infer these edge weights from their pathwise\nversions measured on a set of intersecting paths between a subset of boundary\nvertices, and even the underlying graph when this is not known. In particular,\ntemporal correlations between path metrics have been used infer composite\nweights on the subpath formed by the path intersection. We call these subpath\nweights the Path Correlation Data. In this paper we ask the following question:\nwhen can the underlying weighted graph be recovered knowing only the boundary\nvertices and the Path Correlation Data? We establish necessary and sufficient\nconditions for a graph to be reconstructible from this information, and\ndescribe an algorithm to perform the reconstruction. Subject to our conditions,\nthe result applies to directed graphs with asymmetric edge weights, and\naccommodates paths arising from asymmetric routing in the underlying\ncommunication network. We also describe the relationship between the graph\nproduced by our algorithm and the true graph in the case that our conditions\nare not satisfied.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A communication network can be modeled as a directed connected graph with\nedge weights that characterize performance metrics such as loss and delay.\nNetwork tomography aims to infer these edge weights from their pathwise\nversions measured on a set of intersecting paths between a subset of boundary\nvertices, and even the underlying graph when this is not known. In particular,\ntemporal correlations between path metrics have been used infer composite\nweights on the subpath formed by the path intersection. We call these subpath\nweights the Path Correlation Data. In this paper we ask the following question:\nwhen can the underlying weighted graph be recovered knowing only the boundary\nvertices and the Path Correlation Data? We establish necessary and sufficient\nconditions for a graph to be reconstructible from this information, and\ndescribe an algorithm to perform the reconstruction. Subject to our conditions,\nthe result applies to directed graphs with asymmetric edge weights, and\naccommodates paths arising from asymmetric routing in the underlying\ncommunication network. We also describe the relationship between the graph\nproduced by our algorithm and the true graph in the case that our conditions\nare not satisfied."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gregory Berkolaiko"}, {"name": "Nick Duffield"}, {"name": "Mahmood Ettehad"}, {"name": "Kyriakos Manousakis"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Kyriakos Manousakis"}, "author": "Kyriakos Manousakis", "arxiv_doi": "10.1088/1361-6420/aae798", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1361-6420/aae798", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.04574v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1804.04574v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "25 pages, 19 figures, submitted to IP Journal", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "94C15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.07245v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.07245v2", "updated": "2015-11-15T00:46:09Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 11, 15, 0, 46, 9, 6, 319, 0], "published": "2015-03-25T00:40:57Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 3, 25, 0, 40, 57, 2, 84, 0], "title": "Anomalous nodal count and singularities in the dispersion relation of\n  honeycomb graphs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Anomalous nodal count and singularities in the dispersion relation of\n  honeycomb graphs"}, "summary": "We study the nodal count of the so-called bi-dendral graphs and show that it\nexhibits an anomaly: the nodal surplus is never equal to 0 or $\\beta$, the\nfirst Betti number of the graph. According to the nodal-magnetic theorem, this\nmeans that bands of the magnetic spectrum (dispersion relation) of such graphs\ndo not have maxima or minima at the \"usual\" symmetry points of the fundamental\ndomain of the reciprocal space of magnetic parameters.\n  In search of the missing extrema we prove a necessary condition for a smooth\ncritical point to happen inside the reciprocal fundamental domain. Using this\ncondition, we identify the extrema as the singularities in the dispersion\nrelation of the maximal abelian cover of the graph (the honeycomb graph being\nan important example).\n  In particular, our results show that the anomalous nodal count is an\nindication of the presence of the conical points in the dispersion relation of\nthe maximal universal cover. Also, we discover that the conical points are\npresent in the dispersion relation of graphs with much less symmetry than was\nrequired in previous investigations.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study the nodal count of the so-called bi-dendral graphs and show that it\nexhibits an anomaly: the nodal surplus is never equal to 0 or $\\beta$, the\nfirst Betti number of the graph. According to the nodal-magnetic theorem, this\nmeans that bands of the magnetic spectrum (dispersion relation) of such graphs\ndo not have maxima or minima at the \"usual\" symmetry points of the fundamental\ndomain of the reciprocal space of magnetic parameters.\n  In search of the missing extrema we prove a necessary condition for a smooth\ncritical point to happen inside the reciprocal fundamental domain. The method is applicable to general\nbounded and unbounded graphs. The solutions are constructed by matching a\nlocalized large amplitude elliptic function on a single edge with an\nexponentially smaller remainder on the rest of the graph. This is done by\nstudying the intersections of Dirichlet-to-Neumann manifolds (nonlinear\nanalogues of Dirichlet-to-Neumann maps) corresponding to the two parts of the\ngraph. The perturbation is assumed to be\n\"along\" the eigenfunction $f$, namely $K_0f=0$. The eigenvalue $\\lambda^\\circ$\nbelongs to the spectra of both $H_0$ and $S$. Let $S$ have $\\sigma$ more\neigenvalues below $\\lambda^\\circ$ than $H_0$; $\\sigma$ is known as the spectral\nshift at $\\lambda^\\circ$.\n  We now allow the perturbation to vary in a suitable operator space and study\nthe continuation of the eigenvalue $\\lambda^\\circ$ in the spectrum of $H(K)=S +\nK^* K$. We show that the eigenvalue as a function of $K$ has a critical point\nat $K=K_0$ and the Morse index of this critical point is the spectral shift\n$\\sigma$. A version of this theorem also holds for some non-positive\nperturbations.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider a compact perturbation $H_0 = S + K_0^* K_0$ of a self-adjoint\noperator $S$ with an eigenvalue $\\lambda^\\circ$ below its essential spectrum\nand the corresponding eigenfunction $f$. The perturbation is assumed to be\n\"along\" the eigenfunction $f$, namely $K_0f=0$. The eigenvalue $\\lambda^\\circ$\nbelongs to the spectra of both $H_0$ and $S$. Let $S$ have $\\sigma$ more\neigenvalues below $\\lambda^\\circ$ than $H_0$; $\\sigma$ is known as the spectral\nshift at $\\lambda^\\circ$.\n  We now allow the perturbation to vary in a suitable operator space and study\nthe continuation of the eigenvalue $\\lambda^\\circ$ in the spectrum of $H(K)=S +\nK^* K$. It can be expressed as a double sum over the\nperiodic orbits on the graph. We propose a scheme which allows one to evaluate\nthe periodic orbit sum for a special family of graphs and thus to recover the\nexpression for the form factor predicted by the Random Matrix Theory. The\nscheme, although producing the expected answer, undercounts orbits of a certain\nstructure, raising doubts about an analogous summation recently proposed for\nquantum billiards.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The form factor of a quantum graph is a function measuring correlations\nwithin the spectrum of the graph. It can be expressed as a double sum over the\nperiodic orbits on the graph. We propose a scheme which allows one to evaluate\nthe periodic orbit sum for a special family of graphs and thus to recover the\nexpression for the form factor predicted by the Random Matrix Theory. The\nscheme, although producing the expected answer, undercounts orbits of a certain\nstructure, raising doubts about an analogous summation recently proposed for\nquantum billiards."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gregory Berkolaiko"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Gregory Berkolaiko"}, "author": "Gregory Berkolaiko", "arxiv_comment": "15 pages, 5 figures, to appear in \"Proceedings of Joint Summer\n  Research Conference on Quantum Graphs and Their Applications\", AMS\n  Contemporary Mathematics (G.Berkoaliko, R.Carlson, S.Fulling, P.Kuchment,\n  eds)", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/nlin/0604025v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/nlin/0604025v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "nlin.CD", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "nlin.CD", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.3526v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.3526v2", "updated": "2011-07-11T12:25:33Z", "updated_parsed": [2011, 7, 11, 12, 25, 33, 0, 192, 0], "published": "2010-12-16T07:43:01Z", "published_parsed": [2010, 12, 16, 7, 43, 1, 3, 350, 0], "title": "Transport moments beyond the leading order", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Transport moments beyond the leading order"}, "summary": "For chaotic cavities with scattering leads attached, transport properties can\nbe approximated in terms of the classical trajectories which enter and exit the\nsystem. With a semiclassical treatment involving fine correlations between such\ntrajectories we develop a diagrammatic technique to calculate the moments of\nvarious transport quantities. Namely, we find the moments of the transmission\nand reflection eigenvalues for systems with and without time reversal symmetry.\nWe also derive related quantities involving an energy dependence: the moments\nof the Wigner delay times and the density of states of chaotic Andreev\nbilliards, where we find that the gap in the density persists when subleading\ncorrections are included. Finally, we show how to adapt our techniques to\nnon-linear statistics by calculating the correlation between transport moments.\nIn each setting, the answer for the $n$-th moment is obtained for arbitrary $n$\n(in the form of a moment generating function) and for up to the three leading\norders in terms of the inverse channel number. Our results suggest patterns\nwhich should hold for further corrections and by matching with the low order\nmoments available from random matrix theory we derive likely higher order\ngenerating functions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "For chaotic cavities with scattering leads attached, transport properties can\nbe approximated in terms of the classical trajectories which enter and exit the\nsystem. With a semiclassical treatment involving fine correlations between such\ntrajectories we develop a diagrammatic technique to calculate the moments of\nvarious transport quantities. Namely, we find the moments of the transmission\nand reflection eigenvalues for systems with and without time reversal symmetry.\nWe also derive related quantities involving an energy dependence: the moments\nof the Wigner delay times and the density of states of chaotic Andreev\nbilliards, where we find that the gap in the density persists when subleading\ncorrections are included. Finally, we show how to adapt our techniques to\nnon-linear statistics by calculating the correlation between transport moments.\nIn each setting, the answer for the $n$-th moment is obtained for arbitrary $n$\n(in the form of a moment generating function) and for up to the three leading\norders in terms of the inverse channel number. Our results suggest patterns\nwhich should hold for further corrections and by matching with the low order\nmoments available from random matrix theory we derive likely higher order\ngenerating functions."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gregory Berkolaiko"}, {"name": "Jack Kuipers"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Jack Kuipers"}, "author": "Jack Kuipers", "arxiv_doi": "10.1088/1367-2630/13/6/063020", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1367-2630/13/6/063020", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.3526v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1012.3526v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "Refereed version. 43 pages, 10 figures", "arxiv_journal_ref": "New J Phys 13 (2011) 063020", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "nlin.CD", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "nlin.CD", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/cond-mat/0310735v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/cond-mat/0310735v2", "updated": "2004-01-14T00:04:37Z", "updated_parsed": [2004, 1, 14, 0, 4, 37, 2, 14, 0], "published": "2003-10-30T17:11:39Z", "published_parsed": [2003, 10, 30, 17, 11, 39, 3, 303, 0], "title": "Multiplicity of periodic solutions in bistable equations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Multiplicity of periodic solutions in bistable equations"}, "summary": "We study the number of periodic solutions in two first order non-autonomous\ndifferential equations both of which have been used to describe, among other\nthings, the mean magnetization of an Ising magnet in the time-varying external\nmagnetic field. When the strength of the external field is varied, the set of\nperiodic solutions undergoes a bifurcation in both equations. We prove that\ndespite profound similarities between the equations, the character of the\nbifurcation can be very different. This results in a different number of\ncoexisting stable periodic solutions in the vicinity of the bifurcation. Here we treat such an Andreev billiard semiclassically\nwhere the density of states is expressed in terms of the classical trajectories\nof electrons (and holes) that leave and return to the superconductor. We show\nhow classical orbit correlations lead to the formation of the hard gap, as\npredicted by random matrix theory in the limit of negligible Ehrenfest time\n$\\tE$, and how the influence of a finite $\\tE$ causes the gap to shrink.\nFurthermore, for intermediate $\\tE$ we predict a second gap below $E=\\pi\\hbar\n/2\\tE$ which would presumably be the clearest signature yet of $\\tE$-effects.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The connection of a superconductor to a chaotic ballistic quantum dot leads\nto interesting phenomena, most notably the appearance of a hard gap in its\nexcitation spectrum. 42, 53, 5, 202, 0], "title": "Surgery principles for the spectral analysis of quantum graphs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Surgery principles for the spectral analysis of quantum graphs"}, "summary": "We present a systematic collection of spectral surgery principles for the\nLaplacian on a metric graph with any of the usual vertex conditions (natural,\nDirichlet or $\\delta$-type), which show how various types of changes of a local\nor localised nature to a graph impact the spectrum of the Laplacian. Many of\nthese principles are entirely new, these include \"transplantation\" of volume\nwithin a graph based on the behaviour of its eigenfunctions, as well as\n\"unfolding\" of local cycles and pendants. In other cases we establish sharp\ngeneralisations, extensions and refinements of known eigenvalue inequalities\nresulting from graph modification, such as vertex gluing, adjustment of vertex\nconditions and introducing new pendant subgraphs.\n  To illustrate our techniques we derive a new eigenvalue estimate which uses\nthe size of the doubly connected part of a metric graph to estimate the\nspectral gap. Many of\nthese principles are entirely new, these include \"transplantation\" of volume\nwithin a graph based on the behaviour of its eigenfunctions, as well as\n\"unfolding\" of local cycles and pendants. On combinatorial graphs, one of the bounds is the\nwell-known inequality of Fiedler, of which we give a new variational proof. On\nquantum graphs, the corresponding bound generalizes a recent result of Band and\nL\\'evy. All proofs are general enough to yield corresponding estimates for the\n$p$-Laplacian and allow us to identify the minimizers.\n  Based on the Betti number of the graph, we also derive upper and lower bounds\non all eigenvalues which are \"asymptotically correct\", i.e. agree with the Weyl\nasymptotics for the eigenvalues of the quantum graph. In particular, the lower\nbounds improve the bounds of Friedlander on any given graph for all but\nfinitely many eigenvalues, while the upper bounds improve recent results of\nAriturk. On combinatorial graphs, one of the bounds is the\nwell-known inequality of Fiedler, of which we give a new variational proof. On\nquantum graphs, the corresponding bound generalizes a recent result of Band and\nL\\'evy. All proofs are general enough to yield corresponding estimates for the\n$p$-Laplacian and allow us to identify the minimizers.\n  Based on the Betti number of the graph, we also derive upper and lower bounds\non all eigenvalues which are \"asymptotically correct\", i.e. agree with the Weyl\nasymptotics for the eigenvalues of the quantum graph. Kennedy"}, {"name": "Pavel Kurasov"}, {"name": "Delio Mugnolo"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Delio Mugnolo"}, "author": "Delio Mugnolo", "arxiv_doi": "10.1088/1751-8121/aa8125", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1751-8121/aa8125", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.05264v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1702.05264v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.SP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.SP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "05C50, 34B45, 34L25, 35P15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1305.4875v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1305.4875v2", "updated": "2013-09-20T21:14:14Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 9, 20, 21, 14, 14, 4, 263, 0], "published": "2013-05-21T16:35:42Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 5, 21, 16, 35, 42, 1, 141, 0], "title": "Combinatorial theory of the semiclassical evaluation of transport\n  moments I: Equivalence with the random matrix approach", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Combinatorial theory of the semiclassical evaluation of transport\n  moments I: Equivalence with the random matrix approach"}, "summary": "To study electronic transport through chaotic quantum dots, there are two\nmain theoretical approachs. One involves substituting the quantum system with a\nrandom scattering matrix and performing appropriate ensemble averaging. The\nother treats the transport in the semiclassical approximation and studies\ncorrelations among sets of classical trajectories. There are established\nevaluation procedures within the semiclassical evaluation that, for several\nlinear and non-linear transport moments to which they were applied, have always\nresulted in the agreement with random matrix predictions. We prove that this\nagreement is universal: any semiclassical evaluation within the accepted\nprocedures is equivalent to the evaluation within random matrix theory.\n  The equivalence is shown by developing a combinatorial interpretation of the\ntrajectory sets as ribbon graphs (maps) with certain properties and exhibiting\nsystematic cancellations among their contributions. Remaining trajectory sets\ncan be identified with primitive (palindromic) factorisations whose number\ngives the coefficients in the corresponding expansion of the moments of random\nmatrices. The equivalence is proved for systems with and without time reversal\nsymmetry.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "To study electronic transport through chaotic quantum dots, there are two\nmain theoretical approachs. One involves substituting the quantum system with a\nrandom scattering matrix and performing appropriate ensemble averaging. The\nother treats the transport in the semiclassical approximation and studies\ncorrelations among sets of classical trajectories. There are established\nevaluation procedures within the semiclassical evaluation that, for several\nlinear and non-linear transport moments to which they were applied, have always\nresulted in the agreement with random matrix predictions. We prove that this\nagreement is universal: any semiclassical evaluation within the accepted\nprocedures is equivalent to the evaluation within random matrix theory.\n  The equivalence is shown by developing a combinatorial interpretation of the\ntrajectory sets as ribbon graphs (maps) with certain properties and exhibiting\nsystematic cancellations among their contributions. Remaining trajectory sets\ncan be identified with primitive (palindromic) factorisations whose number\ngives the coefficients in the corresponding expansion of the moments of random\nmatrices. The equivalence is proved for systems with and without time reversal\nsymmetry."}, "authors": [{"name": "G. Berkolaiko"}, {"name": "J. Kuipers"}], "author_detail": {"name": "J. It is\noften assumed that the extrema generating the band edges are non-degenerate.\n  This paper constructs a family of examples of $\\mathbb{Z}^3$-periodic quantum\ngraphs where the non-degeneracy assumption fails: the maximum of the first band\nis achieved along an algebraic curve of co-dimension 2. The example is robust\nwith respect to perturbations of edge lengths, vertex conditions and edge\npotentials. The simple idea behind the construction allows generalizations to\nmore complicated graphs and lattice dimensions. The curves along which extrema\nare achieved have a natural interpretation as moduli spaces of planar polygons.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Edges of bands of continuous spectrum of periodic structures arise as maxima\nand minima of the dispersion relation of their Floquet--Bloch transform. It is\noften assumed that the extrema generating the band edges are non-degenerate.\n  This paper constructs a family of examples of $\\mathbb{Z}^3$-periodic quantum\ngraphs where the non-degeneracy assumption fails: the maximum of the first band\nis achieved along an algebraic curve of co-dimension 2. The example is robust\nwith respect to perturbations of edge lengths, vertex conditions and edge\npotentials. The simple idea behind the construction allows generalizations to\nmore complicated graphs and lattice dimensions. The curves along which extrema\nare achieved have a natural interpretation as moduli spaces of planar polygons."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gregory Berkolaiko"}, {"name": "Minh Kha"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Minh Kha"}, "author": "Minh Kha", "arxiv_doi": "10.1007/s11005-020-01312-x", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s11005-020-01312-x", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2001.03566v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2001.03566v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "16 pages, 10 figures", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.SP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.SP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cond-mat.mes-hall", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cond-mat.mtrl-sci", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1405.5255v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1405.5255v2", "updated": "2015-12-01T16:19:10Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 12, 1, 16, 19, 10, 1, 335, 0], "published": "2014-05-20T22:45:28Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 5, 20, 22, 45, 28, 1, 140, 0], "title": "Inequivalent Factorizations of Permutations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Inequivalent Factorizations of Permutations"}, "summary": "Two factorizations of a permutation into products of cycles are equivalent if\none can be obtained from the other by repeatedly interchanging adjacent\ndisjoint factors. This paper studies the enumeration of equivalence classes\nunder this relation. We obtain closed form expressions for generating series of\ninequivalent minimal transitive factorizations of permutations having up to\nthree cycles, and also of permutations with four cycles when factors are\nrestricted to be transpositions. Our derivations rely on a new correspondence\nbetween inequivalent factorizations and acyclic alternating digraphs.\n  Strong similarities between the enumerative results derived here and\nanalogous ones for \"ordinary\" factorizations suggest that a unified theory\nremains to be discovered. This paper studies the enumeration of equivalence classes\nunder this relation. We obtain closed form expressions for generating series of\ninequivalent minimal transitive factorizations of permutations having up to\nthree cycles, and also of permutations with four cycles when factors are\nrestricted to be transpositions. Our derivations rely on a new correspondence\nbetween inequivalent factorizations and acyclic alternating digraphs.\n  Strong similarities between the enumerative results derived here and\nanalogous ones for \"ordinary\" factorizations suggest that a unified theory\nremains to be discovered. Taking the quotient isolates the part of the spectrum\nsupporting the chosen representation and reduces the complexity of the problem,\nhowever it is not uniquely defined. Here we present a computationally simple\nway of choosing a special basis for the space of intertwiners, allowing us to\nconstruct a quotient that reflects the structure of the original operator. This\nquotient construction generalizes previous definitions for discrete graphs,\nwhich either dealt with restricted group actions or only with the trivial\nrepresentation.\n  We also extend the method to quantum graphs, which simplifies previous\nconstructions within this context, answers an open question regarding\nself-adjointness and offers alternative viewpoints in terms of a scattering\napproach. Applications to isospectrality are discussed, together with numerous\nexamples and comparisons with previous results.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A finite dimensional operator that commutes with some symmetry group admits\nquotient operators, which are determined by the choice of associated\nrepresentation. Taking the quotient isolates the part of the spectrum\nsupporting the chosen representation and reduces the complexity of the problem,\nhowever it is not uniquely defined. Here we present a computationally simple\nway of choosing a special basis for the space of intertwiners, allowing us to\nconstruct a quotient that reflects the structure of the original operator. This\nquotient construction generalizes previous definitions for discrete graphs,\nwhich either dealt with restricted group actions or only with the trivial\nrepresentation.\n  We also extend the method to quantum graphs, which simplifies previous\nconstructions within this context, answers an open question regarding\nself-adjointness and offers alternative viewpoints in terms of a scattering\napproach. We study this distribution (more precisely, the\ndistribution of the \"nodal surplus\") for Laplacian eigenfunctions of a metric\ngraph. The existence of the distribution is established, along with its\nsymmetry. One consequence of the symmetry is that the graph's first Betti\nnumber can be recovered as twice the average nodal surplus of its\neigenfunctions. Furthermore, for graphs with disjoint cycles it is proven that\nthe distribution has a universal form --- it is binomial over the allowed range\nof values of the surplus. We study this distribution (more precisely, the\ndistribution of the \"nodal surplus\") for Laplacian eigenfunctions of a metric\ngraph. For chaotic systems, the statistics of the\nindividual delay times (whose average is the Wigner time delay) are thought to\nbe well described by random matrix theory. Here we present a semiclassical\nderivation showing the validity of random matrix results. In order to simplify\nthe semiclassical treatment, we express the moments of the delay times in terms\nof correlation functions of scattering matrices at different energies. In the\nsemiclassical approximation, the elements of the scattering matrix are given in\nterms of the classical scattering trajectories, requiring one to study\ncorrelations between sets of such trajectories. We describe the structure of\ncorrelated sets of trajectories and formulate the rules for their evaluation to\nthe leading order in inverse channel number. This allows us to derive a\npolynomial equation satisfied by the generating function of the moments. Along\nwith showing the agreement of our semiclassical results with the moments\npredicted by random matrix theory, we infer that the scattering matrix is\nunitary to all orders in the semiclassical approximation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The Wigner time delay is a measure of the time spent by a particle inside the\nscattering region of an open system. For chaotic systems, the statistics of the\nindividual delay times (whose average is the Wigner time delay) are thought to\nbe well described by random matrix theory. Here we present a semiclassical\nderivation showing the validity of random matrix results. In order to simplify\nthe semiclassical treatment, we express the moments of the delay times in terms\nof correlation functions of scattering matrices at different energies. In the\nsemiclassical approximation, the elements of the scattering matrix are given in\nterms of the classical scattering trajectories, requiring one to study\ncorrelations between sets of such trajectories. We describe the structure of\ncorrelated sets of trajectories and formulate the rules for their evaluation to\nthe leading order in inverse channel number. This allows us to derive a\npolynomial equation satisfied by the generating function of the moments. Along\nwith showing the agreement of our semiclassical results with the moments\npredicted by random matrix theory, we infer that the scattering matrix is\nunitary to all orders in the semiclassical approximation."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gregory Berkolaiko"}, {"name": "Jack Kuipers"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Jack Kuipers"}, "author": "Jack Kuipers", "arxiv_doi": "10.1088/1751-8113/43/3/035101", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1751-8113/43/3/035101", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0910.0060v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0910.0060v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "Refereed version. 18 pages, 5 figures", "arxiv_journal_ref": "J Phys A 43 (2010) 035101", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "nlin.CD", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "nlin.CD", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1412.8096v4", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1412.8096v4", "updated": "2016-12-12T04:44:52Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 12, 12, 4, 44, 52, 0, 347, 0], "published": "2014-12-28T01:59:14Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 12, 28, 1, 59, 14, 6, 362, 0], "title": "Symmetry and Dirac points in graphene spectrum", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Symmetry and Dirac points in graphene spectrum"}, "summary": "Existence and stability of Dirac points in the dispersion relation of\noperators periodic with respect to the hexagonal lattice is investigated for\ndifferent sets of additional symmetries. The following symmetries are\nconsidered: rotation by $2\\pi/3$ and inversion, rotation by $2\\pi/3$ and\nhorizontal reflection, inversion or reflection with weakly broken rotation\nsymmetry, and the case where no Dirac points arise: rotation by $2\\pi/3$ and\nvertical reflection.\n  All proofs are based on symmetry considerations. In particular, existence of\ndegeneracies in the spectrum is deduced from the (co)representation of the\nrelevant symmetry group. We find that\nwhen the permutation defining the perturbed ensemble has only long cycles, the\nanswer is universal and approaches the corresponding moment of the Circular\nUnitary Ensemble with a particularly fast rate: the error is of order $1/N^3$\nand the terms of orders $1/N$ and $1/N^2$ disappear due to cancellations. Following the generalization of the Vakhitov--Kolokolov\napproach, we show that the bifurcation of real eigenvalues from the origin is\ncompletely characterized by the Vakhitov--Kolokolov condition $dQ/d\\omega=0$\nand by the vanishing of the energy functional. We give the numerical data on\nthe linear stability in the generalized Gross--Neveu model and the generalized\nmassive Thirring model in the charge-subcritical, critical, and supercritical\ncases, showing the agreement with the Vakhitov--Kolokolov and the energy\nvanishing conditions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study the linear stability of localized modes in self-interacting spinor\nfields, analyzing the spectrum of the operator corresponding to linearization\nat solitary waves. We provide a unified\napproach to prove that every 2-connected subcubic graph on $n$ vertices and $m$\nedges with girth at least four or five, respectively, has an induced forest on\nat least $n-\\frac{2}{9}m$ or $n-\\frac{1}{5}m$ vertices, respectively, except\nfor finitely many exceptional graphs. Our results improve a result of Liu and\nZhao and are tight in the sense that the bounds are attained by infinitely many\n2-connected graphs. Equivalently, we prove that such graphs admit feedback\nvertex sets with size at most $\\frac{2}{9}m$ or $\\frac{1}{5}m$, respectively.\nThose exceptional graphs will be explicitly constructed, and our result can be\neasily modified to drop the 2-connectivity requirement.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we address the maximum number of vertices of induced forests\nin subcubic graphs with girth at least four or five. We provide a unified\napproach to prove that every 2-connected subcubic graph on $n$ vertices and $m$\nedges with girth at least four or five, respectively, has an induced forest on\nat least $n-\\frac{2}{9}m$ or $n-\\frac{1}{5}m$ vertices, respectively, except\nfor finitely many exceptional graphs. Equivalently, we prove that such graphs admit feedback\nvertex sets with size at most $\\frac{2}{9}m$ or $\\frac{1}{5}m$, respectively.\nThose exceptional graphs will be explicitly constructed, and our result can be\neasily modified to drop the 2-connectivity requirement."}, "authors": [{"name": "Tom Kelly"}, {"name": "Chun-Hung Liu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Chun-Hung Liu"}, "author": "Chun-Hung Liu", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.03855v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1603.03855v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.04559v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.04559v2", "updated": "2016-10-28T02:32:20Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 10, 28, 2, 32, 20, 4, 302, 0], "published": "2016-03-15T05:42:00Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 3, 15, 5, 42, 0, 1, 75, 0], "title": "Minimum Size of Feedback Vertex Sets of Planar Graphs of Girth at least\n  Five", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Minimum Size of Feedback Vertex Sets of Planar Graphs of Girth at least\n  Five"}, "summary": "A feedback vertex set of a graph is a subset of vertices intersecting all\ncycles. We provide tight upper bounds on the size of a minimum feedback vertex\nset in planar graphs of girth at least five. We prove that if $G$ is a\nconnected planar graph of girth at least five on $n$ vertices and $m$ edges,\nthen $G$ has a feedback vertex set of size at most $\\frac{2m-n+2}{7}$. By\nEuler's formula, this implies that $G$ has a feedback vertex set of size at\nmost $\\frac{m}{5}$ and $\\frac{n-2}{3}$. These results not only improve a result\nof Dross, Montassier and Pinlou and confirm the girth-5 case of one of their\nconjectures, but also make the best known progress towards a conjecture of\nKowalik, Lu\\v{z}ar and \\v{S}krekovski and solves the subcubic case of their\nconjecture. An important step of our proof is providing an upper bound on the\nsize of minimum feedback vertex sets of subcubic graphs with girth at least\nfive with no induced subdivision of members of a finite family of non-planar\ngraphs.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A feedback vertex set of a graph is a subset of vertices intersecting all\ncycles. We provide tight upper bounds on the size of a minimum feedback vertex\nset in planar graphs of girth at least five. We prove that if $G$ is a\nconnected planar graph of girth at least five on $n$ vertices and $m$ edges,\nthen $G$ has a feedback vertex set of size at most $\\frac{2m-n+2}{7}$. By\nEuler's formula, this implies that $G$ has a feedback vertex set of size at\nmost $\\frac{m}{5}$ and $\\frac{n-2}{3}$. The fractional chromatic number $\\chi_f(G)$ is the infimum of $a/b$ over\nall pairs of positive integers $a,b$ such that $G$ has an $(a:b)$-coloring.\nHeckman and Thomas conjectured that the fractional chromatic number of every\ntriangle-free graph $G$ of maximum degree at most three is at most 2.8. Hatami\nand Zhu proved that $\\chi_f(G) \\leq 3-3/64 \\approx 2.953$. Lu and Peng improved\nthe bound to $\\chi_f(G) \\leq 3-3/43 \\approx 2.930$. Recently, Ferguson, Kaiser\nand Kr\\'{a}l' proved that $\\chi_f(G) \\leq 32/11 \\approx 2.909$. In this paper,\nwe prove that $\\chi_f(G) \\leq 43/15 \\approx 2.867$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "An $(a:b)$-coloring of a graph $G$ is a function $f$ which maps the vertices\nof $G$ into $b$-element subsets of some set of size $a$ in such a way that\n$f(u)$ is disjoint from $f(v)$ for every two adjacent vertices $u$ and $v$ in\n$G$. The fractional chromatic number $\\chi_f(G)$ is the infimum of $a/b$ over\nall pairs of positive integers $a,b$ such that $G$ has an $(a:b)$-coloring.\nHeckman and Thomas conjectured that the fractional chromatic number of every\ntriangle-free graph $G$ of maximum degree at most three is at most 2.8. Hatami\nand Zhu proved that $\\chi_f(G) \\leq 3-3/64 \\approx 2.953$. Lu and Peng improved\nthe bound to $\\chi_f(G) \\leq 3-3/43 \\approx 2.930$. Recently, Ferguson, Kaiser\nand Kr\\'{a}l' proved that $\\chi_f(G) \\leq 32/11 \\approx 2.909$. The edge Roman\ndomination number of $G$, denoted by $\\gamma'_R(G)$, is the minimum weight\n$w(f) = \\sum_{e\\in E(G)} f(e)$ of an edge Roman dominating function $f$ of $G$.\nThis paper disproves a conjecture of Akbari, Ehsani, Ghajar, Jalaly Khalilabadi\nand Sadeghian Sadeghabad stating that if $G$ is a graph of maximum degree\n$\\Delta$ on $n$ vertices, then $\\gamma_R'(G) \\le \\lceil \\frac{\\Delta}{\\Delta+1}\nn \\rceil$. While the counterexamples having the edge Roman domination numbers\n$\\frac{2\\Delta-2}{2\\Delta-1} n$, we prove that $\\frac{2\\Delta-2}{2\\Delta-1} n +\n\\frac{2}{2\\Delta-1}$ is an upper bound for connected graphs. Furthermore, we\nprovide an upper bound for the edge Roman domination number of $k$-degenerate\ngraphs, which generalizes results of Akbari, Ehsani, Ghajar, Jalaly Khalilabadi\nand Sadeghian Sadeghabad. We also prove a sharp upper bound for subcubic\ngraphs.\n  In addition, we prove that the edge Roman domination numbers of planar graphs\non $n$ vertices is at most $\\frac{6}{7}n$, which confirms a conjecture of\nAkbari and Qajar. We also show an upper bound for graphs of girth at least five\nthat is 2-cell embeddable in surfaces of small genus. Finally, we prove an\nupper bound for graphs that do not contain $K_{2,3}$ as a subdivision, which\ngeneralizes a result of Akbari and Qajar on outerplanar graphs.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "An edge Roman dominating function of a graph $G$ is a function $f\\colon E(G)\n\\rightarrow \\{0,1,2\\}$ satisfying the condition that every edge $e$ with\n$f(e)=0$ is adjacent to some edge $e'$ with $f(e')=2$. The edge Roman\ndomination number of $G$, denoted by $\\gamma'_R(G)$, is the minimum weight\n$w(f) = \\sum_{e\\in E(G)} f(e)$ of an edge Roman dominating function $f$ of $G$.\nThis paper disproves a conjecture of Akbari, Ehsani, Ghajar, Jalaly Khalilabadi\nand Sadeghian Sadeghabad stating that if $G$ is a graph of maximum degree\n$\\Delta$ on $n$ vertices, then $\\gamma_R'(G) \\le \\lceil \\frac{\\Delta}{\\Delta+1}\nn \\rceil$. While the counterexamples having the edge Roman domination numbers\n$\\frac{2\\Delta-2}{2\\Delta-1} n$, we prove that $\\frac{2\\Delta-2}{2\\Delta-1} n +\n\\frac{2}{2\\Delta-1}$ is an upper bound for connected graphs. Furthermore, we\nprovide an upper bound for the edge Roman domination number of $k$-degenerate\ngraphs, which generalizes results of Akbari, Ehsani, Ghajar, Jalaly Khalilabadi\nand Sadeghian Sadeghabad. We also prove a sharp upper bound for subcubic\ngraphs.\n  In addition, we prove that the edge Roman domination numbers of planar graphs\non $n$ vertices is at most $\\frac{6}{7}n$, which confirms a conjecture of\nAkbari and Qajar. We also show an upper bound for graphs of girth at least five\nthat is 2-cell embeddable in surfaces of small genus. Finally, we prove an\nupper bound for graphs that do not contain $K_{2,3}$ as a subdivision, which\ngeneralizes a result of Akbari and Qajar on outerplanar graphs."}, "authors": [{"name": "Gerard J. Chang"}, {"name": "Sheng-Hua Chen"}, {"name": "Chun-Hung Liu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Chun-Hung Liu"}, "author": "Chun-Hung Liu", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1405.5622v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1405.5622v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "05C69, 05C35", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1206.5348v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1206.5348v2", "updated": "2013-02-23T21:24:13Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 2, 23, 21, 24, 13, 5, 54, 0], "published": "2012-06-23T01:31:28Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 6, 23, 1, 31, 28, 5, 175, 0], "title": "Linear colorings of subcubic graphs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Linear colorings of subcubic graphs"}, "summary": "A linear coloring of a graph is a proper coloring of the vertices of the\ngraph so that each pair of color classes induce a union of disjoint paths. In\nthis paper, we prove that for every connected graph with maximum degree at most\nthree and every assignment of lists of size four to the vertices of the graph,\nthere exists a linear coloring such that the color of each vertex belongs to\nthe list assigned to that vertex and the neighbors of every degree-two vertex\nreceive different colors, unless the graph is $C_5$ or $K_{3,3}$. This confirms\na conjecture raised by Esperet, Montassier, and Raspaud. Our proof is\nconstructive and yields a linear-time algorithm to find such a coloring.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A linear coloring of a graph is a proper coloring of the vertices of the\ngraph so that each pair of color classes induce a union of disjoint paths. This proves a conjecture of\nTrotignon and Vuskovic."}, "authors": [{"name": "Maria Chudnovsky"}, {"name": "Chun-Hung Liu"}, {"name": "Oliver Schaudt"}, {"name": "Sophie Spirkl"}, {"name": "Nicolas Trotignon"}, {"name": "Kristina Vuskovic"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Kristina Vuskovic"}, "author": "Kristina Vuskovic", "arxiv_doi": "10.1002/jgt.22441", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/jgt.22441", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1704.08104v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1704.08104v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1806.06212v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1806.06212v1", "updated": "2018-06-16T09:48:40Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 6, 16, 9, 48, 40, 5, 167, 0], "published": "2018-06-16T09:48:40Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 6, 16, 9, 48, 40, 5, 167, 0], "title": "Characterization of cycle obstruction sets for improper coloring planar\n  graphs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Characterization of cycle obstruction sets for improper coloring planar\n  graphs"}, "summary": "For nonnegative integers $k, d_1, \\ldots, d_k$, a graph is $(d_1, \\ldots,\nd_k)$-colorable if its vertex set can be partitioned into $k$ parts so that the\n$i$th part induces a graph with maximum degree at most $d_i$ for all $i\\in\\{1,\n\\ldots, k\\}$. A class $\\mathcal C$ of graphs is {\\it balanced\n$k$-partitionable} and {\\it unbalanced $k$-partitionable} if there exists a\nnonnegative integer $D$ such that all graphs in $\\mathcal C$ are $(D, \\ldots,\nD)$-colorable and $(0, \\ldots, 0, D)$-colorable, respectively, where the tuple\nhas length $k$.\n  A set $X$ of cycles is a {\\it cycle obstruction set} of a class $\\mathcal C$\nof planar graphs if every planar graph containing none of the cycles in $X$ as\na subgraph belongs to $\\mathcal C$. This paper characterizes all cycle\nobstruction sets of planar graphs to be balanced $k$-partitionable and\nunbalanced $k$-partitionable for all $k$; namely, we identify all\ninclusion-wise minimal cycle obstruction sets for all $k$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "For nonnegative integers $k, d_1, \\ldots, d_k$, a graph is $(d_1, \\ldots,\nd_k)$-colorable if its vertex set can be partitioned into $k$ parts so that the\n$i$th part induces a graph with maximum degree at most $d_i$ for all $i\\in\\{1,\n\\ldots, k\\}$. A class $\\mathcal C$ of graphs is {\\it balanced\n$k$-partitionable} and {\\it unbalanced $k$-partitionable} if there exists a\nnonnegative integer $D$ such that all graphs in $\\mathcal C$ are $(D, \\ldots,\nD)$-colorable and $(0, \\ldots, 0, D)$-colorable, respectively, where the tuple\nhas length $k$.\n  A set $X$ of cycles is a {\\it cycle obstruction set} of a class $\\mathcal C$\nof planar graphs if every planar graph containing none of the cycles in $X$ as\na subgraph belongs to $\\mathcal C$. This paper characterizes all cycle\nobstruction sets of planar graphs to be balanced $k$-partitionable and\nunbalanced $k$-partitionable for all $k$; namely, we identify all\ninclusion-wise minimal cycle obstruction sets for all $k$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ilkyoo Choi"}, {"name": "Chun-Hung Liu"}, {"name": "Sang-il Oum"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Sang-il Oum"}, "author": "Sang-il Oum", "arxiv_comment": "24 pages, 9 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1806.06212v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1806.06212v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.4428v4", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.4428v4", "updated": "2018-04-27T04:45:28Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 4, 27, 4, 45, 28, 4, 117, 0], "published": "2014-07-16T19:00:35Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 7, 16, 19, 0, 35, 2, 197, 0], "title": "Excluding subdivisions of bounded degree graphs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Excluding subdivisions of bounded degree graphs"}, "summary": "Let $H$ be a fixed graph. What can be said about graphs $G$ that have no\nsubgraph isomorphic to a subdivision of $H$? Grohe and Marx proved that such\ngraphs $G$ satisfy a certain structure theorem that is not satisfied by graphs\nthat contain a subdivision of a (larger) graph $H_1$. Dvo\\v{r}\\'ak found a\nclever strengthening---his structure is not satisfied by graphs that contain a\nsubdivision of a graph $H_2$, where $H_2$ has \"similar embedding properties\" as\n$H$. Building upon Dvo\\v{r}\\'ak's theorem, we prove that said graphs $G$\nsatisfy a similar structure theorem. Our structure is not satisfied by graphs\nthat contain a subdivision of a graph $H_3$ that has similar embedding\nproperties as $H$ and has the same maximum degree as $H$. This will be\nimportant in a forthcoming application to well-quasi-ordering.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $H$ be a fixed graph. What can be said about graphs $G$ that have no\nsubgraph isomorphic to a subdivision of $H$? Grohe and Marx proved that such\ngraphs $G$ satisfy a certain structure theorem that is not satisfied by graphs\nthat contain a subdivision of a (larger) graph $H_1$. Dvo\\v{r}\\'ak found a\nclever strengthening---his structure is not satisfied by graphs that contain a\nsubdivision of a graph $H_2$, where $H_2$ has \"similar embedding properties\" as\n$H$. Building upon Dvo\\v{r}\\'ak's theorem, we prove that said graphs $G$\nsatisfy a similar structure theorem. Our structure is not satisfied by graphs\nthat contain a subdivision of a graph $H_3$ that has similar embedding\nproperties as $H$ and has the same maximum degree as $H$. This will be\nimportant in a forthcoming application to well-quasi-ordering."}, "authors": [{"name": "Chun-Hung Liu"}, {"name": "Robin Thomas"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Robin Thomas"}, "author": "Robin Thomas", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.4428v4", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1407.4428v4", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.07912v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.07912v1", "updated": "2015-08-31T16:45:53Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 8, 31, 16, 45, 53, 0, 243, 0], "published": "2015-08-31T16:45:53Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 8, 31, 16, 45, 53, 0, 243, 0], "title": "Cycle lengths and minimum degree of graphs", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Cycle lengths and minimum degree of graphs"}, "summary": "There has been extensive research on cycle lengths in graphs with large\nminimum degree. In this paper, we obtain several new and tight results in this\narea. Let $G$ be a graph with minimum degree at least $k+1$. We prove that if\n$G$ is bipartite, then there are $k$ cycles in $G$ whose lengths form an\narithmetic progression with common difference two. For general graph $G$, we\nshow that $G$ contains $\\lfloor k/2\\rfloor$ cycles with consecutive even\nlengths and $k-3$ cycles whose lengths form an arithmetic progression with\ncommon difference one or two. In addition, if $G$ is 2-connected and\nnon-bipartite, then $G$ contains $\\lfloor k/2\\rfloor$ cycles with consecutive\nodd lengths.\n  Thomassen (1983) made two conjectures on cycle lengths modulo a fixed integer\n$k$: (1) every graph with minimum degree at least $k+1$ contains cycles of all\neven lengths modulo $k$; (2) every 2-connected non-bipartite graph with minimum\ndegree at least $k+1$ contains cycles of all lengths modulo $k$. These two\nconjectures, if true, are best possible. Our results confirm both conjectures\nwhen $k$ is even. And when $k$ is odd, we show that minimum degree at least\n$k+4$ suffices. This improves all previous results in this direction. Moreover,\nour results derive new upper bounds of the chromatic number in terms of the\nlongest sequence of cycles with consecutive (even or odd) lengths.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "There has been extensive research on cycle lengths in graphs with large\nminimum degree. In this paper, we obtain several new and tight results in this\narea. Let $G$ be a graph with minimum degree at least $k+1$. We prove that if\n$G$ is bipartite, then there are $k$ cycles in $G$ whose lengths form an\narithmetic progression with common difference two. For general graph $G$, we\nshow that $G$ contains $\\lfloor k/2\\rfloor$ cycles with consecutive even\nlengths and $k-3$ cycles whose lengths form an arithmetic progression with\ncommon difference one or two. In addition, if $G$ is 2-connected and\nnon-bipartite, then $G$ contains $\\lfloor k/2\\rfloor$ cycles with consecutive\nodd lengths.\n  Thomassen (1983) made two conjectures on cycle lengths modulo a fixed integer\n$k$: (1) every graph with minimum degree at least $k+1$ contains cycles of all\neven lengths modulo $k$; (2) every 2-connected non-bipartite graph with minimum\ndegree at least $k+1$ contains cycles of all lengths modulo $k$. These two\nconjectures, if true, are best possible. Our results confirm both conjectures\nwhen $k$ is even. And when $k$ is odd, we show that minimum degree at least\n$k+4$ suffices. This improves all previous results in this direction. Moreover,\nour results derive new upper bounds of the chromatic number in terms of the\nlongest sequence of cycles with consecutive (even or odd) lengths."}, "authors": [{"name": "Chun-Hung Liu"}, {"name": "Jie Ma"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Jie Ma"}, "author": "Jie Ma", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.07912v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1508.07912v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/funct-an/9605005v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/funct-an/9605005v2", "updated": "1996-09-12T12:37:55Z", "updated_parsed": [1996, 9, 12, 12, 37, 55, 3, 256, 0], "published": "1996-05-08T10:04:47Z", "published_parsed": [1996, 5, 8, 10, 4, 47, 2, 129, 0], "title": "Two applications of free entropy", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Two applications of free entropy"}, "summary": "Using Voiculsecu's free entropy, it is shown that the free group factors\nL(F_n) lack property C of Popa and that they lack finite multiplicity abelian\nsubalgebras. These have\nrecently been given a formulation in the setting of operator algebras as the\nSchur-Horn problem, where matrix algebras and diagonals are replaced\nrespectively by finite factors and maximal abelian self-adjoint subalgebras\n(masas). There is a special case of the problem, called the carpenter problem,\nwhich can be stated as follows: for a masa A in a finite factor M with\nconditional expectation E_A, can each x in A with 0 <= x <= 1 be expressed as\nE_A(p) for a projection p in M?\n  In this paper, we investigate these problems for various masas. We give\npositive solutions for the generator and radial masas in free group factors,\nand we also solve affirmatively a weaker form of the Schur-Horm problem for the\nCartan masa in the hyperfinite factor.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Two classical theorems in matrix theory, due to Schur and Horn, relate the\neigenvalues of a self-adjoint matrix to the diagonal entries. These have\nrecently been given a formulation in the setting of operator algebras as the\nSchur-Horn problem, where matrix algebras and diagonals are replaced\nrespectively by finite factors and maximal abelian self-adjoint subalgebras\n(masas). There is a special case of the problem, called the carpenter problem,\nwhich can be stated as follows: for a masa A in a finite factor M with\nconditional expectation E_A, can each x in A with 0 <= x <= 1 be expressed as\nE_A(p) for a projection p in M?\n  In this paper, we investigate these problems for various masas. We give\npositive solutions for the generator and radial masas in free group factors,\nand we also solve affirmatively a weaker form of the Schur-Horm problem for the\nCartan masa in the hyperfinite factor."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ken Dykema"}, {"name": "Junsheng Fang"}, {"name": "Don Hadwin"}, {"name": "Roger Smith"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Roger Smith"}, "author": "Roger Smith", "arxiv_comment": "15 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1110.6500v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1110.6500v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L10 (46L54)", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0905.0420v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0905.0420v3", "updated": "2010-03-27T17:52:47Z", "updated_parsed": [2010, 3, 27, 17, 52, 47, 5, 86, 0], "published": "2009-05-04T16:44:18Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 5, 4, 16, 44, 18, 0, 124, 0], "title": "Sum--of--squares results for polynomials related to the\n  Bessis--Moussa--Villani conjecture", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Sum--of--squares results for polynomials related to the\n  Bessis--Moussa--Villani conjecture"}, "summary": "We show that the polynomial S_{m,k}(A,B), that is the sum of all words in\nnoncommuting variables A and B having length m and exactly k letters equal to\nB, is not equal to a sum of commutators and Hermitian squares in the algebra\nR<X,Y> where X^2=A and Y^2=B, for all even values of m and k with 6 <= k <=\nm-10, and also for (m,k)=(12,6). This leaves only the case (m,k)=(16,8) open.\nThis topic is of interest in connection with the Lieb--Seiringer formulation of\nthe Bessis--Moussa--Villani conjecture, which asks whether the trace of\nS_{m,k}(A,B)) is nonnegative for all positive semidefinite matrices A and B.\nThese results eliminate the possibility of using \"descent + sum-of-squares\" to\nprove the BMV conjecture.\n  We also show that S_{m,4}(A,B) is equal to a sum of commutators and Hermitian\nsquares in R<A,B> when m is even and not a multiple of 4, which implies that\nthe trace of S_{m,4}(A,B) is nonnegative for all Hermitian matrices A and B,\nfor these values of m.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We show that the polynomial S_{m,k}(A,B), that is the sum of all words in\nnoncommuting variables A and B having length m and exactly k letters equal to\nB, is not equal to a sum of commutators and Hermitian squares in the algebra\nR<X,Y> where X^2=A and Y^2=B, for all even values of m and k with 6 <= k <=\nm-10, and also for (m,k)=(12,6). This leaves only the case (m,k)=(16,8) open.\nThis topic is of interest in connection with the Lieb--Seiringer formulation of\nthe Bessis--Moussa--Villani conjecture, which asks whether the trace of\nS_{m,k}(A,B)) is nonnegative for all positive semidefinite matrices A and B.\nThese results eliminate the possibility of using \"descent + sum-of-squares\" to\nprove the BMV conjecture.\n  We also show that S_{m,4}(A,B) is equal to a sum of commutators and Hermitian\nsquares in R<A,B> when m is even and not a multiple of 4, which implies that\nthe trace of S_{m,4}(A,B) is nonnegative for all Hermitian matrices A and B,\nfor these values of m."}, "authors": [{"name": "Benoit Collins"}, {"name": "Kenneth J. As an application, we\nshow that the class of direct sums of finitely many von Neumann algebras that\nare interpolated free group factors, hyperfinite II_1-factors, type I_n\nalgebras for n finite, and finite dimensional algebras, is closed under taking\nfree products with amalgamation over finite dimensional subalgebras."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ken Dykema"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Ken Dykema"}, "author": "Ken Dykema", "arxiv_comment": "13 pages. In this paper, we prove that also every DT-operator\nwhose spectrum is concentrated on a single point has a nontrivial, closed,\nhyperinvariant subspace. In fact, each such operator has a one-parameter family\nof them. It follows that every DT-operator generates the von Neumann algebra\nL(F_2) of the free group on two generators.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We previously introduced the class of DT--operators, which are modeled by\ncertain upper triangular random matrices, and showed that if the spectrum of a\nDT-operator is not reduced to a single point, then it has a nontrivial, closed,\nhyperinvariant subspace. In this paper, we prove that also every DT-operator\nwhose spectrum is concentrated on a single point has a nontrivial, closed,\nhyperinvariant subspace. In fact, each such operator has a one-parameter family\nof them. It follows that every DT-operator generates the von Neumann algebra\nL(F_2) of the free group on two generators."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ken Dykema"}, {"name": "Uffe Haagerup"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Uffe Haagerup"}, "author": "Uffe Haagerup", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0301112v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0301112v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/funct-an/9211013v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/funct-an/9211013v1", "updated": "1992-11-28T21:08:43Z", "updated_parsed": [1992, 11, 28, 21, 8, 43, 5, 333, 0], "published": "1992-11-28T21:08:43Z", "published_parsed": [1992, 11, 28, 21, 8, 43, 5, 333, 0], "title": "Free products of hyperfinite von Neumann algebras and free dimension", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Free products of hyperfinite von Neumann algebras and free dimension"}, "summary": "The free product of an arbitrary pair of finite hyperfinite von Neumann\nalgebras is examined, and the result is determined to be the direct sum of a\nfinite dimensional algebra and an interpolated free group factor $L(\\freeF_r)$.\nThe finite dimensional part depends on the minimal projections of the original\nalgebras and the \"dimension\", r, of the free group factor part is found using\nthe notion of free dimension. In the case where H is real and has\nfinite dimension, we give an algorithmic proof. Our main tool in the\ninfinite-dimensional case is a result we have proven which concerns the\ndecomposition of a positive invertible operator into a strongly converging sum\nof (not necessarily mutually orthogonal) self-adjoint projections. This\ndecomposition result implies the existence of tight frames in the ellipsoidal\nsurface determined by the positive operator. In the real or complex finite\ndimensional case, this provides an alternate (but not algorithmic) proof that\nevery such surface contains tight frames with every prescribed length at least\nas large as dim H. A corollary in both finite and infinite dimensions is that\nevery positive invertible operator is the frame operator for a spherical frame.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We prove the existence of tight frames whose elements lie on an arbitrary\nellipsoidal surface within a real or complex separable Hilbert space H, and we\nanalyze the set of attainable frame bounds. In the case where H is real and has\nfinite dimension, we give an algorithmic proof. Our main tool in the\ninfinite-dimensional case is a result we have proven which concerns the\ndecomposition of a positive invertible operator into a strongly converging sum\nof (not necessarily mutually orthogonal) self-adjoint projections. This\ndecomposition result implies the existence of tight frames in the ellipsoidal\nsurface determined by the positive operator. In the real or complex finite\ndimensional case, this provides an alternate (but not algorithmic) proof that\nevery such surface contains tight frames with every prescribed length at least\nas large as dim H. A corollary in both finite and infinite dimensions is that\nevery positive invertible operator is the frame operator for a spherical frame."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ken Dykema"}, {"name": "Dan Freeman"}, {"name": "Keri Kornelson"}, {"name": "David Larson"}, {"name": "Marc Ordower"}, {"name": "Eric Weber"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Eric Weber"}, "author": "Eric Weber", "arxiv_comment": "13 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0304387v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0304387v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "42C15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.07207v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.07207v1", "updated": "2015-03-24T21:08:38Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 3, 24, 21, 8, 38, 1, 83, 0], "published": "2015-03-24T21:08:38Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 3, 24, 21, 8, 38, 1, 83, 0], "title": "Synchronous correlation matrices and Connes' embedding conjecture", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Synchronous correlation matrices and Connes' embedding conjecture"}, "summary": "In a recent paper, the concept of synchronous quantum correlation matrices\nwas introduced and these were shown to correspond to traces on certain\nC*-algebras. It is an\nopen question whether all of these Horn inequalities must hold in all finite\nvon Neumann algebras, and this is related to Connes' embedding problem. For\neach choice of integers $1\\le r\\le n$, there is a set $T^n_r$ of Horn triples,\nand the Horn inequalities are in one-to-one correspondence with $\\cup_{1\\le\nr\\le n}T^n_r$. We consider a property P$_n$, analogous to one introduced by\nTherianos and Thompson in the case of matrices, amounting to the existence of\nprojections having certain properties relative to arbitrary flags, which\nguarantees that a given Horn inequality holds in all finite von Neumann\nalgebras. It is an open question whether all Horn triples in $T^n_r$ have\nproperty P$_n$. Certain triples in $T^n_r$ can be reduced to triples in\n$T^{n-1}_r$ by an operation we call {\\em TT--reduction}. We show that property\nP$_n$ holds for the original triple if property P$_{n-1}$ holds for the reduced\none. We then characterize the TT--irreducible Horn triples in $T^n_3$, for\narbitrary $n$, and for those LR--minimal ones (namely, those having\nLittlewood--Richardson coefficient equal to 1), we perform a construction of\nprojections with respect to flags in arbitrary von Neumann algebras in order to\nprove property P$_n$ for them. This shows that all LR--minimal triples in\n$\\cup_{n\\ge3}T^n_3$ have property P$_n$, and so that the corresponding Horn\ninequalities hold in all finite von Neumann algebras.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider the analogues of the Horn inequalities in finite von Neumann\nalgebras, which concern the possible spectral distributions of sums $a+b$ of\nself--adjoint elements $a$ and $b$ in a finite von Neumann algebra. It is an\nopen question whether all of these Horn inequalities must hold in all finite\nvon Neumann algebras, and this is related to Connes' embedding problem. For\neach choice of integers $1\\le r\\le n$, there is a set $T^n_r$ of Horn triples,\nand the Horn inequalities are in one-to-one correspondence with $\\cup_{1\\le\nr\\le n}T^n_r$. It is an open question whether all Horn triples in $T^n_r$ have\nproperty P$_n$. Certain triples in $T^n_r$ can be reduced to triples in\n$T^{n-1}_r$ by an operation we call {\\em TT--reduction}. We show that property\nP$_n$ holds for the original triple if property P$_{n-1}$ holds for the reduced\none.
