The method preserves all the known invariant domains of the\nEuler system: positivity of the density, positivity of the internal energy and\nthe local minimum principle on the specific entropy. The technique combines a\nfirst-order, invariant domain preserving, Guaranteed Maximum Speed method using\na Graph Viscosity (GMS-GV1) with an invariant domain violating, but entropy\nconsistent, high-order method. Invariant domain preserving auxiliary states,\nnaturally produced by the GMS-GV1 method, are used to define local bounds for\nthe high-order method which is then made invariant domain preserving via a\nconvex limiting process. Numerical tests confirm the second-order accuracy of\nthe new GMS-GV2 method in the maximum norm, where 2 stands for second-order.\nThe proposed convex limiting is generic and can be applied to other\napproximation techniques and other hyperbolic systems.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A new second-order method for approximating the compressible Euler equations\nis introduced. The method preserves all the known invariant domains of the\nEuler system: positivity of the density, positivity of the internal energy and\nthe local minimum principle on the specific entropy. The technique combines a\nfirst-order, invariant domain preserving, Guaranteed Maximum Speed method using\na Graph Viscosity (GMS-GV1) with an invariant domain violating, but entropy\nconsistent, high-order method. Invariant domain preserving auxiliary states,\nnaturally produced by the GMS-GV1 method, are used to define local bounds for\nthe high-order method which is then made invariant domain preserving via a\nconvex limiting process. Numerical tests confirm the second-order accuracy of\nthe new GMS-GV2 method in the maximum norm, where 2 stands for second-order.\nThe proposed convex limiting is generic and can be applied to other\napproximation techniques and other hyperbolic systems."}, "authors": [{"name": "Jean-Luc Guermond"}, {"name": "Murtazo Nazarov"}, {"name": "Bojan Popov"}, {"name": "Ignacio Tomas"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Ignacio Tomas"}, "author": "Ignacio Tomas", "arxiv_comment": "Submitted to SIAM SISC", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1710.00417v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1710.00417v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65M60, 65M12, 35L65, 35L45", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.00228v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.00228v1", "updated": "2016-01-02T22:14:40Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 1, 2, 22, 14, 40, 5, 2, 0], "published": "2016-01-02T22:14:40Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 1, 2, 22, 14, 40, 5, 2, 0], "title": "Hopf automorphisms and twisted extensions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Hopf automorphisms and twisted extensions"}, "summary": "We give some applications of a Hopf algebra constructed from a group acting\non another Hopf algebra A as Hopf automorphisms, namely Molnar's smash\ncoproduct Hopf algebra. This algebra plays the role of the coordinate ring of the\nresulting orbifold and serves as a substitute for the ring of invariant\npolynomials from the viewpoint of geometry and physics. Its Hochschild\ncohomology predicts various Hecke algebras and deformations of the orbifold. In\nthis article, we investigate the ring structure of the Hochschild cohomology of\nthe skew group algebra. We show that the cup product coincides with a natural\nsmash product, transferring the cohomology of a group action into a group\naction on cohomology. We express the algebraic structure of Hochschild\ncohomology in terms of a partial order on the group (modulo the kernel of the\naction). This partial order arises after assigning to each group element the\ncodimension of its fixed point space. We describe the algebraic structure for\nCoxeter groups, where this partial order is given by the reflection length\nfunction; a similar combinatorial description holds for an infinite family of\ncomplex reflection groups.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "When a finite group acts linearly on a complex vector space, the natural\nsemi-direct product of the group and the polynomial ring over the space forms a\nskew group algebra. This skew group algebra illuminates the resulting orbifold and serves as\na replacement for the ring of invariant polynomials, especially in the eyes of\ncohomology. One analyzes the Hochschild cohomology of the skew group algebra\nusing isomorphisms which convert between resolutions. We present an explicit\nchain map from the bar resolution to the Koszul resolution of the symmetric\nalgebra which induces various isomorphisms on Hochschild homology and\ncohomology, some of which have appeared in the literature before. This skew group algebra illuminates the resulting orbifold and serves as\na replacement for the ring of invariant polynomials, especially in the eyes of\ncohomology. One analyzes the Hochschild cohomology of the skew group algebra\nusing isomorphisms which convert between resolutions. We present an explicit\nchain map from the bar resolution to the Koszul resolution of the symmetric\nalgebra which induces various isomorphisms on Hochschild homology and\ncohomology, some of which have appeared in the literature before. This approach\nunifies previous results on homology and cohomology of both the symmetric\nalgebra and skew group algebra. We widen their viewpoint and consider a\nquotient of an algebra that is free over some (not necessarily semisimple)\nsubalgebra. We show that their theorem holds under a weaker hypothesis: We\nrequire the homogeneous version of the nonhomogeneous quadratic algebra to be\nthe skew group algebra (semidirect product algebra) of a finite group acting on\na Koszul algebra, obtaining conditions for the Poincare-Birkhoff-Witt property\nover (nonsemisimple) group algebras. We prove our main results by exploiting a\ndouble complex adapted from Guccione, Guccione, and Valqui (formed from a\nKoszul complex and a resolution of the group), giving a practical way to\nanalyze Hochschild cohomology and deformations of skew group algebras in\npositive characteristic. We widen their viewpoint and consider a\nquotient of an algebra that is free over some (not necessarily semisimple)\nsubalgebra. We show that their theorem holds under a weaker hypothesis: We\nrequire the homogeneous version of the nonhomogeneous quadratic algebra to be\nthe skew group algebra (semidirect product algebra) of a finite group acting on\na Koszul algebra, obtaining conditions for the Poincare-Birkhoff-Witt property\nover (nonsemisimple) group algebras. This algebra plays the role of the coordinate ring of the\nresulting orbifold and serves as a substitute for the ring of invariant\npolynomials from the viewpoint of geometry and physics. Its Hochschild\ncohomology predicts various Hecke algebras and deformations of the orbifold. In\nthis article, we investigate the ring structure of the Hochschild cohomology of\nthe skew group algebra. We show that the cup product coincides with a natural\nsmash product, transferring the cohomology of a group action into a group\naction on cohomology. We express the algebraic structure of Hochschild\ncohomology in terms of a partial order on the group (modulo the kernel of the\naction). This partial order arises after assigning to each group element the\ncodimension of its fixed point space. This skew group algebra illuminates the resulting orbifold and serves as\na replacement for the ring of invariant polynomials, especially in the eyes of\ncohomology. One analyzes the Hochschild cohomology of the skew group algebra\nusing isomorphisms which convert between resolutions. We present an explicit\nchain map from the bar resolution to the Koszul resolution of the symmetric\nalgebra which induces various isomorphisms on Hochschild homology and\ncohomology, some of which have appeared in the literature before. This skew group algebra illuminates the resulting orbifold and serves as\na replacement for the ring of invariant polynomials, especially in the eyes of\ncohomology. One analyzes the Hochschild cohomology of the skew group algebra\nusing isomorphisms which convert between resolutions. We present an explicit\nchain map from the bar resolution to the Koszul resolution of the symmetric\nalgebra which induces various isomorphisms on Hochschild homology and\ncohomology, some of which have appeared in the literature before. This approach\nunifies previous results on homology and cohomology of both the symmetric\nalgebra and skew group algebra. We widen their viewpoint and consider a\nquotient of an algebra that is free over some (not necessarily semisimple)\nsubalgebra. We show that their theorem holds under a weaker hypothesis: We\nrequire the homogeneous version of the nonhomogeneous quadratic algebra to be\nthe skew group algebra (semidirect product algebra) of a finite group acting on\na Koszul algebra, obtaining conditions for the Poincare-Birkhoff-Witt property\nover (nonsemisimple) group algebras. We prove our main results by exploiting a\ndouble complex adapted from Guccione, Guccione, and Valqui (formed from a\nKoszul complex and a resolution of the group), giving a practical way to\nanalyze Hochschild cohomology and deformations of skew group algebras in\npositive characteristic. We widen their viewpoint and consider a\nquotient of an algebra that is free over some (not necessarily semisimple)\nsubalgebra. We show that their theorem holds under a weaker hypothesis: We\nrequire the homogeneous version of the nonhomogeneous quadratic algebra to be\nthe skew group algebra (semidirect product algebra) of a finite group acting on\na Koszul algebra, obtaining conditions for the Poincare-Birkhoff-Witt property\nover (nonsemisimple) group algebras. We study this structure for the Hochschild\ncohomology of the skew group algebra formed by a finite group acting on an\nalgebra by automorphisms. We examine the Gerstenhaber bracket with a view\ntoward deformations and developing bracket formulas. We then focus on the\nlinear group actions and polynomial algebras that arise in orbifold theory and\nrepresentation theory; deformations in this context include graded Hecke\nalgebras and symplectic reflection algebras. We\ndiscuss the explicit computation of certain types of invariants under\ncentralizer subgroups, focusing on the infinite family of complex reflection\ngroups G(r,p,n) to illustrate our ideas. Resulting formulas for Hochschild\ntwo-cocycles give information about deformations of S(V)#G and, in particular,\nabout graded Hecke algebras. We\ndiscuss the explicit computation of certain types of invariants under\ncentralizer subgroups, focusing on the infinite family of complex reflection\ngroups G(r,p,n) to illustrate our ideas. Resulting formulas for Hochschild\ntwo-cocycles give information about deformations of S(V)#G and, in particular,\nabout graded Hecke algebras. When the characteristic of the underlying\nfield divides the order of the group, a new type of deformation emerges that\ndoes not occur in characteristic zero. This analogue of Lusztig's graded affine\nHecke algebra for positive characteristic can not be forged from the template\nof symplectic reflection and related algebras as originally crafted by\nDrinfeld. By contrast, we show that in characteristic zero, for arbitrary\nfinite groups, a Lusztig-type deformation is always isomorphic to a\nDrinfeld-type deformation. This analogue of Lusztig's graded affine\nHecke algebra for positive characteristic can not be forged from the template\nof symplectic reflection and related algebras as originally crafted by\nDrinfeld. By contrast, we show that in characteristic zero, for arbitrary\nfinite groups, a Lusztig-type deformation is always isomorphic to a\nDrinfeld-type deformation. Our\nstrategy has three major steps. We first reduce the problem to the finite\ngeneration of cohomology of finite dimensional Nichols algebras of diagonal\ntype. For the Nichols algebras we do a detailed analysis of cohomology via the\nAnick resolution reducing the problem further to specific combinatorial\nproperties. Finally, to check these properties we turn to the classification of\nNichols algebras of diagonal type due to Heckenberger. In this paper we\ncomplete the verification of these combinatorial properties for major\nparametric families, including Nichols algebras of Cartan and super types and\ndevelop all the theoretical foundations necessary for the case-by-case\nanalysis. The remaining discrete families are addressed in a separate\npublication. Our\nstrategy has three major steps. We first reduce the problem to the finite\ngeneration of cohomology of finite dimensional Nichols algebras of diagonal\ntype. For the Nichols algebras we do a detailed analysis of cohomology via the\nAnick resolution reducing the problem further to specific combinatorial\nproperties. Finally, to check these properties we turn to the classification of\nNichols algebras of diagonal type due to Heckenberger. In this paper we\ncomplete the verification of these combinatorial properties for major\nparametric families, including Nichols algebras of Cartan and super types and\ndevelop all the theoretical foundations necessary for the case-by-case\nanalysis. They simultaneously generalize Weyl algebras, graded (or\nDrinfeld) Hecke algebras, rational Cherednik algebras, symplectic reflection\nalgebras, and universal enveloping algebras of Lie algebras with group actions.\nWe give necessary and sufficient conditions on defining parameters to obtain\nDrinfeld orbifold algebras in two general formats, both algebraic and\nhomological. We explain the connection between Hochschild cohomology and a\nPoincare-Birkhoff-Witt property explicitly (using Gerstenhaber brackets). We\nalso classify those deformations of skew group algebras which arise as Drinfeld\norbifold algebras and give applications for abelian groups.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We define Drinfeld orbifold algebras as filtered algebras deforming the skew\ngroup algebra (semi-direct product) arising from the action of a finite group\non a polynomial ring. They simultaneously generalize Weyl algebras, graded (or\nDrinfeld) Hecke algebras, rational Cherednik algebras, symplectic reflection\nalgebras, and universal enveloping algebras of Lie algebras with group actions.\nWe give necessary and sufficient conditions on defining parameters to obtain\nDrinfeld orbifold algebras in two general formats, both algebraic and\nhomological. We explain the connection between Hochschild cohomology and a\nPoincare-Birkhoff-Witt property explicitly (using Gerstenhaber brackets). The structure group of $X$ is the abelian group of equivalence\nclasses of all pairs $(f, M)$ such that $M$ is a closed oriented manifold and\n$f\\colon M \\to X$ is an orientation-preserving homotopy equivalence. The main\npurpose of this article is to prove that a higher rho invariant defines a group\nhomomorphism from the topological structure group of $X$ to the $C^*$-algebraic\nstructure group of $X$. In fact, we introduce a higher rho invariant map on the\nhomology manifold structure group of a closed oriented connected\n$\\textit{topological}$ manifold, and prove its additivity. This higher rho\ninvariant map restricts to the higher rho invariant map on the topological\nstructure group. More generally, the same techniques developed in this paper\ncan be applied to define a higher rho invariant map on the homology manifold\nstructure group of a closed oriented connected $\\textit{homology}$ manifold. As\nan application, we use the additivity of the higher rho invariant map to study\nnon-rigidity of topological manifolds. More precisely, we give a lower bound\nfor the free rank of the $\\textit{algebraically reduced}$ structure group of\n$X$ by the number of torsion elements in $\\pi_1 X$. Here the algebraic reduced\nstructure group of $X$ is the quotient of the topological structure group of\n$X$ modulo a certain action of self-homotopy equivalences of $X$. We also\nintroduce a notion of homological higher rho invariant, which can be used to\ndetect many elements in the structure group of a closed oriented topological\nmanifold, even when the fundamental group of the manifold is torsion free. In\nparticular, we apply this homological higher rho invariant to show that the\nstructure group is not finitely generated for a class of manifolds.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $X$ be a closed oriented connected topological manifold of dimension\n$n\\geq 5$. The main\npurpose of this article is to prove that a higher rho invariant defines a group\nhomomorphism from the topological structure group of $X$ to the $C^*$-algebraic\nstructure group of $X$. In fact, we introduce a higher rho invariant map on the\nhomology manifold structure group of a closed oriented connected\n$\\textit{topological}$ manifold, and prove its additivity. The group of all diffeomorphisms of the\nmanifold naturally acts on P(M). The moduli group of positive scalar curvature\nmetrics is defined to be the quotient abelian group of this action, i.e. the\ncoinvariant of the action. The moduli group measures the size of the moduli\nspace of positive scalar curvature metrics on M. The higher rho\ninvariant is a secondary invariant and is closely related to positive scalar\ncurvature problems. The main result of the paper connects the higher index of\nthe Dirac operator on a spin manifold with boundary to the higher rho invariant\nof the Dirac operator on the boundary, where the boundary is endowed with a\npositive scalar curvature metric. Our result extends a theorem of Piazza and\nSchick.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we use localization algebras to study higher rho invariants of\nclosed spin manifolds with positive scalar curvature metrics. The higher rho\ninvariant is a secondary invariant and is closely related to positive scalar\ncurvature problems. The main result of the paper connects the higher index of\nthe Dirac operator on a spin manifold with boundary to the higher rho invariant\nof the Dirac operator on the boundary, where the boundary is endowed with a\npositive scalar curvature metric. For every two\nmetrics of positive scalar curvature on a closed manifold and a Galois cover of\nthe manifold, we define a secondary higher index class. "Multiparking Functions, Graph Searching, and the Tutte Polynomial", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Multiparking Functions, Graph Searching, and the Tutte Polynomial"}, "summary": "A parking function of length n is a sequence (b_1, b_2,..., b_n) of\nnonnegative integers whose nondecreasing rearrangement (a_1, a_2,...,a_n) has\nthe property that a_i < i for every i. A well-known result about parking\nfunctions is that the polynomial P_n(q), which enumerates the complements of\nparking functions by the sum of their terms, is the generating function for the\nnumber of connected graphs by the number of excess edges when evaluated at\n(1+q). In this paper we extend this result to arbitrary connected graphs G. In\ngeneral the polynomial that encodes information about subgraphs of G is the\nTutte polynomial, which is the generating function for two parameters, namely\nthe internal and external activities, associated with the spanning trees of G.\nWe define G-multiparking functions, which generalize the G-parking functions\nthat Postnikov and Shapiro introduced in the study of certain quotients of the\npolynomial ring. We construct a family of algorithmic bijections between the\nspanning forests of a graph G and the G-multiparking functions. In particular,\nthe bijection induced by the breadth-first search leads to a new\ncharacterization of external activity, and hence a representation of Tutte\npolynomial by the reversed sum of G-multiparking functions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A parking function of length n is a sequence (b_1, b_2,..., b_n) of\nnonnegative integers whose nondecreasing rearrangement (a_1, a_2,...,a_n) has\nthe property that a_i < i for every i. A well-known result about parking\nfunctions is that the polynomial P_n(q), which enumerates the complements of\nparking functions by the sum of their terms, is the generating function for the\nnumber of connected graphs by the number of excess edges when evaluated at\n(1+q). In this paper we extend this result to arbitrary connected graphs G. In\ngeneral the polynomial that encodes information about subgraphs of G is the\nTutte polynomial, which is the generating function for two parameters, namely\nthe internal and external activities, associated with the spanning trees of G.\nWe define G-multiparking functions, which generalize the G-parking functions\nthat Postnikov and Shapiro introduced in the study of certain quotients of the\npolynomial ring. We construct a family of algorithmic bijections between the\nspanning forests of a graph G and the G-multiparking functions. In particular,\nthe bijection induced by the breadth-first search leads to a new\ncharacterization of external activity, and hence a representation of Tutte\npolynomial by the reversed sum of G-multiparking functions."}, "authors": [{"name": "Dimitrije Kostic"}, {"name": "Catherine Yan"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Catherine Yan"}, "author": "Catherine Yan", "arxiv_comment": "28 pages,9 figures, submitted to Advances in Applied Mathematics", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0607602v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0607602v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "05C30, 05C05 (Primary)", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1403.6223v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1403.6223v1", "updated": "2014-03-25T03:15:40Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 3, 25, 3, 15, 40, 1, 84, 0], "published": "2014-03-25T03:15:40Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 3, 25, 3, 15, 40, 1, 84, 0], "title": "Maximal increasing sequences in fillings of almost-moon polyominoes", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Maximal increasing sequences in fillings of almost-moon polyominoes"}, "summary": "It was proved by Rubey that the number of fillings with zeros and ones of a\ngiven moon polyomino that do not contain a northeast chain of size $k$ depends\nonly on the set of columns of the polyomino, but not the shape of the\npolyomino. Rubey's proof is an adaption of jeu de taquin and promotion for\narbitrary fillings of moon polyominoes. In this paper we present a bijective\nproof for this result by considering fillings of almost-moon polyominoes, which\nare moon polyominoes after removing one of the rows. Explicitly, we construct a\nbijection which preserves the size of the largest northeast chains of the\nfillings when two adjacent rows of the polyomino are exchanged. This bijection\nalso preserves the column sum of the fillings. Using a bijection between partitions and vacillating\ntableaux, we show that if we fix the sets of minimal block elements and maximal\nblock elements, the crossing number and the nesting number of partitions have a\nsymmetric joint distribution. It follows that the crossing numbers and the\nnesting numbers are distributed symmetrically over all partitions of $[n]$, as\nwell as over all matchings on $[2n]$. As a corollary, the number of\n$k$-noncrossing partitions is equal to the number of $k$-nonnesting partitions.\nThe same is also true for matchings. An application is given to the enumeration\nof matchings with no $k$-crossing (or with no $k$-nesting).", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We present results on the enumeration of crossings and nestings for matchings\nand set partitions. Using a bijection between partitions and vacillating\ntableaux, we show that if we fix the sets of minimal block elements and maximal\nblock elements, the crossing number and the nesting number of partitions have a\nsymmetric joint distribution. It follows that the crossing numbers and the\nnesting numbers are distributed symmetrically over all partitions of $[n]$, as\nwell as over all matchings on $[2n]$. As a corollary, the number of\n$k$-noncrossing partitions is equal to the number of $k$-nonnesting partitions.\nThe same is also true for matchings. The Apollonian\n  Group", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Apollonian Circle Packings: Geometry and Group Theory I. The Apollonian\n  Group"}, "summary": "Apollonian circle packings arise by repeatedly filling the interstices\nbetween four mutually tangent circles with further tangent circles. We observe\nthat there exist Apollonian packings which have strong integrality properties,\nin which all circles in the packing have integer curvatures and rational\ncenters such that (curvature)$\\times$(center) is an integer vector. This series\nof papers explain such properties. A {\\em Descartes configuration} is a set of\nfour mutually tangent circles with disjoint interiors. We describe the space of\nall Descartes configurations using a coordinate system $\\sM_\\DD$ consisting of\nthose $4 \\times 4$ real matrices $\\bW$ with $\\bW^T \\bQ_{D} \\bW = \\bQ_{W}$ where\n$\\bQ_D$ is the matrix of the Descartes quadratic form $Q_D= x_1^2 + x_2^2+\nx_3^2 + x_4^2 -{1/2}(x_1 +x_2 +x_3 + x_4)^2$ and $\\bQ_W$ of the quadratic form\n$Q_W = -8x_1x_2 + 2x_3^2 + 2x_4^2$. There are natural group actions on the\nparameter space $\\sM_\\DD$. We observe that the Descartes configurations in each\nApollonian packing form an orbit under a certain finitely generated discrete\ngroup, the {\\em Apollonian group}. This group consists of $4 \\times 4$ integer\nmatrices, and its integrality properties lead to the integrality properties\nobserved in some Apollonian circle packings. We introduce two more related\nfinitely generated groups, the dual Apollonian group and the super-Apollonian\ngroup, which have nice geometrically interpretations. We show these groups are\nhyperbolic Coxeter groups.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Apollonian circle packings arise by repeatedly filling the interstices\nbetween four mutually tangent circles with further tangent circles. We observe\nthat there exist Apollonian packings which have strong integrality properties,\nin which all circles in the packing have integer curvatures and rational\ncenters such that (curvature)$\\times$(center) is an integer vector. This series\nof papers explain such properties. A {\\em Descartes configuration} is a set of\nfour mutually tangent circles with disjoint interiors. We describe the space of\nall Descartes configurations using a coordinate system $\\sM_\\DD$ consisting of\nthose $4 \\times 4$ real matrices $\\bW$ with $\\bW^T \\bQ_{D} \\bW = \\bQ_{W}$ where\n$\\bQ_D$ is the matrix of the Descartes quadratic form $Q_D= x_1^2 + x_2^2+\nx_3^2 + x_4^2 -{1/2}(x_1 +x_2 +x_3 + x_4)^2$ and $\\bQ_W$ of the quadratic form\n$Q_W = -8x_1x_2 + 2x_3^2 + 2x_4^2$. There are natural group actions on the\nparameter space $\\sM_\\DD$. We observe that the Descartes configurations in each\nApollonian packing form an orbit under a certain finitely generated discrete\ngroup, the {\\em Apollonian group}. This group consists of $4 \\times 4$ integer\nmatrices, and its integrality properties lead to the integrality properties\nobserved in some Apollonian circle packings. We introduce two more related\nfinitely generated groups, the dual Apollonian group and the super-Apollonian\ngroup, which have nice geometrically interpretations. We show these groups are\nhyperbolic Coxeter groups."}, "authors": [{"name": "R. L. Graham"}, {"name": "J. C. Lagarias"}, {"name": "C. L. Mallows"}, {"name": "A. R. Wilks"}, {"name": "C. H. Yan"}], "author_detail": {"name": "C. H. Yan"}, "author": "C. H. Yan", "arxiv_comment": "42 pages, 11 figures. Slight revision on March\n  10, 2005", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Discrete and Computational Geometry, 34: 547-585(2005)", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0010298v5", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0010298v5", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.MG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.MG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.GR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.NT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0908.0073v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0908.0073v1", "updated": "2009-08-01T12:23:34Z", "updated_parsed": [2009, 8, 1, 12, 23, 34, 5, 213, 0], "published": "2009-08-01T12:23:34Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 8, 1, 12, 23, 34, 5, 213, 0], "title": "Mixed Statistics on 01-Fillings of Moon Polyominoes", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Mixed Statistics on 01-Fillings of Moon Polyominoes"}, "summary": "We establish a stronger symmetry between the numbers of northeast and\nsoutheast chains in the context of 01-fillings of moon polyominoes. Let $\\M$ be\na moon polyomino with $n$ rows and $m$ columns. Consider all the 01-fillings of\n$\\M$ in which every row has at most one 1. We introduce four mixed statistics\nwith respect to a bipartition of rows or columns of $\\M$. More precisely, let\n$S \\subseteq \\{1,2,..., n\\}$ and $\\mathcal{R}(S)$ be the union of rows whose\nindices are in $S$. For any filling $M$, the top-mixed (resp. bottom-mixed)\nstatistic $\\alpha(S; M)$ (resp. $\\beta(S; M)$) is the sum of the number of\nnortheast chains whose top (resp. bottom) cell is in $\\mathcal{R}(S)$, together\nwith the number of southeast chains whose top (resp. bottom) cell is in the\ncomplement of $\\mathcal{R}(S)$. Similarly, we define the left-mixed and\nright-mixed statistics $\\gamma(T; M)$ and $\\delta(T; M)$, where $T$ is a subset\nof the column index set $\\{1,2,..., m\\}$. Let $\\lambda(A; M)$ be any of these\nfour statistics $\\alpha(S; M)$, $\\beta(S; M)$, $\\gamma(T; M)$ and $\\delta(T;\nM)$, we show that the joint distribution of the pair $(\\lambda(A; M),\n\\lambda(\\bar A; M))$ is symmetric and independent of the subsets $S, T$. In\nparticular, the pair of statistics $(\\lambda(A;M), \\lambda(\\bar A; M))$ is\nequidistributed with $(\\se(M),\\ne(M))$, where $\\se(M)$ and $\\ne(M)$ are the\nnumbers of southeast chains and northeast chains of $M$, respectively.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We establish a stronger symmetry between the numbers of northeast and\nsoutheast chains in the context of 01-fillings of moon polyominoes. Let $\\M$ be\na moon polyomino with $n$ rows and $m$ columns. Consider all the 01-fillings of\n$\\M$ in which every row has at most one 1. We introduce four mixed statistics\nwith respect to a bipartition of rows or columns of $\\M$. More precisely, let\n$S \\subseteq \\{1,2,..., n\\}$ and $\\mathcal{R}(S)$ be the union of rows whose\nindices are in $S$. For any filling $M$, the top-mixed (resp. bottom-mixed)\nstatistic $\\alpha(S; M)$ (resp. $\\beta(S; M)$) is the sum of the number of\nnortheast chains whose top (resp. bottom) cell is in $\\mathcal{R}(S)$, together\nwith the number of southeast chains whose top (resp. bottom) cell is in the\ncomplement of $\\mathcal{R}(S)$. Similarly, we define the left-mixed and\nright-mixed statistics $\\gamma(T; M)$ and $\\delta(T; M)$, where $T$ is a subset\nof the column index set $\\{1,2,..., m\\}$. Let $\\lambda(A; M)$ be any of these\nfour statistics $\\alpha(S; M)$, $\\beta(S; M)$, $\\gamma(T; M)$ and $\\delta(T;\nM)$, we show that the joint distribution of the pair $(\\lambda(A; M),\n\\lambda(\\bar A; M))$ is symmetric and independent of the subsets $S, T$. Zhao", "arxiv_comment": "20 pages, 6 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0908.0073v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0908.0073v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0710.1816v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0710.1816v1", "updated": "2007-10-09T16:11:54Z", "updated_parsed": [2007, 10, 9, 16, 11, 54, 1, 282, 0], "published": "2007-10-09T16:11:54Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 10, 9, 16, 11, 54, 1, 282, 0], "title": "Crossings and Nestings of Two Edges in Set Partitions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Crossings and Nestings of Two Edges in Set Partitions"}, "summary": "Let $\\pi$ and $\\lambda$ be two set partitions with the same number of blocks.\nAssume $\\pi$ is a partition of $[n]$.\n  For any integer $l, m \\geq 0$, let $\\mathcal{T}(\\pi, l)$ be the set of\npartitions of $[n+l]$ whose restrictions to the last $n$ elements are\nisomorphic to $\\pi$, and $\\mathcal{T}(\\pi, l, m)$ the subset of\n$\\mathcal{T}(\\pi,l)$ consisting of those partitions with exactly $m$ blocks.\nSimilarly define $\\mathcal{T}(\\lambda, l)$ and $\\mathcal{T}(\\lambda, l,m)$. We\nprove that if the statistic $cr$ ($ne$), the number of crossings (nestings) of\ntwo edges, coincides on the sets $\\mathcal{T}(\\pi, l)$ and\n$\\mathcal{T}(\\lambda, l)$ for $l =0, 1$, then it coincides on $\\mathcal{T}(\\pi,\nl,m)$ and $\\mathcal{T}(\\lambda, l,m)$ for all $l, m \\geq 0$. We\nprove that if the statistic $cr$ ($ne$), the number of crossings (nestings) of\ntwo edges, coincides on the sets $\\mathcal{T}(\\pi, l)$ and\n$\\mathcal{T}(\\lambda, l)$ for $l =0, 1$, then it coincides on $\\mathcal{T}(\\pi,\nl,m)$ and $\\mathcal{T}(\\lambda, l,m)$ for all $l, m \\geq 0$. These results\nextend the ones obtained by Klazar on the distribution of crossings and\nnestings for matchings."}, "authors": [{"name": "Svetlana Poznanovik"}, {"name": "Catherine Yan"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Catherine Yan"}, "author": "Catherine Yan", "arxiv_comment": "19 pages, 2 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0710.1816v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0710.1816v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "05A18, 05A15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0501230v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0501230v3", "updated": "2005-11-14T20:18:50Z", "updated_parsed": [2005, 11, 14, 20, 18, 50, 0, 318, 0], "published": "2005-01-14T17:37:19Z", "published_parsed": [2005, 1, 14, 17, 37, 19, 4, 14, 0], "title": "Crossings and Nestings of Matchings and Partitions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Crossings and Nestings of Matchings and Partitions"}, "summary": "We present results on the enumeration of crossings and nestings for matchings\nand set partitions. Using a bijection between partitions and vacillating\ntableaux, we show that if we fix the sets of minimal block elements and maximal\nblock elements, the crossing number and the nesting number of partitions have a\nsymmetric joint distribution. It follows that the crossing numbers and the\nnesting numbers are distributed symmetrically over all partitions of $[n]$, as\nwell as over all matchings on $[2n]$. As a corollary, the number of\n$k$-noncrossing partitions is equal to the number of $k$-nonnesting partitions.\nThe same is also true for matchings. An application is given to the enumeration\nof matchings with no $k$-crossing (or with no $k$-nesting).", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We present results on the enumeration of crossings and nestings for matchings\nand set partitions. Using a bijection between partitions and vacillating\ntableaux, we show that if we fix the sets of minimal block elements and maximal\nblock elements, the crossing number and the nesting number of partitions have a\nsymmetric joint distribution. It follows that the crossing numbers and the\nnesting numbers are distributed symmetrically over all partitions of $[n]$, as\nwell as over all matchings on $[2n]$. As a corollary, the number of\n$k$-noncrossing partitions is equal to the number of $k$-nonnesting partitions.\nThe same is also true for matchings. An application is given to the enumeration\nof matchings with no $k$-crossing (or with no $k$-nesting)."}, "authors": [{"name": "William Y. C. Chen"}, {"name": "Eva Y. P. Deng"}, {"name": "Rosena R. Page 20, revised Remark. page 23, added references", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0501230v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0501230v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.CT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "05A18; 05A15, 05E10", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0010302v5", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0010302v5", "updated": "2005-03-11T17:34:27Z", "updated_parsed": [2005, 3, 11, 17, 34, 27, 4, 70, 0], "published": "2000-10-30T17:25:58Z", "published_parsed": [2000, 10, 30, 17, 25, 58, 0, 304, 0], "title": "Apollonian Circle Packings: Geometry and Group Theory II.\n  Super-Apollonian Group and Integral Packings", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Apollonian Circle Packings: Geometry and Group Theory II.\n  Super-Apollonian Group and Integral Packings"}, "summary": "Apollonian circle packings arise by repeatedly filling the interstices\nbetween four mutually tangent circles with further tangent circles. Such\npackings can be described in terms of the Descartes configurations they\ncontain. It observed there exist infinitely many types of integral Apollonian\npackings in which all circles had integer curvatures, with the integral\nstructure being related to the integral nature of the Apollonian group. Here we\nconsider the action of a larger discrete group, the super-Apollonian group,\nalso having an integral structure, whose orbits describe the Descartes\nquadruples of a geometric object we call a super-packing. The circles in a\nsuper-packing never cross each other but are nested to an arbitrary depth.\nCertain Apollonian packings and super-packings are strongly integral in the\nsense that the curvatures of all circles are integral and the\ncurvature$\\times$centers of all circles are integral. We show that (up to\nscale) there are exactly 8 different (geometric) strongly integral\nsuper-packings, and that each contains a copy of every integral Apollonian\ncircle packing (also up to scale). We show that the super-Apollonian group has\nfinite volume in the group of all automorphisms of the parameter space of\nDescartes configurations, which is isomorphic to the Lorentz group $O(3, 1)$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Apollonian circle packings arise by repeatedly filling the interstices\nbetween four mutually tangent circles with further tangent circles. Such\npackings can be described in terms of the Descartes configurations they\ncontain. It observed there exist infinitely many types of integral Apollonian\npackings in which all circles had integer curvatures, with the integral\nstructure being related to the integral nature of the Apollonian group. Here we\nconsider the action of a larger discrete group, the super-Apollonian group,\nalso having an integral structure, whose orbits describe the Descartes\nquadruples of a geometric object we call a super-packing. The circles in a\nsuper-packing never cross each other but are nested to an arbitrary depth.\nCertain Apollonian packings and super-packings are strongly integral in the\nsense that the curvatures of all circles are integral and the\ncurvature$\\times$centers of all circles are integral. We show that (up to\nscale) there are exactly 8 different (geometric) strongly integral\nsuper-packings, and that each contains a copy of every integral Apollonian\ncircle packing (also up to scale). We show that the super-Apollonian group has\nfinite volume in the group of all automorphisms of the parameter space of\nDescartes configurations, which is isomorphic to the Lorentz group $O(3, 1)$."}, "authors": [{"name": "R. Zhao", "arxiv_comment": "20 pages, 6 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0908.0073v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0908.0073v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0709.1717v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0709.1717v2", "updated": "2007-09-27T18:56:45Z", "updated_parsed": [2007, 9, 27, 18, 56, 45, 3, 270, 0], "published": "2007-09-11T20:23:00Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 9, 11, 20, 23, 0, 1, 254, 0], "title": "Lattice and Schroder paths with periodic boundaries", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Lattice and Schroder paths with periodic boundaries"}, "summary": "We consider paths in the plane with $(1,0),$ $(0,1),$ and $(a,b)$-steps that\nstart at the origin, end at height $n,$ and stay to the left of a given\nnon-decreasing right boundary. We show that if the boundary is periodic and has\nslope at most $b/a,$ then the ordinary generating function for the number of\nsuch paths ending at height $n$ is algebraic. Our argument is in two parts. We\nuse a simple combinatorial decomposition to obtain an Appell relation or\n``umbral'' generating function, in which the power $z^n$ is replaced by a power\nseries of the form $z^n \\phi_n(z),$ where $\\phi_n(0) = 1.$ Then we convert (in\nan explicit way) the umbral generating function to an ordinary generating\nfunction by solving a system of linear equations and a polynomial equation.\nThis conversion implies that the ordinary generating function is algebraic.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider paths in the plane with $(1,0),$ $(0,1),$ and $(a,b)$-steps that\nstart at the origin, end at height $n,$ and stay to the left of a given\nnon-decreasing right boundary. We show that if the boundary is periodic and has\nslope at most $b/a,$ then the ordinary generating function for the number of\nsuch paths ending at height $n$ is algebraic. Our argument is in two parts. We\nuse a simple combinatorial decomposition to obtain an Appell relation or\n``umbral'' generating function, in which the power $z^n$ is replaced by a power\nseries of the form $z^n \\phi_n(z),$ where $\\phi_n(0) = 1.$ Then we convert (in\nan explicit way) the umbral generating function to an ordinary generating\nfunction by solving a system of linear equations and a polynomial equation.\nThis conversion implies that the ordinary generating function is algebraic."}, "authors": [{"name": "Joseph P. S. Kung"}, {"name": "Anna de Mier"}, {"name": "Xinyu Sun"}, {"name": "Catherine H. Yan"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Catherine H. Yan"}, "author": "Catherine H. Yan", "arxiv_comment": "22 pages, 1 figure; Revised version, references added and corrected\n  typos", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0709.1717v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0709.1717v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "05A15, 05A10", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0010324v4", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0010324v4", "updated": "2005-03-11T17:36:53Z", "updated_parsed": [2005, 3, 11, 17, 36, 53, 4, 70, 0], "published": "2000-10-31T20:59:34Z", "published_parsed": [2000, 10, 31, 20, 59, 34, 1, 305, 0], "title": "Apollonian Circle Packings: Geometry and Group Theory III. Higher\n  Dimensions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Apollonian Circle Packings: Geometry and Group Theory III. Higher\n  Dimensions"}, "summary": "This paper gives $n$-dimensional analogues of the Apollonian circle packings\nin parts I and II. We work in the space $\\sM_{\\dd}^n$ of all $n$-dimensional\noriented Descartes configurations parametrized in a coordinate system,\nACC-coordinates, as those $(n+2) \\times (n+2)$ real matrices $\\bW$ with $\\bW^T\n\\bQ_{D,n} \\bW = \\bQ_{W,n}$ where $Q_{D,n} = x_1^2 +... + x_{n+2}^2 -\n\\frac{1}{n}(x_1 +... + x_{n+2})^2$ is the $n$-dimensional Descartes quadratic\nform, $Q_{W,n} = -8x_1x_2 + 2x_3^2 + ... + 2x_{n+2}^2$, and $\\bQ_{D,n}$ and\n$\\bQ_{W,n}$ are their corresponding symmetric matrices. There are natural\nactions on the parameter space $\\sM_{\\dd}^n$. We introduce $n$-dimensional\nanalogues of the Apollonian group, the dual Apollonian group and the\nsuper-Apollonian group. These are finitely generated groups with the following\nintegrality properties: the dual Apollonian group consists of integral matrices\nin all dimensions, while the other two consist of rational matrices, with\ndenominators having prime divisors drawn from a finite set $S$ depending on the\ndimension. We show that the the Apollonian group and the dual Apollonian group\nare finitely presented, and are Coxeter groups. We define an Apollonian cluster\nensemble to be any orbit under the Apollonian group, with similar notions for\nthe other two groups. We determine in which dimensions one can find rational\nApollonian cluster ensembles (all curvatures rational) and strongly rational\nApollonian sphere ensembles (all ACC-coordinates rational).", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper gives $n$-dimensional analogues of the Apollonian circle packings\nin parts I and II. We work in the space $\\sM_{\\dd}^n$ of all $n$-dimensional\noriented Descartes configurations parametrized in a coordinate system,\nACC-coordinates, as those $(n+2) \\times (n+2)$ real matrices $\\bW$ with $\\bW^T\n\\bQ_{D,n} \\bW = \\bQ_{W,n}$ where $Q_{D,n} = x_1^2 +... + x_{n+2}^2 -\n\\frac{1}{n}(x_1 +... + x_{n+2})^2$ is the $n$-dimensional Descartes quadratic\nform, $Q_{W,n} = -8x_1x_2 + 2x_3^2 + ... + 2x_{n+2}^2$, and $\\bQ_{D,n}$ and\n$\\bQ_{W,n}$ are their corresponding symmetric matrices. There are natural\nactions on the parameter space $\\sM_{\\dd}^n$. We introduce $n$-dimensional\nanalogues of the Apollonian group, the dual Apollonian group and the\nsuper-Apollonian group. These are finitely generated groups with the following\nintegrality properties: the dual Apollonian group consists of integral matrices\nin all dimensions, while the other two consist of rational matrices, with\ndenominators having prime divisors drawn from a finite set $S$ depending on the\ndimension. We show that the the Apollonian group and the dual Apollonian group\nare finitely presented, and are Coxeter groups. We define an Apollonian cluster\nensemble to be any orbit under the Apollonian group, with similar notions for\nthe other two groups. We determine in which dimensions one can find rational\nApollonian cluster ensembles (all curvatures rational) and strongly rational\nApollonian sphere ensembles (all ACC-coordinates rational)."}, "authors": [{"name": "R. L. Graham"}, {"name": "J. C. Lagarias"}, {"name": "C. L. Mallows"}, {"name": "A. R. Wilks"}, {"name": "C. H. Yan"}], "author_detail": {"name": "C. H. Yan"}, "author": "C. H. These identities allow\none to extract ratios among high-energy string scattering amplitudes in the\nfixed angle regime from high-energy amplitudes in the Regge regime. The proof\nis based on a signless Stirling number identity in combinatorial theory. The\nresults are valid for arbitrary real values $L$ rather than only for $L=0,1$\nproved previously. The identities for non-integer real value $L$ were recently\nshown to be realized in high-energy compactified string scattering amplitudes\n[He S., Lee J.C., Yang Y., arXiv:1012.3158]. It is known that the number of\nnoncrossing linked partitions of [n+1] is equal to the n-th large Schroder\nnumber $r_n$, which counts the number of Schroder paths. In this paper we give\na bijective proof of this result. Then we introduce the structures of linked\npartitions and linked cycles. We present various combinatorial properties of\nnoncrossing linked partitions, linked partitions, and linked cycles, and\nconnect them to other combinatorial structures and results, including\nincreasing trees, partial matchings, k-Stirling numbers of the second kind, and\nthe symmetry between crossings and nestings over certain linear graphs.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The notion of noncrossing linked partition arose from the study of certain\ntransforms in free probability theory. It is possible\nfor every circle in such a packing to have integer radius of curvature, and we\ncall such a packing an {\\em integral Apollonian circle packing.} This paper\nstudies number-theoretic properties of the set of integer curvatures appearing\nin such packings. Each Descartes quadruple of four tangent circles in the\npacking gives an integer solution to the {\\em Descartes equation}, which\nrelates the radii of curvature of four mutually tangent circles: $2 (x^2 + y^2\n+ z^2 + w^2) - (x + y + z + w)^2 = 0.$ Each integral Apollonian circle packing\nis classified by a certain {\\em root quadruple} of integers that satisfies the\nDescartes equation, and that corresponds to a particular quadruple of circles\nappearing in the packing. We determine asymptotics for the number of root\nquadruples of size below $T$. We study which integers occur in a given integer\npacking, and determine congruence restrictions which sometimes apply. Finally,\nwe present evidence suggesting that the set of integer radii of curvatures that\nappear in an integral Apollonian circle packing has positive density, and in\nfact represents all sufficiently large integers not excluded by congruence\nconditions. In a series of companion papersr ``Apollonian Circle Packings:\nGeometry and Group Theory,'' we investigate a variety of group-theoretic\nproperties of these configurations, as well as various extensions to higher\ndimensions and other spaces, such as hyperbolic space.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Apollonian circle packings arise by repeatedly filling the interstices\nbetween mutually tangent circles with further tangent circles. It is possible\nfor every circle in such a packing to have integer radius of curvature, and we\ncall such a packing an {\\em integral Apollonian circle packing.} This paper\nstudies number-theoretic properties of the set of integer curvatures appearing\nin such packings. Each Descartes quadruple of four tangent circles in the\npacking gives an integer solution to the {\\em Descartes equation}, which\nrelates the radii of curvature of four mutually tangent circles: $2 (x^2 + y^2\n+ z^2 + w^2) - (x + y + z + w)^2 = 0.$ Each integral Apollonian circle packing\nis classified by a certain {\\em root quadruple} of integers that satisfies the\nDescartes equation, and that corresponds to a particular quadruple of circles\nappearing in the packing. We determine asymptotics for the number of root\nquadruples of size below $T$. We study which integers occur in a given integer\npacking, and determine congruence restrictions which sometimes apply. Finally,\nwe present evidence suggesting that the set of integer radii of curvatures that\nappear in an integral Apollonian circle packing has positive density, and in\nfact represents all sufficiently large integers not excluded by congruence\nconditions. Like its cousin the Erdos-Renyi random graph, $G$ has a connectivity\nthreshold: an asymptotic value for $\\lambda$ in terms of $n$, above which $G$\nis connected and below which $G$ is disconnected (and in fact has isolated\nvertices in most cases). In the connected zone, we determine upper and lower\nbounds for the graph diameter of $G$. Specifically, almost always,\n$\\diam_p(\\mathbf{B})(1-o(1))/\\lambda \\leq \\diam(G) \\leq\n\\diam_p(\\mathbf{B})(1+O((\\ln \\ln n/\\ln n)^{1/d}))/\\lambda$, where\n$\\diam_p(\\mathbf{B})$ is the $\\ell_p$-diameter of the unit ball $\\mathbf{B}$.\nWe employ a combination of methods from probabilistic combinatorics and\nstochastic geometry.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The unit ball random geometric graph $G=G^d_p(\\lambda,n)$ has as its vertices\n$n$ points distributed independently and uniformly in the $d$-dimensional unit\nball, with two vertices adjacent if and only if their $l_p$-distance is at most\n$\\lambda$. We consider the set F(M, s; A) of all 01-fillings of a moon\npolyomino M with given column sum s whose empty rows are A, and prove that this\nmajor index has the same distribution as the number of north-east chains, which\nare the natural extension of inversions (resp. crossings) for permutations\n(resp. set partitions). These spaces can be\nrepresented as a (possibly infinite) union of 1-dimensional intervals and a\ntotally disconnected (possibly uncountable) compact set, which roughly speaking\nrepresents the set of junction points. Classical quantum graphs and fractal\nspaces such as the Hanoi attractor are included among them. We begin with\nproving the existence of a resistance form on the Hanoi attractor, and go on to\nestablish heat kernel estimates and upper and lower bounds on the eigenvalue\ncounting function of Laplacians corresponding to weakly self-similar measures\non the Hanoi attractor. These estimates and bounds rely heavily on the relation\nbetween the length and volume scaling factors of the fractal. spaces"}, "summary": "With a view towards Riemannian or sub-Riemannian manifolds, RCD metric spaces\nand specially fractals, this paper makes a step further in the development of a\ntheory of heat semigroup based $(1,p)$ Sobolev spaces in the general framework\nof Dirichlet spaces. Under suitable assumptions that are verified in a variety\nof settings, the tools developed by D. Bakry, T. Coulhon, M. Ledoux and L.\nSaloff-Coste in the paper \"Sobolev inequalities in disguise\" allow us to obtain\nthe whole family of Gagliardo-Nirenberg and Trudinger-Moser inequalities with\noptimal exponents. The latter depend not only on the Hausdorff and walk\ndimensions of the space but also on other invariants. Under suitable assumptions that are verified in a variety\nof settings, the tools developed by D. Bakry, T. Coulhon, M. Ledoux and L.\nSaloff-Coste in the paper \"Sobolev inequalities in disguise\" allow us to obtain\nthe whole family of Gagliardo-Nirenberg and Trudinger-Moser inequalities with\noptimal exponents. Davis in \\cite{Davis} in 1976. In this article the\nestimates of the type $\\|Sf\\|_p \\le C_p \\|f\\|_p$, $p\\ge 2$, were considered for\nthe dyadic square function operator $S$, and Davis found the sharp values of\nconstants $C_p$. However, along with the sharp constants one can consider a\nmore subtle characteristic of the above estimate. This quantity is called the\nBellman function of the problem, and it seems to us that it was never proved\nthat the confluent hypergeometric function from Davis' paper (second page)\nbasically gives this Bellman function. Here we fill out this gap by finding the\nexact Bellman function of the unweighted $L^p$ estimate for operator $S$. We\ncast the proofs in the language of obstacle problems. For the sake of\ncomparison, we also find the Bellman function of weak $(1,1)$ estimate of $S$.\nThis formula was suggested by Bollobas \\cite{Bollobas} and proved by Osekowski\n\\cite{Os2009}, so it is not new, but we like to emphasize the common approach\nto those two Bellman functions descriptions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this note we give the formula for the Bellman function associated with the\nproblem considered by B. Davis in \\cite{Davis} in 1976. In this article the\nestimates of the type $\\|Sf\\|_p \\le C_p \\|f\\|_p$, $p\\ge 2$, were considered for\nthe dyadic square function operator $S$, and Davis found the sharp values of\nconstants $C_p$. However, along with the sharp constants one can consider a\nmore subtle characteristic of the above estimate. This quantity is called the\nBellman function of the problem, and it seems to us that it was never proved\nthat the confluent hypergeometric function from Davis' paper (second page)\nbasically gives this Bellman function. Here we fill out this gap by finding the\nexact Bellman function of the unweighted $L^p$ estimate for operator $S$. We\ncast the proofs in the language of obstacle problems. Commutators in the Dirichlet and Neumann Laplacian settings"}, "summary": "In this paper we establish the characterization of the weighted BMO via two\nweight commutators in the settings of the Neumann Laplacian $\\Delta_{N_+}$ on\nthe upper half space $\\mathbb{R}^n_+$ and the reflection Neumann Laplacian\n$\\Delta_N$ on $\\mathbb{R}^n$ with respect to the weights associated to\n$\\Delta_{N_+}$ and $\\Delta_{N}$ respectively. This in turn yields a weak\nfactorization for the corresponding weighted Hardy spaces, where in particular,\nthe weighted class associated to $\\Delta_{N}$ is strictly larger than the\nMuckenhoupt weighted class and contains non-doubling weights. In our study, we\nalso make contributions to the classical Muckenhoupt--Wheeden weighted Hardy\nspace (BMO space respectively) by showing that it can be characterized via area\nfunction (Carleson measure respectively) involving the semigroup generated by\nthe Laplacian on $\\mathbb{R}^n$ and that the duality of these weighted Hardy\nand BMO spaces holds for Muckenhoupt $A^p$ weights with $p\\in (1,2]$ while the\npreviously known related results cover only $p\\in (1,{n+1\\over n}]$. We also\npoint out that this two weight commutator theorem might not be true in the\nsetting of general operators $L$, and in particular we show that it is not true\nwhen $L$ is the Dirichlet Laplacian $\\Delta_{D_+}$ on $\\mathbb{R}^n_+$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper we establish the characterization of the weighted BMO via two\nweight commutators in the settings of the Neumann Laplacian $\\Delta_{N_+}$ on\nthe upper half space $\\mathbb{R}^n_+$ and the reflection Neumann Laplacian\n$\\Delta_N$ on $\\mathbb{R}^n$ with respect to the weights associated to\n$\\Delta_{N_+}$ and $\\Delta_{N}$ respectively. This in turn yields a weak\nfactorization for the corresponding weighted Hardy spaces, where in particular,\nthe weighted class associated to $\\Delta_{N}$ is strictly larger than the\nMuckenhoupt weighted class and contains non-doubling weights. In our study, we\nalso make contributions to the classical Muckenhoupt--Wheeden weighted Hardy\nspace (BMO space respectively) by showing that it can be characterized via area\nfunction (Carleson measure respectively) involving the semigroup generated by\nthe Laplacian on $\\mathbb{R}^n$ and that the duality of these weighted Hardy\nand BMO spaces holds for Muckenhoupt $A^p$ weights with $p\\in (1,2]$ while the\npreviously known related results cover only $p\\in (1,{n+1\\over n}]$. Specifically, if $\\mu$ and $\\lambda$ are biparameter $A_p$ weights,\n$\\nu := \\mu^{1/p}\\lambda^{-1/p}$ is the Bloom weight, and $b$ is in $bmo(\\nu)$,\nthen we prove a lower bound and testing condition $\\|b\\|_{bmo(\\nu)} \\lesssim\n\\sup \\| [b, R_k^1 R_l^2]: L^p(\\mu) \\rightarrow L^p(\\lambda)\\|$, where $R_k^1$\nand $R_l^2$ are Riesz transforms acting in each variable. Further, we prove\nthat for such symbols $b$ and any biparameter Journ\\'{e} operators $T$ the\ncommutator $[b, T]:L^p(\\mu) \\rightarrow L^p(\\lambda)$ is bounded. Previous\nresults in the Bloom setting do not include the biparameter case and are\nrestricted to Calder\\'{o}n-Zygmund operators. Even in the unweighted, $p=2$\ncase, the upper bound fills a gap that remained open in the multiparameter\nliterature for iterated commutators with Journ\\'e operators. Fefferman.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We characterize the boundedness of the commutators $[b, T]$ with biparameter\nJourn\\'{e} operators $T$ in the two-weight, Bloom-type setting, and express the\nnorms of these commutators in terms of a weighted little $bmo$ norm of the\nsymbol $b$. Specifically, if $\\mu$ and $\\lambda$ are biparameter $A_p$ weights,\n$\\nu := \\mu^{1/p}\\lambda^{-1/p}$ is the Bloom weight, and $b$ is in $bmo(\\nu)$,\nthen we prove a lower bound and testing condition $\\|b\\|_{bmo(\\nu)} \\lesssim\n\\sup \\| [b, R_k^1 R_l^2]: L^p(\\mu) \\rightarrow L^p(\\lambda)\\|$, where $R_k^1$\nand $R_l^2$ are Riesz transforms acting in each variable. Further, we prove\nthat for such symbols $b$ and any biparameter Journ\\'{e} operators $T$ the\ncommutator $[b, T]:L^p(\\mu) \\rightarrow L^p(\\lambda)$ is bounded. Previous\nresults in the Bloom setting do not include the biparameter case and are\nrestricted to Calder\\'{o}n-Zygmund operators. Even in the unweighted, $p=2$\ncase, the upper bound fills a gap that remained open in the multiparameter\nliterature for iterated commutators with Journ\\'e operators. The absence of a\nuseful Lebesgue measure on an infinite-dimensional reproducing kernel Hilbert\nspace is a serious obstacle for such stochastic models. We propose an\nestimation model for the ridge regression problem within the framework of\nabstract Wiener spaces and show how the support vector machine solution to such\nproblems can be interpreted in terms of the Gaussian Radon transform.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "There has been growing recent interest in probabilistic interpretations of\nkernel-based methods as well as learning in Banach spaces. He conjectured that\nevery scale-invariant group has polynomial growth, hence is virtually\nnilpotent. We disprove his conjecture by showing that the following groups\n(mostly finite-state self-similar groups) are scale-invariant: the lamplighter\ngroups F\\wr\\Z, where F is any finite Abelian group; the solvable\nBaumslag-Solitar groups BS(1,m); the affine groups A\\ltimes\\Z^d, for any A\\leq\nGL(\\Z,d). It attempts to relate\nthese concepts to more familiar ones, such as fractals, self-similar sets, and\nrenormalizable dynamical systems. In particular, it presents a plausible\ndefinition of what a \"fractal group\" should be, and gives many examples of such\ngroups.\n  A particularly interesting class of examples, derived from monodromy groups\nof iterated branch coverings, or equivalently from Galois groups of iterated\npolynomials, is presented. This class contains interesting groups from an\nalgebraic point of view (just-non-solvable groups, groups of intermediate\ngrowth, branch groups,...), and at the same time the geometry of the group is\napparent in that a limit of the group identifies naturally with the Julia set\nof the covering map.\n  In its survey, the paper discusses finite-state transducers, growth of groups\nand languages, limit spaces of groups, hyperbolic spaces and groups, dynamical\nsystems, Hecke-type operators, C^*-algebras, random matrices, ergodic theorems\nand entropy of non-commuting transformations. Self-similar groups appear then\nas a natural weaving thread through these seemingly different topics.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper is a survey, with few proofs, of ideas and notions related to\nself-similarity of groups, semi-groups and their actions. It attempts to relate\nthese concepts to more familiar ones, such as fractals, self-similar sets, and\nrenormalizable dynamical systems. In particular, it presents a plausible\ndefinition of what a \"fractal group\" should be, and gives many examples of such\ngroups.\n  A particularly interesting class of examples, derived from monodromy groups\nof iterated branch coverings, or equivalently from Galois groups of iterated\npolynomials, is presented. This class contains interesting groups from an\nalgebraic point of view (just-non-solvable groups, groups of intermediate\ngrowth, branch groups,...), and at the same time the geometry of the group is\napparent in that a limit of the group identifies naturally with the Julia set\nof the covering map.\n  In its survey, the paper discusses finite-state transducers, growth of groups\nand languages, limit spaces of groups, hyperbolic spaces and groups, dynamical\nsystems, Hecke-type operators, C^*-algebras, random matrices, ergodic theorems\nand entropy of non-commuting transformations. It is the quotient of the fundamental group $\\pi_1(M)$\nby the intersection of the kernels of its monodromy action for the iterates\n$f^n$. Every iterated monodromy group comes together with a naturally defined\naction on a rooted tree. We present an effective method to compute this action\nand show how the dynamics of $f$ is related to the group. This result was extended to\ninclude monotone convolution by the authors. In recent years, operator-valued\nversions of free, Boolean and monotone probability have also been developed.\nBelinschi, Popa and Vinnikov showed that the Bercovici-Pata bijection holds for\nthe operator-valued versions of free and Boolean probability. In this article,\nwe extend the bijection to include monotone probability theory even in the\noperator-valued case. To prove this result, we develop the general theory of\ncomposition semigroups of non-commutative functions and largely recapture\nBerkson and Porta's classical results on composition semigroups of complex\nfunctions in operator-valued setting. As a biproduct, we deduce that\noperator-valued monotonically infinitely divisible distributions belong to\nmonotone convolution semigroups. Finally, in the appendix, we extend the result\nof the second author on the classification of Cauchy transforms for\nnon-commutative distributions to the Cauchy transforms associated to more\ngeneral completely positive maps.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In a 1999 paper, Bercovici and Pata showed that a natural bijection between\nthe classically, free and Boolean infinitely divisible measures held at the\nlevel of limit theorems of triangular arrays. This result was extended to\ninclude monotone convolution by the authors. In recent years, operator-valued\nversions of free, Boolean and monotone probability have also been developed.\nBelinschi, Popa and Vinnikov showed that the Bercovici-Pata bijection holds for\nthe operator-valued versions of free and Boolean probability. In this article,\nwe extend the bijection to include monotone probability theory even in the\noperator-valued case. To prove this result, we develop the general theory of\ncomposition semigroups of non-commutative functions and largely recapture\nBerkson and Porta's classical results on composition semigroups of complex\nfunctions in operator-valued setting. As a biproduct, we deduce that\noperator-valued monotonically infinitely divisible distributions belong to\nmonotone convolution semigroups. Finally, in the appendix, we extend the result\nof the second author on the classification of Cauchy transforms for\nnon-commutative distributions to the Cauchy transforms associated to more\ngeneral completely positive maps."}, "authors": [{"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}, {"name": "John D. Moreover, we prove the parallel result, in a more\nexplicit way, for the free convolution and the free Meixner class. We then\nconstruct the class of measures satisfying the same property for the two-state\nfree convolution. This class of two-state free convolution semigroups has not\nbeen considered explicitly before. We show that it also has Meixner-type\nproperties. Specifically, it contains the analogs of the normal, Poisson, and\nbinomial distributions, has a Laha-Lukacs-type characterization, and is related\nto the $q=0$ case of quadratic harnesses.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We show that a convolution semigroup of measures has Jacobi parameters\npolynomial in the convolution parameter $t$ if and only if the measures come\nfrom the Meixner class. Moreover, we prove the parallel result, in a more\nexplicit way, for the free convolution and the free Meixner class. We then\nconstruct the class of measures satisfying the same property for the two-state\nfree convolution. This class of two-state free convolution semigroups has not\nbeen considered explicitly before. We show that it also has Meixner-type\nproperties. Specifically, it contains the analogs of the normal, Poisson, and\nbinomial distributions, has a Laha-Lukacs-type characterization, and is related\nto the $q=0$ case of quadratic harnesses."}, "authors": [{"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}, {"name": "Wojciech M\u0142otkowski"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wojciech M\u0142otkowski"}, "author": "Wojciech M\u0142otkowski", "arxiv_doi": "10.1007/s10959-012-0403-x", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10959-012-0403-x", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1001.1540v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1001.1540v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "v3: the article is merged back together with arXiv:1003.4025. Probab. 25 (2012), 1173-1206", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L54 (Primary), 33C45 (Secondary), 46L53, 05A18, 60J25", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1104.1381v4", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1104.1381v4", "updated": "2013-01-22T18:06:14Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 1, 22, 18, 6, 14, 1, 22, 0], "published": "2011-04-07T17:05:03Z", "published_parsed": [2011, 4, 7, 17, 5, 3, 3, 97, 0], "title": "Generators of some non-commutative stochastic processes", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Generators of some non-commutative stochastic processes"}, "summary": "A fundamental result of Biane (1998) states that a process with freely\nindependent increments has the Markov property, but that there are two kinds of\nfree Levy processes: the first kind has stationary increments, while the second\nkind has stationary transition operators. We show that a process of the first\nkind (with mean zero and finite variance) has the same transition operators as\nthe free Brownian motion with appropriate initial conditions, while a process\nof the second kind has the same transition operators as a monotone Levy\nprocess. We compute an explicit formula for the generators of these families of\ntransition operators, in terms of singular integral operators, and prove that\nthis formula holds on a fairly large domain. We also compute the generators for\nthe $q$-Brownian motion, and for the two-state free Brownian motions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A fundamental result of Biane (1998) states that a process with freely\nindependent increments has the Markov property, but that there are two kinds of\nfree Levy processes: the first kind has stationary increments, while the second\nkind has stationary transition operators. We show that a process of the first\nkind (with mean zero and finite variance) has the same transition operators as\nthe free Brownian motion with appropriate initial conditions, while a process\nof the second kind has the same transition operators as a monotone Levy\nprocess. We compute an explicit formula for the generators of these families of\ntransition operators, in terms of singular integral operators, and prove that\nthis formula holds on a fairly large domain. We also compute the generators for\nthe $q$-Brownian motion, and for the two-state free Brownian motions."}, "authors": [{"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}, "author": "Michael Anshelevich", "arxiv_doi": "10.1007/s00440-012-0470-z", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00440-012-0470-z", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1104.1381v4", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1104.1381v4", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "v4: a single correction in Remark 14. v3: minor revision. v2: Theorem\n  13 added, abstract modified accordingly", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Probab. Theory Related Fields 157 (2013), 777-815", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L54 (Primary) 60J25, 47D06 (Secondary)", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0410482v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0410482v2", "updated": "2006-07-03T19:44:02Z", "updated_parsed": [2006, 7, 3, 19, 44, 2, 0, 184, 0], "published": "2004-10-22T02:38:01Z", "published_parsed": [2004, 10, 22, 2, 38, 1, 4, 296, 0], "title": "Orthogonal polynomials with a resolvent-type generating function", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Orthogonal polynomials with a resolvent-type generating function"}, "summary": "The subject of this paper are polynomials in multiple non-commuting\nvariables. For polynomials of this type orthogonal with respect to a state, we\nprove a Favard-type recursion relation. On the other hand, free Sheffer\npolynomials are a polynomial family in non-commuting variables with a\nresolvent-type generating function. Among such families, we describe the ones\nthat are orthogonal. Their recursion relations have a more special form; the\nbest way to describe them is in terms of the free cumulant generating function\nof the state of orthogonality, which turns out to satisfy a type of\nsecond-order difference equation. If the difference equation is in fact first\norder, and the state is tracial, we show that the state is necessarily a\nrotation of a free product state. We also describe interesting examples of\nnon-tracial infinitely divisible states with orthogonal free Sheffer\npolynomials.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The subject of this paper are polynomials in multiple non-commuting\nvariables. For polynomials of this type orthogonal with respect to a state, we\nprove a Favard-type recursion relation. On the other hand, free Sheffer\npolynomials are a polynomial family in non-commuting variables with a\nresolvent-type generating function. Among such families, we describe the ones\nthat are orthogonal. Their recursion relations have a more special form; the\nbest way to describe them is in terms of the free cumulant generating function\nof the state of orthogonality, which turns out to satisfy a type of\nsecond-order difference equation. If the difference equation is in fact first\norder, and the state is tracial, we show that the state is necessarily a\nrotation of a free product state. We also describe interesting examples of\nnon-tracial infinitely divisible states with orthogonal free Sheffer\npolynomials."}, "authors": [{"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}, "author": "Michael Anshelevich", "arxiv_doi": "10.1090/S0002-9947-08-04368-7", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1090/S0002-9947-08-04368-7", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0410482v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0410482v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "19 pages; minor improvements", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Trans. We show that convergence in\ndistribution for products of identically distributed and infinitesimal free\nrandom variables implies superconvergence of their probability densities to the\ndensity of the limit law. Superconvergence to the marginal law of free\nmultiplicative Brownian motion at a specified time is also studied. In the\nunitary case, the superconvergence to free Brownian motion and that to the Haar\nmeasure are shown to be uniform over the entire unit circle, implying further a\nfree entropic limit theorem and a universality result for unitary free L\\'{e}vy\nprocesses. Note that a priori, the distribution of the process with respect to\nthe second state $\\psi$ is arbitrary. We show, however, that if $A$ is a von\nNeumann algebra, the states $\\phi, \\psi$ are normal, and $\\phi$ is faithful,\nthen there is only a one-parameter family of such processes. Moreover, with the\nexception of the actual free Brownian motion (corresponding to $\\phi = \\psi$),\nthese processes only exist for finite time.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In a two-state free probability space $(A, \\phi, \\psi)$, we define an\nalgebraic two-state free Brownian motion to be a process with two-state freely\nindependent increments whose two-state free cumulant generating function is\nquadratic. Note that a priori, the distribution of the process with respect to\nthe second state $\\psi$ is arbitrary. We show, however, that if $A$ is a von\nNeumann algebra, the states $\\phi, \\psi$ are normal, and $\\phi$ is faithful,\nthen there is only a one-parameter family of such processes.
