Conditionally free theory", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Appell polynomials and their relatives III. Conditionally free theory"}, "summary": "We extend to the multivariate non-commutative context the descriptions of a\n\"once-stripped\" probability measure in terms of Jacobi parameters, orthogonal\npolynomials, and the moment generating function. The corresponding map Phi on\nstates was introduced previously by Belinschi and Nica. We then relate these\nconstructions to the c-free probability theory, which is a version of free\nprobability for algebras with two states, introduced by Bozejko, Leinert, and\nSpeicher. This theory includes as two extreme cases the free and Boolean\nprobability theories. The main objects in the paper are the analogs of the\nAppell polynomial families in the two state context. They arise as fixed points\nof the transformation which takes a polynomial family to the associated\npolynomial family (in several variables), and their orthogonality is also\nrelated to the map Phi above. The corresponding map Phi on\nstates was introduced previously by Belinschi and Nica. We then relate these\nconstructions to the c-free probability theory, which is a version of free\nprobability for algebras with two states, introduced by Bozejko, Leinert, and\nSpeicher. This theory includes as two extreme cases the free and Boolean\nprobability theories. The main objects in the paper are the analogs of the\nAppell polynomial families in the two state context. These coefficients have combinatorial significance for many\nclassical families of orthogonal polynomials. Starting with a stochastic\nprocess and using the stochastic measures machinery introduced by Rota and\nWallstrom, we calculate and give an interpretation of linearization\ncoefficients for a number of polynomial families. The processes involved may\nhave independent, freely independent or q-independent increments. The use of\nnoncommutative stochastic processes extends the range of applications\nsignificantly, allowing us to treat Hermite, Charlier, Chebyshev, free Charlier\nand Rogers and continuous big q-Hermite polynomials. We also show that the\nq-Poisson process is a Markov process.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Given a basis for a polynomial ring, the coefficients in the expansion of a\nproduct of some of its elements in terms of this basis are called linearization\ncoefficients. These coefficients have combinatorial significance for many\nclassical families of orthogonal polynomials. Starting with a stochastic\nprocess and using the stochastic measures machinery introduced by Rota and\nWallstrom, we calculate and give an interpretation of linearization\ncoefficients for a number of polynomial families. The processes involved may\nhave independent, freely independent or q-independent increments. The use of\nnoncommutative stochastic processes extends the range of applications\nsignificantly, allowing us to treat Hermite, Charlier, Chebyshev, free Charlier\nand Rogers and continuous big q-Hermite polynomials. The primary of these are the free Appell\npolynomials. In the multivariate case, they can be considered as natural\nanalogs of the Appell polynomials among polynomials in non-commuting variables.\nThey also fit well into the framework of free probability. For the free Appell\npolynomials, a number of combinatorial and \"diagram\" formulas are proven, such\nas the formulas for their linearization coefficients. An explicit formula for\ntheir generating function is obtained. These polynomials are also martingales\nfor free Levy processes. For more general free Sheffer families, a necessary\ncondition for pseudo-orthogonality is given. Another family investigated are\nthe Kailath-Segall polynomials. These are multivariate polynomials, which share\nwith the Appell polynomials nice combinatorial properties, but are always\northogonal. Their origins lie in the Fock space representations, or in the\ntheory of multiple stochastic integrals. Diagram formulas are proven for these\npolynomials as well, even in the q-deformed case.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This paper summarizes some known results about Appell polynomials and\ninvestigates their various analogs. The primary of these are the free Appell\npolynomials. In the multivariate case, they can be considered as natural\nanalogs of the Appell polynomials among polynomials in non-commuting variables.\nThey also fit well into the framework of free probability. For the free Appell\npolynomials, a number of combinatorial and \"diagram\" formulas are proven, such\nas the formulas for their linearization coefficients. An explicit formula for\ntheir generating function is obtained. These polynomials are also martingales\nfor free Levy processes. For more general free Sheffer families, a necessary\ncondition for pseudo-orthogonality is given. Another family investigated are\nthe Kailath-Segall polynomials. These are multivariate polynomials, which share\nwith the Appell polynomials nice combinatorial properties, but are always\northogonal. Their origins lie in the Fock space representations, or in the\ntheory of multiple stochastic integrals. Diagram formulas are proven for these\npolynomials as well, even in the q-deformed case."}, "authors": [{"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}, "author": "Michael Anshelevich", "arxiv_doi": "10.1155/S107379280413345X", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1155/S107379280413345X", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0311043v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0311043v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "45 pages, 2 postscript figures", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Int. Math. Res. Not. 2004 n. 65, 3469-3531", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "Primary 05A; Secondary 46L54", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0712.4185v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0712.4185v1", "updated": "2007-12-27T04:21:56Z", "updated_parsed": [2007, 12, 27, 4, 21, 56, 3, 361, 0], "published": "2007-12-27T04:21:56Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 12, 27, 4, 21, 56, 3, 361, 0], "title": "Appell polynomials and their relatives II. Boolean theory", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Appell polynomials and their relatives II. Boolean theory"}, "summary": "The Appell-type polynomial family corresponding to the simplest\nnon-commutative derivative operator turns out to be connected with the Boolean\nprobability theory, the simplest of the three universal non-commutative\nprobability theories (the other two being free and tensor/classical\nprobability). The basic properties of the Boolean Appell polynomials are\ndescribed. In particular, their generating function turns out to have a\nresolvent-type form, just like the generating function for the free Sheffer\npolynomials. It follows that the Meixner (that is, Sheffer plus orthogonal)\npolynomial classes, in the Boolean and free theory, coincide. This is true even\nin the multivariate case. A number of applications of this fact are described,\nto the Belinschi-Nica and Bercovici-Pata maps, conditional freeness, and the\nLaha-Lukacs type characterization.\n  A number of properties which hold for the Meixner class in the free and\nclassical cases turn out to hold in general in the Boolean theory. Examples\ninclude the behavior of the Jacobi coefficients under convolution, the\nrelationship between the Jacobi coefficients and cumulants, and an operator\nmodel for cumulants. Along the way, we obtain a multivariate version of the\nStieltjes continued fraction expansion for the moment generating function of an\narbitrary state with monic orthogonal polynomials.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The Appell-type polynomial family corresponding to the simplest\nnon-commutative derivative operator turns out to be connected with the Boolean\nprobability theory, the simplest of the three universal non-commutative\nprobability theories (the other two being free and tensor/classical\nprobability). The basic properties of the Boolean Appell polynomials are\ndescribed. In particular, their generating function turns out to have a\nresolvent-type form, just like the generating function for the free Sheffer\npolynomials. It follows that the Meixner (that is, Sheffer plus orthogonal)\npolynomial classes, in the Boolean and free theory, coincide. This is true even\nin the multivariate case. A number of applications of this fact are described,\nto the Belinschi-Nica and Bercovici-Pata maps, conditional freeness, and the\nLaha-Lukacs type characterization.\n  A number of properties which hold for the Meixner class in the free and\nclassical cases turn out to hold in general in the Boolean theory. Examples\ninclude the behavior of the Jacobi coefficients under convolution, the\nrelationship between the Jacobi coefficients and cumulants, and an operator\nmodel for cumulants. Along the way, we obtain a multivariate version of the\nStieltjes continued fraction expansion for the moment generating function of an\narbitrary state with monic orthogonal polynomials."}, "authors": [{"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}, "author": "Michael Anshelevich", "arxiv_doi": "10.1512/iumj.2009.58.3523", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1512/iumj.2009.58.3523", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0712.4185v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0712.4185v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_journal_ref": "Indiana Univ. Math. J. 58 (2009), 929-968", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L53 (Primary), 46L54 (Secondary), 05E35, 30B70", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0803.4279v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0803.4279v2", "updated": "2009-08-12T00:32:24Z", "updated_parsed": [2009, 8, 12, 0, 32, 24, 2, 224, 0], "published": "2008-03-29T20:16:32Z", "published_parsed": [2008, 3, 29, 20, 16, 32, 5, 89, 0], "title": "Appell polynomials and their relatives III. Conditionally free theory", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Appell polynomials and their relatives III. Conditionally free theory"}, "summary": "We extend to the multivariate non-commutative context the descriptions of a\n\"once-stripped\" probability measure in terms of Jacobi parameters, orthogonal\npolynomials, and the moment generating function. The corresponding map Phi on\nstates was introduced previously by Belinschi and Nica. We then relate these\nconstructions to the c-free probability theory, which is a version of free\nprobability for algebras with two states, introduced by Bozejko, Leinert, and\nSpeicher. This theory includes as two extreme cases the free and Boolean\nprobability theories. The main objects in the paper are the analogs of the\nAppell polynomial families in the two state context. They arise as fixed points\nof the transformation which takes a polynomial family to the associated\npolynomial family (in several variables), and their orthogonality is also\nrelated to the map Phi above. In addition, we prove recursions, generating\nfunctions, and factorization and martingale properties for these polynomials,\nand describe the c-free version of the Kailath-Segall polynomials, their\ncombinatorics, and Hilbert space representations.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We extend to the multivariate non-commutative context the descriptions of a\n\"once-stripped\" probability measure in terms of Jacobi parameters, orthogonal\npolynomials, and the moment generating function. The corresponding map Phi on\nstates was introduced previously by Belinschi and Nica. We then relate these\nconstructions to the c-free probability theory, which is a version of free\nprobability for algebras with two states, introduced by Bozejko, Leinert, and\nSpeicher. This theory includes as two extreme cases the free and Boolean\nprobability theories. The main objects in the paper are the analogs of the\nAppell polynomial families in the two state context. They arise as fixed points\nof the transformation which takes a polynomial family to the associated\npolynomial family (in several variables), and their orthogonality is also\nrelated to the map Phi above. In addition, we prove recursions, generating\nfunctions, and factorization and martingale properties for these polynomials,\nand describe the c-free version of the Kailath-Segall polynomials, their\ncombinatorics, and Hilbert space representations."}, "authors": [{"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}, "author": "Michael Anshelevich", "arxiv_comment": "A major revision: same theorems, different emphasis", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Illinois J. We extend this correspondence also to distributions infinitely\ndivisible with respect to the additive monotone convolution. Because of\nnon-commutativity of this convolution, we use a new technique based on the\nChernoff product formula. Boolean theory", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Appell polynomials and their relatives II. Boolean theory"}, "summary": "The Appell-type polynomial family corresponding to the simplest\nnon-commutative derivative operator turns out to be connected with the Boolean\nprobability theory, the simplest of the three universal non-commutative\nprobability theories (the other two being free and tensor/classical\nprobability). The basic properties of the Boolean Appell polynomials are\ndescribed. In particular, their generating function turns out to have a\nresolvent-type form, just like the generating function for the free Sheffer\npolynomials. It follows that the Meixner (that is, Sheffer plus orthogonal)\npolynomial classes, in the Boolean and free theory, coincide. This is true even\nin the multivariate case. A number of applications of this fact are described,\nto the Belinschi-Nica and Bercovici-Pata maps, conditional freeness, and the\nLaha-Lukacs type characterization.\n  A number of properties which hold for the Meixner class in the free and\nclassical cases turn out to hold in general in the Boolean theory. Examples\ninclude the behavior of the Jacobi coefficients under convolution, the\nrelationship between the Jacobi coefficients and cumulants, and an operator\nmodel for cumulants. Along the way, we obtain a multivariate version of the\nStieltjes continued fraction expansion for the moment generating function of an\narbitrary state with monic orthogonal polynomials.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The Appell-type polynomial family corresponding to the simplest\nnon-commutative derivative operator turns out to be connected with the Boolean\nprobability theory, the simplest of the three universal non-commutative\nprobability theories (the other two being free and tensor/classical\nprobability). The basic properties of the Boolean Appell polynomials are\ndescribed. In particular, their generating function turns out to have a\nresolvent-type form, just like the generating function for the free Sheffer\npolynomials. We show how for a B-valued distribution \\mu\none can define convolution powers with respect to free additive convolution and\nwith respect to Boolean convolution, where the exponent considered in the power\nis a suitably chosen linear map \\eta from B to B, instead of being a\nnon-negative real number. More precisely, the Boolean convolution power is\ndefined whenever \\eta is completely positive, while the free additive\nconvolution power is defined whenever \\eta - 1 is completely positive (where 1\nstands for the identity map on B).\n  In connection to these convolution powers we define an evolution semigroup\nrelated to the Boolean Bercovici-Pata bijection. We prove several properties of\nthis semigroup, including its connection to the B-valued free Brownian motion.\n  We also obtain two results on the operator-valued analytic function theory\nrelated to the free additive convolution powers with exponent \\eta. One of the\nresults concerns analytic subordination for B-valued Cauchy-Stieltjes\ntransforms. We show how for a B-valued distribution \\mu\none can define convolution powers with respect to free additive convolution and\nwith respect to Boolean convolution, where the exponent considered in the power\nis a suitably chosen linear map \\eta from B to B, instead of being a\nnon-negative real number. More precisely, the Boolean convolution power is\ndefined whenever \\eta is completely positive, while the free additive\nconvolution power is defined whenever \\eta - 1 is completely positive (where 1\nstands for the identity map on B).\n  In connection to these convolution powers we define an evolution semigroup\nrelated to the Boolean Bercovici-Pata bijection. We prove several properties of\nthis semigroup, including its connection to the B-valued free Brownian motion.\n  We also obtain two results on the operator-valued analytic function theory\nrelated to the free additive convolution powers with exponent \\eta. Amer. Math. Soc. 365 (2013), 2063-2097", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L54", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0803.4280v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0803.4280v2", "updated": "2008-04-12T16:18:30Z", "updated_parsed": [2008, 4, 12, 16, 18, 30, 5, 103, 0], "published": "2008-03-29T20:10:36Z", "published_parsed": [2008, 3, 29, 20, 10, 36, 5, 89, 0], "title": "Free evolution on algebras with two states", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Free evolution on algebras with two states"}, "summary": "The key result in the paper concerns two transformations, Phi(rho, psi) and\nB_t(psi) on states on the algebra of non-commutative polynomials, or\nequivalently on joint distributions of d-tuples of non-commuting operators.\nThese transformations are related to free probability: Phi intertwines the\naction of B_t and the free convolution with the semigroup {rho_t}. The maps\n{B_t} were introduced by Belinschi and Nica as a semigroup of transformations\nsuch that B_1 is the bijection between infinitely divisible distributions in\nthe Boolean and free probability theories. They proved the intertwining\nproperty above for a single-variable version of the map Phi and the particular\ncase of the free heat semigroup. The more general two-variable map Phi comes,\nnot from free probability, but from the theory of two-state algebras, also\ncalled the conditionally free probability theory, introduced by Bozejko,\nLeinert, and Speicher. Orthogonality of the c-free versions of the Appell\npolynomials, investigated in arXiv:0803.4279, is closely related to the\nsingle-variable map Phi. On the other hand, more general free Meixner families\nbehave well under all the transformations above, and provide clues to their\ngeneral behavior. Besides the evolution equation, other results include the\npositivity of the map Phi and descriptions of its fixed points and range.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The key result in the paper concerns two transformations, Phi(rho, psi) and\nB_t(psi) on states on the algebra of non-commutative polynomials, or\nequivalently on joint distributions of d-tuples of non-commuting operators.\nThese transformations are related to free probability: Phi intertwines the\naction of B_t and the free convolution with the semigroup {rho_t}. The maps\n{B_t} were introduced by Belinschi and Nica as a semigroup of transformations\nsuch that B_1 is the bijection between infinitely divisible distributions in\nthe Boolean and free probability theories. They proved the intertwining\nproperty above for a single-variable version of the map Phi and the particular\ncase of the free heat semigroup. The more general two-variable map Phi comes,\nnot from free probability, but from the theory of two-state algebras, also\ncalled the conditionally free probability theory, introduced by Bozejko,\nLeinert, and Speicher. Orthogonality of the c-free versions of the Appell\npolynomials, investigated in arXiv:0803.4279, is closely related to the\nsingle-variable map Phi. On the other hand, more general free Meixner families\nbehave well under all the transformations above, and provide clues to their\ngeneral behavior. Besides the evolution equation, other results include the\npositivity of the map Phi and descriptions of its fixed points and range."}, "authors": [{"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}, "author": "Michael Anshelevich", "arxiv_comment": "Remark 10 and comments before Lemma 3 added; statement of Theorem 10\n  modified", "arxiv_journal_ref": "J. We show that for any\nfree convolution semigroup of measures $\\nu_t$ with finite variance, applying a\nsingle stripping produces semicircular evolution with non-zero initial\ncondition, $J[\\nu_t] = \\rho \\boxplus \\sigma^{\\boxplus t}$, where $\\sigma$ is\nthe semicircular distribution with mean $\\beta$ and variance $\\gamma$. For more\ngeneral freely infinitely divisible distributions $\\tau$, expressions of the\nform $\\rho \\boxplus \\tau^{\\boxplus t}$ arise from stripping $\\mu_t$, where the\npairs $(\\mu_t, \\nu_t)$ form a semigroup under the operation of two-state free\nconvolution. We show that the operator $Q = p\nL_\\mu^2 - q L_\\mu$ has polynomial eigenfunctions if and only if $\\mu$ is a free\nMeixner distribution. The only time $Q$ has orthogonal polynomial\neigenfunctions is if $\\mu$ is a semicircular distribution. More generally, the\nonly time the operator $p (L_\\nu L_\\mu) - q L_\\mu$ has orthogonal polynomial\neigenfunctions is when $\\mu$ and $\\nu$ are related by a Jacobi shift.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The operator $L_\\mu: f \\mapsto \\int \\frac{f(x) - f(y)}{x - y} d\\mu(y)$ is,\nfor a compactly supported measure $\\mu$ with an $L^3$ density, a closed,\ndensely defined operator on $L^2(\\mu)$. These include numerous known examples and one new family, of\n$\\mathcal{B}$-valued free binomial distributions, for which we are able to\ncompute free convolution powers. Moreover, we develop a convenient\ncombinatorial method for calculating the joint distributions of\n$\\mathcal{B}$-free random variables with Jacobi parameters, utilizing two-color\nnon-crossing partitions. This leads to several new explicit examples of free\nconvolution computations in the operator-valued setting. Moreover, we develop a convenient\ncombinatorial method for calculating the joint distributions of\n$\\mathcal{B}$-free random variables with Jacobi parameters, utilizing two-color\nnon-crossing partitions. This leads to several new explicit examples of free\nconvolution computations in the operator-valued setting. Math. 207 (2002), 13-30.", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0102062v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0102062v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L54 (Primary) 60G, 60H (Secondary)", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0702158v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0702158v1", "updated": "2007-02-06T19:46:22Z", "updated_parsed": [2007, 2, 6, 19, 46, 22, 1, 37, 0], "published": "2007-02-06T19:46:22Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 2, 6, 19, 46, 22, 1, 37, 0], "title": "Free Meixner states", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Free Meixner states"}, "summary": "Free Meixner states are a class of functionals on non-commutative polynomials\nintroduced in math.CO/0410482. They are characterized by a resolvent-type form\nfor the generating function of their orthogonal polynomials, by a recursion\nrelation for those polynomials, or by a second-order non-commutative\ndifferential equation satisfied by their free cumulant functional. In this\npaper, we construct an operator model for free Meixner states. By combinatorial\nmethods, we also derive an operator model for their free cumulant functionals.\nThis, in turn, allows us to construct a number of examples. Many of these\nexamples are shown to be trivial, in the sense of being free products of\nfunctionals which depend on only a single variable, or rotations of such free\nproducts. On the other hand, the multinomial distribution is a free Meixner\nstate and is not a product. Neither is a large class of tracial free Meixner\nstates which are analogous to the simple quadratic exponential families in\nstatistics.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Free Meixner states are a class of functionals on non-commutative polynomials\nintroduced in math.CO/0410482. They are characterized by a resolvent-type form\nfor the generating function of their orthogonal polynomials, by a recursion\nrelation for those polynomials, or by a second-order non-commutative\ndifferential equation satisfied by their free cumulant functional. In this\npaper, we construct an operator model for free Meixner states. By combinatorial\nmethods, we also derive an operator model for their free cumulant functionals.\nThis, in turn, allows us to construct a number of examples. Many of these\nexamples are shown to be trivial, in the sense of being free products of\nfunctionals which depend on only a single variable, or rotations of such free\nproducts. On the other hand, the multinomial distribution is a free Meixner\nstate and is not a product. Neither is a large class of tracial free Meixner\nstates which are analogous to the simple quadratic exponential families in\nstatistics."}, "authors": [{"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}, "author": "Michael Anshelevich", "arxiv_doi": "10.1007/s00220-007-0322-3", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00220-007-0322-3", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0702158v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0702158v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "30 pages", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Commun. Math. Phys. 276 (2007), 863-899", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CO", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "Primary 46L54; Secondary 05E35, 33C47", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.08180v4", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.08180v4", "updated": "2016-08-04T17:09:43Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 8, 4, 17, 9, 43, 3, 217, 0], "published": "2016-01-29T16:25:02Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 1, 29, 16, 25, 2, 4, 29, 0], "title": "The exponential map in non-commutative probability", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The exponential map in non-commutative probability"}, "summary": "The wrapping transformation $W$ is a homomorphism from the semigroup of\nprobability measures on the real line, with the convolution operation, to the\nsemigroup of probability measures on the circle, with the multiplicative\nconvolution operation. We show that on a large class $\\mathcal{L}$ of measures,\n$W$ also transforms the three non-commutative convolutions---free, Boolean, and\nmonotone---to their multiplicative counterparts. Moreover, the restriction of\n$W$ to $\\mathcal{L}$ preserves various qualitative properties of measures and\ntriangular arrays. We use these facts to give short proofs of numerous known,\nand new, results about multiplicative convolutions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The wrapping transformation $W$ is a homomorphism from the semigroup of\nprobability measures on the real line, with the convolution operation, to the\nsemigroup of probability measures on the circle, with the multiplicative\nconvolution operation. We show that on a large class $\\mathcal{L}$ of measures,\n$W$ also transforms the three non-commutative convolutions---free, Boolean, and\nmonotone---to their multiplicative counterparts. Moreover, the restriction of\n$W$ to $\\mathcal{L}$ preserves various qualitative properties of measures and\ntriangular arrays. We use these facts to give short proofs of numerous known,\nand new, results about multiplicative convolutions."}, "authors": [{"name": "Michael Anshelevich"}, {"name": "Octavio Arizmendi"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Octavio Arizmendi"}, "author": "Octavio Arizmendi", "arxiv_comment": "v4: added a remark on conditional convolutions; v3: added a\n  unimodality result; corrections throughout following comments by the\n  referees. v2: a correction in Remark 22", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.08180v4", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1601.08180v4", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46L54 (Primary), 46L53 (Secondary)", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1212.5566v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1212.5566v1", "updated": "2012-12-21T19:18:45Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 12, 21, 19, 18, 45, 4, 356, 0], "published": "2012-12-21T19:18:45Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 12, 21, 19, 18, 45, 4, 356, 0], "title": "Viscous regularization of the Euler equations and entropy principles", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Viscous regularization of the Euler equations and entropy principles"}, "summary": "This paper investigates a general class of viscous regularizations of the\ncompressible Euler equations. The properties of the method are based on the\nintroduction of an artificial dissipation that is defined so that any convex\ninvariant sets containing the initial data is an invariant domain for the\nmethod. The invariant domain property is proved for any hyperbolic system\nprovided a CFL condition holds. The solution is also shown to satisfy a\ndiscrete entropy inequality for every admissible entropy of the system. The\nmethod is formally first-order accurate in space and can be made high-order in\ntime by using Strong Stability Preserving algorithms. This technique extends to\ncontinuous finite elements the work of \\cite{Hoff_1979,Hoff_1985}, and\n\\cite{Frid_2001}.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We propose a numerical method to solve general hyperbolic systems in any\nspace dimension using forward Euler time stepping and continuous finite\nelements on non-uniform grids. The properties of the method are based on the\nintroduction of an artificial dissipation that is defined so that any convex\ninvariant sets containing the initial data is an invariant domain for the\nmethod. The invariant domain property is proved for any hyperbolic system\nprovided a CFL condition holds. The solution is also shown to satisfy a\ndiscrete entropy inequality for every admissible entropy of the system. The\nmethod is formally first-order accurate in space and can be made high-order in\ntime by using Strong Stability Preserving algorithms. The emphasis here is not maximally attainable numerical\naccuracy, but beyond textbook accuracy as informed by physical insights. We\ndemonstrate how the interplay of the cusp condition, the asymptotic condition,\nthe electron-correlation, configuration interaction, and the exact one electron\ntwo-center orbitals, can produce energy results approaching chemical accuracy.\nReviews of more traditional calculational approaches, such as Hartree-Fock, are\nalso given.\n  The inclusion of electron correlation via Hylleraas type functions is well\nknown to be important, but difficult to implement for more than two electrons.\nThe use of the D-scaled Bohr model offers the tantalizing possibility of\nobtaining electron correlation energy in a non-traditional way.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this review we first discuss extension of Bohr's 1913 molecular model and\nshow that it corresponds to the large-D limit of a dimensional scaling\n(D-scaling) analysis, as developed by Herschbach and coworkers.\n  In a separate but synergetic approach to the two-electron problem, we\nsummarize recent advances in constructing analytical models for describing the\ntwo-electron bond. The emphasis here is not maximally attainable numerical\naccuracy, but beyond textbook accuracy as informed by physical insights. We\ndemonstrate how the interplay of the cusp condition, the asymptotic condition,\nthe electron-correlation, configuration interaction, and the exact one electron\ntwo-center orbitals, can produce energy results approaching chemical accuracy.\nReviews of more traditional calculational approaches, such as Hartree-Fock, are\nalso given.\n  The inclusion of electron correlation via Hylleraas type functions is well\nknown to be important, but difficult to implement for more than two electrons.\nThe use of the D-scaled Bohr model offers the tantalizing possibility of\nobtaining electron correlation energy in a non-traditional way."}, "authors": [{"name": "Goong Chen"}, {"name": "Siu A. In this paper, we show that H and P(.) suffice\nto generate the unitary group U(2) and, consequently, through controlled-U\noperations and their concatenations, the entire unitary group U(2^n) on\nn-qubits can be generated. Since any quantum computing algorithm in an n-qubit\nquantum computer is based on operations by matrices in U(2^n), in this sense we\nhave the universality of the QFT.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The quantum Fourier transform (QFT) is a powerful tool in quantum computing.\nThe main ingredients of QFT are formed by the Walsh-Hadamard transform H and\nphase shifts P(.), both of which are 2x2 unitary matrices as operators on the\ntwo-dimensional 1-qubit space. In this paper, we show that H and P(.) suffice\nto generate the unitary group U(2) and, consequently, through controlled-U\noperations and their concatenations, the entire unitary group U(2^n) on\nn-qubits can be generated. Since any quantum computing algorithm in an n-qubit\nquantum computer is based on operations by matrices in U(2^n), in this sense we\nhave the universality of the QFT."}, "authors": [{"name": "Charles M. Bowden"}, {"name": "Goong Chen"}, {"name": "Zijian Diao"}, {"name": "Andreas Klappenecker"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Andreas Klappenecker"}, "author": "Andreas Klappenecker", "arxiv_comment": "12 pages, 3 figures, submitted to SIAM Journal on Computing", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0007122v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/quant-ph/0007122v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0011019v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0011019v2", "updated": "2000-11-10T19:35:37Z", "updated_parsed": [2000, 11, 10, 19, 35, 37, 4, 315, 0], "published": "2000-11-06T02:06:21Z", "published_parsed": [2000, 11, 6, 2, 6, 21, 0, 311, 0], "title": "Quantum Multi-object Search Algorithm with the Availability of Partial\n  Information", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Quantum Multi-object Search Algorithm with the Availability of Partial\n  Information"}, "summary": "Consider the unstructured search of an unknown number l of items in a large\nunsorted database of size N. The multi-object quantum search algorithm consists\nof two parts. The first part of the algorithm is to generalize Grover's\nsingle-object search algorithm to the multi-object case and the second part is\nto solve a counting problem to determine l.\n  In this paper, we study the multi-object quantum search algorithm (in\ncontinuous time), but in a more structured way by taking into account the\navailability of partial information. The modeling of available partial\ninformation is done simply by the combination of several prescribed, possibly\noverlapping, information sets with varying weights to signify the reliability\nof each set. The associated statistics is estimated and the algorithm\nefficiency and complexity are analyzed.\n  Our analysis shows that the search algorithm described here may not be more\nefficient than the unstructured (generalized) multi-object Grover search if\nthere is ``misplaced confidence''. However, if the information sets have a\n``basic confidence'' property in the sense that each information set contains\nat least one search item, then a quadratic speedup holds on a much smaller data\nspace, which further expedite the quantum search for the first item.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Consider the unstructured search of an unknown number l of items in a large\nunsorted database of size N. The multi-object quantum search algorithm consists\nof two parts. The first part of the algorithm is to generalize Grover's\nsingle-object search algorithm to the multi-object case and the second part is\nto solve a counting problem to determine l.\n  In this paper, we study the multi-object quantum search algorithm (in\ncontinuous time), but in a more structured way by taking into account the\navailability of partial information. The modeling of available partial\ninformation is done simply by the combination of several prescribed, possibly\noverlapping, information sets with varying weights to signify the reliability\nof each set. The associated statistics is estimated and the algorithm\nefficiency and complexity are analyzed.\n  Our analysis shows that the search algorithm described here may not be more\nefficient than the unstructured (generalized) multi-object Grover search if\nthere is ``misplaced confidence''. However, if the information sets have a\n``basic confidence'' property in the sense that each information set contains\nat least one search item, then a quadratic speedup holds on a much smaller data\nspace, which further expedite the quantum search for the first item."}, "authors": [{"name": "Goong Chen"}, {"name": "Zijian Diao"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zijian Diao"}, "author": "Zijian Diao", "arxiv_doi": "10.1515/zna-2001-1215", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1515/zna-2001-1215", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0011019v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/quant-ph/0011019v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "17 pages, 1 figure", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0303163v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0303163v1", "updated": "2003-03-26T14:19:14Z", "updated_parsed": [2003, 3, 26, 14, 19, 14, 2, 85, 0], "published": "2003-03-26T14:19:14Z", "published_parsed": [2003, 3, 26, 14, 19, 14, 2, 85, 0], "title": "Mathematical Models of Contemporary Elementary Quantum Computing Devices", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Mathematical Models of Contemporary Elementary Quantum Computing Devices"}, "summary": "Computations with a future quantum computer will be implemented through the\noperations by elementary quantum gates. It is now well known that the\ncollection of 1-bit and 2-bit quantum gates are universal for quantum\ncomputation, i.e., any n-bit unitary operation can be carried out by\nconcatenations of 1-bit and 2-bit elementary quantum gates.\n  Three contemporary quantum devices--cavity QED, ion traps and quantum\ndots--have been widely regarded as perhaps the most promising candidates for\nthe construction of elementary quantum gates. In this paper, we describe the\nphysical properties of these devices, and show the mathematical derivations\nbased on the interaction of the laser field as control with atoms, ions or\nelectron spins, leading to the following: (i) the 1-bit unitary rotation gates;\nand (ii) the 2-bit quantum phase gates and the controlled-not gate. This paper\nis aimed at providing a sufficiently self-contained survey account of\nanalytical nature for mathematicians, physicists and computer scientists to aid\ninterdisciplinary understanding in the research of quantum computation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Computations with a future quantum computer will be implemented through the\noperations by elementary quantum gates. It is now well known that the\ncollection of 1-bit and 2-bit quantum gates are universal for quantum\ncomputation, i.e., any n-bit unitary operation can be carried out by\nconcatenations of 1-bit and 2-bit elementary quantum gates.\n  Three contemporary quantum devices--cavity QED, ion traps and quantum\ndots--have been widely regarded as perhaps the most promising candidates for\nthe construction of elementary quantum gates. In this paper, we describe the\nphysical properties of these devices, and show the mathematical derivations\nbased on the interaction of the laser field as control with atoms, ions or\nelectron spins, leading to the following: (i) the 1-bit unitary rotation gates;\nand (ii) the 2-bit quantum phase gates and the controlled-not gate. This paper\nis aimed at providing a sufficiently self-contained survey account of\nanalytical nature for mathematicians, physicists and computer scientists to aid\ninterdisciplinary understanding in the research of quantum computation."}, "authors": [{"name": "G. Chen"}, {"name": "D. A. Church"}, {"name": "B. -G. Englert"}, {"name": "M. S. Zubairy"}], "author_detail": {"name": "M. S. Zubairy"}, "author": "M. S. Zubairy", "arxiv_comment": "40 pages, 10 figures. A. Bandrauk, M.C. Delfour, and C. Le Bris, ed.,\n  ``Quantum Control: Mathematical and Numerical Challenges, CRM (Centre de\n  Recherches Mathematiques, Universite de Montreal) Proceedings Lecture Notes\n  Series, American Mathematical Society Publications, Providence, R.I., 2003,\n  to appear", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0303163v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/quant-ph/0303163v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1905.10602v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1905.10602v1", "updated": "2019-05-25T14:28:20Z", "updated_parsed": [2019, 5, 25, 14, 28, 20, 5, 145, 0], "published": "2019-05-25T14:28:20Z", "published_parsed": [2019, 5, 25, 14, 28, 20, 5, 145, 0], "title": "Parallelization of the inverse fast multipole method with an application\n  to boundary element method", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Parallelization of the inverse fast multipole method with an application\n  to boundary element method"}, "summary": "We present an algorithm to parallelize the inverse fast multipole method\n(IFMM), which is an approximate direct solver for dense linear systems. The\nparallel scheme is based on a greedy coloring algorithm, where two nodes in the\nhierarchy with the same color are separated by at least $\\sigma$ nodes. We\nproved that when $\\sigma \\ge 6$, the workload associated with one color is\nembarrassingly parallel. However, the number of nodes in a group (color) may be\nsmall when $\\sigma = 6$. Therefore, we also explored $\\sigma = 3$, where a\nsmall fraction of the algorithm needs to be serialized, and the overall\nparallel efficiency was improved. We implemented the parallel IFMM using OpenMP\nfor shared-memory machines. Successively, we applied it to a fast-multipole\naccelerated boundary element method (FMBEM) as a preconditioner, and compared\nits efficiency with (a) the original IFMM parallelized by linking a\nmulti-threaded linear algebra library and (b) the commonly used parallel\nblock-diagonal preconditioner. Our results showed that our parallel IFMM\nachieved at most $4\\times$ and $11\\times$ speedups over the reference method\n(a) and (b), respectively, in realistic examples involving more than one\nmillion variables.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We present an algorithm to parallelize the inverse fast multipole method\n(IFMM), which is an approximate direct solver for dense linear systems. The\nparallel scheme is based on a greedy coloring algorithm, where two nodes in the\nhierarchy with the same color are separated by at least $\\sigma$ nodes. We\nproved that when $\\sigma \\ge 6$, the workload associated with one color is\nembarrassingly parallel. However, the number of nodes in a group (color) may be\nsmall when $\\sigma = 6$. Therefore, we also explored $\\sigma = 3$, where a\nsmall fraction of the algorithm needs to be serialized, and the overall\nparallel efficiency was improved. We implemented the parallel IFMM using OpenMP\nfor shared-memory machines. Successively, we applied it to a fast-multipole\naccelerated boundary element method (FMBEM) as a preconditioner, and compared\nits efficiency with (a) the original IFMM parallelized by linking a\nmulti-threaded linear algebra library and (b) the commonly used parallel\nblock-diagonal preconditioner. Our results showed that our parallel IFMM\nachieved at most $4\\times$ and $11\\times$ speedups over the reference method\n(a) and (b), respectively, in realistic examples involving more than one\nmillion variables."}, "authors": [{"name": "Toru Takahashi"}, {"name": "Chao Chen"}, {"name": "Eric Darve"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Eric Darve"}, "author": "Eric Darve", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.cpc.2019.106975", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cpc.2019.106975", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1905.10602v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1905.10602v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "physics.comp-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "physics.comp-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.05188v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.05188v1", "updated": "2017-02-16T23:55:55Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 2, 16, 23, 55, 55, 3, 47, 0], "published": "2017-02-16T23:55:55Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 2, 16, 23, 55, 55, 3, 47, 0], "title": "A finite element method for elliptic problems with observational\n  boundary data", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A finite element method for elliptic problems with observational\n  boundary data"}, "summary": "In this paper we propose a finite element method for solving elliptic\nequations with the observational Dirichlet boundary data which may subject to\nrandom noises. The method is based on the weak formulation of Lagrangian\nmultiplier. We show the convergence of the random finite element error in\nexpectation and, when the noise is sub-Gaussian, in the Orlicz 2- norm which\nimplies the probability that the finite element error estimates are violated\ndecays exponentially. Numerical examples are included.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper we propose a finite element method for solving elliptic\nequations with the observational Dirichlet boundary data which may subject to\nrandom noises. The method is based on the weak formulation of Lagrangian\nmultiplier. We show the convergence of the random finite element error in\nexpectation and, when the noise is sub-Gaussian, in the Orlicz 2- norm which\nimplies the probability that the finite element error estimates are violated\ndecays exponentially. Numerical examples are included."}, "authors": [{"name": "Zhiming Chen"}, {"name": "Rui Tuo"}, {"name": "Wenlong Zhang"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Wenlong Zhang"}, "author": "Wenlong Zhang", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.05188v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1702.05188v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.12050v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.12050v1", "updated": "2022-01-28T11:28:30Z", "updated_parsed": [2022, 1, 28, 11, 28, 30, 4, 28, 0], "published": "2022-01-28T11:28:30Z", "published_parsed": [2022, 1, 28, 11, 28, 30, 4, 28, 0], "title": "Fast multipole boundary element method for the acoustic analysis of\n  finite periodic structures", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Fast multipole boundary element method for the acoustic analysis of\n  finite periodic structures"}, "summary": "In this work, two fast multipole boundary element formulations for the linear\ntime-harmonic acoustic analysis of finite periodic structures are presented.\nFinite periodic structures consist of a bounded number of unit cell\nreplications in one or more directions of periodicity. Such structures can be\ndesigned to efficiently control and manipulate sound waves and are referred to\nas acoustic metamaterials or sonic crystals. Our methods subdivide the geometry\ninto boxes which correspond to the unit cell. A boundary element discretization\nis applied and interactions between well separated boxes are approximated by a\nfast multipole expansion. Due to the periodicity of the underlying geometry,\ncertain operators of the expansion become block Toeplitz matrices. This allows\nto express matrix-vector products as circular convolutions which significantly\nreduces the computational effort and the overall memory requirements. The\nefficiency of the presented techniques is shown based on an acoustic scattering\nproblem. In addition, a study on the design of sound barriers is presented\nwhere the performance of a wall-like sound barrier is compared to the\nperformance of two sonic crystal sound barriers.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this work, two fast multipole boundary element formulations for the linear\ntime-harmonic acoustic analysis of finite periodic structures are presented.\nFinite periodic structures consist of a bounded number of unit cell\nreplications in one or more directions of periodicity. Such structures can be\ndesigned to efficiently control and manipulate sound waves and are referred to\nas acoustic metamaterials or sonic crystals. Our methods subdivide the geometry\ninto boxes which correspond to the unit cell. A boundary element discretization\nis applied and interactions between well separated boxes are approximated by a\nfast multipole expansion. Due to the periodicity of the underlying geometry,\ncertain operators of the expansion become block Toeplitz matrices. This allows\nto express matrix-vector products as circular convolutions which significantly\nreduces the computational effort and the overall memory requirements. The\nefficiency of the presented techniques is shown based on an acoustic scattering\nproblem. In addition, a study on the design of sound barriers is presented\nwhere the performance of a wall-like sound barrier is compared to the\nperformance of two sonic crystal sound barriers."}, "authors": [{"name": "Christopher Jelich"}, {"name": "Wenchang Zhao"}, {"name": "Haibo Chen"}, {"name": "Steffen Marburg"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Steffen Marburg"}, "author": "Steffen Marburg", "2020-02-12T08:34:47Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 2, 12, 8, 34, 47, 2, 43, 0], "published": "2020-02-12T08:34:47Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 2, 12, 8, 34, 47, 2, 43, 0], "title": "An isogeometric boundary element method for soft particles flowing in\n  microfluidic channels", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "An isogeometric boundary element method for soft particles flowing in\n  microfluidic channels"}, "summary": "Understanding the flow of deformable particles such as liquid drops,\nsynthetic capsules and vesicles, and biological cells confined in a small\nchannel is essential to a wide range of potential chemical and biomedical\nengineering applications. Computer simulations of this kind of fluid-structure\n(membrane) interaction in low-Reynolds-number flows raise significant\nchallenges faced by an intricate interplay between flow stresses, complex\nparticles' interfacial mechanical properties, and fluidic confinement. Here, we\npresent an isogeometric computational framework by combining the finite-element\nmethod (FEM) and boundary-element method (BEM) for an accurate prediction of\nthe deformation and motion of a single soft particle transported in\nmicrofluidic channels. The proposed numerical framework is constructed\nconsistently with the isogeometric analysis paradigm; Loop's subdivision\nelements are used not only for the representation of geometry but also for the\nmembrane mechanics solver (FEM) and the interfacial fluid dynamics solver\n(BEM). We validate our approach by comparison of the simulation results with\nhighly accurate benchmark solutions to two well-known examples available in the\nliterature, namely a liquid drop with constant surface tension in a circular\ntube and a capsule with a very thin hyperelastic membrane in a square channel.\nWe show that the numerical method exhibits second-order convergence in both\ntime and space. To further demonstrate the accuracy and long-time numerically\nstable simulations of the algorithm, we perform hydrodynamic computations of a\nlipid vesicle with bending stiffness and a red blood cell with a composite\nmembrane in capillaries. The present work offers some possibilities to study\nthe deformation behavior of confining soft particles, especially the particles'\nshape transition and dynamics and their rheological signature in channel flows.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Understanding the flow of deformable particles such as liquid drops,\nsynthetic capsules and vesicles, and biological cells confined in a small\nchannel is essential to a wide range of potential chemical and biomedical\nengineering applications. Computer simulations of this kind of fluid-structure\n(membrane) interaction in low-Reynolds-number flows raise significant\nchallenges faced by an intricate interplay between flow stresses, complex\nparticles' interfacial mechanical properties, and fluidic confinement. Here, we\npresent an isogeometric computational framework by combining the finite-element\nmethod (FEM) and boundary-element method (BEM) for an accurate prediction of\nthe deformation and motion of a single soft particle transported in\nmicrofluidic channels. The proposed numerical framework is constructed\nconsistently with the isogeometric analysis paradigm; Loop's subdivision\nelements are used not only for the representation of geometry but also for the\nmembrane mechanics solver (FEM) and the interfacial fluid dynamics solver\n(BEM). We validate our approach by comparison of the simulation results with\nhighly accurate benchmark solutions to two well-known examples available in the\nliterature, namely a liquid drop with constant surface tension in a circular\ntube and a capsule with a very thin hyperelastic membrane in a square channel.\nWe show that the numerical method exhibits second-order convergence in both\ntime and space. To further demonstrate the accuracy and long-time numerically\nstable simulations of the algorithm, we perform hydrodynamic computations of a\nlipid vesicle with bending stiffness and a red blood cell with a composite\nmembrane in capillaries. The present work offers some possibilities to study\nthe deformation behavior of confining soft particles, especially the particles'\nshape transition and dynamics and their rheological signature in channel flows."}, "authors": [{"name": "J. News editorial is a genre of\npersuasive text, where the argumentation structure is usually implicit.\nHowever, the arguments presented in an editorial typically center around a\nconcise, focused thesis, which we refer to as their perspective. MultiOpEd aims\nat supporting the study of multiple tasks relevant to automatic perspective\ndiscovery, where a system is expected to produce a single-sentence thesis\nstatement summarizing the arguments presented. We argue that identifying and\nabstracting such natural language perspectives from editorials is a crucial\nstep toward studying the implicit argumentation structure in news editorials.\nWe first discuss the challenges and define a few conceptual tasks towards our\ngoal. To demonstrate the utility of MultiOpEd and the induced tasks, we study\nthe problem of perspective summarization in a multi-task learning setting, as a\ncase study. We show that, with the induced tasks as auxiliary tasks, we can\nimprove the quality of the perspective summary generated. We hope that\nMultiOpEd will be a useful resource for future studies on argumentation in the\nnews editorial domain.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We propose MultiOpEd, an open-domain news editorial corpus that supports\nvarious tasks pertaining to the argumentation structure in news editorials,\nfocusing on automatic perspective discovery. News editorial is a genre of\npersuasive text, where the argumentation structure is usually implicit.\nHowever, the arguments presented in an editorial typically center around a\nconcise, focused thesis, which we refer to as their perspective. MultiOpEd aims\nat supporting the study of multiple tasks relevant to automatic perspective\ndiscovery, where a system is expected to produce a single-sentence thesis\nstatement summarizing the arguments presented. We argue that identifying and\nabstracting such natural language perspectives from editorials is a crucial\nstep toward studying the implicit argumentation structure in news editorials.\nWe first discuss the challenges and define a few conceptual tasks towards our\ngoal. To demonstrate the utility of MultiOpEd and the induced tasks, we study\nthe problem of perspective summarization in a multi-task learning setting, as a\ncase study. We show that, with the induced tasks as auxiliary tasks, we can\nimprove the quality of the perspective summary generated. We hope that\nMultiOpEd will be a useful resource for future studies on argumentation in the\nnews editorial domain."}, "authors": [{"name": "Siyi Liu"}, {"name": "Sihao Chen"}, {"name": "Xander Uyttendaele"}, {"name": "Dan Roth"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Dan Roth"}, "author": "Dan Roth", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2106.02725v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2106.02725v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "cs.CL", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "cs.CL", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1802.06110v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1802.06110v1", "updated": "2018-02-16T20:23:58Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 2, 16, 20, 23, 58, 4, 47, 0], "published": "2018-02-16T20:23:58Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 2, 16, 20, 23, 58, 4, 47, 0], "title": "Light, the universe, and everything -- 12 Herculean tasks for quantum\n  cowboys and black diamond skiers", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Light, the universe, and everything -- 12 Herculean tasks for quantum\n  cowboys and black diamond skiers"}, "summary": "The Winter Colloquium on the Physics of Quantum Electronics (PQE) has been a\nseminal force in quantum optics and related areas since 1971. It is rather\nmindboggling to recognize how the concepts presented at these conferences have\ntransformed scientific understanding and human society. In January, 2017, the\nparticipants of PQE were asked to consider the equally important prospects for\nthe future, and to formulate a set of questions representing some of the\ngreatest aspirations in this broad field. The result is this multi-authored\npaper, in which many of the world's leading experts address the following\nfundamental questions: (1) What is the future of gravitational wave astronomy?\n(2) Are there new quantum phases of matter away from equilibrium that can be\nfound and exploited - such as the time crystal? (3) Quantum theory in uncharted\nterritory: What can we learn? (4) What are the ultimate limits for laser photon\nenergies? It is rather\nmindboggling to recognize how the concepts presented at these conferences have\ntransformed scientific understanding and human society. In January, 2017, the\nparticipants of PQE were asked to consider the equally important prospects for\nthe future, and to formulate a set of questions representing some of the\ngreatest aspirations in this broad field. Modern Optics (42 figures, 74 pages)", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "cond-mat.other", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "physics.optics", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1608.06102v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1608.06102v1", "updated": "2016-08-22T09:53:41Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 8, 22, 9, 53, 41, 0, 235, 0], "published": "2016-08-22T09:53:41Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 8, 22, 9, 53, 41, 0, 235, 0], "title": "The virial theorem and ground state energy estimate of nonlinear\n  Schr\u00f6dinger equations in $\\mathbb{R}^2$ with square root and saturable\n  nonlinearities in nonlinear optics", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The virial theorem and ground state energy estimate of nonlinear\n  Schr\u00f6dinger equations in $\\mathbb{R}^2$ with square root and saturable\n  nonlinearities in nonlinear optics"}, "summary": "The virial theorem is a nice property for the linear Schrodinger equation in\natomic and molecular physics as it gives an elegant ratio between the kinetic\nand potential energies and is useful in assessing the quality of numerically\ncomputed eigenvalues. If the governing equation is a nonlinear Schrodinger\nequation with power-law nonlinearity, then a similar ratio can be obtained but\nthere seems no way of getting any eigenvalue estimate. It is surprising as far\nas we are concerned that when the nonlinearity is either square-root or\nsaturable nonlinearity (not a power-law), one can develop a virial theorem and\neigenvalue estimate of nonlinear Schrodinger (NLS) equations in R2 with\nsquare-root and saturable nonlinearity, respectively. Furthermore, we show here\nthat the eigenvalue estimate can be used to obtain the 2nd order term (which is\nof order $ln\\Gamma$) of the lower bound of the ground state energy as the\ncoefficient $\\Gamma$ of the nonlinear term tends to infinity.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The virial theorem is a nice property for the linear Schrodinger equation in\natomic and molecular physics as it gives an elegant ratio between the kinetic\nand potential energies and is useful in assessing the quality of numerically\ncomputed eigenvalues. If the governing equation is a nonlinear Schrodinger\nequation with power-law nonlinearity, then a similar ratio can be obtained but\nthere seems no way of getting any eigenvalue estimate. It is surprising as far\nas we are concerned that when the nonlinearity is either square-root or\nsaturable nonlinearity (not a power-law), one can develop a virial theorem and\neigenvalue estimate of nonlinear Schrodinger (NLS) equations in R2 with\nsquare-root and saturable nonlinearity, respectively. Furthermore, we show here\nthat the eigenvalue estimate can be used to obtain the 2nd order term (which is\nof order $ln\\Gamma$) of the lower bound of the ground state energy as the\ncoefficient $\\Gamma$ of the nonlinear term tends to infinity."}, "authors": [{"name": "Tai-Chia Lin"}, {"name": "Milivoj R. Belic"}, {"name": "Milan S. Petrovic"}, {"name": "Hichem Hajaiej"}, {"name": "Goong Chen"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Goong Chen"}, "author": "Goong Chen", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1608.06102v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1608.06102v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "nlin.PS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "physics.optics", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0007077v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0007077v1", "updated": "2000-07-20T16:06:19Z", "updated_parsed": [2000, 7, 20, 16, 6, 19, 3, 202, 0], "published": "2000-07-20T16:06:19Z", "published_parsed": [2000, 7, 20, 16, 6, 19, 3, 202, 0], "title": "On the quantum mechanical nature in liquid NMR quantum computing", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "On the quantum mechanical nature in liquid NMR quantum computing"}, "summary": "The quantum nature of bulk ensemble NMR quantum computing --the center of\nrecent heated debate, is addressed. Concepts of the mixed state and\nentanglement are examined, and the data in a 2 qubit liquid NMR quantum\ncomputation are analyzed. It is pointed out that the key problem in the current\ndebate is the understanding of entanglement in a mixed state system. The\nfollowing points are concluded in this Letter: 1)Density matrix describes the\n\"state\" of an average particle in an ensemble. It can not describe the state of\nan individual particle in an ensemble in detail; 2) Entanglement is a property\nof the wave function of a quantum particle(such as an molecule in a liquid NMR\nsample). Separability of the density matrix can not be used to measure the\nentanglement of mixed ensemble; 3)The evolution of states in bulk-ensemble NMR\nquantum computation is quantum mechanical; 4) The coefficient before the\neffective pure state density matrix, $\\epsilon$, is an measure of the\nsimultaneity of the molecules in an ensemble. It reflects the intensity of the\nNMR signal and has no significance in quantifying the entanglement in the bulk\nensemble NMR system. We conclude that the liquid NMR quantum computation is\ngenuine, not just classical simulations.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The quantum nature of bulk ensemble NMR quantum computing --the center of\nrecent heated debate, is addressed. Concepts of the mixed state and\nentanglement are examined, and the data in a 2 qubit liquid NMR quantum\ncomputation are analyzed. It is pointed out that the key problem in the current\ndebate is the understanding of entanglement in a mixed state system. The\nfollowing points are concluded in this Letter: 1)Density matrix describes the\n\"state\" of an average particle in an ensemble. It can not describe the state of\nan individual particle in an ensemble in detail; 2) Entanglement is a property\nof the wave function of a quantum particle(such as an molecule in a liquid NMR\nsample). Separability of the density matrix can not be used to measure the\nentanglement of mixed ensemble; 3)The evolution of states in bulk-ensemble NMR\nquantum computation is quantum mechanical; 4) The coefficient before the\neffective pure state density matrix, $\\epsilon$, is an measure of the\nsimultaneity of the molecules in an ensemble. It reflects the intensity of the\nNMR signal and has no significance in quantifying the entanglement in the bulk\nensemble NMR system. We conclude that the liquid NMR quantum computation is\ngenuine, not just classical simulations."}, "authors": [{"name": "G L Long"}, {"name": "H Y Yan"}, {"name": "Y s Li"}, {"name": "C C Tu"}, {"name": "s J Zhu"}, {"name": "D Ruan"}, {"name": "Y Sun"}, {"name": "J X Tao"}, {"name": "H M Chen"}], "author_detail": {"name": "H M Chen"}, "author": "H M Chen", "arxiv_comment": "4 pages", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Commun. Theor. Phys. 38, 306-308(2002)", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0007077v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/quant-ph/0007077v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1105.4228v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1105.4228v1", "updated": "2011-05-21T08:17:06Z", "updated_parsed": [2011, 5, 21, 8, 17, 6, 5, 141, 0], "published": "2011-05-21T08:17:06Z", "published_parsed": [2011, 5, 21, 8, 17, 6, 5, 141, 0], "title": "Simulation of chemical reaction dynamics on an NMR quantum computer", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Simulation of chemical reaction dynamics on an NMR quantum computer"}, "summary": "Quantum simulation can beat current classical computers with minimally a few\ntens of qubits and will likely become the first practical use of a quantum\ncomputer. One promising application of quantum simulation is to attack\nchallenging quantum chemistry problems. Here we report an experimental\ndemonstration that a small nuclear-magnetic-resonance (NMR) quantum computer is\nalready able to simulate the dynamics of a prototype chemical reaction. The\nexperimental results agree well with classical simulations. We conclude that\nthe quantum simulation of chemical reaction dynamics not computable on current\nclassical computers is feasible in the near future.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Quantum simulation can beat current classical computers with minimally a few\ntens of qubits and will likely become the first practical use of a quantum\ncomputer. One promising application of quantum simulation is to attack\nchallenging quantum chemistry problems. Here we report an experimental\ndemonstration that a small nuclear-magnetic-resonance (NMR) quantum computer is\nalready able to simulate the dynamics of a prototype chemical reaction. The\nexperimental results agree well with classical simulations. We conclude that\nthe quantum simulation of chemical reaction dynamics not computable on current\nclassical computers is feasible in the near future."}, "authors": [{"name": "Dawei Lu"}, {"name": "Nanyang Xu"}, {"name": "Ruixue Xu"}, {"name": "Hongwei Chen"}, {"name": "Jiangbin Gong"}, {"name": "Xinhua Peng"}, {"name": "Jiangfeng Du"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Jiangfeng Du"}, "author": "Jiangfeng Du", "arxiv_doi": "10.1103/PhysRevLett.107.020501", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.107.020501", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1105.4228v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1105.4228v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "37 pages, 7 figures", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Phys.
