Lett. 107, 020501 (2011)", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0407109v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0407109v1", "updated": "2004-07-15T07:43:03Z", "updated_parsed": [2004, 7, 15, 7, 43, 3, 3, 197, 0], "published": "2004-07-15T07:43:03Z", "published_parsed": [2004, 7, 15, 7, 43, 3, 3, 197, 0], "title": "Ensemble Algorithm for the Selection Problem by NMR Ensemble Quantum\n  Computers", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Ensemble Algorithm for the Selection Problem by NMR Ensemble Quantum\n  Computers"}, "summary": "In this paper, we present an ensemble algorithm for selection problem to find\nthe k-th smallest element in the unsorted database. We will search the k-th\nsmallest element by using \"divide-and-conquer\" strategy. We first divide D, the\ndomain of the database, into two parts, determine which of the two parts the\nobject element sought belongs to, and then concentrate on that part. We repeat\ndivide that part until object element is found. The determination of which part\ndepends on the output of ensemble counting scheme, which outputs the number of\nassignments satisfying the value of the oracle query function is set to one.\nOur algorithm modifies the ensemble counting scheme by constructing a new\noracle query function g_y(j). We set g_y(j) to one if the j-th element is less\nthan or equal to y. At first, we set y to the middle value of D and perform the\nensemble counting scheme with the oracle query function g_y(.) to compute the\nnumber C, the number of j satisfying g_y(j)=1. If C>k, the object element lies\nin the first half of D. If C<=k, then it must be in the second half of D. We\nrecursively apply this method by adapting y until the object element is found.\nOur algorithm thus requires O(ln|D|) oracle queries for adequate measure\naccuracy to find the k-th smallest element, where |D| denotes the size of D.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we present an ensemble algorithm for selection problem to find\nthe k-th smallest element in the unsorted database. We will search the k-th\nsmallest element by using \"divide-and-conquer\" strategy. We first divide D, the\ndomain of the database, into two parts, determine which of the two parts the\nobject element sought belongs to, and then concentrate on that part. We repeat\ndivide that part until object element is found. The determination of which part\ndepends on the output of ensemble counting scheme, which outputs the number of\nassignments satisfying the value of the oracle query function is set to one.\nOur algorithm modifies the ensemble counting scheme by constructing a new\noracle query function g_y(j). We set g_y(j) to one if the j-th element is less\nthan or equal to y. At first, we set y to the middle value of D and perform the\nensemble counting scheme with the oracle query function g_y(.) to compute the\nnumber C, the number of j satisfying g_y(j)=1. If C>k, the object element lies\nin the first half of D. If C<=k, then it must be in the second half of D. We\nrecursively apply this method by adapting y until the object element is found.\nOur algorithm thus requires O(ln|D|) oracle queries for adequate measure\naccuracy to find the k-th smallest element, where |D| denotes the size of D."}, "authors": [{"name": "Chien-Yuan Chen"}, {"name": "Chih-Cheng Hsueh"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Chih-Cheng Hsueh"}, "author": "Chih-Cheng Hsueh", "arxiv_comment": "16 pages, 1 figure", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0407109v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/quant-ph/0407109v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.04885v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.04885v1", "updated": "2015-03-17T00:56:53Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 3, 17, 0, 56, 53, 1, 76, 0], "published": "2015-03-17T00:56:53Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 3, 17, 0, 56, 53, 1, 76, 0], "title": "Optimal control of the state statistics for a linear stochastic system", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Optimal control of the state statistics for a linear stochastic system"}, "summary": "We consider a variant of the classical linear quadratic Gaussian regulator\n(LQG) in which penalties on the endpoint state are replaced by the\nspecification of the terminal state distribution. The resulting theory\nconsiderably differs from LQG as well as from formulations that bound the\nprobability of violating state constraints. We develop results for optimal\nstate-feedback control in the two cases where i) steering of the state\ndistribution is to take place over a finite window of time with minimum energy,\nand ii) the goal is to maintain the state at a stationary distribution over an\ninfinite horizon with minimum power. For both problems the distribution of\nnoise and state are Gaussian. In the first case, we show that provided the\nsystem is controllable, the state can be steered to any terminal Gaussian\ndistribution over any specified finite time-interval. In the second case, we\ncharacterize explicitly the covariance of admissible stationary state\ndistributions that can be maintained with constant state-feedback control. The\nconditions for optimality are expressed in terms of a system of dynamically\ncoupled Riccati equations in the finite horizon case and in terms of algebraic\nconditions for the stationary case. In the case where the noise and control\nshare identical input channels, the Riccati equations for finite-horizon\nsteering become homogeneous and can be solved in closed form. The present paper\nis largely based on our recent work in arxiv.org/abs/1408.2222,\narxiv.org/abs/1410.3447 and presents an overview of certain key results.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider a variant of the classical linear quadratic Gaussian regulator\n(LQG) in which penalties on the endpoint state are replaced by the\nspecification of the terminal state distribution. The resulting theory\nconsiderably differs from LQG as well as from formulations that bound the\nprobability of violating state constraints. We develop results for optimal\nstate-feedback control in the two cases where i) steering of the state\ndistribution is to take place over a finite window of time with minimum energy,\nand ii) the goal is to maintain the state at a stationary distribution over an\ninfinite horizon with minimum power. For both problems the distribution of\nnoise and state are Gaussian. In the first case, we show that provided the\nsystem is controllable, the state can be steered to any terminal Gaussian\ndistribution over any specified finite time-interval. In the second case, we\ncharacterize explicitly the covariance of admissible stationary state\ndistributions that can be maintained with constant state-feedback control. The\nconditions for optimality are expressed in terms of a system of dynamically\ncoupled Riccati equations in the finite horizon case and in terms of algebraic\nconditions for the stationary case. In the case where the noise and control\nshare identical input channels, the Riccati equations for finite-horizon\nsteering become homogeneous and can be solved in closed form. The present paper\nis largely based on our recent work in arxiv.org/abs/1408.2222,\narxiv.org/abs/1410.3447 and presents an overview of certain key results."}, "authors": [{"name": "Yongxin Chen"}, More specifically, we provide mutually\ncompatible tools for hierarchical, sequential, and independent parallel\ncomposition. In our framework, hierarchies of hybrid systems correspond to\ntemplate-anchor pairs, which we model as spans of subdividing and embedding\nsemiconjugacies. Hierarchical composition of template-anchor pairs corresponds\nto the composition of spans via pullback. To model sequential composition, we\nintroduce \"directed hybrid systems,\" each of which flows from an initial\nsubsystem to a final subsystem in a Conley-theoretic sense. Sequential\ncomposition of directed systems is given by a pushout of graph embeddings,\nrewriting the continuous dynamics of the overlapping subsystem to prioritize\nthe second directed system. Independent parallel composition corresponds to a\ncategorical product with respect to semiconjugacy. To formalize the\ncompatibility of these three types of composition, we construct a vertically\ncartesian double category of hybrid systems where the vertical morphisms are\nsemiconjugacies, and the horizontal morphisms are directed hybrid systems.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We develop a compositional framework for formal synthesis of hybrid systems\nusing the language of category theory. More specifically, we provide mutually\ncompatible tools for hierarchical, sequential, and independent parallel\ncomposition. In our framework, hierarchies of hybrid systems correspond to\ntemplate-anchor pairs, which we model as spans of subdividing and embedding\nsemiconjugacies. Hierarchical composition of template-anchor pairs corresponds\nto the composition of spans via pullback. To model sequential composition, we\nintroduce \"directed hybrid systems,\" each of which flows from an initial\nsubsystem to a final subsystem in a Conley-theoretic sense. Sequential\ncomposition of directed systems is given by a pushout of graph embeddings,\nrewriting the continuous dynamics of the overlapping subsystem to prioritize\nthe second directed system. Independent parallel composition corresponds to a\ncategorical product with respect to semiconjugacy. Indeed, mostly we focus on a finite point\ncharge electrical field $F =(X,Y)$ in $\\mathbb R^2$. The well-known conjecture\nis that the zero set of $F = (X,Y)$ is finite. We show that this is true in a\nSpecial Case: when the point charges for $F = (X,Y)$ lie on a line. In\naddition, we give fairly complete structural information about the zero sets of\n$X$ and $Y$ for $F = (X,Y)$ in the Special Case. Indeed, mostly we focus on a finite point\ncharge electrical field $F =(X,Y)$ in $\\mathbb R^2$. The well-known conjecture\nis that the zero set of $F = (X,Y)$ is finite. We show that this is true in a\nSpecial Case: when the point charges for $F = (X,Y)$ lie on a line. A sequence of Littlewood polynomials that satisfies a remarkable\nflatness property on the unit circle of the complex plane is given by the\nRudin-Shapiro polynomials. It is shown in this paper that the Mahler measure\nand the maximum modulus of the Rudin-Shapiro polynomials on the unit circle of\nthe complex plane have the same size. It is also shown that the Mahler measure\nand the maximum norm of the Rudin-Shapiro polynomials have the same size even\non not too small subarcs of the unit circle of the complex plane. Not even\nnontrivial lower bounds for the Mahler measure of the Rudin Shapiro polynomials\nhave been known before.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Littlewood polynomials are polynomials with each of their coefficients in\n{-1,1}. It is shown in this paper that the Mahler measure\nand the maximum modulus of the Rudin-Shapiro polynomials on the unit circle of\nthe complex plane have the same size. It is also shown that the Mahler measure\nand the maximum norm of the Rudin-Shapiro polynomials have the same size even\non not too small subarcs of the unit circle of the complex plane. Not even\nnontrivial lower bounds for the Mahler measure of the Rudin Shapiro polynomials\nhave been known before."}, "authors": [{"name": "Tamas Erdelyi"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Tamas Erdelyi"}, "author": "Tamas Erdelyi", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1406.2233v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1406.2233v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CV", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CV", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.01189v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.01189v2", "updated": "2017-09-18T22:18:53Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 9, 18, 22, 18, 53, 0, 261, 0], "published": "2017-08-03T16:01:26Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 8, 3, 16, 1, 26, 3, 215, 0], "title": "The asymptotic value of the Mahler measure of the Rudin-Shapiro\n  polynomials", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The asymptotic value of the Mahler measure of the Rudin-Shapiro\n  polynomials"}, "summary": "In signal processing the Rudin-Shapiro polynomials have good autocorrelation\nproperties and their values on the unit circle are small. Binary sequences with\nlow autocorrelation coefficients are of interest in radar, sonar, and\ncommunication systems. In this paper we show that the Mahler measure of the\nRudin-Shapiro polynomials of degree $n=2^k-1$ is asymptotically $(2n/e)^{1/2}$,\nas it was conjectured by B. Saffari in 1985. Our approach is based heavily on\nthe Saffari and Montgomery conjectures proved recently by B. Rodgers.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In signal processing the Rudin-Shapiro polynomials have good autocorrelation\nproperties and their values on the unit circle are small. Binary sequences with\nlow autocorrelation coefficients are of interest in radar, sonar, and\ncommunication systems. In this paper we show that the Mahler measure of the\nRudin-Shapiro polynomials of degree $n=2^k-1$ is asymptotically $(2n/e)^{1/2}$,\nas it was conjectured by B. Saffari in 1985. Our approach is based heavily on\nthe Saffari and Montgomery conjectures proved recently by B. Rodgers."}, "authors": [{"name": "Tam\u00e1s Erd\u00e9lyi"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Tam\u00e1s Erd\u00e9lyi"}, "author": "Tam\u00e1s Erd\u00e9lyi", "arxiv_comment": "arxiv admin note: text "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.05823v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.05823v2", "updated": "2019-02-13T17:37:44Z", "updated_parsed": [2019, 2, 13, 17, 37, 44, 2, 44, 0], "published": "2017-02-20T00:26:07Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 2, 20, 0, 26, 7, 0, 51, 0], "title": "Improved lower bound for the number of unimodular zeros of\n  self-reciprocal polynomials with coefficients in a finite set", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Improved lower bound for the number of unimodular zeros of\n  self-reciprocal polynomials with coefficients in a finite set"}, "summary": "Let $n_1 < n_2 < \\cdots < n_N$ be non-negative integers. In a private\ncommunication Brian Conrey asked how fast the number of real zeros of the\ntrigonometric polynomials $T_N(\\theta) = \\sum_{j=1}^N {\\cos (n_j\\theta)}$ tends\nto $\\infty$ as a function of $N$. Conrey's question in general does not appear\nto be easy.Let ${\\mathcal P}_n(S)$ be the set of all algebraic polynomials of\ndegree at most $n$ with each of their coefficients in $S$. For a finite set $S\n\\subset {\\mathbb C}$ let $M = M(S) := \\max\\{|z|: z \\in S\\}$. It has been shown\nrecently that if $S \\subset {\\mathbb R}$ is a finite set and $(P_n)$ is a\nsequence of self-reciprocal polynomials $P_n \\in {\\mathcal P}_n(S)$ with\n$|P_n(1)|$ tending to $\\infty$, then the number of zeros of $P_n$ on the unit\ncircle also tends to $\\infty$. In this paper we show that if $S \\subset\n{\\mathbb Z}$ is a finite set, then every self-reciprocal polynomial $P \\in\n{\\mathcal P}_n(S)$ has at least $$c(\\log\\log\\log|P(1)|)^{1-\\varepsilon}-1$$\nzeros on the unit circle of ${\\mathbb C}$ with a constant $c > 0$ depending\nonly on $\\varepsilon > 0$ and$M = M(S)$. Our new result improves the exponent\n$1/2 - \\varepsilon$ in a recent result by Julian Sahasrabudhe to $1 -\n\\varepsilon$. Sahasrabudhe's new idea [66] is combined with the approach used\nin [34] offering an essencially simplified way to achieve our improvement. We\nnote that in both Sahasrabudhe's paper and our paper the assumption that the\nfinite set $S$ contains only integers is deeply exploited.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $n_1 < n_2 < \\cdots < n_N$ be non-negative integers. In a private\ncommunication Brian Conrey asked how fast the number of real zeros of the\ntrigonometric polynomials $T_N(\\theta) = \\sum_{j=1}^N {\\cos (n_j\\theta)}$ tends\nto $\\infty$ as a function of $N$. Conrey's question in general does not appear\nto be easy.Let ${\\mathcal P}_n(S)$ be the set of all algebraic polynomials of\ndegree at most $n$ with each of their coefficients in $S$. For a finite set $S\n\\subset {\\mathbb C}$ let $M = M(S) := \\max\\{|z|: z \\in S\\}$. It has been shown\nrecently that if $S \\subset {\\mathbb R}$ is a finite set and $(P_n)$ is a\nsequence of self-reciprocal polynomials $P_n \\in {\\mathcal P}_n(S)$ with\n$|P_n(1)|$ tending to $\\infty$, then the number of zeros of $P_n$ on the unit\ncircle also tends to $\\infty$. In this paper we show that if $S \\subset\n{\\mathbb Z}$ is a finite set, then every self-reciprocal polynomial $P \\in\n{\\mathcal P}_n(S)$ has at least $$c(\\log\\log\\log|P(1)|)^{1-\\varepsilon}-1$$\nzeros on the unit circle of ${\\mathbb C}$ with a constant $c > 0$ depending\nonly on $\\varepsilon > 0$ and$M = M(S)$. Our new result improves the exponent\n$1/2 - \\varepsilon$ in a recent result by Julian Sahasrabudhe to $1 -\n\\varepsilon$. Sahasrabudhe's new idea [66] is combined with the approach used\nin [34] offering an essencially simplified way to achieve our improvement. We\nnote that in both Sahasrabudhe's paper and our paper the assumption that the\nfinite set $S$ contains only integers is deeply exploited."}, "authors": [{"name": "Tam\u00e1s Erd\u00e9lyi"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Tam\u00e1s Erd\u00e9lyi"}, "author": "Tam\u00e1s Erd\u00e9lyi", "arxiv_comment": "arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with arXiv:1602.02284", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.05823v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1702.05823v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2001.08151v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2001.08151v2", "updated": "2020-07-07T20:20:46Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 7, 7, 20, 20, 46, 1, 189, 0], "published": "2020-01-22T17:17:10Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 1, 22, 17, 17, 10, 2, 22, 0], "title": "Do flat skew-reciprocal Littlewood polynomials exist?", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Do flat skew-reciprocal Littlewood polynomials exist?"}, "summary": "Polynomials with coefficients in $\\{-1,1\\}$ are called Littlewood\npolynomials. Using special properties of the Rudin-Shapiro polynomials and\nclassical results in approximation theory such as Jackson's Theorem, de la\nVall\\'ee Poussin sums, Bernstein's inequality, Riesz's Lemma, divided\ndifferences, etc., we give a significantly simplified proof of a recent\nbreakthrough result by Balister, Bollob\\'as, Morris, Sahasrabudhe, and Tiba\nstating that there exist absolute constants $\\eta_2 > \\eta_1 > 0$ and a\nsequence $(P_n)$ of Littlewood polynomials $P_n$ of degree $n$ such that\n$$\\eta_1 \\sqrt{n} \\leq |P_n(z)| \\leq \\eta_2 \\sqrt{n}\\,, \\qquad z \\in\n\\mathbb{C}\\,, \\, \\, |z| = 1,,$$ confirming a conjecture of Littlewood from\n1966. Moreover, the existence of a sequence $(P_n)$ of Littlewood polynomials\n$P_n$ is shown in a way that in addition to the above flatness properties a\ncertain symmetry is satisfied by the coefficients of $P_n$ making the\nLittlewood polynomials $P_n$ close to skew-reciprocal.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Polynomials with coefficients in $\\{-1,1\\}$ are called Littlewood\npolynomials. Using special properties of the Rudin-Shapiro polynomials and\nclassical results in approximation theory such as Jackson's Theorem, de la\nVall\\'ee Poussin sums, Bernstein's inequality, Riesz's Lemma, divided\ndifferences, etc., we give a significantly simplified proof of a recent\nbreakthrough result by Balister, Bollob\\'as, Morris, Sahasrabudhe, and Tiba\nstating that there exist absolute constants $\\eta_2 > \\eta_1 > 0$ and a\nsequence $(P_n)$ of Littlewood polynomials $P_n$ of degree $n$ such that\n$$\\eta_1 \\sqrt{n} \\leq |P_n(z)| \\leq \\eta_2 \\sqrt{n}\\,, \\qquad z \\in\n\\mathbb{C}\\,, \\, \\, |z| = 1,,$$ confirming a conjecture of Littlewood from\n1966. Moreover, the existence of a sequence $(P_n)$ of Littlewood polynomials\n$P_n$ is shown in a way that in addition to the above flatness properties a\ncertain symmetry is satisfied by the coefficients of $P_n$ making the\nLittlewood polynomials $P_n$ close to skew-reciprocal."}, "authors": [{"name": "Tam\u00e1s Erd\u00e9lyi"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Tam\u00e1s Erd\u00e9lyi"}, "author": "Tam\u00e1s Erd\u00e9lyi", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2001.08151v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2001.08151v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "11C08, 41A17, 26C10, 30C15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1809.07733v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1809.07733v1", "updated": "2018-09-20T16:50:46Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 9, 20, 16, 50, 46, 3, 263, 0], "published": "2018-09-20T16:50:46Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 9, 20, 16, 50, 46, 3, 263, 0], "title": "Reverse Markov- and Bernstein-type inequalities for incomplete\n  polynomials", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Reverse Markov- and Bernstein-type inequalities for incomplete\n  polynomials"}, "summary": "Let ${\\mathcal P}_k$ denote the set of all algebraic polynomials of degree at\nmost $k$ with real coefficients. Let ${\\mathcal P}_{n,k}$ be the set of all\nalgebraic polynomials of degree at most $n+k$ having exactly $n+1$ zeros at\n$0$. Let $$\\|f\\|_A := \\sup_{x \\in A}{|f(x)|}$$ for real-valued functions $f$\ndefined on a set $A \\subset {\\Bbb R}$. Let $$V_a^b(f) :=\n\\int_a^b{|f^{\\prime}(x)| \\, dx}$$ denote the total variation of a continuously\ndifferentiable function $f$ on an interval $[a,b]$. We prove that there are\nabsolute constants $c_1 > 0$ and $c_2 > 0$ such that $$c_1 \\frac nk\\leq \\min_{P\n\\in {\\mathcal P}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}\\|_{[0,1]}}{V_0^1(P)}} \\leq \\min_{P\n\\in {\\mathcal P}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}\\|_{[0,1]}}{|P(1)|}} \\leq c_2 \\left(\n\\frac nk + 1 \\right)$$ for all integers $n \\geq 1$ and $k \\geq 1$. We also\nprove that there are absolute constants $c_1 > 0$ and $c_2 > 0$ such that $$c_1\n\\left(\\frac nk\\right)^{1/2} \\leq \\min_{P \\in {\\mathcal\nP}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}(x)\\sqrt{1-x^2}\\|_{[0,1]}}{V_0^1(P)}} \\leq \\min_{P\n\\in {\\mathcal P}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}(x)\\sqrt{1-x^2}\\|_{[0,1]}}{|P(1)|}}\n\\leq c_2 \\left(\\frac nk + 1\\right)^{1/2}$$ for all integers $n \\geq 1$ and $k\n\\geq 1$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let ${\\mathcal P}_k$ denote the set of all algebraic polynomials of degree at\nmost $k$ with real coefficients. Let ${\\mathcal P}_{n,k}$ be the set of all\nalgebraic polynomials of degree at most $n+k$ having exactly $n+1$ zeros at\n$0$. Let $$\\|f\\|_A := \\sup_{x \\in A}{|f(x)|}$$ for real-valued functions $f$\ndefined on a set $A \\subset {\\Bbb R}$. Let $$V_a^b(f) :=\n\\int_a^b{|f^{\\prime}(x)| \\, dx}$$ denote the total variation of a continuously\ndifferentiable function $f$ on an interval $[a,b]$. We prove that there are\nabsolute constants $c_1 > 0$ and $c_2 > 0$ such that $$c_1 \\frac nk\\leq \\min_{P\n\\in {\\mathcal P}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}\\|_{[0,1]}}{V_0^1(P)}} \\leq \\min_{P\n\\in {\\mathcal P}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}\\|_{[0,1]}}{|P(1)|}} \\leq c_2 \\left(\n\\frac nk + 1 \\right)$$ for all integers $n \\geq 1$ and $k \\geq 1$. The result may be compared with\nErdos's classical Markov-type inequality (1940) for polynomials of degree at\nmost n having only real zeros outside the interval (-1,1)."}, "authors": [{"name": "Tamas Erdelyi"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Tamas Erdelyi"}, "author": "Tamas Erdelyi", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1406.2843v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1406.2843v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1206.4729v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1206.4729v2", "updated": "2013-02-06T01:21:34Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 2, 6, 1, 21, 34, 2, 37, 0], "published": "2012-06-20T21:55:52Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 6, 20, 21, 55, 52, 2, 172, 0], "title": "Riesz Polarization Inequalities in Higher Dimensions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Riesz Polarization Inequalities in Higher Dimensions"}, "summary": "We derive bounds and asymptotics for the maximum Riesz polarization quantity\n$$M_n^p(A) := \\max_{{\\bold x}_1, {\\bold x}_2, \\ldots, {\\bold x}_n \\in A}\n{\\min_{{\\bold x} \\in A}{\\sum_{j=1}^n{\\frac{1}{|{\\bold x} - {\\bold\nx}_j|^{p}}}}}$$ (which is $n$ times the Chebyshev constant) for quite general\nsets $A \\subset {\\Bbb R}^m$ with special focus on the unit sphere and unit\nball. We combine elementary averaging arguments with potential theoretic tools\nto formulate and prove our results. We also give a discrete version of the\nrecent result of Hardin, Kendall, and Saff which solves the Riesz polarization\nproblem for the case when $A$ is the unit circle and $p>0,$ as well as provide\nan independent proof of their result for $p=4$ that exploits classical\npolynomial inequalities and yields new estimates. Furthermore, we raise some\nchallenging conjectures.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We derive bounds and asymptotics for the maximum Riesz polarization quantity\n$$M_n^p(A) := \\max_{{\\bold x}_1, {\\bold x}_2, \\ldots, {\\bold x}_n \\in A}\n{\\min_{{\\bold x} \\in A}{\\sum_{j=1}^n{\\frac{1}{|{\\bold x} - {\\bold\nx}_j|^{p}}}}}$$ (which is $n$ times the Chebyshev constant) for quite general\nsets $A \\subset {\\Bbb R}^m$ with special focus on the unit sphere and unit\nball. We combine elementary averaging arguments with potential theoretic tools\nto formulate and prove our results. We also give a discrete version of the\nrecent result of Hardin, Kendall, and Saff which solves the Riesz polarization\nproblem for the case when $A$ is the unit circle and $p>0,$ as well as provide\nan independent proof of their result for $p=4$ that exploits classical\npolynomial inequalities and yields new estimates. This is intimately tied to irreducibility questions and proved as a\nconsequence of a new result."}, "authors": [{"name": "Peter Borwein"}, {"name": "Tamas Erdelyi"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Tamas Erdelyi"}, "author": "Tamas Erdelyi", "arxiv_comment": "9 pages, number theory", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1206.5371v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1206.5371v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.07340v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.07340v3", "updated": "2021-07-08T01:55:27Z", "updated_parsed": [2021, 7, 8, 1, 55, 27, 3, 189, 0], "published": "2020-06-12T17:25:39Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 6, 12, 17, 25, 39, 4, 164, 0], "title": "Fourier Sparse Leverage Scores and Approximate Kernel Learning", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Fourier Sparse Leverage Scores and Approximate Kernel Learning"}, "summary": "We prove new explicit upper bounds on the leverage scores of Fourier sparse\nfunctions under both the Gaussian and Laplace measures. In particular, we study\n$s$-sparse functions of the form $f(x) = \\sum_{j=1}^s a_j e^{i \\lambda_j x}$\nfor coefficients $a_j \\in \\mathbb{C}$ and frequencies $\\lambda_j \\in\n\\mathbb{R}$. Bounding Fourier sparse leverage scores under various measures is\nof pure mathematical interest in approximation theory, and our work extends\nexisting results for the uniform measure [Erd17,CP19a]. Practically, our bounds\nare motivated by two important applications in machine learning:\n  1. Kernel Approximation. They yield a new random Fourier features algorithm\nfor approximating Gaussian and Cauchy (rational quadratic) kernel matrices. For\nlow-dimensional data, our method uses a near optimal number of features, and\nits runtime is polynomial in the $statistical\\ dimension$ of the approximated\nkernel matrix. It is the first \"oblivious sketching method\" with this property\nfor any kernel besides the polynomial kernel, resolving an open question of\n[AKM+17,AKK+20b].\n  2. Active Learning. They can be used as non-uniform sampling distributions\nfor robust active learning when data follows a Gaussian or Laplace\ndistribution. Using the framework of [AKM+19], we provide essentially optimal\nresults for bandlimited and multiband interpolation, and Gaussian process\nregression. These results generalize existing work that only applies to\nuniformly distributed data.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We prove new explicit upper bounds on the leverage scores of Fourier sparse\nfunctions under both the Gaussian and Laplace measures. In particular, we study\n$s$-sparse functions of the form $f(x) = \\sum_{j=1}^s a_j e^{i \\lambda_j x}$\nfor coefficients $a_j \\in \\mathbb{C}$ and frequencies $\\lambda_j \\in\n\\mathbb{R}$. Bounding Fourier sparse leverage scores under various measures is\nof pure mathematical interest in approximation theory, and our work extends\nexisting results for the uniform measure [Erd17,CP19a]. Practically, our bounds\nare motivated by two important applications in machine learning:\n  1. Kernel Approximation. They yield a new random Fourier features algorithm\nfor approximating Gaussian and Cauchy (rational quadratic) kernel matrices. For\nlow-dimensional data, our method uses a near optimal number of features, and\nits runtime is polynomial in the $statistical\\ dimension$ of the approximated\nkernel matrix. It is the first \"oblivious sketching method\" with this property\nfor any kernel besides the polynomial kernel, resolving an open question of\n[AKM+17,AKK+20b].\n  2. Active Learning. They can be used as non-uniform sampling distributions\nfor robust active learning when data follows a Gaussian or Laplace\ndistribution. Using the framework of [AKM+19], we provide essentially optimal\nresults for bandlimited and multiband interpolation, and Gaussian process\nregression. In particular, we study\n$s$-sparse functions of the form $f(x) = \\sum_{j=1}^s a_j e^{i \\lambda_j x}$\nfor coefficients $a_j \\in \\mathbb{C}$ and frequencies $\\lambda_j \\in\n\\mathbb{R}$. Bounding Fourier sparse leverage scores under various measures is\nof pure mathematical interest in approximation theory, and our work extends\nexisting results for the uniform measure [Erd17,CP19a]. Practically, our bounds\nare motivated by two important applications in machine learning:\n  1. Kernel Approximation. They yield a new random Fourier features algorithm\nfor approximating Gaussian and Cauchy (rational quadratic) kernel matrices. For\nlow-dimensional data, our method uses a near optimal number of features, and\nits runtime is polynomial in the $statistical\\ dimension$ of the approximated\nkernel matrix. It is the first \"oblivious sketching method\" with this property\nfor any kernel besides the polynomial kernel, resolving an open question of\n[AKM+17,AKK+20b].\n  2. Active Learning. They can be used as non-uniform sampling distributions\nfor robust active learning when data follows a Gaussian or Laplace\ndistribution. Using the framework of [AKM+19], we provide essentially optimal\nresults for bandlimited and multiband interpolation, and Gaussian process\nregression. These results generalize existing work that only applies to\nuniformly distributed data.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We prove new explicit upper bounds on the leverage scores of Fourier sparse\nfunctions under both the Gaussian and Laplace measures. Bounding Fourier sparse leverage scores under various measures is\nof pure mathematical interest in approximation theory, and our work extends\nexisting results for the uniform measure [Erd17,CP19a]. Practically, our bounds\nare motivated by two important applications in machine learning:\n  1. Kernel Approximation. They yield a new random Fourier features algorithm\nfor approximating Gaussian and Cauchy (rational quadratic) kernel matrices. For\nlow-dimensional data, our method uses a near optimal number of features, and\nits runtime is polynomial in the $statistical\\ dimension$ of the approximated\nkernel matrix. Let ${\\mathcal P}_{n,k}$ be the set of all\nalgebraic polynomials of degree at most $n+k$ having exactly $n+1$ zeros at\n$0$. Let $$\\|f\\|_A := \\sup_{x \\in A}{|f(x)|}$$ for real-valued functions $f$\ndefined on a set $A \\subset {\\Bbb R}$. Let $$V_a^b(f) :=\n\\int_a^b{|f^{\\prime}(x)| \\, dx}$$ denote the total variation of a continuously\ndifferentiable function $f$ on an interval $[a,b]$. We prove that there are\nabsolute constants $c_1 > 0$ and $c_2 > 0$ such that $$c_1 \\frac nk\\leq \\min_{P\n\\in {\\mathcal P}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}\\|_{[0,1]}}{V_0^1(P)}} \\leq \\min_{P\n\\in {\\mathcal P}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}\\|_{[0,1]}}{|P(1)|}} \\leq c_2 \\left(\n\\frac nk + 1 \\right)$$ for all integers $n \\geq 1$ and $k \\geq 1$. We also\nprove that there are absolute constants $c_1 > 0$ and $c_2 > 0$ such that $$c_1\n\\left(\\frac nk\\right)^{1/2} \\leq \\min_{P \\in {\\mathcal\nP}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}(x)\\sqrt{1-x^2}\\|_{[0,1]}}{V_0^1(P)}} \\leq \\min_{P\n\\in {\\mathcal P}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}(x)\\sqrt{1-x^2}\\|_{[0,1]}}{|P(1)|}}\n\\leq c_2 \\left(\\frac nk + 1\\right)^{1/2}$$ for all integers $n \\geq 1$ and $k\n\\geq 1$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let ${\\mathcal P}_k$ denote the set of all algebraic polynomials of degree at\nmost $k$ with real coefficients. Let ${\\mathcal P}_{n,k}$ be the set of all\nalgebraic polynomials of degree at most $n+k$ having exactly $n+1$ zeros at\n$0$. Let $$\\|f\\|_A := \\sup_{x \\in A}{|f(x)|}$$ for real-valued functions $f$\ndefined on a set $A \\subset {\\Bbb R}$. Let $$V_a^b(f) :=\n\\int_a^b{|f^{\\prime}(x)| \\, dx}$$ denote the total variation of a continuously\ndifferentiable function $f$ on an interval $[a,b]$. We prove that there are\nabsolute constants $c_1 > 0$ and $c_2 > 0$ such that $$c_1 \\frac nk\\leq \\min_{P\n\\in {\\mathcal P}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}\\|_{[0,1]}}{V_0^1(P)}} \\leq \\min_{P\n\\in {\\mathcal P}_{n,k}}{\\frac{\\|P^{\\prime}\\|_{[0,1]}}{|P(1)|}} \\leq c_2 \\left(\n\\frac nk + 1 \\right)$$ for all integers $n \\geq 1$ and $k \\geq 1$. In its simplest form, stable point separation\nimplies that if $f$ is \"far away\" from $0$, and one is given a random sample\n$(f(Z_i))_{i=1}^m$ where a proportional number of the sample points may be\ncorrupted by noise, that information is still enough to exhibit that $f$ is far\nfrom $0$.\n  Stable point separation is well understood in the context of iid sampling,\nand to explore it for general sampling methods we introduce a new notion---the\n\\emph{coordinate small-ball} of a random vector $X$. Roughly put, this feature\ncaptures the number of \"relatively large coordinates\" of\n$(|<TX,u_i>|)_{i=1}^m$, where $T:\\mathbb{R}^n \\to \\mathbb{R}^m$ is an arbitrary\nlinear operator and $(u_i)_{i=1}^m$ is any fixed orthonormal basis of\n$\\mathbb{R}^m$.\n  We show that under the bare-minimum assumptions on $X$, and with high\nprobability, many of the values $|<TX,u_i>|$ are at least of the order\n$\\|T\\|_{S_2}/\\sqrt{m}$. As a result, the \"coordinate structure\" of $TX$\nexhibits the typical Euclidean norm of $TX$ and does so in a stable way.\n  One outcome of our analysis is that random sub-sampled convolutions satisfy\nstable point separation under minimal assumptions on the generating random\nvector---a fact that was known previously only in a highly restrictive setup,\nnamely, for random vectors with iid subgaussian coordinates.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Recovery procedures in various application in Data Science are based on\n\\emph{stable point separation}. In its simplest form, stable point separation\nimplies that if $f$ is \"far away\" from $0$, and one is given a random sample\n$(f(Z_i))_{i=1}^m$ where a proportional number of the sample points may be\ncorrupted by noise, that information is still enough to exhibit that $f$ is far\nfrom $0$.\n  Stable point separation is well understood in the context of iid sampling,\nand to explore it for general sampling methods we introduce a new notion---the\n\\emph{coordinate small-ball} of a random vector $X$. Roughly put, this feature\ncaptures the number of \"relatively large coordinates\" of\n$(|<TX,u_i>|)_{i=1}^m$, where $T:\\mathbb{R}^n \\to \\mathbb{R}^m$ is an arbitrary\nlinear operator and $(u_i)_{i=1}^m$ is any fixed orthonormal basis of\n$\\mathbb{R}^m$.\n  We show that under the bare-minimum assumptions on $X$, and with high\nprobability, many of the values $|<TX,u_i>|$ are at least of the order\n$\\|T\\|_{S_2}/\\sqrt{m}$. As a result, the \"coordinate structure\" of $TX$\nexhibits the typical Euclidean norm of $TX$ and does so in a stable way.\n  One outcome of our analysis is that random sub-sampled convolutions satisfy\nstable point separation under minimal assumptions on the generating random\nvector---a fact that was known previously only in a highly restrictive setup,\nnamely, for random vectors with iid subgaussian coordinates."}, "authors": [{"name": "Shahar Mendelson"}, {"name": "Grigoris Paouris"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Grigoris Paouris"}, "author": "Grigoris Paouris", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1904.08532v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1904.08532v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.ST", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "stat.TH", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1607.00519v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1607.00519v1", "updated": "2016-07-02T15:06:09Z", "updated_parsed": [2016, 7, 2, 15, 6, 9, 5, 184, 0], "published": "2016-07-02T15:06:09Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 7, 2, 15, 6, 9, 5, 184, 0], "title": "Randomized isoperimetric inequalities", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Randomized isoperimetric inequalities"}, "summary": "We discuss isoperimetric inequalities for convex sets. These include the\nclassical isoperimetric inequality and that of Brunn-Minkowski,\nBlaschke-Santalo, Busemann-Petty and their various extensions. We show that\nmany such inequalities admit stronger randomized forms in the following sense:\nfor natural families of associated random convex sets one has stochastic\ndominance for various functionals such as volume, surface area, mean width and\nothers. We give an overview of when such stochastic dominance\narises and its applications in convex geometry and probability.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We discuss isoperimetric inequalities for convex sets. These include the\nclassical isoperimetric inequality and that of Brunn-Minkowski,\nBlaschke-Santalo, Busemann-Petty and their various extensions. "published": "2015-01-09T06:35:15Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 1, 9, 6, 35, 15, 4, 9, 0], "title": "Bounding marginal densities via affine isoperimetry", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Bounding marginal densities via affine isoperimetry"}, "summary": "Let $\\mu$ be a probability measure on $\\mathbb{R}^n$ with a bounded density\n$f$. We prove that the marginals of $f$ on most subspaces are well-bounded. For\nproduct measures, studied recently by Rudelson and Vershynin, our results show\nthere is a trade-off between the strength of such bounds and the probability\nwith which they hold. Our proof rests on new affinely-invariant extremal\ninequalities for certain averages of $f$ on the Grassmannian and affine\nGrassmannian. These are motivated by Lutwak's dual affine quermassintegrals for\nconvex sets. We show that key invariance properties of the latter, due to\nGrinberg, extend to families of functions. The inequalities we obtain can be\nviewed as functional analogues of results due to Busemann--Straus, Grinberg and\nSchneider. As an application, we show that without any additional assumptions\non $\\mu$, any marginal $\\pi_E(\\mu)$, or a small perturbation thereof, satisfies\na nearly optimal small-ball probability.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Let $\\mu$ be a probability measure on $\\mathbb{R}^n$ with a bounded density\n$f$. We prove that the marginals of $f$ on most subspaces are well-bounded. For\nproduct measures, studied recently by Rudelson and Vershynin, our results show\nthere is a trade-off between the strength of such bounds and the probability\nwith which they hold. Our proof rests on new affinely-invariant extremal\ninequalities for certain averages of $f$ on the Grassmannian and affine\nGrassmannian. These are motivated by Lutwak's dual affine quermassintegrals for\nconvex sets. We show that key invariance properties of the latter, due to\nGrinberg, extend to families of functions. The inequalities we obtain can be\nviewed as functional analogues of results due to Busemann--Straus, Grinberg and\nSchneider. We show that the real part, $R$, of such a zero\nset can be approximated by the $(n-1)$-dimensional skeleton, $T$, of a\npolyhedral subdivision of $\\mathbb{R}^n$. In particular, we give an explicit\nupper bound on the Hausdorff distance: $\\Delta(R,T)\n=O\\left(t^{3.5}/\\delta\\right)$, where $t$ and $\\delta$ are respectively the\nnumber of terms and the minimal spacing of the frequencies of $g$. On the side\nof computational complexity, we show that even the $n=2$ case of the membership\nproblem for $R$ is undecidable in the Blum-Shub-Smale model over $\\mathbb{R}$,\nwhereas membership and distance queries for our polyhedral approximation $T$\ncan be decided in polynomial-time for any fixed $n$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study the complexity of approximating complex zero sets of certain\n$n$-variate exponential sums. We show that the real part, $R$, of such a zero\nset can be approximated by the $(n-1)$-dimensional skeleton, $T$, of a\npolyhedral subdivision of $\\mathbb{R}^n$. In particular, we give an explicit\nupper bound on the Hausdorff distance: $\\Delta(R,T)\n=O\\left(t^{3.5}/\\delta\\right)$, where $t$ and $\\delta$ are respectively the\nnumber of terms and the minimal spacing of the frequencies of $g$. On the side\nof computational complexity, we show that even the $n=2$ case of the membership\nproblem for $R$ is undecidable in the Blum-Shub-Smale model over $\\mathbb{R}$,\nwhereas membership and distance queries for our polyhedral approximation $T$\ncan be decided in polynomial-time for any fixed $n$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Alperen Erg\u00fcr"}, {"name": "Grigoris Paouris"}, {"name": "J. The Program consists of first establishing a Weak\nGeneralized Dual Sudakov Minoration, involving the dimension $n$ of the ambient\nspace, which is then self-improved to a dimension-free estimate after applying\na dimension-reduction step. The latter step may be thought of as a conjectural\n\"small-ball one-sided\" variant of the Johnson--Lindenstrauss\ndimension-reduction lemma. We establish the Weak Generalized Dual Sudakov\nMinoration for a variety of log-concave probability measures and convex bodies\n(for instance, this step is fully resolved assuming a positive answer to the\nSlicing Problem). The Separation Dimension-Reduction step is fully established\nfor ellipsoids and, up to logarithmic factors in the dimension, for cubes,\nresulting in a corresponding Generalized (regular) Dual Sudakov Minoration\nestimate for these bodies and arbitrary log-concave measures, which are shown\nto be (essentially) best-possible. Along the way, we establish a regular\nversion of (\\ref{eq:abstract}) for all $p \\geq n$ and provide a new direct\nproof of Sudakov Minoration via The Program.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We propose a program for establishing a conjectural extension to the class of\n(origin-symmetric) log-concave probability measures $\\mu$, of the classical\ndual Sudakov Minoration on the expectation of the supremum of a Gaussian\nprocess: \\begin{equation} \\label{eq:abstract} M(Z_p(\\mu), C \\int ||x||_K d\\mu\n\\cdot K) \\leq \\exp(C p) \\;\\;\\, \\forall p \\geq 1 . \\end{equation} Here $K$ is an\norigin-symmetric convex body, $Z_p(\\mu)$ is the $L_p$-centroid body associated\nto $\\mu$, $M(A,B)$ is the packing-number of $B$ in $A$, and $C > 0$ is a\nuniversal constant. The Program consists of first establishing a Weak\nGeneralized Dual Sudakov Minoration, involving the dimension $n$ of the ambient\nspace, which is then self-improved to a dimension-free estimate after applying\na dimension-reduction step. The latter step may be thought of as a conjectural\n\"small-ball one-sided\" variant of the Johnson--Lindenstrauss\ndimension-reduction lemma. We establish the Weak Generalized Dual Sudakov\nMinoration for a variety of log-concave probability measures and convex bodies\n(for instance, this step is fully resolved assuming a positive answer to the\nSlicing Problem). The Separation Dimension-Reduction step is fully established\nfor ellipsoids and, up to logarithmic factors in the dimension, for cubes,\nresulting in a corresponding Generalized (regular) Dual Sudakov Minoration\nestimate for these bodies and arbitrary log-concave measures, which are shown\nto be (essentially) best-possible. We obtain concentration estimates for\nsums of Lyapunov exponents, a quantitative rate of convergence of the empirical\nmeasure of the normalized squared singular values to the uniform distribution\non $[0,1]$, and results on the joint normality of Lyapunov exponents when $N$\nis sufficiently large as a function of $n.$ Our technique consists of\nnon-asymptotic versions of the ergodic theory approach at $N=\\infty$ due\noriginally to Furstenberg and Kesten in the 1960's, which were then further\ndeveloped by Newman and Isopi-Newman as well as by a number of other authors in\nthe 1980's. Our key technical idea is that small ball probabilities for volumes\nof random projections give a way to quantify convergence in the multiplicative\nergodic theorem for random matrices.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This article concerns the non-asymptotic analysis of the singular values (and\nLyapunov exponents) of Gaussian matrix products in the regime where $N,$ the\nnumber of term in the product, is large and $n,$ the size of the matrices, may\nbe large or small and may depend on $N$. To do this, we introduce a\nstochastic approximation procedure that sees each convex body K as the limit of\nintersections of Euclidean balls of large radii and centered at randomly chosen\npoints. We show that, for any $m,k\n\\geq 2$ with $(m,k) \\neq (2,2)$, there is an $n \\leq 4$ for which we have the\nseparation $C_q^{(n)}(m,k) \\neq C_{qs}^{(n)}(m,k)$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Samuel J. Harris", "arxiv_comment": "11 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1806.08745v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1806.08745v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "quant-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1812.11474v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1812.11474v2", "updated": "2020-11-03T15:05:09Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 11, 3, 15, 5, 9, 1, 308, 0], "published": "2018-12-30T06:10:33Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 12, 30, 6, 10, 33, 6, 364, 0], "title": "Bigalois extensions and the graph isomorphism game", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Bigalois extensions and the graph isomorphism game"}, "summary": "We study the graph isomorphism game that arises in quantum information theory\nfrom the perspective of bigalois extensions of compact quantum groups. We show\nthat every algebraic quantum isomorphism between a pair of (quantum) graphs $X$\nand $Y$ arises as a quotient of a certain measured bigalois extension for the\nquantum automorphism groups $G_X$ and $G_Y$ of the graphs $X$ and $Y$. In\nparticular, this implies that the quantum groups $G_X$ and $G_Y$ are monoidally\nequivalent. We also establish a converse to this result, which says that every\ncompact quantum group $G$ monoidally equivalent to $G_X$ is of the form $G_Y$\nfor a suitably chosen quantum graph $Y$ that is quantum isomorphic to $X$. As\nan application of these results, we deduce that the $\\ast$-algebraic,\nC$^\\ast$-algebraic, and quantum commuting (qc) notions of a quantum isomorphism\nbetween classical graphs $X$ and $Y$ all coincide. Using the notion of\nequivalence for non-local games, we deduce the same result for other\nsynchronous non-local games, including the synBCS game and certain related\ngraph homomorphism games.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study the graph isomorphism game that arises in quantum information theory\nfrom the perspective of bigalois extensions of compact quantum groups. We show\nthat every algebraic quantum isomorphism between a pair of (quantum) graphs $X$\nand $Y$ arises as a quotient of a certain measured bigalois extension for the\nquantum automorphism groups $G_X$ and $G_Y$ of the graphs $X$ and $Y$. In\nparticular, this implies that the quantum groups $G_X$ and $G_Y$ are monoidally\nequivalent. We also establish a converse to this result, which says that every\ncompact quantum group $G$ monoidally equivalent to $G_X$ is of the form $G_Y$\nfor a suitably chosen quantum graph $Y$ that is quantum isomorphic to $X$. As\nan application of these results, we deduce that the $\\ast$-algebraic,\nC$^\\ast$-algebraic, and quantum commuting (qc) notions of a quantum isomorphism\nbetween classical graphs $X$ and $Y$ all coincide. Using the notion of\nequivalence for non-local games, we deduce the same result for other\nsynchronous non-local games, including the synBCS game and certain related\ngraph homomorphism games."}, "authors": [{"name": "Michael Brannan"}, {"name": "Alexandru Chirvasitu"}, {"name": "Kari Eifler"}, {"name": "Samuel Harris"}, {"name": "Vern Paulsen"}, {"name": "Xiaoyu Su"}, {"name": "Mateusz Wasilewski"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Mateusz Wasilewski"}, "author": "Mateusz Wasilewski", "arxiv_doi": "10.1007/s00220-019-03563-9", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00220-019-03563-9", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1812.11474v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1812.11474v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "33 pages", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Comm. Phys. 375 (2020), no. 3, 1777-1809", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math-ph", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.MP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.QA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1205.3255v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1205.3255v1", "updated": "2012-05-15T04:23:10Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 5, 15, 4, 23, 10, 1, 136, 0], "published": "2012-05-15T04:23:10Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 5, 15, 4, 23, 10, 1, 136, 0], "title": "Localized bases for kernel spaces on the unit sphere", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Localized bases for kernel spaces on the unit sphere"}, "summary": "Approximation/interpolation from spaces of positive definite or conditionally\npositive definite kernels is an increasingly popular tool for the analysis and\nsynthesis of scattered data, and is central to many meshless methods. For a set\nof $N$ scattered sites, the standard basis for such a space utilizes $N$\n\\emph{globally} supported kernels; computing with it is prohibitively expensive\nfor large $N$. Easily computable, well-localized bases, with \"small-footprint\"\nbasis elements - i.e., elements using only a small number of kernels -- have\nbeen unavailable. Working on $\\sphere$, with focus on the restricted surface\nspline kernels (e.g. the thin-plate splines restricted to the sphere), we\nconstruct easily computable, spatially well-localized, small-footprint, robust\nbases for the associated kernel spaces. Our theory predicts that each element\nof the local basis is constructed by using a combination of only\n$\\mathcal{O}((\\log N)^2)$ kernels, which makes the construction computationally\ncheap. We prove that the new basis is $L_p$ stable and satisfies polynomial\ndecay estimates that are stationary with respect to the density of the data\nsites, and we present a quasi-interpolation scheme that provides optimal $L_p$\napproximation orders. Although our focus is on $\\mathbb{S}^2$, much of the\ntheory applies to other manifolds - $\\mathbb{S}^d$, the rotation group, and so\non. Finally, we construct algorithms to implement these schemes and use them to\nconduct numerical experiments, which validate our theory for interpolation\nproblems on $\\mathbb{S}^2$ involving over one hundred fifty thousand data\nsites.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Approximation/interpolation from spaces of positive definite or conditionally\npositive definite kernels is an increasingly popular tool for the analysis and\nsynthesis of scattered data, and is central to many meshless methods. For a set\nof $N$ scattered sites, the standard basis for such a space utilizes $N$\n\\emph{globally} supported kernels; computing with it is prohibitively expensive\nfor large $N$. Easily computable, well-localized bases, with \"small-footprint\"\nbasis elements - i.e., elements using only a small number of kernels -- have\nbeen unavailable. Working on $\\sphere$, with focus on the restricted surface\nspline kernels (e.g. the thin-plate splines restricted to the sphere), we\nconstruct easily computable, spatially well-localized, small-footprint, robust\nbases for the associated kernel spaces. Our theory predicts that each element\nof the local basis is constructed by using a combination of only\n$\\mathcal{O}((\\log N)^2)$ kernels, which makes the construction computationally\ncheap. We prove that the new basis is $L_p$ stable and satisfies polynomial\ndecay estimates that are stationary with respect to the density of the data\nsites, and we present a quasi-interpolation scheme that provides optimal $L_p$\napproximation orders. Although our focus is on $\\mathbb{S}^2$, much of the\ntheory applies to other manifolds - $\\mathbb{S}^d$, the rotation group, and so\non. Finally, we construct algorithms to implement these schemes and use them to\nconduct numerical experiments, which validate our theory for interpolation\nproblems on $\\mathbb{S}^2$ involving over one hundred fifty thousand data\nsites."}, "authors": [{"name": "E. They generate\nLagrange functions that are uniformly bounded and decay away from their center\nat an exponential rate. An immediate corollary is that the corresponding\nLebesgue constant will be uniformly bounded with a constant whose only\ndependence on the set of data sites is reflected in the mesh ratio, which\nmeasures the uniformity of the data.\n  The analysis needed for these results was inspired by some fundamental work\nof Matveev where the Sobolev decay of Lagrange functions associated with\ncertain kernels on \\Omega \\subset R^d was obtained. With a bit more work, one\nestablishes the following: Lebesgue constants associated with surface splines\nand Sobolev splines are uniformly bounded on R^d provided the data sites \\Xi\nare quasi-uniformly distributed. The non-Euclidean case is more involved as the\ngeometry of the underlying surface comes into play. In addition to establishing\nbounded Lebesgue constants in this setting, a \"zeros lemma\" for compact\nRiemannian manifolds is established.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The purpose of this paper is to establish that for any compact, connected\nC^{\\infty} Riemannian manifold there exists a robust family of kernels of\nincreasing smoothness that are well suited for interpolation. They generate\nLagrange functions that are uniformly bounded and decay away from their center\nat an exponential rate. An immediate corollary is that the corresponding\nLebesgue constant will be uniformly bounded with a constant whose only\ndependence on the set of data sites is reflected in the mesh ratio, which\nmeasures the uniformity of the data.\n  The analysis needed for these results was inspired by some fundamental work\nof Matveev where the Sobolev decay of Lagrange functions associated with\ncertain kernels on \\Omega \\subset R^d was obtained. With a bit more work, one\nestablishes the following: Lebesgue constants associated with surface splines\nand Sobolev splines are uniformly bounded on R^d provided the data sites \\Xi\nare quasi-uniformly distributed. The non-Euclidean case is more involved as the\ngeometry of the underlying surface comes into play. For a wide class of\ncompact, connected $C^\\infty$ Riemannian manifolds, including the important\ncases of spheres and SO(3), we establish, using techniques involving\ndifferential geometry and Lie groups, that the kernels obtained as fundamental\nsolutions of certain partial differential operators generate Lagrange functions\nthat are uniformly bounded and decay away from their center at an algebraic\nrate, and in certain cases, an exponential rate. An immediate corollary is that\nthe corresponding Lebesgue constants for interpolation as well as for $L_2$\nminimization are uniformly bounded with a constant whose only dependence on the\nset of data sites is reflected in the mesh ratio, which measures the uniformity\nof the data. The kernels considered here include the restricted surface splines\non spheres, as well as surface splines for SO(3), both of which have elementary\nclosed-form representations that are computationally implementable. In addition\nto obtaining bounded Lebesgue constants in this setting, we also establish a\n\"zeros lemma\" for domains on compact Riemannian manifolds -- one that holds in\nas much generality as the corresponding Euclidean zeros lemma (on Lipschitz\ndomains satisfying interior cone conditions) with constants that clearly\ndemonstrate the influence of the geometry of the boundary (via cone parameters)\nas well as that of the Riemannian metric.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "This article is devoted to developing a theory for effective kernel\ninterpolation and approximation in a general setting. For a wide class of\ncompact, connected $C^\\infty$ Riemannian manifolds, including the important\ncases of spheres and SO(3), we establish, using techniques involving\ndifferential geometry and Lie groups, that the kernels obtained as fundamental\nsolutions of certain partial differential operators generate Lagrange functions\nthat are uniformly bounded and decay away from their center at an algebraic\nrate, and in certain cases, an exponential rate. An immediate corollary is that\nthe corresponding Lebesgue constants for interpolation as well as for $L_2$\nminimization are uniformly bounded with a constant whose only dependence on the\nset of data sites is reflected in the mesh ratio, which measures the uniformity\nof the data. The kernels considered here include the restricted surface splines\non spheres, as well as surface splines for SO(3), both of which have elementary\nclosed-form representations that are computationally implementable. In addition\nto obtaining bounded Lebesgue constants in this setting, we also establish a\n\"zeros lemma\" for domains on compact Riemannian manifolds -- one that holds in\nas much generality as the corresponding Euclidean zeros lemma (on Lipschitz\ndomains satisfying interior cone conditions) with constants that clearly\ndemonstrate the influence of the geometry of the boundary (via cone parameters)\nas well as that of the Riemannian metric."}, "authors": [{"name": "T. October 2012, Volume 12,\n  Issue 5, pp 625-670", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "41A05, 41A63, 46E22, 46E35", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1211.5171v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1211.5171v1", "updated": "2012-11-21T23:41:30Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 11, 21, 23, 41, 30, 2, 326, 0], "published": "2012-11-21T23:41:30Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 11, 21, 23, 41, 30, 2, 326, 0], "title": "Kernel Based Quadrature on Spheres and Other Homogeneous Spaces", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Kernel Based Quadrature on Spheres and Other Homogeneous Spaces"}, "summary": "Quadrature formulas for spheres, the rotation group, and other compact,\nhomogeneous manifolds are important in a number of applications and have been\nthe subject of recent research. The main purpose of this paper is to study\ncoordinate independent quadrature (or cubature) formulas associated with\ncertain classes of positive definite and conditionally positive definite\nkernels that are invariant under the group action of the homogeneous manifold.\nIn particular, we show that these formulas are accurate -- optimally so in many\ncases -- and stable under an increasing number of nodes and in the presence of\nnoise, provided the set X of quadrature nodes is quasi-uniform. The stability\nresults are new in all cases. In addition, we may use these quadrature formulas\nto obtain similar formulas for manifolds diffeomorphic to $\\mathbb{S}^n$,\noblate spheroids for instance. The weights are obtained by solving a single\nlinear system. For $\\mathbb{S}^2$, and the restricted thin plate spline kernel\n$r^2 \\log r$, these weights can be computed for two-thirds of a million nodes,\nusing a preconditioned iterative technique introduced by us.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Quadrature formulas for spheres, the rotation group, and other compact,\nhomogeneous manifolds are important in a number of applications and have been\nthe subject of recent research. The main purpose of this paper is to study\ncoordinate independent quadrature (or cubature) formulas associated with\ncertain classes of positive definite and conditionally positive definite\nkernels that are invariant under the group action of the homogeneous manifold.\nIn particular, we show that these formulas are accurate -- optimally so in many\ncases -- and stable under an increasing number of nodes and in the presence of\nnoise, provided the set X of quadrature nodes is quasi-uniform. The stability\nresults are new in all cases. In addition, we may use these quadrature formulas\nto obtain similar formulas for manifolds diffeomorphic to $\\mathbb{S}^n$,\noblate spheroids for instance. The weights are obtained by solving a single\nlinear system. For $\\mathbb{S}^2$, and the restricted thin plate spline kernel\n$r^2 \\log r$, these weights can be computed for two-thirds of a million nodes,\nusing a preconditioned iterative technique introduced by us."}, "authors": [{"name": "E. The main result establishes $L_p$ Sobolev error estimates\nand shows that the error is controlled by the $L_p$ multiplier norm of a\nFourier multiplier closely related to the cardinal interpolant, and comparable\nto the Hilbert transform. Consequently, its multiplier norm is bounded\nindependent of the grid spacing when $1<p<\\infty$, and involves a logarithmic\nterm when $p=1$ or $\\infty$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, interpolation by scaled multi-integer translates of Gaussian\nkernels is studied. The main result establishes $L_p$ Sobolev error estimates\nand shows that the error is controlled by the $L_p$ multiplier norm of a\nFourier multiplier closely related to the cardinal interpolant, and comparable\nto the Hilbert transform. Ward", "arxiv_doi": "10.1007/s00041-011-9185-2", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00041-011-9185-2", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1008.3168v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1008.3168v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "18 pages", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Journal of Fourier Analysis and Applications: Volume 18, Issue 1\n  (2012), Page 67-86", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.CA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "41A15, 41A25, 41A63, 42B15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0308250v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0308250v1", "updated": "2003-08-26T20:13:36Z", "updated_parsed": [2003, 8, 26, 20, 13, 36, 1, 238, 0], "published": "2003-08-26T20:13:36Z", "published_parsed": [2003, 8, 26, 20, 13, 36, 1, 238, 0], "title": "Geometric Aspects of Frame Representations of Abelian Groups", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Geometric Aspects of Frame Representations of Abelian Groups"}, "summary": "We consider frames arising from the action of a unitary representation of a\ndiscrete countable abelian group. We show that the range of the analysis\noperator can be determined by computing which characters appear in the\nrepresentation. This allows one to compare the ranges of two such frames, which\nis useful for determining similarity and also for multiplexing schemes. Our\nresults then partially extend to Bessel sequences arising from the action of\nthe group. We apply the results to sampling on bandlimited functions and to\nwavelet and Weyl-Heisenberg frames. This yields a sufficient condition for two\nsampling transforms to have orthogonal ranges, and two analysis operators for\nwavelet and Weyl-Heisenberg frames to have orthogonal ranges. The sufficient\ncondition is easy to compute in terms of the periodization of the Fourier\ntransform of the frame generators.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider frames arising from the action of a unitary representation of a\ndiscrete countable abelian group. We show that the range of the analysis\noperator can be determined by computing which characters appear in the\nrepresentation. This allows one to compare the ranges of two such frames, which\nis useful for determining similarity and also for multiplexing schemes. Our\nresults then partially extend to Bessel sequences arising from the action of\nthe group. We apply the results to sampling on bandlimited functions and to\nwavelet and Weyl-Heisenberg frames. This yields a sufficient condition for two\nsampling transforms to have orthogonal ranges, and two analysis operators for\nwavelet and Weyl-Heisenberg frames to have orthogonal ranges. The sufficient\ncondition is easy to compute in terms of the periodization of the Fourier\ntransform of the frame generators."}, "authors": [{"name": "Akram Aldroubi"}, {"name": "David Larson"}, {"name": "Wai-Shing Tang"}, {"name": "Eric Weber"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Eric Weber"}, "arxiv_affiliation": "Iowa State", "author": "Eric Weber", "arxiv_comment": "20 pages; contact author: Eric Weber", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0308250v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0308250v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "43A70, 94A20, 42C40", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.6151v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.6151v1", "updated": "2013-07-23T16:50:13Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 7, 23, 16, 50, 13, 1, 204, 0], "published": "2013-07-23T16:50:13Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 7, 23, 16, 50, 13, 1, 204, 0], "title": "Framings and dilations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Framings and dilations"}, "summary": "The notion of framings, recently emerging in P. In that memoir we\ndeveloped a general dilation theory for operator valued measures acting on\nBanach spaces where operator-valued measures (or maps) are not necessarily\ncompletely bounded. The main results state that any operator-valued measure,\nnot necessarily completely bounded, always has a dilation to a\nprojection-valued measure acting on a Banach space, and every bounded linear\nmap, again not necessarily completely bounded, on a Banach algebra has a\nbounded homomorphism dilation acting on a Banach space. Here the dilation space\noften needs to be a Banach space even if the underlying space is a Hilbert\nspace, and the projections are idempotents that are not necessarily\nself-adjoint. These results lead to some new connections between frame theory\nand operator algebras, and some of them can be considered as part of the\ninvestigation about \"noncommutative\" frame theory.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We will give an outline of the main results in our recent AMS Memoir, and\ninclude some new results, exposition and open problems. In that memoir we\ndeveloped a general dilation theory for operator valued measures acting on\nBanach spaces where operator-valued measures (or maps) are not necessarily\ncompletely bounded. The main results state that any operator-valued measure,\nnot necessarily completely bounded, always has a dilation to a\nprojection-valued measure acting on a Banach space, and every bounded linear\nmap, again not necessarily completely bounded, on a Banach algebra has a\nbounded homomorphism dilation acting on a Banach space. Here the dilation space\noften needs to be a Banach space even if the underlying space is a Hilbert\nspace, and the projections are idempotents that are not necessarily\nself-adjoint. These results lead to some new connections between frame theory\nand operator algebras, and some of them can be considered as part of the\ninvestigation about \"noncommutative\" frame theory."}, "authors": [{"name": "Deguang Han"}, {"name": "David R. We show that every\noperator-valued system of imprimitivity has a dilation to a probability\nspectral system of imprimitivity acting on a Banach space. This completely\ngeneralizes a well-kown result which states that every frame representation of\na countable group on a Hilbert space is unitarily equivalent to a\nsubrepresentation of the left regular representation of the group. The dilated\nspace in general can not be taken as a Hilbert space. However, it can be taken\nas a Hilbert space for positive operator valued systems of imprimitivity. We\nalso prove that isometric group representation induced framings on a Banach\nspace can be dilated to unconditional bases with the same structure for a\nlarger Banach space This extends several known results on the dilations of\nframes induced by unitary group representations on Hilbert spaces.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Motivated by a general dilation theory for operator-valued measures, framings\nand bounded linear maps on operator algebras, we consider the dilation theory\nof the above objects with special structures. We show that every\noperator-valued system of imprimitivity has a dilation to a probability\nspectral system of imprimitivity acting on a Banach space. This completely\ngeneralizes a well-kown result which states that every frame representation of\na countable group on a Hilbert space is unitarily equivalent to a\nsubrepresentation of the left regular representation of the group. We\nalso prove that isometric group representation induced framings on a Banach\nspace can be dilated to unconditional bases with the same structure for a\nlarger Banach space This extends several known results on the dilations of\nframes induced by unitary group representations on Hilbert spaces."}, "authors": [{"name": "Deguang Han"}, {"name": "David R. In the case where H is real and has\nfinite dimension, we give an algorithmic proof. Our main tool in the\ninfinite-dimensional case is a result we have proven which concerns the\ndecomposition of a positive invertible operator into a strongly converging sum\nof (not necessarily mutually orthogonal) self-adjoint projections. This\ndecomposition result implies the existence of tight frames in the ellipsoidal\nsurface determined by the positive operator. In the real or complex finite\ndimensional case, this provides an alternate (but not algorithmic) proof that\nevery such surface contains tight frames with every prescribed length at least\nas large as dim H. A corollary in both finite and infinite dimensions is that\nevery positive invertible operator is the frame operator for a spherical frame.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We prove the existence of tight frames whose elements lie on an arbitrary\nellipsoidal surface within a real or complex separable Hilbert space H, and we\nanalyze the set of attainable frame bounds. In the case where H is real and has\nfinite dimension, we give an algorithmic proof. Our main tool in the\ninfinite-dimensional case is a result we have proven which concerns the\ndecomposition of a positive invertible operator into a strongly converging sum\nof (not necessarily mutually orthogonal) self-adjoint projections. This\ndecomposition result implies the existence of tight frames in the ellipsoidal\nsurface determined by the positive operator. In the real or complex finite\ndimensional case, this provides an alternate (but not algorithmic) proof that\nevery such surface contains tight frames with every prescribed length at least\nas large as dim H. A corollary in both finite and infinite dimensions is that\nevery positive invertible operator is the frame operator for a spherical frame."}, "authors": [{"name": "Ken Dykema"}, {"name": "Dan Freeman"}, {"name": "Keri Kornelson"}, {"name": "David Larson"}, {"name": "Marc Ordower"}, {"name": "Eric Weber"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Eric Weber"}, "author": "Eric Weber", "arxiv_comment": "13 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0304387v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0304387v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "42C15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0910.0870v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0910.0870v2", "updated": "2010-11-05T17:16:57Z", "updated_parsed": [2010, 11, 5, 17, 16, 57, 4, 309, 0], "published": "2009-10-05T21:28:03Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 10, 5, 21, 28, 3, 0, 278, 0], "title": "Irreducible wavelet representations and ergodic automorphisms on\n  solenoids", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Irreducible wavelet representations and ergodic automorphisms on\n  solenoids"}, "summary": "We focus on the irreducibility of wavelet representations.
