We prove that this\nduality principle extends to any dual pairs of projective unitary\nrepresentations of countable groups. We examine the existence problem of dual\npairs and establish some connection with classification problems for $\\rm\nII_{1}$ factors. While in general such a pair may not exist for some groups, we\nshow that such a dual pair always exists for every subrepresentation of the\nleft regular unitary representation when $G$ is an abelian infinite countable\ngroup or an amenable ICC group. For free groups with finitely many generators,\nthe existence problem of such a dual pair is equivalent to the well known\nproblem about the classification of free group von Neumann algebras.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The duality principle for Gabor frames states that a Gabor sequence obtained\nby a time-frequency lattice is a frame for $L^{2}(\\R^{d})$ if and only if the\nassociated adjoint Gabor sequence is a Riesz sequence. We prove that this\nduality principle extends to any dual pairs of projective unitary\nrepresentations of countable groups. We examine the existence problem of dual\npairs and establish some connection with classification problems for $\\rm\nII_{1}$ factors. While in general such a pair may not exist for some groups, we\nshow that such a dual pair always exists for every subrepresentation of the\nleft regular unitary representation when $G$ is an abelian infinite countable\ngroup or an amenable ICC group. For free groups with finitely many generators,\nthe existence problem of such a dual pair is equivalent to the well known\nproblem about the classification of free group von Neumann algebras."}, "authors": [{"name": "Dorin Ervin Dutkay"}, {"name": "Deguang Han"}, {"name": "David Larson"}], "author_detail": {"name": "David Larson"}, "author": "David Larson", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0902.2767v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0902.2767v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1812.03019v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1812.03019v1", "updated": "2018-12-07T13:19:18Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 12, 7, 13, 19, 18, 4, 341, 0], "published": "2018-12-07T13:19:18Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 12, 7, 13, 19, 18, 4, 341, 0], "title": "A duality principle for groups II: Multi-frames meet super-frames", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A duality principle for groups II: Multi-frames meet super-frames"}, "summary": "The duality principle for group representations developed in \\cite{DHL-JFA,\nHL_BLM} exhibits a fact that the well-known duality principle in Gabor analysis\nis not an isolated incident but a more general phenomenon residing in the\ncontext of group representation theory. There are two other well-known\nfundamental properties in Gabor analysis: The Wexler-Raz biorthogonality and\nthe Fundamental Identity of Gabor analysis. In this paper we will show that\nthese fundamental properties remain to be true for general projective unitary\ngroup representations. The main purpose of this paper is present a more general\nduality theorem which shows that that muti-frame generators meet super-frame\ngenerators through a dual commutant pairs. In particular, for the Gabor\nrepresentations $\\pi_{\\Lambda}$ and $\\pi_{\\Lambda^{o}}$ with respect to a pair\nof dual time-frequency lattices $\\Lambda$ and $\\Lambda^{o}$ in $\\R^{d}\\times\n\\R^{d}$ we have that $\\{\\pi_{\\Lambda}(m, n)g_{1} \\oplus ... \\oplus\n\\pi_{\\Lambda}(m, n)g_{k}\\}_{m, n \\in \\Z^{d}}$ is a frame for\n$L^{2}(\\R^{d})\\oplus ... \\oplus L^{2}(\\R^{d})$ if and only if\n$\\cup_{i=1}^{k}\\{\\pi_{\\Lambda^{o}}(m, n)g_{i}\\}_{m, n\\in\\Z^{d}}$ is a Riesz\nsequence, and $\\cup_{i=1}^{k}\\{\\pi_{\\Lambda}(m, n)g_{i}\\}_{m, n\\in\\Z^{d}}$ is a\nframe for $L^{2}(\\R^{d})$ if and only if $\\{\\pi_{\\Lambda^{o}}(m, n)g_{1} \\oplus\n... \\oplus \\pi_{\\Lambda^{o}}(m, n)g_{k}\\}_{m, n \\in \\Z^{d}}$ is a Riesz\nsequence. This appears to be new even in the context of Gabor analysis.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The duality principle for group representations developed in \\cite{DHL-JFA,\nHL_BLM} exhibits a fact that the well-known duality principle in Gabor analysis\nis not an isolated incident but a more general phenomenon residing in the\ncontext of group representation theory. There are two other well-known\nfundamental properties in Gabor analysis: The Wexler-Raz biorthogonality and\nthe Fundamental Identity of Gabor analysis. In this paper we will show that\nthese fundamental properties remain to be true for general projective unitary\ngroup representations. The main purpose of this paper is present a more general\nduality theorem which shows that that muti-frame generators meet super-frame\ngenerators through a dual commutant pairs. In particular, for the Gabor\nrepresentations $\\pi_{\\Lambda}$ and $\\pi_{\\Lambda^{o}}$ with respect to a pair\nof dual time-frequency lattices $\\Lambda$ and $\\Lambda^{o}$ in $\\R^{d}\\times\n\\R^{d}$ we have that $\\{\\pi_{\\Lambda}(m, n)g_{1} \\oplus ... \\oplus\n\\pi_{\\Lambda}(m, n)g_{k}\\}_{m, n \\in \\Z^{d}}$ is a frame for\n$L^{2}(\\R^{d})\\oplus ... \\oplus L^{2}(\\R^{d})$ if and only if\n$\\cup_{i=1}^{k}\\{\\pi_{\\Lambda^{o}}(m, n)g_{i}\\}_{m, n\\in\\Z^{d}}$ is a Riesz\nsequence, and $\\cup_{i=1}^{k}\\{\\pi_{\\Lambda}(m, n)g_{i}\\}_{m, n\\in\\Z^{d}}$ is a\nframe for $L^{2}(\\R^{d})$ if and only if $\\{\\pi_{\\Lambda^{o}}(m, n)g_{1} \\oplus\n... \\oplus \\pi_{\\Lambda^{o}}(m, n)g_{k}\\}_{m, n \\in \\Z^{d}}$ is a Riesz\nsequence. This appears to be new even in the context of Gabor analysis."}, "authors": [{"name": "Radu Balan"}, {"name": "Dorin Ervin Dutkay"}, {"name": "Deguang Han"}, {"name": "David Larson"}, {"name": "Franz Luef"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Franz Luef"}, "author": "Franz Luef", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1812.03019v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1812.03019v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "42C15, 46C05, 47B10", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0707.3272v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0707.3272v1", "updated": "2007-07-22T15:47:38Z", "updated_parsed": [2007, 7, 22, 15, 47, 38, 6, 203, 0], "published": "2007-07-22T15:47:38Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 7, 22, 15, 47, 38, 6, 203, 0], "title": "Operator valued frames", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Operator valued frames"}, "summary": "We develop a natural generalization of vector-valued frame theory, we term\noperator-valued frame theory, using operator-algebraic methods. This extends\nwork of the second author and D. Han which can be viewed as the multiplicity\none case and extends to higher multiplicity (e.g., multiframes) their dilation\napproach. We prove several results for operator-valued frames concerning their\nparametrization, duality, disjointeness, complementarity, and composition and\nthe relationship between the two types of similarity (left and right) of such\nframes. We then apply these notions to prove that the collection of multiframe\ngenerators for the action of a discrete group on a Hilbert space is norm\npathwise-connected precisely when the von Neumann algebra generated by the\nright representation of the group has no minimal projections. The proof is\nobtained by parametrizing this collection by a class of partial isometries in a\nlarger von Neumann algebra. In the multiplicity one case this class reduces to\nthe unitary class which is path-connected in norm, but in the infinite\nmultiplicity case this class is path connected only in the strong operator\ntopology and the proof depends on properties of tensor product slice maps.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We develop a natural generalization of vector-valued frame theory, we term\noperator-valued frame theory, using operator-algebraic methods. This extends\nwork of the second author and D. Han which can be viewed as the multiplicity\none case and extends to higher multiplicity (e.g., multiframes) their dilation\napproach. We prove several results for operator-valued frames concerning their\nparametrization, duality, disjointeness, complementarity, and composition and\nthe relationship between the two types of similarity (left and right) of such\nframes. We then apply these notions to prove that the collection of multiframe\ngenerators for the action of a discrete group on a Hilbert space is norm\npathwise-connected precisely when the von Neumann algebra generated by the\nright representation of the group has no minimal projections. The proof is\nobtained by parametrizing this collection by a class of partial isometries in a\nlarger von Neumann algebra. In the multiplicity one case this class reduces to\nthe unitary class which is path-connected in norm, but in the infinite\nmultiplicity case this class is path connected only in the strong operator\ntopology and the proof depends on properties of tensor product slice maps."}, "authors": [{"name": "Victor Kaftal"}, {"name": "David Larson"}, {"name": "Shuang Zhang"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Shuang Zhang"}, "arxiv_affiliation": "University of Cincinnati", "author": "Shuang Zhang", "arxiv_comment": "37 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0707.3272v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0707.3272v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.OA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "42C15, 47A13 (Primary); 42C40, 46C05, 46L05 (Secondary)", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0707.3303v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0707.3303v2", "updated": "2007-09-26T12:14:34Z", "updated_parsed": [2007, 9, 26, 12, 14, 34, 2, 269, 0], "published": "2007-07-23T02:23:55Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 7, 23, 2, 23, 55, 0, 204, 0], "title": "Operator valued frames on C*-modules", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Operator valued frames on C*-modules"}, "summary": "Frames on Hilbert C*-modules have been defined for unital C*-algebras by\nFrank and Larson and operator valued frames on a Hilbert space have been\nstudied in arXiv.0707.3272v1.[math.FA]. Goal of the present paper is to\nintroduce operator valued frames on a Hilbert C*-module for a sigma-unital\nC*-algebra. Theorem 1.4 reformulates the definition given by Frank and Larson\nin terms of a series of rank-one operators converging in the strict topology.\nTheorem 2.2. shows that the frame transform and the frame projection of an\noperator valued frame are limits in the strict topology of a series of elements\nin the multiplier algebra and hence belong to it. Theorem 3.3 shows that two\noperator valued frames are right similar if and only if they share the same\nframe projection. Theorem 3.4 establishes a one to one correspondence between\nMurray-von Neumann equivalence classes of projections in the multiplier algebra\nand right similarity equivalence classes of operator valued frames and provides\na parametrization of all Parseval operator-valued frames on a given Hilbert\nC*-module. In that memoir we\ndeveloped a general dilation theory for operator valued measures acting on\nBanach spaces where operator-valued measures (or maps) are not necessarily\ncompletely bounded. The main results state that any operator-valued measure,\nnot necessarily completely bounded, always has a dilation to a\nprojection-valued measure acting on a Banach space, and every bounded linear\nmap, again not necessarily completely bounded, on a Banach algebra has a\nbounded homomorphism dilation acting on a Banach space. Here the dilation space\noften needs to be a Banach space even if the underlying space is a Hilbert\nspace, and the projections are idempotents that are not necessarily\nself-adjoint. In that memoir we\ndeveloped a general dilation theory for operator valued measures acting on\nBanach spaces where operator-valued measures (or maps) are not necessarily\ncompletely bounded. The main results state that any operator-valued measure,\nnot necessarily completely bounded, always has a dilation to a\nprojection-valued measure acting on a Banach space, and every bounded linear\nmap, again not necessarily completely bounded, on a Banach algebra has a\nbounded homomorphism dilation acting on a Banach space. Here the dilation space\noften needs to be a Banach space even if the underlying space is a Hilbert\nspace, and the projections are idempotents that are not necessarily\nself-adjoint. By bridging an erasure set we mean replacing\nthe erased Fourier coefficients of a function with respect to a frame by\nappropriate linear combinations of the non-erased coefficients. We prove that\nif a minimal redundancy condition is satisfied bridging can always be done to\nmake the reduced error operator nilpotent of index 2 using a bridge set of\nindices no larger than the cardinality of the erasure set. This results in\nperfect reconstruction of the erased coefficients in one final matricial step.\nWe also obtain a new formula for the inverse of an invertible partial\nreconstruction operator. This leads to a second method of perfect\nreconstruction from frame and sampling erasures in finitely many steps. This\ngives an alternative to the bridging method for many (but not all) cases. The\nmethods we use employ matrix techniques only of the order of the cardinality of\nthe erasure set, and are applicable to rather large finite erasure sets for\ninfinite frames and sampling schemes as well as for finite frame theory. Some\nnew classification theorems for frames are obtained and some new methods of\nmeasuring redundancy are introduced based on our bridging theory.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We give some new methods for perfect reconstruction from frame and sampling\nerasures in finitely many steps. By bridging an erasure set we mean replacing\nthe erased Fourier coefficients of a function with respect to a frame by\nappropriate linear combinations of the non-erased coefficients. We prove that\nif a minimal redundancy condition is satisfied bridging can always be done to\nmake the reduced error operator nilpotent of index 2 using a bridge set of\nindices no larger than the cardinality of the erasure set. This results in\nperfect reconstruction of the erased coefficients in one final matricial step.\nWe also obtain a new formula for the inverse of an invertible partial\nreconstruction operator. The\nmethods we use employ matrix techniques only of the order of the cardinality of\nthe erasure set, and are applicable to rather large finite erasure sets for\ninfinite frames and sampling schemes as well as for finite frame theory. From this discussion we\nfind that objects in braided fusion categories with integral squared dimension\nhave distinctive properties. A large and interesting class of non-integral\nmodular categories such that every simple object has integral\nsquared-dimensions are the metaplectic categories that have the same fusion\nrules as $SO(N)_2$ for some $N$. We describe and complete their classification\nand enumeration, by recognizing them as $\\mathbb{Z}_2$-gaugings of cyclic\nmodular categories (i.e. metric groups). We prove that any modular category of\ndimension $2^km$ with $m$ square-free and $k\\leq 4$, satisfying some additional\nassumptions, is a metaplectic category. This illustrates anew that dimension\ncan, in some circumstances, determine a surprising amount of the category's\nstructure.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We discuss several useful interpretations of the categorical dimension of\nobjects in a braided fusion category, as well as some conjectures demonstrating\nthe value of quantum dimension as a quantum statistic for detecting certain\nbehaviors of anyons in topological phases of matter. From this discussion we\nfind that objects in braided fusion categories with integral squared dimension\nhave distinctive properties. A large and interesting class of non-integral\nmodular categories such that every simple object has integral\nsquared-dimensions are the metaplectic categories that have the same fusion\nrules as $SO(N)_2$ for some $N$. We describe and complete their classification\nand enumeration, by recognizing them as $\\mathbb{Z}_2$-gaugings of cyclic\nmodular categories (i.e. metric groups). We prove that any modular category of\ndimension $2^km$ with $m$ square-free and $k\\leq 4$, satisfying some additional\nassumptions, is a metaplectic category. This illustrates anew that dimension\ncan, in some circumstances, determine a surprising amount of the category's\nstructure."}, "authors": [{"name": "Paul Bruillard"}, {"name": "Paul Gustafson"}, {"name": "Julia Yael Plavnik"}, {"name": "Eric Carson Rowell"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Eric Carson Rowell"}, "author": "Eric Carson Rowell", "arxiv_comment": "v2: Title and sections restructured to clarify the relationship\n  between the paper's two major topics. A na\\\"ive computer search approach to\nthe classification of rank $n$ integral modular categories using this bound\nquickly overwhelms the computer's memory (for $n\\geq 7$). We use a modified\nstrategy: find general conditions on modular categories that imply integrality\nand study the classification problem in these limited settings. The first such\ncondition is that the order of the twist matrix is 2,3,4 or 6 and we obtain a\nfairly complete description of these classes of modular categories. The second\ncondition is that the unit object is the only simple non-self-dual object,\nwhich is equivalent to odd-dimensionality. In this case we obtain a (linear)\nimprovement on the bounds and employ number-theoretic techniques to obtain a\nclassification for rank at most 11 for odd-dimensional modular categories.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "It is a well-known result of Etingof, Nikshych and Ostrik that there are\nfinitely many inequivalent integral modular categories of any fixed rank $n$.\nThis follows from a double-exponential bound on the maximal denominator in an\nEgyptian fraction representation of 1. A na\\\"ive computer search approach to\nthe classification of rank $n$ integral modular categories using this bound\nquickly overwhelms the computer's memory (for $n\\geq 7$). We use a modified\nstrategy: find general conditions on modular categories that imply integrality\nand study the classification problem in these limited settings. The first such\ncondition is that the order of the twist matrix is 2,3,4 or 6 and we obtain a\nfairly complete description of these classes of modular categories. The second\ncondition is that the unit object is the only simple non-self-dual object,\nwhich is equivalent to odd-dimensionality. In this case we obtain a (linear)\nimprovement on the bounds and employ number-theoretic techniques to obtain a\nclassification for rank at most 11 for odd-dimensional modular categories."}, "authors": [{"name": "Paul Bruillard"}, {"name": "Eric C. This completes the classification of weakly integral modular\ncategories through rank $7$. Our results imply that all integral modular\ncategories of rank at most $7$ are pointed (that is, every simple object has\ndimension $1$). All strictly weakly integral (weakly integral but non-integral)\nmodular categories of ranks $6$ and $7$ have dimension $4m$, with $m$ an odd\nsquare free integer, so their classification is an application of our main\nresult. The classification of rank $7$ integral modular categories is\nfacilitated by an analysis of two actions on modular categories: the Galois\ngroup of the field generated by the entries of the $S$-matrix and the group of\nisomorphism classes of invertible simple objects. The interplay of these two\nactions is of independent interest, and we derive some valuable arithmetic\nconsequences from their actions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We classify all modular categories of dimension $4m$, where $m$ is an odd\nsquare-free integer, and all ranks $6$ and $7$ weakly integral modular\ncategories. This completes the classification of weakly integral modular\ncategories through rank $7$. Our results imply that all integral modular\ncategories of rank at most $7$ are pointed (that is, every simple object has\ndimension $1$). Physically, super-modular categories\ndescribe universal properties of quasiparticles in fermionic topological phases\nof matter. In general one does not have a representation of the modular group\n$\\mathrm{SL}(2,\\mathbb{Z})$ associated to a super-modular category, but it is\npossible to obtain a representation of the (index 3) $\\theta$-subgroup:\n$\\Gamma_\\theta<\\mathrm{SL}(2,\\mathbb{Z})$. We study the image of this\nrepresentation and conjecture a super-modular analogue of the Ng-Schauenburg\nCongruence Subgroup Theorem for modular categories, namely that the kernel of\nthe $\\Gamma_\\theta$ representation is a congruence subgroup. We prove this\nconjecture for any super-modular category that is a subcategory of modular\ncategory of twice its dimension, i.e. admitting a minimal modular extension.\nConjecturally, every super-modular category admits (precisely 16) minimal\nmodular extensions and, therefore, our conjecture would be a consequence.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A super-modular category is a unitary pre-modular category with M\\\"uger\ncenter equivalent to the symmetric unitary category of super-vector spaces.\nSuper-modular categories are important alternatives to modular categories as\nany unitary pre-modular category is the equivariantization of a either a\nmodular or super-modular category. Physically, super-modular categories\ndescribe universal properties of quasiparticles in fermionic topological phases\nof matter. In general one does not have a representation of the modular group\n$\\mathrm{SL}(2,\\mathbb{Z})$ associated to a super-modular category, but it is\npossible to obtain a representation of the (index 3) $\\theta$-subgroup:\n$\\Gamma_\\theta<\\mathrm{SL}(2,\\mathbb{Z})$. We study the image of this\nrepresentation and conjecture a super-modular analogue of the Ng-Schauenburg\nCongruence Subgroup Theorem for modular categories, namely that the kernel of\nthe $\\Gamma_\\theta$ representation is a congruence subgroup. We prove this\nconjecture for any super-modular category that is a subcategory of modular\ncategory of twice its dimension, i.e. admitting a minimal modular extension.\nConjecturally, every super-modular category admits (precisely 16) minimal\nmodular extensions and, therefore, our conjecture would be a consequence."}, "authors": [{"name": "Parsa Bonderson"}, {"name": "Eric C. We\nfirst construct new representations of extraspecial 2-groups. Extending the\nlatter by the symmetric group, we construct new unitary braid representations,\nwhich are solutions to generalized Yang-Baxter equations and use them to\nrealize new braiding quantum gates. These gates generate the GHZ\n(Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger) states, for an arbitrary (particularly an\n\\emph{odd}) number of qubits, from the product basis. We also discuss the\nYang-Baxterization of the new braid group representations, which describes\nunitary evolution of the GHZ states. Our study suggests that through their\nconnection with braiding gates, extraspecial 2-groups and the GHZ states may\nplay an important role in quantum error correction and topological quantum\ncomputing.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper we describe connections among extraspecial 2-groups, unitary\nrepresentations of the braid group and multi-qubit braiding quantum gates. We\nfirst construct new representations of extraspecial 2-groups. Extending the\nlatter by the symmetric group, we construct new unitary braid representations,\nwhich are solutions to generalized Yang-Baxter equations and use them to\nrealize new braiding quantum gates. These gates generate the GHZ\n(Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger) states, for an arbitrary (particularly an\n\\emph{odd}) number of qubits, from the product basis. We also discuss the\nYang-Baxterization of the new braid group representations, which describes\nunitary evolution of the GHZ states. Our study suggests that through their\nconnection with braiding gates, extraspecial 2-groups and the GHZ states may\nplay an important role in quantum error correction and topological quantum\ncomputing."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric C. Our point of view is to regard the three strand braid group\n$\\mathcal{B}_3$ as a subgroup of $\\mathcal{LB}_3$ and study the problem of\nextending $\\mathcal{B}_3$ representations. We introduce the notion of a\n\\emph{standard extension} and characterize $\\mathcal{B}_3$ representations\nadmiting such an extension. In particular we show, using a classification\nresult of Tuba and Wenzl, that every irreducible $\\mathcal{B}_3$ representation\nof dimension at most $5$ has a (standard) extension. We show that this result\nis sharp by exhibiting an irreducible $6$-dimensional $\\mathcal{B}_3$\nrepresentation that has no extensions (standard or otherwise). Unitary $R$-matrices, namely unitary solutions\nto the Yang-Baxter equation, afford explicitly local unitary representations of\nbraid groups. Inspired by topological quantum computation, we study whether or\nnot it is possible to reassemble the irreducible summands appearing in the\nunitary braid group representations from a unitary braided fusion category with\npossibly different positive multiplicities to get representations that are\nuniformly equivalent to the ones from a unitary R-matrix. Such an equivalence\nwill be called a localization of the unitary braid group representations. We\nshow that the q=exp(\\pi i/6) specialization of the unitary Jones representation\nof the braid groups can be localized by a unitary $9\\times 9$ R-matrix.\nActually this Jones representation is the first one in a family of theories\n(SO(N),2) for an odd prime N>1, which are conjectured to be localizable. We\nformulate several general conjectures and discuss possible connections to\nphysics and computer science.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Governed by locality, we explore a connection between unitary braid group\nrepresentations associated to a unitary $R$-matrix and to a simple object in a\nunitary braided fusion category. Unitary $R$-matrices, namely unitary solutions\nto the Yang-Baxter equation, afford explicitly local unitary representations of\nbraid groups. Inspired by topological quantum computation, we study whether or\nnot it is possible to reassemble the irreducible summands appearing in the\nunitary braid group representations from a unitary braided fusion category with\npossibly different positive multiplicities to get representations that are\nuniformly equivalent to the ones from a unitary R-matrix. The essential problem is to\ndetermine when a family of braid representations can be uniformly modelled upon\na tensor power of a fixed vector space in such a way that the braid group\ngenerators act \"locally\". Although related to the notion of (quasi-)fiber\nfunctors for fusion categories, remarkably, such localizations can exist for\nrepresentations associated with objects of non-integral dimension. The essential problem is to\ndetermine when a family of braid representations can be uniformly modelled upon\na tensor power of a fixed vector space in such a way that the braid group\ngenerators act \"locally\". We formulate a $16$-fold way\nconjecture for the minimal modular extensions of super-modular categories to\nspin modular categories, which is a categorical formulation of gauging the\nfermion parity. We formulate a $16$-fold way\nconjecture for the minimal modular extensions of super-modular categories to\nspin modular categories, which is a categorical formulation of gauging the\nfermion parity. We investigate general properties of super-modular categories\nsuch as fermions in twisted Drinfeld doubles, Verlinde formulas for naive\nquotients, and explicit extensions of $PSU(2)_{4m+2}$ with an eye towards a\nclassification of the low-rank cases."}, "authors": [{"name": "Paul Bruillard"}, {"name": "Cesar Galindo"}, {"name": "Tobias Hagge"}, {"name": "Siu-Hung Ng"}, {"name": "Julia Yael Plavnik"}, {"name": "Eric C. We study two TQFTs\nconstructed from Jones' subfactor theory which are believed to be\ncounterexamples to this conjecture: one is the quantum double of the even\nsectors of the $E_6$ subfactor, and the other is the quantum double of the even\nsectors of the Haagerup subfactor. We cannot prove mathematically that the two\nTQFTs are indeed counterexamples because CSW TQFTs, while physically defined,\nare not yet mathematically constructed for every pair $(G,\\lambda)$. The cases\nthat are constructed mathematically include:\n  1. $G$ is a finite group--the Dijkgraaf-Witten TQFTs;\n  2. $G$ is torus $T^n$;\n  3. $G$ is a connected semi-simple Lie group--the Reshetikhin-Turaev TQFTs.\n  We prove that the two TQFTs are not among those mathematically constructed\nTQFTs or their direct products. Both TQFTs are of the Turaev-Viro type: quantum\ndoubles of spherical tensor categories. We further prove that neither TQFT is a\nquantum double of a braided fusion category, and give evidence that neither is\nan orbifold or coset of TQFTs above. Moreover, representation of the braid\ngroups from the half $E_6$ TQFT can be used to build universal topological\nquantum computers, and the same is expected for the Haagerup case.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "It has been conjectured that every $(2+1)$-TQFT is a Chern-Simons-Witten\n(CSW) theory labelled by a pair $(G,\\lambda)$, where $G$ is a compact Lie\ngroup, and $\\lambda \\in H^4(BG;Z)$ a cohomology class. We study two TQFTs\nconstructed from Jones' subfactor theory which are believed to be\ncounterexamples to this conjecture: one is the quantum double of the even\nsectors of the $E_6$ subfactor, and the other is the quantum double of the even\nsectors of the Haagerup subfactor. We cannot prove mathematically that the two\nTQFTs are indeed counterexamples because CSW TQFTs, while physically defined,\nare not yet mathematically constructed for every pair $(G,\\lambda)$. The cases\nthat are constructed mathematically include:\n  1. $G$ is a finite group--the Dijkgraaf-Witten TQFTs;\n  2. $G$ is torus $T^n$;\n  3. $G$ is a connected semi-simple Lie group--the Reshetikhin-Turaev TQFTs.\n  We prove that the two TQFTs are not among those mathematically constructed\nTQFTs or their direct products. Both TQFTs are of the Turaev-Viro type: quantum\ndoubles of spherical tensor categories. We further prove that neither TQFT is a\nquantum double of a braided fusion category, and give evidence that neither is\nan orbifold or coset of TQFTs above. Moreover, representation of the braid\ngroups from the half $E_6$ TQFT can be used to build universal topological\nquantum computers, and the same is expected for the Haagerup case."}, "authors": [{"name": "Seung-moon Hong"}, {"name": "Eric Rowell"}, {"name": "Zhenghan Wang"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhenghan Wang"}, "author": "Zhenghan Wang", "arxiv_comment": "Minor changes and addition of a few references. As such, a conjecture of the second author would imply that images\nof the braid group representations associated with metaplectic categories are\nfinite groups, i.e. have property $F$. While it was recently shown that\n$SO(N)_2$ itself has property $F$, proving property $F$ for the more general\nclass of metaplectic modular categories is an open problem. We verify this\nconjecture for $N$-metaplectic modular categories when $N$ is odd, exploiting\ntheir classification and enumeration to relate them to $SO(N)_2$. In another\ndirection, we prove that when $N$ is divisible by $8$ the $N$-metaplectic\ncategories have $3$ non-trivial bosons, and the boson condensation procedure\napplied to 2 of these bosons yields $\\frac{N}{4}$-metaplectic categories.\nOtherwise stated: any $8k$-metaplectic category is a $\\mathbb{Z}_2$-gauging of\na $2k$-metaplectic category, so that the $N$ even metaplectic categories lie\ntowers of $\\mathbb{Z}_2$-gaugings commencing with $2k$- or $4k$-metaplectic\ncategories with $k$ odd.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "$N$-Metaplectic categories, unitary modular categories with the same fusion\nrules as $SO(N)_2$, are prototypical examples of weakly integral modular\ncategories. As such, a conjecture of the second author would imply that images\nof the braid group representations associated with metaplectic categories are\nfinite groups, i.e. have property $F$. While it was recently shown that\n$SO(N)_2$ itself has property $F$, proving property $F$ for the more general\nclass of metaplectic modular categories is an open problem. We verify this\nconjecture for $N$-metaplectic modular categories when $N$ is odd, exploiting\ntheir classification and enumeration to relate them to $SO(N)_2$. In another\ndirection, we prove that when $N$ is divisible by $8$ the $N$-metaplectic\ncategories have $3$ non-trivial bosons, and the boson condensation procedure\napplied to 2 of these bosons yields $\\frac{N}{4}$-metaplectic categories.\nOtherwise stated: any $8k$-metaplectic category is a $\\mathbb{Z}_2$-gauging of\na $2k$-metaplectic category, so that the $N$ even metaplectic categories lie\ntowers of $\\mathbb{Z}_2$-gaugings commencing with $2k$- or $4k$-metaplectic\ncategories with $k$ odd."}, "authors": [{"name": "Paul Gustafson"}, {"name": "Eric Rowell"}, {"name": "Yuze Ruan"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Yuze Ruan"}, "author": "Yuze Ruan", "arxiv_comment": "version 3: condensed proofs", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00698v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.00698v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.QA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.QA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2002.07744v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2002.07744v1", "updated": "2020-02-18T17:22:24Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 2, 18, 17, 22, 24, 1, 49, 0], "published": "2020-02-18T17:22:24Z", "published_parsed": [2020, 2, 18, 17, 22, 24, 1, 49, 0], "title": "Symplectic level-rank duality via tensor categories", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Symplectic level-rank duality via tensor categories"}, "summary": "We give two proofs of a level-rank duality for braided fusion categories\nobtained from quantum groups of type $C$ at roots of unity. Geom. Topol. 8 (2008) 2063-2079", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.GR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.GR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "20F36; 20C15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0712.1377v4", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0712.1377v4", "updated": "2009-11-09T18:04:18Z", "updated_parsed": [2009, 11, 9, 18, 4, 18, 0, 313, 0], "published": "2007-12-09T23:35:50Z", "published_parsed": [2007, 12, 9, 23, 35, 50, 6, 343, 0], "title": "On classification of modular tensor categories", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "On classification of modular tensor categories"}, "summary": "We classify all unitary modular tensor categories (UMTCs) of rank $\\leq 4$.\nThere are a total of 70 UMTCs of rank $\\leq 4$ (Note that some authors would\nhave counted as 35 MTCs.) In our convention there are two trivial unitary MTCs\ndistinguished by the modular $S$ matrix $S=(\\pm1)$. Each such UMTC can be\nobtained from 10 non-trivial prime UMTCs by direct product, and some symmetry\noperations.\n  UMTCs encode topological properties of anyonic quantum systems and can be\nused to build fault-tolerant quantum computers. We conjecture that there are\nonly finitely many equivalence classes of MTCs for any given rank, and a UMTC\nis universal for anyonic quantum computation if and only if its global quantum\ndimension $D^2$ is \\emph{not} an integer.\n  Discovery of non-abelain anyons in Nature will be a landmark in condensed\nmatter physics. The non-abelian anyons in UMTCs of rank $\\leq 4$ are the\nsimplest, and, therefore, are most likely to be found. G. Moore and N. Read\nproposed that non-abelian statistics could occur in fractional quantum Hall\n(FQH) liquids. The Read-Rezayi conjecture predicts the existence of anyons\nrelated to $SU(2)_k$ in FQH liquids at filling fractions $\\nu=2+\\frac{k}{k+2}$\nfor $k=1,2,3$. For $\\nu={5/2}$ and $SU(2)_2$, there is a numerical proof and\nexperimental evidence for this conjecture. The Ising anyons might exist in\nchiral superconductors (strontium ruthenate). There are theoretical designs for\nthe toric code MTC using Josephson junction array, for the $Fib\\times Fib$ MTC\nusing optical lattice, and for the $SU(2)_k$ using cold trapped bosonic atoms.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We classify all unitary modular tensor categories (UMTCs) of rank $\\leq 4$.\nThere are a total of 70 UMTCs of rank $\\leq 4$ (Note that some authors would\nhave counted as 35 MTCs.) In our convention there are two trivial unitary MTCs\ndistinguished by the modular $S$ matrix $S=(\\pm1)$. Each such UMTC can be\nobtained from 10 non-trivial prime UMTCs by direct product, and some symmetry\noperations.\n  UMTCs encode topological properties of anyonic quantum systems and can be\nused to build fault-tolerant quantum computers. We conjecture that there are\nonly finitely many equivalence classes of MTCs for any given rank, and a UMTC\nis universal for anyonic quantum computation if and only if its global quantum\ndimension $D^2$ is \\emph{not} an integer.\n  Discovery of non-abelain anyons in Nature will be a landmark in condensed\nmatter physics. The non-abelian anyons in UMTCs of rank $\\leq 4$ are the\nsimplest, and, therefore, are most likely to be found. G. Moore and N. Read\nproposed that non-abelian statistics could occur in fractional quantum Hall\n(FQH) liquids. The Read-Rezayi conjecture predicts the existence of anyons\nrelated to $SU(2)_k$ in FQH liquids at filling fractions $\\nu=2+\\frac{k}{k+2}$\nfor $k=1,2,3$. For $\\nu={5/2}$ and $SU(2)_2$, there is a numerical proof and\nexperimental evidence for this conjecture. The Ising anyons might exist in\nchiral superconductors (strontium ruthenate). There are theoretical designs for\nthe toric code MTC using Josephson junction array, for the $Fib\\times Fib$ MTC\nusing optical lattice, and for the $SU(2)_k$ using cold trapped bosonic atoms."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric Rowell"}, {"name": "Richard Stong"}, {"name": "Zhenghan Wang"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhenghan Wang"}, "author": "Zhenghan Wang", "arxiv_comment": "Several references added. Here\n$\\mathcal{L}_n$ consists of $n$ pairwise unlinked Euclidean circles each linked\nto an auxiliary circle. Partially motivated by physical considerations, we\nstudy representations of the necklace braid group $\\mathcal{NB}_n$, especially\nthose obtained as extensions of representations of the braid group\n$\\mathcal{B}_n$ and the loop braid group $\\mathcal{LB}_n$. We show that any\nirreducible $\\mathcal{B}_n$ representation extends to $\\mathcal{NB}_n$ in a\nstandard way. We also find some non-standard extensions of several well-known\n$\\mathcal{B}_n$-representations such as the Burau and LKB representations.\nMoreover, we prove that any local representation of $\\mathcal{B}_n$ (i.e.\ncoming from a braided vector space) can be extended to $\\mathcal{NB}_n$, in\ncontrast to the situation with $\\mathcal{LB}_n$. From this discussion we\nfind that objects in braided fusion categories with integral squared dimension\nhave distinctive properties. A large and interesting class of non-integral\nmodular categories such that every simple object has integral\nsquared-dimensions are the metaplectic categories that have the same fusion\nrules as $SO(N)_2$ for some $N$. We describe and complete their classification\nand enumeration, by recognizing them as $\\mathbb{Z}_2$-gaugings of cyclic\nmodular categories (i.e. metric groups). We prove that any modular category of\ndimension $2^km$ with $m$ square-free and $k\\leq 4$, satisfying some additional\nassumptions, is a metaplectic category. From this discussion we\nfind that objects in braided fusion categories with integral squared dimension\nhave distinctive properties. A large and interesting class of non-integral\nmodular categories such that every simple object has integral\nsquared-dimensions are the metaplectic categories that have the same fusion\nrules as $SO(N)_2$ for some $N$. We describe and complete their classification\nand enumeration, by recognizing them as $\\mathbb{Z}_2$-gaugings of cyclic\nmodular categories (i.e. metric groups). A na\\\"ive computer search approach to\nthe classification of rank $n$ integral modular categories using this bound\nquickly overwhelms the computer's memory (for $n\\geq 7$). We use a modified\nstrategy: find general conditions on modular categories that imply integrality\nand study the classification problem in these limited settings. The first such\ncondition is that the order of the twist matrix is 2,3,4 or 6 and we obtain a\nfairly complete description of these classes of modular categories. The second\ncondition is that the unit object is the only simple non-self-dual object,\nwhich is equivalent to odd-dimensionality. In this case we obtain a (linear)\nimprovement on the bounds and employ number-theoretic techniques to obtain a\nclassification for rank at most 11 for odd-dimensional modular categories.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "It is a well-known result of Etingof, Nikshych and Ostrik that there are\nfinitely many inequivalent integral modular categories of any fixed rank $n$.\nThis follows from a double-exponential bound on the maximal denominator in an\nEgyptian fraction representation of 1. A na\\\"ive computer search approach to\nthe classification of rank $n$ integral modular categories using this bound\nquickly overwhelms the computer's memory (for $n\\geq 7$). We use a modified\nstrategy: find general conditions on modular categories that imply integrality\nand study the classification problem in these limited settings. The first such\ncondition is that the order of the twist matrix is 2,3,4 or 6 and we obtain a\nfairly complete description of these classes of modular categories. The second\ncondition is that the unit object is the only simple non-self-dual object,\nwhich is equivalent to odd-dimensionality. In this case we obtain a (linear)\nimprovement on the bounds and employ number-theoretic techniques to obtain a\nclassification for rank at most 11 for odd-dimensional modular categories."}, "authors": [{"name": "Paul Bruillard"}, {"name": "Eric C. The first is the family of semisimple\nquotients of H. Andersen's tilting module categories for quantum groups of Lie\ntype $B$ specialized at odd roots of unity. The second consists of categories\nconstructed from a particular family of finite-dimensional quotients of the\ngroup algebra of Artin's braid group known as $BMW$-algebras of type $BC$. Our\nmain result is to show that these families coincide as braided tensor\ncategories using a recent theorem of Tuba and Wenzl. This completes the classification of weakly integral modular\ncategories through rank $7$. Our results imply that all integral modular\ncategories of rank at most $7$ are pointed (that is, every simple object has\ndimension $1$). All strictly weakly integral (weakly integral but non-integral)\nmodular categories of ranks $6$ and $7$ have dimension $4m$, with $m$ an odd\nsquare free integer, so their classification is an application of our main\nresult. The classification of rank $7$ integral modular categories is\nfacilitated by an analysis of two actions on modular categories: the Galois\ngroup of the field generated by the entries of the $S$-matrix and the group of\nisomorphism classes of invertible simple objects. The interplay of these two\nactions is of independent interest, and we derive some valuable arithmetic\nconsequences from their actions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We classify all modular categories of dimension $4m$, where $m$ is an odd\nsquare-free integer, and all ranks $6$ and $7$ weakly integral modular\ncategories. We classify all super-modular categories up to\nrank=$6$, and spin modular categories up to rank=$11$. In particular, we show\nthat, up to fusion rules, there is exactly one non-split super-modular category\nof rank $2,4$ and $6$, namely $PSU(2)_{4k+2}$ for $k=0,1$ and $2$. Physically, super-modular categories\ndescribe universal properties of quasiparticles in fermionic topological phases\nof matter. In general one does not have a representation of the modular group\n$\\mathrm{SL}(2,\\mathbb{Z})$ associated to a super-modular category, but it is\npossible to obtain a representation of the (index 3) $\\theta$-subgroup:\n$\\Gamma_\\theta<\\mathrm{SL}(2,\\mathbb{Z})$. We study the image of this\nrepresentation and conjecture a super-modular analogue of the Ng-Schauenburg\nCongruence Subgroup Theorem for modular categories, namely that the kernel of\nthe $\\Gamma_\\theta$ representation is a congruence subgroup. We prove this\nconjecture for any super-modular category that is a subcategory of modular\ncategory of twice its dimension, i.e. admitting a minimal modular extension.\nConjecturally, every super-modular category admits (precisely 16) minimal\nmodular extensions and, therefore, our conjecture would be a consequence.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A super-modular category is a unitary pre-modular category with M\\\"uger\ncenter equivalent to the symmetric unitary category of super-vector spaces.\nSuper-modular categories are important alternatives to modular categories as\nany unitary pre-modular category is the equivariantization of a either a\nmodular or super-modular category. Physically, super-modular categories\ndescribe universal properties of quasiparticles in fermionic topological phases\nof matter. In general one does not have a representation of the modular group\n$\\mathrm{SL}(2,\\mathbb{Z})$ associated to a super-modular category, but it is\npossible to obtain a representation of the (index 3) $\\theta$-subgroup:\n$\\Gamma_\\theta<\\mathrm{SL}(2,\\mathbb{Z})$. We study the image of this\nrepresentation and conjecture a super-modular analogue of the Ng-Schauenburg\nCongruence Subgroup Theorem for modular categories, namely that the kernel of\nthe $\\Gamma_\\theta$ representation is a congruence subgroup. We prove this\nconjecture for any super-modular category that is a subcategory of modular\ncategory of twice its dimension, i.e. admitting a minimal modular extension.\nConjecturally, every super-modular category admits (precisely 16) minimal\nmodular extensions and, therefore, our conjecture would be a consequence."}, "authors": [{"name": "Parsa Bonderson"}, {"name": "Eric C. We\nfirst construct new representations of extraspecial 2-groups. Extending the\nlatter by the symmetric group, we construct new unitary braid representations,\nwhich are solutions to generalized Yang-Baxter equations and use them to\nrealize new braiding quantum gates. These gates generate the GHZ\n(Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger) states, for an arbitrary (particularly an\n\\emph{odd}) number of qubits, from the product basis. We also discuss the\nYang-Baxterization of the new braid group representations, which describes\nunitary evolution of the GHZ states. Our study suggests that through their\nconnection with braiding gates, extraspecial 2-groups and the GHZ states may\nplay an important role in quantum error correction and topological quantum\ncomputing.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper we describe connections among extraspecial 2-groups, unitary\nrepresentations of the braid group and multi-qubit braiding quantum gates. We\nfirst construct new representations of extraspecial 2-groups. Extending the\nlatter by the symmetric group, we construct new unitary braid representations,\nwhich are solutions to generalized Yang-Baxter equations and use them to\nrealize new braiding quantum gates. These gates generate the GHZ\n(Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger) states, for an arbitrary (particularly an\n\\emph{odd}) number of qubits, from the product basis. We also discuss the\nYang-Baxterization of the new braid group representations, which describes\nunitary evolution of the GHZ states. Our study suggests that through their\nconnection with braiding gates, extraspecial 2-groups and the GHZ states may\nplay an important role in quantum error correction and topological quantum\ncomputing."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric C. Our point of view is to regard the three strand braid group\n$\\mathcal{B}_3$ as a subgroup of $\\mathcal{LB}_3$ and study the problem of\nextending $\\mathcal{B}_3$ representations. We introduce the notion of a\n\\emph{standard extension} and characterize $\\mathcal{B}_3$ representations\nadmiting such an extension. In particular we show, using a classification\nresult of Tuba and Wenzl, that every irreducible $\\mathcal{B}_3$ representation\nof dimension at most $5$ has a (standard) extension. We show that this result\nis sharp by exhibiting an irreducible $6$-dimensional $\\mathcal{B}_3$\nrepresentation that has no extensions (standard or otherwise). Our point of view is to regard the three strand braid group\n$\\mathcal{B}_3$ as a subgroup of $\\mathcal{LB}_3$ and study the problem of\nextending $\\mathcal{B}_3$ representations. We introduce the notion of a\n\\emph{standard extension} and characterize $\\mathcal{B}_3$ representations\nadmiting such an extension. In particular we show, using a classification\nresult of Tuba and Wenzl, that every irreducible $\\mathcal{B}_3$ representation\nof dimension at most $5$ has a (standard) extension. We verify\nintegral metaplectic modular categories have property $\\textbf{F}$ by showing\nthese categories are group theoretical. For the special case of integral\ncategories $\\mathcal{C}$ with the fusion rules of $SO(8)_2$ we determine the\nfinite group $G$ for which $Rep(D^{\\omega}G)$ is braided equivalent to\n$\\mathcal{Z}(\\mathcal{C})$. Unitary $R$-matrices, namely unitary solutions\nto the Yang-Baxter equation, afford explicitly local unitary representations of\nbraid groups. Inspired by topological quantum computation, we study whether or\nnot it is possible to reassemble the irreducible summands appearing in the\nunitary braid group representations from a unitary braided fusion category with\npossibly different positive multiplicities to get representations that are\nuniformly equivalent to the ones from a unitary R-matrix. Such an equivalence\nwill be called a localization of the unitary braid group representations. We\nshow that the q=exp(\\pi i/6) specialization of the unitary Jones representation\nof the braid groups can be localized by a unitary $9\\times 9$ R-matrix.\nActually this Jones representation is the first one in a family of theories\n(SO(N),2) for an odd prime N>1, which are conjectured to be localizable. We\nformulate several general conjectures and discuss possible connections to\nphysics and computer science.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Governed by locality, we explore a connection between unitary braid group\nrepresentations associated to a unitary $R$-matrix and to a simple object in a\nunitary braided fusion category. Unitary $R$-matrices, namely unitary solutions\nto the Yang-Baxter equation, afford explicitly local unitary representations of\nbraid groups. Inspired by topological quantum computation, we study whether or\nnot it is possible to reassemble the irreducible summands appearing in the\nunitary braid group representations from a unitary braided fusion category with\npossibly different positive multiplicities to get representations that are\nuniformly equivalent to the ones from a unitary R-matrix. We study two TQFTs\nconstructed from Jones' subfactor theory which are believed to be\ncounterexamples to this conjecture: one is the quantum double of the even\nsectors of the $E_6$ subfactor, and the other is the quantum double of the even\nsectors of the Haagerup subfactor. We cannot prove mathematically that the two\nTQFTs are indeed counterexamples because CSW TQFTs, while physically defined,\nare not yet mathematically constructed for every pair $(G,\\lambda)$. The cases\nthat are constructed mathematically include:\n  1. $G$ is a finite group--the Dijkgraaf-Witten TQFTs;\n  2. $G$ is torus $T^n$;\n  3. $G$ is a connected semi-simple Lie group--the Reshetikhin-Turaev TQFTs.\n  We prove that the two TQFTs are not among those mathematically constructed\nTQFTs or their direct products. Both TQFTs are of the Turaev-Viro type: quantum\ndoubles of spherical tensor categories. We further prove that neither TQFT is a\nquantum double of a braided fusion category, and give evidence that neither is\nan orbifold or coset of TQFTs above. Moreover, representation of the braid\ngroups from the half $E_6$ TQFT can be used to build universal topological\nquantum computers, and the same is expected for the Haagerup case.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "It has been conjectured that every $(2+1)$-TQFT is a Chern-Simons-Witten\n(CSW) theory labelled by a pair $(G,\\lambda)$, where $G$ is a compact Lie\ngroup, and $\\lambda \\in H^4(BG;Z)$ a cohomology class. We study two TQFTs\nconstructed from Jones' subfactor theory which are believed to be\ncounterexamples to this conjecture: one is the quantum double of the even\nsectors of the $E_6$ subfactor, and the other is the quantum double of the even\nsectors of the Haagerup subfactor. We cannot prove mathematically that the two\nTQFTs are indeed counterexamples because CSW TQFTs, while physically defined,\nare not yet mathematically constructed for every pair $(G,\\lambda)$. The cases\nthat are constructed mathematically include:\n  1. $G$ is a finite group--the Dijkgraaf-Witten TQFTs;\n  2. $G$ is torus $T^n$;\n  3. $G$ is a connected semi-simple Lie group--the Reshetikhin-Turaev TQFTs.\n  We prove that the two TQFTs are not among those mathematically constructed\nTQFTs or their direct products. Both TQFTs are of the Turaev-Viro type: quantum\ndoubles of spherical tensor categories. We further prove that neither TQFT is a\nquantum double of a braided fusion category, and give evidence that neither is\nan orbifold or coset of TQFTs above. Moreover, representation of the braid\ngroups from the half $E_6$ TQFT can be used to build universal topological\nquantum computers, and the same is expected for the Haagerup case."}, "authors": [{"name": "Seung-moon Hong"}, {"name": "Eric Rowell"}, {"name": "Zhenghan Wang"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhenghan Wang"}, "author": "Zhenghan Wang", "arxiv_comment": "Minor changes and addition of a few references. As such, a conjecture of the second author would imply that images\nof the braid group representations associated with metaplectic categories are\nfinite groups, i.e. have property $F$. While it was recently shown that\n$SO(N)_2$ itself has property $F$, proving property $F$ for the more general\nclass of metaplectic modular categories is an open problem. We verify this\nconjecture for $N$-metaplectic modular categories when $N$ is odd, exploiting\ntheir classification and enumeration to relate them to $SO(N)_2$. In another\ndirection, we prove that when $N$ is divisible by $8$ the $N$-metaplectic\ncategories have $3$ non-trivial bosons, and the boson condensation procedure\napplied to 2 of these bosons yields $\\frac{N}{4}$-metaplectic categories.\nOtherwise stated: any $8k$-metaplectic category is a $\\mathbb{Z}_2$-gauging of\na $2k$-metaplectic category, so that the $N$ even metaplectic categories lie\ntowers of $\\mathbb{Z}_2$-gaugings commencing with $2k$- or $4k$-metaplectic\ncategories with $k$ odd.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "$N$-Metaplectic categories, unitary modular categories with the same fusion\nrules as $SO(N)_2$, are prototypical examples of weakly integral modular\ncategories. In our convention there are two trivial unitary MTCs\ndistinguished by the modular $S$ matrix $S=(\\pm1)$. Each such UMTC can be\nobtained from 10 non-trivial prime UMTCs by direct product, and some symmetry\noperations.\n  UMTCs encode topological properties of anyonic quantum systems and can be\nused to build fault-tolerant quantum computers. We conjecture that there are\nonly finitely many equivalence classes of MTCs for any given rank, and a UMTC\nis universal for anyonic quantum computation if and only if its global quantum\ndimension $D^2$ is \\emph{not} an integer.\n  Discovery of non-abelain anyons in Nature will be a landmark in condensed\nmatter physics. The non-abelian anyons in UMTCs of rank $\\leq 4$ are the\nsimplest, and, therefore, are most likely to be found. G. Moore and N. Read\nproposed that non-abelian statistics could occur in fractional quantum Hall\n(FQH) liquids. The Read-Rezayi conjecture predicts the existence of anyons\nrelated to $SU(2)_k$ in FQH liquids at filling fractions $\\nu=2+\\frac{k}{k+2}$\nfor $k=1,2,3$. For $\\nu={5/2}$ and $SU(2)_2$, there is a numerical proof and\nexperimental evidence for this conjecture. The Ising anyons might exist in\nchiral superconductors (strontium ruthenate). In our convention there are two trivial unitary MTCs\ndistinguished by the modular $S$ matrix $S=(\\pm1)$. Each such UMTC can be\nobtained from 10 non-trivial prime UMTCs by direct product, and some symmetry\noperations.\n  UMTCs encode topological properties of anyonic quantum systems and can be\nused to build fault-tolerant quantum computers. We conjecture that there are\nonly finitely many equivalence classes of MTCs for any given rank, and a UMTC\nis universal for anyonic quantum computation if and only if its global quantum\ndimension $D^2$ is \\emph{not} an integer.\n  Discovery of non-abelain anyons in Nature will be a landmark in condensed\nmatter physics. The non-abelian anyons in UMTCs of rank $\\leq 4$ are the\nsimplest, and, therefore, are most likely to be found. G. Moore and N. Read\nproposed that non-abelian statistics could occur in fractional quantum Hall\n(FQH) liquids. The Read-Rezayi conjecture predicts the existence of anyons\nrelated to $SU(2)_k$ in FQH liquids at filling fractions $\\nu=2+\\frac{k}{k+2}$\nfor $k=1,2,3$. For $\\nu={5/2}$ and $SU(2)_2$, there is a numerical proof and\nexperimental evidence for this conjecture. The Ising anyons might exist in\nchiral superconductors (strontium ruthenate). Topological precision has been confirmed in quantum Hall liquids\nby experiments to an accuracy of $10^{-10}$, and harnessed to stabilize quantum\nmemory. In this survey, we discuss the conceptual development of this\ninterdisciplinary field at the juncture of mathematics, physics and computer\nscience. Our focus is on computing and physical motivations, basic mathematical\nnotions and results, open problems and future directions related to and/or\ninspired by topological quantum computing.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In topological quantum computing, information is encoded in \"knotted\" quantum\nstates of topological phases of matter, thus being locked into topology to\nprevent decay. Topological precision has been confirmed in quantum Hall liquids\nby experiments to an accuracy of $10^{-10}$, and harnessed to stabilize quantum\nmemory. In this survey, we discuss the conceptual development of this\ninterdisciplinary field at the juncture of mathematics, physics and computer\nscience. Our focus is on computing and physical motivations, basic mathematical\nnotions and results, open problems and future directions related to and/or\ninspired by topological quantum computing."}, "authors": [{"name": "Eric C. Here\n$\\mathcal{L}_n$ consists of $n$ pairwise unlinked Euclidean circles each linked\nto an auxiliary circle. Partially motivated by physical considerations, we\nstudy representations of the necklace braid group $\\mathcal{NB}_n$, especially\nthose obtained as extensions of representations of the braid group\n$\\mathcal{B}_n$ and the loop braid group $\\mathcal{LB}_n$. We show that any\nirreducible $\\mathcal{B}_n$ representation extends to $\\mathcal{NB}_n$ in a\nstandard way. We also find some non-standard extensions of several well-known\n$\\mathcal{B}_n$-representations such as the Burau and LKB representations.\nMoreover, we prove that any local representation of $\\mathcal{B}_n$ (i.e.\ncoming from a braided vector space) can be extended to $\\mathcal{NB}_n$, in\ncontrast to the situation with $\\mathcal{LB}_n$. We also discuss some\ndirections for future study from categorical and physical perspectives.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The necklace braid group $\\mathcal{NB}_n$ is the motion group of the $n+1$\ncomponent necklace link $\\mathcal{L}_n$ in Euclidean $\\mathbb{R}^3$. Here\n$\\mathcal{L}_n$ consists of $n$ pairwise unlinked Euclidean circles each linked\nto an auxiliary circle. Partially motivated by physical considerations, we\nstudy representations of the necklace braid group $\\mathcal{NB}_n$, especially\nthose obtained as extensions of representations of the braid group\n$\\mathcal{B}_n$ and the loop braid group $\\mathcal{LB}_n$. We show that any\nirreducible $\\mathcal{B}_n$ representation extends to $\\mathcal{NB}_n$ in a\nstandard way. We also find some non-standard extensions of several well-known\n$\\mathcal{B}_n$-representations such as the Burau and LKB representations.\nMoreover, we prove that any local representation of $\\mathcal{B}_n$ (i.e.\ncoming from a braided vector space) can be extended to $\\mathcal{NB}_n$, in\ncontrast to the situation with $\\mathcal{LB}_n$. We show that Sobolev estimates for the\ncomplex Green operator hold simultaneously for forms of symmetric bidegrees,\nthat is, they hold for $(p,q)$--forms if and only if they hold for\n$(m-p,m-1-q)$--forms. Here $m$ equals the CR dimension of $M$ plus one.\nSymmetries of this type are known to hold for compactness estimates. We further\nshow that with the usual microlocalization, compactness estimates for the\npositive part percolate up the complex, i.e. if they hold for $(p,q)$--forms,\nthey also hold for $(p,q+1)$--forms. We show that\ncompactness of the complex Green operator $G_{q}$ on $(0,q)$-forms on $b\\Omega$\nimplies compactness of the $\\bar{\\partial}$-Neumann operator $N_{q}$ on\n$\\Omega$. We prove that if $1 \\leq q \\leq n-2$ and $b\\Omega$ satisfies $(P_q)$\nand $(P_{n-q-1})$, then $G_{q}$ is a compact operator (and so is $G_{n-1-q}$).\nOur method relies on a jump type formula to represent forms on the boundary,\nand we prove an auxiliary compactness result for an `annulus' between two\npseudoconvex domains. The model\narises in the mathematical modeling of ultra-slow diffusion processes observed\nin some physical problems, whose solution decays only logarithmically as the\ntime $t$ tends to infinity. We develop a space semidiscrete scheme based on the\nstandard Galerkin finite element method, and establish error estimates optimal\nwith respect to data regularity in $L^2(D)$ and $H^1(D)$ norms for both smooth\nand nonsmooth initial data. Further, we propose two fully discrete schemes,\nbased on the Laplace transform and convolution quadrature generated by the\nbackward Euler method, respectively, and provide optimal convergence rates in\nthe $L^2(D)$ norm, which exhibits exponential convergence and first-order\nconvergence in time, respectively. Extensive numerical experiments are provided\nto verify the error estimates for both smooth and nonsmooth initial data, and\nto examine the asymptotic behavior of the solution.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this work, we consider the numerical solution of an initial boundary value\nproblem for the distributed order time fractional diffusion equation. The model\narises in the mathematical modeling of ultra-slow diffusion processes observed\nin some physical problems, whose solution decays only logarithmically as the\ntime $t$ tends to infinity. We develop a space semidiscrete scheme based on the\nstandard Galerkin finite element method, and establish error estimates optimal\nwith respect to data regularity in $L^2(D)$ and $H^1(D)$ norms for both smooth\nand nonsmooth initial data. Further, we propose two fully discrete schemes,\nbased on the Laplace transform and convolution quadrature generated by the\nbackward Euler method, respectively, and provide optimal convergence rates in\nthe $L^2(D)$ norm, which exhibits exponential convergence and first-order\nconvergence in time, respectively. Extensive numerical experiments are provided\nto verify the error estimates for both smooth and nonsmooth initial data, and\nto examine the asymptotic behavior of the solution."}, "authors": [{"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "Raytcho Lazarov"}, {"name": "Dongwoo Sheen"}, {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}, "author": "Zhi Zhou", "arxiv_comment": "25 pages, 2 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1504.01529v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1504.01529v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.00253v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.00253v1", "updated": "2015-01-01T06:30:44Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 1, 1, 6, 30, 44, 3, 1, 0], "published": "2015-01-01T06:30:44Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 1, 1, 6, 30, 44, 3, 1, 0], "title": "An analysis of the L1 Scheme for the subdiffusion equation with\n  nonsmooth data", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "An analysis of the L1 Scheme for the subdiffusion equation with\n  nonsmooth data"}, "summary": "The subdiffusion equation with a Caputo fractional derivative of order\n$\\alpha\\in(0,1)$ in time arises in a wide variety of practical applications,\nand it is often adopted to model anomalous subdiffusion processes in\nheterogeneous media. The L1 scheme is one of the most popular and successful\nnumerical methods for discretizing the Caputo fractional derivative in time.\nThe scheme was analyzed earlier independently by Lin and Xu (2007) and Sun and\nWu (2006), and an $O(\\tau^{2-\\alpha})$ convergence rate was established, under\nthe assumption that the solution is twice continuously differentiable in time.\nHowever, in view of the smoothing property of the subdiffusion equation, this\nregularity condition is restrictive, since it does not hold even for the\nhomogeneous problem with a smooth initial data. In this work, we revisit the\nerror analysis of the scheme, and establish an $O(\\tau)$ convergence rate for\nboth smooth and nonsmooth initial data. The analysis is valid for more general\nsectorial operators. In particular, the L1 scheme is applied to one-dimensional\nspace-time fractional diffusion equations, which involves also a\nRiemann-Liouville derivative of order $\\beta\\in(3/2,2)$ in space, and error\nestimates are provided for the fully discrete scheme. Numerical experiments are\nprovided to verify the sharpness of the error estimates, and robustness of the\nscheme with respect to data regularity.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The subdiffusion equation with a Caputo fractional derivative of order\n$\\alpha\\in(0,1)$ in time arises in a wide variety of practical applications,\nand it is often adopted to model anomalous subdiffusion processes in\nheterogeneous media. The L1 scheme is one of the most popular and successful\nnumerical methods for discretizing the Caputo fractional derivative in time.\nThe scheme was analyzed earlier independently by Lin and Xu (2007) and Sun and\nWu (2006), and an $O(\\tau^{2-\\alpha})$ convergence rate was established, under\nthe assumption that the solution is twice continuously differentiable in time.\nHowever, in view of the smoothing property of the subdiffusion equation, this\nregularity condition is restrictive, since it does not hold even for the\nhomogeneous problem with a smooth initial data. In this work, we revisit the\nerror analysis of the scheme, and establish an $O(\\tau)$ convergence rate for\nboth smooth and nonsmooth initial data. The analysis is valid for more general\nsectorial operators. In particular, the L1 scheme is applied to one-dimensional\nspace-time fractional diffusion equations, which involves also a\nRiemann-Liouville derivative of order $\\beta\\in(3/2,2)$ in space, and error\nestimates are provided for the fully discrete scheme. Numerical experiments are\nprovided to verify the sharpness of the error estimates, and robustness of the\nscheme with respect to data regularity."}, "authors": [{"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "Raytcho Lazarov"}, {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}, "author": "Zhi Zhou", "arxiv_comment": "19 pp", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.00253v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1501.00253v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1612.04846v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1612.04846v3", "updated": "2018-03-01T20:56:11Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 3, 1, 20, 56, 11, 3, 60, 0], "published": "2016-12-14T21:25:51Z", "published_parsed": [2016, 12, 14, 21, 25, 51, 2, 349, 0], "title": "Optimal Solvers for Linear Systems with Fractional Powers of Sparse SPD\n  Matrices", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Optimal Solvers for Linear Systems with Fractional Powers of Sparse SPD\n  Matrices"}, "summary": "In this paper we consider efficient algorithms for solving the algebraic\nequation ${\\mathcal A}^\\alpha {\\bf u}={\\bf f}$, $0< \\alpha <1$, where\n${\\mathcal A}$ is a symmetric and positive definite matrix obtained form finite\ndifference or finite element approximations of second order elliptic problems\nin ${\\mathbb R}^d$, $d=1,2,3$. We establish the Sobolev regularity of the homogeneous\nproblem for both smooth and nonsmooth initial data $v$, including $v\\in\nL^2(\\Omega)$. A space semidiscrete Galerkin scheme using continuous piecewise\nlinear finite elements is developed, and optimal with respect to initial data\nregularity error estimates for the finite element approximations are derived.\nFurther, two fully discrete schemes based on the backward Euler method and\nsecond-order backward difference method and the related convolution quadrature\nare developed, and optimal error estimates are derived for the fully discrete\napproximations for both smooth and nonsmooth initial data. The error analysis of the fully discrete scheme is\n  shortened", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1404.2953v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1404.2953v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1105.1131v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1105.1131v1", "updated": "2011-05-05T17:46:20Z", "updated_parsed": [2011, 5, 5, 17, 46, 20, 3, 125, 0], "published": "2011-05-05T17:46:20Z", "published_parsed": [2011, 5, 5, 17, 46, 20, 3, 125, 0], "title": "Robust Domain Decomposition Preconditioners for Abstract Symmetric\n  Positive Definite Bilinear Forms", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Robust Domain Decomposition Preconditioners for Abstract Symmetric\n  Positive Definite Bilinear Forms"}, "summary": "An abstract framework for constructing stable decompositions of the spaces\ncorresponding to general symmetric positive definite problems into \"local\"\nsubspaces and a global \"coarse\" space is developed. Particular applications of\nthis abstract framework include practically important problems in porous media\napplications such as: the scalar elliptic (pressure) equation and the stream\nfunction formulation of its mixed form, Stokes' and Brinkman's equations. The\nconstant in the corresponding abstract energy estimate is shown to be robust\nwith respect to mesh parameters as well as the contrast, which is defined as\nthe ratio of high and low values of the conductivity (or permeability). The\nderived stable decomposition allows to construct additive overlapping Schwarz\niterative methods with condition numbers uniformly bounded with respect to the\ncontrast and mesh parameters. The coarse spaces are obtained by patching\ntogether the eigenfunctions corresponding to the smallest eigenvalues of\ncertain local problems. A detailed analysis of the abstract setting is\nprovided. The proposed decomposition builds on a method of Efendiev and Galvis,\nMultiscale Model. Simul., 8 (2010), pp. 1461--1483, developed for second order\nscalar elliptic problems with high contrast. Applications to the finite element\ndiscretizations of the second order elliptic problem in Galerkin and mixed\nformulation, the Stokes equations, and Brinkman's problem are presented. A\nnumber of numerical experiments for these problems in two spatial dimensions\nare provided.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "An abstract framework for constructing stable decompositions of the spaces\ncorresponding to general symmetric positive definite problems into \"local\"\nsubspaces and a global \"coarse\" space is developed. Particular applications of\nthis abstract framework include practically important problems in porous media\napplications such as: the scalar elliptic (pressure) equation and the stream\nfunction formulation of its mixed form, Stokes' and Brinkman's equations. The\nconstant in the corresponding abstract energy estimate is shown to be robust\nwith respect to mesh parameters as well as the contrast, which is defined as\nthe ratio of high and low values of the conductivity (or permeability). The\nderived stable decomposition allows to construct additive overlapping Schwarz\niterative methods with condition numbers uniformly bounded with respect to the\ncontrast and mesh parameters. The coarse spaces are obtained by patching\ntogether the eigenfunctions corresponding to the smallest eigenvalues of\ncertain local problems. A detailed analysis of the abstract setting is\nprovided. The proposed decomposition builds on a method of Efendiev and Galvis,\nMultiscale Model. Simul., 8 (2010), pp. 1461--1483, developed for second order\nscalar elliptic problems with high contrast.
