Willems", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1105.1131v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1105.1131v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65F10, 65N20, 65N22, 65N30, 65N55", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1805.11309v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1805.11309v1", "updated": "2018-05-29T08:47:56Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 5, 29, 8, 47, 56, 1, 149, 0], "published": "2018-05-29T08:47:56Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 5, 29, 8, 47, 56, 1, 149, 0], "title": "Numerical methods for time-fractional evolution equations with nonsmooth\n  data: a concise overview", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Numerical methods for time-fractional evolution equations with nonsmooth\n  data: a concise overview"}, "summary": "Over the past few decades, there has been substantial interest in evolution\nequations that involving a fractional-order derivative of order\n$\\alpha\\in(0,1)$ in time, due to their many successful applications in\nengineering, physics, biology and finance. Thus, it is of paramount importance\nto develop and to analyze efficient and accurate numerical methods for reliably\nsimulating such models, and the literature on the topic is vast and fast\ngrowing. The present paper gives a concise overview on numerical schemes for\nthe subdiffusion model with nonsmooth problem data, which are important for the\nnumerical analysis of many problems arising in optimal control, inverse\nproblems and stochastic analysis. We focus on the following aspects of the\nsubdiffusion model: regularity theory, Galerkin finite element discretization\nin space, time-stepping schemes (including convolution quadrature and L1 type\nschemes), and space-time variational formulations, and compare the results with\nthat for standard parabolic problems. Further, these aspects are showcased with\nillustrative numerical experiments and complemented with perspectives and\npointers to relevant literature.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Over the past few decades, there has been substantial interest in evolution\nequations that involving a fractional-order derivative of order\n$\\alpha\\in(0,1)$ in time, due to their many successful applications in\nengineering, physics, biology and finance. Thus, it is of paramount importance\nto develop and to analyze efficient and accurate numerical methods for reliably\nsimulating such models, and the literature on the topic is vast and fast\ngrowing. The present paper gives a concise overview on numerical schemes for\nthe subdiffusion model with nonsmooth problem data, which are important for the\nnumerical analysis of many problems arising in optimal control, inverse\nproblems and stochastic analysis. We focus on the following aspects of the\nsubdiffusion model: regularity theory, Galerkin finite element discretization\nin space, time-stepping schemes (including convolution quadrature and L1 type\nschemes), and space-time variational formulations, and compare the results with\nthat for standard parabolic problems. Further, these aspects are showcased with\nillustrative numerical experiments and complemented with perspectives and\npointers to relevant literature."}, "authors": [{"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "Raytcho Lazarov"}, {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}, "author": "Zhi Zhou", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.cma.2018.12.011", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cma.2018.12.011", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1805.11309v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1805.11309v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "24 pages, 3 figures", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1510.02825v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1510.02825v1", "updated": "2015-10-09T21:10:33Z", "updated_parsed": [2015, 10, 9, 21, 10, 33, 4, 282, 0], "published": "2015-10-09T21:10:33Z", "published_parsed": [2015, 10, 9, 21, 10, 33, 4, 282, 0], "title": "On Nonnegativity Preservation in Finite Element Methods for Subdiffusion\n  Equations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "On Nonnegativity Preservation in Finite Element Methods for Subdiffusion\n  Equations"}, "summary": "We consider three types of subdiffusion models, namely single-term,\nmulti-term and distributed order fractional diffusion equations, for which the\nmaximum-principle holds and which, in particular, preserve nonnegativity. Hence\nthe solution is nonnegative for nonnegative initial data. Following earlier\nwork on the heat equation, our purpose is to study whether this property is\ninherited by certain spatially semidiscrete and fully discrete piecewise linear\nfinite element methods, including the standard Galerkin method, the lumped mass\nmethod and the finite volume element method. It is shown that, as for the heat\nequation, when the mass matrix is nondiagonal, nonnegativity is not preserved\nfor small time or time-step, but may reappear after a positivity threshold. For\nthe lumped mass method nonnegativity is preserved if and only if the\ntriangulation in the finite element space is of Delaunay type. Numerical\nexperiments illustrate and complement the theoretical results.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider three types of subdiffusion models, namely single-term,\nmulti-term and distributed order fractional diffusion equations, for which the\nmaximum-principle holds and which, in particular, preserve nonnegativity. Hence\nthe solution is nonnegative for nonnegative initial data. Following earlier\nwork on the heat equation, our purpose is to study whether this property is\ninherited by certain spatially semidiscrete and fully discrete piecewise linear\nfinite element methods, including the standard Galerkin method, the lumped mass\nmethod and the finite volume element method. It is shown that, as for the heat\nequation, when the mass matrix is nondiagonal, nonnegativity is not preserved\nfor small time or time-step, but may reappear after a positivity threshold. For\nthe lumped mass method nonnegativity is preserved if and only if the\ntriangulation in the finite element space is of Delaunay type. Numerical\nexperiments illustrate and complement the theoretical results."}, "authors": [{"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "Raytcho Lazarov"}, {"name": "Vidar Thom\u00e9e"}, {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}, "author": "Zhi Zhou", "arxiv_comment": "17 pp", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1510.02825v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1510.02825v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1208.3219v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1208.3219v1", "updated": "2012-08-15T20:48:31Z", "updated_parsed": [2012, 8, 15, 20, 48, 31, 2, 228, 0], "published": "2012-08-15T20:48:31Z", "published_parsed": [2012, 8, 15, 20, 48, 31, 2, 228, 0], "title": "Some error estimates for the finite volume element method for a\n  parabolic problem", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Some error estimates for the finite volume element method for a\n  parabolic problem"}, "summary": "We study spatially semidiscrete and fully discrete finite volume element\nmethods for the homogeneous heat equation with homogeneous Dirichlet boundary\nconditions and derive error estimates for smooth and nonsmooth initial data. We\nshow that the results of our earlier work \\cite{clt11} for the lumped mass\nmethod carry over to the present situation. In particular, in order for error\nestimates for initial data only in $L_2$ to be of optimal second order for\npositive time, a special condition is required, which is satisfied for\nsymmetric triangulations. Without any such condition, only first order\nconvergence can be shown, which is illustrated by a counterexample.\nImprovements hold for triangulations that are almost symmetric and piecewise\nalmost symmetric.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study spatially semidiscrete and fully discrete finite volume element\nmethods for the homogeneous heat equation with homogeneous Dirichlet boundary\nconditions and derive error estimates for smooth and nonsmooth initial data. We\nshow that the results of our earlier work \\cite{clt11} for the lumped mass\nmethod carry over to the present situation. In particular, in order for error\nestimates for initial data only in $L_2$ to be of optimal second order for\npositive time, a special condition is required, which is satisfied for\nsymmetric triangulations. Without any such condition, only first order\nconvergence can be shown, which is illustrated by a counterexample.\nImprovements hold for triangulations that are almost symmetric and piecewise\nalmost symmetric."}, "authors": [{"name": "P. Chatzipantelidis"}, {"name": "R. D. Lazarov"}, {"name": "V. Thomee"}], "author_detail": {"name": "V. Thomee"}, "author": "V. The\nstandard Galerkin finite element approximation converges slowly due to the\npresence of singularity term $x^{\\alpha-1}$ in the solution representation. In\nthis work, we develop a simple technique, by transforming it into a\nsecond-order two-point boundary value problem with nonlocal low order terms,\nwhose solution can reconstruct directly the solution to the original problem.\nThe stability of the variational formulation, and the optimal regularity pickup\nof the solution are analyzed. A novel Galerkin finite element method with\npiecewise linear or quadratic finite elements is developed, and $L^2(D)$ error\nestimates are provided. The\nstandard Galerkin finite element approximation converges slowly due to the\npresence of singularity term $x^{\\alpha-1}$ in the solution representation. In\nthis work, we develop a simple technique, by transforming it into a\nsecond-order two-point boundary value problem with nonlocal low order terms,\nwhose solution can reconstruct directly the solution to the original problem.\nThe stability of the variational formulation, and the optimal regularity pickup\nof the solution are analyzed. A novel Galerkin finite element method with\npiecewise linear or quadratic finite elements is developed, and $L^2(D)$ error\nestimates are provided. The approach is then applied to the corresponding\nfractional Sturm-Liouville problem, and error estimates of the eigenvalue\napproximations are given. These fractional derivatives lead to non-symmetric boundary\nvalue problems, which are investigated from a variational point of view. The\nvariational problem for the Riemann-Liouville case is coercive on the space\n$H_0^{\\alpha/2}(0,1)$ but the solutions are less regular, whereas that for the\nCaputo case involves different test and trial spaces. The numerical analysis of\nthese problems requires the so-called shift theorems which show that the\nsolutions of the variational problem are more regular. The regularity pickup\nenables one to establish convergence rates of the finite element\napproximations. Finally, numerical results are presented to illustrate the\nerror estimates.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this work, we consider boundary value problems involving Caputo and\nRiemann-Liouville fractional derivatives of order $\\alpha\\in(1,2)$ on the unit\ninterval $(0,1)$. These fractional derivatives lead to non-symmetric boundary\nvalue problems, which are investigated from a variational point of view. The\nvariational problem for the Riemann-Liouville case is coercive on the space\n$H_0^{\\alpha/2}(0,1)$ but the solutions are less regular, whereas that for the\nCaputo case involves different test and trial spaces. The numerical analysis of\nthese problems requires the so-called shift theorems which show that the\nsolutions of the variational problem are more regular. The regularity pickup\nenables one to establish convergence rates of the finite element\napproximations. They arise in the\nmathematical modeling of asymmetric super-diffusion processes in heterogeneous\nmedia. The well-posedness of the formulations and sharp regularity pickup of\nthe variational solutions are established. A novel finite element method is\ndeveloped, which employs continuous piecewise linear finite elements and\n\"shifted\" fractional powers for the trial and test space, respectively. The new\napproach has a number of distinct features: It allows deriving optimal error\nestimates in both $L^2(D)$ and $H^1(D)$ norms; and on a uniform mesh, the\nstiffness matrix of the leading term is diagonal and the resulting linear\nsystem is well conditioned. Further, in the Riemann-Liouville case, an enriched\nFEM is proposed to improve the convergence. Extensive numerical results are\npresented to verify the theoretical analysis and robustness of the numerical\nscheme.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this work, we develop variational formulations of Petrov-Galerkin type for\none-dimensional fractional boundary value problems involving either a\nRiemann-Liouville or Caputo derivative of order $\\alpha\\in(3/2, 2)$ in the\nleading term and both convection and potential terms. They arise in the\nmathematical modeling of asymmetric super-diffusion processes in heterogeneous\nmedia. The well-posedness of the formulations and sharp regularity pickup of\nthe variational solutions are established. A novel finite element method is\ndeveloped, which employs continuous piecewise linear finite elements and\n\"shifted\" fractional powers for the trial and test space, respectively. The new\napproach has a number of distinct features: It allows deriving optimal error\nestimates in both $L^2(D)$ and $H^1(D)$ norms; and on a uniform mesh, the\nstiffness matrix of the leading term is diagonal and the resulting linear\nsystem is well conditioned. We discuss a multiscale model reduction\ntechnique in the framework of the discontinuous Galerkin finite element method.\nWe propose three different finite element spaces on the coarse mesh.\n  The first space is based on a local eigenvalue problem that uses a weighted\n$L_2-$norm for computing the \"mass\" matrix. Part I.\n  Polynomial and homogenization-based multiscale spaces"}, "summary": "We introduce a finite element method for numerical upscaling of second order\nelliptic equations with highly heterogeneous coefficients. The method is based\non a mixed formulation of the problem and the concepts of the domain\ndecomposition and the hybrid discontinuous Galerkin methods. The method\nutilizes three different scales: (1) the scale of the partition of the domain\nof the problem, (2) the sale of partition of the boundaries of the subdomains\n(related to the corresponding space of Lagrange multipliers), and (3) the fine\ngrid scale that is assumed to resolve the scale of the heterogeneous variation\nof the coefficients. Our proposed method gives a flexible framework that (1)\ncouples independently generated multiscale basis functions in each coarse patch\n(2) provides a stable global coupling independent of local discretization,\nphysical scales and contrast (3) allows avoiding any constraints on coarse\nspaces. In this paper, we develop and study a multiscale HDG method that uses\npolynomial and homogenization-based multiscale spaces. These coarse spaces are\ndesigned for problems with scale separation. In our consequent paper, we plan\nto extend our flexible HDG framework to more challenging multiscale problems\nwith non-separable scales and high contrast and consider enriched coarse spaces\nthat use appropriate local spectral problems.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We introduce a finite element method for numerical upscaling of second order\nelliptic equations with highly heterogeneous coefficients. The method is based\non a mixed formulation of the problem and the concepts of the domain\ndecomposition and the hybrid discontinuous Galerkin methods. The method\nutilizes three different scales: (1) the scale of the partition of the domain\nof the problem, (2) the sale of partition of the boundaries of the subdomains\n(related to the corresponding space of Lagrange multipliers), and (3) the fine\ngrid scale that is assumed to resolve the scale of the heterogeneous variation\nof the coefficients. We analyze two semidiscrete schemes based on the standard Galerkin and\nlumped mass finite element methods. We analyze two semidiscrete schemes based on the standard Galerkin and\nlumped mass finite element methods. We\nshow that the results of our earlier work \\cite{clt11} for the lumped mass\nmethod carry over to the present situation. In particular, in order for error\nestimates for initial data only in $L_2$ to be of optimal second order for\npositive time, a special condition is required, which is satisfied for\nsymmetric triangulations. Without any such condition, only first order\nconvergence can be shown, which is illustrated by a counterexample.\nImprovements hold for triangulations that are almost symmetric and piecewise\nalmost symmetric.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study spatially semidiscrete and fully discrete finite volume element\nmethods for the homogeneous heat equation with homogeneous Dirichlet boundary\nconditions and derive error estimates for smooth and nonsmooth initial data. We\nshow that the results of our earlier work \\cite{clt11} for the lumped mass\nmethod carry over to the present situation. In particular, in order for error\nestimates for initial data only in $L_2$ to be of optimal second order for\npositive time, a special condition is required, which is satisfied for\nsymmetric triangulations. Without any such condition, only first order\nconvergence can be shown, which is illustrated by a counterexample.\nImprovements hold for triangulations that are almost symmetric and piecewise\nalmost symmetric."}, "authors": [{"name": "P. Chatzipantelidis"}, {"name": "R. D. Lazarov"}, {"name": "V. Thomee"}], "author_detail": {"name": "V. Thomee"}, "author": "V. Thomee", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1208.3219v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1208.3219v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "65M60, 65M15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1805.00711v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1805.00711v1", "updated": "2018-05-02T10:25:59Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 5, 2, 10, 25, 59, 2, 122, 0], "published": "2018-05-02T10:25:59Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 5, 2, 10, 25, 59, 2, 122, 0], "title": "Comparison analysis on two numerical methods for fractional diffusion\n  problems based on rational approximations of $t^\u03b3, \\ 0 \\le t \\le 1$", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Comparison analysis on two numerical methods for fractional diffusion\n  problems based on rational approximations of $t^\u03b3, \\ 0 \\le t \\le 1$"}, "summary": "We discuss, study, and compare experimentally three methods for solving the\nsystem of algebraic equations $\\mathbb{A}^\\alpha \\bf{u}=\\bf{f}$, $0< \\alpha\n<1$, where $\\mathbb{A}$ is a symmetric and positive definite matrix obtained\nfrom finite difference or finite element approximations of second order\nelliptic problems in $\\mathbb{R}^d$, $d=1,2,3$. The first method, introduced by\nHarizanov et.al, based on the best uniform rational approximation (BURA)\n$r_\\alpha(t)$ of $t^{1-\\alpha}$ for $0 \\le t \\le 1$, is used to get the\nrational approximation of $t^{-\\alpha}$ in the form $t^{-1}r_\\alpha(t)$. Here\nwe develop another method, denoted by R-BURA, that is based on the best\nrational approximation $r_{1-\\alpha}(t)$ of $t^\\alpha$ on the interval $[0,1]$\nand approximates $t^{-\\alpha}$ via $r^{-1}_{1-\\alpha}(t)$. The third method,\nintroduced and studied by Bonito and Pasciak, is based on an exponentially\nconvergent quadrature scheme for the Dundord-Taylor integral representation of\nthe fractional powers of elliptic operators. All three methods reduce the\nsolution of the system $\\mathbb{A}^\\alpha \\bf{u}=\\bf{f}$ to solving a number of\nequations of the type $(\\mathbb{A} +c\\mathbb{I})\\bf{u}= \\bf{f}$, $c \\ge 0$.\nComprehensive numerical experiments on model problems with $\\mathbb A$ obtained\nby approximation of elliptic equations in one and two spatial dimensions are\nused to compare the efficiency of these three algorithms depending on the\nfractional power $\\alpha$. The presented results prove the concept of the new\nR-BURA method, which performs well for $\\alpha$ close to $1$ in contrast to\nBURA, which performs well for $\\alpha $ close to $0$. As a result, we show\ntheoretically and experimentally, that they have mutually complementary\nadvantages.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We discuss, study, and compare experimentally three methods for solving the\nsystem of algebraic equations $\\mathbb{A}^\\alpha \\bf{u}=\\bf{f}$, $0< \\alpha\n<1$, where $\\mathbb{A}$ is a symmetric and positive definite matrix obtained\nfrom finite difference or finite element approximations of second order\nelliptic problems in $\\mathbb{R}^d$, $d=1,2,3$. The first method, introduced by\nHarizanov et.al, based on the best uniform rational approximation (BURA)\n$r_\\alpha(t)$ of $t^{1-\\alpha}$ for $0 \\le t \\le 1$, is used to get the\nrational approximation of $t^{-\\alpha}$ in the form $t^{-1}r_\\alpha(t)$. Here\nwe develop another method, denoted by R-BURA, that is based on the best\nrational approximation $r_{1-\\alpha}(t)$ of $t^\\alpha$ on the interval $[0,1]$\nand approximates $t^{-\\alpha}$ via $r^{-1}_{1-\\alpha}(t)$. The third method,\nintroduced and studied by Bonito and Pasciak, is based on an exponentially\nconvergent quadrature scheme for the Dundord-Taylor integral representation of\nthe fractional powers of elliptic operators. All three methods reduce the\nsolution of the system $\\mathbb{A}^\\alpha \\bf{u}=\\bf{f}$ to solving a number of\nequations of the type $(\\mathbb{A} +c\\mathbb{I})\\bf{u}= \\bf{f}$, $c \\ge 0$.\nComprehensive numerical experiments on model problems with $\\mathbb A$ obtained\nby approximation of elliptic equations in one and two spatial dimensions are\nused to compare the efficiency of these three algorithms depending on the\nfractional power $\\alpha$. The presented results prove the concept of the new\nR-BURA method, which performs well for $\\alpha$ close to $1$ in contrast to\nBURA, which performs well for $\\alpha $ close to $0$. As a result, we show\ntheoretically and experimentally, that they have mutually complementary\nadvantages."}, "authors": [{"name": "Stanislav Harizanov"}, {"name": "Raytcho Lazarov"}, {"name": "Pencho Marinov"}, {"name": "Svetozar Margenov"}, {"name": "Joseph Pasciak"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Joseph Pasciak"}, "author": "Joseph Pasciak", "arxiv_comment": "12 pages, 5 tables, 2 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1805.00711v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1805.00711v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.06477v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.06477v1", "updated": "2017-02-21T17:12:19Z", "updated_parsed": [2017, 2, 21, 17, 12, 19, 1, 52, 0], "published": "2017-02-21T17:12:19Z", "published_parsed": [2017, 2, 21, 17, 12, 19, 1, 52, 0], "title": "A numerical study of the homogeneous elliptic equation with fractional\n  order boundary conditions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A numerical study of the homogeneous elliptic equation with fractional\n  order boundary conditions"}, "summary": "We consider the homogeneous equation ${\\mathcal A} u=0$, where ${\\mathcal A}$\nis a symmetric and coercive elliptic operator in $H^1(\\Omega)$ with $\\Omega$\nbounded domain in ${{\\mathbb R}}^d$. The boundary conditions involve fractional\npower $\\alpha$, $ 0 < \\alpha <1$, of the Steklov spectral operator arising in\nDirichlet to Neumann map. For such problems we discuss two different numerical\nmethods: (1) a computational algorithm based on an approximation of the\nintegral representation of the fractional power of the operator and (2)\nnumerical technique involving an auxiliary Cauchy problem for an\nultra-parabolic equation and its subsequent approximation by a time stepping\ntechnique. "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Pointwise Asymptotic Behavior of Perturbed Viscous Shock Profiles"}, "summary": "We consider the asymptotic behavior of perturbations of Lax and\novercompressive type viscous shock profiles arising in systems of regularized\nconservation laws with strictly parabolic viscosity, and also in systems of\nconservation laws with partially parabolic regularizations such as arise in the\ncase of the compressible Navier--Stokes equations and in the equations of\nmagnetohydrodynamics. Under the necessary conditions of spectral and hyperbolic\nstability, together with transversality of the connecting profile, we establish\ndetailed pointwise estimates on perturbations from a sum of the viscous shock\nprofile under consideration and a family of diffusion waves which propagate\nperturbation signals along outgoing characteristics. Our approach combines the\nrecent $L^p$-space analysis of Raoofi [$L^p$ Asympototic Behavior of Perturbed\nViscous Shock Profiles, to appear J. Hyperbolic Differential Equations] with a\nstraightforward bootstrapping argument that relies on a refined description of\nnonlinear signal interactions, which we develop through convolution estimates\ninvolving Green's functions for the linear evolutionary PDE that arises upon\nlinearization of the regularized conservation law about the distinguished\nprofile. Our estimates are similar to, though slightly weaker than, those\ndeveloped by Liu in his landmark result on the case of weak Lax type profiles\narising in the case of identity viscosity [Pointwise Convergence to Shock Waves\nfor Viscous Conservation Laws, Comm. Pure Appl. Hyperbolic Differential Equations] with a\nstraightforward bootstrapping argument that relies on a refined description of\nnonlinear signal interactions, which we develop through convolution estimates\ninvolving Green's functions for the linear evolutionary PDE that arises upon\nlinearization of the regularized conservation law about the distinguished\nprofile. As pointed out in\n\\cite{Liu91, Liu97}, the key to obtaining sharp bounds is to take account of\ncancellation associated with the property that the solution decays faster along\ncharacteristic than in other directions. As pointed out in\n\\cite{Liu91, Liu97}, the key to obtaining sharp bounds is to take account of\ncancellation associated with the property that the solution decays faster along\ncharacteristic than in other directions. Formally, $\\mathcal L$ is a map $\\partial \\mathcal T\n\\rightarrow \\mathbb{Z}_d$ from the boundary of the tree to the integer\n$p$-adics whose values are determined by a Moore machine. The distribution of\nits outputs yields a probabilistic measure $\\mu$ on $\\partial \\mathcal T$,\nwhich in some cases can be computed by a Mealy-type machine (we then say that\n$\\mu$ is finite-state). A number of examples illustrating the different cases with\n$\\mathcal A$ being the adding machine is provided.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We introduce the notion of the Automatic Logarithm $\\mathcal L_{\\mathcal A,\n\\mathcal B}$ with the purpose of studying the expanding properties of Schreier\ngraphs of action of the group generated by two finite initial Mealy automata\n$\\mathcal A$ and $\\mathcal B$ on the levels of a regular $d$-ary rooted tree\n$\\mathcal T$, where $\\mathcal A$ is level-transitive and of bounded activity.\n$\\mathcal L_{\\mathcal A, \\mathcal B}$ computes the lengths of chords in this\nfamily of graphs. Formally, $\\mathcal L$ is a map $\\partial \\mathcal T\n\\rightarrow \\mathbb{Z}_d$ from the boundary of the tree to the integer\n$p$-adics whose values are determined by a Moore machine. The distribution of\nits outputs yields a probabilistic measure $\\mu$ on $\\partial \\mathcal T$,\nwhich in some cases can be computed by a Mealy-type machine (we then say that\n$\\mu$ is finite-state). In the\npresent paper we establish an effective criterion for Eulerian multizeta\nvalues, which characterizes when a multizeta value is a rational multiple of a\npower of the Carlitz period. For example, we show by direct computation that the Galois\ngroup of the Schubert problem of 3-planes in C^8 meeting 15 fixed 5-planes\nnon-trivially is the full symmetric group S_6006."}, "authors": [{"name": "Anton Leykin"}, {"name": "Frank Sottile"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Frank Sottile"}, "author": "Frank Sottile", "arxiv_comment": "17 pages, 4 figures. 3 references added", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0710.4607v4", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0710.4607v4", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "14N15, 65H20", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0310016v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0310016v1", "updated": "2003-10-01T19:00:41Z", "updated_parsed": [2003, 10, 1, 19, 0, 41, 2, 274, 0], "published": "2003-10-01T19:00:41Z", "published_parsed": [2003, 10, 1, 19, 0, 41, 2, 274, 0], "title": "Combinatorial Hopf algebras and generalized Dehn-Sommerville relations", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Combinatorial Hopf algebras and generalized Dehn-Sommerville relations"}, "summary": "A combinatorial Hopf algebra is a graded connected Hopf algebra over a field\n$F$ equipped with a character (multiplicative linear functional) $\\zeta:H\\to\nF$. We show that the terminal object in the category of combinatorial Hopf\nalgebras is the algebra $QSym$ of quasi-symmetric functions; this explains the\nubiquity of quasi-symmetric functions as generating functions in combinatorics.\nWe illustrate this with several examples. We prove that every character\ndecomposes uniquely as a product of an even character and an odd character.\nCorrespondingly, every combinatorial Hopf algebra $(H,\\zeta)$ possesses two\ncanonical Hopf subalgebras on which the character $\\zeta$ is even\n(respectively, odd). The odd subalgebra is defined by certain canonical\nrelations which we call the generalized Dehn-Sommerville relations. We show\nthat, for $H=QSym$, the generalized Dehn-Sommerville relations are the\nBayer-Billera relations and the odd subalgebra is the peak Hopf algebra of\nStembridge. We prove that $QSym$ is the product (in the categorical sense) of\nits even and odd Hopf subalgebras. We also calculate the odd subalgebras of\nvarious related combinatorial Hopf algebras: the Malvenuto-Reutenauer Hopf\nalgebra of permutations, the Loday-Ronco Hopf algebra of planar binary trees,\nthe Hopf algebras of symmetric functions and of non-commutative symmetric\nfunctions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A combinatorial Hopf algebra is a graded connected Hopf algebra over a field\n$F$ equipped with a character (multiplicative linear functional) $\\zeta:H\\to\nF$. We show that the terminal object in the category of combinatorial Hopf\nalgebras is the algebra $QSym$ of quasi-symmetric functions; this explains the\nubiquity of quasi-symmetric functions as generating functions in combinatorics.\nWe illustrate this with several examples. We prove that every character\ndecomposes uniquely as a product of an even character and an odd character.\nCorrespondingly, every combinatorial Hopf algebra $(H,\\zeta)$ possesses two\ncanonical Hopf subalgebras on which the character $\\zeta$ is even\n(respectively, odd). The odd subalgebra is defined by certain canonical\nrelations which we call the generalized Dehn-Sommerville relations. We show\nthat, for $H=QSym$, the generalized Dehn-Sommerville relations are the\nBayer-Billera relations and the odd subalgebra is the peak Hopf algebra of\nStembridge. We prove that $QSym$ is the product (in the categorical sense) of\nits even and odd Hopf subalgebras. These are unmixed systems\nassociated to certain polytopes. For the order polytope of a poset P this lower\nbound is the sign-imbalance of P and it holds if all maximal chains of P have\nlength of the same parity. While the multiplihedra may be\nunfamiliar to the algebraic combinatorics community, it is nestled between two\nfamilies of polytopes that certainly are not: the permutahedra {S_n} and\nassociahedra {Y_n}. The maps between these families reveal several new Hopf\nstructures on tree-like objects nestled between the Malvenuto-Reutenauer (MR)\nHopf algebra of permutations and the Loday-Ronco (LR) Hopf algebra of planar\nbinary trees. We begin their study here, constructing a module over MR and a\nHopf module over LR from the multiplihedra. Rich structural information about\nthis module is uncovered via a change of basis--using M\\\"obius inversion in\nposets built on the 1-skeleta of the {M_n}. While the multiplihedra may be\nunfamiliar to the algebraic combinatorics community, it is nestled between two\nfamilies of polytopes that certainly are not: the permutahedra {S_n} and\nassociahedra {Y_n}. The maps between these families reveal several new Hopf\nstructures on tree-like objects nestled between the Malvenuto-Reutenauer (MR)\nHopf algebra of permutations and the Loday-Ronco (LR) Hopf algebra of planar\nbinary trees. We begin their study here, constructing a module over MR and a\nHopf module over LR from the multiplihedra. Rich structural information about\nthis module is uncovered via a change of basis--using M\\\"obius inversion in\nposets built on the 1-skeleta of the {M_n}. They showed that the inclusion of the\nHopf algebra of non-commutative symmetric functions in the Malvenuto-Reutenauer\nHopf algebra of permutations factors through their Hopf algebra of trees, and\nthese maps correspond to natural maps from the weak order on the symmetric\ngroup to the Tamari order on planar binary trees to the boolean algebra.\n  We further study the structure of this Hopf algebra of trees using a new\nbasis for it. We give explicit formulas for its antipode, prove that\nit is a cofree coalgebra, determine its primitive elements and its coradical\nfiltration, and show that it decomposes as a crossed product over the Hopf\nalgebra of quasi-symmetric functions. In addition, we describe the structure\nconstants of the multiplication as a certain number of facets of the\npermutahedron. As a consequence we obtain a new interpretation of the product\nof monomial quasi-symmetric functions in terms of the facial structure of the\ncube. The Hopf algebra of Malvenuto and Reutenauer has a linear basis indexed\nby permutations. Our results are obtained from a combinatorial description of\nthe Hopf algebraic structure with respect to a new basis for this algebra,\nrelated to the original one via M\\\"obius inversion on the weak order on the\nsymmetric groups. This is in analogy with the relationship between the monomial\nand fundamental bases of the algebra of quasi-symmetric functions. Such\nequations from geometry for which we have information about their real\nsolutions are the subject of these lecture notes, which focuses on bounds, both\nupper and lower, as well as situations in which all solutions can be real.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Understanding, finding, or even deciding on the existence of real solutions\nto a system of equations is a very difficult problem with many applications.\nWhile it is hopeless to expect much in general, we know a surprising amount\nabout these questions for systems which possess additional structure.\nParticularly fruitful--both for information on real solutions and for\napplicability--are systems whose additional structure comes from geometry. The first, Stanley's reciprocity theorem,\nrelates the rational generating functions for the integer points in a cone K\nand for those in its interior. The second, Stanley's Positivity theorem asserts\nthat the generating function of the Ehrhart quasipolynomial of a rational\npolytope P can be written as a rational function with nonnegative numerator.\nThe third, Stanley's Monotonicity Theorem, asserts that if a polytope Q\ncontains P, then each coefficient in the numerator for Q is at least as large\nas the corresponding coefficient in the numerator for P. Our proofs are based\non elementary (primary school) counting afforded by irrational decompositions\nof rational polyhedra.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We give new proofs of three theorems of Stanley on generating functions for\nthe integer points in rational cones. The first, Stanley's reciprocity theorem,\nrelates the rational generating functions for the integer points in a cone K\nand for those in its interior. The second, Stanley's Positivity theorem asserts\nthat the generating function of the Ehrhart quasipolynomial of a rational\npolytope P can be written as a rational function with nonnegative numerator.\nThe third, Stanley's Monotonicity Theorem, asserts that if a polytope Q\ncontains P, then each coefficient in the numerator for Q is at least as large\nas the corresponding coefficient in the numerator for P. Our proofs are based\non elementary (primary school) counting afforded by irrational decompositions\nof rational polyhedra."}, "authors": [{"name": "Matthias Beck"}, {"name": "Frank Sottile"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Frank Sottile"}, "author": "Frank Sottile", "arxiv_comment": "7 pages. We show that Pi is closed under coproduct, and\ntherefore a Hopf algebra, and describe the kernel of the retraction. Billey and\nHaiman, in their work on Schubert polynomials, also defined a new class of\nquasi-symmetric functions --- shifted quasi-symmetric functions --- and we show\nthat Pi is strictly contained in the linear span Xi of shifted quasi-symmetric\nfunctions. We show that Xi is a coalgebra, and compute the rank of the n-th\ngraded component.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In his work on P-partitions, Stembridge defined the algebra of peak functions\nPi, which is both a subalgebra and a retraction of the algebra of\nquasi-symmetric functions. Billey and\nHaiman, in their work on Schubert polynomials, also defined a new class of\nquasi-symmetric functions --- shifted quasi-symmetric functions --- and we show\nthat Pi is strictly contained in the linear span Xi of shifted quasi-symmetric\nfunctions. This constitutes the largest\nfamily of enumerative problems whose Galois groups have been largely\ndetermined. Using a criterion of Vakil and a special position argument due to\nSchubert, our result follows from a particular inequality among Kostka numbers\nof two-rowed tableaux. In most cases, a combinatorial injection proves the\ninequality. For the remaining cases, we use the Weyl integral formula to obtain\nan integral formula for these Kostka numbers. This rewrites the inequality as\nan integral, which we estimate to establish the inequality.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We show that the Galois group of any Schubert problem involving lines in\nprojective space contains the alternating group. This constitutes the largest\nfamily of enumerative problems whose Galois groups have been largely\ndetermined. Using a criterion of Vakil and a special position argument due to\nSchubert, our result follows from a particular inequality among Kostka numbers\nof two-rowed tableaux. In most cases, a combinatorial injection proves the\ninequality. For the remaining cases, we use the Weyl integral formula to obtain\nan integral formula for these Kostka numbers. Algorithms for the\nfirst three involve the familiar procedures of jeu de taquin, row insertion,\nand column insertion. The fourth operation, hopscotch, is new, although\nspecialised versions have appeared previously. Like the other three operations,\nthis new operation may be computed with a set of local rules in a growth\ndiagram, and it preserves Knuth equivalence class. Each of these four\noperations gives rise to an a priori distinct theory of dual equivalence. We\nshow that these four theories coincide. The four operations are linked via the\ninvolutive tableau operations of complementation and conjugation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We study four operations defined on pairs of tableaux. Algorithms for the\nfirst three involve the familiar procedures of jeu de taquin, row insertion,\nand column insertion. The fourth operation, hopscotch, is new, although\nspecialised versions have appeared previously. Like the other three operations,\nthis new operation may be computed with a set of local rules in a growth\ndiagram, and it preserves Knuth equivalence class. Each of these four\noperations gives rise to an a priori distinct theory of dual equivalence. We\nshow that these four theories coincide. Specifically, given any collection of Schubert conditions on lines in\nprojective space which generically determine a finite number of lines, we show\nthere exist real generic conditions determining the expected number of real\nlines. Specifically, given any collection of Schubert conditions on lines in\nprojective space which generically determine a finite number of lines, we show\nthere exist real generic conditions determining the expected number of real\nlines. The first\nalgorithm assumes that we may only compute values of f - this may occur if f is\ngiven as a straight-line program, as a determinant, or as an oracle. The second\nalgorithm assumes that H is represented numerically via a witness set. That is,\nit computes the Newton polytope of H using only the ability to compute\nnumerical representatives of its intersections with lines. Their\nproof is quite remarkable, using ideas from integrable systems, Fuchsian\ndifferential equations, and representation theory. There is now a second proof\nof this result, and it has ramifications in other areas of mathematics, from\ncurves to control theory to combinatorics. Despite this work, the original\nShapiro conjecture is not yet settled. While it is false as stated, it has\nseveral interesting and not quite understood modifications and generalizations\nthat are likely true, and the strongest and most subtle version of the Shapiro\nconjecture for Grassmannians remains open.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The theorem of Mukhin, Tarasov, and Varchenko (formerly the Shapiro\nconjecture for Grassmannians) asserts that all (a priori complex) solutions to\ncertain geometric problems in the Schubert calculus are actually real. Their\nproof is quite remarkable, using ideas from integrable systems, Fuchsian\ndifferential equations, and representation theory. There is now a second proof\nof this result, and it has ramifications in other areas of mathematics, from\ncurves to control theory to combinatorics. Despite this work, the original\nShapiro conjecture is not yet settled. While it is false as stated, it has\nseveral interesting and not quite understood modifications and generalizations\nthat are likely true, and the strongest and most subtle version of the Shapiro\nconjecture for Grassmannians remains open."}, "authors": [{"name": "Frank Sottile"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Frank Sottile"}, "author": "Frank Sottile", "arxiv_comment": "41 pages", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0907.1847v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0907.1847v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.QA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "14N15, 14P99, 05E10", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0906.2497v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0906.2497v2", "updated": "2009-11-20T16:24:42Z", "updated_parsed": [2009, 11, 20, 16, 24, 42, 4, 324, 0], "published": "2009-06-13T19:24:21Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 6, 13, 19, 24, 21, 5, 164, 0], "title": "Experimentation at the Frontiers of Reality in Schubert Calculus", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Experimentation at the Frontiers of Reality in Schubert Calculus"}, "summary": "We describe a general framework for large-scale computational experiments in\nmathematics using computer resources that are available in most mathematics\ndepartments. We compute the dimension of the space of\nsplines with large degree in two extreme cases when the cell decomposition has\na single interior vertex. First, when the forms defining the edges span a\ntwo-dimensional space of forms of degree n---then the curves they define meet\nin n^2 points in the complex projective plane. They were first considered by Wang, Chui, and Stiller. We\ncompute the dimension of the space of semialgebraic splines in two extreme\ncases. If the polynomials defining the edges span a three-dimensional space of\npolynomials, then we compute the dimensions from the dimensions for a\ncorresponding rectilinear mesh. Computing\nmonodromy permutations using numerical algebraic geometry gives information\nabout the group, but can only determine it when it is the full symmetric group.\nWe give numerical methods to compute the Galois group and study it when it is\nnot the full symmetric group. This\nupper bound is non-trivial in that it is smaller than either the Kouchnirenko\nor the Khovanskii bounds for these systems. This\nextends work of Helmke, et al., who studied static symmetric feedback control\nof symmetric and Hamiltonian linear systems. 15, 15, 53, 2, 156, 0], "title": "Common transversals and tangents to two lines and two quadrics in P^3", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Common geometry: For which\narrangements of two lines and two spheres in R^3 are there infinitely many\nlines simultaneously transversal to the two lines and tangent to the two\nspheres?\n  We also treat a simultaneously transversal to the two lines and tangent to the two\nspheres?\n  We also treat a generalization of this problem to projective quadrics:\nReplacing the spheres in R^3 by quadrics in "published_parsed": [2009, 8, 31, 16, 55, 0, 0, 243, 0], "title": "Khovanskii-Rolle continuation for real solutions", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Khovanskii-Rolle continuation for real solutions"}, "summary": "We present a new continuation algorithm to find all nondegenerate real\nsolutions to a system of polynomial equations. Unlike homotopy methods, it is\nnot based on a deformation of the system; instead, it traces real curves\nconnecting the solutions of one system of equations to those of another,\neventually leading to the desired real solutions. It also differs from homotopy\nmethods in that it follows only real paths and computes no complex solutions of\nthe original equations. The number of curves traced is bounded by the fewnomial\nbound for real solutions, and the method takes advantage of any slack in that\nbound.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We present a new continuation algorithm to find all nondegenerate real\nsolutions to a system of polynomial equations. Unlike homotopy methods, it is\nnot based on a deformation of the system; instead, it traces real curves\nconnecting the solutions of one system of equations to those of another,\neventually leading to the desired real solutions. It also differs from homotopy\nmethods in that it follows only real paths and computes no complex solutions of\nthe original equations. The number of curves traced is bounded by the fewnomial\nbound for real solutions, and the method takes advantage of any slack in that\nbound."}, "authors": [{"name": "Dan Bates"}, {"name": "Frank Sottile"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Frank Sottile"}, "author": "Frank Sottile", "arxiv_comment": "21 pages, 7 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0908.4579v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/0908.4579v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "14P99, 65H10, 65H20", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0002207v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0002207v2", "updated": "2000-07-19T21:41:15Z", "updated_parsed": [2000, 7, 19, 21, 41, 15, 2, 201, 0], "published": "2000-02-24T22:40:54Z", "published_parsed": [2000, 2, 24, 22, 40, 54, 3, 55, 0], "title": "Some real and unreal enumerative geometry for flag manifolds", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Some real and unreal enumerative geometry for flag manifolds"}, "summary": "We present a general method for constructing real solutions to some problems\nin enumerative geometry which gives lower bounds on the maximum number of real\nsolutions. We apply this method to show that two new classes of enumerative\ngeometric problems on flag manifolds may have all their solutions be real and\nmodify this method to show that another class may have no real solutions, which\nis a new phenomenon. This method originated in a numerical homotopy\ncontinuation algorithm adapted to the special Schubert calculus on\nGrassmannians and in principle gives optimal numerical homotopy algorithms for\nfinding explicit solutions to these other enumerative problems.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We present a general method for constructing real solutions to some problems\nin enumerative geometry which gives lower bounds on the maximum number of real\nsolutions. We apply this method to show that two new classes of enumerative\ngeometric problems on flag manifolds may have all their solutions be real and\nmodify this method to show that another class may have no real solutions, which\nis a new phenomenon. This is also the formula for\nmultiplying a type $B$ (respectively, type $C$) Schubert polynomial by the\nSchur $P$-polynomial $p_m$ (respectively, the Schur $Q$-polynomial $q_m$).\nGeometric constructions and intermediate results allow us to ultimately deduce\nthis from formulas for the classical flag manifold. We\nshow that this definition extends a recent construction of Schubert polynomials\ndue to Bergeron and Sottile in terms of certain increasing labeled chains in\nBruhat order of the symmetric group. These skew Schubert polynomials expand in\nthe basis of Schubert polynomials with nonnegative integer coefficients that\nare precisely the structure constants of the cohomology of the complex flag\nvariety with respect to its basis of Schubert classes. Equivalently,\nthe structure constants for the ring of polynomials in variables $x_1,x_2,...$\nin terms of its basis of Schubert polynomials. We use combinatorial, algebraic,\nand geometric methods, notably a study of intersections of Schubert varieties\nand maps between flag manifolds. We establish a number of new identities among\nthese structure constants. This leads to formulas for some of these constants\nand new results on the enumeration of chains in the Bruhat order. A new graded\npartial order on the symmetric group which contains Young's lattice arises from\nthese investigations. We also derive formulas for certain specializations of\nSchubert polynomials.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We illuminate the relation between the Bruhat order on the symmetric group\nand structure constants (Littlewood-Richardson coefficients) for the cohomology\nof the flag manifold in terms of its basis of Schubert classes. Equivalently,\nthe structure constants for the ring of polynomials in variables $x_1,x_2,...$\nin terms of its basis of Schubert polynomials. We use combinatorial, algebraic,\nand geometric methods, notably a study of intersections of Schubert varieties\nand maps between flag manifolds. We establish a number of new identities among\nthese structure constants. This leads to formulas for some of these constants\nand new results on the enumeration of chains in the Bruhat order. One type\nexpresses any specialization of a Grothendieck polynomial in at least two sets\nof variables as a linear combination of products Grothendieck polynomials in\neach set of variables, with coefficients Schubert structure constants for\nGrothendieck polynomials. Our methods are based upon the geometry\nof permutation patterns.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We give new formulas for Grothendieck polynomials of two types. We show how\nnon-vanishing in the Schubert calculus for cominuscule flag varieties is\nsimilarly recursive. For these varieties, the non-vanishing of products of\nSchubert classes is controlled by the non-vanishing products on smaller\ncominuscule flag varieties. In particular, we show that the lists of Schubert\nclasses whose product is non-zero naturally correspond to the integer points in\nthe feasibility polytope, which is defined by inequalities coming from\nnon-vanishing products of Schubert classes on smaller cominuscule flag\nvarieties. Nilsson and Passare described the\nstructure of the coamoeba and its complement (a zonotope) when the reduced\nA-discriminant is a function of two variables. For the\nproblem of plane conics tangent to five general conics, the (surprising) answer\nis that all 3264 may be real. These highly symmetric convex bodies lie at the crossroads\nof several fields, in particular convex geometry, optimization, and algebraic\ngeometry. We present a self-contained theory of orbitopes, with particular\nemphasis on instances arising from the groups SO(n) and O(n). These include\nSchur-Horn orbitopes, tautological orbitopes, Caratheodory orbitopes, Veronese\norbitopes and Grassmann orbitopes. We study their face lattices, their\nalgebraic boundary hypersurfaces, and representations as spectrahedra or\nprojected spectrahedra.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "An orbitope is the convex hull of an orbit of a compact group acting linearly\non a vector space. These highly symmetric convex bodies lie at the crossroads\nof several fields, in particular convex geometry, optimization, and algebraic\ngeometry. We present a self-contained theory of orbitopes, with particular\nemphasis on instances arising from the groups SO(n) and O(n). These include\nSchur-Horn orbitopes, tautological orbitopes, Caratheodory orbitopes, Veronese\norbitopes and Grassmann orbitopes. The subalgebra generated by their coefficients is the coordinate ring of\nthe quantum Grassmannian, a singular compactification of the space of rational\ncurves of degree np in the Grassmannian of p-planes in (m + p)-space. These\nsubalgebra generators are shown to form a sagbi basis. The resulting flat\ndeformation from the quantum Grassmannian to a toric variety gives a new\n`Gr\\\"obner basis style' proof of the Ravi-Rosenthal-Wang formulas in quantum\nSchubert calculus. The coordinate ring of the quantum Grassmannian is an\nalgebra with straightening law, which is normal, Cohen-Macaulay, Gorenstein and\nKoszul, and the ideal of quantum Pl\\\"ucker relations has a quadratic Gr\\\"obner\nbasis. This holds more generally for skew quantum Schubert varieties. These\nresults are well-known for the classical Schubert varieties (n=0). We also show\nthat the row-consecutive p by p-minors of a generic matrix form a sagbi basis\nand we give a quadratic Gr\\\"obner basis for their algebraic relations.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "The maximal minors of a p by (m + p) matrix of univariate polynomials of\ndegree n with indeterminate coefficients are themselves polynomials of degree\nnp. The subalgebra generated by their coefficients is the coordinate ring of\nthe quantum Grassmannian, a singular compactification of the space of rational\ncurves of degree np in the Grassmannian of p-planes in (m + p)-space. These\nsubalgebra generators are shown to form a sagbi basis. The resulting flat\ndeformation from the quantum Grassmannian to a toric variety gives a new\n`Gr\\\"obner basis style' proof of the Ravi-Rosenthal-Wang formulas in quantum\nSchubert calculus. The coordinate ring of the quantum Grassmannian is an\nalgebra with straightening law, which is normal, Cohen-Macaulay, Gorenstein and\nKoszul, and the ideal of quantum Pl\\\"ucker relations has a quadratic Gr\\\"obner\nbasis. This holds more generally for skew quantum Schubert varieties. These\nresults are well-known for the classical Schubert varieties (n=0). We also show\nthat the row-consecutive p by p-minors of a generic matrix form a sagbi basis\nand we give a quadratic Gr\\\"obner basis for their algebraic relations."}, "authors": [{"name": "Frank Sottile"}, {"name": "Bernd Sturmfels"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Bernd Sturmfels"}, "arxiv_affiliation": "University of California-Berkeley", "author": "Bernd Sturmfels", "arxiv_comment": "18 pages, 3 eps figure, uses epsf.sty. Using a criterion of Vakil and\na special position argument due to Schubert, this follows from a particular\ninequality among Kostka numbers of two-rowed tableaux. In most cases, an easy\ncombinatorial injection proves the inequality. For the remaining cases, we use\nthat these Kostka numbers appear in tensor product decompositions of\nsl_2(C)-modules. Interpreting the tensor product as the action of certain\ncommuting Toeplitz matrices and using a spectral analysis and Fourier series\nrewrites the inequality as the positivity of an integral. We establish the\ninequality by estimating this integral.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We show that the Galois group of any Schubert problem involving lines in\nprojective space contains the alternating group. Using a criterion of Vakil and\na special position argument due to Schubert, this follows from a particular\ninequality among Kostka numbers of two-rowed tableaux. In most cases, an easy\ncombinatorial injection proves the inequality. For the remaining cases, we use\nthat these Kostka numbers appear in tensor product decompositions of\nsl_2(C)-modules. These have\nrecently been given a formulation in the setting of operator algebras as the\nSchur-Horn problem, where matrix algebras and diagonals are replaced\nrespectively by finite factors and maximal abelian self-adjoint subalgebras\n(masas). There is a special case of the problem, called the carpenter problem,\nwhich can be stated as follows: for a masa A in a finite factor M with\nconditional expectation E_A, can each x in A with 0 <= x <= 1 be expressed as\nE_A(p) for a projection p in M?\n  In this paper, we investigate these problems for various masas. We give\npositive solutions for the generator and radial masas in free group factors,\nand we also solve affirmatively a weaker form of the Schur-Horm problem for the\nCartan masa in the hyperfinite factor.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Two classical theorems in matrix theory, due to Schur and Horn, relate the\neigenvalues of a self-adjoint matrix to the diagonal entries. These have\nrecently been given a formulation in the setting of operator algebras as the\nSchur-Horn problem, where matrix algebras and diagonals are replaced\nrespectively by finite factors and maximal abelian self-adjoint subalgebras\n(masas). There is a special case of the problem, called the carpenter problem,\nwhich can be stated as follows: for a masa A in a finite factor M with\nconditional expectation E_A, can each x in A with 0 <= x <= 1 be expressed as\nE_A(p) for a projection p in M?\n  In this paper, we investigate these problems for various masas. For $n\\geq 3$ and a free ergodic probability\nmeasure preserving action of $SL_n(\\mathbb Z)$ on a standard nonatomic\nprobability space $(X,\\mu)$, write $M=((L^\\infty(X,\\mu)\\rtimes SL_n(\\mathbb\nZ))\\,\\overline{\\otimes}\\, R$, where $R$ is the hyperfinite II$_1$ factor. We\nshow that whenever $M$ is represented as a von Neumann algebra on some Hilbert\nspace $\\mathcal H$ and $N\\subseteq\\mathcal B(\\mathcal H)$ is sufficiently close\nto $M$, then there is a unitary $u$ on $\\mathcal H$ close to the identity\noperator with $uMu^*=N$. This provides the first nonamenable class of von\nNeumann algebras satisfying Kadison and Kastler's conjecture.\n  We also obtain stability results for crossed products\n$L^\\infty(X,\\mu)\\rtimes\\Gamma$ whenever the comparison map from the bounded to\nusual group cohomology vanishes in degree 2 for the module $L^2(X,\\mu)$. In\nthis case, any von Neumann algebra sufficiently close to such a crossed product\nis necessarily isomorphic to it. In particular, this result applies when\n$\\Gamma$ is a free group.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "A conjecture of Kadison and Kastler from 1972 asks whether sufficiently close\noperator algebras in a natural uniform sense must be small unitary\nperturbations of one another. For $n\\geq 3$ and a free ergodic probability\nmeasure preserving action of $SL_n(\\mathbb Z)$ on a standard nonatomic\nprobability space $(X,\\mu)$, write $M=((L^\\infty(X,\\mu)\\rtimes SL_n(\\mathbb\nZ))\\,\\overline{\\otimes}\\, R$, where $R$ is the hyperfinite II$_1$ factor. We\nshow that whenever $M$ is represented as a von Neumann algebra on some Hilbert\nspace $\\mathcal H$ and $N\\subseteq\\mathcal B(\\mathcal H)$ is sufficiently close\nto $M$, then there is a unitary $u$ on $\\mathcal H$ close to the identity\noperator with $uMu^*=N$. This provides the first nonamenable class of von\nNeumann algebras satisfying Kadison and Kastler's conjecture.\n  We also obtain stability results for crossed products\n$L^\\infty(X,\\mu)\\rtimes\\Gamma$ whenever the comparison map from the bounded to\nusual group cohomology vanishes in degree 2 for the module $L^2(X,\\mu)$. In\nthis case, any von Neumann algebra sufficiently close to such a crossed product\nis necessarily isomorphic to it. In the infinite index setting an inclusion\n$uNu^*\\subseteq N$ can be strict, forcing us to also investigate the semigroup\nof one-sided normalizers. We relate these normalizers of $N$ in $M$ to\nprojections in the basic construction and show that every trace one projection\nin the relative commutant $N'\\cap < M,e_N>$ is of the form $u^*e_Nu$ for some\nunitary $u\\in M$ with $uNu^*\\subseteq N$. This enables us to identify the\nnormalizers and the algebras they generate in several situations. In particular\neach normalizer of a tensor product of irreducible subfactors is a tensor\nproduct of normalizers modulo a unitary. We also examine normalizers of\nirreducible subfactors arising from subgroup--group inclusions $H\\subseteq G$.\nHere the normalizers are the normalizing group elements modulo a unitary from\n$L(H)$. We prove that a triple of finite von Neumann algebras\n$B\\subseteq N\\subseteq M$ has the relative weak asymptotic homomorphism\nproperty if and only if $N$ contains the set of all $x\\in M$ such that\n$Bx\\subseteq \\sum_{i=1}^n x_iB$ for a finite number of elements $x_1,...,x_n$\nin $M$. Such an $x$ is called a one sided quasi-normalizer of $B$, and the von\nNeumann algebra generated by all one sided quasi-normalizers of $B$ is called\nthe one sided quasi-normalizer algebra of $B$.\n  We characterize one sided quasi-normalizer algebras for inclusions of group\nvon Neumann algebras and use this to show that one sided quasi-normalizer\nalgebras and quasi-normalizer algebras are not equal in general. We also give\nsome applications to inclusions $L(H)\\subseteq L(G)$ arising from containments\nof groups. A partial isometry $v\\in M$ is called a\ngroupoid normalizer if $vBv^*, v^*Bv\\subseteq B$. Given two such inclusions\n$B_i\\subseteq M_i$, $i=1,2$, we find approximations to the groupoid normalizers\nof $B_1 \\vnotimes B_2$ in $M_1\\vnotimes M_2$, from which we deduce that the von\nNeumann algebra generated by the groupoid normalizers of the tensor product is\nequal to the tensor product of the von Neumann algebras generated by the\ngroupoid normalizers. Examples are given to show that this can fail without the\nhypothesis $B_i'\\cap M_i\\subseteq B_i$, $i=1,2$. We also prove a parallel\nresult where the groupoid normalizers are replaced by the intertwiners, those\npartial isometries $v\\in M$ satisfying $vBv^*\\subseteq B$ and $v^*v, vv^*\\in\nB$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider an inclusion $B\\subseteq M$ of finite von Neumann algebras\nsatisfying $B'\\cap M\\subseteq B$. A partial isometry $v\\in M$ is called a\ngroupoid normalizer if $vBv^*, v^*Bv\\subseteq B$. Given two such inclusions\n$B_i\\subseteq M_i$, $i=1,2$, we find approximations to the groupoid normalizers\nof $B_1 \\vnotimes B_2$ in $M_1\\vnotimes M_2$, from which we deduce that the von\nNeumann algebra generated by the groupoid normalizers of the tensor product is\nequal to the tensor product of the von Neumann algebras generated by the\ngroupoid normalizers. Examples are given to show that this can fail without the\nhypothesis $B_i'\\cap M_i\\subseteq B_i$, $i=1,2$. We also prove a parallel\nresult where the groupoid normalizers are replaced by the intertwiners, those\npartial isometries $v\\in M$ satisfying $vBv^*\\subseteq B$ and $v^*v, vv^*\\in\nB$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Junsheng Fang"}, {"name": "Roger R. Take a product metric on $M\n\\times {\\mathbb R}$, and rescale its ${\\mathbb R}$-component by a factor\n$\\lambda^2$. We show that generically, for large $\\lambda$, the\nMorse-Smale-Witten chain complex is isomorphic to the one for $f$ and the\nmetric restricted to ${\\mu^{-1}(0)}$, with grading shifted by one. On the other\nhand, let $\\lambda\\to 0$, we obtain another chain complex, which is\ngeometrically quite different but has the same homology as the singular\nhomology of $\\mu^{-1}(0)$ and the isomorphism between them is provided by the\nhomotopy by varying $\\lambda$. Our proofs contain both the implicit function\ntheorem on Banach manifolds and geometric singular perturbation theory.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Given two Morse functions $f, \\mu$ on a compact manifold $M$, we study the\nMorse homology for the Lagrange multiplier function on $M \\times {\\mathbb R}$\nwhich sends $(x, \\eta)$ to $f(x) + \\eta \\mu(x)$. Take a product metric on $M\n\\times {\\mathbb R}$, and rescale its ${\\mathbb R}$-component by a factor\n$\\lambda^2$. We show that generically, for large $\\lambda$, the\nMorse-Smale-Witten chain complex is isomorphic to the one for $f$ and the\nmetric restricted to ${\\mu^{-1}(0)}$, with grading shifted by one. On the other\nhand, let $\\lambda\\to 0$, we obtain another chain complex, which is\ngeometrically quite different but has the same homology as the singular\nhomology of $\\mu^{-1}(0)$ and the isomorphism between them is provided by the\nhomotopy by varying $\\lambda$. Our proofs contain both the implicit function\ntheorem on Banach manifolds and geometric singular perturbation theory."}, "authors": [{"name": "Stephen Schecter"}, {"name": "Guangbo Xu"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Guangbo Xu"}, "author": "Guangbo Xu", "arxiv_doi": "10.1016/j.jde.2014.08.018", "links": [{"title": "doi", "href": "http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jde.2014.08.018", "rel": "related", "type": "text/html"}, {"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1211.3028v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1211.3028v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_comment": "v3. 39 pages, published version, 4 figures. v2: 38 pages, 4 figures.\n  Removed the last section of the previous version, improved literature", "arxiv_journal_ref": "Journal of Differential Equations 257 (2014), 4277-4318", "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.GT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.GT", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.DS", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.SG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "57R70, 37D15", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1405.6352v3", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1405.6352v3", "updated": "2014-11-03T15:12:44Z", "updated_parsed": [2014, 11, 3, 15, 12, 44, 0, 307, 0], "published": "2014-05-25T00:43:27Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 5, 25, 0, 43, 27, 6, 145, 0], "title": "Analysis of gauged Witten equation", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Analysis of gauged Witten equation"}, "summary": "The gauged Witten equation was essentially introduced by Witten in his\nformulation of gauged linear $\\sigma$-model (GLSM). We\nexhibit for certain classes $\\cC$ of metric spaces, families of metric spaces\n$(M_i, d_i)_{i\\in I}$ which have the property that a metric space $(X,d_X)$ in\n$\\cC$ is coarsely, resp. Lipschitzly, universal for all spaces in $\\cC$ if the\ncollection of spaces $(M_i,d_i)_{i\\in I}$ equi-coarsely, respectively\nequi-Lipschitzly, embeds into $(X,d_X)$. Such families are built as certain\nSchreier-type metric subsets of $\\co$. We deduce a metric analog to Bourgain's\ntheorem, which generalized Szlenk's theorem, and prove that a space which is\ncoarsely universal for all separable reflexive asymptotic-$c_0$ Banach spaces\nis coarsely universal for all separable metric spaces. One of our coarse\nuniversality results is valid under Martin's Axiom and the negation of the\nContinuum Hypothesis. We discuss the strength of the universality statements\nthat can be obtained without these additional set theoretic assumptions. In the\nsecond part of the paper, we study universality properties of Kalton's\ninterlacing graphs. In particular, we prove that every finite metric space\nembeds almost isometrically in some interlacing graph of large enough diameter.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper we provide several \\emph{metric universality} results. We\nexhibit for certain classes $\\cC$ of metric spaces, families of metric spaces\n$(M_i, d_i)_{i\\in I}$ which have the property that a metric space $(X,d_X)$ in\n$\\cC$ is coarsely, resp. Lipschitzly, universal for all spaces in $\\cC$ if the\ncollection of spaces $(M_i,d_i)_{i\\in I}$ equi-coarsely, respectively\nequi-Lipschitzly, embeds into $(X,d_X)$. Such families are built as certain\nSchreier-type metric subsets of $\\co$. We deduce a metric analog to Bourgain's\ntheorem, which generalized Szlenk's theorem, and prove that a space which is\ncoarsely universal for all separable reflexive asymptotic-$c_0$ Banach spaces\nis coarsely universal for all separable metric spaces. One of our coarse\nuniversality results is valid under Martin's Axiom and the negation of the\nContinuum Hypothesis. We discuss the strength of the universality statements\nthat can be obtained without these additional set theoretic assumptions. In the\nsecond part of the paper, we study universality properties of Kalton's\ninterlacing graphs. In particular, we prove that every finite metric space\nembeds almost isometrically in some interlacing graph of large enough diameter."}, "authors": [{"name": "Florent P. Baudier"}, {"name": "Gilles Lancien"}, {"name": "Pavlos Motakis"}, {"name": "Thomas Schlumprecht"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Thomas Schlumprecht"}, "author": "Thomas Schlumprecht", "arxiv_comment": "25 pages; this submission contains a preliminary result that has\n  appeared earlier in Section 6 of arXiv:1806.00702v2 (but does not appear in\n  arXiv:1806.00702v3)", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2004.04806v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/2004.04806v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.MG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.MG", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.FA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "46B06, 46B20, 46B85, 46T99, 05C63, 20F65", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.7738v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.7738v2", "updated": "2020-12-22T00:14:37Z", "updated_parsed": [2020, 12, 22, 0, 14, 37, 1, 357, 0], "published": "2014-09-26T22:55:11Z", "published_parsed": [2014, 9, 26, 22, 55, 11, 4, 269, 0], "title": "Barycentric gluing and geometry of stable metrics", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Barycentric gluing and geometry of stable metrics"}, "summary": "We discuss various aspects of a local-to-global embedding technique and the\nmetric geometry of stable metric spaces and of two of its important subclasses:\nlocally finite spaces and proper spaces. We explain how the barycentric gluing\ntechnique, which has been mostly applied to bi-Lipschitz embedding problems\npertaining to locally finite spaces, can be implemented successfully in a much\nbroader context. For instance, we show that the embeddability of an arbitrary\nmetric space into $\\ell_p$ is determined by the embeddability of its balls. We\nalso introduce the notion of upper stability. This new metric invariant lies\nformally between Maurey-Krivine (metric) notion of stability and Kalton's\nproperty $\\mathcal{Q}$. We show that several results of Raynaud and Kalton for\nstable metrics can be extended to the broader context of upper stable metrics\nand we point out the relevance of upper stability to a long-standing embedding\nproblem raised by Kalton. Applications to compression exponent theory are\nhighlighted and we recall old and state new, important open problems. This\narticle was written in a style favoring clarity over conciseness in order to\nmake the material appealing, accessible, and reusable to geometers from a\nvariety of backgrounds, and not only to Banach space geometers.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We discuss various aspects of a local-to-global embedding technique and the\nmetric geometry of stable metric spaces and of two of its important subclasses:\nlocally finite spaces and proper spaces. We explain how the barycentric gluing\ntechnique, which has been mostly applied to bi-Lipschitz embedding problems\npertaining to locally finite spaces, can be implemented successfully in a much\nbroader context. For instance, we show that the embeddability of an arbitrary\nmetric space into $\\ell_p$ is determined by the embeddability of its balls. We\nalso introduce the notion of upper stability. This new metric invariant lies\nformally between Maurey-Krivine (metric) notion of stability and Kalton's\nproperty $\\mathcal{Q}$. We show that several results of Raynaud and Kalton for\nstable metrics can be extended to the broader context of upper stable metrics\nand we point out the relevance of upper stability to a long-standing embedding\nproblem raised by Kalton. Applications to compression exponent theory are\nhighlighted and we recall old and state new, important open problems. This\narticle was written in a style favoring clarity over conciseness in order to\nmake the material appealing, accessible, and reusable to geometers from a\nvariety of backgrounds, and not only to Banach space geometers."}, "authors": [{"name": "Florent Pierre Baudier"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Florent Pierre Baudier"}, "author": "Florent Pierre Baudier", "arxiv_comment": "v1 (22 pages) which was meant to be essentially expository has been\n  completely rewritten. v2 (now 37 pages) contains new material (c.f. abstract)\n  but the expository style has been preserved for the most part. We prove that lamplighter graphs over trees bi-Lipschitzly\nembed into Hamming cubes with distortion at most~$6$. It follows that\nlamplighter graphs over countable trees bi-Lipschitzly embed into $\\ell_1$. We\nstudy the metric behaviour of the operation of taking the lamplighter graph\nover the vertex-coalescence of two graphs. Based on this analysis, we provide\nmetric characterizations of superreflexivity in terms of lamplighter graphs\nover star graphs or rose graphs. Finally, we show that the presence of a clique\nin a graph implies the presence of a Hamming cube in the lamplighter graph over\nit.
