In\nparticular it is shown that for every $\\varepsilon>0$ and $k\\in\\mathbb{N}$,\n$D_k^\\omega$ embeds bi-Lipschiztly with distortion at most $6(1+\\varepsilon)$\ninto any reflexive Banach space with an unconditional asymptotic structure that\ndoes not admit an equivalent asymptotically uniformly convex norm. On the other\nhand it is shown that the sequence $(D_k^\\omega)_{k\\in\\mathbb{N}}$ does not\nadmit an equi-bi-Lipschitz embedding into any Banach space that has an\nequivalent asymptotically midpoint uniformly convex norm. Combining these two\nresults one obtains a metric characterization in terms of graph preclusion of\nthe class of asymptotically uniformly convexifiable spaces, within the class of\nseparable reflexive Banach spaces with an unconditional asymptotic structure.\nApplications to bi-Lipschitz embeddability into $L_p$-spaces and to some\nproblems in renorming theory are also discussed.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this article, the bi-Lipschitz embeddability of the sequence of countably\nbranching diamond graphs $(D_k^\\omega)_{k\\in\\mathbb{N}}$ is investigated. Defosseux. The vertical boundary acts as a reflecting wall.\nThe particle system lies in the Anisotropic Kardar-Parisi-Zhang with a wall\nuniversality class. Defosseux. The vertical boundary acts as a reflecting wall.\nThe particle system lies in the Anisotropic Kardar-Parisi-Zhang with a wall\nuniversality class. The family\nincludes previously discovered Plancherel measures for the infinite-dimensional\northogonal and symplectic groups. The construction uses certain BC-type\northogonal polynomials which generalize the characters of these groups.\n  The local asymptotics near the hard edge where one expects distinguishing\nbehavior yields the multi-time $(\\alpha, \\beta)$-dependent discrete Jacobi\nkernel and the multi-time $\\beta$-dependent hard-edge Pearcey kernel. For\nnonnegative integer values of $\\beta$, the hard-edge Pearcey kernel had\npreviously appeared in the asymptotics of non-intersecting squared Bessel paths\nat the hard edge.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We introduce a two parameter ($\\alpha, \\beta>-1$) family of interacting\nparticle systems with determinantal correlation kernels expressible in terms of\nJacobi polynomials $\\{ P^{(\\alpha, \\beta)}_k \\}_{k \\geq 0}$. The family\nincludes previously discovered Plancherel measures for the infinite-dimensional\northogonal and symplectic groups. The construction uses certain BC-type\northogonal polynomials which generalize the characters of these groups.\n  The local asymptotics near the hard edge where one expects distinguishing\nbehavior yields the multi-time $(\\alpha, \\beta)$-dependent discrete Jacobi\nkernel and the multi-time $\\beta$-dependent hard-edge Pearcey kernel. For\nnonnegative integer values of $\\beta$, the hard-edge Pearcey kernel had\npreviously appeared in the asymptotics of non-intersecting squared Bessel paths\nat the hard edge."}, "authors": [{"name": "Mark Cerenzia"}, {"name": "Jeffrey Kuan"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Jeffrey Kuan"}, "author": "Jeffrey Kuan", "arxiv_comment": "this article supersedes arXiv:1506.08742", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1608.06384v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1608.06384v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.PR", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0904.2607v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/0904.2607v2", "updated": "2011-03-07T04:49:18Z", "updated_parsed": [2011, 3, 7, 4, 49, 18, 0, 66, 0], "published": "2009-04-16T23:58:50Z", "published_parsed": [2009, 4, 16, 23, 58, 50, 3, 106, 0], "title": "Random surface growth with a wall and Plancherel measures for\n  O(infinity)", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Random surface growth with a wall and Plancherel measures for\n  O(infinity)"}, "summary": "We consider a Markov evolution of lozenge tilings of a quarter-plane and\nstudy its asymptotics at large times. In addition, we establish a priori bounds on a suitable scattering norm\nof the radial wave maps and exhibit concentration compactness properties of\nsequences of radial wave maps with uniformly bounded energies. This extends and\ncomplements the beautiful classical work of Christodoulou-Tahvildar-Zadeh [3,\n4] and Struwe [31, 33] as well as of Nahas [22] on radial wave maps in the case\nof the unit sphere as the target. The proof is based upon the concentration\ncompactness/rigidity method of Kenig-Merle [6, 7] and a \"twisted\"\nBahouri-Gerard type profile decomposition [1], following the implementation of\nthis strategy by the second author and Schlag [17] for energy critical wave\nmaps into the hyperbolic plane as well as by the last two authors [16] for the\nenergy critical Maxwell-Klein-Gordon equation.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider radially symmetric, energy critical wave maps from (1 +\n2)-dimensional Minkowski space into the unit sphere $\\mathbb{S}^m$, $m \\geq 1$,\nand prove global regularity and scattering for classical smooth data of finite\nenergy. In addition, we establish a priori bounds on a suitable scattering norm\nof the radial wave maps and exhibit concentration compactness properties of\nsequences of radial wave maps with uniformly bounded energies. This extends and\ncomplements the beautiful classical work of Christodoulou-Tahvildar-Zadeh [3,\n4] and Struwe [31, 33] as well as of Nahas [22] on radial wave maps in the case\nof the unit sphere as the target. The proof is based upon the concentration\ncompactness/rigidity method of Kenig-Merle [6, 7] and a \"twisted\"\nBahouri-Gerard type profile decomposition [1], following the implementation of\nthis strategy by the second author and Schlag [17] for energy critical wave\nmaps into the hyperbolic plane as well as by the last two authors [16] for the\nenergy critical Maxwell-Klein-Gordon equation."}, "authors": [{"name": "Elisabetta Chiodaroli"}, {"name": "Joachim Krieger"}, {"name": "Jonas Luhrmann"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Jonas Luhrmann"}, "author": "Jonas Luhrmann", "arxiv_comment": "103 pages. The main discovery in this work is a striking resonant\ninteraction between specific spatial frequencies of the variable coefficient\nand the temporal oscillations of the solutions. In the resonant case a novel\ntype of modified scattering behavior occurs that exhibits a logarithmic\nslow-down of the decay rate along certain rays. In the non-resonant case we\nintroduce a new variable coefficient quadratic normal form and establish sharp\ndecay estimates and asymptotics in the presence of a critically dispersing\nconstant coefficient cubic nonlinearity. An interesting feature of this problem compared\nto the more widely studied case on the Euclidean plane is the existence of a\nrich new family of finite energy harmonic maps. These are stationary solutions,\nand thus play an important role in the dynamics of Schr\\\"odinger maps. The main\nresult of this article is the asymptotic stability of (some of) such harmonic\nmaps under the Schr\\\"odinger maps evolution. More precisely, we prove the\nnonlinear asymptotic stability of a finite energy equivariant harmonic map $Q$\nunder the Schr\\\"odinger maps evolution with respect to non-equivariant\nperturbations, provided $Q$ obeys a suitable linearized stability condition.\nThis condition is known to hold for all equivariant harmonic maps with values\nin the hyperbolic plane and for a subset of those maps taking values in the\nsphere. One of the main technical ingredients in the paper is a global-in-time\nlocal smoothing and Strichartz estimate for the operator obtained by\nlinearization around a harmonic map, proved in the companion paper [36].", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We consider the Cauchy problem for the Schr\\\"odinger maps evolution when the\ndomain is the hyperbolic plane. An interesting feature of this problem compared\nto the more widely studied case on the Euclidean plane is the existence of a\nrich new family of finite energy harmonic maps. These are stationary solutions,\nand thus play an important role in the dynamics of Schr\\\"odinger maps. The main\nresult of this article is the asymptotic stability of (some of) such harmonic\nmaps under the Schr\\\"odinger maps evolution. More precisely, we prove the\nnonlinear asymptotic stability of a finite energy equivariant harmonic map $Q$\nunder the Schr\\\"odinger maps evolution with respect to non-equivariant\nperturbations, provided $Q$ obeys a suitable linearized stability condition.\nThis condition is known to hold for all equivariant harmonic maps with values\nin the hyperbolic plane and for a subset of those maps taking values in the\nsphere. To appear in Annals of PDE", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.09101v3", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1503.09101v3", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.0888v2", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.0888v2", "updated": "2013-09-03T15:39:39Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 9, 3, 15, 39, 39, 1, 246, 0], "published": "2013-07-03T00:49:09Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 7, 3, 0, 49, 9, 2, 184, 0], "title": "Numerical Approximation of Fractional Powers of Elliptic Operators", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Numerical Approximation of Fractional Powers of Elliptic Operators"}, "summary": "We present and study a novel numerical algorithm to approximate the action of\n$T^\\beta:=L^{-\\beta}$ where $L$ is a symmetric and positive definite unbounded\noperator on a Hilbert space $H_0$. The numerical method is based on a\nrepresentation formula for $T^{-\\beta}$ in terms of Bochner integrals involving\n$(I+t^2L)^{-1}$ for $t\\in(0,\\infty)$.\n  To develop an approximation to $T^\\beta$, we introduce a finite element\napproximation $L_h$ to $L$ and base our approximation to $T^\\beta$ on\n$T_h^\\beta:= L_h^{-\\beta}$. The direct evaluation of $T_h^{\\beta}$ is extremely\nexpensive as it involves expansion in the basis of eigenfunctions for $L_h$.\nThe above mentioned representation formula holds for $T_h^{-\\beta}$ and we\npropose three quadrature approximations denoted generically by $Q_h^\\beta$. The\ntwo results of this paper bound the errors in the $H_0$ inner product of\n$T^\\beta-T_h^\\beta\\pi_h$ and $T_h^\\beta-Q_h^\\beta$ where $\\pi_h$ is the $H_0$\northogonal projection into the finite element space. We note that the\nevaluation of $Q_h^\\beta$ involves application of $(I+(t_i)^2L_h)^{-1}$ with\n$t_i$ being either a quadrature point or its inverse. Efficient solution\nalgorithms for these problems are available and the problems at different\nquadrature points can be straightforwardly solved in parallel. Numerical\nexperiments illustrating the theoretical estimates are provided for both the\nquadrature error $T_h^\\beta-Q_h^\\beta$ and the finite element error\n$T^\\beta-T_h^\\beta\\pi_h$.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We present and study a novel numerical algorithm to approximate the action of\n$T^\\beta:=L^{-\\beta}$ where $L$ is a symmetric and positive definite unbounded\noperator on a Hilbert space $H_0$. The numerical method is based on a\nrepresentation formula for $T^{-\\beta}$ in terms of Bochner integrals involving\n$(I+t^2L)^{-1}$ for $t\\in(0,\\infty)$.\n  To develop an approximation to $T^\\beta$, we introduce a finite element\napproximation $L_h$ to $L$ and base our approximation to $T^\\beta$ on\n$T_h^\\beta:= L_h^{-\\beta}$. The direct evaluation of $T_h^{\\beta}$ is extremely\nexpensive as it involves expansion in the basis of eigenfunctions for $L_h$.\nThe above mentioned representation formula holds for $T_h^{-\\beta}$ and we\npropose three quadrature approximations denoted generically by $Q_h^\\beta$. The\ntwo results of this paper bound the errors in the $H_0$ inner product of\n$T^\\beta-T_h^\\beta\\pi_h$ and $T_h^\\beta-Q_h^\\beta$ where $\\pi_h$ is the $H_0$\northogonal projection into the finite element space. We note that the\nevaluation of $Q_h^\\beta$ involves application of $(I+(t_i)^2L_h)^{-1}$ with\n$t_i$ being either a quadrature point or its inverse. Efficient solution\nalgorithms for these problems are available and the problems at different\nquadrature points can be straightforwardly solved in parallel. Numerical\nexperiments illustrating the theoretical estimates are provided for both the\nquadrature error $T_h^\\beta-Q_h^\\beta$ and the finite element error\n$T^\\beta-T_h^\\beta\\pi_h$."}, "authors": [{"name": "Andrea Bonito"}, {"name": "Joseph E. Pasciak", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.0888v2", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1307.0888v2", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35S15, 65R20, 65N12, 65N50, 65N30", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1803.10055v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1803.10055v1", "updated": "2018-03-27T13:01:58Z", "updated_parsed": [2018, 3, 27, 13, 1, 58, 1, 86, 0], "published": "2018-03-27T13:01:58Z", "published_parsed": [2018, 3, 27, 13, 1, 58, 1, 86, 0], "title": "Numerical Approximation of Fractional Powers of Elliptic Operators", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Numerical Approximation of Fractional Powers of Elliptic Operators"}, "summary": "In this paper, we develop and study algorithms for approximately solving the\nlinear algebraic systems: $\\mathcal{A}_h^\\alpha u_h = f_h$, $ 0< \\alpha <1$,\nfor $u_h, f_h \\in V_h$ with $V_h$ a finite element approximation space. Such\nproblems arise in finite element or finite difference approximations of the\nproblem $ \\mathcal{A}^\\alpha u=f$ with $\\mathcal{A}$, for example, coming from\na second order elliptic operator with homogeneous boundary conditions. The\nalgorithms are motivated by the recent method of Vabishchevich, 2015, that\nrelates the algebraic problem to a solution of a time-dependent initial value\nproblem on the interval $[0,1]$. Here we develop and study two time stepping\nschemes based on diagonal Pad\\'e approximation to $(1+x)^{-\\alpha}$. The first\none uses geometrically graded meshes in order to compensate for the singular\nbehavior of the solution for $t$ close to $0$. The second algorithm uses\nuniform time stepping but requires smoothness of the data $f_h$ in discrete\nnorms. For both methods, we estimate the error in terms of the number of time\nsteps, with the regularity of $f_h$ playing a major role for the second method.\nFinally, we present numerical experiments for $\\mathcal{A}_h$ coming from the\nfinite element approximations of second order elliptic boundary value problems\nin one and two spatial dimensions.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this paper, we develop and study algorithms for approximately solving the\nlinear algebraic systems: $\\mathcal{A}_h^\\alpha u_h = f_h$, $ 0< \\alpha <1$,\nfor $u_h, f_h \\in V_h$ with $V_h$ a finite element approximation space. Such\nproblems arise in finite element or finite difference approximations of the\nproblem $ \\mathcal{A}^\\alpha u=f$ with $\\mathcal{A}$, for example, coming from\na second order elliptic operator with homogeneous boundary conditions. The\nalgorithms are motivated by the recent method of Vabishchevich, 2015, that\nrelates the algebraic problem to a solution of a time-dependent initial value\nproblem on the interval $[0,1]$. Here we develop and study two time stepping\nschemes based on diagonal Pad\\'e approximation to $(1+x)^{-\\alpha}$. The first\none uses geometrically graded meshes in order to compensate for the singular\nbehavior of the solution for $t$ close to $0$. The second algorithm uses\nuniform time stepping but requires smoothness of the data $f_h$ in discrete\nnorms. For both methods, we estimate the error in terms of the number of time\nsteps, with the regularity of $f_h$ playing a major role for the second method.\nFinally, we present numerical experiments for $\\mathcal{A}_h$ coming from the\nfinite element approximations of second order elliptic boundary value problems\nin one and two spatial dimensions."}, "authors": [{"name": "Beiping Duan"}, {"name": "Raytcho Lazarov"}, {"name": "Joeseph Pasciak"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Joeseph Pasciak"}, "author": "Joeseph Pasciak", "arxiv_comment": "20 pages, 2 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1803.10055v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1803.10055v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "35S15, 65R20, 65N12, 65N50", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1303.2932v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1303.2932v1", "updated": "2013-03-12T15:55:47Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 3, 12, 15, 55, 47, 1, 71, 0], "published": "2013-03-12T15:55:47Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 3, 12, 15, 55, 47, 1, 71, 0], "title": "Galerkin FEM for fractional order parabolic equations with initial data\n  in $H^{-s},~0 < s \\le 1$", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Galerkin FEM for fractional order parabolic equations with initial data\n  in $H^{-s},~0 < s \\le 1$"}, "summary": "We investigate semi-discrete numerical schemes based on the standard Galerkin\nand lumped mass Galerkin finite element methods for an initial-boundary value\nproblem for homogeneous fractional diffusion problems with non-smooth initial\ndata. We assume that $\\Omega\\subset \\mathbb{R}^d$, $d=1,2,3$ is a convex\npolygonal (polyhedral) domain. We theoretically justify optimal order error\nestimates in $L_2$- and $H^1$-norms for initial data in $H^{-s}(\\Omega),~0\\le s\n\\le 1$. We confirm our theoretical findings with a number of numerical tests\nthat include initial data $v$ being a Dirac $\\delta$-function supported on a\n$(d-1)$-dimensional manifold.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "We investigate semi-discrete numerical schemes based on the standard Galerkin\nand lumped mass Galerkin finite element methods for an initial-boundary value\nproblem for homogeneous fractional diffusion problems with non-smooth initial\ndata. We assume that $\\Omega\\subset \\mathbb{R}^d$, $d=1,2,3$ is a convex\npolygonal (polyhedral) domain. We theoretically justify optimal order error\nestimates in $L_2$- and $H^1$-norms for initial data in $H^{-s}(\\Omega),~0\\le s\n\\le 1$. We confirm our theoretical findings with a number of numerical tests\nthat include initial data $v$ being a Dirac $\\delta$-function supported on a\n$(d-1)$-dimensional manifold."}, "authors": [{"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "Raytcho Lazarov"}, {"name": "Joseph Pasciak"}, {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Zhi Zhou"}, "author": "Zhi Zhou", "arxiv_comment": "13 pages, 3 figures", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1303.2932v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1303.2932v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}, {"id": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.4795v1", "guidislink": true, "link": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.4795v1", "updated": "2013-07-17T21:44:19Z", "updated_parsed": [2013, 7, 17, 21, 44, 19, 2, 198, 0], "published": "2013-07-17T21:44:19Z", "published_parsed": [2013, 7, 17, 21, 44, 19, 2, 198, 0], "title": "Variational formulation of problems involving fractional order\n  differential operators", "title_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "Variational formulation of problems involving fractional order\n  differential operators"}, "summary": "In this work, we consider boundary value problems involving Caputo and\nRiemann-Liouville fractional derivatives of order $\\alpha\\in(1,2)$ on the unit\ninterval $(0,1)$. These fractional derivatives lead to non-symmetric boundary\nvalue problems, which are investigated from a variational point of view. The\nvariational problem for the Riemann-Liouville case is coercive on the space\n$H_0^{\\alpha/2}(0,1)$ but the solutions are less regular, whereas that for the\nCaputo case involves different test and trial spaces. The numerical analysis of\nthese problems requires the so-called shift theorems which show that the\nsolutions of the variational problem are more regular. The regularity pickup\nenables one to establish convergence rates of the finite element\napproximations. Finally, numerical results are presented to illustrate the\nerror estimates.", "summary_detail": {"type": "text/plain", "language": null, "base": "", "value": "In this work, we consider boundary value problems involving Caputo and\nRiemann-Liouville fractional derivatives of order $\\alpha\\in(1,2)$ on the unit\ninterval $(0,1)$. These fractional derivatives lead to non-symmetric boundary\nvalue problems, which are investigated from a variational point of view. The\nvariational problem for the Riemann-Liouville case is coercive on the space\n$H_0^{\\alpha/2}(0,1)$ but the solutions are less regular, whereas that for the\nCaputo case involves different test and trial spaces. The numerical analysis of\nthese problems requires the so-called shift theorems which show that the\nsolutions of the variational problem are more regular. The regularity pickup\nenables one to establish convergence rates of the finite element\napproximations. Finally, numerical results are presented to illustrate the\nerror estimates."}, "authors": [{"name": "Bangti Jin"}, {"name": "Raytcho Lazarov"}, {"name": "Joseph Pasciak"}], "author_detail": {"name": "Joseph Pasciak"}, "author": "Joseph Pasciak", "arxiv_comment": "21 pages, 7 tables", "links": [{"href": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.4795v1", "rel": "alternate", "type": "text/html"}, {"title": "pdf", "href": "http://arxiv.org/pdf/1307.4795v1", "rel": "related", "type": "application/pdf"}], "arxiv_primary_category": {"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"}, "tags": [{"term": "math.NA", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}, {"term": "math.AP", "scheme": "http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom", "label": null}]}]
